Posted: January 25, 2020
Mass Transportation

Snakeybus is an arcade driving game developed by Stovetop LLC. As the name might suggest, this is a bus-centric take on the classic snake, and yes, it’s as wacky as it sounds. On one of eleven different maps, your goal will be to pick up passengers and take them to a destination. When you drop off passengers, your bus gets longer, letting you pick up more passengers but eventually making it harder to navigate the maps.

I found this game decently enjoyable. I wanted to play it to get all of the achievements, but after I was done doing that, I lost all interest in playing it. It’s a fun concept but it gets stale pretty quickly.

Positives:











Snakeybus is a great concept and it’s fun for a little bit, but it gets stale rather quickly. I’d say it’s worth grabbing for a couple of bucks, but I wouldn't pay more than that.

If you found this review helpful, please consider following my curator page:

Posted: April 10, 2021
This game saved my life.

I am 36.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

The game is an artistic statement on capitalism's guaranteed demise. The bus, which is the state of technology, continually moves forward and the path behind inevitably blocks further development. The passengers, which represent the consumers, climb in at the forefront of technology and depart only when they have reached the destination someone else chose. Posted: January 31, 2021
Probably the best of the under-$3 games I've bought, Snakeybus is so bizarre but at the same time really fun to play. Controlling the buses themselves is easy, and getting the hang of mapping in your head where your bus trail is in relation to where you are in the game world to avoid crashes is pretty simple. The first three worlds are more conducive to massive buses of 500+ carriages, while the later ones are tricky with tight streets or bizarre layouts like the modernist museum.

Visuals are great for such a cheap game, and the soundtrack is mostly good. Controls are pretty straightforward although "aiming" the bus while it's airborne can be a bit of a pain. Note there is an in-cab view, but if you suffer from vertigo using it will mean you spend lots of time alternately screaming and puking. Folks using older computers, expect some lag as your bus grows beyond 300 segments.

For you achievement hunters, my game bugged upon launch and granted two thirds of the achievements at once...but I'd say you're looking at about an hour to unlock everything barring the Paris Night level which requires luck, good aim, and maybe a video guide.

Easy recommend when this goes on for 75% off. Regular price is somewhat steep though, as apart from climbing the scoreboards for each level there's little replayability here.

Posted: May 25, 2019
Product received for free

I Want To Walk To Work In A Snakeybus

For me, 'simple with great execution' trumps 'ambitious with poor execution' every time. That every review and preview starts to blur into one amorphous mass is a testament to how true this really is for Snakeybus. You can only reiterate 'Crazy Taxi meets Snake' in so many ways.

Here's my stab at it. Taking control of an articulated bus you deliver passengers to destinations - so far so normal. The twists in the tale are, one, that the bus doesn't ever stop (thankfully passengers can embark/disembark in an ethereal manner, lest you be driving a bus in name only!) and, most importantly, two, passengers delivered add sections that extend your bus. Snake was always genius, but there's something about its translation to 3D space here that feels yet more so.

Watching hundreds of bus sections trundling behind you occupy every free space in the map is a sight to behold and one for which few games can compare. Eventually, your minimap, which marks your extended presence on the map becomes an incomprehensible mess of squiggles, or worse, an outline of the entire map. Every movement needs to be purposeful, lest you get halted in your tracks or make an ill-judged turn into an abyss - game over. It's all wonderful mind game stuff. You can use time-limited rocket boosters to create openings for yourself to drive under or play the more desperate moment to moment game of panic-cutting across gaps or jumping over yourself. Like the finest score attack games of its kind (e.g. Devil Daggers), finding and breaking the upper limit of your time intact is compulsive.

Snakeybus doles out its levels according to the number of level plays (making you give each level its due) and starts off strong with a 'squint and it has a real photorealistic quality,' squashed depiction of Pa-ree. True to its claims, its later levels aren't just visual variation with its 80s Miami, striking cylindrical abstraction, etc, but generate markedly different forms of play too. Paris's cramped roads and hazardous river give way to winding platforms and perhaps worse, open areas and complete freedom. The bus select screen eschews menus for a physical bus swerving around a corner and taking out whatever live, dynamic traffic is there at that time. And the music, the MUSIC - the lo-fi study beats that have become such an internet sensation are a masterstroke here.

It helps the control is pitch perfect. Not content with oversimplifying, Snakeybus gives you the ability to drift, to accelerate, and as mentioned, to rocket-propelled jump which gets cut off for a significant time after depletion. It controls like a dream on a keyboard or now controller. A first-person perspective can be toggled to, but I wouldn't recommend the handicap! Just another dose of fun in a bottle of it.

As with any score attack game and repeat plays, the interesting part comes later into the level when you've got to the length wherein you're impeding yourself. A genre issue, perhaps, that you have to go through the motions on each replay to get to that moment or your personal best. Maybe some kind of toggle-on rewind mechanic is the answer to this? That would compromise the leaderboard purity the game achieves, however. All in all, it's a short space of time to complain about, but it did come to mind.

With its inspired design and surprising spectacle, it's my favourite kind of game. One that's focused on delivering unique gameplay you couldn't get anywhere in the triple-A space, but not disposable and delivered with the polish and execution regardless. I just can't wait to see how updates proceed for this one. The potential is through the roof. It's cheap (but anything but cheap); it's brilliant; it's Snakeybus.

Posted: May 14, 2019
It's Snake in 3D. No, I promise it's very entertaining!


Gameplay

So there's not much to really say. It's snake in 3D, but you drive an infinitely-extending accordion bus. You have a jump button to help with the 3D, you unlock more bus types, you unlock more levels. It takes a while to understand the mechanics, but once you understand the mechanics, you start trying to get the highest records of Steam and ask yourself How the hell did people get 900 bus length?

The soundtrack, at first I didn't like it. I felt the game could have used more... upbeat adrenaline-rushing music, but after playing the game for an hour, it started to sink in: You're not driving a car at extremely fast speeds, it's just a bus around a closed-off map. Just take your time, and carefully tread around the map.




During my playthrough, I... never really paid attention to the framerate. I didn't notice any drops, so I can say I was always higher than 60fps with my i9 9820X, 64GB of Ram, 2x 1080Tis in SLI (Did not check if SLI was actually working). The game was installed on an SSHD where each level took ~7 seconds to load. Quick to load, quick to start playing, and I like that for a small game like this.

Posted: January 27, 2020
Follow our curator page: IndieGems if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.

Snakeybus is a 3D snake game with some pretty cool maps and casual gameplay. Whole thing is very easy and relaxing, unless you are really trying to go for that high score each time. For me, it's the experience that matters. And I have to say, I had more fun with it than I anticipated. The people at the bus stations are the usual apples/dots that you take in as the snake, and as expected of a 3D snake game, you have a jetpack/jump function that allows you to move over obstacles, including the rest of the lengthy train/body.

The price is a little high at base for $9.99 US, but since it's on 75% discount right now, it's well worth it. The achievements were all very easy to get except for getting to 420 train carts and also getting one of the maps, which I had to follow specific instructions for. Otherwise, they just unlock as you play on. For me, it was right around 1.5 hours for 100%. I did not play the multiplayer version of the game, which is fine. You do not need to play MP to get the achievements. It allows you to take some pretty cool pictures as well, if you decide to do so when you have built up a pretty awesome looking train.

Example here:


It's pretty fun, so grab it on sale and enjoy it for what it is--a really nice take on the simple game of snake with nice graphics and a 3D environment.

I only played with a controller. Needed to click on Single Player after launch with the mouse first, after that, the joystick was used for Menu navigation and also gameplay. You will be able to accelerate/decelerate in addition to jumping and just moving/turning.

Nice visually designed maps, each rather unique and gives a different feel from the others.

Very casual and relaxing, accompanies the game well.

Casual players looking for a very casual experience.

As above, base price a bit high, sale price is well worth it.

soars through the Parisian night sky as people watch in amazement. It's a plane, it's a train, it's a Snakeybus!

Posted: January 31, 2022
This game is a literal masterpiece, one of the best I've played. Language can't begin to describe why it's so good, but I'll make a feeble attempt here. On the surface, it's simple enough: bus but snake; once you step behind the wheel however, you'll see that the game's appeal extends far beyond what's found at the surface. It can be a very relaxing game as you lazily go from stop to stop, performing an essential function necessary to any healthy public transportation system. It can also be fast-paced, deep, and riveting, as you drive a bus on a row of buses, dodging and weaving among your past jumps and abusing absurd twists to launch yourself to the heavens in the quest for leaderboard glory.

This game has many lessons to teach, on logistic growth, on ecological collapse, on non-newtonian physics and space-filling curves; but most of all it reaches into the soul and probes the deeper questions of human experience: Why are we here? Why do we keep up this fruitless search for unending growth in the face of inevitable death? I can't answer these questions, but after playing this game I find I no longer need to.

I'm utterly perplexed by the few negative reviews with the gall to complain about a lack of content or poor value for money. I find it very telling that the current 'most helpful' review that complains about 'being bored after a few hours' comes from an account that has now played it for nearly 20. Speaking of which, this game would be a bargain at $20, not to speak of the $10 it currently costs. I can't imagine what motivates these deranged individuals to spread lies; perhaps a financial incentive from car manufacturers is to blame. Nevertheless, I rest assured that the mere presence of Snakeybus in their libraries will one day emancipate them from their psychotic state and restore them to normal functioning.

Posted: May 30
This is not merely a game. It is an experience. At first you will play it like any other variation of snake, but then you realize you can go down the same street 2 or 3 times side-by-side with your own trail, the ghost of bussing past. And then you realize you can jump. And by this point, the entire street network has been consumed by the bus. The West has fallen. Billions must bus. The diorama of a normal cityscape has fallen apart. Cars lay on their roofs, pedestrians have all gone home, the only people left alive are those saved from your wrath by the comfort of their home, and those waiting at the bus stops to enter Mr Bones' Wild Ride: Public Transportation Edition. At this point, you begin driving on top of your trail, and the main street begins stacking. The main road, already consumed entirely by 3-4 different bus trails, now rises like a building under construction to 2, then 3 levels. Your bus defines an era. There is BC, there is AD, and then there is AB (After Bus). And then, as suddenly as it began, it ends, because you missed a jump and fell into the river. You fool. You moron. You goober.

Overall I give this game a 10/10 but be sure to change the settings because it defaults to a 30FPS cap. I can recommend this game for everyone: hardcore gamers, casuals, children, the elderly, toddlers, fetuses, the souls of the damned, you name it. Everyone can enjoy an Abnormally Long Bus in equal measure. It's a fun little 30 minute distraction, but looking at the leaderboard there are apparently people who have managed to play the game without crashing into themselves (or the river) for almost an hour. Replay value is also really solid; just like snake, you learn, you get better, and eventually your bus will consume all known space in the universe.

Posted: May 29, 2020
Dear Stovetop LLC,

This game is very good, but personally there are some changes that I would make.

First of all, the city maps need to be bigger. I am well aware that it's supposed to be challenging when you get to the 300-400 segment range, but those city maps feel like you are smushed. I'd say make them a little bit bigger.

FYI to all the people looking to buy this game, Coriolis is the best map. Period.
(Especially if you want to get the 'Blaze It' achievement.)

This part isn't necessarily a gripe about the game itself, but its a gripe of my heartache. Before writing this, I was on the Coriolis map trying to get the 'Blaze It' achievement. This achievement requires 420 segments, and I died at 418 segments trying to drop off my people.

The soundtrack is very well done, and if it was added as a DLC, I would probably buy it. And I never usually buy soundtrack DLCs.

Overall very very VERY good game, and is very well made for multiplayer. If you have the money for this game, I highly suggest trying it out.

9.8/10

Posted: January 28, 2020
This seems like a fairly simple game on the surface, blending a first-person bus-driving simulation with classic Snake gameplay. You drive your bus around, sucking up screaming passengers and dropping them off at various destinations, weaving through increasingly tight spaces until you crash or run out of room to keep moving. It's all fairly ridiculous.

Beneath this deceptively silly veneer, however, the game speaks to the soul-crushing plight of the modern worker. You are compelled to keep driving forward in the endless quest for productivity, your very survival at stake, your mission growing more futile and insurmountable with each passing moment, the burden of responsibility weighing heavier, all remaining paths to success shrinking into nothingness, until the pace is no longer even remotely sustainable and it all comes crashing down in a massive avalanche of liability lawsuits, hospital bills, and death.

Highly recommended.

Posted: November 27, 2020
Ridiculous 3D Snake As A Bus
You're a crazy busdriver with heavy feet so you cannot stop. You can accelerate and decelerate, but not stop. Drive over passengers waiting at the bus stop to scream and fly into your bus. Deliver them to the specified bus stop. By doing so your bus lengthens with extra bus wagons behind your first bus proportional to the amount of passengers you delivered. You get ludicrously many bus wagons behind you, making you a very long bus train like a giant snake in a city filling the streets with its tail. You're not dead if you run into your own tail as in the original game "Snake" on old mobile phones, but you can fall off ledges and are game over if your movement is blocked by your tail for a few seconds. You can jump, jetpack fly and Rocket League like roll and tilt through the air to avoid your own tail. This gets crazy funny, but loses it's appeal soon, although there are some bus customization unlocks and new levels. I got all 17 achievements of this game in almost 1 hour. I guess this says something about the game. Though, I really like the concept/idea and it's very well done! But the single player won't hold you for very long if you're not into super try hard highscore chasing.

What make even more fun and hold you for longer is the multiplayer of the game. But the community is pretty dead, so you gotta bring your own friends for that bigger fun.

I liked it how it is, though. Good ridiculous fun for one session.

Recommended if you want it for the novelty or a once-in-a-while timewaster, especially on sale or as bundle filler.

Snakeybus is fun as all get out and I'm excited to see what the developers do next.

Posted: January 23, 2020
Diary: Snakeybus

Day 1 - 1/23/2020
It's 1 AM, I should be sleeping, but I saw a snake game but with buses and had to play it for a bit. I selected the first level, which was a dorm, and started to collect people until I became so big that I screwed up and couldn't move anymore because I crashed into a corner badly.

This game feels like a far more lenient version of snake, which makes me appreciate the game all the more, it allows me to get further and have a much bigger transport unit as a result. Long live the busses.


Day 2 - 1/23/2020
Well, now that It's middle of the day, I guess ill play the game, instead of you know 1 AM. Going into the game, I like how nice the graphics look for what it is. It's pretty decent, and there is plenty of alternative transports you could use once you earn enough points. You also unlock a bunch of levels that have their nice themes. Being able to use the sky cam to hover over your transport creation nightmare train is pretty fun too. I wouldn't say to my friends to get this full price, it's better to wait for a sale, but man is it just an overall fun little game if you're a fan of the snake genre.

Posted: May 17, 2019
A good game putting a great concept into practice with decent art design and relaxing music.
After completing the achievement of reaching 420 fragments, I felt the game was celebrating the urban-planner's efficient use of space: as long as you follow a well-designed route (which is what you're supposed to do as a bus driver), you will be totally fine.
Miami is the map I like the most. The gird doesn't seem abrupt and does give you a sense of design, a sense of futurism and a sense of minimalism. This game is an art piece to me.

Posted: May 11, 2019
In London, it sometimes costs £10 or more to take the bus.
I just paid £6 to crash a Snakeybus around Paris.

10/10 would recommend!

Take it for what it is: It's an arcade style crazy-taxi but with a bendybus. Boris Johnson would be proud. Apart from missing a DLC where you can get stuck on a zipwire flying two Union Jacks, it seems to have enough to keep you interested for an hour or two. This isn't a game to play for hours and hours but its really entertaining.

Paris and Miami make you plan and navigate tight streets and time your jumps just right, while some of the other levels are just plain out of this world - I'm talking rainbow road-esque but with more motion sickness!

Controller support isn't ready just yet, but I played with WASD and had a lot of fun. It's cheap, Devs seem chuffed to bits and I love the art. When controller becomes available I'll definitely use it to pass the time!

Get it, you won't be disappointed!

Posted: June 19, 2019
All Snake, No Meat, No Venom

As far as 2D to 3D transitions go, Snakeybus is not at all a bad attempt; in fact it's done so well it could best be described as a direct "dimensional port".

Here, you may notice why I'm not recommending this game; with the above, coupled with the price tag you must ask yourself: "Do I want to pay $10USD for a 3D snake clone?" A game mind you, that would pass easily as a free mobile game and perhaps even better as a free Flash game back in the day.

Let me acknowledge though, if this game were marked as "early access" or even simply as an alpha or a demo I wouldn't have a problem; knowing this is bare bones for a reason and that there is a glimmer of more content on the horizon I might happily have paid for this experience. However it doesn't appear that there are any signs of further content or perhaps even gameplay changes. The game appears to be and will maintain being a 3D snake clone for $10USD and if that alone is enough for you, each to their own; however I disagree given that there's much better games available on steam for either the same price or even cheaper.



Snakeybus charges the player with taking control of a high speed bus that cannot slow down (stop me if you've heard this one) and consequently must deliver as many passengers as possible without stopping; all the while having more carriages added on, resulting in fewer space to maneuver, that requires pre-planning to successfully stay moving.

The game offers a total of 6 small individual levels, each of which can be played through in roughly 5-10 minutes. The level design is done quite well. You can tell the dev(s) designed the levels around one single idea and built the level around it; so as a result you are offered 6 different stages, each with their own aesthetic and strategies. You unlock each stage with a very unconventional method, whereby you must play the previous level(s) a minimum of 5 times for an unspecified amount of time/progress.

The game features a 'credit' system whereby you are rewarded an unspecified amount of credits per level and can spend them on 5 different bus skins; one of which is a reskin of the default model and each being cosmetic only. The skins can all be collected in a span of roughly 40 minutes.

The added "twist" to Snakeybus because of its transition to 3D (allowing for verticality to become apart of the equation) is a jump feature, allowing the player to jump between ~40second intervals.

Those with a keen eye and possibly even a creative mind may have noticed very large gaps that can be easily filled and expand the gameplay beyond 90minutes and also that the game is very vague and provides little feedback/reward; however it remains a mystery why these problems have not been addressed. The game is very bare bones. There is no overarching challenge. Rarely any tension. No real progression or attainable goals to keep you playing. Again, if that's your cup of tea (which for most who bought this game it seems to be) than buy this, if not; look elsewhere.

Here's a few things the dev(s) could add or look towards implementing:















I hope the dev(s) consider these changes/additions. Right now the game just feels lazy, like this was a weekend project shortly abandoned so they just stuck a $10USD price tag on it and shipped it. I get the whole 'minimalism' angle but there's a fine line between simplistic design and anorexic-like content. Right now, the game is just $10 bucks for a 3D snake that you could find on an apps store for much cheaper; or better yet, spend that $10 on a game that'll keep you occupied for well over 90 minutes in short sittings.

Posted: 28 June, 2021
My wife and I are hugely into local co-op games, but we almost bounced off this one. We failed so many times that the first level took us well over an hour. We wondered if maybe it was just too difficult for us, and we've finished some truly challenging games together.

We took a small break, came back to give it one more try and... the second level was challenging, but totally doable and we finished in a much more reasonable time. By the end of the game, we even went back and replayed the first level, and while it was certainly easier for having gained a lot of practice, but it was still insanely hard for a first level. The level order seems completely random to me, and seems to have nothing to do with creating any kind of difficulty curve.

The game is plagued with inconsistent, and often seemingly insurmountable, difficulty spikes... but... it was a lot of fun. If you like co-op games that require a combination of skill and efficient communication, this is definitely for you. Play it with a loved one and you'll both be belly laughing over all your stupid mistakes... when you're not teetering closer and closer to passive aggressively blaming each other for everything that goes wrong. If you can clear the first level, I think you can make it all the way, but it will never be a 'walk' in the park.

Posted: 26 March, 2020
Biped is one of the best co-op games to be released in a long time, and a strong contender for my co-op game-of-the-year for 2020!

Even though the base mechanics of the game are fairly simple, each level modifies them in interesting and amusing ways. It tests your ability to work together to progress through really fun challenges.

Each of the main story levels took us about 20-30 minutes to complete, and all total it took around 4 hours to finish them all up. After that, each level has 2 additional "Pro Levels", which have very tough challenges based on the mechanics from the corresponding story mission.

The levels and mechanics were varied enough to always feel fresh and this game was easily worth the price. I'm already looking forward to Biped 2!

«Biped» Review(En/RUS)
Casual Arcade + Excellent co-op mode for two players
Gameplay:
YouTube™ Video: Biped - Local Co-op Gameplay (Casual Arcade+ Excellent co-op mode for two players) 
Views: 1,335
Biped - Local Co-op Gameplay (Casual Arcade+ Excellent co-op mode for two players) Steam: https://store.steampowered.com/app/1071870/Biped/ Review (En): This is not a puzzle, but a magnificent arcade...


«Review(En):»
This is not a puzzle, but a magnificent arcade game with cute biped robots. You move the legs of the robot one step at a time, climb up platforms and complete tasks. You move the legs of the robot with the mouse buttons or sticks of the gamepad.
If you play together, the difficulty increases, but the game becomes more fun, unpredictable and exciting.
You need a mouse and a controller or a pair of controllers for a local co-op. The keyboard is not used in the game.
The devs recommend playing with a gamepad (the game says so in the splash intro screen), but to playing is much more convenient and easier if you use a mouse.
You cannot use two mice in the game. The game will ask you to connect the controller as an addition to the mouse, even if having two mice connected. The only way to play with two mice is in an online co-op!
When you play together online co-op, the progress of coins, stars and open levels is saved only at the host! This is what the developer intended (the second player helps the host in his progress).
+ Excellent co-op mode for two players (online and local with on common screen without split screen).
+ There is a single mode.
+ Cute robots.
+ Beautiful graphics.
+ Great music and sounds.
+ High-quality mechanics, physics, design and gameplay.
+ The game is suitable for adults and children.
- No support Remote Play Together.

Это не головоломка, а великолепная аркада с милыми двуногими роботами. Мы по очереди передвигаем ноги робота, чтобы преодолеть препятствия, карабкаться по платформам и выполнять задания. Ноги робота двигаем кнопками мышки или стиками геймпада.
Если играете вдвоем, то сложность увеличивается, но игра становится более веселой, непредсказуемой и увлекательной.
Для локального кооператива вам понадобится мышь и контроллер или пара контроллеров. Клавиатура в игре не используется. Хоть в игре пишут, что предпочтительнее играть на геймпаде, но на мышке играть гораздо удобнее и проще. Жаль, но использовать две мышки в игре нельзя. Игра попросит вас подключить контроллер в качестве дополнения к мышке, даже если будет подключено две. Единственный способ играть с двумя мышками - это в онлайн-кооперативе!
В онлайн-кооперативе прогресс монет, звезд и открытых уровней сохраняется только у хоста! Так задумано разработчиком (второй игрок помогает хозяину в его прогрессе).
+ Великолепный кооперативный режим для двоих (онлайн и локальный с общим экраном без разделения).
+ Есть одиночное прохождение.
+ Симпатичные роботы.
+ Красивая графика.
+ Отличная музыка и звуки.
+ Качественная механика, физика, дизайн и геймплей.
+ Игра подходит взрослым и детям.
- Нет поддержки Remote Play Together.

Biped is the most fun I've had in a co-op game in a while. To me, it is a satisfying blend of mechanics, puzzles, graphics, and overall enjoyment.

The controls are simple. Just the two mouse buttons or the two analog sticks on controller. The real spice are the puzzles that you face. Each level you pass introduces a new mechanic that adds a twist to how you play. I got to say that playing this game blind and seeing all the new mechanics slowly unfold filled me with a surprising amount of joy. Now, sprinkle some lively and cute graphics and you've an attractive puzzle wonderland.

A co-op game wouldn't be a co-op game without chaos and Biped provides a lot of that chaotic energy. (Given that you are playing with the appropriate person.) Hit up a friend and enjoy as chaos ensues.

What's not to love about this game? It's the prefect blend of straightforward mechanics, challenging yet enjoyable puzzles, eye-catching graphics and tons of chaotic fun.

10/10

Posted: September 10, 2022
We're strong together

Pros Cons
✔️ Great character design. ❌ Short playtime (took us three hours to complete).
✔️ Fun puzzles and mechanics. ❌ Waterlevel.
✔️ Successful co-op elements. ❌ Collision detection feels weird sometimes.
✔️ Neat and innovative controls. ❌ Stereotype worlds you see everywhere (Ice, desert, jungle etc.).

Who doesn't fondly remember the days when the Internet wasn't as omnipresent as it is today and we met up with friends to play video games sitting on the couch, whether against each other or in co-op mode. You know - live and in color. Some manufacturers like Nintendo continue to hold this local-multiplayer flag high, but commonly today, people play mostly online with each other, and the face-to-face, social component is falling away.

The story in Biped is told quite quickly. You play the two humanoid robots Sila and Aku. The tin pals are sent to Earth to light beacons that will allow them to teleport across the planet. To complete this task, they have to travel to different locations and overcome obstacles. Among other things, you'll move through the ruins of ancient civilizations in the shape of the two robo-friends, roam through desert regions and slide over icy mountains to get to your destination. In the process, Sila and Aku are dependent on the help of other robots and, of course, on each other. Only together can the obstacles be crossed - well, at least if you go off together with a friend. Biped also has a solo mode, in which you can live through the story campaign alone. The eight levels, including the tutorial, are then adapted to one person and you'll encounter more other robots, who will take over the tasks that would otherwise take up your partner. The solo campaign, like the co-op campaign, is also played through after three hours at the latest.



Biped is only played with the mouse or the two analog sticks of a controller - we played with the gamepad. The whole control system is thus reduced to a minimum, but there are still a large number of actions that can be performed. The two legs of our robot are each controlled with one of the two sticks, and different movements lead to different results. This requires practice, but after a while you get used to the unusual concept and can perform precise actions and movements. The sticks are also used when activating switches, holding onto ropes and walls, and grabbing objects. To do this, you just have to hold the stick, and thus the leg, to certain objects. With each mission, new mechanics and obstacles are presented, matching the setting. For example, in order to get to the top of a snowy mountain, we'll have to swing up ropes, use air locks to catapult ourselves upwards, and hang on magnetic walls to avoid falling down. In another area, we have to help the robot inhabitants with sawing and transport the finished wood along conveyor belts. Each level offers new, innovative puzzles and tasks that guarantee a lot of variety and fun and most importantly: It's absolutely kids / family friendly.

Cooperation is also important when it comes to swinging from one platform to another. The collision detection irritated us a few times, though, and also caused moments of frustration. The small robots can slide over flat levels, which allows them to progress faster. However, it was not always obvious where these accessible levels begin and end, but it's also a bit due to the camera, which causes problems every now and then. As a result, we sometimes got stuck on edges or were thrown over the target.




Biped surprised me quite a bit, because rarely have I laughed so hard during a co-op title. This is ultimately due to the interesting game concept, because in the game you and your partner each embody a robot, whose individual legs you have to control separately. What necessarily follows are rather chaotic and whimsical moments, which always arise when you dare to tackle one of the many fairly designed challenges. At the same time, Biped is intuitive, excellently done by the game design and manages to build up a pleasant learning and motivation curve. You're also offered a solo mode, but it's clear that the game focuses on the co-op aspect, and in this respect it shines. The stages serve common platform stereotypes that have been around for decades: Ice World, Desert World, Jungle World, etc. With coins found in the levels you can buy some headgear for the little robots - but I've seen that in funnier or more motivating ways elsewhere. Unfortunately, the very short gameplay time gets in the way. You can play through Biped with your game partner in one evening, but after 3-4 hours, depending on how well you do, all the fun is over. However, if you're looking for a decent co-op title, you can still get it, especially since Biped isn't too expensive at 12,49€ (I would highly recommend waiting for a sale).

As of this review I've played for about 3 hours. My compy specs are: i5-4460 3.2ghz, 16gb RAM, GeForce GTX 980, Win 10. I've experienced no crashes and one bug where I was stuck in a loadscreen while my coop partner had already loaded into the game, a quick restart and it worked the 2nd time.

I feel really bad giving this game a bad review but, this game is really really short. My friend and I beat it in under 3 hours with about an hour of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ around in there. It has a whopping EIGHT levels with 2 additional variants of each level. I'm telling you, you'll feel like you just started the game and it's all over. The gameplay is outstanding and the coop puzzling mechanics are well done but, they only serve to drive home how short the game is. If you have money to blow or don't care about value $/hour then this is an excellent game with great coop mechanics, please remember this game isn't just $14 because you need 2 copies tho ( the game now supports remote play). The short time I was playing it I had an absolute blast and we were falling out of our chairs laughing at points but, I can get that with many different coop games that will give me far more then 3 hours of content (at a better rate than $9/hour too).

Posted: June 26, 2020
Biped is a fun, cute co-op and solo game. I mention co-op first because it's really designed around playing with another person. However, you can still enjoy solo play. The controls are very innovative and novel. The first place I ever came across using dual sticks to control separate motion was from a tank arcade game back in the 1990s. The control is a bit confusing at first, but then becomes very intuitive rapidly.


The only critical critiques I have about this game, are:

1. The camera

2. Only co-op host seems to get stars that both players got playing together.

For the first critique, if you ever played Super Mario 64 you know that camera makes a world of difference. In Biped, sometimes the camera is just right, other times it is completely unbearable. Sometimes it cuts off speech bubbles or useful areas, while other times you don't even think about it.

The second item is a personal frustration. My friend and I have separately gotten all of the stars in the solo game. However, when we played coop together we noticed that he would get 4/4 when I would only get 3/4. We haven't figured out why this is happening if it is suppose to happen. Worse yet, it doesn't seem that many, if any, are attached to my account for the achievement. This means we would have to play through ALL of the co-op levels together again (all the regular AND pro ones) with ME as host. That seems rather odd and I would guess that it's not intended? But it is immensely frustrating. I'm not sure if there's any way for the devs to fix this?


Other than those 2 issues, Biped has been a really fun, simple, cute co-op game.



2020-07-08 Update - We noticed some serious issues of the game lagging out when we would hit difficult parts. I'm not sure how they coordinated the network for co-op but it was frustrating at times to have lag kill us.

A third issue that I neglected to mention is that only the HOST can see the status of completion for each level (time, deaths, stars), which lends itself to possibly explaining why only the host gets full credit for stars.

WHAT was strange, was when I was hosting, part of the levels were completed and unlocked and it seemed somewhat random. We really didn't enjoy the boat level. It was interesting and novel, but super annoying. That's just our preference. What was nice was that those were all completed on my side, making me wonder if the devs deliberately wanted co-op gamers to replay the non-sucky levels? Or maybe there's just a sync issue with level completion stats.


If you're just looking for a cutesy co-op game, Biped is a good game for you.

However, if you care about completion, and fully polished games, I would give Biped a TEPID rating.

SUMMARY: Good solid start on a game. Needs more polish.

Posted: July 26, 2021
I can’t really join the euphoric chorus in a lot of reviews here. Sure, it’s an alright local coop game all in all, but a long way from a masterpiece in my opinion, mostly because of the tedious movement system (you control each foot separately, hell if your controller got mechanical issues) and the sudden difficulty spikes in between. Sometimes levels were easy and fun, other levels were simply frustrating or annoying (already the first one), especially if you try to collect all the stars (good advice: DON’T, because you need the ones from the bonus levels for any achievement as well). I wouldn’t even call it a puzzle game, as coordination and agility challenges based around those leg movements and the according physics are predominant. The main story also is rather short, only 8 levels including the tutorial, and has rather few variations (mostly the standard, like river, ice, forest etc.). Instead, after finishing, the game offers several bonus challenge levels as mentioned which really are extremely hard, and this is no joke, they’re truly diabolical. To be honest, we gave up after a few tries, yeah, that’s how much fun they were. By the way, I also finished it in single player, which is surprisingly much easier and features a bit different level designs, but of course is short, too. And before I forget, there are indeed slight customization possibilities by buying some funny hats in the shop with coins you find during the levels, but the achievement to buy them all is rather grindy and requires to at least repeat the tutorial 30 additional times.

I’ll still give this a positive rating, just because it was not all bad, but it definitely wouldn’t be my first choice for a local coop game to have fun. Too much hassle in between, too little variety, and I’d wait for a good sale keeping the short game length in mind.

Posted: October 11
Biped is a charming and cooperative puzzle-platformer that delivers a fun and lighthearted experience. You control adorable robots, "Aku" and "Sila," as they traverse a series of levels that require precision, teamwork, and creative problem-solving. The game’s standout mechanic is its unique movement system, where each leg is controlled individually, adding an extra layer of challenge and hilarity as you wobble around.

The puzzles are well-designed and progressively more difficult, encouraging communication and coordination, especially in co-op mode. Whether you’re balancing on narrow platforms or solving timing-based puzzles, every moment feels like a fun test of your teamwork skills.

Visually, the game’s colorful, minimalist aesthetic adds to its charm, and the lighthearted soundtrack complements the cheerful vibe. However, the game is relatively short, and while it’s perfect for a few hours of fun, some players might wish for more content.

Overall, Biped is a delightful co-op game that shines in its simplicity and creativity. It’s an ideal choice for those looking to enjoy some light puzzle-solving with a friend.

Posted: May 28, 2022
Biped is a fun little “puzzle” game with a well done main mechanic(which is movement). The game introduces some small new mechanics here and there but nothing too special. You can play Biped solo or co-op, but I would highly recommend co-op. So, it’s supposed to be a puzzle game, but I would not really call them puzzles. They are not challenging but that actually doesn’t even matter. They’re more like obstacles you have to pass with fun little mechanics.It’s just a blast to work together with your friend and mess around.

So to sum up, Biped is a fun little snack between other games, and it gave me and my friend a lot of laughs. But I don’t think I can recommend it to play solo. I would also wait for a good sale to pick it up as it’s only worth a couple of bucks in my opinion.

Posted: January 24, 2021
Please, beware if you're buying the game to play online.

The game seems really fun if you're playing local, but online there's a gigantic issue regarding how the engine handles the connection.

My friend and I live in the same city, we both have relatively low ping; I have 15ms, he has 50-130 (a few spikes). My friend doesn't lag in most games, but this game is utterly unplayable. Somehow, the game decides that the lag between my friend's computer and me should be added as input lag into the game; so it's impossible for him and I to play the game, since it feels like we're playing on ice.

It's horrible, it wouldn't surprise me if programs like Parsec (A program that allows another person to play from his computer in your computer like if you were in local cooperative) would make it more playable.

I wish we could've played it the way it was intended, but jesus, our internet is decent, it shouldn't act like this.

Posted: March 29, 2021
In Biped, each player controls their own robot. You have to move each leg of your robot independently, so it requires a fair amount of brain power to move with precision. Then you throw in difficult puzzle challenges which require you to co-ordinate well with your partner and you get a hilarious game where your friendship is tested.

It's pretty short, but it's definitely worth the money because:
* it's clearly made with care and love
* it's fairly cheap
* because of remote play, you only need one copy of the game to play with anyone you like
* there are awards for each level (time trial, etc) that encourage replayability
* it's fun to play through multiple times with different people because it's all about co-ordinating with your partner

Posted: July 9
Biped can be very frustrating or very rewarding or both at the same time. Good communication is needed with your partner or there will be a lot of potential yelling and blaming. However, if you're able to be a good sport and forgive mistakes while working together, then Biped is a really good co-op game. It reminds me of Portal 2 a bit in the cooperation aspect but the puzzles are more physical than mental.

A few puzzles can get frustrating so I recommend taking breaks as needed, but overall the game has a good progression of introducing a new concept to you and then repeating the concept in progressively more challenging scenarios.

I can't speak on the single-player but I found this to be a really rewarding co-op game with the right partner. It's a little short so maybe get it on sale, but I played it halfway once and then completed it on a second full run with a little idling, so the playtime is around 4 or 5 hours max depending on how quickly you can complete the puzzles and how much you want to go for extra coins.

For people having issues with online co-op, double check that you're both in the same region. It's a bit silly, but you need to be in the same region to join each others' rooms/games. I had more luck entering the room code than I did with Steam's invites system.

🧑‍🤝‍🧑 Check out for reviews of more co-op games to play with your friends or partner.

Hi adventurer,

1) Please, opened the folder: %USERPROFILE%/AppData/LocalLow/PostmetaGamesLimited/Biped
at your local PC.
2) Open the folder:
%USERPROFILE%/AppData/LocalLow/NExTStudios/Biped
Copy-paste all the files from the 2-nd folder to the first one and launch the game. It should solve your save files problem.

Posted: February 4, 2022
Lots of fun when playing co-op, and not too difficult. The movement in the game is really neat and plays well with a controller. I'm usually a D-Pad only kind of player with controller, but using the 2 analog sticks was really entertaining with this game. Used a PS4 controller for this game, but any controller would probably work well. With this game, if playing co-op it's probably best to have two people that are somewhat decent at games and you communicate well with, would possibly be nearly impossible to play without voice calling.

------------------------------
Control Scheme I Used:
Gamepad, PS4 Controller because I like the analog sticks it. Can't use D-Pad but that's to be expected with type of movement mechanics in this game.

------------------------------
Worth the current price (CDN$ 17.49)? Yes, although you'll need 2 copies to play with a friend online, so maybe not then.
What I actually paid: $12.19

------------------------------
Completionist Review:
DLC Achievements: No DLC
Rating: Overall not too bad to get everything.
Can be completed in one run: Unlikely as you wouldn't earn enough coins in one playthrough.
Chapter Select: Yes, with clear indications as to which levels to replay, can also load individual checkpoints.
Did I need/use a guide? No.

You will need to play this game fully with co-op and single player, most of the completion stuff is just beating the game, 1 type of collectable, and replaying enough times to earn coins to unlock all outfits. Could be easily done with 2-3 playthroughs tops. Only a few levels had specific time and death achievements, although all levels have goals you can shoot for past the listed achievements.

Posted: November 18, 2023
Finally a sequel to ARMS: LEGS!

It’s like Octodad except with cute little robots. It’s a really fun game to play with your wife’s boyfriend.

I first played this on the Switch and I was almost able to beat the game without touching the controller thanks to all the joycon drift doing it themselves! Glad to report it works a lot better on the Steam Deck.

It’s a perfect date game. Fun platformer and party game for you and a friend. Bought this when I saw it come out to play with my wife’s boyfriend and it's a super fun and unique co-op game.

In the game, each player controls the legs of a robot using the analog sticks. The left analog stick controls the left leg, and the right analog stick controls the right leg. Using them in conjunction allows you to skate around and knock each other off the edge, providing some hilarious moments.

It might be a cute game but don’t sell it short because of that, l'm a decent gamer and sometimes I struggled to keep up with some of the challenges. The teamwork required during this game is phenomenal. Try not to get too angry.

Depending on how you approach it, and how good you and your partner work together, you could probably get through the main campaign around the 4 hour mark, but collecting everything will obviously add multiple hours to that.

I like short games like this that don't overstay their welcome. It makes it easy to play through in one sitting when someone comes over, like watching a movie with someone versus watching a series with them. I'd definitely recommend picking it up, specially on a sale.

7/10

Posted: August 29, 2021
BIPED

Rating: Good
100% Time: 10~ hours
Genre: Co-op/Puzzle
Quick Summary: An interesting co-op game with an enormous focus on complicated character movement rather than complicated puzzles. Short enough that you can beat it in one sitting with a friend before you really start to see the flaws.

Positives
A relatively unique gameplay premise that hasn't been seen much: complicated movement. The game HAS to be played with a controller; each stick controls one of your characters legs so the real challenge is remembering what legs to move under pressure.

Posted: November 26, 2020
This game is fairly simple and straight forward about it's core mechanics. The controls felt very innovative and I must say, I have never played anything like it before and it is tremendous amounts of fun!!! Also, the robots are very cute, well animated and made me bond with them in an instant.
With Biped you and your fellow player will laugh, yell, puzzle and enjoy almost every minute of it, while feeling like a true team along the way, which the level and puzzle layouts promote nicely. For those who want even more coordinated cooperative gameplay, the puzzle missions add just the right amount of difficulty to have somewhat of a game outside of the main game, once that is finished, which can be done in a couple of hours / over the course of a few evenings.

Altogether, you can tell that the developers aspired to create something unique, "balancedly" challenging and, team-building and, as mentioned before of course, fun.

The gameplay idea left me thinking that there would be many more possible puzzle types and fresh spins on the core mechanics. This is by no means a detriment to the game, it just means that, should there ever be any DLCs or even a sequel, I will most certainly give it a go. Fully recommended for those looking for a cooperative game, that you can play specifically with 2 players.

Posted: March 6
Didn't realize we had beaten it as we ended after the end with the idea of coming back. But we did, so time to review:
Game has very cute graphics and nice music. It was nice throughout.
I enjoy the fact that we can beat up and mug the NPCs, and the mechanics are pretty good once you get used to the movement.

Now, that said... there are a few puzzles that were rough and at least one that felt unnecessary for online co-op. There is tunnel crossing controlled by a switch, and if the partner has ANY sort of latency this becomes very painful. It was clearly tested with couch co-op because even a half second increases the difficulty by a very huge margin. I'd really have appreciated if, after enough fails, we get a "Skip" option, or if the developers were able to test with someone in another State/Country and make adjustments to the breathing room.

And on the topic of co-op, the lobby is painful. "Lobby is full" with one person, failures to invite, and more. They have a beta for better client that we didn't know about until the end, but this really should have been added to the main system at some point in the last few years.

With that said: It was still enjoyable, we got a good number of laughs and I don't regret playing. The amount of frustration was acceptable and I'd still recommend, just try to play with people closer or go into the Betas and get the betterping one before struggling.

Posted: March 29, 2020
Saw this some hours ago while randomly browsing Steam. Told a friend about it and we decided to buy the game and give it a go as we were really bored and wanted something casual and fun to spend the time while we are social distancing due to the virus. I'd like to say for the few hours I played this I enjoyed it a lot. It's beautiful, "fluffy", smooth, and super chill and worth the cost. The only issue we faced with the game was a lag spike that looked like it was affecting frames but it wasn't, it just momentarily froze the game because of the ping spike. Besides that the game runs super smooth and is quick to get the hang of and becomes intuitive. I can't wait to see the potential of player made maps if that's in their to-do list or not. I would love to see 3 or 4 player cap to add more to the chaos but for a co-op it is super beautiful.

Overall I 100% recommend this if you and a friend are looking for something to have a nice and casual fun session.

I plan on updating the review upon playing it further later.

Posted: July 15, 2021
Biped is a 3D Puzzle game, where you or / and friend controlling a robot, and your job is to restart all of the beacons on Earth, before the catastrophe, meanwhile you need to solve puzzles.

My favourite part in Biped, is the gameplay. It's short with not too many levels, but the puzzles and the levels itself don't feel boring at all. Some levels are challanging, you need to really get used to the controlls, which I will get to it later. You can collect coins, stars and completing the levels in time for achivments or for coins, you can buy hats, which adds to the fun factor. The game is a bit childish, but it's for everyone and can bring fun to you alone or to your friend, too. There are also additional levels, which ramp up the difficulty, after you beat the game, if you need extra challange. Long story short, pretty fun gameplay with new elements and not boring at all.

Controlls seemed bit difficult for me at first, but it was really good. I played the game with controller, due to the game recommended it. You basically controlling the two legs of Biped with the two joystick, which seems bit difficult, but later in the game, you will get used to it. It's responsive and easy to get into, but hard to master it.

Surprisingly graphics is also a strong point of the game. It's a fact, that further textures not looking detailed at all, but the graphics in general fits for the game. I didn't saw any graphics bugs either, it's just wholesome.

Sound desing is also nice. There are no dialouges, only beeping but those are not annoying in my opinion. Pretty good stuff.

Story is basically told at the beginning, which is Earth has beacons and Bipeds needs to restart it, before something bad happens. Simple is that, however there is no need for additional story. Few of the levels has some story with different robots, which is just enough for the end of the level, and that's all right.

Biped surprisingly a really solid puzzle game, with cute graphics and design, yet challanging gameplay at some point, but not annoyingly hard. The only issue is that the game is quite short, but the solo and coop campaign together could give you enough gameplay. I can defiently recommend the game, even for the full price!

Pros

Posted: 10 February, 2021
Worms Rumble is an example of how to NOT do a online service. I respect Team 17 and their developers but its very apparent that this is their first attempt for a fully online experience.

This game is fun and I really enjoy it when I get around to playing it but my god is the waiting times a chore. If i'm not waiting 5-10 minutes if i'm lucky with 1/6th of the lobby filled, I'm waiting for the game to boot me out of searching for that match to reset the process.

The games bugs make the game almost unfun to play half the time. Any projectile based weapon like a bazooka or a plasma gun just clip through the map and do no damage. The shield will sometimes lose its collision box and just become a useless piece of junk and a mark on your back. The fact these bugs have been going on since launch its obvious they're never going to get around to fixing them due to their only interest being cosmetic fluff.

The game was basically dead on arrival only ever able to scrape 600 players at launch and the only reason why the game isn't dead is because of Playstation Plus. And, with no interest as it seems to adding more platforms for the game to exist on I doubt the issue of dying will ever be fixed before its too late.

Their roadmap is shocking and depressing its almost like they know their game is doomed to fall and they're trying to cover it up. Don't just say more information coming soon and only showing the next month this might be aggressive but your game is dying and it only feels like you're trying to squeeze out every penny you can before it sinks.

Overall, Worms Rumble is a sinking ship thats only repairs are with sticky tape and twigs. Take my 100 hours as advice to never buy this game unless they seriously add more then 4 arenas, 5 gamemodes and 24/7 online play which barely functions.

P.S: If anyone is interested in knowing what i'd fix in this game I have a link here:

Edit: (27/2/2020) This will probably be the last time I address this game but I just wanted to list every bug that isn't fixed to this day and when I noticed them.

-Sometimes breakables won't break and you'll clip through them (Launch)
-Projectiles clipping through walls (Random, January)
-Shield sometimes not working doing no damage and not protecting you (Just swap weapons quickly, January)
-Unopenable chests (January)
-Being kicked out of queue (Random, January)
-Holding swap weapons will sometimes not even give you your item (Recent patch)

Posted: June 16, 2021
Pros
Decent variety of weapons
Gameplay feels fluid and fun for the most part
DLC packs add more purely cosmetic customisation options
Crossplatform parties/lobbies

Your mileage may vary
The real-time style is a stark departure from the typical turn-based fare of the series

Cons
Alarmingly low playerbase
Imbalanced matchmaking (likely caused by the above)
Don't expect to have good ping unless you're based in EU
Large, but few maps
Online multiplayer only

Was the writing already on the wall at the time of the announcement? Hard to tell. , announced for the series' 25th anniversary, eschews with the turn-based nature of its predecessors and shifts to a real-time style more akin to and .

Honestly, it's way more fun than it would seem. I've been a fan for as long as I remember, gaming with my cousins on a bootleg version of , with my school mates on even more , then finally amassing my collection on Steam over the years. Suffice to say, I definitely miss the turn-based nature, and some of the wacky weapons we got in the past games (among my friend group, I was the undisputed Aqua Sheep king) - but does partly make up for it with a more concentrated variety of weapons that mostly still feel rather solid.

But let's take a look at the elephant in the room. You can tend to gauge how well a game has sold by the number of reviews, even if they only count Steam reviews. (with 320k+) massively took off, and even though the playerbase has obviously decreased since then, there are still thousands playing the game daily. The same cannot be said for , which is languishing on 1/356 of that amount, and a Steam player count of 2 digits. The only reason lobbies can still even be found are due to the PlayStation playerbase that got it from PS Plus, which at least is the one tactical masterstroke the game launched with.

This severely thin playerbase, I'm guessing, is what has led to the matchmaking being seemingly imbalanced. When I tried it out during the free weekend, I admit I criticised it too harshly, claiming it was programmed by "literal donkeys". In retrospect, that's a pretty unfair assessment, because what can you do when there's so few people playing it? You'll just get matched up against the same pros over and over again because there aren't too many players at a similar skill level rushing in to queue into matches; you're just thrown in at the deep end. And that's not including the fact that I can't even find matches for Last Squad/Worm Standing either.

Also, I'm based in the eastern side of the world - and searching for matches on the automatic setting just throws me into Europe games because there is no other playerbase; just the EU folk. This results in me having to play at a perpetual ping disadvantage. Fun, eh?

In actuality, I do find myself liking this game and wanting it to somehow succeed; this is still a pretty fun addition to the series, despite this dramatic shakeup. It's just a shame that the abysmal playerbase is causing quite a lot of problems.

Unfortunately, I can only suggest to get this on any form of sale. Humble Choice June 2021 was an option (and where I got mine), but it now also goes on 90%-off discounts on Steam. There are too many questions regarding this game's longevity, and getting it at full-price is a questionable decision at best. If you were lucky enough to claim it for free on PS Plus back on launch day, there is no point to double-dipping; just enjoy your copy of the game from there.

Posted: January 12
Something needs to be done.

I bought this game and all its DLC on Steam, Nintendo Switch, and PS5. I did this because all I want is to see every Worms game succeed so we can continue to see more entries released implementing new game-changing mechanics. Unfortunately it is not an enjoyable experience to play this game in its current state.

You will only find matches if you queue up for quick play. Even then it can take up to 10 minutes to find a match, and when it does there will only be at most 5 people in the game. Of those 5 people, at least 1 of them will be a level capped player with upwards of 5 million lifetime damage. The team this player is assigned to will win. It makes it feel like the other individual players don’t matter, as these matches typically end with scores 20 to 1.

This issue likely drives new players away, which is problematic because this contributes to the lack of players online. So few players online renders multiple daily challenges impossible to complete. The majority of daily challenges must be completed in specific game modes. Game modes that you cannot queue up for, as the only queue you will find matches in is quick play.

Because of this, daily challenges are painstakingly slow to complete, as it’s a coin toss whether or not quick play will put you in the game mode you need to complete the challenge.

This makes the game feel very devoid of purpose when everything is solely dependent on luck. Will you win the match? Depends on if you get teamed with the 3,000+ hour playtime veteran. Will the match you waited 10 minutes for be relevant for your daily challenges? Depends on the mercy of quick play.

Neither of these issues can be resolved by queuing up with a friend, as my friend and I have tested, two players queued separately for one game mode does not create a new lobby. You will both sit in queue until it times out and disconnects you.

The only clear resolution to these issues would be to get new players. Whether or not this means becoming free to play, I don’t know. All I know is that if SOMETHING is not done, this game is going to die.

Worms Rumble is a 2.5D fast-paced real-time combat, instead of turn-based the franchise is known for, where worms fight each other for laughs and giggles. I played on both PC and PS5 (it was free for PS Plus owners last month). There are three game modes: Deathmatch (free-for-all) and Last Squad/Worm Standing (fast-paced battle royale). I was a little irritated at first that they chose this route, but after playing for quite some time I started to enjoy it.

Pros:
✔️ Intense and fun gameplay: Play Deathmatch if you want to have cause mayhem and kill other worms as much as possible, or Last Squad/Worm Standing (where 32 players are against one another, group of three or solo) and be the last man/squad standing, while using iconic weapons and items from previous games, such as the sheep launcher and the holy grenade.
✔️ You can fight other players online across console and PC. Don’t let the steam player count fool you, the game is very much alive and it doesn’t take me too long to find a match, especially since it was free for PS Plus owners last month.
✔️ The 2.5D cartoonish graphics are very different and vibrant, compared to the previous games, and they look pretty good
✔️ didn’t face any technical issues, just buttery smooth 60fps.

❌ Don’t buy this game if you are looking for some single-player content.
❌ There are only four maps and three of which look somewhat identical to one another.
❌ It’s not turn based and require less strategy. On the other hand, I don’t blame them for choosing this route; change is good and there are plenty of single-player games on steam, plus not a lot of people are fond of turn based combat.


There are disconnection issues, according to other reviews. Fortunately, I haven't experienced one, not even on the PS5. In conclusion, if you want to play fast-paced PVP matches, using some of the most ridiculous weapons out there, then I recommend it, especially since it’s only $15. If you are looking for single-player content and some good turn-based combat, then I recommend and (my personal favorite).

Posted: December 2, 2020
Follow my Curator Page for more Strategy Games!

Worms Rumble is a battle royale game with cross-play. It's basically Worms without having to wait for your turn and available on Steam, Playstation 4, and Playstation 5.

There are three different modes, ten weapons, a handful of items (different grenades, jetpack, etc.), and three maps. You can customize your character with innumerable cosmetic items as well as your weapons with different skins. You level up by playing the game and unlock new cosmetic items which you then have to buy for coins. You can't buy coins with real money. There are no microtransactions in the game!

Deathmatch is one of the modes available to play. It works just as in every other game. 8 minutes, respawns and the one with the most kills wins. On the map are several crates with loot in them. That way, you can find better/different weapons, med-kits, grenades, and more. You also recover some health after time.
In the beta, you had to wait 15 seconds or more 'til you could respawn. Fortunately, they changed it in the full game. You can now immediately respawn. It's a quite nice improvement and shows that the devs listen to the community.

The main attractions of the game are the battle royal modes - Last Worm Standing and Last Squad Standing. The first one lets you play alone against 31 other worms. Just like in other BR games, the map gets smaller after some time. In Worms Rumble, you don't immediately die if you're out of the safe zone. The map shows you which area gets toxic and you'll lose health every few seconds if you're in it. There's enough time to leave the area if you pay attention.
Losing early is kind of frustrating since the matchmaking takes a bit longer here. The game recommends starting this mode if you reach level 10 with indicates you're not a beginner anymore.

Last Squad Standing is a battle royale with teams of three players. You can either invite your friends to play or get random teammates. One of you decides where your team spawns on the map. After that, it's the same as LWS. This mode is recommended for players who reach level 5 but you can play both modes immediately after starting the game for the first time.

Worms Rumble is a multiplayer-only game. Steamcharts shows that the player count is pretty small right now (Not even 1000 players on release day usually indicates the game is dead in a few weeks/months). Thanks to cross-play you don't have to worry about that. The game is well alive and matchmaking takes 30 seconds the most. The game is free if you have PlayStation plus which secures a healthy player base.

Having that many customization options is a good thing. Especially since there are no microtransactions and you can get everything by playing the game. It's also very playable with a controller and there is no real advantage for M+K users which makes it a casual experience overall.
It's a competitive game for sure but easier for everyone who never got a chicken dinner in similar BR games. I even got first place in Deathmatch in the beta after playing like five matches and chicken dinner in LSS in my second match with random teammates (me having the most kills) and I'm not a pro player by any means.

The game is fun and these little Worms are as charming as ever. The one thing we have to wait for is longevity. Will they add more maps, weapons, or even modes for free in the future? Maybe tournaments, special events, or challenges (There are daily challenges at least for now)? If they can deliver new content fast enough, they can make it worth it.
Otherwise, I'm not quite sure the game will be fun for solo-players in the long run. Playing with friends is a blast though and it's definitely worth it if you got friends to play with!

Posted: December 5, 2020
Worms finally has a game in the franchise that features real-time combat.
Do I prefer this over turn-based Worms? Sometimes.
Do I think all worms games should be real time from now on? No.
That being said, I think it's a great addition to the Worms franchise.
There are a few things I think long time fans will find questionable. The Bazooka has no charge up time and shoots in a straight line. There's no wind mechanics. All weapons can be fired while moving. This is a very different Worms experience. It's basically SOLDAT with a highly polished Worms theme.
The modes currently available are Deathmatch (Solo), Last Team Standing (trio BR) and Last Worm Standing (solo BR).
The game has unlockable skins like you'd find in other shooters like Call of Duty or Counterstrike, as well as cosmetic items to customize your Worm with.
Overall I think the game looks and plays great and as long as you know what to expect you should really enjoy this entry in the series.

I wasn't sold on this concept but I've played every worms game I can get my hands on so mild OCD took over. I would say this is a solid "yeah this is fun to jump into a match or two while I wait for friends to get online" experience. It seems to be shooting for the same chaotic multiplayer feeling that Fall Guys was going for, which works well enough for now, although I would like to see more objective based gameplay (capture the flag or king of the hill) in the future.

Overall, It's an interesting take on the Worms franchise, with no real risk involved. If I want to play something more tactical or with challenges, there's like 25 years of history to go back through on PC alone that I can always return to.

I worry a bit about the playerbase, but that will work itself out one way or the other over the next month or so, and being crossplay AND free on Playstation will help with those numbers, but it is worth noting that as of launch week it has not broken into the top 100 current steam games .
