Product received for free

Let's Get Ready To Rumble!!! Upon starting the game for the first time, you will be asked if you would like to enable Cross-Platform Gameplay. It doesn’t really matter which you choose right now as you can enable and disable the feature in the settings. Next, you’ll be asked if you wish to Begin Training or Go to Menu.

On the main menu screen along the top of the screen you’ll find, Play, The Lab, Worm and Weapons, Your Rank, Name, Money, Stats, Friends and Settings. On the left of the screen is some of the latest news, along with three daily challenges to unlock. In completing these challenges you’ll gain a gift reward of some sort. Beneath these is where you choose your Game Mode, hitting the Play button will then search for a game. You might want to go into the options and set the matchmaking region to the closest one available to you. There are four matchmaking regions, Central Europe, US West, US East and Asia, if you are unsure of which to choose you can set it too Automatic.

The Game Modes on offer currently are Deathmatch, Last Squad Standing and Last Worm Standing. Training can also be found along with the game modes. The Last Man Standing is recommended once you have reached Level Five, while Last Worm Standing is recommended that you be Level Ten.

Selecting to go through training will take you over the basics, how to move, jump shoot, throw grenades etcetera as you make your way through the training area. Reaching the end, you will arrive at an assault course, here you have Target Practice and Armoury. Target Practice is where you need to take out Twenty targets in the quickest time possible. In the Armoury you can mess around with all weapons, grenades and equipment. If you wish you can also take the toys around the assault course for a spin.

There is one more game mode The Lab, each week there will be specific rules and map. This week's Lab Mode is Melee Only Deathmatch where the only weapon you’ll use is the Baseball Bat on the map Missile Mall. There’s also a Weekly Reward, with this week's reward being a Pink Dinosaur outfit (yes, I do look good in it but as it’s Chrimbo Season I’m rocking a red reindeer outfit with snowflakes and a golden nose).

While in a match you’ll have to keep your mince pies on your stamina. Rolling and Wall Jumping to get around the map will eat into your stamina. You can always crawl along at worm speed to save some stamina but if you really want to get your botty moving then you’re going to have to start rolling. There are other forms of moving around from place to place if you can get your hands on the Jetpack or Grabble Hook.

You start with One-Hundred health and once it’s gone you die; you will respawn after a few seconds (at least in deathmatch). Collecting First Aid Boxes or Cans of Energy Drink, these can replenish your health if you can manage to get it down your neck before someone comes along and spanks your botty. You can carry two weapons at one time and you’ll get random weapons, equipment from a crate at the start of each round. More weapons can be found after being dropped from fellow defeated worms.

After each match you’ll be rewarded with Experience Points and Coins depending on how well you did. You will get a Breakdown of the match and earn experience points and coins in Match Completed, Eliminations, Damage and Position. These experience points will Level Up your character. You also get a Breakdown on any Weapons used, you will gain Experience Points in Eliminations, Damage and Time Held, these points will Level Up that weapon. Gaining experience and coin will unlock new weapon skins, costumes, look and other customisable items for your character.

In the settings you’ll find options for Audio - Master, Gameplay, Music, Speech and Announcer Volume Sliders, also here is Audio Output Device. Video - Display Mode, Resolution, Resolution Scale, V-Sync, Limit FPS and Max FPS. Brightness, Render Quality, Ambient Occlusion, Anti-Aliasing, SSR, Bloom, Shadow Quality, Post Process Quality and Particle Detail.

Game - Auto-Switch Empty Weapons, Auto-Switch New Weapon, Nameplates, Enemy Health Bars, Roll Toggle. Account – Cross-Platform Play (On/Off) and Matchmaking Region (Automatic, Europe Central, US West, US East and Asia). Accessibility - Colour Blind Mode, Held Buttons and Screen Shake.

Controller - Controller Bindings, Aim Sensitivity, Aim Assist, Movement Aim, Vibration, Left and Right Stick Deadzone. Mouse & Keyboard - Movement, Action and Equipment Bindings.

I’ve enjoyed playing Worms Rumble, especially the Melee Only Deathmatch (this weeks The Lab game mode). I chose the Europe region for matchmaking with me coming from England. The game seemed to run pretty smooth, I never felt like I was lagging at all.

Searching for a game doesn’t hasn’t taken too long to find one, a minute or two at most. Although I do have cross-platform multiplayer selected in the options so as to make sure I get a game, which hasn‘t been a problem so far. I haven’t tried to search for a game against just Steam players, I don’t mind spankin’ the botty of other platform gamers using my keyboard and mouse … All Hail the PC Master Race!!!

I have had a Network Error occur three or four times, one of these errors occurred while in game and I was kicked out. While the other times I got the errors when trying to connect to a game. Other than that, Worms Rumble is a refreshingly fun and enjoyable game.

Positives
+ Fun and enjoyable to play
+ Nice graphics
+ Multiple game modes
+ Cross-Platform multiplayer
+ Full controller support
+ Has achievements

Negatives
- Network errors
- No cards currently

Take to the arena in thirty-two player cross-platform battles, customise your worm and cause chaos with old and new weapons in Worms Rumble

8/10

Posted: April 10, 2021
Review by Gaming Masterpieces - The greatest games of all time on Steam.

Is this game a masterpiece? Well, it is an online only multiplayer brawler. Can this be an eternal masterpiece?

After it's 1995 Amiga release, Worms became one of the larger franchises in gaming history. Now, after about a dozen games in the series, Worms Rumble is the first online-only and real-time Worms. Quite a change from the usual formula. So lets say this clearly - the game mechanics are completely different from older Worms games.

You get a real-time, online multiplayer action game. Kill all other worms, excluding your team in the team modes. The roots of Worms are still here - from the banana grenade to the attacking sheep, but if you want slower turn-based Worms gameplay, stay with the (reasonably good) Worms W.M.D. or Armageddon. Worms Rumble comes with 2 basic game modes, either (Team) Deathmatch to score the most kills or Last Squad/Worm Standing to survive, both in Team or FFA mode. The matchmaking is automatic, but you can invite friends. Servers are populated atm, so you will find a deathmatch game with short waiting time. Rounds take a few minutes, and you unlock tons of cosmetic items to dress your worm. There are also a bunch of cosmetic DLCs available, if you still don't like your looks.

Gameplay is frantic, the controls are responsive, it is easy to score a few kills even for beginners. Collect the spawning loot boxes to receive better weapons (or health, ammo), jump or roll around the (few) well-thought out and large levels, shoot with your gun/rocket launcher or throw (holy) grenades - that's it, basically. Fun, but probably not a masterpiece.


Good online brawler in the Worms universe.

𝕎𝕙𝕒𝕥 𝕙𝕒𝕡𝕡𝕖𝕟𝕤 𝕥𝕠 𝕒𝕟 𝕆𝕟𝕝𝕚𝕟𝕖 𝕘𝕒𝕞𝕖 𝕨𝕙𝕖𝕟 𝕚𝕥'𝕤 𝕝𝕖𝕗𝕥 𝕗𝕠𝕣 𝕕𝕖𝕒𝕕 𝕓𝕪 𝕚𝕥𝕤 𝕕𝕖𝕧𝕤 𝕒𝕟𝕕 𝕪𝕠𝕦 𝕜𝕟𝕠𝕨 𝕒𝕟𝕕 𝕥𝕙𝕖𝕪 𝕜𝕟𝕠𝕨 𝕚𝕥'𝕤 𝕘𝕠𝕥 𝕙𝕦𝕘𝕖 𝕡𝕠𝕥𝕖𝕟𝕥𝕚𝕒𝕝?

I'm not even complaining; I mean, for what it's worth the game is functional, great-looking and smooth... However, you'd rather play other "better" party-based online games like "Fall Guys".

Being part of the Worms universe (If you don't know Worms, just scroll down NOW), the game remains true to the whole premise that you're in control of an armed and dangerous worm that slithers around the battlefield, killing other worms to win the game. In Worms Rumble, you've got different modes, all of which would optimally require 40 or more players... You can really visualise what they tried to do here: complete rumble and mayhem as 40 or more worms are trying to kill each other for the high score or to be the last worm standing... The game, however, is deserted... with very few veterans still playing it.

The queue time is actually short, believe it or not, and the game would start with ten players that probably only play this game, because I've played two games so far with the exact same ten people twice... Ten worms that start with bazookas, sniper rifles, sheep that explode? homing missiles... every single weaponry that looks like it would take you over 500 hours playing this dead game to get... You can imagine my frustration at being able to hit literally nobody with my cute pink pistol that does crap damage lol.

Because the game is deserted, you're faced with only one of two options: keep playing the game, getting completely obliterated every single game by the same few people that still play it? Or go play something else. Well, an achievement hunter knows his choices, you should know yours. For the smooth gameplay, I'm ranking this game slightly over a grade that would put it into the red zone, with . Great premise and execution; abandonned too early!

Posted: March 27, 2022
I didn't want to have to not recommend this game.

When I initially saw the trailers for Worms Rumble, I thought, "Ooh, this is a fun twist on the original concept." I figured it was different enough from your typical battle royale to stand out a little more. I even decided to preorder the game, because I genuinely love the Worms series, and Team17 has put out a lot of games I enjoy.

Do I enjoy playing Worms Rumble? Yes, absolutely. But can I recommend it to anyone? No, not at the stage it's in. I hadn't played for a while, so I hopped on today to do a few deathmatches. First time I tried to get into a game, I waited a few minutes before cancelling and trying again. This has been an issue in the past that I've noticed. Then when I finally did get into the game, I seemed to be playing with a lot of the same people. Each match was dominated, of course, by a few diehard, level 50 players.

This game is slowly sinking, and the devs don't seem too keen on doing anything about it. It's been, what, half a year since we got any sort of update or event? The rewards system is, ironically, unrewarding. And frankly, I'm not terribly interested in investing time into a game that's gonna eventually go offline once there's no profit to be made from it. Once that happens, all our time and money will have been for nothing.

So yeah, go play Worms WMD instead.

Posted: January 6, 2021
I always wanted to learn how to ninja rope like the pros in Worms 1999. Now there is Worms Rumble, a real time action game with ninja ropes. The jetpack will probably give you a bigger advantage, but that's ok since ninja roping is way more fun! There were many bugs we came across at the release, but after a week the devs fixed most of them and continue to work hard making the game better. The devs always replied to my concerns and complaints in the forums. There are many complaints about wanting destructible environments, girders, land mines, and other cherished worms related things, but as you can see this is a real time action game and not turn based so I welcome the new changes.

The game can be unfair at times, but I think that is the nature of "Battle Royale" type games. The spawns can give quite a challenge when you are randomly thrown into a small area with lots of other players. Look for the ninja-rope or jetpack and get away as fast as possible, but don't forget to rescue your team mates! For long term playability, there are many hats and vanity items to collect and of course you can change the voice of your worm. I'm sure they have more maps, weapons, game modes planned for the future.

Overall it is a great game with intense action, just needs a few more updates to polish glitches in movement/clipping. Most of the time I can play for hours perfectly, but can randomly crash. I recommend it regardless of the issues we had since the devs fixed game breaking problems very quickly.

If you are looking for a regular Worms game, this is not one of them. If you are looking for a fun Worms spin-off (akin to Worms Golf or Worms Blast), then you are about have a wonderful time! I played both the alpha and the beta of this game, so my in-game time isn't fully accurate.

This is an incredibly fun fast-packed 2D arena shooter. There are currently 3 maps and 3 modes:
- Deathmatch (get the most kills)
- Last Worm Standing (Battle Royale)
- Team Last Worm Standing (3-worm team Battle Royale)

Each one of those is extremely fun to play, and the only hope is that developers keep on supporting this game and adding content for the years to come. They already did wonders to this game after taking feedback from the alpha and beta, and I hope that this trend continues.

Posted: April 30, 2021
It's a good game that had all the makings of what could have been a great game but it missed it's mark.

Notalgia of playing worms 2? yes!
the chaos and unpredictable wildness of the classic Quake arena? sure it kinda has that.
Various competitive game modes? they put that in there too! (deathmatch, last worm standing, etc.)

It's really a bit of fun to play but there's just one problem... they have to fix the fact that it isn't playable sometimes. If there is no one else online to play, you CAN'T play.

Here's the bottom line on the mixed reviews - their match making system needs work. A lot of work.
- Matches taking between 5-10 minutes (i'm not kidding)
- Deathmatch games having players popping in an out on occasion.
- player ranking lobbies are a lawless wasteland. (imagine jumping in on your first game with 5 level 50 players while you're still trying to get a feel for the game). Not fun.

Now, this is probably because of a loss of players because the devs may have neglected to add certain parts of the worms franchise that made the game fun.

- Setting up private rooms to pick and choose who you play with (friends and/or people in a certain region for instance).
- Offline game modes and challenges for new players to get to enjoy the mechanics the devs worked quite hard to polish.
- A spectator mode where players can watch on-going matches and possibly learn the maps.


I really do like the game... but i don't think i can recommend the game to anyone else I know until they polish up a few things with the game.

Beyond that, the game stands a chance to be one of the great games. Really It does.

The attention to detail they put into it shows with their audio and visual designs. Personally I appreciated small touches like putting a mild echo on the bathroom areas, adding pinball and arcade sounds in the lobby areas, the grapple hook mechanics were really evident.

If the devs ever do get to read this, I hope that they get put more (modes) into it. It honestly feels more like an early access game than anything not because the game isn't good. It feels like an early access game because the game could be so much more than what it is. It HAS so much potential to be one of the greats.

Posted: December 3, 2020
A fun game like no other, changing the way we play Worms!

Graphics: The graphics are decent with some nice reflections, graphical spark to some explosions or electric but overall, a very decent platform style game.

Audio: All the lovely worms sounds are here from noises, to the awesome 'Holy Hand Grenade' "ooooo" noise. It's all bang on.

Controls: Super easy and simple to get used too, nothing hard or confusing, pickup and play.

Game-play and everything else: The game is not turn based which is a nice welcome to the series. It's a side scrolling platform shoot them up with some really good modes, weapons, character customising skins to unlock, levels to earn with weapon levels too. It's really good fun and cross-play makes the matches even better for constant games.

As I write this review, a few days after release. The only issue I have is the lack of maps right now. I am sure this will be fixed further down the line, but right now it's lacking maps.
Yes, the game is really good fun and you can party with people, drag into games so always on the same map etc, it's all very very simple, it's just the maps that I have an issue with but I know, in time it will be fixed.

There are different modes to death-match, last team standing etc but all are fun to play and learn the game. The weapons are all unique and some really fun to use. You jump, dive, roll into pipes, elevators etc. It's all here from the Worms fun and a platform shooter.

Would I recommend the game? 100% yes! It's dirt cheap and a lot of fun with hours to play solo or with friends, it's a game underestimated and fun!

Posted: December 3, 2020
Product received for free

I also made a longer, more in-depth video review here:
YouTube™ Video: Worms Rumble Review | This Is My New Favorite Game 
Views: 12,161
Worms Rumble has blown my expectations out of the water and it is already my new favorite game. It's an intense, real-time deathmatch and battle royale game that has an incredible progression system...

Worms Rumble has blown my expectations out of the water and it is already my new favorite game.

If you have any experience with the Worms Franchise you know that they are mainly these turn-based tactical games and so Worms Rumble is a crazy new take on the Worms formula and it works incredibly well.

Instead of playing like the old Worms Games, Worms Rumble is a super intense, real-time deathmatch and battle royale game that is super fun. Also it is just a breath of fresh air in terms of multiplayer games for me personally.

The battle royale mode is extremely fast paced which is great and the inventory management system is super streamlined.

And I will say the weapons are probably one of the best parts about this game. There are several unique weapons like some classics like the shotgun, assault rifle, and the rocket launcher, but then you have these other crazy weapons like a gun that shoots exploding sheep that run to the enemy, which if you play other Worms game you will definitely recognize.

And the attention to detail on these maps is pretty incredible. The 2.5D artsyle is really awesome and all the different areas are visually different which makes the maps feel like they have a ton of variety. Also there are several different maps with unique gimmicks to them so you don’t have to worry about getting bored on the maps at all.

In terms of the playerbase, the game seems to be doing crazy good right now, its a free game for premium playstation users in December I believe, and the game is cross platform at launch so with all the platforms together I don’t think you will have to worry about getting in games of 32 people.

And so the gameplay is fast paced, exciting, and crazy fun but that’s only half of why I love this game so much.

This game has a progression system that actually managed to make me care. A lot of games do the type of progression system tied to cosmetics and normally they don’t interest me at all but for some reason this game just does it right and makes me love it.

It kind of works like the progression in COD and also kind of Apex Legends in a way. So you can level up your overall account and that unlocks new customizations for your worm like hats, faces, and even card backgrounds and different stat tracking things to brag about on your cards like Apex Legends does.

Also you can level up each individual weapon which will allow you to get new weapon skins for those guns and the final weapon skin is gold which reminds me so much of Call of Duty and I love that because I always liked grinding for gold weapon skins.

So for me pesonally this game is just everything I could ask for in a game. You have crazy good and fast paced gameplay, you have super fun weapons to fight with, you have really good looking maps and just an overall amazing theme, I’ve always loved the worms franchise, and a really simple yet impactful progression system that gets you new cosmetics for your worm and your weapons.

The only piece of criticism or feedback I would give is that there is sometimes a little bit of downtime between the matches. The game takes a little to find a match and then the loading into that match takes a decent amount of time. It’s nothing unbearable but after playing a couple games in a row I started to notice it and if you die instantly in the battle royale mode it might suck to have to go through that whole process again.

But besides that, hands down I would recommend this game in a heartbeat.

Posted: 28 June, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
What an absolute gem of a game.

It saddens me that until now people (including myself) were not aware of this games existence. It appeared to completely slip on the radar before trending recently. And it absolutely deserves that overwhelmingly positive score it has.

This game has clearly taken a lot of inspiration from beloved childhood games, such as Henry Stickmin, Simpsons Hit and Run and, at least visually speaking, something like Unturned or Little Big Planet. The graphics are simplistic, but that is not a criticism. They're bright and bouncy and make you feel good. It has that quintessentially British humour, with much of the core of the game revolving around jelly (or jello for our American friends) and jelly-related terms. The music reminds me of Stardew Valley and similar games, and is light-hearted and adorable. A few missions have music that is evocatively similar to other games. For example, the pizza delivery mission plays a song intentionally similar to Spider Man's infamous side-mission, even including the music speeding up. Such detail and references are welcome, wholesome and fill me with joy.

There is actually quite a lot to do in the game. At first it seems to not be the case, but as you expand the map and are made aware of the various island 'worlds' that make it up, then it is actually quite jam packed with content; especially considering the price. There's an assortment of vehicles, houses, pets and places to explore. You can customise your little Wobbly character with a variety of fun outfits. The quests are the perfect balance of relaxed difficulty: easy enough to have fun and also to sit back and not stress too much about it. I generally hate timed quests in games, but this game does them well with enough room for forgiving mistakes and are short and enjoyable enough to eagerly give a second and twentieth go.

The co-op is fantastic. My only criticism is for some reason there is a controller button that allows me to spawn a second character in addition to my own and then splits the screen. The controls then become unplayable as it is attempting to use dual inputs, requiring me to restart. It isn't a major deal, but I hope they fix this very strange bug or feature? I'm unsure. Thankfully joining back into a game with someone is incredibly easy, progress is saved easily, the game loads quickly and is all-around well optimised for cooperative play. Joining missions with your friends is easy and allows you to equally reap the rewards for completing them. I would recommend playing it with friends over solo, as the missions are definitely oriented for multiple people. Not to say solo is not also not wonderfully enjoyable.

The controls you might expect would be terrible, as this is a game akin to Goat Simulator. I think the controls are better. They are actually surprisingly responsive to such a game. The developers have clearly combined just enough physics as to be amusing without eternal frustration of bugging out. There are surprisingly few bugs in this regard. While I have managed to slingshot into the stratosphere a few times, it never broke the game or what I was doing and was instead enjoyably awaited. And for the few times I did clip through something, there is a respawn button, which should be ubiquitous in these games. The vehicles feel responsive but definitely control like much older titles where they are challenging beasts to turn at speed. All of this makes for much hilarity, without much frustration. I honestly cannot believe this game is still in Early Access for the amount of polish it has in most areas.

If you're having a bad day. If this world is seeming just a little too existential, then come to Wobbly Island, buy a house for $1,000 to taste the sweet sugary tones of ownership and firmly attach your stubby gelatinous hands to any passing vehicles.
Because, remember...

The Simpsons Hit & Run meets Goat Simulator.

It's lacking a lot of features to keep it interesting, but that's because you're supposed to bring along your friends and build your own fun. The world feels empty and hollow because it lacks NPCs going about their business. There are a few people driving vehicles that you can see from time to time, but nowhere near enough to convince me that this world is truly lived in.
You sadly cannot mix hairstyles with hats, so you could either have a gnome beard or a gnome hat, but never both at once. How am I supposed to fulfil my gnome roleplay fantasies if I can't be bearded with a pointy hat? It's outrageous. I'd also like to see more options for customisation in the future.

The characters with dialogue are all 2 dimensional and zany, which makes them kind of samey.

Posted: September 20, 2023
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
LOTS OF FUN, BUT ALSO FRUSTRATION. I HAVE PLAYED MORE THAN 100 HOURS AND I MEAN IT FOR REAL.

My kids love it! The game is really COOL to play CASUALLY in coop (allows local split screen):

- wonderfull, silly, violence-free open world
- many jobs to do and puzzles to solve
- unlockable pets, vehicles and suits
- creative nad memorable moments (feeding the monster, hoverboard ride, getting shrunk in the laboratory etc)
- arcade arena with different games: hide&seek, "Fall guys"-type running, a sandbox mode, conveyor belt game
- supports modding

But after some time of exploring and just casually hanging around, you want to complete tasks, get artefacts, unlock things and earn money to buy cars/houses. Then the frustration kicks in:

- money bags randomly dissapear
- hard-earned artefacts just noclip through the trunk of your car and get lost
- chests are sometimes spawned under the buildings, or the loot slips in the water
- artefacts and gold get stuck under the floor
- some vehicles are almost uncontrollable (airplanes, water scooter)
- airplanes and helicopters randomly explode
- sometimes jobs cannot be done (job target is so far away you cannot complete the job - furniture delivery, fireman...)
- some platforms bounce you off randomly into the water
- fishing is probably the worst minigame I have played in years
- interesting quests like the police job, the temple or secret laboratory are really scarce, 99.5% of the game are just repetitive jobs
- NPCs are scarce, the world is almost empty
- I have been trying real hours to get the randomly generated artifacts like the uranium crystal from the mine or the golden trinket in the trashcan - but unlucky me, they didnt spawn
- at the moment, there is maybe 1 interesting mod available

I understand that most of these are probably early-access bugs, that they appear randomly and not all the time - but they can ruin your gameplay anyway. Imagine playing with your little buddy, thying for half an hour to get an artefact from a cave - and on your way back your helicopter randomly explodes, your artefact gets lost and the little buddy has tears in his eyes...
On the other hand, if you are playing the game coop with your kids that just want to give silly dress to their character, ride the jelly car and bump into everything in their way, then your money is well-spent.

Hey, I might sound negative, but I like the game and it was worth the money. Get it now :)
PS: I am looking forward for the space update!

Posted: March 3, 2023
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
So what happens when you take the ragdoll and grab physics of Human Fall Flat and drop them into a open-world adventure with no real goal except to have fun just flailing about and creating chaos? You get Wobbly Life. I'll admit that I had actually never heard of this game until I saw a certain group of Youtubers fooling around with it and that got me interested in looking at what the game had to offer. When I actually picked it up and played it, it's safe to say I wasn't disappointed.

The open world here is surprisingly-big for what you would tend to expect from a game like this. The game is, so far, split up into a selection of around half a dozen islands, each with their own selection of things to do, jobs to earn money with and unlockables. Want to go to the mine and dig up some ore in exchange for cash in the island up north? Want to go to a disco club on the main island and make some money in a rhythm game? Want to just forego the money and go exploring the nearby tropical island to see if there's any mysteries there you can unlock cool stuff with? You're free to do whatever you want whenever you want it. The only goal you have when you start the game is to afford a place of your own, and after that you're just left to your own devices. This game is super easygoing on how you progress and it actually rewards curious and explorative players with special unlockable goodies like unique vehicles, clothing and pets.

Additionally, I'm surprised at the level of puzzle-solving there is in this game due to it clearly being a game that gamers of all ages can pick up and play. A lot of the things in this game are easy enough to figure out but unlocking some of the special cars, clothing and pets requires a surprising amount of steps with very little hints or clues. I won't give any specific examples here just for the sake of potentially spoiling a cool reward for someone who hasn't unlocked it yet but a couple of unlocks require you to do something while in the process of doing a specific job or in the middle of a timed race. Personally I really like that because the game goes out of the way to reward people who like to explore.

Now, I should also bring this up: This game was very-clearly made with multiplayer in mind. The game is perfectly playable and fun if you're playing on your own but there are a handful of jobs in the game that are a royal pain to do without a couple extra sets of hands helping you. For me, the newspaper and ice cream jobs are especially annoying to try and do on my own and you need to be near-perfect with how you play either of those games if you're solo and still want to pass the jobs. Like I said, I know that the games were made to be fun for more than one player but, since I've only played solo so far, the only thing those jobs have brought me thus far is just headaches.

I definitely recommend this game, especially if you're the type that likes to explore at your own pace or if you're looking for some mindless fun you can have with a few friends. I wasn't expecting the game to be as fun as it is when I picked it up, and I think it exceeded my expectations greatly considering the Youtubers that introduced me to the game didn't actually do much with it now that I see what the game has to offer. Now I'm looking forward to seeing what the devs do next with it and what they do to add to the game when there's already quite a bit to do here.

Posted: July 10, 2020
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Wobbly Life

While perusing Steam's upcoming releases in the Co-Op category, I came across this game as it caught my eye. The trailer reminded me of a lot of Human Fall Flat (one of my favorite games) except with childhood innocence. You have a bright and positive world to interact with which also includes many tasks to keep you busy and provides rewards for your character. I quickly wish listed the game and showed a couple of my friends. Then I waited for it's release and was happy to see the price was even generous.

Upon installing and loading up the game, the main menu shows you an overview of your little island and character. The happy music that accompanies the scene (and even throughout the game) puts you in a good mood and even made me smile.

Perks:
- Game is only $8.99 which I think is a pretty good bargain for a new release.
- It will remind some of Human Fall Flat and Total Reliable Delivery Service with the controls favoring a Human Fall Flat approach thankfully.
- It's an open-world sandbox with lots of locations, jobs for your character, mini-games, and even vehicles you can drive.
- You can complete jobs or tasks around the island and earn currency which you can spend on various things including properties and the ability to buy customizable clothes and vehicles.
- The game has both single-player mode and multiplayer modes.
- Online Co-Op is in Beta currently but I'm glad I can play with my friends on it.
- The controls for your player are very simple as well are driving vehicles or carrying objects. Left stick controls your left arm, right stick controls your right, and X even makes your player fall over all of which are just like Human Fall Flat.
- Arcade is coming soon which I assume is mini-game related.


I haven't put a lot of time into this game yet but can already tell I'm glad I bought it. I had my assumptions before it's release and it hasn't been disappointing yet. I think this game has a lot of potential going forward and considering it was made by such a small development team is impressive. I'm expecting a lot of quality updates in the future and interested in how they go about adding more content.

I would definitely recommend this game as I feel it's worth a try. Looking forward to having fun with my friends on it accompanied by a lot of laughs.

Posted: June 15
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
You know, this isn't a bad game! I don't hate it. What a weird way to start things off though, right? It oozes with character! There's just one little issue I have with it. One teeny-tiny itsy-bitsy issue.

This game almost made my wife puke.

Upon a moment of reflection, that's actually a huge issue.

This game makes some people insanely motion sick, and there's very little you can do about it. If you get motion sickness from games, you really should do a hard pass on this one.

Now, if you don't get motion sickness... I don't know, the best comparison I have is GTA Online, with only your friends, and no crimes. Also wobbly.

If that doesn't mean anything to you, this is your jam: You'll roam around a game map, Grand Theft Auto style, finding jobs to do, and doing those jobs in the form of various minigames. There's a lot of jobs. All of them pay you as long as you meet some of the job objectives, but better success gets you better payouts. That money can be used to buy one or more houses in the game world. Or clothes. Or cars.

Not that you just can't "borrow" a car as it drives by. Or find one parked in somebody's yard and make do with that. I mean, wait, you can. You totally CAN do that.

What separates this from GTA, well, obviously the lack of crime. And obviously the art style. But this game leans on ragdoll hijinks and clumsy character physics. Your mouse buttons extend each arm. With arm extended, whatever you touch you "grab" until you release the mouse. This is how you press buttons, pick up items in the game world, or grip the rear bumper of a car and consent to getting dragged around by your coop partner.

And yes, coop. So you can roam around being a goof.

And much like GTA's game world, most of it is coop, and there's a lot of secrets hidden about, so you don't have to helicopter-rescue injured people or make hamburgers, you can just meander and see what's to be seen.

So despite the fact that the missus is out, I'll probably poke at this a little more yet. I wanted to get that chalet in the mountains. It looked nice. And then I'll move on to other things.

It's not a deep game, it's a very willfully shallow and absurd game, but clearly it's a work of passion by its developers. I respect that more than mere words can express. I just wish it didn't make my wife puke.

We stopped playing this online, and moved on to other things to stream. That streaming happens at . I put this on the bottom on purpose, because people who read all this are exactly my kind of people. I'm chatty. Say hello.

Posted: June 29, 2023
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Genuinely one of the best open world experiences on steam right now that i can think of, i dont think ive seen any game quite like this that gives true free reign to explore while having so much to discover, ive played for 11 hours and im still discovering stuff that was technically there the whole time that i never noticed

The world actually feels alive which is what i think a lot of open world games struggle with but, a surprising majority of the set pieces are interactable where youd expect them to be static backdrops in other games. for example, a simple music store would most likely be an decal over a geometric prop, in this game you can go inside and play with the instruments and talk to the guy running the store, even though you cant buy the instruments

Several little things like this are scattered through the game not to mention the actual hidden side quests that end up being much more in depth than I would assume at the beginning, this all isnt even to mention the many jobs that are available to earn money to buy random stuff, theres so much going on its genuinely difficult to give a concise review but i highly recommend this game, i havent even checked out the arcade or multiplayer yet but its still a great time just exploring finding unique things in every corner

Posted: April 13, 2021
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Wobbly Life is such a neat game, it's basically an open-world version of Human Fall Flat crossed with Surgeon Simulator were the controls in that title actually sensible. This game is challenging and not ragequit-inducing, which is a nice switch. If you fail a job it's not really a big deal, but maybe there's another way to approach it that'll guarantee success next time.

The majority of Wobbly Life can be played solo if you wish, but some job types such as flipping burgers at this time essentially need two or more players. Certain hidden objectives also benefit greatly from having a crew of friends. Note while this supports drop-in multiplayer the random players I've encountered have ALL been griefers looking to steal your cash or destroy your vehicle for no reason. A mention also needs to be made that some missions vary between online and off, hospital work with others involves a medevac chopper while playing solo sees you pulling ambulance duty.

There is quite a bit of content here for around $10, but those of you achievement hunters seeking to 100% Wobbly Life should note you'll be doing a ton of grinding for around 40 to 50 hours to do so. While there are varied careers there is a somewhat limited number of each task so you'll see repeated jobs quickly.

I'm honestly surprised word of mouth hasn't exploded this title yet as it's really accessible, but with a steady stream of updates since initial Early Access release and developers regularly appearing on the hub I'm assuming this will happen at some point. Easy recommend, that I can't quit playing it says it all.

Posted: July 10, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
It's as if Grand Theft Auto and Human Fall Flat had a baby.

- One of the best CO-OP party games to play with another friend.

- A pretty b*tchin' soundtrack.

- A visually appealing artstyle with simplistic but eye-candy graphics.

- Simple but extremely fun and addicting gameplay mechanics.

- You're gonna be laughing your ass off constantly depending on how you play this game in CO-OP. It's best played with 1 or 2 more people with voice chat as well. Playing in Single Player is significantly less fun and duller.

- A big open world to explore, filled with collectables and jobs that you can complete to earn money. Money is spent to further customize your character and purchase goods which further aid you in the open world.

- Physics-Based chaos throughout your playtime.

- CO-OP play is encouraged and rewarded by allowing your buddy to help you during certain jobs, allowing you to complete it significantly quicker. You can also get creative, think outside of the box and complete specific jobs in new ways that you cannot do in Single Player.


Basically, buy this game! BUY IT! STOP READING THIS SH*T AND BUY IT! IT'S GREAT!!

Posted: July 4, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Early Access v0.7.6 review

Man, trust me, your kid ages 5-12 has a pretty good chance of getting your money's worth out of Wobbly Life in playtime or awe. And that's my review for Wobbly Life.

No, but, really, this is a charming game. It's a little rough around the edges and budget indie jank but (surprisingly not too bad) it's a whole lot of fun especially for the bargain price. Things that could improve the game would be: more of an economy (right now everything roughly costs the same), tighter controls, remove the rare but present possibilities of getting stuck, better and less awkward handling of vehicles, more items to spend your money on with purpose. (Rather than just houses and props.)

Still, I'm way out of the age bracket to be playing this game and I still am having a really good time. There's no violence, death, explosions, injury, anything bad. Sometimes it's relaxing to go back to that era and with most of the mini-games being mild to moderate difficulty hand-eye coordination of your standard console fair, it's perfectly low stress and really open to all audiences.

I almost considered if I'd made the right purchase or not until I spent some time reflecting on the fact that the game is nice in that it doesn't push me toward any goals, I can complete it at my leisure, it's quite pleasing to look at and I have fun trying new things in the huge landscape to explore. There's no pressure and I can set it down and pick it back up at my leisure. I found a few interesting things to do as well, such as join a disco or a quiz show. The mini-games have variety.

This game is inevitably more fun with partners. You can find a few easter egg items in the world that will allow you to have more fun with more people, such as a tractor-drawn tomato gun in a barn. In the online mode, up to four players can play together in a drop-in drop-out non-persistent game world. For that reason, it reminds one of another popular game series on a smaller scale. It's basically a GTA free roam clone for all ages and fun for the whole family.

If you want a more polished game, wait for the price to be increased (as stated by the developers) and for it to leave Early Access and for the bugs to be hammered out. But in the meantime, it is a cheap and harmless way to spend a few hours grinding money, taking in the cute scenery and nice experiences.

💑 Check out for more recommendations to play with a friend or partner.
💯 Check out my Curator for more recommendations of casual games like this!

Posted: May 26, 2022
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Update: Added more stuff in review as i played more of the game
Update2: They addressed the issue i had with the metal detector and i'm so happy they did! now the only thing they need to address is the UFO signals and i think this game is good so far with deaf or hard hearing people! Also added info on Steam Deck support and how well it works on it.

This is a really nice game that i wasn't expecting to enjoy as much as i do.
In this game you play as a thing called "Wobbly" and you do a bunch of activites to earn money to be able to buy a house, car, props, pets and all sorts of things.

Initially when i bought this i thought this game will be nothing but you doing jobs and driving around but it turns out this game has MUCH MORE to offer like finding artifacts for the museum, Finding parts to unlock a vehicle, Solve puzzles, collect presents for cash and clothes, treasure hunting and much more!

Character controls relatively nicely, you use mouse buttons or triggers on controller for each arm to grab things or hold unto things like cars. Multiplayer however has some movement delay which i hope is gonna be fixed.

Physics are surprisingly stable although there are sometimes moments where the prop/object would get stuck. One example being that the seashell artifact found in jungle could get stuck in a jeep in between the seats. Sometimes when crashing into something the props inside the van would just suddenly disappear, but i'm sure those are things that could be fixed as the game develops because so far the physics are relatively good, especially for multiplayer!

Speaking of multiplayer i wish there was some sort of text chat. I can understand why there isn't text chat as the game is played by kids but i wish that at least the friends only servers could have an option to chat as i have a deaf friend and the only way to communicate with him is via text so i have to resort to using Steam's chat instead. The game offers an emote wheel for some kind of communication but i wish it had more options like "Thanks", "Sorry" and yes and no option and perhaps an ability to sit down.

Speaking of Deaf people, initially when i wrote this review i talked about how the metal detector didn't had visual clarity but in update 0.7.6 they added visual clarity to the metal detector! But there still is a problem and it's with the quest to get the UFO Signals from telescopes as those require you to listen in to know how many times it beeped. A visual clarity like a "growing ring that fades at the end" effect around the UFO to show that it beeped would be good. Very happy that the devs addressed this issue!

The jobs in the game are fun to do and are sort of like a minigame. The one Job i have the most problems with is the Ice Cream Factory one and it mainly has to do with physics and colorblindness. The physics are sometimes difficult in this one as the things in the cone fall off easily. maybe a longer timer would be better for this one cos of how careful you have to be to make things inside the cone not fall off. Regarding the colorblindness thing, i have sometimes hard time seeing what color is of the sauce cos the color is too similar to each other for me. The fishing job is fun but i feel like the fishing spot shouldn't be too far away as it takes so long to get there, perhaps faster boats maybe? I also wish however there was a easier way to quit the job, like in the "pause" menu there could be a button to quit a job instead of having to walk to the wobbly or have to intentionally fail the job.

The game is filled with a bunch of props to play with and i really like how interactive everything is. I like that there are also some Wobblys driving a car to show the world is lively and populated. also a lot of the wobbly NPCs have something to say which is cool. The world itself is fun to explore as sometimes the game rewards you with presents for exploring certain areas of the game. Also i wish there was some way of storing props, or eating the food items.

The vehicles are also nice too. I wish however that the big helicopter had a button to close the door as transporting things with it can be a little challenging cos things can fall off from it. I like the camping van and how you can enter inside, same with the bus too. I wish the vehicle shop had more vehicles to offer like the hovercraft cos i like that one the most cos it can go on water at a good speed and can strafe.

Overall i really like this game and i can't wait to see more updates added to this. This is a really fun game that i can imagine fun playing with a younger brother. Hopefully this comes to more platforms than Steam and Xbox, perhaps even with crossplay.

-- STEAM DECK section of the review --
It works well on Steam Deck althought it can have performance hiccups when being around the city. Game ran at 60fps with TDP turned down to 10. Controller support works out of the box HOWEVER i wish there was an option to set sensitivity of the mouse and controller separately as i found myself often switching it up and down every time i switched devices. Either have 2 sliders for both mouse and controller stick or just don't make it sync via Cloud Saves.

Posted: April 26, 2023
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
For it's single player I can recommend the game, as for the multiplayer I simply cannot in it's current state. I bought this game to play with my fiance but it completely unplayable no matter who the host is. Our internet is good and we live under the same roof so we should have no issues as we play other more demanding games with no issues that run under P2P (peer to peer) connections, after doing research on Reddit and Wobbly Life's Discord I found the problem lies in how the developers handle lag (which is adding a internal delay to your input in multiplayer to prevent stutters) but all this does is create massive delays in your input i'm talking +5 seconds and if it gets really out of hand you can see yourself stuck floating somewhere while the host sees you running off into the middle of nowhere and then you finally catchup after two minutes. This type of delay is unplayable because most of the "jobs" in Wobbly Life require you to use your reflexes and you physically cannot do that with an input delay.

I really hate having to give a game like this a negative review, I can see it's potential and I can see it's charm but as it stands this is a as I've read numerous discussions of people falling into the same problem as myself and the developers have acknowledged this issue but it seems they refuse to look further or for a solution (I'm certain a dedicated server would fix this but they don't support that currently)

Posted: July 11, 2022
Product received for free

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
*DE unten

Quasi my Lego island 3 of dreams ^^

It looked like a game from my childhood, which I had searched up and down on my ME computer back then. I also played the second part very much and enjoyed it. We're talking about Lego Island. I've been waiting for a third part for almost 20 years, but it hasn't come until today... And this game not only looks like Lego Island, but theoretically it is. Wobbly Life acts like a spiritual successor. I don't know if this is coincidence or intentional, but it doesn't matter either. All that is missing is building your own vehicles. But otherwise nothing is really missing, because even the pizza job is included.

There is so much to discover in this game. Even if the game world is not one of the largest maps in video game history, there is more to see and experience than in a world from e.g. Ubisoft or other major game developers. There is something interesting to explore around every corner. In the city it's the shops and houses, in the jungle there are mysterious caves. Each exploration is rewarded with gifts and unlocks new clothes or pets or companions.

The movement and appearance of the characters are reminiscent of Human Fall Flat, but the controls aren't nearly as complex. The three of us were looking for it yesterday for almost 8 hours in one go... and really had a lot of fun. And even though the game has a child-like look, adults can also enjoy this game. Especially if you are one of the Lego Island fans. There is a lot of love in this game, and you can feel it as a player from the very first moment. This game perfectly shows how Indian titles can be better than the Triple A productions that are all about MONEY.

Wishes for the future:
- a German translation
- even more exciting places to explore
- Revision of the somewhat spongy controls
- Being able to rename pets afterwards (at any time).
- Being able to design and build your own vehicles
- Being able to set up your own home independently
- Be able to sell fish more easily and quickly

PS: Many thanks to BigWaross, he gave me the game.


Es sah aus wie ein Spiel aus meiner Kindheit, welches ich damals auf meinem ME Rechner rauf und runter gesuchtet hatte. Auch den zweiten Teil habe ich sehr viel und gerne gespielt. Die rede ist von Lego Insel. Ich warte seid fast 20 Jahren auf einen dritten Teil, der aber bis heute nicht gekommen ist...Und dieses Spiel, sieht nicht nur aus wie Lego Insel, sondern ist es theoretisch auch. Wobbly Life wirkt wie ein geistiger Nachfolger. Ob dies Zufall ist oder beabsichtigtet weiß ich nicht, aber das spielt auch keine Rolle. Alles was fehlt ist das Bauen von eigenen Fahrzeugen. Aber ansonsten fehlt eigentlich nichts, denn selbst der Pizza-Job ist drin.

In diesem Spiel gibt es total viel zu entdecken. Auch wenn die Spielwelt nicht zu grössten Maps der Videospielgeschichte gehört, gibt es mehr zu sehen und zu erleben als in einer Welt von z.B Ubisoft oder anderen großen Spielentwicklern. An jeder Ecke gibt es etwas interessanten zum erkunden. In der Stadt sind es die Geschäfte und Wohnhäuser, im Dschungel geheimnisvolle Hölen. Jede Erkunden wird belohnt mit Geschenken und Freischaltungen neuer Kleidung oder Haustiere bzw. Begleitern.

Die Bewegung und das äußerliche der Figuren erinnern an Human Fall Flat, nur ist die Steuerung ist bei weitem nicht so komplex. Wir haben es gestern fast 8h an einem Stück zu dritt gesuchtet...und hatten wirklich viel Spaß. Und auch wenn das Spiel einen Kindlichen Look hat, können auch Erwachsene sich an diesem Spiel erfreuen. Erst recht wenn du einer der Lego Insel Fans bist. In diesem Spiel steckt sehr viel Liebe drin, und das Spürt man als Spieler vom ersten Moment an. Dieses Spiel zeigt perfekt, wieso Indi Titel besser sein können als die Tripple A Produktionen, bei denen es nur ums GELD geht.

Wünsche für die Zukunft:
- eine deutsche Übersetzung
- noch mehr spannende Orte zum erkunden
- Überarbeitung der etwas schwammigen Steuerung
- Pets nachträglich ( zu jederzeit ) umbenennen zu können
- Eigene Fahrzeuge entwerfen und bauen zu können
- Eigenheime selbstständig einrichten zu können
- Fische leichter und schneller verkaufen zu können

PS: Vielen Dank an BigWaross, er hat mir das Spiel geschenkt.

Möchtest du mehr Meinungen von mir lesen? Dann folge meinem Kurator!


Du kannst auch bei meiner Partnergruppe vorbeischauen. Dort gibt zu ein paar Hundert Reviews, auch von anderen.

Posted: September 6
An absolutely amazing party game providing hours of fun for anyone, with some toxicity (propelled by the game itself) and basically zero offline support.

The good

I think Party Animals is an immensely fun game, I really enjoy playing it, especially with friends in custom games. Custom games have support for bots (with three difficulty levels), making games with even 2-3 human players fun and chaotic. There's a lot of variety through maps and the newly introduced Smash and Mario Kart-esque Nemo Kart game modes. The game supports local split-screen play, albeit it's a bit limited, see below. While there are micro-transactions, they are cosmetic-only, and the game allows you to earn some of its premium currency, too, through level ups and achievements, which I think is a very nice addition - I have been able to buy skins that cost premium currency only by playing the game.

There is also a "friend pass", which lets anyone download the game for free, and play with you when you invite them, basically giving you two copies of the game for the price of one. They can do the tutorial on their own and then join a game you invite them to, and even progress.


As for the negatives, which will be much longer, but not because I think the game is bad. I'm hoping that my review will not only help those looking at buying this game, but also the developers.

1. , for which it has been criticized heavily. My biggest gripe with it is that even a supposedly local game in custom match mode, where I'm the only player, is still running through the internet: if my connection is shaky, my character will lag. We played with friends in split-screen through Wi-Fi in a custom game with bots, and it was unplayable. This can be a serious gripe for those looking for offline fun: you cannot play this game without a stable internet connection, not even custom games, where you cannot complete weekly quests (though you earn XP). I wish the developers leaned a bit more into making at least custom games offline-accessible, even if there was no progression while the game is offline. Also, you create a separate profile (account) in the game, which is a bit weird. Deep Rock Galactic did this much better with all data being in your save files (and thus tied to your Steam account), though that game has less micro-transactions and is also not competitive in any way.

2. . It works, but not in every game mode, and it's a bit basic. For example, the months-old Smash and Nemo Kart game modes (at the time of writing) still cannot be played in split-screen. The game simply tells you that you cannot do that with local players. Second, since most maps are relatively small, it would make sense to do some dynamic split screen or even play on one big screen, but you are limited to always being split. This is a bit disadvantageous, as the screen is split horizontally in the middle (the two screens are next to each other), severely limiting horizontal view, which is essential to get a grasp of the (usually quite chaotic) situation around you (you don't look much up and down, but you do have to look left and right a lot). This is only an issue with 2 players, as with 3 or 4, you have your regular screen aspect ratio for your view. Playing with friends on a large screen works, though.

3. . I am happy that voice chat can be turned off as-is (I did so when first booting up the game), which from today, requires a verified phone number to use anyway. I wish we could disable text chat, too, or at least limit it to team only. While the occasional emote spamming and "ez" text chats aren't too common (luckily I encounter these in about less than 1 of 5 matches), I think the developers could greatly reduce the remaining toxicity by removing quests that require you to win games - especially since these quests are usually the ones that give you "regular" currency, and this is the only way to earn it besides progression. The other quests ("play X games as an animal that can dive" and such) are really creative, and if only these were left in, I'm sure it would ease the tension. It's a bit easy to get hooked and focus on just winning the game, and I think it's partly due to the quests that are tied to victory.

4. . The game is frequently updated, but patch logs are often not supplied with the updates. We've had one when the Nemo Kart game mode was introduced, for example, but for smaller changes, we usually don't get any. I've just found out that the previously Last Stand (4 teams of 2 players) "Ice breaker" map was changed to play out with 2 teams of 4 players, but I've never seen a patch log mentioning this.


Buy this game if you're into party games and have at least one friend. Solo, and become toxic in quick matches. Great game, lots of cute animals (skins), fun, sometimes quirky physics-based mechanics and smooth gameplay.

Posted: September 25, 2023
You must be curious why this game has so many negative reviews in Chinese.
For English speakers:
If you know what this game has done in China, you will know why Chinese players give so many negative reviews to a game produced by a Chinese studio.
They had released a demo three years ago, when the epidemic was in lockdown and everyone was at home with nothing to do. If they had released the game then, it would have been a monumental achievement in the history of gaming, probably on par with 2016's Overwatch. But they didn't, insisting that the game needed more processing, which took almost four years. The pandemic is over, and naturally people don’t have time to play party games.
This is actually not the point. I just want to complain a bit as a player who has waited for so long.
The real point begins here.
Before the game was finally released, the producers made it clear in interviews that their nitpicks resulted in the game being too expensive to run, and they were not shy about making it clear that they were prepared to make players pay for the company's operational missteps. However, there doesn’t seem to be much problem with the price in Europe or the United States?
We all know that games on Steam are priced differently in different countries, which usually depends on economic conditions and exchange rates. The same type of party games are often priced as much in China as in the United States, while Party Animals are almost the price as in the United States. To refer back to the previous paragraph,
even though this is a Chinese studio. Their attitude towards Chinese players is ignorance and arrogance.
After almost four years of work, what's the difference between a game and a demo? I don't know how many of you have played that demo, but the answer is, except for some paid skins and raffle boxes.
In addition, in China, the in-game currency was officially designated as "ni mo bi". If translated into English, it would be, " ", just read it out.
Yes, this has nothing to do with any non-Chinese people. I just want to show that our anger is not unfounded.
How ironic! But if you still can’t understand the reason for so many bad reviews based on Chinese, then I can only wish you good luck.

I've waited. A good long while for this game to come out. Played the beta in 2020. Immediately fell in love with the style and a new game to the party brawlers. Waited patiently for 3 more years. Let me explain.
What I liked
The gameplay. Its fun! It's a TON of fun. Its Gang Beasts meets Fall Guys. Its fun and easy to get into. Theres a lot of powerful items and moves, but the randomness in the physics and the large amount of players. Means theres still a pretty low skill ceiling and approachable to everyone.

The style! Its so cute. Its a very pretty game and the fluffy animals beating the absolute piss out of each others is a fun spectacle.

The maps! While I havent played much of the new maps. The maps that were in the beta. Were fun, unique, had a neat gimmick to them. Theyre well designed and fun to fight in.

Posted: October 7, 2023
My negative review doesn't fully display the picture, I'd love to be able to give this game a positive review to but don't think I can yet.
If you don't want to read the whole pros-cons list / essay, skip to the summary at the bottom.

Pros:
- Easy to find a game, never had to wait more than 2 minutes at any time.

- Super fun with friends, it's a better, bigger version of gang beasts.

- Good variety of maps. modes & weapons to make things interesting.

- Characters are cute and charming, the IP colabs are really well done.

- Lots of replay-ability, this has become my groups "go-to" game for the past week.

- Matches are quick and easy to drop in & out.

- Overall great party game.

- No OCE/Aus or South America server, this makes the game very difficult to play with a ping of 160+ at least. If you're in this region you'll often find yourself starting match knocked out and all the other cons that come with playing on 180 ping.

- If you have a party of 3 we've found that it likes to consistently pair the same people up no matter who the party leader is or join order, it often leaves that third person the odd one out.

- Without frequent updates adding new maps, modes & weapons this game will probably not have much longevity, after 19 hours the magic is slowly starting to wear off.

- don't really need to explain much more on this but after spending $30 on the game finding out skins you want are locked behind the combo of a store & mystery crates (in the form of eggs), leaves a little bit of a sour taste in your mouth, feels a lot like it's going to be made free-to-play at some stage.

- Overall toxicity, there's little censorship in the game, people can name themselves a variety of slurs without problem, but words like & are censored?

- No offline play, huge issue for a lot of people and the way they addressed it seemed quite disingenuous.


The game has the building blocks to set it up to be amazing, it unfortunately falls short at the moment but it's nothing it can't fix.
The introduction of new servers, offline play, map & modes and removal of monetisation are all things that could be added or fixed in future updates.

you're someone who's on the fence about buying the game or your friends are trying to gaslight you into getting it even though you think you won't enjoy it, I'd say your best bet would be to wait a month or so and keep an eye on the updates & see if the reviews take an upturn.

you have the disposable income, friends live somewhere there's a server & this won't stop you from buying another game this month, go for it. It's a super fun game best enjoyed with other people not focusing on being competitive I guarantee you'll have a good time.

Posted: March 26
Party Animals is one of my most played games in my library and I continue to enjoy it on every revisit. But the more I play it, the more I see that it's difficult to recommend to newcomers. On the surface you can imagine that it's a casual party game with cute animals punching each other; however, this is deeply contrasted by the extremely competitive nature of the in-game community. Players who have previous experience with similar physics-based games, such as Gang Beasts or Human Fall Flat, should have a knack for Party Animals and it'd be an easy recommendation. But players with no prior experience should carefully consider if this game is right for them. The following sections of this review will elaborate on my complicated love and hate story with Party Animals.




The fighting controls are more complex than Gang Beasts' and random weapons spawn on the arena to spice up each round. There are several modes to play such as Last Stand (2v2v2v2 or 4v4), Team Score (4v4), and Cabin (for casual off-brand Uno games). The combat is very rewarding once you get a proper handle on it. Exp earned unlocks unique rewards up to level 100, and the achievements also unlock costumes and currency. Players who invest enough time into Party Animals can get around the gacha and game currency limits by gaining experience past level 100 to earn daily mystery boxes containing cookies, Nemo bucks, or lottery coins. I never had a hard time buying the costumes I like in the game's shop because I've earned and saved plenty of currency.

The majority of my hours was spent in solo play but I had more fun whenever I was in a party with friends. Team work is at the heart of each game mode and it's very fun to embrace it with like-minded players. My favorite map of all time is Fluffy Redemption. The respawns are unlimited and there's room for mistakes. I like to switch my roles whenever needed, I could be placing coals into the firebox for a few minutes, attack the opposite team's train to slow them down, and then go back to my train to defend it.

I love the animal and environment physics! Animals can be tossed out of the arena with the right momentum and movement. Each Last Stand map has a hazard that gets deadlier as time passes. Castleween is notable for its random environment destruction. I also enjoy how it's possible to knock out animals with random stuff such as lamps, fishes, and hats. There's no shortage of crazy stuff that can happen in Party Animals. The replayability is practically infinite.




The initial two hours played on Party Animals may not be enough time to determine if the game is right for some players. In my case, I had a blast during my first 100 hours even while I was solo queuing for matches. But I'm sure newcomers will be frustrated once they encounter the tryhards and toxics in the community.

The matchmaking in Party Animals is split into 2 categories: Quick Match and Custom Games. Custom Games offers limited exp gained daily, and Quick Match allows you to level up indefinitely to level 100 + 3 daily mystery boxes. Custom Games are filled with AI bots and it's not obvious which ones have human players. Quick Match is a very simplified system with no variety of options. You can't select Last Stand or Team Score as the mode you'd prefer to join, and you can't opt to join a queue filled with other solo queue'd players. Instead, Quick Match will join together solo queue'd players with coordinated players in a party, and they'll have to vote on a Last Stand or Team Score map. This creates an environment that throws newcomers into a trial by fire. I've read other players' reviews on Party Animals and I can definitely see where they're coming from: the game turns into a waiting simulator after being eliminated quickly in Last Stand. I find that Team Score modes are more casual than Last Stand, and it'd be a great boon for newcomers if there was a "Quick Match - Team Score" option.

Quick Match is also the only practical way to earn rewards + exp. Winning will award a lot of exp towards a level up, and losing will award very minimal exp regardless of how well you've played. And many of the achievements require amazing feats in Quick Match. Here's an example: "666 - In Buzz Ball, single-handedly accumulate all points for your team and win (Quick Match)." These tryhard achievements contrast the intended spirit of a casual party game. All in all, players are encouraged to play competitively to extremes if they want to earn currency or unique costumes. It's no surprise that there're so many tryhards and toxics, not to the mention the AFK players who farm exp.










There's a lot to love about Party Animals, but there's also a lot to hate about it. I keep returning to Party Animals because I love physics-based games and platformers. I think the good outweighs the bad, despite having many complaints. Newcomers, on the other hand, should beware of the Quick Matchmaking and the community's git gud attitude. Party Animals' learning curve is pretty high but will reward those who are willing to overcome it. My final rating for the game: 9/10. My rating for the in-game community: 6/10.

Posted: September 24, 2023
A great party game for people who don't throw great parties.


Things to help improve your experience:

1. Accept that you are not in control of your character, the magic 8-ball Party Animals uses as a physics engine is.
1.1. You may go flying across the arena at a moment's notice. Why? Don't ask, just accept it.
1.2. You are able to climb back into most arenas using the jump and hold buttons together, but that's only the case until the game decides you're not.

2. Turn the the music volume aaaaaaalllll the way down. Congratulations, the Ice Breaker stage is now bearable.

Inviting friends to your party is as easy as a digesting a chicken steak tartare. Recreate Games has decided to make Steam's social system redundant by creating their own. You'll have to set up your profile, collect your account ID and then pass them to your friends rather than just inviting them directly through Steam.

There is no offline mode despite the game advertising one. As it turns out, this is a huge deal for some people. Keep this in mind if you're looking to buy Party Animals.

Microphone chat is ON by default.

The game is intended to be played using a controller.

No one gets to use Moonmoon but me. It's mine. Pick something else.

Recreate has decided to punish people who choose to leave the game by giving them a Quick Match ban (as if this game is a serious esport), but don't do anything about people who will stay AFK in a match for prolonged periods of time. It takes a really long time for you to get kicked for being idle and replaced with an AI. If you get unlucky enough to be matched with an AFK teammate, will be the one punished if you leave, your teammate might be able to stay idle for long enough to collect the experience at the end of a match. Thanks Recreate, very cool.


Ultimately, there is a lot to enjoy here if you have the patience to put up with all of the bugs in the game's physics. Your character will never quite do what you're telling it to do and this will get you eliminated more often than not, which can be frustrating if you're particularly competitive.
The sound design is nice, the soundtrack absolutely is not.
The graphics are cute and highly stylised, but can already seem quite dated if you notice the weird pixel edges around fur and some objects. Other than that the graphics look great.

Posted: September 20, 2023
No offline mode.

I am seriously tired of games advertised as having singleplayer and local coop not being playable offline because they need to sell their microtransactions. I was excited for this game but now I couldn't care less.

Literally false advertising:

"Fight your friends as puppies, kittens and other fuzzy creatures in PARTY ANIMALS! Paw it out with your friends both online and **offline**. Interact with the world under our realistic physics engine. Did I mention PUPPIES?"

Edit:

The devs responded by pointing out that the game was only playable online during closed testing. I have participated in many closed and open alpha and beta tests and can say this is standard in the industry for a game that hasn't released. Studios typically make playtest builds require internet connection so that they can control when players can access a free copy of the game, stress test servers, collect playtesting data, and avoid the game being accessible early through piracy which is completely reasonable for an unreleased game that noone has bought. With that, an online requirement for an early play test of a game in no way says that the game wouldn't be playable offline on release. As an example COD typically requires you to be online when playing the beta tests however every COD on console has offline play. I would have been shocked if any decent size game was playable offline during playtesting.

But the devs expected me to ignore the product description that specifically said the game was playable offline and judge whether or not the game was playable offline on a closed play test I had access to? You guys said the game was playable offline in the product description and have the audacity to say "The game did not feature an offline mode in the recent three rounds of playtesting either."

This lazy attempt at blaming players for trusting their false advertising is ridiculous and "nonsensical."

Posted: September 25
Long story short? 🤔
The game is fun and justifies its price (I’ve paid ~$6.5) — it has a really slick and nice UI, UX is decent enough, the gameplay is tons of fun and some modes/maps are hilarious 😂

There’s quite a variety of modes:
• Mario Kart alike gamemode
• Fighting maps
• Team based maps where you need to do various objectives (the most diversed mode)
• Smash Bros-esque 6 rounds fighting mode with roguelite (kinda) element!
• Also there’s a hub map (available only in Custom Modes) with 2 board games — one is, basically, UNO, but another one I didn’t try (needs more than 2 players).
• And so on…

My main gripe with the game is that Party Animals desperately needs more content — and I’m not talking about cosmetics, but maps and modes.

Currently, there’s quite little variety!

While the game is fun for the first time which you can prolong by playing a few maps per one time, but you will consume all the content pretty fast. Actually very fast. The game will last way longer if you have friends/family/partner, but it still won’t last long. Maybe a few weekends, tops.

The only solution I see is for the devs to drop one map/mode per month, at least.
Okay, maybe per two months, which is hilariously bad, but still something.

The game is paid but there’s such a huge amount of paid content, it’s baffling.

Like so many paid currencies!

Remember that hub map I’ve talked about? You can buy placeable stuff like swings and fireworks for ONE OF PAID CURRENCIES — and these placeables are CONSUMABLES, so they are not infinite. You can, somehow, earn this paid currency, but it’s very-very slow.

There’s an in-game currency (which you can still exchange to via main paid currency), but you cannot buy much stuff for it. There are even loot boxes. I’m okay-ish with them, however you get very little currency for said loot boxes — though you can pay real money to get them, of course.

Anyway, I wish the devs all the best, I really hope they will add more content reasonably fast.

If they implement some sort of map/mode builder, then it’ll be a banger for sure! 🔥

Well, that’s about it.

Message to the devs ✉️

“You are cooking a really good game, you already making something extremely fun and diverse — please continue making good stuff and do not abandon the game, neither flood it with microtransactions. Also, thanks a lot for the Friend’s Pass system — it’s amazing! We can invite one player for free and play with them in (almost?) all modes!”

P.S:

The game doesn’t have an offline mode (or so it seems). Please keep it in mind. I didn’t test local co-op, but, as far as I understand, it works. However, again, you need to have internet connection. I do not know any limitations of local co-op, but I do know that there’s split screen (not every map/mode has it!) and you can connect multiple controllers.

Hopefully someone will make a handler for this game for NucleusCOOP 💯

Posted: September 28, 2023
Ok, so lets clear some things up.

This game has mixed reviews, which this game definitely does not deserve.

Lots of people are giving this game negative reviews because of the fact that the game does not have an 'offline' singe-player mode, or because of the fact that the game has micro-transactions.

Let's start with the offline single-player mode.

To clear things up; the game DOES support couch split-screen co-op. The only thing it doesn't support is offline play, as you need an online connection to be able to play the game at all. I do understand people being upset about this, as the devs could have been more clear about this, and shouldn't have used the word 'offline' in the game description (which they removed as of now).

Micro-transactions

In no way is this game pay-to-win. All the micro-transactions in this game are cosmetic, and don't give you an advantage in any way. Matter of fact, both types of currency's are obtainable through just playing the game, and completing weekly/daily challenges! Which means that if you want to spend money to get your characters to look different, go ahead! But it's also obtainable by just playing the game and saving up the currency you get!


Even though i haven't played a lot yet, I can definitely say that I love this game. If you liked Gang Beasts, you're gonna love this one. The gameplay is almost identical, though it feels a little less clunky, and more controllable. Also the fact that this game adds quite some weapons to use, quite a lot of maps on release, and several game-modes to play, makes it so the game doesn't get old quick (which I did have with Gang Beasts). If the devs continue to update the game with more maps, game-modes, weapons and characters (which they are actively doing right now), this game is going to be fun, and fresh for a long time!

If you liked Gang Beasts, you're definitely gonna love this one. Don't let the reviews fool you, the game is a blast! Especially with friends.
