💀 ɪғ ʏᴏᴜ ɴᴇᴇᴅ ᴄᴏʀʀᴏʙᴏʀᴀᴛɪᴏɴ ᴏɴ ᴍʏ ʀᴇᴠɪᴇᴡ, ᴊᴜsᴛ ʀᴇᴀᴅ ᴛʜᴇ ᴄᴏᴍᴍᴇɴᴛs ᴜɴᴅᴇʀɴᴇᴀᴛʜ ᴛʜɪs ᴏʀ ᴛʜᴇ ᴏɴᴇs ᴏɴ ᴍʏ ᴘʀᴏғɪʟᴇ 💀

I really really want to recommend this game, but the state it is in at this very moment I cannot.

The concept is amazing, and I adore all the cute animals along with the cosmetics that are out, and the collabs they've done. Visually it is a really good, a cute cartoon-y game where you get to be a stuffed animal.

Unfortunately, the community is already incredibly toxic and the game hasn't even been out more than two weeks. I am a girl and I feel like I am in a COD lobby by the amount of hate I get when speaking. It is very common to get cussed out in games and called slurs because you knocked somebody out or are just playing that game the way it is meant to be played, OR because you sound like a girl.

You would think with the game being about really cute stuffed animals the community would be nice and welcoming, but it's not. You can argue that I should just mute the voice chat or just ignore it, but the game was made with voice chat and I enjoy interacting with the wholesome section of this community, the ones that are just trying to have fun and don't threaten to un-alive you for knocking them out.

And the game play, I could write an entire review just about this. You can pick up a weapon, and it is pretty much game over for everyone else without a weapon unless the weapon holder is miraculously knocked out, or they run out of stamina. If you get nun-chucks or a shovel then it is almost impossible to get close enough to that person to knock them out, especially on maps like the alligator river or airplane, because those are not at all forgiving and one misjudged jump is the end. I think weapons should have some type of cool down or some type of durability at least. There should be no reason a single cat with a pair of nun-chucks can knock out eight people in a row and win the game simply because they were the first person to pick up a weapon. It is ridiculous.

Speaking of being knocked out, what is the point in playing when people can just stand over you and continuously knock you out? There have been many times where somebody is upset and targets me or another person and tries to keep them knocked out for the entirety of that game, and it is incredibly frustrating to stand up only to be drop kicked into the shadow realm once again.

This is just a quality of life request really, but they should add something in the game where you can see your own stuffed animal better. This would help visually impaired individuals, because sometimes you can lose your own character in the chaos of everyone. Maybe a little glowing outline or something else to better indicate where you are in the group.

Overall, I like the concept of this game. It is cute and fun with friends, but it certainly can be improved. If you are looking to buy it I would wait a little while to see if there are any updates.



They reverted back to the 2v2 modes thankfully

Just updating this for the Steam Awards, (for the better with friends catergory) but I think that the changes the devs are implementing soon will definitely help the game.

Posted: August 15
Having played the game practically since its release, I think I have a good overview of its evolution so far and, unfortunately, since its launch. Too little has gone in the right direction...

Improving on the gang beast concept, it had everything to please graphically. There are even a plethora of good arguments to recommend this game to you, but...

At launch, the game was sold as an 8-player brawler featuring some twenty different maps:
- 9 Last Stand maps (fighting in teams of 2 or 4)
- 9 Team Score maps (4vs4 with objectives to reach)
- 2 Arcade maps (can only be played by creating a private lobby or joining one).

In the first few months, the Chinese studio got the job done. Just over a month after the game's release, on Halloween, the developers were already adding relative content. But at the same time, problems were already beginning to emerge as the Chinese studio partnered with Chinese streaming platforms (Bilibili and Douyin to start with) and granted them exclusive skins (for Halloween, for example) that could only be obtained by Chinese users, thus penalizing other players. This led to a number of problems, as these skins, obtained by code, could (to cut a long story short) be used twice. As a result, Chinese players, having used the code once for themselves, would try to exchange it with players from Europe, North America, South America... for a code that the studio had set up with Discord (also usable twice) and which penalized Chinese players. In this code exchange, there were numerous scams on both sides, and in the end, it created a very bad climate between the gaming communities.

Shortly afterwards, the studio announced its roadmap, explaining that there would be a major update every 3 months, including a new map and new skins, which augured well for the future.

The problem was that their first major update was delayed by a month. To fill the gap, they added a new map and introduced the “Friend Pass”, allowing players to invite their friends to play the game with them for free. A fine initiative, to be sure.

Unfortunately, the worrying comments made by the studio were already summed up in this sentence: “We've noticed that many players are looking for a place to chat with others, rather than just fight” (patch note dated 16/12/2023). I don't know which players they're talking about, but nobody expected the studio to focus their money and energy on creating a place within the game where players could chat instead of fighting... Not only because this place already exists (the arcade maps), but also because if players have paid for a fighting game, it's because they want content related to what they've paid for!

At the end of January, these concerns prove to be well-founded. Their first update for the brawler they'd sold to players introduced a UNO game renamed PAWS in one of the arcade maps, as well as a jukebox... THAT'S IT! To counterbalance the anger of the players, less than 10 days later they released a new map, which didn't convince anyone because it was too similar in principle to another existing map.

The 2nd update doesn't do much better, as it also arrives a month late, and once again takes players by surprise. It introduces a new game mode with 2 missions playable solo or in pairs against bots. After 10 minutes of discovery to complete them (and I'm still being kind), you start to wonder if you haven't been ripped off, as the devs are moving further and further away from the fighting game they originally sold us.

Well, I'm tempering that a little, because there's one good thing in this update, and that's the appearance of another game mode, “SMASH”, which fits into the “combat” category. It's well thought-out, it's fun and it deserves to be said.

The 3rd update arrived on schedule! Are we going back to basics? No, of course not. This time, Recreate set out to offer players a Mario Kart version of Party Animals. It's certainly well done, and there's much more fun to be had in the one and only race than in the 2 challenge missions of the previous update, but when are you going to keep your promises? Where's the roadmap?

But all this is nothing compared to what's to come. The ultimate betrayal that buries the game for good. In the game, there are several ways to knock out your opponents:
- Light punching is the use of small punches (LP).
- Heavy punch: run and punch (HP)
- Dropkick: jump and kick (DK)
- Headbutt is a headbutt (HB)

There are two other techniques which are not explained in the game's tutorial and which have been found by players through experimentation:
- The superman punch is a combination of three keys and allows the player to levitate briefly after his punch.
- The fling is an improvement on the superman punch, combining 4 keys and allowing the player to project himself in the direction of his choice, knocking out anyone in his path. On the other hand, the fling is not without risk, as it can backfire if misdirected or controlled.

These techniques, and the fling in particular, have rapidly become extremely popular among players, because although they are extremely satisfying to perform, mastering them requires training and demonstrates a skill that any player wishing to improve must master.

Can you see it coming? At Recreate, they're doing everything they can to kill the fun. Since the release of their game, they've only done what they wanted to do, and whether we like it or not, that's the way it is. Our only treasure was the fling, but they took it away from us.

Faced with the tidal wave of anger, they backed down, but in the worst possible way. The fling now consumes a phenomenal amount of stamina and can no longer be played...

Worse still, the fling's nerf has created a domino effect on all gameplay, and the game's dynamics have been completely ruined:
- HP has become punishing for the user, as it consumes far more stamina and hits the opponent even less than before.
- The LP, which already consumed no stamina, has become much better, as it hits far more than the HP.
- DK has become exceptional

Before the nerf, the game required skill. It wasn't simply a matter of doing DK over and over again. In your desire to make the game more user-friendly for new players, you've not hesitated to scuttle the rules of the game. What you're doing is not the right solution. All you're doing is making the game less attractive. You change the rules without prior communication, without even telling the players what has changed. You're gradually destroying the trust and esteem the players had in you.

At the time of writing, there are barely 3,000 daily players on the game. This pales in comparison with the 60,000 of the early days. This lack of players has prompted Recreate to find “solutions”. Already present from the start of the game, bots have become the most important player community. If you thought you were playing with a player called SnoopDogg or PapaSmurf, you're just playing with a bot. Their intelligence is disastrous, and you'll soon realize it. Bots are of no use to the game. Worse still, there's a good chance they'll get in your way or accidentally kill you.

It seems vital to go back to an earlier version of the gameplay mechanics and the very foundations of the game. Until this is done, this game deserves this comment.

Posted: June 29
Party Animals: A Review Where Fur Flies and Friendships Fray

Forget the picket fences and cozy crafting of other survival games. Party Animals throws you headfirst into a chaotic world where the cutest creatures become the most deranged brawlers. This isn't your grandma's tea party – it's a hilarious physics-based battle royale where the only thing softer than the characters are their landings.

Get into chaotic brawls! 
A Screenshot of Party Animals
By: Nirhildija



Party Animals' charm lies in its utter pandemonium. The wobbly physics turns every punch, flail, and flying body into a side-splitting spectacle. Sending your best friend plummeting off a cliff or into a spinning fan never gets old – just make sure you're not next!




Don't let the cuddly exteriors fool you. Party Animals offers a surprising amount of depth. Choose your favorite fighter from a quirky cast, each with its particular style and humor! Multiple game modes keep things fresh, from free-for-alls to objective-based battles where teamwork (or lack thereof) is key. Play soccer games, survive black holes, or be the last animal standing in a submerging submarine!




While the core gameplay is a blast, there are a few things to consider. The physics-based controls take some getting used to, and mastering throws and dodges requires practice. Half the battle in Party Animals is fighting the controller! (and button smashing to get up~). The current map selection, while creative, could be expanded for long-term play. Local multiplayer feels less polished compared to the smooth online experience.



Party Animals is a fantastic party game for anyone looking to unleash their inner animal (and unleash some hilarious chaos) with friends. The wacky physics, multiple modes, and adorable cast create an unforgettable experience. While the learning curve exists and the maps could be more plentiful, Party Animals is a must-have for your next game night. Just remember – friendships may be tested, but your sides will be split with laughter!


If you enjoy and find the review helpful, please follow my curator!

Posted: September 24, 2023
Product received for free

A friend bought this for me because we both enjoyed Gang Beasts and he figured we'd both enjoy this one, too. He wasn't wrong.

The core concept and gameplay loop are both fun, and we find that not taking the game seriously (that is, just goofing around and enjoying the silly spectacle of animals beating each other up with frying pans, baseball bats, nunchucks, and more) is leagues more enjoyable than when you try really hard. That kind of play saps all the fun out of the experience, and unfortunately you do get some players who do exactly that.

This game is also more content-rich than Gang Beasts (more game modes; each map has a specific mode and gimmick(s) attached to it) which is an added plus, on top of the animals being generally adorable (or silly, in some cases, like Barbie the gorilla, or Underbite the dinosaur(?)).

As much as I do like playing the game, I must admit I do not condone some of the developer's choices, such as the addition of microtransactions (albeit just for cosmetics; several base animals are unlocked by default, but many skins and outfits are locked behind the in-game shop--which may cost "cookies" (standard currency) or "Nemo bucks" (premium currency) or sometimes even actual US dollars--whose contents change daily for common/uncommon skins and weekly for the rarer stuff; other cosmetics can be acquired through level-up progression or unlocking certain achievements) or the total lack of an offline mode; the latter point means that the game can potentially become totally unplayable for some or all players globally, so keep that in mind.

Overall, it's not bad. I would've done some things differently had I been at the helm of the project, but that's just me. If you liked Gang Beasts (or anything similar), you'll probably enjoy this, too.

Posted: January 9
Gamemodes:
Party Animals offers a variety of game modes that are both fun and engaging. From Beat-Up Bridge to Beast Soccer, each mode is unique and provides a different experience. The game also has a Custom Game mode that allows you to create your own game rules and play with your friends.

Skins:
The game has a wide range of skins that you can unlock by playing the game and completing achievements. The skins are cute and quirky, and they add a lot of personality to the game.

Achievements:
Party Animals has a total of 95 achievements that you can unlock by playing the game. Each achievement is assigned a reward, including various cosmetic items for the game’s cute characters. The achievements are well-designed and provide a great incentive to keep playing the game.

General Rating:
The game is a lot of fun to play, and it’s perfect for parties or just hanging out with friends. The game modes are engaging, the skins are cute and quirky, and the achievements provide a great incentive to keep playing. The only downside is that the game can get repetitive after a while, but that’s a minor issue compared to all the fun you’ll have playing it.

Posted: September 30, 2023
Let's be honest. I am from what someone would call "a region with restricted access". I.e. China. I am writing this review partly because of the grudge accumulated from the years of waiting, being mistreated and outright abused, and partly because of the necessity of clarifying why we, as a whole, have such a negative attitude towards Recreate, the company that made this Game. I am writing this in English so that all of you, the honest players, can take a peek at what happened behind the colourful screen.

## Can We Talk About the Game First?

Sure. Party Animals is, as you've guessed from the name, a party game. It follows the slapstick formula with cute, fluffy animals as the dressing. It is visually appealing and is an easy pick-up for players at all levels.

The control is intentionally awkward so it fits the "everyone can have fun" party game style. You don't have to worry about someone being too pro at the game that it would crush the competition. But this awkwardness takes some time to get used to. For starters, you can't really control where you are facing and the pick-and-grab mechanism will get in the way if you spam the grab button, trying to pick up the key item.

Aside from the brawl, there are a lot of minigames that spice up the tone. But what minigame you get to play depends on the roll of the dice (and the minds of other players). Each round, you get 3 randomly selected maps to vote for.

The biggest downside is the **lack of local multiplayer**. As a party game, it is a courageous decision not to have a local multiplayer mode. My guess is that all the maps are designed around the 8-player versus mode. Typical 4-player mode won't make the cut.

The price point is also a bit too high for a party game. Oh, it might not be the case for YOUR region. In addition to the microtransaction built-in, I honestly don't know what should I feel. I paid a premium for this Game, only to be hit by a gacha machine in the face.

I guess it's a good time to explain the grudge.

## Why the Negativity?

As you may have known, Recreate is a Chinese company. I am not hinting about all the conspiracies revolving around privacy issues and data breaching -- it's too bland even for an avid conspiracy theorist. I am talking about the aspect of community management.

Recreate, at least in the domestic market, did not perform well in community management. Back in late 2019, when everything was still in the good ol' order, Recreate had released a beta version of the Game. The Game was already well-polished. We were all hyped and expected its release.

However, this is where it all started to go downhill.

It starts with the delays. Well, I guess that's a norm for game development. They always delay. But a three-year delay is more than what we can manage. During the Pandemic, while we were staying indoors, longing for a game for distraction, Recreate had chosen to "perfect" their work. They wanted "a better hair rendition" for the animal avatars. Okay, it's their artistic decisions. I won't judge. But what we have here is something practically identical to the 2019 demo. I guess they have improved the hair rendering code so it can run on a lower-end machine. (What's funny is that this fine hair rendering looks quite strange on Xbox such that some are questioning why the animals look jagged. I think they have fixed this issue but, still!)

If it's only that simple, I don't think it deserves such a bad rating.

As I have stated from the start, it all comes down to the community management. Party Animals was officially announced to the domestic market as early as 2020. But for all these years, there is virtually no official announcement made. No devlogs. No progress indication. Nothing. However, they haven't missed any international game events -- there were ads being made.

I mean, really? You have the manhours to make those ads, but not posting a tweet about where the project is going? Seriously?

I guess ads also count, at least they can let us take a peek at what the game would be, followed by a date that's either too vague or will get delayed (again). They didn't even bother to add a Chinese subtitle. All the press materials come in English first.

Fine. I'll take that as a try of i18n. Recreate wants to ship the game overseas. They are an ambitious company. But it just nudges the domestic market in a wrong way.

And then, the utterly tone-deaf interviews landed. Producer Luo, I remember that you said you wanted to make a "perfect game". Is this what you've dreamed of? Maybe. It's glitch-free. It is perfect in the sense that it runs without a hiccup. But a game is consumed with paratexts. A game cannot be played in a vacuum, in an idealized plane. I don't want to be harsh towards the developers and artists working for Recreate, but Animal Party is a dumpster fire and you know it. Are your servers stressing out? Should we "buy the game but never play it"? Because "as soon as we started playing it, [you are] losing money"? I know it's meant as a joke. It's a joke that nobody laughed.

98 CNY. Is this the price you are asking for? For a party game? Sure, I can afford that. But you chose to not add local multiplayer. It means if I wanted to invite my friends to play this game, they would have to pay for a copy themselves! That's a red bank note a pop! Let's have a check on other party games. Almost all of them are below 50 CNY. For those who didn't see the problem: imagine that this game asks for $40 or more, will you be so tolerant to microtransactions? Will you still think that "fluffy animal cute"?

About the controversial naming, I'd left it aside. Again, those are jokes, whether intentional or not, that got nobody laughing. Well, maybe some laughed. Puns to vulgar terms always work as a filler. At least the name was addressed before the launch. I'll give it a pass.

I'd like to address some additional operations from Recreate in the domestic market. We do have a homegrown gaming community and it is as toxic and chaotic as yours. In the Party Animals board, there is not a single negative review of the game. You should really give the board moderator a raise. They are developing tenosynovitis just from swinging the ban hammer too much.

## Can Recreate Redeem Itself?

Now the Game is finally released for good. We laughed, we wept.

A game company, no matter the size, can always redeem itself. But not by doing the wrong thing one after another. None of the problems were unredeemable, but without proper treatment, they would accumulate and finally burst.

The game itself is of great quality (in terms of overall robustness). But the community disaster has already happened. Let's see if Recreate can come up with something better to turn this thumb upside-down.

Oh, by the way, if the game becomes F2P in a year (with boosted microtransactions), I would consider it a backstabbing move and this review will become settled.

Posted: February 23
Playing this since release, I have now surpassed 500 hours in this creative masterpiece, and am desperately attempting to take a break from it, I feel like it's a good milestone to take some time and talk about it.

I have no doubt I will spend thousands of hours here as the time goes. This game has been no contest the alltime best investment of my money on Steam, and that won't change simply because of how much fun I've had with it already. I laughed in the ways I didn't know I could laugh, and honestly - I really needed that. I never expected it to tick all my boxes, but it sure did.

This game is goofy, silly, random and super stylish. Everything, EVERYTHING is superb- gameplay mechanics, visual presentation and the kickass funk fusion of a soundtrack. Even the tiny references here and there to various creative works around the world.

Even if it doesn't seem to be your cup of tea, even if you are turned away by XYZ things about it - just play 10 or so games, and I guarantee you will have a good chuckle at some point.



Even though the game is very random at times (and that's its design intention, even though I may not agree with some parts of it), there's plenty room for being competitive and showing "skill", which I personally consider important. It's this mix of pure random and skill based factors that make it more fun for me, there's a certain beauty in trying to tame the chaotic nature of the game.

Oh, and it's a great place to make friends, actually really great.

Now the devs themselves have admitted this is their first serious project and they are new to game development, it shows partially, but I haven't really seen anything critically bad. So far they have responded rather quickly to critical game issues, bugs, and at the same time add more and more content to the game.

A lot of the criticism regarding the game I don't get, like the micro transaction stuff, there's nothing wrong with it. It's not a pay to win game or heavily micro transaction based. If you don't gamble all your "Nemo Bucks" away on eggs to get the skins that will always be available, especially now with the redesigned reward system, the developers give you around 10k of those for free as long as you reach Level 100 (a bit of a grind, but not tedious in the slightest). You can also get that currency from mystery boxes that drop daily.

There are a bunch of bugs that haven't been adressed for a long time (like the bugged steam friendlist), but I can forgive that. The rest is just miscellaneous game random or ping related things, or servers lagging because more and more people flock to the game.

All in all, I find it simply great and it has quickly become one of my all-time favorite games. I hope it thrives and flourishes for a long time, and more people get to experience this amazing unhinged chaos. 🙂

Posted: September 21, 2023
7/20/24: For the foreseeable future, I have quit Party Animals, and suspect it will be indefinite. Instead of updates to refine connectivity and reduce latency input from an unfortunately always-online game, we got those which managed to make PAWS less fun. The new power-up mode was kind of fun, if not broken, and certainly not suitable for Quick Match, a mode that already suffers from being somewhat a good time at best and utterly insufferable at worst. Soon after, an update introduces it to Quick Match. Now, we have a kart game mode in early beta. All of this while the skin prices and battle pass progression continue to be utterly egregious, at the same time as xp rewards continue to dwindle so you'll just keep playing this live service game. While I understand why this is being done from a business perspective, I do not have time for a game which seems to prefer having an identity crisis compared to what the game originally was when I demoed it years ago, versus fixing what I originally paid for. No more. None of what I originally criticized has been fixed in the game's current state, therefore no more. There are too many excellent and outright better games to play out there compared to Party Animals, and I suggest you spend your time elsewhere even if you find the characters adorable.

Note #3: will edit again, but to keep it short, I've discovered custom matches only award you a quarter of what quick matches do for winning. Will reflect this proper in review. It is apparent that earning only 1 xp in custom matches on release to have been a bug, and I appreciate the developers fixing that.

Speaking from the perspective of someone who wanted the game solely to play custom matches with friends.

Started playing second playtest, was awesome, wasn't even aware of an XP cap on custom games because it was so lenient.

Third playtest, hit the cap in less than an hour of play. Okay, a little fair, can't have people grinding premium cosmetics with bots, but still. Gave feedback requesting that it should be increased, or that we should receive a % less once the daily limit is hit, until it's reset.

Boot up the game today to see what's happened, earned exactly 1 XP for a match by myself, based on "game time". Later I would see the same thing happen when playing with a friend locally, no matter how long our match lasted. What on earth. It's possible to earn XP with one other online player in your lobby, albeit much less than we ever earned during playtests, so it's still far from ideal.

While cosmetics are not everything, to be able to earn fair progression by playing with friends is all I ever originally asked for. I tried quick matches, and it was awful; everyone was sweating for achievements and/or xp, and i suspect it will only get much, much worse now that custom matches are no longer an option (unless you want to play literal thousands of matches to progress *one* level). Not me, not my friends, not anybody should be walled off from progressing in a party game because we decide how we want to have fun with it.

The microtransactions are frankly egregious, and initially I excused it because it wouldn't be that hard to earn them with xp, even with the third playtest's crappy daily cap. Now? Money is the only way for me & others who refuse quick matches, and I'm not very inclined to spend anything further after the game's turning out on release day.

And there's the fact that the game is online-only, which is pretty silly for a party game. While the team is chalking it up to a misinterpretation due to translation, and that could very well be the truth, I'm not sure. There had to be time to make this very clear to the players, especially considering the practice of online-only games has gained infamy for its use.

Please make it so that people can actually earn XP/earn a decent amount of XP from custom games again. What took a few hours of play over the course of 2 days during Playtest #2 to get to Level 26 has already been a crawl in comparison over 3; currently just hit Level 20.

While I understand offline mode won't come in a day, that would be great, too.

When I first played the game in 2020, I saw it as the new Gang Beasts, because said game managed to be ruined from the alpha days leading up to final release, and I thought Party Animals would be an exception. I hoped it would not become the same story, but here we are. Although I am certainly enjoying the core gameplay--it is much more fun than Gang Beasts was on retail release--I cannot recommend anyone buy this game in its current state, until, at the very least, the grievances about micros & XP gain are fixed.

Please do not let the game go out like this.

Posted: September 23, 2023
Please Read before you buy

There's a lot to like, but let's be real and address all the negatives first and foremost:

1) The game is always played with 8 people. So if you've only got three friends who own the game, prepare to be matched with 8 random internet strangers, some of whom are probably 5 years old, all of whom are pretty awful. "Well, that's not so bad, as long as my friends and I are on a team," I hear you say. *ahem*
2) Whether your game is a free for all, four teams of two, or two teams of four is entirely dependent on the arena selected and, I'll remind you, random internet strangers will be the ones controlling at least a considerable slice of this vote.
3) You could work around issues 1 and 2 if the game would take a leaf from Rocket League's playbook and allow you and your group of friends to select the sort of match you'd like to play before queuing up. Seriously, why can't me and 3 friends select "4v4 matchmaking" and then be presented ONLY with arenas that are compatible with that? AT THIS STAGE, I'M NOT ASKING FOR NEW ARENAS OR GAMEPLAY MECHANICS -- just a filter!
4) Some new game modes would be helpful, but even they don't require all new arenas to be made. Ice Hockey, Soccer, etc could still be fun even in a 2v2 setting. But no, you *have* to be online in this PARTY game with "PARTY" literally written in the name. And the "why" you have to be online might be the biggest downside of this game by far:
5) This is a game that you purchase (for $20 USD, no less) that then expects you to shell out money indefinitely for costumes and characters. I want you to pay attention to the quotation marks I'm about to use here, because they mean a lot tonally: You can "earn" opportunities to "win" a "chance" at a character or costume that you want, but those require you to win matches and earn experience points. Not only does the experience required to go from level to level increase drastically (meaning that you might need to win 10 matches to "earn" your first "chance" at a character or costume, but you'll have to win 30 to "earn" your next), but their tied to your "animal level" which has a limit.

So even if you were MADE of free time and just really LOVED the game, you will eventually run out of opportunities to 'win' the character or costume you want and there are already far more characters and costumes than there will be ever be opportunities you can "earn" as opposed to "buy."

Does any of this sound familiar to you? Well, it should if you're familiar with the rise and fall (heheh) of "Fall Guys" which started as a pay-to-play game, people were irritated at the level of money the game was expecting you to pump into it for cosmetics and so started requesting refunds. Steam put pressure on the publisher to change their pricing, and they said, "well if you want us to go free to play, we'll sign on with Epic since they'll pay us for exclusivity on PC" and even with their sizable check from Epic and all the whales spending real life money to buy cosmetics, the devs still abandoned any efforts to stop hackers/cheaters from ruining the game for everyone leading in a rapid decrease in the game's popularity.



So with that all said, let's address the good: Do you like gang beasts? Well this is that but with cute animals.

If that's enough for you to enjoy yourself, then by all means have fun. But you might be better waiting for this game to become free to play, which I can pretty well guarantee will happen sooner than later.

Posted: October 1
I'll be honest..

I have spent far more time on this game over the last week + since buying it than I probably should have. Any time I have had free time, this game has taken priority because, as frustrating as it can be when things don't go the way you wanted them to, it's so darn silly and such good fun it's hard NOT to want to play it. Subtract about 6 - 8 hours at a guess from leaving the game running whilst AFK, and that's the genuine playtime.

Let's talk about this awesome little game and it's modes.

Last-Team Standing, with sports based and objective modes, all of the fun stuff.
Pure combat. Every round, pick a card based power up and win points over six rounds.
Kart-racing. More or less a carbon-copy of MK and a mid one at that.

Classic is, for me, the ideal, go-to mode. You have your combat maps, you have maps designed around securing objectives whilst fighting and you have maps designed around fighting and playing sports.

SMASH is, okay? If you like pure combat and no real objectives, this one is great as it'll rotate maps between rounds as you secure power-ups. Comeback potential is there as later rounds afford more points.

Nemo Kart is not that good. No reason to play it over other well designed alternatives really. It's there, but I think the developers should focus on other things, it's sub-par to me.



It's goofy, physics based, doesn't always go the way you expect it nor want it to, but even when it's frustrating, it's grand. I'd be lying if I said I haven't had mid-game mini-rants, arguing as to why I'm knocked out longer after a single punch than someone who I've KO'd three times for example, but even when it's frustrating, it can be funny and oh so enjoyable.

There isn't much complexity to it, knowledge comes more down to timing than anything else. You have a punch / sprint punch, kick / drop-kick and a headbutt / roll. You can obviously grab too. The grabbing is based more on proximity of where your arms are, rather than you having control of each arm, punches will be carried by momentum, headbutts aided by your ability to grab people and drop kicks are either super intentional or super random.



Right now, there's a free battle pass event going on, I'm unaware of previous passes. Upon purchase of the game, you'll also progress a 100-tier track through normal play and normal XP gain, of which you'll get multiple currencies and cosmetics. Cookies are given out very fairly, many shop skins can be bought with those, NEMO bucks given out more sparingly, but enough to use on the gacha system to test your luck if you wish and they also throw egg coins at you for the gacha system too, so you have a chance to unlock things always, without buying into MTX.



See if you have a mate that owns it first, ask them if they're willing to invite you and let you try via the friend pass and give it a go. If not, it's fairly affordable for what it is and I think monetisation contrasted with the progression you get is more than fair in this day and age.

I think it's worth every penny personally. I've loved it, I encouraged my kids to play it with me and we've laughed at it, I've had a few funny session with my wife on it too and I've even played it with some of my good mates as well and it's been top-notch every time, even when I get frustrated.

Great, adorable little game.

Posted: September 21, 2023
TL;DR: The gameplay is a lot of fun and it's easy to pick up, but there are better, cheaper party games that come without the over-monetisation and live-service issues. Best to wait for a sale or choose a different game altogether.

The Good
I played the original demo back in October 2020, along with my friends. We all loved it; it was simple and lighthearted, with easy-to-learn mechanics, cute fuzzy animals, vibrant colours, and creatively designed maps. When I got playtest access, I was excited to learn that all these highlights had survived the long development process and had even been improved upon in some respects – new maps, new animals, new ways to customise your animal. Unfortunately, these were the only improvements over the original demo, and the only good things I have to say about the game.

The Bad
Monetisation
At 20 USD, Party Animals is comparable in price to other party games. Unlike other party games though, the upfront cost doesn't grant access to everything. Many items need to be purchased using one of 2 currencies - Cookies or Nemo Bucks - or randomly obtained from Eggs (their cute version of lootbox / gacha mechanics). Initially, I was under the impression that all these currencies could be obtained through regular gameplay real-money purchases, and so I treated it as a progression system (I have since learned that Nemo Bucks are only available for real-money purchases). Thinking that everything was tied to these 3 currencies, I was surprised on day 1 when I opened the shop to see a bundle for a new character that didn't appear in my locker - the "Cabbage Dog". It was only available through a bundle costing real money - 5.9 USD to be exact, or a little under 1/3 the price of the game. It was incredibly insulting after paying an upfront cost to be presented with content that was inaccessible without paying more.
I wasn't surprised that the time-limited playtest required an internet connection to play, but I wasn't expecting it from the full release. Unfortunately, there is offline mode. Want to look through your locker at the animals and cosmetics you’ve collected? You need to be connected to the internet. Having some friends over and want to play with them on your couch? You need to be connected to the internet. Going to a party and want to bring this game along? Better hope they’ll give you their internet password. Going on a road trip? Plane ride? Camping trip? Anywhere else with a lack of stable internet? Tough. You can’t play this game, even locally, until you’re reconnected.
Even if you're someone who is always connected to the internet, the online-only model makes me question the longevity of the game. Party games tend to be short-lived. They are the type of game you return to when you want mindless fun, not the type of game you play consistently. As such, party games tend to quickly lose their players. For a game that's online only, a consistently low playerbase is the indicator of an upcoming end-of-service. When that happens, say goodbye to your access, and any hope of playing your beloved game again.

Party Animals is a solid party game. Its controls and mechanics are well polished, its visuals are gorgeous, and each match is full of mindless fun. You will enjoy your time with it, especially if you have friends to play with. But enjoyment is not the same as being worth the price. The lack of an offline mode means that even your local games will be affected by high ping, and further means that you will lose access altogether if/when the servers get shut down. If you want to get it, wait for a sale... but there are plenty of party game alternatives available that can be played offline or online, and don’t charge for cosmetics.

My initial review of this wonderful game was negative because my experience was very undesirable. However, upon gaining more playtime, looking at the developer's responses to feedback, and what other people say, I can confidently change this review to a positive one.

I'm a guy who has waited a long time for a lot of games. Elden Ring, Tears of the Kingdom, Persona 3 Reload, Pikmin 4, Baldur's Gate III, The Thousand-Year Door remake and the like... but I digress. Games aside, I have waited like the rest of you for this release. Sure, this game does have it's issues. There are complaints that certain regions, such as Australia, simply don't have any servers. The community's understanding was that this game would feature both online AND offline multiplayer. However, the developer's have since retracted and edited their statement, saying they have no plans to create an offline mode. I would highly, highly suggest they reconsider. This is an amazing title with a large following who has waited for a very long time- we're here to see it grow, not just stagnate several years down the line when online play is no longer supported.

Sure, some games have a gripping story, beautiful music, and some even the potential to romance intricate characters. Yadda yadda yadda, but can you knock the absolute cr*p out of them like this..? I didn't think so.

[TL;DR] In conclusion, this game is worth your money and your time. I hope that the games offline capabilities and online server availability will continue to grow so that more people can experience it both now and long down the line.

10/10, would animal violence again.

In it's curent state, I am very sad I say I can't recommend it. I always liked all the BTD series, and was really looking forward to playing this, but unfortunately, it is way too predatory with it's monetization system. You earn around 50-300 xp per match per tower, and you need 2000 xp for the least expensive tier 3 upgrades for the towers. I don't even want to look at how much it is for tier 4 or 5. The cash earning is decent given the amount needed, but the xp is way too low. Hopefully they will increase it in the near future, because I really want to be able to play this.

Edit after 1.0.2:

While now the game feels slightly more playable, with village not being as painful as before to level up as before for example, I still think this is slightly far off from what should be done. While you now consistently earn around 200 xp in each of your 3 towers per match, or even more if you only use 2/1 tower and win (unlikely but doable), and temporal buffs longer, it still probably takes around 40 hours just to max ONE tower.
While it's around 5 times less than before (it was around 200 hours according to my estimates), it still is waaaay too slow. I played for an hour and a half only using boat, alch and ninja, all of this while having a 2 hours boost to xp (so xp is multiplied by 2) and only got 1-2 tier 3s per tower. Again, it's definetly better than before, when those 2 hour boost didn't even exist as far as I was aware, but still takes too long. Keep in mind that I ONLY played those 3 towers and in around 15 matches and an hour and a half got around 4k xp on each with double xp active. And the tier 4s are 10k at least, with some up to 20k. Tier 5s are all over 20k, so the amount of grind needed for just 1 tower is really absurd.
I will probably keep playing because I like the actual game, but I really hope they improve the xp rate a bit more, as I won't actually recommend it to someone if that's not done.

Posted: 12 January, 2022
This game has fantastic bones underneath it all, but it's overshadowed by some MAJOR issues (listed below). Most of my qualms come from wanting this game to have serious competitive viability and Ninja Kiwi's decisions that hinder such viability. I'm confident the balance and bug issues will be fixed in time. Hopefully in a few months, the game will be playable. But for now it's just not fun :'( Scroll to the end for a TLDR.

1. The EXP system: This idea is a holdover from Battles 1 from a LONG time ago. However, the rate of EXP gain is entirely too small, even after it's been raised multiple times already. I'm over 100 hours into the game and still have not come CLOSE to unlocking all the tower upgrades. Also, locking late game viability behind a thousand-hour grind wall is absolutely terrible for any sort of "competitive" play. Given this game is exclusively PvP, that's not acceptable. Imagine playing Street Fighter for the first time and picking Ryu... but you can't throw fireballs, dragon punch, or hurricane kick until you've played Ryu for 75 hours. Then you still have to unlock all the moves for the other characters too at 75 hours each. Or imagine playing chess but your Rooks can only move vertically till you've played 50 hours and your Queen can only move diagonally backwards until 100 hours in. The reality is that ONLY cosmetics should be locked behind such a MASSIVE grind wall. Anything affecting actual game play should be available once you finish the tutorial. I understand the need to monetize, as Ninja Kiwi needs to eat and keep the lights on like the rest of us... but if they want this to be taken seriously as a "competitive" game then punishing players who can't play 40 hours a week is NOT the way to do it. I'd have gladly payed 20-30 bucks to buy the game with all the towers and upgrades unlocked.

2. Lack of Sandbox/Training Mode: This is surprising since BTD6 and Battles 1 both already have Sandbox mode for testing. How am I supposed to know which towers are good at solving which problems (if they're good at all) if I can't test in Sandbox? Again, this is abhorrent for competitive play. In the modern era, there NEEDS to be something like Training Mode in every competitive game out there. Otherwise the competitive community is seriously gimped.

3. Input Delay: I've played a lot of fighting games and have strong opinions on how netcode should be handled. Ninja Kiwi have implemented a Delay based system for Battles 2. On the surface, it makes sense. If the connection between 2 players is struggling, then put in a minor delay on every input to allow for a "buffer" time to compensate, this is common in fighting games. However, there's been a big push for Rollback netcode in fighting games. Rollback would not really work for a Tower Defense game, admittedly, but when you need to sell 3 farms to buy 5 bomb shooters and upgrade them all to tier 4 and activate their abilities before a swarm of DDTs blow by the screen, that "minor" delay makes it virtually impossible. I strongly prefer the Battles 1 net code that allowed you to micro (buy/sell/target/upgrade/etc) as fast as your fingers could, at the cost of occasional desync'ing issues. Right now you have to prepare for rushes BEFORE they happen, then when they don't happen you're behind. It really limits the "strategy" aspect of the game as very few things can be done as reaction. Everything must be preemptive, leading to very flowcharty redundant game play. Either you have 90% of the defense needed to defend a rush in advance and they don't rush you since already spent the money to defend, or you die because the input delay won't let you micro. UPDATE: The input delay now feels worse with 1.0.6 and 1.0.7 updates. I start to enjoy games as it's no the same dartling meta every game, then I try to boost and count to 12 before it activates but I'm already dead.

I won't even speak about the poor balancing or game breaking bugs here, as it's still a new game and new games take time to fix/balance. NK are people too, and nobody's perfect. I do believe NK is working hard to fix the bugs and balance issues, and the patches they have released so far have all been big steps in the right direction. My real complaints are the decisions they've made that cripple the notion of "competitive" play. Especially when NK mentioned something about potential eSports a while ago.

TLDR
-New game is new, and has new game problems (bugs/balance). I'm ok with that because they're working hard to fix these. (with 1.0.6 they've fixed many bugs and balance issues but now the input delay is WORSE)
-There are several major decisions that hinder competition and suggest a lack of understanding of the state of competitive gaming and ignorance of the struggles of past competitive games.

Posted: 30 November, 2021
Coming from BTD6, this was kind of a letdown. Admittedly, it has potential to surpass BTDB1 and BTD6, but as of right now, it is a P2W.

The xp and cash rewards from a victory is too little to actually be rewarding and unlock any upgrades Tier 3 and more, making it an incredibly grindy unlock system. This creates a very rigid meta for new players and there won't be much change or variety in early matches. Hardcore fans might not be so bothered by this, and may see it as a reason to play and get better at the game. Also, unlocking a reward chest by winning games can be exhausting for a players who can't win consistently due to oppressive metas.

It's buggy as well, no surprise for a game's initial launch but I'll state mine, and my friends' personal experience for posterity. We experienced a glitch in the final section of the tutorial where we had multiple copies of our Heroes but they didn't fire, this didn't affect the result of that battle since it was a tutorial fight but thought we should let the developers know.



1) 1 Free tower unlock for each category, so that new players can experiment with different builds, other than Dart, Bomb and Tack as a start. The tutorial's cash rewards aren't enough to even buy a Support tower, and barely get a Magic tower.

2) The tutorial should teach most damage types as it only explains energy damage can't pop purples. New players starting in BTDB2 may not know ice damage can't pop white bloons, explosion damage can't pop black bloons. With the tutorial teaching players how to place towers down, it has the opportunity to show damage types as well.

3) Social battles should still have some amounts of xp and cash rewards, alleviating the starting grind for friends. To mitigate this, social battles don't have to benefit from competitive bonuses like No Lives Lost and First Blood.

This is just my own personal opinion about BTDB2. It is very much still an enjoyable game but it is lacking.

Posted: March 1, 2022
It's a mobile game, it has all the hallmarks of one and it has the design of one. Its premium shop is predatory; Ninjakiwi is creating a problem and selling the solution. Bloons TD6 has you gain experience with each tower before you can upgrade it so its higher tiers can be accessed in a match, this works in that game because it's Co-op. You gradually become stronger and can take your team further. This however does not work in a PvP setting, especially when you can buy boosters and currency in the premium shop. The game is poorly optimised for PC and I get constant desynchronisation issues, the graphics stutter and the gameplay often lags behind with the health bars not properly showing the amount of HP a player has left.

The PC version does not have ads because apparently Ninjakiwi believes people who play on mobile are easily exploitable morons who never set foot outside of Plato's cave and thinks that these shenanigans would never fly with the clearly superior demographic of PC neckbeards.

At its core it's still a Bloons game. It will grant you some nostalgia of your childhood playing this in the back of your computer science class, maybe even some hiraeth if your time between then and now was particularly rocky. Sadly, you can pick only 3 towers and as you'll come to learn there are only 3 correct choices and all the others will have you eating mud the second the ZOMG class unlocks for both players. This may seem like a scathing review but keep in mind I'm recommending this. It's still a good way to spend an hour. The gameplay is fun and engaging enough and will keep you entertained for a little while.

Out of all the games that exist out there, this is one of them.

Posted: December 13, 2021
(if anyone still sees this, the game is probably good now, it has improved greatly - gamemodes are still lacking, but it isn't a mess like it used to be. but i still think it completely failed to live up to its predecessor)


January 7th update: The game has received one minor patch since 1.0.4, the game is the same as it was last month. Right now, the main concern of players has shifted from XP to the meta being boring, many towers being bugged to make them weaker/stronger than intended, and lag/desync. The next patch is still weeks away ( patch notes here ), and we'll be waiting longer than that for the addition of casual mode, universal xp and new maps. It's not really something to complain about, as the developers were understandably taking a break for the holidays, I just mean to say that the 1.0.4 section of this review is still valid. Although even if you don't mind the grind for xp, you might not enjoy playing against the same meta loadout (most meta towers are bugged which makes them much more powerful than they should be) in the majority of your games.


(Dec. 15) The XP gain was increased by a pretty large amount in this update. The rate at which you obtain it is much better, and f2p players shouldn't feel entirely hopeless while grinding anymore. The game is in a somewhat decent place compared to it's launch, and it might be worth a try if you thought it was too unforgiving before. Some people are perfectly fine with the game as it is right now, and I can understand some of that.

However, I still can't recommend the game in it's current state. The system is still fundamentally flawed and does not belong in a competitive game. Trying new tower loadouts shouldn't be as punishing as it once was, but an increase in xp doesn't change the fact that attempting to level up different towers is going to result in unbalanced matches. The amount of XP itself isn't the main problem, it's just another factor that makes the entire system more frustrating.

The state of the game for f2p, as of 1.0.4, isn't nearly as terrible as before. Keep in mind that the amount of games you need to play (and probably lose) to suitably level up a 2-2-2 tower is already quite brutal as a VIP, and of course for f2p it's much more punishing. Though with the recent xp increase, the grind is much more bearable, and there are plenty of f2p players who were able to cruise up to BFB-ZOMG arenas with just a few tier 4's. If you enjoy a grind, the game can certainly be enjoyable as a f2p.

On December 13th, NK's co-founder released an official statement reflecting on the game's first two weeks after launch, and how they plan to improve it. They are planning two improvements to the XP system, those being and These changes are precisely what many were hoping to see, and I'm so glad that these were announced sooner rather than later. I can confidently say that these two changes should vastly improve the community's opinion on the game. Universal XP solves the primary issue with the xp system, that being the fact that you are required to actively use the tower you need xp for in every game. If universal xp is done right, the game should eventually be more friendly to beginners and players in high arenas alike.

So, at least we know the developers weren't scamming us here, it was just a series of stupid decisions. Now that NK has confirmed that the xp is getting major changes, I'm hoping that it will start to feel somewhat on par with battles 1 within a year or so. The question is, do we bash them for releasing a bad product, or praise them for improving that bad product? Well, that's up to you. The game is beginning to go the right direction, so I'm happy. (P.S. thanks to the people who awarded this)


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------



there's no way the game can stay like this for long because the system is just so poor. the monetization was done so bad it's not even funny. seriously, it would be better if they put a price tag to instantly unlock all towers and upgrades, because even though that would make most players quit, (just as the current system is doing) they would at least get a decent amount of money spent by hardcore fans. right now, the game is pay to win, but even the people who DO pay still feel as though it isn't enough. VIP just isn't a large enough increase and you still have to grind hundreds and hundreds of games if you want tier 5's.

there is no skill involved here. even if you and your opponent both own VIP, you'll still be on separate playing fields because grinding xp for a tower you haven't used much will always be disadvantageous. I can't think of a way they could possibly fix this terrible design without removing it completely. what kind of pvp game implements a system that requires you to play thousands of games, just to be able to have a fair fight? It's so poorly executed, I don't know how they thought this was okay.

what happens if I'm in a high arena, and the one strategy that I've been using isn't working so well anymore? well, All I have for the other towers are 2-2-2, so the only option I get there is to start surrender farming - because it's not like anyone can get by with tier 2 towers in the 60+ trophy arenas. This completely forces you to always stick to the meta, unless you want to lose 30 times in a row while mindlessly spamming the same tower. And since every single tower has it's own separate xp pool, players are encouraged even more to continuously use the same loadout every time. There's no diversity in strategies, and that makes things really stale. Realistically, you won't ever unlock every upgrade, so there won't ever be a competition that's actually fair.

They could monetize cosmetics, emotes, gamemodes, guilds (if they plan to have those) and maybe even the hero skins, and players would be happy because none of those things are crucial to gameplay. But instead they monetized XP... which requires you to pay money AND to grind. On top of that, they made hero cosmetics free......... how does that make any sense?

Even if the possible solutions presented in this review were horrible and poorly thought out, they would likely still improve the mess that the XP system is right now. The game will surely be fixed eventually, but it really needs to be addressed as soon as possible. Increasing the xp isn't a fix, and it's clear that the game won't last so long if they keep it this way.

It's sad because I really enjoy everything else about the game. If all upgrades were unlocked by default and everything else cost real money, I would happily play this game all day. For now, it's not worth it.

Posted: June 5, 2022
It's a good game, but before you play, know it's predatory marketing

Ninja Kiwi has always handled micro-transactions well, even in the original battles. You COULD purchase micro transactions to unlock tower upgrades quicker, but it was fairly easy to unlock all the tower upgrades legitimately and very quickly if you knew what you were doing. The problem with this game is... you can pay a MONTHLY subscription (or even TRI-MONTHLY) to get THREE TIMES the rewards of a normal player. Three. Times. It's just so poorly done. And the thing is, battles 1 had something similar, but it was a 5 dollar one-time fee and you got essentially new game modes, which, while you COULD make more currency that way, it was pretty much fine. This, however, is just such a horrible business practice. I'm sure they're making bank from it, and the game is fun, as shown by my playtime, but I can't recommend YOU to play it.

The worst part is that after EVERY battle there is an option to multiply your earnings by 3 by upgrading to vip. It is an option. At the end. Of every. Battle. If you click it, it brings you to a page within the game to pay for VIP, which is just asking for little timmy to take mommy's credit card and get bloons vip.

It just doesn't feel right when I'm in a ranked match and I lose because the other guy has a better hero than me, or more upgrades than me, because he's a "VIP" lol. Most of the games I lose I usually just excuse as "ah, didn't know that could happen, I'll adjust to this information" but.. sometimes I lose because the other person payed real life money, and that sucks. You can get to the point where you max out everything, however it takes exponentially longer in this game than the first one, which just sucks to see as a battles veteran.
I have 17 hours in the game and have much less than half the upgrades unlocked. Probably even less than a quarter.

You may ask; how can you avoid micro transactions for a free game on pc? and here's the answer:
you can't. What you CAN do is make micro transactions purely cosmetics or hide game modes behind a paywall. Free games need to be free-to-play, pay-to-have-fun, while still being fun to play normally, EXACTLY like how battles 1 is. Source: every successful free pc game ever

TL;DR
In conclusion, it's a good game, and if you have some money to drop on it to get that extra edge or just don't mind a lot of micro-transactions/losing due to pay-to-win mechanics, it's a good time. It's even fun for me, someone who doesn't exactly wanna pay like 5 bucks a month for a game I might log on to play a few hours every few days.

Posted: December 5, 2021
The real problem in this game is the balance, the reason you see everyone using the same towers is because this game has limited options for composition.

The first game worked well because you were allowed 4 towers, but in this game youre only allowed 3 towers with a hero, and a hero DOES NOT make up for a missing tower, a hero is only there to support your towers with abilities or passive buffs (Gwen, Striker) every once in a while, but it still doesnt make up for the missing tower slot. Because of this, if you arent using a Village, Alch, Banana Farm, or any combination of the 3 in your loadout, then you are at a MASSIVE disadvantage at various stages of the game, especially later on when Blimps come into play, there are loadouts that straight up cant compete without a slot used up for a primary buff tower, which severely hurts composition diversity and synergy, because in order to survive you have to use the meta towers since they are the strongest by themselves as long as you buff them (example: Tack, Alch, Village). This is a problem with the amount of towers that are NOT viable, they are simply too limited to work without sacrificing a slot for a buff.

The diverse strategies and synergies of BTD are disincentivized. I think that in order for this game to truly be fun like the first game, they need to let us use 4 towers again, with a hero, for 5 total slots, so that you have the option of supporting more of your towers without such heavy sacrifice. That MAY sound like a lot at first but trust me it would help the balance of this game a lot in the future if players were actually able to use the tower compositions that they WANT to use, instead of tower compositions that they HAVE to use in order to survive. It's not even like this will stop the meta from existing, but at least players who want to use other strats will be at a more even playing field, instead of dying instantly on round 12/26.

At the end of the day, this is a PvP game, and arent PvP games supposed to be yknow, balanced? at least a little bit?

Posted: December 3, 2021
Absolutely love Bloons and Ninja Kiwi, if you check my profile you'll see I've got over a thousand hours in Bloons TD6 (I have a problem I know), but Jesus. Battles 2 is so busted, and the release was absolutely rushed. The game constantly crashes even when BTD6 and everything else runs fine on my PC, if opponents disconnect sometimes the round just... Stops. The game doesn't end, no one wins or loses, but bloons stop sending and rounds stop moving forward, so you can sit there making income, building towers selling doing whatever you please.... But with absolutely nothing happening until you forfeit and lose out on rewards and ranks. And the upgrade system, please excuse my french but holy mother ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥, what in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ HELL is this? I'd prefer to get XP by having a cheese grater shoved up my ass and turned in to spaghetti. You get to yellow stadium and suddenly you're utterly screwed and have to level up every single monkey one at a time (IF YOU'RE LUCKY) because the upgrade system is not only so immensely slow it can take a dozen games just to get all the tier 3 upgrades for a tower (if you're lucky and win all dozen of those games that is) but because of how it's split depending on what you buy in the game that means you have to spam god awful towers if you weren't spending the entirety of Red Bloon Stadium just grinding XP on your crap towers later on (which absolutely doesn't work considering with 3 tower slots, losing out on one to terrible towers AND trying to balance greed/defense/XP investment = you're gonna lose a solid 50% more of the time atleast). And due to this horrible leveling system people get in to yellow stadium without good/reliable de-camo options like camo village or bloontonium reactor (normal support sub works fine for smaller rushes but is way too slow to de-camo massive camo purple bloonsends, trust me I've tried double intel support subs and with just a few queues of purple camo bloonsends at LEAST half of'em just fly right by the sub like nothing happened depending on the map) and just instantly lose to round 12 camo purple rushes or some other form of cheap bs that's not on the fault of the players, but on Ninja Kiwi for constructing a game mechanic system so immensely busted that your only options for decently countering certain strategies is by dumping all your money in to de-camo (assuming you even have it) and praying your opponent isn't smart enough to save up a couple income ticks so they can balls to the wall spam camo purples or camo leads. Or better yet, doesn't see that you're doing the smart thing by saving up for de-camo and thus most likely lacking in proper earlier game defenses and just blasts you with whatever you're weak against (thankfully though thats a gigabrain strat that takes a LOT of focus/wit to pull so I've only been slapped with bloonboosted regrow zebras while relying on a bomb shooter cuz I'm busy trying to level up boomerang twice)

Honestly there's a lot of stuff that's really subjective to me, personally I feel like income should be increased slightly to make early games and anti-cheese "instantly end 80% of games with this ONE WEIRD TRICK!" strategies juust a bit harder, but the one thing that isn't subjective is that BTDB2 is utterly busted from a bug standpoint and a basic "overlooked issues in the core game design" standpoint, and should have had way the Hell more QA testing. That or at LEAST make it clear this is an early access game, because in the name of Guy Fieri our Lord and Savior this does not take me to flavor town.

update: Ninja Kiwi has decided to solve the problem of rounds constantly disconnecting and just stopping by automatically forcing you to lose if the game desyncs. Which is lots of fun. Boy do I love clappin mad cheeks and suddenly getting ranked down and wasting my time because Ninja Kiwi decided to bone me instead of just neutralizing the game like most online games do when their servers are hosted by a toaster :)))))

Posted: May 30
Before the 4.0 update, I really enjoyed the game. I am a casual player, and I could join the game at any point, play a few casual games, and leave and come back months later. After the 4.0 update, I feel like I can't play the game anymore. The 4.0 update completely overhauled the battle system, entirely removing the casual play option, and forced entirely ranked play. There is now no way to play the game without it being a constant challenge, and I see this as a serious issue for new and casual players. If you aren't sure how to play the game, or play for fun from time to time, you will be forced to play against players much more experienced and competitive than you. It isn't fun. I can no longer pick the game up and put it down at any time, and the games that I do have are always against players who seemingly don't want to have long and fun games, but they just want to win. I don't even care whether I win or lose, as long as the rounds are fun I will enjoy the game, but the forced ranked matching system removes the possibility for me to do so. I tried learning how to play with Etienne, the new hero, but I simply couldn't because every game was competitive and there simply wasn't a mode where I could experiment with the new hero. The game feels hostile now towards new or returning players, and being in that category, I simply cannot play this game. It's better to just uninstall it and free up space on my computor. I absolutely loved this game before, and I know I still would if they hadn't changed what wasn't broken. There was already a system for ranked play, but there was also the option for casual play, so all they really did was remove casual play and add a hero. I truly hope they reverse this update, but knowing game developers, they probably won't. If you are a sweaty, hardcore BTD Battles 2 player, then enjoy your sweaty game and give it all the wonderful ratings you want. If you are a returning casual player, give it a try for yourself, but I suspect you will experience the same dissappointment that I did. If you are a new player, or if you are looking into buying this game, I would highly recommend rethinking your choice, and unless if you are also a sweaty gamer that likes being competitive and you want to do so on a funny monkey game, I recommend saving your money. Go spend it on BTD 6, or another game that is still friendly to new players.

Honestly would not recommend to waste your time on this game right now.
- Netcode is horrible, in about 40% of my matches someone "loses connection" and is forced to surrender. I have never seen this in any other "big" game.
- It contains horrendously predatory marketing while offering extremely little in terms of balancing the game, they simply add more paid content every update. Some upgrades have been bugged since release or so horrendously bad in the game that I refuse to believe they have been tested even once (Spectre, Apache Prime, Flying Fortress, Sun God).
- If you surrender a couple of matches in a row you will automatically get shadow-banned for "boosting". There is no warning regarding the shadow-ban. It does not say anywhere that you are banned and for what reason, and there is no way to repeal the ban.
- The grind is weeks long and the Elo system is unbalanced. If you win their your first few games in the "Hall of Masters" you can become the No.2 ranked player worldwide, over players with hundreds of wins.
+ The only good thing about the game is the Random Quad gamemode, as it offers a break from tediously playing against the same tactic that the developers refuse to nerf and allow for some more interesting gameplay.

____________________________

This game starts out fun but as soon as you hit Yellow Stadium everything starts to go downhill very fast.
You start this game with barely any tower or upgrades and unlocking anything takes ages. You start this game with barely any towers that actually detect camo bloons so when you actually reach Yellow Stadium all hell breaks loose. The entire game revolts around just rushing round 12 with camo bloons. You can't defend them and there's a solid 50% chance your opponent cant either because this game starts you out without any towers that actually detect camo and can pop a lot of bloons at the same time. Now here's where you can buy VIP and get 3x rewards every match to unlock everything at an ungodly pace meaning you get situations where you have to fight players with tier 4 towers while you only have tier 2 and maybe 1 or 2 tier 3 upgrades unlocked. You can't do anything about them, you are just destined to lose. Nk couldnt even keep their promise to not make this game grindy or p2w. Massive disappointment.

There is a lot of grind needed to start playing this game at a competitive level, and if they don't fix it, I guess I will stick with the simple yet perfectly balanced og btd battles.

Posted: December 13, 2021
In it's current state this game can feel pay to win at times but the system of separating players among different arenas based on their number of wins limits this to some degree. All players within the same arena will in theory have similar access to the number of towers and upgrades for those towers. This creates a nice and gradual sense of progression as with better towers and upgrades matches will last longer and go into later rounds more often as you progress through the arenas. In practice this is still true but not always. With the nature of a game like this which requires grinding to even compete at higher levels, paired with the option to speed up this grinding with VIP, you'll often encounter opponents who are either far more equipped to last longer into the later rounds due to having more or better upgrades available, or who are far less equipped as they are grinding exp for one or two of their towers which doesn't have as many upgrades unlocked. The arena system does limit this to some extent, but many players find it easier to grind in lower arenas and as a result purposefully attempt to stay within in them. Nowhere is this more true than the earlier arenas and the penultimate arena as once the final arena is reached, there is no way to return to any of the previous ones.
The actual battles that are the game's namesake are quite fun despite this however. The fun and strategy behind each match comes from knowing you and your opponents weaknesses, exploiting theirs, and minimizing yours. Even if in theory your opponent should win because they have better towers with better upgrades, keen observation and your knowledge of what their towers' limits are can still allow you to squeeze out a win. The opposite is also true so it's never a good idea to underestimate any opponent or their defense. It keeps you on your toes and commands your attention in the same way the original BTD Battles did but doesn't contain all of the unique, and sometimes controversial, elements from it. When compared I'd say it's a more "pure" experience than current BTD Battles. Even so I hope that in the future some elements from that game make their way into this game.
Overall if you were a fan of the original or the more competitive game modes of normal Bloons Tower Defense I'd highly recommend this game. There aren't many problems with it but those few problems are obvious and can easily be fixed in future updates. Ninja Kiwi has already shown some interest in making the game more fun and balanced with an update within the first few days of release. If development is anything like development of BTD 6 then we can expect balance changes almost as often as with that game.

Posted: August 19
As a long time fan of the BTD series, it disappoints me that a game with so much potential has so many anti consumer practices. This game is incredibly P2W, making it horrible for new players, and the newest change to arenas makes it so a player with a 90% win rate is unable to progress and reach better opponents, and puts a player who wins 30 games and loses 100 ahead of a player who wins 30 games and loses 5 (without a 10 game win streak at any point). For the beginner experice, I believe if you started off with all the monkeys tier 5 and all the heros, this game would still make ninja kiwi absurd amounts of money with all the cosmetics and the club membership. New players must either spend insane amounts of money or grind many many hours in order to have a chance against their opponents. In general multiplayer games that let you gain competitive advantages by spending money are extremely anti consumer and should never be supported financially.

TLDR: P2W, rewards playing more games rather then winning games, and punishes people who have a life with demoting inactive players. Horrible practices ruining a game that could so easily be so good

I should caveat this bad review with: I still play it occasionally and it can definitely be fun, but it gets frustrating quickly and needs some work. There is potential here and I will change this if I see it worked on.

I'd really like to recommend this game, but the microtransactions are oppressive and the servers are sketchy at best. I was holding off on this review until I started disconnecting from games taking an instant loss (with a fully functioning internet connection).

The matchmaking also doesn't seem to take into account any amount of accumulated experience so you're likely to match with people who have many times your exp and therefore substantially better towers.
