Posted: July 12, 2022
The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.
Strategy
His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.
The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells.
A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more.
The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball.
However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter.
Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible.
It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.
In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation.
Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage.
When there are buildings placed in the middle to counter the Hog Rider, understanding the placement of the Hog Rider and the type of building placed can help the Hog Rider to bypass certain buildings.
Passive buildings such as spawners and Elixir Collector have a larger hitbox than defensive buildings; which means that if a passive building was placed 3 tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, then it is impossible for the Hog Rider to bypass that placement as the Hog Rider will get pulled to that building.
Defensive buildings have a smaller hitbox than a passive building, which means if that if a defensive building was placed three tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, a Hog Rider placed at the very left or right side of the Arena may be able to bypass it due to its smaller hitbox.
If the player has a building already placed down in the center of the arena, and the opponent tries to bypass it with a Hog Rider at the edge of the arena, they can use certain air troops to push the Hog Rider towards the building as it jumps over the river, effectively denying the bypass attempt. They must be already hovering over the correct placement, as very quick reflexes are required to correctly perform this technique.
For Bats, Skeleton Dragons, and Minion Horde, they should be placed right in front of the Hog Rider as soon as it is deployed.
For Minions, Skeleton Barrel, Mega Minion, Flying Machine, Electro Dragon, Baby Dragon, Inferno Dragon, Balloon, and Lava Hound, stagger the above placement one tile to the right if the Hog Rider is placed on the left side of the arena, and vice versa.
They can also use ground troops to achieve the same result. Something like an Ice Golem deployed at the Hog Rider’s landing spot will obstruct his path and force him to go around the unit, which causes him to be closer to the building instead of the Crown Tower.
The Hog Rider can kite Very Fast non-building targeting troops due to his own Very Fast speed and building only targeting if he is placed on the fourth tile from the bridge, slightly into the opposite lane. He can also stall grounded units when placed right at the bridge. He will pull them towards him while deploying, and then be untargetable by them when he jumps over the bridge. After landing, he will pull them back. This can be useful when the player needs to deal damage in the same lane they are defending. It will also help separate troops behind a tank in a large push.
A Tornado placed on the second tile front of the player's King's Tower and staggered two tiles towards the Princess Tower will activate it without any damage dealt to the Princess Tower, helping them in defending future pushes. This can also be a method of mitigating all damage dealt to a Princess Tower, but doing this more than three times may result in the King's Tower's health being low enough to be targeted directly, opening up the possible threat of a back door three crown. A better alternative is to pull the Hog away from the Princess Tower into the attacking range of all three Crown Towers, which will negate all damage as long as none of them are already distracted
A very powerful combo is the Hog Rider, the Musketeer, and the Valkyrie, typically referred to as the Trifecta. The Musketeer will defend against most troops, while the Valkyrie can protect her and the Hog Rider from swarms or high damage units. The Hog Rider is used to deal damage to the tower.
This can be effectively countered by Lightning, one-shotting the Musketeer and severely damaging both the Valkyrie and Hog Rider. The Minion Horde is also effective, but the enemy can Zap them and the Musketeer will one-shot them all. Even if the Musketeer is defeated, the Hog Rider and Valkyrie will have enough time to severely damage the Tower.
The Hog Rider should be placed behind the Valkyrie to give it a boost so that it stays in front of the Hog Rider, protecting it.
A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage. However, a Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower.
Pairing the Hog Rider with the Balloon can deal devastating damage. If executed properly, the Hog Rider will act as a tank while the Balloon threatens to deal massive damage. The Hog Rider can also destroy any buildings attempting to slow down the combo. However, this combo is very vulnerable to swarms and anti-air cards as neither of the troops target anything but buildings. Additionally,

Posted: February 12, 2022
I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2020 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. We spent 7 hours on the game that night and we had killed the first 3 bosses. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.



Thank you, Crab Game.

What I wish the next update's changelog looks like:

+ The server default is now WITHOUT bots.
+ the Rifleman now uses your Steam username instead of your Epic Games username.
+ Added bullet penetration through players and objects
+ Added killfeed icons for no-scope and penetration kills, with corresponding experience rewards.
+ Better networking so players don't get knifed from shooting distance.
+ The players crosshair now doesn't move and is now a more orthodox crosshair in the middle of the screen.
+ Player's ping is now noted in numbers instead of the signal graph
+ Ping for servers
+ Host migration always chooses the player with the most stable internet connection.
+ Players with a bad connection don't teleport and flicker around. Added animation and location insertion.
+ Added a clear way of distinguishing bots from players by means of a different name colour.
+ The spawn protection indication is now based on team colour instead of blue.
+ Improved hitboxes for many objects, especially trees.
- Removed the "take revenge x times" missions. Some players never get dominated so this mission forced you to lose.
+ Nerfed knives.
+ AI Nerf: Bots now sometimes miss on close range.
+ AI Nerf: Bots don't pull their knife as often as before.
+ AI Improvement: Bots don't all move in the same direction and walk in chains.
+ AI Improvement: Bots don't look through, and try to shoot through walls anymore.
+ Blurred the background slightly of the sniper scope when zooming in.
+ Rename the game Riflemen, without the 'the'.
+ Added unicode and font support for non-alphabet languages
+ Various bug fixes and improvements.

Planned for the future:

More content
More achievements
Add Steam Trading cards
Make the in-game weapon skins into Steam items instead of unlockables.
Make the Premium DLC into a Prime status like CS:GO.

Posted: 8 September, 2023
Summary
The Riflemen is a First Person Shooter where your goal is either to capture points on the map or to get a certain amount of kills before the enemy team. It's a standard FPS game and offers variety in form of maps and different supply drops that you can use to try and get an edge against the enemy team.
Pros
+ Poly FPS
+ Free to play
+ Multiple decently designed maps
Cons
- MAJOR features locked behind paywall. This includes core features of the game such as making a private match, turning off bots in your game, or making your lobby singleplayer.
- All cosmetics are locked behind a paywall. Although you have to earn all of them, you still have to pay. There is absolutely no free cosmetics or any content for free to play players to work towards.
- Horrible optimisation. There is no cap set on your GPU usage, so it will use up 100% of your GPU, despite it not requiring nearly that much power. There is no way to change this in game, and can only be fixed through the developer making a patch or using third party software.
- Dead playerbase and terrible servers
- Horribly made achievement. Achievements are lazily slapped on with an 1000 kill requirement for all weapons without considering the rarity or difficulty it is to get kills on each weapon.
The Riflemen is just another cheap FPS game with very little effort put into it. As with most games published by this publisher, the games are generally low effort and by newer developers. This game is no exception. With all the poor design choices that this game has, I cannot possible recommend this game. There isn't any enjoyment to be had here, I would suggest looking for alternatives.

Premium. The paywall for cosmetics is a bit ridiculous, if you want stuff the lowest level you have to get to is level 10 for an in game profile icon, and even if you do buy the premium pack its a battle pass system.

Apart from all that, the game is fun and fast paced with everyone being 1 shot.

Posted: September 5, 2023
Honestly this game has a lot of potential. There are a few things that could be improved upon.

Likes:
1. The fast paced action adds a lot to the experience. The respawn time is perfect to get back to fighting.
2. The game is simple yet challenging if that makes sense. Positioning is key.
3. Servers are mostly full except for the occasional bot.
4. There is only one primary and secondary available to keep it balanced. I think this is the best way to keep the game
balanced.
5. The game is colorful so you can tell things apart from each other.
6. Maps are designed to make it so no team can camouflage better than the other team, keeping the action going and the game less campy.

Dislikes/Annoyances:
1. Some maps are small and suffocating.
2. I don't know if its just me, but I always seem to get stuck with either the grenades or shotgun as my random drop. In the
6-7 full games I have played, I have only received the katana once, and the RPG twice.
3. The lag on some servers can lead to intense rubberbanding, leading to an unhitable target.
4. Perhaps my biggest dislike is the iron sight on the main rifle. Its terrible in my personal opinion. The very small triangle makes it very difficult to hit the target. A possible feature that could be added to help with this is a way to change the iron sight on the rifle to a personal preference for all players. Players could look in a catalog of iron sights and select which one they wish to use, with no iron sight being better than the rest to keep it 100% balanced.


This is my 100% honest review of The Riflemen. This game has crazy potential to do well if well maintained and updated. I cant wait to see where this game goes in the future.

This game is a very basic First Person Shooter, but for people new to the genre its absolutely perfect. It has all the basic mechanics youd expect from a game like this, and its also great fun with friends. It's fun to test the limits of this game. Just as an example, I was supposed to get a cat out of a tree. Most people would spawn a ladder and go get the cat. I went a different route. I typed the word "jetpack" not expecting it to work. Surprisingly, it did work. I gave the jetpack to the cat, and the cat strapped it on. But it still wouldn't go anywhere. I never expected that bone headed idea to work, but it just showed me that this game was way more than meets the eye. Definitely worth the small price.

Posted: 8 June, 2017
For the first time on the PC... I remember Myself playing the first game in This series (Scribblenauts) for the first time on the Nintendo DS and I truly loved it. I just wrote words on a notepad in the game and they appeared out of nowhere in the game-world itself... and I was like: "WOW!" This is one, is one of those games that has supported and helped Me improve plus learn the English language as a very young child (I'm not from any English-speaking country)

THE STORY
-------------
It tells of the main character's (Maxwell) parents past, starting a family til They had about 42 children. Every kid is very unique when it comes to personality, ethnicity and appearance. Especially Maxwell's sister (Lily) one day Both of Them plays a prank on one old hungry man by giving Him a "rotten apple" This man becomes enraged because of this and places a curse upon Maxwell's sister Lily. Each of her every "body parts" is about to turn into stone each hour passing by. Maxwell tends to help His sister, but how is that possible? How will he be able to unrelease this curse that is turning His sister into stone?

GAMEPLAY
------------
You start as Maxwell You can add pretty much anything into the game with Your magical notepad. You need to use items that is fitting well to solve the problem of the situation You're trying to finish. For some examples: Help a plant to sprout. My solution: add anything that can water over it. Help the kitty down from the tree. My solution: add small wings on the kitty so it can fly down from the sky. An old man wants to sail across the sea. My solution: get Him a sailing raft. Y'know... Stuff like THAT.

Not only can You play as Maxwell but on each level in the game on your map (almost) You can unlock all His 40 siblings and play as Them. And You can also change Your avatar by clicking on Your current avatar and go down to the avatar-menu or whatever the hell it's called...! And then You can customize Your avatar how You want Them to look like. Plus in the game itself You can add clothes acessories or a tail, maybe even wings on Your avatar and do alot of other crazy stuff for fun, solving the people in the game's problems.

MY OPINION AND RATING
---------------------------
I like This game. However I prefer the first game over this one. The one for the DS, y'know? I know. I'm kinda weird for liking the DS-game a little better instead of This one for the PC because This one is improved and much bigger than the original first game. But You know what They say: "The originals beats the sequels!" Heh. But still This game has alot of potential and can inspire so much, that you don't even know what more to say about it.

My rating however, for this game 's going to be a 6/10 because it can't beat the first game (in My opinion) Scribblenauts for nintendo DS: 8.5/10. {however if You've played the first one, I do think You'll like this one a little more (;} the game has good music and can get You joyful for playing it, but it might get a little repeating and monotonous after a while. At least for Me...!

Posted: 16 January, 2014
"Write anything, solve everything." This has been the mantra for Scribblenauts since its creation in 2009, and each new installment comes closer and closer to realising this goal. Scribblenauts Unlimited on Steam has taken the "write anything" part to heart, but falters a bit of the "solve everything" side of the equation.

The Steam Workshop support for this game is quite huge. If you can think of an object that the game doesn't recognise (mostly copyrighted content), then it's possible that someone has either created it for you, or some toying around with the game's impressive object editor will make your dreams a reality. Even better, you can upload your creations for all Steam users to enjoy.

As awesome as this is, the gameplay is a tad disappointing. At least, we finally have an explanation for Maxwell's endless search for Starites (the game's MacGuffin). The story acts as a prequel to the series, as Maxwell struggles to retrieve the errant Starites to rescue his sister, Lilly (one of literally dozens of his relatives, all of whom are playable characters), from being turned into stone. This story is quickly forgotten once you start summoning vuvuzuela-playing pink jaguars to fight a winged preposterous black knight riding atop a cowardly telekinetic cybernetic T-rex, with only the occasional interlude reminding you of your main objective.

To retrieve the Starites, Maxwell must help people around the game's expansive world with various problems, from helping an up-and-coming rock band gain a fanbase, to helping patients in a hospital with their various ailments. While its nice to have a large amount of different areas to explore, many of which feel alive with various characters mulling about, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was just playing nicer-looking versions of the DS games' title screens. Worse yet, many of the main challenges don't encourage your imagination as often as you think they would.

Despite these problems, I would still highly recommend this game to anyone who hasn't played the series before. The visuals are crisp, the sheer amount of objects that can be generated is mind boggling (not counting the extensive Workshop creations), and it's still fun to see how each object and adjective interacts with each object in the world.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------


+ Graphics look amazing, even on low-powered laptops
+ Amazing object editor
+ "Write anything": only limited to your imagination
+ Always fun to see object/adjective interactions
+ Nice origin story for Maxwell...



- ...but is quickly forgotten while goofing off
- Worlds feel like glorified title screens from the DS games
- Many challenges limit/stifle creativity

Posted: April 4, 2015
A charming game that expresses the innocent sense of curiosity and imagination of a young child in a way I have rarely seen.

If you're not familiar with the Scribblenauts series, they are platformer sandbox puzzle games where you can summon just about any object from the dictionary (with some reasonable exceptions such as copyrighted things, alcohol, and proper nouns) and expect them to interact in a believable way. If you can think of any food, animal, household item, weapon, mythological creature, or vehicle, chances are you can make it appear. We're talking tens of thousands of possibilities. A few surprises can also be summoned, such as a variety of internet memes and special objects, if you can think of them.

You can summon objects, or add adjectives to existing objects, to solve puzzles and make all the townspeople happy. Or, you could just screw around for hours summoning gods and beasts and riding them across the world as your epic mounts, or watching them run loose and terrorize the villagers.

The puzzles are all ridiculously easy, but difficulty is obviously not the point. Personally, my favorite way to play this game is to think of the most obnoxiously ridiculous solutions to every puzzle. Most puzzles will have a bluntly obvious solution, but you can make hilarity ensue if you can think of something creative. For instance, a guy wanted something to help carve his ice sculpture. I gave him a toenail clipper. Hansel and Gretel needed something to make a trail with through the forest. I gave them thumbtacks. A buzzard wanted something to eat. I gave it a dead baby. A tracking dog needed something that smelled like Santa so he could search for Santa. I summoned Santa.

It's an excellent game packed with great humor and content, and it's miles ahead of the Nintendo DS games it was based on. My only complaint is that it got a bit boring after the first few hours, but I fixed that just by taking some breaks and not playing it all on one sitting. But I never once stopped appreciating how wonderful the game is. Highly recommended for anyone who wants to rediscover their inner child, complete with borderline politically incorrect humor, in a way that very few games can provide.

(Achievement hunters: getting 100% is very tedious, as you will need to solve over a hundred riddles to acquire the remaining bonus pieces. Usually you will solve some of them on accident throughout normal gameplay if you try to use creative solutions. However, if you ever get bored, you can just look at a FAQ to fully complete the game effortlessly.)

A game with lots of creativity. You control a boy who can turn anything to life by writing it on his notebook. Lots of crazy things to do in this game like shooting down a building with "Destroyer", turning a lizard into a Ice Dragon and make him fight a "Flamethrower Soldier", building a school underwater, make a health potion and drink it if you are hurt and low on health, add dead as an adjective... Also has cool story. Its not a game for Everyone though. You might get bored of it quickly if you don't like these kind of games. And...! You can get past most of the game without killing people! Type "Sleepy" or "Sleeping" as adjective insteed! Had a great time in this game. Will play more.

+ Creativity at Its Finest

+ Lots of Characters and Customization
+ Improve Your Spelling Skills! :P
+ Good Story
+ Makes You Think
+ Truely Open World
+ Lasts Long

- Not for Everyone. Some People Might Get Bored of It Quickly
- Resetting the Whole level After the Death of a Quest Related NPC for Level Completion. Respawn Feature Would Have Been Nice...

Posted: March 21, 2014
What I love about scribblenauts is its creative problem solving and peaceful attitude.
Problem: Did the children of the neighborhood land their ball on the old geezer's lawn that won't give it back?
Solution: Spawn a gun and kill him! It works!
Problem: Nurse being chased by an angry heart?
Solution: Spawn a gun and kill it!
Problem: Want to contact a manager at the other side of a wall?
Solution: Spawn a grenade launcher!
Problem: Frozen people encased in ice?
Solution: Spawn a flamethrower! Bonus: Watch their life points diminish as you melt/burn away!
The thing that bugged me the most and made me sad is the cruelty towards animals. For example, as I visited a restaurant I made friends with a brown recluse spider and a cockroach, petting them and watching their happy little faces light up. Then some evil quest-giving person wanted me to kill them for a pest-control inspection, the nerve! And for a starlite fragment I had to kill my newly made bug friends?! What cruel madness is this!
Also while going through the object shards achievements I had to prod a cow?! Shame on you scribblenauts. I hope they will fix those issues in future installments. In the meanwhile I will continue riding my black&red huge supersonic fire-breathing dragon that is immune to damage, while going around helping people and making their lives better (sometimes with the use of supreme firepower).

Posted: October 11, 2023
I had NO idea this game even existed. And it has blown my mind...
WTH IS THIS GAME!?!?! WHat the hell??? This game is unlike any other you have played. It is not about maneuvering, tab targeting, using specials, etc. No. This game is entirely based on your words, your imagination! Your character has a super-powered magical notebook to write or draw in. Whatever Maxwell writes comes true. It reminds me of an old cartoon they used to have as part of Captain Kangaroo, a little cartoon about a boy named Simon, and whatever he would draw with his magic chalk would come to life!

It's Simon, plus Adventure Time. This game MUST have been inspired by adventure time. This game is a little bit dated now, and a little bit buggy depending on what platform you're on. But, the upside is that this game HAS been around for a long time and therefore there is a lot out there about and for this game. Lots of guides, and lots of stuff on the Steam Workshop!

This game, it's so different that I have to actually take a break from time to time. It really shows how mind numbing most games are. Just SEE ENEMY PIXELS, PRESS BUTTON. over and over. On Scribblenauts, you have to imagine something, then you just write it.

It's fun to just go somewhere in the game and sit there and experiment. Making actual people, animals,, machines, etc. and modifying them, giving them items, messing with their motives. Sometimes they just randomly fight, or maybe other creatures get spawned in by all the weird interactions going on, There's even been a few times I've seen one of the quests for the level I'm in just spontaneously get solved by some crazy thing I spawned in! Like, on this prison level, I sat right at the entrance and was messing around and spawned some SWAT team guys, a tank for them to use, and a general to command them. As soon as I spawned in the general, something happened, and one of the quests resolved. LMAO.

Also, I love that you can spawn something, then open it in the editor and REALLY change it around, and then you can summon THAT item with the pad. THEN, there's even this quick pad thing. You spawn something in, maybe even one of your custom items, a police helicopter with a swat guy in it, and then you grab that, and drag it up to the back pack icon in the upper left. He will actually go up in there. When you look, you will see a picture of him, and you can drag and drop him back into the world! It's crazy! You can make as many copies as you want.

I went ahead and got Scribblenauts Unmasked as well, and in that one you can summon in like EVERY DC COMICS CHARACTER EVER. I'm not even kidding.

This game is ridiculous, you should play it, it's certainly something different. It is even appropriate for kids.

Posted: November 14, 2013
I highly recommend this fun for all ages kinda game. It is like mad libs come to life. You wander around what is basically a 2D open world mad libbing people's issues. Issues like I need something to scare away crows.... well just spawn a zombie or a scarecrow, or an angry hunter, or a gun to do it yourself! There's a lot of unintentional yet intentional fun here. Spawning a zombie to solve one puzzle might chase away other NPCs. Unless you add the adjective, friendly zombie. Its really the interactivity with the world that makes the game such silly fun. Did your zombie make a fire? Well have a firefighter put out that fire. Its a silly fun game that I can imagine would be great for kids. Simple controls that really thrive with a keyboard when you're typing things like 'pretty pink princess.' There are good area settings too, everywhere from standard city areas like hospitals and a fire station, to more creative areas like Jurassic Park, a haunted house and a castle. Overall, the game is pretty easy. Easy enough that anyone can see it through to the end.

You can do whatever you want! My favourite part of the game is killing innocents and watching them run and call for help, but there is nothing they can do. Or forcing people to cannibalism by starving them to death and adding the adjectives "delicious", "tasty" or "edible" to their friend. This causes them to eat their friend out of hunger! You can also create a box and trap a citizen in it forever, and never let them out! You can watch as they scream, cry for help, and then eventually quiet down and suffocate. You can create hideous abominations and add adjectives like "hungry" "evil" or "aggressive". This will cause the monster to attack innocent citizens for no reason, and kill them! One of the things I love about this game, it that it is a learning experience! It can teach kids new adjectives! This is a very fun, family friendly, wholesome game, and I cannot recommend it enough! I hope this review helped a lot, and maybe even got you to buy the game! :)

Posted: August 8, 2020
Information

Scribblenauts Unlimited is a puzzle game developed by 5th Cell Media.

Gameplay

The adventurer Edgar was reputed to be the most famous adventurer in the world. When he wanted to retrieve a gold-plated figure from an ancient temple, he only found the adventurer Julie there, who preceded him and was about to eat her lunch. Later, Edgar and Julie competed against each other, adventure after adventure. Julie beat Edgar when she opened a treasure chest, but the treasure she found was an engagement ring. Edgar and Julie get married and initially had only one son named Edwin, but later they raised 42 children, all of whom are their children! They gave each of their children a special relic, the two twins Maxwell and Lily got a globe with which one can travel to any point in the world, and a magical notebook which, as soon as you write a word in it, makes it a reality! However, they got too used to their gifts that their parents fear that they will spoil them too much. So they sent their children to discover the world. On their way into town, Maxwell and Lily met a hungry old man. Maxwell conjures him an apple, which was rotten. The old man cursed Lily, she gradually turns to stone. Maxwell and Lily went to their eldest brother, Edwin. Edwin told them about starites, magical stars that arise from the joy of others. Maxwell sees it as his job to save his twin sister and collect enough starites for her to be fine again.

Also good to know: In contrast to its predecessors, there is no longer a level selection screen, but a large, connected upper world that the player can freely explore. This adds an adventure element to the game in addition to the puzzle. Another innovation in the game is that players can now create new objects themselves using an object editor.


+ Child-friendly
+ open game world
+ good puzzles
+ Create tons of crazy objects and solve puzzles with simple text input
+ coherent soundtrack
+ funny object editor and worldwide exchange function
+ Trading cards and achievements


- Sometimes solutions are difficult to find
- does not always recognize all words at the same time as they are entered
- Control a bit awkward, especially in the editor and the action inserts


Scribblenauts Unlimited turned out to be a good puzzle game, even if it doesn't quite match its predecessor.



Scribblenauts Unlimited ist RätselSpiel, welches von 5th Cell Media entwickelt wurde.


Der Abenteurer Edgar war angeblich der berühmteste Abenteurer der Welt. Als er eine vergoldete Figur aus einem antiken Tempel bergen wollte, fand er dort nur die Abenteurerin Julie vor, welche ihm zuvorkam und gerade ihr Mittagessen essen wollte. Später konkurrierten Edgar und Julie gegeneinander Abenteuer um Abenteuer. Julie kam Edgar beim Öffnen einer Schatzkiste zuvor, doch der Schatz, den sie vorfand, war ein Verlobungsring. Edgar und Julie heiraten und bekamen vorerst nur einen Sohn namens Edwin, aber später zogen sie 42 Kinder groß, welche alle ihre Kinder sind! Sie gaben jedem ihrer Kinder ein spezielles Relikt, die beiden Zwillinge Maxwell und Lily bekamen einen Globus, mit dem man an jeden Punkt der Welt reisen kann, und ein magisches Notizbuch, welches, sobald man ein Wort hineinschreibt, dieses sofort Wirklichkeit werden lässt! Jedoch gewöhnten sie sich zu sehr an ihre Geschenke, so dass ihre Eltern befürchten, dass sie die beiden zu sehr verwöhnen. Also schickten sie ihre Kinder los, so dass sie die Welt entdecken. Auf dem Weg in die Stadt trafen Maxwell und Lily einen hungrigen alten Mann. Maxwell zaubert ihm einen Apfel, welcher jedoch faul war. Der alte Mann verfluchte Lily, sie verwandelt sich nach und nach in Stein. Maxwell und Lily gingen zu ihrem ältesten Bruder Edwin. Edwin erzählte ihnen von Starites, das sind magische Sterne, welche aus der Freude anderer entstehen. Maxwell sieht es als seine Aufgabe, seine Zwillingsschwester zu retten und genug Starites für sie zu sammeln, dass es ihr wieder gut geht.

Auch gut zu wissen: Es gibt im Gegensatz zu den Vorgängern gibt es keine Levelauswahl-Bildschirm mehr, sondern eine große, verbundene Oberwelt, die der Spieler frei erkunden kann. Dadurch bekommt das Spiel neben dem Puzzle- auch ein Adventure-Element hinzu. Eine weitere Neuerung im Spiel ist, dass Spieler nun mithilfe eines Objekt-Editors selbst neue Objekte erschaffen können.


+ Kinderfreundlich
+ offene Spielwelt
+ gute Rätsel
+ mit einfacher Text-Eingabe Unmengen verrückter Objekte erschaffen und Rätsel lösen
+ stimmiger Soundtrack
+ lustiger Objekt-Editor und weltweite Tausch-Funktion
+ Trading Cards und Errungenschaften


- Lösungen teils schwer zu finden
- erkennt nicht immer gleich alle Wörter bei der Eingabe
- Steuerung etwas umständlich, vor allem im Editor und den Action- Einlagen


Scribblenauts Unlimited ist ein gutes Puzzle-Spiel geworden, auch wenn es nicht ganz an die Vorgänger heran kommt.

Posted: December 4, 2017
Scribblenauts unlimited: Summon words to conjure Lovecraftian horrors

This was given to me by a good friend of mine. He, much like a lot of other people I know adores this game. I did hear quite a bit about Scribblenauts before playing it and was looking forward to playing it. Well now that I have finished the story I would like to chat about it.

Scribblenauts has a very simple story with a simple but universal message about kindness and helpfulness. Maxwell and his sister Lily are two children who love to cause mischief. The two have a magic notebook from their parents that can create anything they write down. This makes them become spoiled as a result. That all changes when they trick an old man to eat a rotten apple, the old man curses Lilly to slowly turn to stone with the only cure being Starite; magic stars that manifest when people are helped. It is up to Max to help people so he can save Lilly from becoming a stature and learning charity in the process. That is the entire story I can give without going into spoilers. It is nice, to the point and gives a good message for all children and adults.

Gameplay is also simple; it is a sidescroller with some light platforming in some levels, none of it is too difficult making it available for everyone. You control Maxwell with either the mouse or keyboard and you type nouns or adjectives as needed. This game is solely a puzzle game where you are creating the puzzle pieces. The game is very forgiving to spelling errors which are nice for someone like me or others who struggle with spelling. You cannot write anything vulgar so do not bother writing stuff that would be under that classification. There is nothing really wrong with the gameplay asides from some of the puzzles being slightly uneven in difficultly but that is kind of it.

The graphics and art style are brilliant, everybody looks like and moves like wooden dolls and the back rounds appear to look like hand painted boxes, it all looks so adorable and so enduring. I could not help but feel warm and fuzzy when I was playing through it. There is always the problem when it comes to such upbeat and cheerful media is that it could become obnoxious and insulting to the children. Scribblenauts balances the cheerfulness out with the underlying threat that Lilly is going to turn to stone and it will be all his fault, it shows children that actions have consequences and not all can be solved easily if at all. This and the fact that some of the humour has a dark edge to it when you stop to think about the jokes but most, if not all of it will go over children’s heads.

The game runs fantastically well with no problems at all, in the end a very well optimised game.

I have enjoyed Scribblenauts tremendously, a must play for children and adults alike.

Posted: October 1, 2014
This game just makes me happy when I play it. It's fun and I laugh a lot while I play it. Do you really need anything else from anything?

It's not a difficult game by any stretch as a simple story game of collecting stars to help save somethign from something with a lot of cool/cute art and object making. It lets you use your imagination to create an enormous amount of objects to just drop into the world and play with. Want a monkey? How about a GIANT monkey? You can make one and then ride it. Hilarious notebook? Sure. It will make every NPC that it passes by laugh. Create a Living Garden Gnome riding on a Tiny Goat. You can even create NPCs that will fight with one another, or even jsut play nice. Using adjectives in front of objects makes them even more interesting than they already are.

You can save objects you create in your backpack for easy access, you can get objects created by other Steam users in the Workshop with simple in-game menus and a couple clicks. Tons of user created stuff is amazing and hilarious so make sure to spend a good amount of time in the Steam Workshop for this game.

This is a Family Friendly game that anyone with a soul should play and enjoy. If you are a ginger, well we know you have no soul, but even YOU would probably be able to find some joy here.

It's an easy 100% Achievements game and they just take the time of finishing all the stars mostly and making objects they tell you to. Trading cards as well of course.

Posted: December 21, 2021
It's difficult for me to give this a thumbs down, both because it's a nostalgic game I played when I was younger and because I don't think it's a bad game. I know you must be asking, well if it's not a bad game, why don't you recommend it?

Scribblenauts is for kids. At least, this one is, that much was obvious to me coming back to this game and playing it for the first time in years. With certain forms of "kids" media they can be made to be enjoyable for both kids AND adults at the same time. Take the movie Shrek for example, it's a movie intended for kids yes, but it has plenty of adult humor in it and as a result I find that movie just as fun to watch now as I did as a kid. Scribblenauts Unlimited is not like that.

The big issue I have with Scribblenauts Unlimited is that it's not really a game when you break it down. The basic gameplay loop of this game can be summed up like this; enter a level, click on an npc and they ask you to spawn something, you spawn it grab the starite/starite piece and move on to the next npc and repeat. And to add to this, every single quest or puzzle that npc's give you is insanely simple. It'll be something like "I need something to eat this soup with!" and you give them a spoon. Every single task in the game is like this, only near the end does it get more difficult and I would argue not in a good way because most of the time it's the way the task is written that confuses you and makes you unable to think of what would help the npc.

Another thing that really bothers me about this game is that it never rewards you for being creative, and there's no incentive for creativity even though the main draw of Scribblenauts (no pun intended) is that you get to be creative and do anything you want to. Most of the time when you choose to spawn something more unique or interesting than the basic, easy to solve answer you're met with nothing and it begs the question, why waste time trying to be creative and come up with cool or interesting solutions to the puzzles when there's no incentive to do so, and when giving the boring easy option is both faster and requires less thinking?

It's frustrating because Scribblenauts has such a unique game mechanic that being the notebook, but it feels like they spent all their time developing all these things to spawn and didn't give enough time to design the game to work around it. So instead we got all these filler quests and puzzles to pad out the game, none of which are particularly fun or interesting FOR ADULTS. That's the keyword, I think this game is fantastic for kids 12 and under, but if you're above that age I really cannot recommend this game. It will bore you and you will likely give up about an hour into the game when you realize every quest is the exact same and requires the brainpower of a peanut.

Posted: March 21, 2020
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#342 out of 612)... it's time for Scribblenauts Ulimited.

It's Scribblenauts, and it functions exactly as you'd expect it to from reading the description, and has the exact same flaws you'd likely imagine it to have from reading the same. In brief: a simple puzzle-game where you type nouns, occasionally modified with adjectives, to summon objects into the world to solve problems. The game has a very large dictionary, but is far from thorough, so if you have a sufficiently large English vocabulary, you likely won't get much mileage from the game as you'll frequently type in words that the game does not correctly recognize. All the same, Scribblenauts is a fun puzzle game that encourages lateral thinking and is probably best suited for non-native English speakers hoping to learn the language, and children hoping to expand their language skills.

Posted: June 10, 2018
An adorable little puzzle game originally designed for children, the game revolves around typing out words which will then spawn in the world or affect other items/npc's to help solve challenges.

With a massive database of words, adjectives and items to play with, you can solve a puzzle in pretty much any way imaginable, which makes it pretty fun even if you're an adult - I tried to solve pretty much every problem with guns, and it worked suprisingly well.

- Open up and play whenever, you'll be able to progress a little bit in just a few minutes.
- Even if you're an adult, you'll be wracking your brain trying to think of ways to solve challenges in unique or interesting ways.
- If you rush through all the maps there's probably still a good 6+ hours of gameplay to the end, if you go for 100% you could likely double that.
- This game could last basically forever, the art is simple but appealing, and there's so much variation you can't really get tired of it. I mean you could always set it on fire to make it more interesting.

- It's pretty obvious from the get go that this is designed for the DS, as its touchscreen interface makes obvious. Mouse controls can be a little but clunky, and hitboxes for items are HUGE and regularly overlapping.
- If you're trying to 100% levels, you have to go around the entire level solving peoples problems, but sometimes these can be a bit hard to find. You'll quickly end up putting 'flying' and 'fast' adjectives on yourself and speeding round in the mode that allows you to see the tasks you haven't completed easier, but also unfortunately kind of ruins the aesthetic of the game with a big grey overlay.
- It's sometimes a bit frustrating to try and find the correct combination of words to do something, and quite often you end up reaching for brand names or copywritten words that are unfortunately not in the games database. I don't blame the developers for this, but I found this quite regularly breaking my immersion a little and leaving me frustrated. Thankfully, this is quite easy to fix with the Workshop, where you can go and download thouands more words and items.
- Being British, I write and spell very slightly differently to Americans, and it seems that the game expects American spelling and words. For example, where I would write 'tap', the game might expect 'faucet', which can get confusing at times. There are also a few tasks which required knowledge of American history, which I'm pretty lacking in, and took me several minutes to solve. However, this might not be a bad thing, as I actually had to think about what I was doing.

All in all, I enjoyed playing this game for a few hours and may go back to casually complete it at some point. I would absolutely love to see proper mod support for something like this, and being able to download large packs of new items and words would be pretty cool.

Posted: April 5, 2019
Fun for the whole family! Kids could probably spend days and days in this, as for adults, you can just mess around with entertaining results, using your superior vocabulary to create awkward scenarios. Like I once got tasked with deconstruction of old building and creation of a new establishment in it's place - I built a morgue, in the middle of suburb, and everyone got so excited they even put up wacky inflatible tube men during grand opening!

Anyways, it's a sort-of sandbox where you travel different areas and give or create people items they need. You can just write any object like "microscope" or "dress" or "centaur" or "multiple rocket launcher" and it'll spawn, and then you can add adjectives to most things which will give you even more options. Because all scenarios are handled trough item tags, you can get really creative - say, instead of giving hungry guy a pie or an apple, you can attach an "edible" adjective to a toilet or baby, for some family friendy cannibalism. It's all freeform, and altrough vulgarity is banned, you can still make things pretty dark or toilet humory.

So, most of game progression involves helping people on different levels, and some missions require completing different actions beyond just giving characters what they need, like helping a desert settlement defend from bandits by setting up defenses and spawning somebody who'd train the settlers, or navigating a hazard course where you have to devise the ways to walk trough fire and other traps. The progression only unlocks character skins (which you can create your own, even) and new levels, all the items you can spawn are available from start, and they all have some sort of interaction - there's even special achievements and challenges for figuring out different tasks, which demonstrate more unique interactions between objects, like using warmth to make a chicken egg hatch or making werewolf transform due to moonlight. It's pretty entertaining to discover, overall.

It's customary to bring up story and graphics and audio and, you know , they're there and they're fine, nothing remarkable but it's nice. Overall, this is an amusing title, go for it if you like messing in sandboxes even in singleplayer.

Posted: November 30, 2018
Scribblenauts Unlimited is a word puzzle game with colourful and cute "doodle-like" artstyle. We play as Maxwell who has a magical notebook that can create anything that he writes in it. He is on a journey to do good and help others in need in order to gather enough "Starites" to save his sister who is turning into stone.

Scribblenauts Unlimited is pretty unique for a puzzle game as you would be given hints as to how to solve a problem and you would type out an item which you think might be the solution. Do not fret if you are stuck as the game does gives more hints to a puzzle as time goes on and when enough time passes, they would just give you the answer. There is a decent amount of puzzles spread across 38 levels, each with their own unique theme and atmosphere (Range from a big city to an alien planet!).

The puzzles are mostly really easy as this game is mainly aim for young children based on the artstyle and storyline. However some puzzles are pretty challenging and might leave you stuck for quite abit (no worries thought, there is the hint feature that give you more hints overtime!)

Even after "Finishing the game" you could create your own fun by typing out various monsters/villians and heroes to pit them against each other and watch them brawl it out!

To sum up, Scribblenauts Unlimited is a really cute and colourful word puzzle game meant for young children (Adults can have fun with it too!)

Posted: June 27, 2020
A really fun experience all around. As a middle school kid, this franchise was a great way to learn to think outside the box. This game does not disappoint. The central mechanic is to solve people's problems through Green Lantern-esque conjuration abilities. Whatever you can describe you can create.

The game is so open ended to the extent that it allows you to manipulate the world by simply modifying nouns with adjectives. In a restaurant and the table is too small? Click on it, and the word "table" will appear. Change that to "big table" and you have altered reality to suit your will as the table visually grows in size. The game gives a diverse range of challenges for players to explore and excersize their personalities through writing and gameplay. This is the closest I have ever seen a video game get to the personal expression of role playing games like Dungeons and Dragons.

As an adult playing the game I started to notice a few issues, but take these with a grain of salt as I am not the intended audience.

For one thing, the gameplay begins to feel algorithmic at a certain point. The game is centered around creativity, but there are always easy answers. What can the lumberjack use on the tree? A saw. The fun comes in when you give a weird word to see if it works like "beaver" or "extremely sharp pillow." At a certain point however, through trial and error, you start to see how the objects the game offers are categorized, and what attributes the game is seeking with each question. At this point in the game is when the ragdoll cartoony style begins to become monotonous as the characters all perform the same actions and provide the same level of challenge.

If you are looking for my recommendation of this as a game or as a learning tool, it is absolutely well made and a joy to play. Scribblenauts nailed its central mechanic and provides a great avenue for players to stretch their use of it.

However, if you are a more savvy consumer looking for something like this game, but with less mundane challenges and more push towards the creatively absurd, I would recommend Scribblenauts DC over this. You interact with DC superheroes to use your powers with theirs.

Posted: January 24
Scribblenauts Unlimited is a classic puzzle video game that was released in 2012. Developed by 5th Cell and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, the game quickly became a favorite among gamers of all ages.

The premise of Scribblenauts Unlimited is simple yet innovative. Players control the main character, Maxwell, as he embarks on a quest to collect Starites and save his sister from an evil curse. What sets this game apart is its unique feature that allows players to summon almost any object or creature simply by typing its name into the game's interface.

This open-ended gameplay mechanic provides endless possibilities for solving puzzles and challenges throughout the game. Whether it's summoning a ladder to reach high places or creating a friendly dinosaur to scare away enemies, players are limited only by their imagination.

Furthermore, Scribblenauts Unlimited encourages creativity and critical thinking skills. Players must carefully consider which objects or creatures they need to solve each level's objectives effectively. This promotes problem-solving abilities and fosters out-of-the-box thinking.

The charming art style and catchy soundtrack add to the overall appeal of the game. The colorful visuals bring the imaginative world of Scribblenauts Unlimited to life, while the upbeat music keeps players engaged and motivated.

In conclusion, Scribblenauts Unlimited is a classic video game that offers an unparalleled level of creativity and problem-solving opportunities. Its unique gameplay mechanics combined with its charming aesthetics make it an enjoyable experience for gamers of all ages.

For me, playing Scribblenauts Unlimited is a very entertaining way to touch and play a little with my inner child! For those who play it, everything seems like a simple logic problem that must be solved with a bunch of creativity. The fact the game has a simple and at the same time full of imaginative possibilities mechanic, which matches with the clean artwork and graphics, drives the player to this very wished psychological place of not worrying or not having to follow any kinds of protocols, by fullfiling complex and hard-to-understand objectives; but yet being driven and carried on by such direct and fundamental moral themes: making other people a little happier with the powers we have and struggling to undo an "evil" caused by our own acts. With the nowadays tendence of creating very human like heroes and villains, with a spectrum of mixed moral values and affections, Scribblenauts makes us all remeber a little what is like to have possibilities of believing and making things look and feel better without the need of titanic actions and moves. I have a 10 here, but that's likely because I really like to hang around with the kiddo side of myself!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Another favorite made by Behemoth. In its current state (Early Access update 3), it stands strong on an excellent foundation for what can be a masterpiece once finished. I'll list some pros and cons below for its current state.

PROS:

Artwork.
Voice acting.
Funny.
Turn-based made fun.
World exploration.
Co-op, both local and online!
Daily leader board with rewards (replay value).
World seems to have 'pick up or ignore' side quests.
Capturing new recruits to join your team is currently my favorite part.
The weapon and shield choices are great, and hilarious! Spatula for a sword, large piece of bacon for a shield, lol!

CONS:

Main storyline is limited to only one, really awesome btw, quest once the tutorial missions have been completed.
Sound track is VERY limited at this point, and music can get repetitive.
There needs to be about 20 more monster types added for capturing and battle variety.

CONCLUSION
Great game that's worth a buy already. Made by a team you can trust to see the project through to the end and finish with a great product. Highly recommended, worth it for the laughs alone.

Posted: 16 January, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Pit People is XCOM, Fire Emblem, and Pokemon thrown into the minds of Behemoth and what they made is a funny and good looking game. The meat of the game is doing battle with teams of bad guys with your very own squad that you find through the story mode until you find Sophia the Recruitador (a lot of characters in this game have funny names). Then, the game branches into another way of playing it. You can capture any unit you fight on the battlefield when you leave it as the last one alive. There are several character classes from the human fighters to the penguins to the beefy giants to the cupcake healer class. Every character has their own name from Gluten to Pipistrella.

This is an early access title as of January, and it shows only in the story mode. The rest of the game is polished and balanced with each weapon type and class, but the story mode is farly short. What it lacks in length it makes up in character and gameplay. The narrator Stamper was present in their previous game Battleblock Theater as well but he takes the role of a godlike bear that overlooks the story as a sort of meta-narrator, talking to the characters and talking to the player. Apart from the short story quests, there are a few side quests that are all five parts incrasing in difficulty. These serve the same purpose as side quests in different games, to give you some more gold and flesh out the characters. These side quests take a bit longer than the story.

Apart from the insanely fun singleplayer, there exists an in-universe multiplayer PvP called the Pit, which is pretty much the only reference to the title of the game. You and a partner control your squads to defeat two other people's squads. It's a very satisfying game mode as you can learn from the other people's squad composition to increase chances of success. Think XCOM PvP. You get story rewards as well depending on how many games you win per day. As it is now, Pit People is very fun and well balanced even though the story mode was short and as sweet as the cupcake healer class.

Posted: 24 June, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I grew up at the tail end of what I'll call "the Newgrounds generation"-- that is, the adolescent boys (and, to a lesser degree, girls) who spent their youth on the website of Tom Fulp, engaging in the flash animations and games and becoming part of that underground internet subculture. I was always captivated by that which made Newgrounds, Newgrounds-- the fact that anyone could make anything and upload it, and anyone else could comment on it or rate it. And nothing stood out to my juvenille mind more than the works that made the website famous; the ultra-violent Madness Combat series; the absurdist humor of Eddsworld; the insane difficulty of early iterations of Super Meat Boy... The list of media that changed my budding self can go on and on. I retained all of it; I'll blame my entire personality and sense of humor on what I grew up watching and playing on my dad's old laptop. But the one export of Newgrounds that I always loved the absolute most was The Behemoth. I fell in love with their beat-em-up classic Castle Crashers at a Kid's Night Out party, as I played it on an Xbox 360 there. I was obsessed. Every waking moment I would think about, draw about, talk about the game. When I finally got my own Xbox 360, Castle Crashers was one of the first games I bought for it, back when you paid in Xbox points (where one dollar was equal to 80 or 160 points). I was a junkie for that game; I even brought my own Xbox to my friend's houses so we could play together locally. Years later, when I heard they made Battleblock Theatre, I bought it on the spot. It was everything I wished for-- The Behemoth's signature art style, sense of humor, and pefectly challenging gameplay, but on a platformer. I had a new drug, and I was hooked. I played that game whenever I could. Sadly, eventually, the burning passion I held in my youth died out. I would still play both games (Alien Homonid too, but to a lesser extent) from time to time, reminiscing on the bygone era of the post-Golden age of Newgrounds. Time passed, and I caught wind of a new Behemoth game from either Game Informer or PC Gamer in the magazine rack of a local supermarket. And this time, it was a turn-based RPG! I was amazed. I was excited. I spent as much time as I could researching it, trying to find out where, when, and how I could play it. That was years ago. Pit People was a cloudy fuzz of nostalgia and excitement in my mind until the day I opened up steam and what did I see on the front page-- Out now, Pit People. I was ecstatic. I couldn't wait to get it. What stopped me? My own wallet. In my youth my pocket changed flowed freely, and I splurged on whatever I felt like-- games, DLC, food, movies-- but in my teenage years I was not the same. I decided to myself, "ah, early access. I'll wait until it comes out for real". 4 updates passed, and I couldn't hold back. I whipped out my debit card on the first day of the Summer Sale and proceeded to buy it. And I must say, it's everything I hoped for and so, so much more. Where do I begin? Everything is exactly as I remember The Behemoth. The gameplay is challenging, in just the right level of fun. There's tons of options for how you want to play the game. There are cosmetics galore. The story is humorous but engaging, light but oh so rich. The announcer is the same from Battleblock Theatre and I love it as I did back then. This is the kind of game I would have made for the young version of myself growing up at my dad's overheating computer playing on Internet Explorer until I accidentally discovered Firefox. I give this game a perfect 10. If anyone at The Behemoth is reading this post, I want to tell you: Keep up the great work. The Behemoth quite literally shaped my mind as a child and it's just as good as I remember it.

Posted: 13 January, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I haven’t seen very many qualitative reviews yet, so I’m attempting my own. This is based on what I’ve experienced in the game so far playing three hours on my Xbox One and on Steam altogether.

A turn-based strategy game, you can build a team of up to six characters with their own customized equipment. Everyone can have different weapons, some with effects and some that are strong against enemies wearing particular equipment. An example of this is that swords will be weak against people with helmets but maces will be strong against them. While customizing you character, you will see a bar graph which tells you their equip load, damage, range, defense, and dodge. Going above 100% equip load will reduce the character’s move points by one, and staying below 50% grants an additional move point. You can designate one person on your team as the hero. Doing so gives them more health, damage, and greater equip load.

The combat is fairly simple. Move your melee team members adjacent to enemies, and they will attack them. Ranged team members supposedly need at least one empty space between the enemy and themselves. If there are multiple enemies that can be targeted within the vicinity, that unit will seemingly choose a random enemy to strike. Some of the fights can take a few minutes depending on how fast your thinking is when it comes to moving your team.

Early in the game, you will find a city where you will be buying some of your items, fighting in the pit against A.I. or other people online for gold, and customizing your characters or changing your team members as you obtain equipment and people throughout the game. Gold and items can be obtained outside of this place, but you are limited to how many items you can carry. Two important items I’ve come across are campfires, which allow you to heal your team outside of combat, and recruit cages, which allows you to recruit enemies to join your team. Mind that you will need to unlock the recruit cages through meeting a certain character first. I would recommend not fighting in the pit early in the game against A.I.'s beyond story mode. Three consecutive rounds can be difficult to finish.

Story mode is not finished yet, but there are many battles across the map you travel through outside of combat. Alongside the story mode quests, there are other quests you can choose from. You can also encounter optional quests while exploring the map. The game will point you to the objective once you’ve accepted a quest.

The art and music are reminiscent of previous titles, but they feel updated as well. The narration is just as funny as it was in Battleblock Theater. Castle crasher players will recognize the combat style immediately. Battleblock Theater players will know how this game is loosely connected to it.

I've recently tried co-op. Pretty much the second person you play with will have the same stuff as you from the very beginning. When you unlock a character, they get a variation of them as well. They will also have the main characters in character selection when they have the chance to change team members.

I have not tried PvP yet, so I can’t say anything about them. Hopefully someone else can tell you guys about them. Other than that, that’s all I can tell you about the game. Hopefully you will find other qualitative reviews better than mines. If you buy the game, I hope you enjoy playing it as I did.

Posted: January 16, 2017
First thing to note is that game being early access just means the story is not complete. Gameplay is finished, and there's a lot a of quests (which vary a lot) and stuff to do, including PvP mode, and extra difficulty. However, expect that after 2 hours, you'll have finished the story in it, which doesn't mean the game ends.

I loved the presentation of the game. classic Behemoth style, with a lot of humor, the same hilarious narrator from Battleblock Theater, and a lot personality behind it. Great music, with a lot of variety. For me, one of the selling points.

The gameplay is also great, however, is much simpler than your average turn based grid strategy game. Your characters attack on their own if they are on range of an enemy, for example. If you're looking for "hardcore gameplay", you might be disappointed with it. But I think that it goes in the right direction and it fits the game, while being very accesible for people not so into the genre. This is neat because the game has local and online co-op, so you can play this with a lot of people, not just hardcore turn based gamers.

Overall, i really liked the game. I would recommend it if you like the presentation, and you want to be playing it just to explore the world that the Behemoth people have created. If you're looking for a story driven campaign already finished, wait for the full release.

Posted: February 12, 2018
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
From the creators of the amazing games that are Castle Crashers and Battleblock Theater, Pit People shares an iconic artstyle from Dan Paladin that has been gracing his games with for over a decade now. Despite this however, Pit People definitely holds its own from the rest of The Behemoth's titles. With countless amounts of unlockables this game will have a grasp on the completionists for a good while. Offering 18 or so unit types the team combinations are quite varied. It is unlikely you will see 2 team compositions back to back and even less likely that these team combinations will have the same gear. Strategy is up to the user and many troops have varying success rates depending on what their teammates are. Team synergy and positioning is the name of the game for Pit People and the game makes it quite obvious. Cupcakes can heal most units in the game but when it comes to the Electrobot unit type they cannot. The player learns that the Robots would do better in a team with Gnomes instead as the Gnomes can heal the Electrobots.

The game has countless hours of playtime. I played it in Xbox Game Preview and decided to get it on steam as well. Even as an Early Access title I would highly recommend this game. The main thing you don't have access to in early access is the complete story. You still get the first handful of missions but the final ones are not in it yet. You still have access to a large quantity of side quests and the online Pvp and Unfair challenge let you test yourself and recieve exclusive rewards for ranking high in the leaderboard among 99 other players. The game is great. The main things I hope for in a future update(s) is a that the story hopefully has more than just one more mission for the cutscenes are great. The game could standalone from its story without a problem, the story is just the icing on top. My biggest wish is hopefully after launch the game continues to update with new items (like a costume for the mascot that makes it look like the Raccoon from Battleblock if that can't become a new unit) and I cross my fingers for a potential new unit. We already have a good handful to select from but I have been playing for a while on Game Preview and I have played around with the units a lot. One more unit would be an awesome surprise. The game is awesome and the devs are just as awesome. They listen to the community unlike many developers nowadays and make good changes in their games. Keep it up The Behemoth.

Posted: February 20, 2017
Product received for free

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I'm happy to add another positive review to the thousands of already existing ones. Let me explain why.

Pit People is a great game and yet another instant hit, like Castle Crashers and Battleblock Theater before it. It might seem like youtuber bait at first glance, with all the "memes" and (literaly) toilet humor, but it's got depth, it's got great customisation and it's got humor that is gonna appeal to all ages. The Behemoth team delivered again (might I mention, they are the only devs with multiple games that all have 95% on steam I know) and I'm looking forward to watching the game evolve and grow.

Now let's get started for the actual review. As you might have already noticed, the aesthetic is very similiar to the previous games. The similarities don't end there either. You will often encounter creatures from the previous games and all kind of other references. These apear mostly in a huge variety of costumes and already mentioned creatures.

So how is Pit People different? Well, almost everything else is new. The combat system is turn based, kind of simplistic but very well implemented. Each creature has its own (mostly passive) abilities and stats, which can further be modified by items and weapons. Latter stands mostly for humans. There are four different types of elemental damage (fire, explosion, poison and ice), but there are also helmets and shields, armor, dodge and many more mechanics, that make fighting interesting (hint - stay AWAY from the farting mushrooms).

Your base of operation is a town where you pick quests, equip items, fight in a pit or simply buy new items and fighters (there is no need for that really, as you frequently get them during wandering anyway). Once you set foot on the huge map, you encounter various groups of enemies, which you can avoid or fight. You can also pick up new quests on the fly, ranging from quite a selection. I've heard there are more than 100 avaliable.

Another big thing I've yet to mention - co-op. It's not 100% required in order to have fun, but it helps to have a partner. You both plan out your turn at the same time and due to much larger number of fighters, it can really get quite chaotic (which suits the theme of the game). However a thing that has been bothering is the camera, which is quite wonky during co-op battles, expecialy on larger maps. But hey, that's why early access exists.

The last thing I'd like to cover is the look, sound and narration. I've already stated the cartoonish look suits the game perfectly and I stand by it. Naration is done by Will Stamper, same old cynical guy you've had to put up with in Battleblock Theater. He does a fantastic job in being both annoying and funny at the same time, pestering your heroes and making smug remarks. The soundtrack is great as well and I haven't gotten bored by it even after 10 hours of play.

Conclusion
Would I recommend Pit People? You bet your ass I would. It might not be 100% finished, expecialy the main story is lacking at the moment and I hope more creatures get introduced during development. Still, the game is well worth its price and has made me chuckle many times (expecialy some of the names). It's just as silly as it is serious and the combination simply works. BIg thumbs up from me!

Rating: It's early access you silly, I can't give a rating.
