Posted: April 30, 2018
Pit People is an RPG with a turn based combat system. The story is completely ridiculous in a good way, filled with unusual creatures, wacky humour and jokey one-liners. You are Horatio, a simple blueberry farmer who the narrator tells us is the most boring person in the world, and you're on a quest to get revenge (I won't spoil why) on a huge bear who floats in space. Things only get stranger from there.

Battles are fun, but tactics are very simplistic, with the focus on making them flow quickly. Most characters only have one kind of attack, so you don’t have any interesting decisions to make about when to use a special ability. The only real control you have during a battle is the positioning of your squad of 6 characters on the hex grid. After you tell your people where to stand, they will decide which enemy to attack. You can influence this slightly by placing them next to a single enemy, denying them the choice. But as there are usually 6+ enemies in a battle, this isn’t always possible.

When they stand next to 2 or more enemies, they will often attack the “wrong” target, for example I saw so many times when they had a choice between an enemy on full health, and an enemy close to death, and they attacked the full health guy instead of taking the kill. Its not always possible to focus fire on what you consider to be the main threat, like a healer or a summoner. Trying to avoid friendly fire with AoE attacks, without precise control over the target area, is problematic.

You can recruit enemies and make them fight for you, by throwing a cage onto the last living enemy during a battle. There are a wide range of characters to choose from. Cupcakes heal allies by throwing their frosting, sacrificing a little of their own health. Vampires can grow wings to move further, and regain health after a successful attack. Pixies have a ranged AoE attack. Octoclops can confuse enemies, resulting in them attacking their friends. Choosing which characters are a good fit for your party is the most tactical thing you can do.

The narrator's voice acting is great and he has some funny, sarcastic lines. But no other character has proper voice acting, instead you hear a nonsensical “hurble burble blah”, which gets annoying after about an hour. Especially when you realise that they only have a couple of variations of their nonsense that they repeat constantly. The music is fantastic and I haven’t suffered from any bugs or crashes.

The main story is quite short, but there are lots of side quests scattered around the world map. After 26 hours I still haven’t done everything, which means a full price purchase is good value. The simple combat feels a bit repetitive after a while, but I was motivated to keep playing because I wanted to see what strange scenario I’d encounter next. In one side quest, a motivational speaker gives his students tips on how to be a better cannibal, while another is set in an arcade where the current champion kills new players before they can beat his high score.

Overall Pit People is a good game, worth checking out, but I just wish the developers had added more tactical depth to the combat to elevate it to being a great game.

Posted: January 23, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Pit People is great fun! A few things definately need to be worked on and tweaked, but hey - for an Early Access game from a well-trusted developer, this is looking real good.

Essentially, this plays like a modernized quirky version of Final Fantasy Tactics. Everything you want from a tactical turn-based party battle management game is pretty much here. Lots of collectibles, both functional and cosmetic. Definately has a good chunk of different kinds of units (the deep customization really helps here in making it feel even more extensive). The online play is off to a great start - they are doing it right.

One thing I'll say right up front is that I'm thoroughly confused about people complaining about the short 'main story line' right now. First off, that's the tutorial folks - there is more coming. Secondly, there are over 100 missions WITH storyline dialogue that will certainly take you over a dozen hours to complete. Thats a conservative estimate, too.



First off, the camera desperately needs work with local co-op. They already said they would fix this as a high priority, so fine. Secondly, while the map is , it sort of, well, lacks a strong flavor. I think it feels very flat, and simply uniformly dotted with either small buildings or landscape chunks. While the map artwork is good and that is set, I'd like to see a bit of TLC go into making the terrain feel better in general. I hear keyboard and mouse controls are abismal, so be warned (I didn't try them because of this warning). Lastly, I think the music is fantastic, although it is not very artistically cohesive. One minute it is high fantasy classical-esque, then it's western cowboy music, and yet another it is techno-ish. Don't get me wrong, it is all good, but sometimes this difference made me wonder about how it was all chosen and put together.

Another thing I'd like to mention is the difficulty. In five hours, I had never lost. Mind you, I didn't play on 'insane' difficulty, but still. I finished the 'main story', which is just a tutorial or prequal to the actual story (this version ends where it appears the real story begins). I finished 11 quests and a few other things. With only a few hours in, I'm going to chalk this up to early game build-up. Plus, I think online play will likely be a different story. I did play online, but only very briefly.

Lastly, I felt that single player mode felt much better than local co-op. Local co-op was fun, but the screen was almost too busy, and I felt there was even less strategy. It was like 'just send the units wherever they are next to an enemy' kind of thing. It worked, which is the questionable part.


+Fantastically addictive combat; everything is done really really right
+Although I didn't like or as much as everyone else (I felt they were shallow), this game has really hit the mark with the depth it brings, respectively
+Controller support is great
+Don't be fooled - there is a ton of content right now; yes the 'main story' (ie. tutorial) is less than 2 hours - I assure you this will change; further, there are over 100 side quests and some 1,300 collectibles (I could see 15-20 hours easy - as an estimate)
+There are various parts of this game to enjoy, and it smartly lets you choose - you can turn on AI to actually do all the battling for you, which is great if you just like the larger aspects of the game


-Difficulty is questionable - I can't seem to ever lose
-Local co-op is just too busy to be enjoyable; it hardly felt strategic, either
-While the music is great, there is no artistic cohesion; this may be fine, albeit weird
-Overall, I'd like it to feel like there is more strategy involved than what I've felt so far

Posted: March 7, 2018
There are already some longer Negative reviews here which essentially echo how I feel about Pit People.

I bought in EA around a year ago and waited until launch to play.

It starts out with the charm offensive set to Ludicrous. The first hour or so contains some amazing animation and acting that rivals the best cartoons of today. Unfortately this outstanding presentation is paired with some of the shallowest and dullest combat I've encountered. It bored me to tears as each fight can last upwards of 10 minutes and it never really gets more complicated than your first battle. Other than some boss fights or quest mobs which may require you to break through a door or a wall, or face a swarm of spawning enemies, it's the same. You simply try to position your guys and click end turn and hope that the round goes well. You're bombarded with EXP gains and LVL UP fanfare in combat yet your heroes don't seem to develop or progress. They don't unlock interesting abilities as far as I'm aware, at least not in my time with the game. The map appears to be packed with interesting locations yet they remain useless window dressing. You gather a metric butt-tonne of loot from completing quests and fighting map mobs, and while it seems like there are many items, there aren't many different items other than the visual gag of it being a fence post or a lolly pop. There are plenty of entertaining cosmetics which have no effect and I believe you need to sacrifice valuable armor in order to wear them.

I was bored to death after around 5 hours. The combat is so shallow and directionless, and is presented in a frustratingly clunky manner making it confusing when shuffling around 6 heroes. An auto-battler is available in options allowing the cpu to take your turns for you. It seems more efficient to just allow the AI to do it's thing unless you need to take over to perform a specific activity such as capturing an enemy. You can enable or disable it whenever at will, so that's a good thing? It's the only reason I played more than two hours.

If there were a tonne more quests and a... I was gonna say a fleshed out combat system, but combat system would be better than this. I'm reminded of how Endless Legend played out it's manual battles, except there you could actually direct which unit to try to attack, and I still ended up automising them because of how shallow it felt.

Perhaps it's more enjoyable in co-op or pvp. I could see this working well on the Switch or on the sofa with a partner for some mindless banter. If they can vibe with the at-times crass humor, then I'd particularly recommend for players completely new or unfamiliar to gaming. But if you were hoping for an evenly weighted, hilarious strategy game, then Pit People feels like it's missing a leg.

Was it blown off in to space by a giant space bear? Possibly.

[edits for minor typos]

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
[]

>> tl;dr:
Same old but very new fantastic Behemoth game, but missing something important that will hopefully come in the development process. 8.5/10

----
>> For ape creatures who read:
Although there are many, many things about this game that make it just as good as any other Behemoth-- given, better than most other games out there right now-- I'm going to start this review with my one main criticism that I hope the Devs were already considering, which is that:

The battle dynamics, although at first really fun and definitely well-thought through by the devs, feels like it lacks an extra important layer of depth to keep the replayability of the game and the challenge of the battles exciting. To better explain this, the depth of the game's battle strategy can be broken down into:

- Organize and modify your team at base [making a compatible party suitable to your playstyle].
- Strategically place your units on the field of battle for optimum damage, tank-ability and utility.
- [Sometimes] manage which enemies you target to save the last enemy to be recruited.

These two and a half only layers of the battle scenarios are strangely enough to keep you playing the game for a long time. But, I do admit, it eventually can become redundant, and maybe even boring. There are only so many combinations of your "team set-up vs. enemy team set-up"s you can go through before it starts to become repetitive routine strategy.

What I can only hope for is that the Devs add in at least one sort of extra layer of depth to the battle-dynamic which they add in through the development process; A layer like:

- In-battle item use.
- Added character-type activatable or auto-activated abilities (ex: leap for archers, charge for cyclops, etc).
- Talent tree sort-of-thing for personalization of each character you own.
- Something more brilliant that only a Behemoth dev can come up with.

A layer that can take you out of your routine comfort in a battle to yell "F***, I hate it when that f***er does that" or "F***, I love it when my little character dude does that".

Anyway, despite that one main criticism, the game really does nail everything you can love about a Behemoth game and more: Comedy, re-playability, well-constructed world, killer music, the always loved animation style, the unpredictability of every story-quest. Other reviews capture the best parts of the game in more depth.

All in all, 8.5/10. I just think it needs that one bit of spice.

Posted: January 20, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
See written review below or watch it here:
YouTube™ Video: Pit People - Review (Early Access) 
Views: 6,001
Pit People is a strategy adventure game with turn-based combat brought to you by the developers who also made BattleBlock Theater and Castle Crashers.

TL;DR: SKIP TO CONCLUSION!

Pit People is a strategy adventure game with turn-based combat brought to you by the developers who also made BattleBlock Theater and Castle Crashers. Pit People is a different genre of game than their previous games, but the character style and sense of humour is consistent in Pit People as well.

You create a team to with up to 6 characters on it, and battle against the enemies in turn based combat until one team is defeated or your objective is accomplished. I’ve been playing mostly on normal difficulty. I always heal to full health before each encounter, and so far I haven’t found the fights too challenging. I tried a mission on the insane difficulty, and if it wasn’t for my characters leveling up (to restore them to full hp) mid-combat, I would have died for sure. You can bring more than one of the same character type at a time, but the cupcakes don’t heal other cupcakes. If all of your characters die, you lose some gold and maybe some items, but there is no perma-death, so the game is forgiving in that sense.

During your turn you lock in all of your moves at once before ending the turn. If you make a mistake with the move, you can always change it before you end your turn. You are given plenty of time to lock in your moves. The combat has some random factors, like dodging, crits, and most notably which target you actually hit. You have control over your team’s movement, but you have no say as to which target you will actually attack. For example: if you place a character in a hex that’s adjacent to multiple targets, your character can attack any of the available targets, and not necessarily the target you want. There is friendly fire with AE abilities, and you can accidentally heal enemies as well.

You journey out from town to explore, or complete missions by driving around the map in a nitro-boosted wagon...that poops. There are enemies everywhere, but it’s nice that you can easily avoid combat by stunning them and running past if you want to. It’s a lot better than having to flee combat, since fleeing makes all of your characters take damage, and drops your items on the ground.

You can play by yourself against the AI, or in two player co-op either online or locally. There is voice and text chat In co-op, so you can coordinate easier. Both you and your ally take your turns at the same time, and there are a lot more enemies to compensate for there being a second player. There is also an arena where you can battle against other players in 2v2 battles or compete for scores on the leaderboard against AI.

In almost every battle, you have the option to recruit the last remaining enemy by capturing them with a net and cage. I think it’s awesome that you can capture any enemy you come across, and that it never fails to capture. It’s also neat that you get to keep all of the equipment that they are wearing when you are recruit them. Sometimes I wish I could capture more than one enemy per battle though. There are different species that have special abilities, and other species that can be equipped with gear. There are no skill points to allocate, but the equipment let’s you customize each character.
















If you’re hoping for story, there isn’t much in the way of a story campaign just yet, but there are still plenty of quests to do. Playing against the AI as single player is fun, but it feels repetitive after a while. The co-op is enjoyable, but I wasn’t able to try the PvP since I got impatient waiting for it to pop. Overall, it’s a nicely polished turn-based strategy game that’s not too punishing, and it has an abundance of collectibles, and the sense of humour you would expect from a Behemoth title. I have no regrets with the purchase, and I look forward to more of the story being added.

If you like my reviews, please feel free to join my Steam group, and follow my curations
You can also view this review on my website

As a big fan of BattleBlock Theater and Castle Crashers I was really looking forward to trying Pit People out. It’s quite amazing how they can make a game which shares a lot of the good things with the previous games even though its gameplay is completely different. You can definitely tell that it was made by The Behemoth when you see the art style, hear the music and experience the humor in Pit People.

I really like turn based games so being able to play one in co-op with another player was an amazing experience. The amount of story and conversations was absolutely satisfying. It was mostly something we could laugh about. No story heavy "you must pay attention all the time" kind of game. Those are better for single player games anyway.

The turn based combat is very special compared to other turn based games I have played before. Mostly because it’s a lot about your movement, rather than % chance to hit or miss. That makes the gameplay very simple and easy to learn, but at the same time getting really good takes some knowledge of units and practice.

I made a spoiler-free StingeReview video of Pit People and you can check it out here:



If you are searching for a funny co-op game to play with your friend, you can never go wrong with a game from The Behemoth. I would recommend you to get all of their games. It’s really worth it!

Posted: January 14, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
* Do remember this is Early Access, and as such the value of this title as I review it. My review is based mostly upon the mechanics and what is here, rather than a story that has yet to unfold.

Behemoth once again delivers a class A experience with their one of a kind over the top humor. A robust and expansive world, a myriad of memorable characters, and enough loot to make your butt fall off. Pit People has a diverse and simplistic combat style accessible to players new to the strategy RPG format. Yet still it goes so much deeper than that to the true strategist. Offering near limitless customization this game allows for any playstyle. From people who like to hide behind ponies, to those who crave the boom boom, to those who simply love rainbows. Whether you are a tried and true fan of Behemoth and their past works, or a newcomer to the party, I do believe this is shaping up to be one of the best games of the coming year.

That being said, if you are looking strictly to play a large story filled with conquest, glory, and pain, Pit People may not be the title you want...YET. As it sits you will not run short of things to do, amongst them being PVP, Co-Op shenanigans, loot hunting, side quests, and dying with laughter. This is not a typical gotcha early access. What you get right now, without the story, is well beyond the price value. Behemoth made the right decision to let us get the jump start on such a sweet game.


Pros:

+ Excellent Voiceover
+ Wonderful and Diverse Art
+ A+++ Soundtrack
+ Fluid and Simple Combat
+ Deep Customization
+ Fantastic Price Point
+ Contains the Color Teal
+ Fantastic and Lag Free PVP Servers
+ Co-Op Couch Play (Bless you Behemoth for keeping the old ways alive.)
+ Early Access (This game is well and far beyond what I expected to get at day 1 early access.)
+ Flawless Controller Play

Cons (Most Likely To Disappear by Full Release) :

- Early Access (This is only a con because my body is ready for the whole thing.)
- Difficulty Curve for The Unsuspecting/New Player (A.I.'s beyond story mode is a CHALLENGE, PVP garnishes more experienced SRPG Players)
- Keyboard/Mouse Controls Need Refined
- Can't Buy The Soundtrack

Posted: July 25, 2018
If you're a turn based strategy/tactics fan with a friend who hasn't played such games, you probably want a couple copies of this game.

I'm into XCOM, Civ, and all of that nerdy goodness. I've been playing Pit People with a friend who is not, and we're enjoying Pit People enough that I'm pretty sure Pit People will act as her gateway into deeper TBS games.

The combat is tactical and challenging enough to be interesting to someone like me, even if it's a little on the light side, but the HP values are so high that you generally have time to respond to units in untenable positions and get them back to healers without them dying so long as you stay on top of things. This is all clear enough as to be obvious to someone with virtually no experience in this style of combat. Unit variety and different team synergies are great, with plenty for more experienced players to sink their teeth into.

The tutorialing is absolutely awful. The game seems unfinished in this regard. There's so many aspects of the game that're never explained, or explained poorly, leaving you to gradually realise how things work. This problem is compounded by poor wiki support. Normally when faced with this kind of confusion I'd hit the wiki, but in this case I was dissappointed. This didn't prevent us from enjoying the game, but expect to be confused for a long time.

The humour is very lol random, penguin of doom absurdism. It'll be a matter of taste. We loved it. When Yosef did that thing he did, we properly cracked up laughing. Some people will find this intolerable, and I doubt those people could enjoy the game. Look at the screenshots. If people firing hotdog bows and wearing celery helmets, penguins dressed as purple lions, doge hats and fish swords seems like it might be appealing, give it a go, but if this stuff turns you off then you're probably not going to be able to power through it, because this style of humour is a constant feature in the game. The game has tons of character.

For us, this was exactly the sort of chill co-op game we were looking for.

If you wanna get a TBS game with endless humor, Pit People is for you.

I've forever been a groupie of Behemoth, savoring their humor that drops from the sky like anvils in a Looney Tunes episode, all while dressed in their over-the-top, crayon-colored antics. It's like they harnessed the power of absurdity and crammed it into their games. Some strange power prevented me from playing their next games. However, my desire was built up over the years, until the time has come for Pit People. So I told myself, “Well, I don’t wanna play a long game, lets pick it up and everything will be fine”. Oh boy I was wrong... Too much content as you can see from my playtime.

Well, the main story is shorter than a cat's attention span, but the side-quests, oh yes, the side-quests. There are more of them than you can shake a stick at – over 100. Each is filled with hilariously absurd tales turning your brain upside down. But the real gem is the main plot. What made me wet my pants are the boneheaded antics of the protagonists and everything about the antagonists, especially the narrator (the head honcho of bad guys). If Behemoth ever needs an extra narrator, they should totally give that guy a raise!

Ok let’s talk about the gameplay for Honey’s sake. This game is like a wacky, turn-based strategy cartoon where your team and the enemies are placed on hexagons (who needs squares, anyway?).


Your teammates are a motley crew, ranging from humans with all sorts of wacky weapon abilities to creatures you capture, like some Pokémon fever dream. Some of the abilities include stabbing, stunning, freezing (aka stunning but with ice), smacking enemies like baseballs, creating EXPLOSIONS, and a whole lot more.

There are endless combinations you can do with the crew. But you can’t just pick anything from your dirty sleeves and expect to conquer the world. Especially not in Insane mode. Oh boy, this one really made me sweaty. You'll need a balanced, versatile team to face every threat under the sun (or the hexagon, as it were).

Now that you're a pro at assembling your squad, let's dive into the missions themselves. Most of the time, the objective is simple: "massacre them all." But you'll also come across missions like "protect those folks until X," "get to the other side pronto while tangling with foes," and a never-ending list of craziness. The main missions are even more unique and you can tell the developers worked on them like they had a bone-shaped biscuit dangling in front of their noses.

I managed to snag 100% of the achievements, and let me tell you, the most challenging part was finding someone to play versus in the multiplayer. It is dead like the bear that crashed into our frail planet. However, if you find someone to play with (versus and even co-op) you will enjoy it even more than tackling Insane Mode.

Posted: November 10, 2019
Pit people is a game I really want to recommend, but has a lot of major problems
that will keep it down.

To start off I was looking through common criticism of the game. and I found the most common 2 problems, is the game being repetitive, and the game not being very in depth, or having shallow gameplay. The reason people find this game so repetitive is because this game was designed so you will win with any strategy, and with any teamcomp in pve. even though this game has all the different units with all their different strengths and weaknesses, the average player has no real opportunity to explore this in pve, they can't really explore how in depth the game can be, with all the different strategies and teamcomps you can do. the pve both never ramps high enough if difficulty, or at least not often enough for the average player to come across it, and even the few times the game does get difficult enough, if they do have trouble with it, there best choice won't be counter pick units, it will be their highest level units. The game actually incentives using the same teamcomp because of the leveling system. your highest level units will outperform your lower level ones. so the game punishes you from trying something new. No ♥♥♥♥ everyone finds the game repetitive. The entire leveling system is just poor game design, and the way the game counters this is by making pve overall way easier than it needs to be, so you can get away with just about anything. so people will either mindlessly through stuff together, and just place everything in range to attack something. or they will stick with all their highest level units, and never explore other units. This is why people think the game is shallow and repetitive. either keep doing what works, and just do whatever because you can. insane mode is hardly more difficult and gives hardly any more loot, and that loot probably won't be what you are looking for, so there isn't really a point in ever turning it on. and permadeath mode is just grindy. because you need to keep capturing new stuff.

this game really really shines in its pvp. pvp is the best place to try out the game mechanics, and strategies of this game. the fact that both teams will be the same level, and same slot worth of units. you can't just bring in whatever and have it work all the time, and you can't just go to your high levels when you struggle. it's about just actual teamcomp and positioning if you want to do well. However this game has almost no incentive to play pvp, and because pvp is so different the pve is unappealing to a lot of people. all you can get is some extra item drops that you can also get from unfair challenges. The leaderboard isn't an incentive because it just shows who plays the most pvp, or unfair challenge that day. also there is a huge barrier of entry of actually exploring the pvp of this game, because you have to play a ton of pve first, to get enough different units and items, to actually start exploring interesting teamcomps and strategies. and if you actually want to play some pvp, good luck finding anyone to play with, the pvp lobby is dead. once I had sat in the pvp lobby for 8 hours straight, 3 days back to back and found 0 people to play pvp with in that time, it is incredibly sad.

given what the pve system is, I think that the quests and missions are decently well done for what the game is, even though most of it still suffers from how repetitive the game inherently is. though lack any replayability. humor is subjective, it's not all good, but I think at least through most of the main story, and a decent amount of the side quests the humor lands(but definitely not all of it). but the side missions lack replayability, and the main story isn't worth playing through more than twice. The only incentive to redo missions/quests is if you want to capture all the items, but considering most items are just cosmetic, there are so many. it's not an incentive for most people. so outside of pvp the game doesn't have very much replayability, unless you really like capturing tinted units.
also the game just feels incomplete. it has unobtainable items, it has 3 empty music slots for the town music. a lot of the animations don't feel finished, like the ranged human melee attack. among other stuff. the game just isn't finished and the behemoth has made it seem like they don't care about adding anything to this game anymore, their most recent update. update 7, was also a horrible update. adding the worst quest in the game, along with some other bad quests. along with adding bear blood rain randomly causing random damage and movement, they made sure it didn't happen on any quests they didn't want it to, but they decided to let it happen in pvp. making it so pvp matches can be decided by something completely out of the players control. along with 2 new cyclops weapons, thousand shards, and the storm stick, which are way better than anything else in pvp, and now what's left of this games pvp community calls them cancer sticks. and makes us wonder if the devs ever bothered play testing.

even though pvp is the best part of the game, it isn't perfect. excluding cancer sticks, pvp still isn't terribly well balanced, once you play extensively you will see some team comps are just clearly way better than others. a lot of items and units are completely outclassed by other stuff in pvp. units you choose as leader is the least balanced thing in the game, you have no reason to hero anything other than mushrooms cupcakes, and occasionally humans. Rainbow horses are unhealthy for pvp, they are literally just rng units, it makes it so rng can determine the outcome of the match pretty much no matter what. yes the game is inherently heavily rng, but unicorns take it to too much of a degree where it's almost a coin flip as to who wins if there is one in play. and gnomes are almost entirely useless in pvp, pvp has problems forsure on a competitive level.

There once was a time when I thought this game could come back, a time when I thought if just the behemoth added new update 8, that focused almost entirely on pvp. making the leaderboards better measure skill instead of play time, make pvp easier to get into, and make it more competitive. increase incentives to play pvp, I once though that would be enough to bring some life into the game, but I feel this is no longer the case, update 7 stepped on what was left of a dying community. I know multiple competitive pvpers who leave this game, and will never return because of how bad that update was, this game was objectively better pre update 7. Early access also killed this game, most of what this game has to offer existed during early access. The height of the community existed during early access, it started dropping before the game came out, and never picked up since, and at this point never will, as much as I want it too. I wasn't even able to play back then either, as I had a mac, I figured this game would be out on mac by the time of its official release, it wasn't not, and still isn't out on mac or linux. so there is another potential player base gone, keeping this game's numbers even lower. The behemoth has for the most part moved on from this game development wise. to work on alien hominid invasions, so we aren't getting anything new anytime soon anyways, if ever.

So would I recommend this game? I really really want to say yes, even with the problems the pvp has, there are still hours upon hours of fun to be had in pvp. I myself have well more than 2000 hours in pvp alone, and that was all well after the majority of this game's community has left, but I know the community has only died further since then. realistically, it is impossible for you to get anything out of pvp anymore with how dead it is. so if I'm to be in good faith I can only really recommend this game for its pve. which all it really has going for it's kinda funny story mode, and a few decent side quests, and that's is it.

Posted: November 23, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Pit people is a turn-based tactical pokemonesque rpg about positioning and throwing people into the dungeon gathering volunteers to fight for you. There's hundreds of items to collect and missions to do. Almost every unit you see can be captured and put to death the test against people or AI. I personally prefer fighting other people, as of now I have about 1,500 victories in pvp. Although you don't gain experience when fighting players, you do get rewards and more points than you would in the unfair arena if you're working towards gold rankings. If fighting isn't your style, you can always spectate a battle and get rich by watching battles between players. You may even find me in there destroying someones team.

If the game is feeling too easy for you, you can turn on the insane difficulty and enable permadeath and bring your warriors into the pit.

Main story line can be completed in under 18 hours(Even faster if you don't want to have fun) while also doing some other quests. Doing only main quests finishes the game quickly but the story itself is told nonsensically which is the norm for Behemoth games and I liked it. There is a New Game+ if you decide to also complete the monsters and quests

Though this is in the same universe as battleblock and Castle Crashers it doesnt continue their storyline at all(bummer) but you can still get their cosmetics as freebies for owning and supporting them +

Gameplay is Hex Grid tactic\turn based RPG though it differs from most due ot the fact that you are unable to control which target you are able to hit UNLESS you position your characters correctly. It also relies hits on RNG than the others. Initially I thought that it was hard to play due to RNG but the game is mostly about postioning\ placement and not about levels.

Pros-
- Plot is full of laughter and fun times
- VA Will Stamper is is back from BBT!?!?!
- Mining friendly game. no issues at all or even FPS drops
- Auto mode is nice addition since there are scenarios where it is pretty much a sure win
- Free Cosmetics if you own previous BEHEMOTH games


Cons
- Story though complete lacks a bit of continuity
- Levels don't seem to do anything much. More health but it really does not seem to actually do anything
- Saving system can be better explained(I had to check HOW TO SAVE)
- Items feel a bit redundant due to stats being nearly the same with each other

Posted: June 29
As a Behemoth fan (played Alien Hominid HD, Castle Crashers, Battleblock Teather and now this) I can say that this game has the same kind of effort and love all the other games got from the studio.

The soundtrack, style and narration are top-notch, and they heavily carry the game, and The Behemoth proves they can improve on the comedic style of their games. In my opinion, it's one of the better turn-based games of the 2010-2020 decade, and I finished this twice back in the Xbox One release.

However, the main complaint a lot of people had (and still have) is the fact that the game plays very differently from all the other Behemoth titles: this is the first one that is a turn-based strategy game. This is where the takes get spicy, because I acknowledge that turn-based strategy is not for everyone, and it will definitely filter a lot of people that are used to the other Behemoth titles.

If you are ok with turn-based strategy, do get this game, it's really fun and you can literally spend hundreds of hours on this. If you can't handle such gameplay, I'd recommend you to instead watch the story from YouTube, instead of comitting to the grind.

Posted: December 1, 2023
Like what everyone else is saying, the gameplay does get repetitive. The way I look at it is this:

The positives:
Incredibly funny and engaging story with likable characters and "laugh out loud" moments
Fun world design with unique enemies
Gameplay can be intensely fun at times

Negatives:
With Pit People, there is no particular incentive to come back and play. The combat is the same no matter who you fight, and the only real variety in the weapons/combat mechanics is the random effects or the weapons' appearances.

My biggest issue is that the battles take ages to complete! If each encounter ended up being a fraction of the length that they end up being, I'd recommend this game in a heartbeat. It would mean I'd want to run up to the random enemies in the wild, and it would mean I'd want to do the side missions. Instead, I look at each encounter as a commitment that I have to deal with instead of a fun experience that I get to have. I wanted to love this game, seriously, but I can't bring myself to play it over other games I could be playing instead.

TL;DR: I'd recommend watching a sped-up walkthrough so you still get to experience the amazing story without committing hours to stretched-out gameplay that could've been a few minutes long.

Posted: February 3, 2022
Simple at surface level but still my favorite turn-based RPG ever.

I don't play a lot of them, not a weeb so that narrows it all down pretty hard, but i grew up playing Tactics as a kid and I've dabbled in a few other weird ones like "Eternal Eyes", but they all seem to have pretty boring flaws.

Pit People is like a simplified turn-based-tactical (I'm gonna say tbt from now on, shush) fused with a collect-a-thon, with no arbitrary boundaries in team composition. Outside of the small percent of main-story content, you are free to create any team composition you desire.

You start with a predetermined story team and very quickly you're thrust out into the open world, no leveled zones or limitations, you can go wherever you want (barring story levels) and capture whatever units you want. No unit types are locked behind progression, so you can have literally anything you want before you pick up the story again after the tutorial. I started the story about 90 hours or so in.

The game gets pretty simple when you get a powerful team, regardless of whether or not you're going with a "meta" so it's suggested you turn on Insane Mode (in the capital city) pretty early on. It beefs up the encounters and adds far more enemies, so it's a good challenge. One of the biggest complaints I'd often see were people saying the game was braindead easy when running meta teams (Like two Troll Moms and a Unicorn) but every game comes with it's overpowered, boring builds. Pit People excels best when you stray as far from the meta as you can, building strange, niche support teams like 6 Zombies 1 Mascot, or 4 robots 2 gnomes.

NOTE ABOUT CO-OP: While I adore this game alone, it's substantially better with a friend. Co-Op play doubles your team size and therefore your enemy team sizes, letting you have 12 team slots to customize. This game has local co-op and local shares the same bank of units, so if you plug in a second controller you can play co-op by yourself and utilize a huge army of units. I rarely see people mention this and it adds so much to the game if you start to get bored!

Quick word on PvP: You're not going to have a great time looking for PvP games. Since the game launched, people almost exclusively use really boring meta builds, so if you want to PvP, do so with a friend and lay down some house rules. Some people will tell you double Spider/Archer isn't broken but they're also lying to you.

Posted: May 14, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Another classic Behemoth game. Like the others, Pit People is an amazing co-op game and can also be played singleplayer. Will Stamper from Battleblock Theater returns as the narrator in this game again. The game is full of Behemoth humor, along with delivering a nice challenge. The strategy behind the game is what makes it so interesting. You don't choose who your units attack, so if a unit is in range of multiple enemies it'll select which one to attack randomly. Some units are more effective, and weaker against others. This makes the positioning of your units are important and is what makes the game fun. There's a ton of different customization options for different types of helmets and weapons as well.

All in all, a great game. 10/10 - hard to pass up for $15.

Posted: January 14, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
In Pit People you are a farmer and also a father who has lost his home and son. As you continue on, you dive deeper into insanity as you massacre entire populations of towns. You witness as innocent people are kidnapped in front of your eyes while you can't help them. You capture people to kill more efficiently. You let them die but bring them back to life to have them suffer the fate of death again and again. You kill people just for the hat they have on their heads. The story told is dark and chilling, showing us the struggles of Horatio in this unique setting. Pit People is possibly one of the greatest horror games of all time and will remain my favorite.

Posted: February 2, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Pit people is a hilarious, turn based strategy game. It WILL have you laughing the whole damn time. What the game offers so far is a few hours of highly enjoyable gameplay co-op or solo.

I would recommend getting a friend to play with though. As far as the "main" story goes I completed it in less than 2 hours and that was with some messing around and exploring. There are tons of side quests though and the Pit where you can do 2v2's or face the AI. You will gain daily rewards for winning in the Pit.

The best part about Pit People is that it is genuinely funny and has the biggest ♥♥♥♥ of a narrator that I have ever had the pleasure of listening to. The narrator is a giant bear that tries to ruin your characters lives in the funniest, worst kind of ways. Every third or so time you return to your city, the bear will pick it up and move it somewhere else. Which isn't all bad because it keeps things fresh, but the nerve of some people, am I right? Just know that he will be intervening and "helping" you out in any way he can.

PROS
Actual Humour
"Easy To Learn Hard To Master Combat"
Great Teambuilder
Co-op
Tons of Loot and Cosmetics to Collect
Great SoundTrack

CONS
Sort of Annoying Inventory Selection (I only used a mouse)
Took Me Around 2ish Hours to Complete the Main Story Quests (EARLY ACCESS)
RNG (not terrible xD)


Overall Pit People definitely isn't a finished product hence the EARLY ACCESS, but there are still hours of fun to be had and plenty of laughs to well....laugh. If you are wanting a great game and are willing to wait a little while for more content then I would suggest picking it up. If you are into solo gamplay and want a story driven experience, I would probably wait until a few more patches or the full release some time this year.

Posted: October 29, 2020
This game is a hard one to review, whille i love the art and humor of behemoth, this game also has a lot of problems on it's core design, let's go on parts.

Story and side quests, honestly the saving grace of this game for me, some missions are boring but those are few, mostly of them have that humor from behemoth the we know and love.

The units, after about 1 hour gameplay or even less you probally have seen all that has to be seen about units, it get's even worse when you realize that running a team of full humans is better than mixing all of the already small roster of units.

loot doesn't get much better, you do have stuff that changes combat for an extent but also falls short since when you got one of those the rest are pure cosmetic so when you get a new sword "oh a new sword that do the exact same amount of damage that the one i already have but it looks better, neat"

Exploration, gets repetitive real fast, after a while you just stop looking for stuff and head straight to quests.

NOW the combat, oh boy THE COMBAT, THE STRATEGY that this game lacks. I can't really even express how BORING combat is, it was fun for the frist 1 hour of gameplay with the narrator going nuts when you got multiple kills etc, but when you realize it's going to be like that all the time with no new mechanics being introduced as you progress the magic ends. it's so simple, there's no real strategy other than making sure your guys don't get in a position where they would have to chose targets, but at the same making sure that your opponent have to choose between two or more of your units. For those who don't know, you move your units but you can't choose who to attack, the unit does that.

Difficulty: there's basicly none, and that's why most ''hard'' missions are just a bunch of waves rushing at you, and this aggravates the gameplay since combat is already so simplist.

Final point, if you don't mind using the same units over and over again, the super casual aproach to an stratagy game, you will have a great time on the pit, otherwise avoid it.

Oh and yeah this game has online and local co-op so that's always a plus.

Posted: January 8, 2019
Pit People is a good game. I really did enjoy everything about it when I first started playing it.

QUICK SUMMARY:
When it comes to the plot and the writing, the game is clearly not trying to take itself seriously. This is one of the strenghts of the game: It's silly and absurd, similar to that of Borderlands 2. The artstyle and the voice acting of the game, definately adds to the silly nature of the experience, and it skillfully made. The gameplay, while not perfect, is still polished and good.

IN DEPTH CRITICISM:

The game itself mostly consists of turn-based and positionally based combat wherein you recuit different types of warriors and races, and equip them with gear that you can also collect. All with their weaknesses and strenghts. The biggest criticism I have for the game, is honestly that some types units are just too weak while others are too strong, and that some weapons are just... straight upgrades. I do appreciate how most weapons are just sidegrades though, but in the long run you realise that having a lot of armor is USUALLY better than having higher attack. The gameplay style that annoys me the most is the team that has a lot of mortar humans, or unicorns, and they all sit in the back trying to attack your units. The most efficient way to counter this is usually to rush them down, but very often they will still end up killing one or two of your characters. The level-up mechanic is a welcome addition to the game as it makes it possible to beat, but it also makes many battles far too easy. One of the reasons why I think it has been implemented is that they sometimes swarm you with many more units than your own lineup can hold. Sometimes in the wild you may encounter teams that consist of 8 character slots, while you only have 6. If you didn't regain your health through the level-up mechanic many of these fights would be too difficult. I feel like there must be a sweet spot must be there in between.

The world map as a mechanic first got me really confused. I thought that it was randomly generated, as every couple of runs you did into the wild you got put into a completely new place. But as time went on I slowly understood that, the map is just switching between a couple of presets. This is completely fine but a new player has no way to understand this, if they're not paying enough attention. Chances are they are going to be more interested in the scenery, the art, quests, dodging the enemies rather than comparing the world map across several hours of gameplay. There is also a fog of war mechanic each time you get put into the map, which is also part of the confusion. If I have been in a location in a specific world map 10 times, why doesn't the game reflect it? Once we've been in a place it's a given that we should be able to see it more clearly, and enjoy how the game looks instead of looking at ugly gray clouds.

As for the story quests, I won't spoil anything. The final couple of quests, that were added in the full release, were also very good but in some ways they seemed rushed. Especially the cutscenes. If you compare the cutscenes early on in the game and the ones in the final quest, you would think you are playing a beta version of the game still. They clearly rushed things in order to finish it up for the official release date: Which is something I can understand, especially for an indie studio, so I am more forgiving than some people.

Multiplayer is great fun, you can co-op the story mode or play against random people online. The one thing missing in it though, is to see how many other people are online OR searching for a PVP opponent. I waited an hour several times only to find nobody else was searching. Maybe include a link to a steam group, or discord, so you can find someone to play against? Something that also isn't made clear either is wether or not your fighter's level matters at all in PVP.

Posted: May 13, 2018
Product received for free

Overview
Pit People is a turn-based strategy that is full of crude and sarcastic humor. The battles have been rid of as much RNG as possible, while some is left in to balance the game. During the player’s journeys, they will come across a variety of people and creatures to recruit. It is so much fun to see a new creature that is able to be captured. I haven’t had as much assembling a team since Pokémon. The graphics are comprised of 2D, hand-drawn, art. The music is enjoyable, but the sound effects really shine. The story is constantly poking fun at itself in a sarcastic and crude way. The story is absurd, but is so crazy that it always left me wanting to find out more.


The game starts the player out in a turn-based battle, which is the most prevalent phase of gameplay. The player may move the members of their team into the range of enemies to attack. Unlike other turn-based strategies, if the player moves a character near multiple enemies, the game will decide which enemy to attack. This makes positioning an important mechanic that the player must constantly focus on so that they attack their targets efficiently. That is one form of RNG in the game. The other form is ranged unit attacks. Ranged units will attack a target within a certain range. Depending upon how far away they are from the target, ranged units will either miss or could hit anyone around the target, including an ally. Thankfully, if the player is playing strategically they can avoid most of the RNG. The main resource in one of these battles is hit points. Every attack takes away hit points from the target. Some attacks have elemental attributes attached to them which are batter against certain creatures.

Shortly after starting the game, the player will be given the ability to capture opponents. I was initially hesitant about this feature, as many games have tried the capturing mechanic and failed. To my surprise, I found myself enjoying the battle system quite a bit. The player buys cages at the gate before they leave the city. After beating most of an enemy team to a pulp, the player is allowed to use a unit with the ranged net ability to capture the last enemy. This consumes a cage. The player doesn’t own the creature yet, as the player may drop the cage if they flee from a battle and must be recollected. Once the player is near the city, they can deposit their loot. This includes any captured creatures.

The city is the game’s menu. In the city the player is able to listen to music tracks, play against their friends or strangers, turn on insane mode, shop at the market, and visit the house. The two areas the player will spend most time in are the house and the market. The market allows the player to buy new weapons, cosmetic hats, and expensive mercenary units. This location is meant to allow the player to offload some excess gold. The house allows the player to delve into the RPG equipment system and cosmetic creature customization.

Every human fighter is able to be customized with a ton of cosmetics and equipment lookouts. While humans don’t have any special abilities during the fights, their special ability is that they can equip a variety of weapons. These include rapiers, swords, huge swords, and mallets. Rapiers are a bit weak, but they attack twice. Swords attack once and deal moderate damage. Huge swords deal a ton of damage, but they make characters go over the weight limit which reduces every stat. Mallets deal extra damage to enemies with armor which are in the form of helmets. Helmets greatly reduce the damage taken by swords, but take are weak to mallets. The ranged weapons include guns, double axes, a short bow, a medium bow, and a long bow. The guns and double axes can attack when in melee range, unlike the bows. Small bows aren’t very powerful but shoot the six times. Bow shots decrease as the bow gets larger. Bows only shoot half of their shots if the character is moved on their turn. Weapons also have special abilities, while rare weapons have elemental and debuff effects. These rare weapons don’t do as much damage or lose some of the weapon’s base abilities. They can be helpful when completing quests that are against a specific enemy type.

After choosing a quest, a side quest, arranging the party, and buying items, the player is able to journey out into the overworld. While in the overworld, the player will see enemies running around. If the player runs into one then a turn-based battle starts. It is nice that they are avoidable. The player also has a cannon that will stun enemies so that they don’t move on the overworld. Coins can also be gained by small coin trails. The overworld also has short mini quests that aren’t long but are still provide some silly dialogue and great items. The player doesn’t have to journey alone!

The entire campaign can be played in multiplayer with another player. This is a daunting feature to include in a game. I’m quite impressed that the developer, “Team Behemoth”, was able to include it is well. The battles feel just as balanced as they do in single player. I never noticed any lag or had any desync problems. Loot is given to each player so there isn’t any arguing over items. It doesn’t feel tacked on at all and is so much fun. This is a great choice for two turn-based strategies fans looking for a game to play together.

Overall, this is a great game that is a perfect in coop. It gets rid of a ton of frustrating RNG and instead replaces it with strategy. It is masterfully crafted and didn’t get boring in the slightest. It can be enjoyed by causal players and hardcore strategists equally. It is an great game for any strategy game fans.


The story uses a ton of crude humor. While this usually becomes tiring after a while, “Pit People” combines its crudeness with sarcastic, self-aware humor that isn’t afraid to poke fun at its own absurdity. Very few games have made me laugh with their writing, but I’m happy to say that this game is one of the few.


The sound design is quite good. Every hit from the characters feels so satisfying and the weapons have recognizable sounds. This way it was easy to keep track of the action. Special abilities and elemental attacks also have their own sound effects. The music is enjoyable, but since the game requires strategy, I turned it off after six hours.


The graphics are awesome. They are 2d, hand-drawn, line art. The animation is smooth and the graphics are crisp. The cut scenes are fully animated and look amazing. I couldn’t wait to watch the next story cut scene to see what absurd graphic was going to appear on my screen next.


Amazing Gameplay
Entire Campaign is Coop
Crisp Graphics
Enjoyable Capture Technique
Crazy, Absurd, and Amazing Story



Distracting Music


.

Posted: January 23, 2017
Product received for free

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
If you're here reading my review you must be wondering if this game is worth buying or not. Well, I'll go ahead and let you sort out your own opinion and you can decide for yourself. PLEASE NOTE: This game is in Early Access, so don't let this review effect your views on the actual game when it comes out. Thanks!

Pros:

Great Team-Builder type game. If you love the type of game where it's critical to build your own team, this one is for you The units I've discovered thus far are as follows: Tank, short ranged but fast archers, long ranged but slow morters, healers, heavy hitter, DPS, and self-sufficient. All characters spare Healer and self-sufficent are interchangable. You may equip them with items varying from a rainbow.. bow to a chalk board with Einstine's "E=MC2". Though beware, as weight limits may prohibit you from reaching your characters full potential!

In the world, you may fight to get loot. Beware though! If you lose a fight or flee you may lose your items! You must make the difficult decision of staying outside and battling for more loot as you complete quests, or you can venture back home and attempt to drop off your loot. Very good system!

Wonderful balance. The game does a great job of making you feel challenged but not overwhelmed. Never before in this game have I desired to quit the game because a level was brutally unfair to me. It gives me a great challenge, even if playing with a friend, but if it gets too easy for you INSANE MODE is already implimented in the game and ready to use. Turning it on is as easy as completing the tutorial level.

The game becomes self-aware.. mostly. The game only makes you complete its lengthy tutorial once, and after that you can jump right into your 5 out of 6 starting group and play away the day. It also holds nice polishes as to changes in the HUB city. Incuding little changes you might see after completing a quest..

The characters and personalitys are diverse. Going into this I was scared that all of the characters might be static and comedy-esq where I know they only joke. While yes this game has an AMAZING sense of humor, it is very careful to pick and choose when to be full on comedy and when to dawn the garb of light hearted seriousness.

Many refrences. If you're a proud owner of BattleBlock or Castle Crashers like I am, you are rewarded with headwear for your characters that have.. actually pretty reasonable stats. Long live Hatty Hattington, The Tearful Warrior!

Cons:

The interface for equiping weapons and armor is... foreign to say the least. Things don't add up. There are three kinds of swords: Short, Medium, and Large (Forgive me if the names are wrong, but that's the jist). Good mechanic overall, but the swords vary in damage only slightly while other stats such as DODGE and DEF. may suffer or benefit greatly. I found myself unable to equip items that may have looked amazing, or that I got from the games Early Access finale. Worst of all is that the swords add to your weight, so I find myself using almost only the starting weapons since they have the most balance.

Leveling is broken. A big part of the appeal to this game was the Leveling system.. only to find out it does nothing. Amidst the wilds of the map you might discover a wild band of raiders you wish to attack. You kill one and a beam of purple erupts from your character while the letters, "LVL UP!" appear briefly. Is it noticable? No, the ATK, DEF, Ect buff is so small you'd have to level up quite a few times. I'm talking 20+ times, and leveling up does get progressively harder.

Armor eye appeal. There is said to be 1300+ items in the game to equip, and the majority look pretty cool. Be it a cup of joe to a Doge refrence. However... don't expect your people to look cool if you favor stats. As unbalanced as the items are currently, you are ALWAYS stuck with the default "T-shirt" so to speak. Cool helmet? Great. B.A. Sword? Even Better. I just hope those things look cool on your plain white shirt or furry black hair troll.


Overall:

This game is a wonderful game in my eyes, and I hate turn based combat spare Pokemon. It will take you on a few laughs and possibly make you wonder if Stamper's voice hurts after hearing his strange diologue where he occasionally yells. I feel this game is a wonderful addition to the Behemoth family and is on the forefront of breaking the bad trend of video game companies pumping out reskin sequels.

For only the price of 15$ I would reccomend this game if it had a few more fixes onto it. It has a nice touch to it and great replay value to those who enjoy playing with team building options.


What could be fixed/changed:

Wagon upgrades, something to spend the money you'll accumulate as you progress. Something that's not needed nessesaraly, but something that would make the journey more enjoyable if you could customize your ride with cool looking cannons or an alternate horse type.

Biome types. The game is very scattered and geographically makes utterly no sense. While yes, it is the Bear-apocalypse that doesn't mean the world should be as mixed as it is. I feel as if the map should have started with plains at least, expanding into a mountain zone to the west and a lake/island region to the east. Something to help pinpoint where the player is at. Something where the player could say: "To get to the Desert, go North onto the flaming fields, once you've reached the volcano zone stop and head east towards the island region. Follow along this route North-east until the islands begin to clump together and you'll see the desert. Enjoy!"

Biome types. The characters are diverse in this game, but you take no advantage of it. Keep the little bandits in the fields, and the massive cyclopse men in the farther out areas so the player FEELs threatened. Am I saying exclude them from the lower levels? No, but I would suggest making them more frequent and powerful the farther they are from the current location of your Town is.

Town/HUB Movement. It's a good idea, but if you went off of the Biome type idea I mentioned previously you might see an oppertinuty. This town movement instills adventure out of your comfort zone, but having the biome types could help the player navigate the landscape and perhaps even feel a bit more comfortable dodging the raining bear blood on their next quest.

The Pit. Give the player the choice to "Descend" the pit. It would eliminate part of the feel of grinding enemies outside, but here's the twist. The pit only gives EXP and little gold. The real incentive is if you can make it to X floor then you get a reward. However, to make it a challenge for your team you have to get down to X floor in one go. Perhaps a checkpoint at every 5th, 20th, or 50th floor depending on difficulty of individual floors? This pit idea would make the overworld seem less comforting as you'd be spending less time there, and the game would seem bigger as there's another objective for the player to do.

ADD TORSO EQUIPMENT. I've already said this in my review, but PLEASE add this. My team looks really sad-sack. I know the game is in the apocalypse, but the fact they never change shirts shouldn't hold in that situation either..

Leveling. Perhaps if you got your character to say... LVL 100. There should be some kind of choice you can make. Here's what I think that choice should be. Getting to LVL 100 unlocks a quest where you BLAH BLAH BLAH you're left with the option to keep them at 100, split the 100 with the other team members on your team, or spend the levels on unlockables NOT NESSESARY TO THE GAME. Ex) Rare music disc's, unused Stamper audio, paints to re-color your items to make them match. Things a perfectionist, most people who reach 100 would be this, would crave.



That's about it for now, as I'd hate to waste anyones time who's still reading this. I hope this review helped! Have a nice day!

Posted: March 5, 2018
I feel very torn over having to write this review. Between patches 1-5 and the final release patch, it almost feels like different people worked on the game, (i know that wasnt the case, just so we're clear) and the people who did the 2nd half of the game just tried to emulate the first half's work.

I'll explain why i get this feeling. The game starts with a witty sarcastic humourous narrrator, good interaction between him and the protagonist, and a sense that you need to take revenge, there are good cutscenes with voice acting and humor. But this doesnt last.

The story of the game ends up feeling very weak and unintersting, and has you doing a lot for seemingly no reason at all, like needing to retrieve an item for one of the characters, so that you can retrieve another item for that character, so that you can use that item to...spot jerkimeties taking a spa day while you fall from the location that you retrieved the 2nd item from. Literally thats it, the 2nd item that the game up until now had you searching for and working towards served one tiny purpose, and the spa could have been seen with the naked eye.

And at this point in the story there is this weird feeling that something is missing now, there seems to be no real humor in the game anymore, and the cinematics have no voice acting, or real animation in them at all anymore, and worst of all, the hilaious narrator who would make quips and jokes isnt there, and hasnt been for a while now.

Ok so, the item you got was basically pointless, but thats ok because now the story is going to move on in a meaningful way right? ehh..no so much. You now basically play hide and go seek with jerkimedies as you catch him and he just teleports away, you catch him, he teleports away, then you go to his main base to fight him. Why wouldnt you just go there to begin with??

So after that he decides to help you for (very very) weak plot reasons, (i dont want to spoil the whole plot of the game) then you're off, to fight THE FINAL BOSS YEAHH!!

SPOILERS AHEAD

Sorry, i just couldn't NOT address this. So the giant bear who crashed into the planet was apparently a good guy, until a character from battle block theatre blasted a laser into his lover, killing him/her, causing him to become an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. And during this, a 5 word song is playing, saying "it all makes sense now" over and over. But it doesn't. IT DOES NOT MAKE ANY SENSE NOW. Seriously, you mean to tell me, that because a character that wasnt even seen in this game, did something to him, he decided to take revenge on a TOTALLY RANDOM BLUEBERRY FARMER?! Seriously, he kidnaps his son and makes it out like horatio is the ultimate ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but he didnt do anything at all. He then...my god its so stupid...he then grabs the battle block theatre guy, who has a laser shining out of his head, and uses him to destroy EVERYTHING. THEN a horse floats by, and grants him one wish..... so horatio goes back to the past, saves pipestrella before her dad dies, saves the cupcake before he is taken prisoner and meets up with yosef and sofia at the town, then it cuts to the bear sad in space saying "what about my dream" before the horse floats into frame and it fades to black with the end on the screen.

There is no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ closure in that, that isnt a resolution to anything, the bear would have still been terrorizing the world, and who knows what his wish would have been.

END SPOILERS

So without spoiling it, let me just tell you, there is no resolution to the plot, none of it made sense, the game lost all its comedic value after literally the first 30 minutes of the game and the ENTIRE story of the game probably takes less than 6 hours to COMPLETE.

So this means that the majority of the game will be spent doing terrible low effort missions and quests that are basically nothing but random map encounters with flavor text thrown in and called "content". There are a total of like 15 different monsters and characters you can control, which is far too little, and all the weapons and armor choices basically boil down to cosmetic choices, and leveling up characters is borderline pointless due to how low the stat gains are.

Overall i LIKED the game, but im super dissapointed with how it seemed to be handled, in the beginning of the game it was clear there was a lot of love and care being put into it, but it became super obvious the further into the story you got, that the less motivated and interested they were in the game, and just wanted to rush out the finished product and be done working on it, and the game as a whole suffered. The second half of the game feels soulless and basically just "there" for lack of a better term, the story makes little sense and a LOT of it serves no purpose and goes around in circles for no reason, all just to end up with no real conclusion, which is really unsatisfying.

This game had a ton of potential, but it was squandered. If they decide to add more content and continue the storyline further out, then fine, ill change this review accordingly, but as it stands, i would not reccomend this game, the story is far too short, there is too little variety in party members, the gameplay is slow and not very strategic, it isnt challenging, leveling characters feels pointless, as does getting gear aside from the cosmetic purposes, and literally 80% of the game's content are side missions, which are basically random encounters with a few lines of flavor text thrown in.

5/10.

Posted: September 30, 2018
Another great game by the Behemoth. A very simplified, but fun, grid and turn based strategy game. Lots of flavor, though the narrator was a bit underutilized in this one. Incredible amount of unlockable equipment and most characters in the game are recruitable, which keeps things interesting. The only team based two player game of its type to my knowledge, which was a blast for local co-op. There are ... more quests (with minor, amusing story attached) than you'll want to work through given that there are only so many classes to mix and match, but there are new mechanics added to a surprisingly large number of stages to try to keep things fresh. Highly recommend.

Posted: August 17, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Disclaimer

To start off I would like to first highlight that despite having 17 hours in the game as of the time of writing this review, I have yet to experience some of the major aspects of this game.

A. These being first Co-op element of the game which typically increases the fun factor of most games by upwards of 100% and I feel in this games case would make for a far far far superior experience.

B. The pit, an arena in the games city hub area thingy that features arena battles against both npcs and AI with coop also being an option.

C. The "hard core mode" or whatever it is called, while less important as not many people will be hinging their purchase decision on an additional difficulty setting, it still bears mention.
(Okay not entirely true, I did switch it on at one point but there were loud noises, flashing light, smoke and fire... long story short I got scared an immediately turned it off again ;-;)




This game. Is. Bonkers.
I never expected in my life that I would be setting the personal objective to go out of my way in a video game in order to..

Get a prettier pair of leggings.. that are purely cosmetic.. for my spider lady.. so that they would match the style of my companion.. who rides on her back.. and is also a sentient cupcake.. that flings portions of its body into teammates mouths.. so that it can heal them.. while slowly killing itself in the process.

Now in case you aren’t sold quite yet, here are some more general pros in my opinion.

- It can be described as "babies first strategy game" and and a derogatory sense.
Even if you have never played a strategy game or plain suck at any of those that you have tried, rest assured that you will be able to perform competently in this game. Simple and Satisfying is the motto I use for the gameplay.

The system cannot be called shallow so easily given the wealth of weapon types, unit types, team combinations and hazards/status effects that all serve to enrich the base combat experience.

Additional likeable features of the game that come to mind include the games vast degree of customization items (well over 1000 individual items) that give little advantage over each other in reguards to stats.
Sure some might have certain resistances or attributes such etc.

However as a whole this does not subtract from the game experience, it helps avoid a balancing nightmare and constant player worrying "are the stats good enough? Do I have anything optimal? Omg heavens forbid I am not min/maxing to the fullest extent" ad infimum."

Instead this lets the player simply... have fun! New hat? Like the hat? Stick that sucker on!
Fashion souls to your hearts content, better to kick butt in style am I right! ^-^

A final attractive feature I will mention before moving along to the next portion of this review is the games full co-op (both local and online) functionality. Worked seamlessly into the game, for example;








Combat can get very repetitive and once you capture all the creatures you want, unless you spot an over world mob with an item you want, you may find yourself in the same position as me.
Actively avoiding combat outside of quests and even if you get sucked into one... just fleeing because scccreeww that.

This however is not a con within the context of said quests, this being due to the simple fact that a lot of tender love and care is put into quests. The maps which these encounters take place in are typically hand crafted and narrated, not only adding charm and character to both the enemies and the environment but also changing the gameplay.

Through adding in map objectives (camps to destroy, buttons to press, key targets, etc.) you can complete the mission without having to actually kill everything in the level!

My favourite example of this is during a mission where most of the gimmick is to throw tons more foes at you than you initially expected.
This still works. Why? The way the enemies are introduced is entertaining and each new enemy adds a new map objective making it easier beat the level beyond brute forcing i.t


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Another issue with the game to some might be the early access status of the game, however with Behemoth working on the game given their track record with past titles and the update work on this game over the years you can stand to feel a little less anxious.

The main storyline is still underdeveloped in the sense that there are only a handful of mission (albeit recently paced, narrated and designed with interesting cut scenes and objectives) that you can be done within a few hours easily.
This will however continue to be expanded over time and is more forgivable given both the quality level and the games vast array of side quests.

These aforementioned side quests will keep you running all over the world map always excited for the next to see how the stories unfold. For example (spoilers) One mission leads you to

A final note before we wrap up for the cons is… hard core strategy players...
This might not be the game for you, the game is quite simplistic compared to other strategy games due to features such as the fact that if you move a unit to a positon. Whereby it *can* target more than one opponent... you have no control over which foe it will actually attack so... soooo yeah, that might cheese your onions if you know what I mean.


The game is only going to get better with time and the price is said to be getting hiked up about five bucks or so whenever the game leaves early access. So all around I would say it is a fantastic monetary and time investment.

Posted: January 28, 2020
This is a decent game but it has a major flaw: You must have a minimum of an hour and a half to complete just one mission and you cannot save the game after starting a mission. You must return to town to save your game progress and if you do before completing the mission, you are penalized by having your town location randomized on the map.

There REALLY should be a better way to save the game, as it makes playing the game impossible for me. I usually only have about two hours each night where I can play and at any moment it can be interrupted by a 30 minute break to deal with a crying baby. On several occasions we had to call it quits very close to the end of a mission which meant completely abandoning our progress AND occurring a penalty for the trouble. On top of that annoyance, a mission can randomly be longer or shorter than average due to story elements. So you might think you have enough time to run a 90 minute mission only to find this mission takes 120-150 minutes!

Otherwise, I find the game cute and fun. There are interesting elements to the combat and the dialogue is constantly silly. You never quite know what to expect from the game except silliness. One other minor annoyance is the fact that there seems to be only one song. I don't know if I just haven't unlocked more tracks but I'm stuck listening to the same electro swing hit every time I play. I love electro swing but that song may be forever burned into my brain.

Ultimately I would recommend against the game due to the poor save setup. However, if you've got more free time and less obligations than I do, check the game out.
