For a game that's early access, it really doesn't feel like it. I'm going to highlight what I feel is wrong/needs to be improved, in hopes the devs see it and consider it. For a review, I'll keep it short. A very interesting world, full of LOTS of stuff, like LOTS, complete with music, great sound, and mostly good controls The music is amazing, I'll have it stuck in my head for days. Behemoth has yet another wonderful game out on the market. On to some gripes about the game.

The PC controls are mostly good, but could use some fine tuning to make them not so wonky when selecting loadouts, the default controls are questionable, but rebindable so that's not that big of a deal. Also, in the intro, the load out screen and differences between "tiers" of items (i.e. cosmetics, light helmets, heavy helmets) isn't at all explained. It was super super confusing because I had no clue what I was doing. So the tutorial could use some more fine tuning as well.

There are other things not very well explained, like what's on the HUD, I didn't know what I was looking at, or what it meant for a while. The items, such as campfires, and how to buy them isn't at all explained. I think my #1 glaring problem was the lack of explanation, so if you're reading this, Behemoth, it would be good to look into that.

These are the most notable issues I saw, but damn this game is freaking fun. Doing Coop is sooooo much fun, but online is a mess. The biggest thing this game could benefit from is more flushed out tutorials, really explaining what everythng is. Keep it up Behemoth, it's a damn good game. Also, put people queued together on the same team. Or at least have an option to.

Posted: February 23, 2023
If you can look past the shallow, slow combat, then you might enjoy Behemoth's unique humor, art, and world present in Pit People.

I could not. You control up to six characters, and the only thing you have control of in combat is movement. There is a good amount of unit types, but they normally only have one mechanic: a Cupcake which only heals but can't attack, a Cyclops that moves slowly that can sometimes throw enemies, and a good 17 other units with similar features. But it doesn't have a noticeable impact on how you play the game. You keep your tanks in the front-line, ranged in the back-line, and that's about it (generally). Environments don't have enough going on to keep it interesting in either its campaign or open world, so it's a lot of marching forward to the closest enemy. Fights go on for way too long as enemies have large health pools, requiring many turns of...moving your characters to the enemy to continue. Every party member has to slowly move into position and attack, which becomes unwieldy in large battles, so there's a lot of time spent doing near nothing in combat.

Progression doesn't exist. There are different weapon types, and tons of weapon models, but there's very little difference in their damage. One weapon might have a certain element attached to it, but that's about it. Armor's the same. You level up, but you don't get to customize a character's stats. Leveling up results in the character receiving full health and a 0.24% increase to their damage. Gear is the largest determinant to a character's stats.

The campaign is very short, consisting of eight quests that usually don't offer anything particularly unique. Characters receive little to no character development. While there's the distinct Behemoth humor and art present, it doesn't hold up well gameplay-wise.

Posted: March 3, 2018
Wow... Just wow. What happened?

I'd like to start by saying I was an early access player. As someone who just now discovered this game you might think it's content filled, a fully finished game, and my hours playing it justifies how much game you can get out of it... Wrong. I erased my old early access review thinking it wouldn't be relevant anymore, but I couldn't be more wrong.

Not only was the development cycle of this game all over the place, so is the community.

To start, Pit People isn't a horrible game but it definitely isn't great. If you like turn based strategy or The Behemoth's typical humor you will most likely enjoy this game...at first. When stepping into Pit People you have this incredible feeling of exploration and a deep combat system with nearly infinite unlocks and collectables. However after a few hours the game is bare-boned and shallow as they come.

Firstly, the classes of characters in this game are not developed and balanced enough. They don't feel unique enough and when putting them in raw combat to compare they all pretty much play out the same. There really isn't a strategy aspect to the game as it stands and I don't think it ever will. Your party will almost always be able to take on 2 encounters before having to heal or return back to the hub. If you're great or if you're terrible it always takes about 2 battles to make you need to retreat. This game gets incredibly stale after your 10th battle; they're all the same despite what enemies are present and how many there are. It is very clear The Behemoth is doing trial and error on this one as they go. The strategy aspect of this game is absent.

Secondly, the map and it's exploration. This game has about 5-6 maps in which each time you load into a new world it picks a spawn point on one of those 6 maps. There's really no point to this aspect of the game. I was fine with it at first but after updates they removed the beacon back to the city. This makes trying to get back more annoying than difficult because time stops when you stop to open the map and try to guess where you are... funnily enough, they were basically forced to revert this in the release. There is now a marker pointing to the city at all times. Over the updates there was also a feature to make elite enemies stun immune, more aggressive, and inescapable. This is incredibly annoying because now special enemies on the world map just attack you out of nowhere and there's no way to stop them beyond out-driving them. I'm not too sure, but I'm fairly sure they got rid of this too. The same missions spawn in all the same places each time there's really no point. They could have just gone with a really big static map and it wouldn't have changed anything...

Lastly the collectables. This aspect is just rushed. They had their artists pump in as many crazy things as they could but they're almost entirely cosmetic. The weapons in this game used to be all the same and they tried to change that by making some unique. As time went on, they did this more and more with wider differences. Now, a lot of these weapons are beyond useless and simply cant be used in a strategic sense. There's no easy way to get these collectables or direct means of getting them. If you could just pay for a random item in a gambling machine it would be fine. Currently, the only way to obtain items is catching an enemy (kill all the enemies first, and have a character with a net catch it) and by random loot drops from doing missions/beating enemies.

Everything about this game just screams placeholder and subject to change on a balance level. The Behemoth was taking their sweet time with the game. (months between updates) Despite these huge time gaps between content they aren't changing much. The gameplay didn't get anymore engaging, the main story didn't progress (They delayed the release for cinematics of which, are still-shot sketches, nothing like the first cutscenes), and most of each update was just more collectable dumps. The core of this game never changed. It's still the same casual flat "strategy game" through and through. After countless rebalances of how levels and stats work the game is still exactly the same as the first build, worse really. In the final release they ended up undoing a solid 40% of things they changed from the first build. I wanted to give this game a good review, I really did but it's clear these are permanent problems lingering over the game.

The icing on the disaster cake is the community. Right off the bat, it's dead. Most people try to be helpful but it's just a ghost town.

I have personal problems with this community day in and day out. Back in the day I used to be extremely active, I would help people with any questions or problems. I would boast about having the most completion because I loved the game and played it religiously. However the downfall of the community was The Behemoth and their connection to said community.

They moved over to discord and the forums here were getting more and more silent by the day. So they decided to make a community manager, a fellow player. I don't want to seem jealous, but they made this guy a manager out of no where for no reason and he isn't an employee. He simply embraced a meme and became the center of attention by making his profile themed after Pit People. Sure, this is fine at first but he really isn't helpful or active like I was. He was basically made community mod to be a jester to liven up the place. (That worked really well right...?)

Then I go onto the forums after being disappearing after many months and updates. I come looking for help to get 100% completion or as close as I could. What do we have...? No one. The forums are empty for the most part. I stumble across a group of select people trying to make a full list of everything in the game. Turns out, they're close buddies who won't help out unless it's to help themselves. They just want Steam forum fame on an empty game. So I continue my search...

I go to the Discord asking around there. I find someone who's willing to help. To my surprise they had more items than me despite me 100%'ing the game a few updates ago. What do they do? Oh yeah, they scam me. Turns out this guy is also buds with the small group of completionists. Wow, great community huh? He accused me of cheating for having the max number of items when I played this game a lot longer before there was more content but okay...

The community is ran by 3 people and it's pretty obvious who they are, they AREN'T the devs. They own all the big guides, respond to everything, are overly toxic, and they scam. These 3 should be banned. What kind of a weird shut-in do you have to be to claim a steam forum for yourself, get buddy-buddy with the devs, then pose as a community manager to glorify yourself...

Hi friends,

This is the only game thats inspiried me to actually write a review. If you enjoy games like Final Fantasy Tatics you'll love this game. Although this is still early access the game is very much complete although some of the story is missing. Not only is it hilarious but the game is very fullfilling to play.

The reason I've already played 24+ hours of this game is because of the pit. The Pit is a place you can use the characters you've developed to fight other people in 1v1 or 2v2. There are countless classes, weapons, armor and tatics on how you can win your next battle.

After each battle if you keep 1 person alive you can capture him/her/it and it will join your team. Any battle you encounter you can capture 1 of the enemies no matter how large they may be. You then can use its armor/weapons to put on your other characters or keep them whole.

I'd easily pay $50 for the game as it is right now. One of the best games i've played in a long time. If your on the fence, buy it, you won't regret it.

Much love and life!

Posted: November 10, 2018
When Pit people first released, I would have recommended it in a heartbeat. Its funny, the mechanics (while simplified quite a lot compared to other strategy games) were fun in my book and still are, though some people might not like the spongeyness of all of the units, though i thought it worked in this games case as you were able to be a little more reckless than most strategy games. i loved the wide array of cosmetics and the vast amount of single player content, and my favorite part of all, the pvp. Pairing up with some random person and running troll moms or making a team of all cupcakes and mascots to buff your teammate into infinity was so satisfying.

So then why dont I recommend the game?

Well mainly it comes down to the fact that it gets old real fast, especially since multiplayer is essentially dead, as with most of the other behemoth games. The devs have consistantly updated the game with new content, but its almost always just more cosmetics, more ways to get money and cosmetics, and more quests to do so you can get cosmetics. The amount of unit types in the game are pretty small, and half of your team will be humans anyway since they are the most versitile of the units, so most of the others are made somewhat irrelevant. And i can kind of understand why they might not have wanted to do add more because of balancing things and the fact that adding new things to the world that arent mentioned at all before that would be kind of weird, but this isnt the type of game you play for immersion and i would rather see new units and mechanics and have them be shoehorned in without context in the game world than be stuck with such a small cast, because when your base mechanics are simplefied to the level that they are in this game, then its kind of important to at least have a lot of pieces to play around with to counteract that. You can only do so many different lineups and gimmicks with such a small cast before you are out of combinations to try out. And due to people running out of new fun combos to sick on each other, the pvp died out, and then once that was gone, going around collecting units and playing the single player just kinda felt pointless since now who are you going to show that new shaking colored name unit you got off to? Who are you going to pull dumb strategies off with and feel the satisfaction of beating a normal tried and true team or at least just have fun getting your ass handed to you with?

There is no community, there is nothing new and exciting, and there is simply nothing to come back to this game for. And i dont blame the developers because obviously they wanted to make a game that was focused on the single player aspect and that is fine. But its just sad to see that they didnt realize that that the best feature of their game, a feature that is literally the name of the game, THE PIT, the mutiplayer battle to death, was for the most part ignored.

And that is why i simply cannot recommend this game. I want to recommend it so badly but unfortunately it just isnt worth it unless it was on a heavy sale just for being able to go through the single player once for the humor.

This game was on my radar since fellow named TotalBiscuit made a first impression video on it from PAX. Since then I was patiently waiting for time to come so I could play another game from The Behemoth - studio so different with their vision, with exciting and ridiculous sense of humor.

Day of release has come, but I wasn't entirely sure to dip my toes into this fun loving, colourful water from get go, and I wanted to wait for full/finished product.
Everything changed when I watched video by another fellow named Jesse Cox. Him and gentleman I already mentioned few sentences before, started series together. Watching them play, and having fun encourage me to jump right in without any hesitation.

Oh boy! Oh boy! This game delivered.
Five hours in so far and I'm having so much fun. Too much fun. Insane amount of fun; and what I say now, might be a stretch, but I feel is fun loving cousin of and in terms of excitement that I have in me while playing.

Gameplay is just too damn addictive.
Writing and humor so ridiculously charming.
Possibilities with customisation are endless, same as number of different characters or creatures.
Music is absolutely awesome, I can't wait for official soundtrack to come out.
Visuals as always nice to look at, with many, many, many, many, many, many bits and pieces that makes the world feel vibrant and alive.
Everything this shows how much though was put into this game, and you can see it from start thru multiple playthroughs.

Besides unfinished story mode this game is polished to perfection ... well, I guess not perfection because inventory management bugs me quite a bit, more than I would like - but with this exception it is perfection in my eyes in terms of gaming experience.

Well done oh mighty . You guys delivered another instant classic.

I know, I know I'm just gushing no much saying praises, but it is just because I am filled with satisfaction and overwhelmed by how good this game actually is, and I need to get out of my system and spread it around.
If you liked previous efforts from this devs, I don't know what are you waiting for; don't be like me and just do it! - BUY IT!!!

Hey yo -
I think it's obvious from get jump that this is a fun game. It's well animated, it has a silly plot, it has fun characters, overall it's a good time.
Is it for you?
Maybe.
If you've never played a tactics type of game before - I'll be the first to say, this is a good place to start. The game is pretty simple, and the combat flow is forgiving. It has elements of randomness to keep you on your toes. It has a lot of great music that never gets annoying witch matches perfectly with the fun character animations that make it a joy to play.
If you're a veteran of XCOM then this might feel a little light weight for you. You'll smoke this game and move on.
Are you trying to play with someone else?
I'm of two minds...
The coop was built in from the start, and It's not hard to see that it works pretty well, but I found that if you're playing for a campaign, I'd let this one go. The side missions, the silly world exploration and the character collecting and customizing are where the bulk of the fun is to be had in coop.

The campaign is designed for solo play. I made a video covering the coop campaign.

I've put over 100 hours into this game and I can't deny that it's great. I love it.
If you're looking to just play with friends, I'd probably play it like a sandbox, just mess around with it, but don't try to engage in the campaign.

Posted: June 29, 2019
It's a good game. Maybe even great. Not amazing.

Vintage Behemoth style and charm. If you liked it before, you still will with this.

Turn-based strategy on a hex map that emphasizes positioning, thoughtful planning, and build creation. The game definitely has a theory crafting element to the build creation; this adds to the play time and enjoyment a lot.

Fun little overworld with decent replayability, but... it can get old.

Simple enough mechanics to not be intimidating, yet it contains adequate unlocks, depth, and complexity to last for quite a while imo. The diversity of unit types is pretty good and interesting. Ofc some are better than others, but each one has its purpose on the right team. The different types synergize well, and keep things interesting with the resistances, strengths, and powerful connections between certain unit types. For example, a classic powerful build is 2 x Kobold, 2 x Pixie, 2 x Vampiress. That is a synergized glass cannon, squishy but deadly sort of team setup. If you plan to get the game or already have it, try that out.

There is challenge to the single player, but it is rarely too burdensome. It is enough that you usually need to think and play strategically, but it won't destroy you mercilessly if you make errors. If a mission is destroying you, your team build itself is likely the main issue.

The party system and characters of different classes, that can use many different gear setups, have a simple, addictive charm. A bit reminiscent of Pokemon collecting/leveling/battling.

The autobattler is quite nice for afking, if you're into that sort of thing. It is certainly suboptimal to knowledgeable, active human play (as it should be), but the AI performs well enough to make it worth using. You can even manually add target priorities.

Co-op adds a lot of fun and strategy to the story/questing/overworld/arena combat.

Overall I would say 7.9/10

Posted: August 27, 2017
Product received for free

Great artstyle, great voice overs and packed with humor...
The developers of this game have 2 other games that are 'Overwhelmingly Positive' on Steam... and in my opinion, Pit People is another that deserves that title! It seems this developer CAN'T make a bad (or even mediocre) game.

Pit People is a tactical-turn-based, squad-management, open-world game. Right after finishing the prologue, you can travel ANYWHERE you want on the world map and fight anything and anyone that you want, which is a refreshing degree of freedom. The game is quite difficult if you don't understand the positioning of your squad on the battlefield, or the squad-management aspect of the game but you shouldn't feel bad if your squad gets destroyed... the game honestly has a nice degree of difficulty to it. Combat is 'slow', but it's a turn-based game so that can be expected... battles can sometimes take 10minutes+ for per fight, but time simply FLIES by because of the amazingly-upbeat music. The music is simply delightful and gives the whole game a whimsical feel (almost makes it feel like a cartoon). The dialogue of the characters is also quite funny and the 'voices' of the characters even more so... There's honestly nothing negative I can say about the game and for $15 it's WELL worth it, because you can easily get 50hours+ out of the game. The game is fantastic.

Posted: 1 June, 2017
Duck Game is, quite possibly, one of the greatest games of all time.

The basis of Duck Game is simple: you spawn into the map at the same time as 1-3 of your close friends, and the lot of you proceed to look for weapons to murder each other with. Once everyone else is dead, you get a point. Once someone gets 10 points, they win the round.

It's a really easy game to pick up and play, yet the true entertainment in this game comes from the large variety of possible outcomes on each map. Depending on where players decide to go and which guns they like to use, each map can play out radically differently, resulting in new moments of hilarity in each gameplay session.

Just when the base game gets boring, you can then head to the Steam Workshop and download a quackload of mods that give you new maps, new weapons, and new hats. Ever wanted to fight to the death with Danny Devito's beautiful mug in the background? You can. Ever wanted to wield a lightsaber in your feathered fist? You can. With new mods still getting made every week, the possibilities are truly endless.

Duck Game is my go-to for laughing with friends and having a good time. I've already sunk nearly 70 hours into the game in the year or so I've owned it and I know it won't be long before I hit the 100 hour mark. Do yourself a favor and pick this game up, grab some friends, and quack it out together.

Posted: 14 July, 2015
I'll try to make this review as legitimate as possible without saying quack throughout the whole thing...

Overwiew
Duck Game is a 2D fast paced multiplayer shooter that faces up to four ducks in a head-to-head tournament to reach the score limit, which is achieved by winning each round.

Combat
Duck Game has combat that results in a fast paced round almost every time you play. It features one-hit weapons that will surely finish your opponents with ease, while also leaving you to play tactically so that you dont end up victim of those who face you.
There is a vast array of weaponry to take out your foes with, such as the devastating minigun, land mines, revolvers, and even bananas to make your opponents slip. Every weapon will kill you instantly if hit, unless you happen to find armor sprawled around the map.
One of the most talked about features in the game is the dedicated button for quaking, which is great for many things such as taunting your opponents or breaking the silence in an awkward situation. Another great feature is the ability to ragdoll your character, which when used at the right moment may lead others to believe you are dead, giving you an advantage or leaving you vulnerable to be picked up and possibly thrown off the map or into a trap.

Duck game is well worth it's price in my opinion. Playing with friends will lead to a great time, and quite possibly an ended friendship. Overall, the game is well done and it may be one of my favorite games of this year.

I rate it a 10/10, would quack again

Posted: 2 February, 2016
Serious review time.

Duck Game is a sidescrolling 2D free-for-all multiplayer platforming shooter. A fairly complex one at that, in fact complexity is the keyword here, it's what keeps the game fresh and at the same time somewhat inaccessible, more about that later.

Watching the trailer, it might seem like a complete clusterduck, and that's what it is, but it's an organized clusterduck, and it's genuinely fun. What I'm trying to say is that this isn't a gimmick game. It doesn't exist solely for youtubers to hit the quack button repeatedly (keep in mind quacking is still an integral and inseparable part of the experience). There is a reason to keep coming back to this game even after the novelty of hearing the same soundfile over and over wears off.

The crux of gameplay is that you are thrown into the fray with up to 3 opponents, last one standing wins. Generally you start off with no weapons at all and you have to race to obtain them before your opponents do. Most maps are built in such a way that you have either no or very weak weapons near your spawn location, with more powerful ones placed further away, hidden in bizarre places or even locked away.

When it comes to weapons themselves, as the trailer says, there is an irresponsible amount, and that's a big part of the complexity of the game. Each weapon works in a different way and to remain at least a bit competitive, you have to be able to properly use all of them, the whole irresponsible amount of them. Not talking about pro level duckgame MLG 1v1 ladder invite prem clan level, just to make it through the average casual match without dying first every single round which is barely any fun.

To elaborate on the weapons, they work in somewhat eccentric ways. For instance, you have to pump pump action shotguns after shooting them, and forgetting to do so can be fatal. You might find yourself successfully throwing a grenade to find out it's not going off for some reason, then have somebody pick it up, pull the pin, then throw it back at you. Reloading muskets, blunderbusses and bazookas is a very realistic process, and can't be cancelled, making you a sitting duck (pun very intended). Chainsaws are similarly realistic in how they can be thrown to land upside-down, leaking gas on the ground - subsequently sparking a fire with the blade is a possibility. Another quirk of chainsaws is that you can "ride" them by laying down, holding the blade in the desired direction of travel and revving it. Most guns have finite ammo much like Hotline Miami, and empty guns disappear after being dropped.

Swords however, swords work as expected. Swing it to kill a dude. Duck (hehehehe) to block. Throw with the throw key, thrown swords are just as lethal as expected. If somebody flying really fast lands at the tip of the blade, they get impaled, as expected.

Then there are some outright outlandish weapons that I've never seen in any other MP game, such as mind control gun that literally allows you to take control of the victim while the trigger is pulled, a net gun that shoots, well, nets, that trap your opponents, allowing you to pick them up and throw them into hazards, or the mooninite gun (consult Aqua Teen Hunger Force for details). Then there are weapons that seem outright useless at first, such as literal nerf guns and books, but everything can be lethal if the conditions are right.

All of above is just a fraction of the game's complex mechanics (not even going into said conditions when nerf guns are useful). It may all seem kind of gimmicky, but everything has a place in the game and it makes for a mostly balanced fun (mind control gun is as evil as it sounds though). The game does do a pretty good job explaining itself, though.

Some people prefer to jump straight into MP, as I did, and then finding everything very confusing, counter-intuitive and generally not fun. For those of us, there is the singleplayer component. "Singleplayer component" might be too strong a term, it really is just a tutorial/training mode. One that will take several hours to complete, not gonna lie. It does a pretty good job explaining the monumental amount of game mechanics, though. And yet, it still does omit a fair share that you discover by playing MP, but at least it does a good job easing you into the game and allowing you to actually enjoy it online the way it was meant to be played.

One thing that does a fairly good job helping you overcome the complexity is the control scheme. Putting this upfront - there's a negative review criticising the default control scheme and I have to absolutely agree, it's atrocious. I don't remember what it was before I turned it upside-down (pretty much the first thing I did in the game), but it had up arrow for jumping which confuses some people attempting to ride their chainsaws.

Other than the bindings, which can be easily changed, there are some measures taken to streamline complex interactions with the game. Other than basic movement keys (jump, duck, left, right), there are five vital functions: Grab/throw, use, strafe, limp and quack. Of these, you'll be mostly using the first two (and the last one). As complex and eccentric as the game is, the control scheme is very easy and doesn't stand in the way. However due to said eccentric nature of the game, certain basic actions require a lot of keystrokes - equipping a full set of armor and a sword requires you to rapidfire grab/use (with fast fingers, it will still take less than a second).

Once you get used to it, it's all about quick reflexes and making the most of your options - as you would expect out of a proper MP game. It's fast, it's complex, and the strategies being employed by skilled players can be mindboggling - one dude predicted three of us to run into a room with the flamethrower, so the clever bastard placed a box against the door from outside, preventing anyone to escape the fiery hell, including the guy who picked up the flamethrower (me). As we burned to death inside, he played a trumpet outside, next to a fire extinguisher.

Well worth the asking price.

Posted: September 23, 2019
After almost 1.5k hours of playing this game, I finally decided to give it a review.

This is the best game I have and it is the game I spend most of my spare time playing.

What is Duck Game?

Duck Game has and is everything that I want and look for in a game. It's funny, fun, challenging and has an extremely high skill cap.
At first glance, this game looks like a funny party game that would be a great hit amongst your friends. There is a dedicated quack button with several miscellaneous "weapons" that make the game extremely comical and there is a button that makes you ragdoll all across the map. To more skilled players, that ragdoll button actually has a function that is extremely helpful.

All in all, Duck Game is a game that you can play with your friends locally or online. There are several mods on the steam workshop that allow for some interesting gameplay and other mods that let you play with even more people (an 8 player mod for example). Duck Game offers some hilarious moments when you accidentally get caught in a net that conveniently falls onto an opponents head killing them, when everyone on the map is on fire and running around and more.

What are the pros and cons of Duck Game?
As with all games, there are pros and cons. The pros of this game far outweigh the cons in my opinion.
(I decided to start with the cons as there are fewer of them).



















In conclusion, Duck Game can be placed into the following categories:






I 10/10 recommend this game to anyone who is either looking for a challenge, or simply looking for an absurd amount of fun. Best game on steam in my opinion 10/10.


P.S. The fix for not seeing many games open? The Global-Matchmaking mod can solve that (if you don't mind a bit of lag).

Posted: August 21, 2015
Frenetic and comical rounds in a multiplayer arena with ducks... wearing hats. You can choose your hat. If you're playing teams then you wear the same hat as your team mate. Hats are important.

Loads of different weapons and well designed arenas. Some battles, if you blink then you will miss them. It would be unusual for a fight to last longer than 30 seconds.

The biggest factor that makes Duck Game a success is the smoothness of the gameplay and the tightness of the controls. These mechanics are spot on.

Duck game is the best game of this type I have played, no other comes close.

Posted: June 5, 2015
I don't mean to ruffle your feathers, but I need you to shut the duck up for a second so I can tell you that this game is DEFINATLEY all its quacked up to be and getting this game is a flying V for Victory.
Pros:
+A button dedicated to quacking!
+A game about ducks battling to the death, what more could you need?
+Many weapons to help you do said killing!
+Many maps to do said killing on!
+An offline arcade mode for those who want a challenge that isn't just killing other players!
+Hats, and plenty of them to wear while killing other ducks wearing hats of their own!
+Up to 4 players on the same system playing against each other if you want to!
+You can make your own levels to play!
Cons:
-None that I could find, so stop being a silly goose and get Duck Game!

10/10

Posted: July 19, 2017
so i saw a recent review and wanted to clear things up for some people since i am an expert in duck history

some people say its the great duck game war but that is false

This game is a metaphor for the early years of World War I

It tells the tale of how many countries (or ducks) went to war because they created alliances meant to keep them safe (which is ironic considering this was the most deadly war by this point). They sent out troops one after another to face certain death. Much like how you can respawn in duck game and are sent out into an arena like battlefield where only one of them can survive, honestly the mortality rate is HIGHER than that of world war one, where around 75% of the participants face a gruesome death at the hands of fellow ducks.

much like in World War one the ducks used any weapons available like flamethrowers and pistols and giga laser rifles from the planet xenon. these weapons often leave the victim completely disfigured just like in the real war, some weapons completely cook the victim turning them into a delicious thanksgiving meal, just like in the real war. often times the ducks will use any means available to end their lives, whether it be a grenade or just throwing a box up and breaking their neck.

and just like how the real war seemed it never ended, in an infinite stalemate killing eachother over and over, even when it seemed their was a victor another battle would begin making the victory very short lived. honestly, in my opinion from the evidence i have seen, i would much rather be in World War I than be a duck in duck game. The makers have really brought to life the horrors of war in a disturbing way. some ducks even pretend to be dead so the other bloodthirsty ducks would leave them alone. But then the ducks would just pick them up, and jump off the infinite void ending both of their lives, just like in the real war.


so yeah that was a quick history lesson and appreciation of the game makers impressive attention to detail.










and if you dont find this review helpful im going to hang myself with a bunch of connected swirly straws from my sippy cup

Posted: July 8, 2020
Follow my Curator page, Fruit N Doggie Reviews, so you can be updated whenever I post a new review.
Overall Rating - High Quality ★★★★☆

First Impressions
I saw quite a few videos on Duck Game (DG), and thought it looked like a hoot. After a while, the maps and situations started to blend together, so I had to wonder how long the entertainment value would last. When I played it with my friends, I was surprised by how fun it was, and how I had no issues playing match after match. I was more than satisfied with DG, and know it'll be a go-to game the next time they're over.


DG is basically a free-for-all death battle, with the first to reach ten points being the victor. After selecting the number of players and costumes, with a brief overview of the controls each time, you'll start loading random maps to fight in. You can change the options so that certain types of maps or weapons are chosen, but otherwise you'll play with the default settings. Each arena will have stage hazards such as spikes and bottomless pits, with at least one weapon available. These range from standard weapons like mines, muskets, and chainsaws, to the more fanciful like net guns, laser cannons, and holy scripture. Never underestimate the power of a charismatic speaker. One thought that comes to mind is that it'd be interesting if more than four people could play on a map at once, but maybe that'd be a feature they'd include in a sequel.

There's also has a single-player mode available, which plays out like small arcade games. They consist of challenges based on either platforming, or getting kills with a weapon, and you either have to beat the clock, or rack up a high kill count. They're all relatively short, but the difficulty in getting the best scores possible is rather high. Beating these challenges nets tickets you can spend to buy new game modes.


Per my preferences I played DG with a controller, and it works quite well. Certain items and weapons will control slightly differently, most of which you can learn more about in the single-player challenges. An interesting example is what the chainsaw is capable of. Another important mechanic is the ability to quack, which you have to do at least once upon winning a round. To not do so is Most important of all, you can press down to duck. Philosophically, I'd argue that by playing as a duck, by simply being, you're already ducking.


This would have to be inferred from the results screen and stadium of fans, but this seems to be a sports event, with viewers tuning in to see the performance you put on. Otherwise, there's no story.


This title was made using pixel, and looks pretty good. Environments have background features, such as the close-up view of Saturn, and the technological supports for the floating islands in the space arenas. The various costumes help make the different-colored ducks stand out from one another, though remembering who chose what can be hard at times. Since the screen isn't cluttered, it's easy to guess what role each object has. For instance, the clothing and armor are equipable, the key opens locked doors, barrels are flammable, and most weapons are easy to sum up just by looking at them. A few might do something unexpected, but they're easy to distinguish from one another once you know how they work.


Honestly, I paid no heed to the background music while either watching or playing DG. When I checked to see how it sounds, I found it enjoyable. The music is upbeat and catchy, though many of the songs are fairly short at around one minute each. With the various weapons in DG, they have appropriate SFX, like all the guns when they fire. Also, the sounds of quacking are on point.


🌟 DG is a good party game. You will see differences in skill level, but as long as people don't go try-hard, everyone can take it easy and enjoy a few rounds. The tone of the game doesn't lend itself to rage moments, though I suppose that depends on who plays it. I never got mad when I lost a round, or made a mistake.
🌟 There are a series of challenges to play in one player mode that allows you to unlock other options for the multiplayer modes. They're pretty difficult, but also serve as good practice.
🌟 There's good variety in the map layouts and weapon selection. This game has good longevity due to this, but it's hard to predict when the game might get stale for you.


❌ There's online play available, but the few times I checked, I wasn't able to find anyone to play with. If you try to use mods, this will disrupt the ability to find matches, but the game checks for this, and asks if you want to disable them to search for other games.
❌ Though you can play the game against only one opponent, rounds tend to be too short and lack the same level of interest that even one other player would provide. Plus, there are no bots available.


🔍 You'll want to learn how the different weapons function and how to properly use them. The single player challenges are a great place to learn about features that aren't inherently obvious, such as how the chainsaws can be ridden around like deadly motorbikes.
🔍 Don't get uptight over DG; just have fun with it.


DG is a very fun game that doesn't take itself too seriously. I suppose some party poopers could get tired of people flopping around while playing dead, victory quacks, and accidental suicides. However, if you have seen any of the videos on this game and enjoyed it, there's a solid chance you'd enjoy playing this title for yourself. Since you can play both online or locally, there are decent opportunities to enjoy the action. However, I tried finding online matches, but wasn't successful. So, you'd want to make sure you'd have people to play with, from either your friends list, or in person, as the single player challenges won't hold your attention very long. Not unless you really get hung up on mastering them. That aside, I highly recommend DG if you've got people to play with, as it's what it quacks up to be.

Posted: December 29, 2016
A party game with the danger of addiction
!Handle with caution!

A friend of mine told me about this game about a year ago, when it first came out.
We tried it in school and after a few rounds others also showed interest. So they tried it too and just couldn't stop playing.
That's where the addiction started to grow.
It soon became a habit that, as soon as whether I came into the classroom and sat down or until I took my notebook out of my schoolbag, I got asked: "Duck Game?"
You could already tell, that nearly every break was used for playing Duck Game.


But after a few months the premade maps got repetitive and we found out, that we could build our own.
Well ... damn.
So everyone, who was playing along, wanted to build his/her own map. :')

Then another few months later we encountered the opportunity to make our own custom duck hats.
... oh my gosh :P
Everyone wanted to have/make their own hat(s). :'')



It was a hard time for me as I soon had no time in the breaks (and also in some lessons!) to use my notebook for own purposes, like research, checking my mails or just social networks and surfing.
So I started to resist the requests what didn't work that well at the beginning, but I managed to put an end to the addiction of Duck Game in May/June 2016. Not an easy task to accomplish.

So that's my story about Duck Game.



Duck Game is a local/online multiplayer arena platformer for up to four players, featuring deathmatch, team deathmatch and single-player challenges, a map-editor and a variety of hats to be activated/discovered and mods to be purchased by in-game credits.
And this game was created by one man, Landon Podbielski.


There's a wide range of weapons in the game which are spread on the maps and you have to pick them up. But no map features every weapon (except you build your own map where you place every type) so you also have to be able to use any weapon in any situation. All projectiles from firearms and every single swing from a melee weapon are a one-hit-kill. The different types of weapons only differ from the range, the speed and the spread of the bullet(s)/edges. It features very fast paced movement, you're able to swim, glide, slide and pretend to be dead (ragdoll mode). And you can quack!


This game runs on 1080p at smooth 60fps and features a lovely retro-arcade pixel shading.
And all the assets, sprites, whatsoever are created by hand by Landon Podbielski, the one-man developer team behind Duck Game.


As already mentioned there are two ways to customize your Duck Game experience:

The mapeditor simply lets you build your own maps with all objects, weapons and decorations available.
You can also upload your maps to the Steam workshop.

And of course the possibility to create your very own hat. Therefore you'll need a software which allows you to draw pixels and export to PNG file like Photoshop or and the template from this site


If you have friends and want to challenge them but all the other games get old, get yourself a copy of Duck Game.
You can fight in deathmatch, teamdeathmatch or unfair (a team of three against one). Also there are no rules except the last survivor in a round gets +1 point, but you could also play where one with the least amount of points is the winner ;)
And if you don't have friends ... well the single-player challenges are cool?
No seriously, this is a multiplayer experience.



Overall a solid 85/100






Cheers :)

Posted: January 30, 2019
Review by Sven Evil - Steam's best local 4-player curator! See 100s of more local 4-player reviews at my curator page!

You enjoy competitive platform combat games with your friends?

Then look no further and PLAY THIS GAME! It doesn't get much better in the genre. While the premise of the game is so simple that anyone understands it within a few seconds (grab weapon, kill other player(s)), the gameplay is rather varied. This is because of the 50+ different levels (from very small to rather big) and the 50+ completely different weapons.

From an old muzzleloader with one shot and very long reload times to a minigun with a recoil that throws you back a few meters to laser pistols you find all kinds of small arms. You also have swords (and armor to wear) or more exotic equipment like a mind control helmet to take control over your enemies (and direct them into the abyss, hehe) with a tin-foil hat as counter measure. And don't forget the land mines or the hand grenades. Or the flame-throwers to transform your enemies into a roasted duck! The multitude of weapons is what makes this game shine!

Your duck can jump, use weapons or equipment, play dead to deceive your enemies, and you can QUAK to annoy your friends.

Game works for 4-player local as well as online. XBox One or XBox 360 controllers work flawlessly.



One the same level of supreme quality than Towerfall: Ascension! Combat platform games don't get much better!

Quack!

Duck Game is a side-on pixel art local and online multiplayer shooter where you can win by preaching to opponents. Duck Game has a vast arsenal of lethal and non-lethal weapons ranging from fire extinguishers to bazookas to suicide pistols, not to mention any guns you mod in. Duck Game has a variety of pre-built maps that are well designed and enjoyable to play and learn, there is also the ability to turn on random maps that are procedurally generated, but these can end up with unfair spawns and can get rather boring. There is also a singleplayer mode that is based around challenges using a certain mechanic from the game, these can be fun and frustrating but also sometimes a bit lacklustre and not a reason to buy the game. By completing these challenges you get points than can be used to unlock modifiers and hats from the shop. After a while the maps, hats and weapons in the game can get boring and lack the variety they originally had, this is where the workshop comes in. The workshop for this game is consistently active with new hats, weapons and maps being added daily so you can keep your game fresh every time you play. You can also add to the workshop by using the built-in map editor, it can be a bit fiddly but is overall OK.














Duck Game is a fun and fast paced action game that is great for a group of friends to play either on the couch or over the internet. It is very well made but can get boring after a while though it can be refreshed easily with the wide range of high quality and easy to access content on the workshop. It is only majorly let down by the singleplayer aspect of it and that isn't even too bad. Overall I would highly recommend Duck Game to you if you are looking for a game to play with 3 or 4 friends, but if your looking for a great singleplayer experience you won't find it here.

Posted: June 19, 2015
DISCLAIMER: THIS IS NOT A CRITIQUE OR MEANT TO BE WELL WRITTEN/ENTERTAINING REVIEW, IT"S JUST ME EXPLAINING AND RECCOMENDING IT.

Duck Game is an Ouya game ported to Steam, published by Adultswim. It's a 4 player sideview 2d Deathmatch game. 2 vs 2 is also possible. Similar to towerfall, players die in one hit and then go to the next level when everyone is dead.

First when starting it up you'll notice the great sega genesis style soundtrack.
Second, you'll notice presenation is great. For example the main menu is navigated by actually walking to the options, and it is a nice looking menu.
When you start the game, you'll be thrown into a little waiting lobby that also explains the controls. You can change your profile here, and pick what hat you want to wear. You have to destroy the glass next to you to step into a beam and start floating in it. When you get into the beam you can either find a multiplayer game or play or, play the single player arcade missions. If another person is there, you can play locally instead.

The gameplay of Duck Game is simple. 4 people get thrown into a level, and in that level weapons and items are scattered throughout the map quake style, or hidden in blocks which you have to jump into like in Mario. The objective is ofcourse to kill eachother with these weapons. Everything is a one hit kill. When everyone is dead the person who survives gets a point and the next map loads. When 1 person has 10 points the game ends. The controls are simple. You move with the directional keys, and you have a jump and a shoot button. If you press down you can slide, which you can use to slide under small places. Unique to Duck Game is a dedicated button to pick the weapons up. When weapons or items are picked up, the player can throw them with the same button. These throwing physics are very well implemented. The movement speed is fast, and you're in pretty much full control of your jumps. If you jump and let go of the right or left button you'll almost immidiately fall. If you jump, and hold the jump button in mid air you'll slowly descent to the ground. There's also a feign death button, not sure what it's for but it's nice.
Oh, and there's a dedicated quack button, to, well, just make a quack sound.
The game is fast paced, chaotic fun. It's very easy to pick up and play. There's always funny moments to be had. People accidentally suiciding in the most stupid way right after winning and thus not awarded a point for example.


Most weapons are bullet based, and have a bit of a random spread. You also often can't see the ammo you have left. With some guns there's knockback, which gets higher when you crouch. They kind of work like incredibly fast projectiles, and the range varies. What you'll notice is that seemingly, you can only shoot sideways. On the surface it seems like Duck Game has no depth to it and is just casual fun. However, when playing for a while you'll notice there's quite a few things to get good at. First of all, many weapons have their own unique little quirks. A small thing is that many weapons require the button to be pressed again to for example eject shells before they can be shot again. You can mostly just shoot left and right, but aiming can actually be more skillfull then you think for a 2d game like this. You can walk through enemies, and when standing in an enemy the gun often can't hit that person, which happens a lot because of the fast movement. When you throw a weapon hard enough at your enemy, the enemy's weapon drops.
When you jump and hold down the jump button in mid air, not only will you slowly descent, but your weapon will point upwards, so you actually can shoot up. Not only can you do this, but you can actually shoot up diagonally. Since the gun doesn't point up immidiately, if hold the jump button and almost immidiately press the shoot button right after, you'll shoot diagonally.

The revolver has kickback, so if you keep shooting you can shoot diagonally with the recoil.
For the grenades you press the shoot button to take the pin off, and then you can throw it in any direction with the other button, and the physics (and the ease of killing yourself) of it make it a skillful weapon to use.
The grenade launcher not just arcs and then explodes on contact, but when you hold it down it goes up, so you can aim it. The longer you hold the button the more upward it aims.
The chainsaw has to be activated by pressing shoot twice, and after, you can do all kinds of crazy movements with it.
With the hammer you can also effect your movement but in a different way, and since it's heavy you can kill someone by dropping it.
There's an net gun that has a fast arcing projectile which traps your enemy, and then you can pick your enemy up and throw him out of the map.
There's a flamethrower and flame gun that can be extinguished by fire extinguishers, and the nerf gun ammunition catches on fire when shot at the flamethrower.
And there's more. 2 shotguns (with 1 you can see your ammo left on the gun itself), a few pistol's, a minigun, a sword you can also throw kill people with (and slash downwards in the air), lasers that bounce off of walls, a small laser gun you can charge up, a gun you can charge up for a HUGE laser, the mooninites gun from Aqua Teen Hunger force that shoots a really slow moving square and has a big knockback effect when shot, a magnet gun to push people off the map, a gun that turns people into you, a rocket launcher that destroys terrain, a sniper rifle, a rifle with a really long reload time, some thing powerful that I forgot, a flaregun, mines, an uzi type thing and an earthworm jim type gun, and a suicide gun. I think I got most of them. There's enough vereity in weapons to be had here, although I'd love there to be more interesting projectile weapons.

Aside from weapons, There's sometimes jetpacks and grappling hooks to find for movement, and there's body armor, a helmet and shoes(against spikes).

as far as the levels themselves go, you can pick up blocks in certain levels that you can use to drop on people's heads. There's other blocks you can use to block doors with. There's keys you can pick up to open certain doors with better weapons. There's hazards such as spikes. There's oil drums you can shoot to make all the oil come out. There's windows that can be broken open when pressing down or shooting on them. In a few levels there's teleporters you can actually shoot in and the nyour bullets come out of the other portal. What's cool is that there's a level editor, but an issue is that you can't play these online yet. Otherwise there's some crashes, and there's no game browser to speak of, only automatic matchmaking.

The singleplayer arcade missions are not that special, but they're a nice addition. Some of them are pretty fun. They're missions such as shoot as many targets as you can in a certain amount of time, or finish an obstacle course as quickly as possible, etc. You can either get a bronze, silver, golden or blue medal, and the better the medal the more tickets you get to spend on a few gameplay modifiers and hats.

Duck Game is not as competetive as something such as Towerfall but it does have a good skill ceiling, despite it at first glance seeming like it lacks depth. If you like games like Towerfall, Super Mario War and Samurai Gunn, be sure to give this one a try, especially since it has online multiplayer.

Posted: June 23, 2015
Duck Game is great.

How great? That really depends on several factors. If I was comparing this with anything else, it would be asking if you like Super Smash Brothers. Super Smash Brothers, in my opinion is only 5/10 if you’re by yourself, but a solid 10/10 when you get a couple guys to play with. Duck Game fares similarly, being a competitive, 2D, PVP focused game with skill based platforming and reaction time. The difference is that Duck Game has the one hit kill intensity found in Samurai Gunn. The kicker is that you can’t attack if you don’t have a weapon, so the start of the match is just a rapid scrambling for firearms and panicked firing. It’s an intense, skill based shootout that I hope to be playing for the next 10 years at least.

Duck Game’s true greatness is its subtleties present in its design. At first it may seem constraining to not be able to aim in all directions like you would expect, but you eventually find that if you’re pressed up against an object your duck aims upward, still allowing you to fire. A particular gun that looks like a giant magnum recoils with each shot, letting you aim slightly higher to hit enemies, essentially you exploit a handling characteristic of the weapon into a game mechanic. The ducks can even float around on stubby wings and slide on their knees if you duck while running (ha ha), allowing you to do Matrix-like dodges against your enemies. Really great stuff, with a high skill ceiling but still easy enough to allow new players to get the drop on more experienced ones, which is the “sweet spot” I adore in competitive games. There’s a button completed dedicated to quacking (SERIOUSLY) which adds a layer of absurdity and humor to the already ridiculous setting that Duck Game takes place in.

One fear I have is the staying power of the online community. Too many indie games, have I bought on a super-sale only to see that the fan base has since moved on to other games. Duck Game is still relatively new as of 6/22/2015, so finding a game isn’t too difficult, but I really, really REALLY hope this game has longevity in the future. Like I said, 10 years please. One of the upsides this game has over Samurai Gunn is its near perfect online gameplay, which I hope keeps the game alive. I only had a couple of disconnects but the lag never really messed with me too bad. Even if the online dies out, with the local play, all it requires really is a couple of controllers and a few brewskies to have a great time. I love this game.

I just realized, bordering on too late, that I had never reviewed Duck Game.

This game is, unequivocally, the best couch competitive game I've ever played in my life. It's easy and fast enough for friends who aren't really great at gaming to continue playing even if they're getting destroyed by more skilled players, it's varied, it's so wildly "pick-up-and-play", you can hook it up and play a few rounds with barely any setup.

It's the only game that we love enough to have set up on a projector outside to play around a fire on some summer nights. We played it over the internet during covid, and countless hours between.

Now for the editorial part. WB Discovery is reportedly pulling this game among many others as part of their ever-increasing desire to make wonderful things disappear to see the line go up. It's unconscionable. Give the dev full rights to their game. It's too wonderful to make disappear.

Posted: September 3, 2018
My favorite game by far. The mechanics are excellent. The combat is fast-paced and frantically fun. There are many great maps in both the base game and on the Steam workshop. The community is for the most part very respectful and tolerant regardless of skill.

In all honesty though this game is not for everyone. New players may have a rough time if they're joining random games. A skilled player can easily trounce newer players and it's tough to learn how to play when your opponents kill you in 2 seconds. The player count is down from Duck Game's heyday so sometimes it takes a few minutes to join a random matchup, but if you add players you enjoy fighting against you can get a match going at any time. If you have friends who'd be interested in playing, this is a must buy.

If you're willing to die a lot and can handle losing matches when you start out, Duck Game will reward with you the most satisfying gameplay in the genre. I've gotten more laughs and amazing moments out of Duck Game than anything I've played in my 25 years of gaming. My friends list is filled with over 180 ducks I've met over the 3 years I've been playing. I always find myself coming back to Duck Game because nothing else compares with the humor, intensity, and skillful gaming to be had here.

I fully and wholeheartedly recommend Duck Game. There's a reason so many players have hundreds or thousands of hours invested. It's amazingly fun, and enjoyably challenging. Also there's a dedicated button for quacking. Who could resist?

UPDATE 10/19:
It's been a year since I wrote the review and this game is still awesome. Can still find a good game any night of the week. Still a lot of active players. Still recommending it.

Posted: June 30, 2019
The best 2D multiplayer game you can buy on Steam. At first glance, it doesn't seem much different than any other game in the weirdly specific yet surprisingly well-populated genre of "2d-4-player-one-hit-kill-battle-game" but the incredible variety of weapons and level designs make it really stand out. You're never in the same situation twice. And on top of that, it has robust mod support via Steam Workshop.

All of this would make it among the best, but here's the major difference that rockets it above all other similar games: Duck Game has online play. Unlike Towerfall or Samurai Gunn, there's no need to get your friends in the same room or set up Parsec or go to other lengths. Duck Game's online play just works.

Also, it has a dedicated quack button - and a dedicated analogue trigger to modify the pitch of the quacking.

Posted: June 5, 2015
>>>>>Click Here For Video Impressions<<<<<

Duck Game is a very special game. It's a game designed for everyone, but especially crafted for anyone who grew up in the Couch Multiplayer era, specifically Sega Genesis fans. It's a game with simple mechanics and an endless supply of frantic over the top fun.

The rules are simple, first to 10 match victories wins! Matches generally last about 10-30 seconds, after which the next one starts up almost immediately on a randomly selected map. The rhythm of the game is almost never broken up, keeping a quick and exciting pace throughout. There's an ungodly amount of weapons, each with their own variety and mechanics. You'll find everything from Derringers, to Shotguns, to Nerf Guns, to Mooninite Lasers!

Although the main draw of this game is easily the Multiplayer, the Single-Player challenges offer you a chance to train your skills through a series of modes. These challenges give you major insights into lesser known mechanics of the game, which can give you that little edge in combat. Through winning challenges you get Tickets, which you can spend not only to buy hats, but also GAMEPLAY MODIFIERS for multiplayer!

Did I mention there's a dedicated Quack Button? That can be pressed at any time. Seriously. It's the best thing ever.

So grab this game, grab some friends, grab some RPGs, and let the feathers fly!

Posted: November 24, 2016
A shooter platformer and a damn fine one at that!

Duck game is one of those games where you could say the Devs thought about everything.
If you grab some friends you can dive into the main game of fast paced deathmatches on a variety of maps with both gimmicks and balanced designs in mind. If you somehow get bored of those, you are covered by a very intuitive level editor as well as the steam workshop where you can get content ranging from maps to weapons, hats and stuff like that.

Locally and over the internet, it supports a wide number of controllers and it's really simple to set up games and customize to your liking in many ways.

Alone? Not a problem really, single player challenges and the level editor can keep you busy. The single player portion of the game can teach you a ton about the mechanics and also make you practice some skills that will be useful for multiplayer, you can even unlock cosmetics and mutators too.

Gameplay wise the game really shines on both it's vanilla map design and weapons, you are sometimes forced to be creative and even stylish with the way you use them and will always keep learning new mechanics and intricacies that can add some really satisfying depth to the combat.

In terms of movement nothing is ever wasted in this game. Ducks are nimble and control superbly. You can hold the jump button after a jump to flutter (Which also makes you aim diagonally and then up in just a few frames, keep that in mind :>) Ragdolling makes you gain some more momentum for those high jumps you thought impossible, you can slide while running to break windows as well as dodge bullets.
Pretty much every movement option in this game has at least a couple of uses that may not be apparent at first glance.

With a few exceptions, the weapons of Duck game will kill you in one shot and since the game is a platformer. Every player can see each other and when fights are not mayhem and explosions at break-neck speeds, they can turn into tense mind games and some amazing plays. Or comical accidents that will be rewarding anyway.

When you think of aesthetics Duck Game is impeccable with it's Genesis inspired soundtrack and clean pixel art which looks nice and is easy to understand even with the game's frantic pace, If i needed to describe the songs and atmosphere in a more subjctive way. I would say they feel like summers when you were young. They are some catchy tunes with a care-free attitude as well as adrenaline pumping songs that will accompany any situations with ease and really fit the personality and charm the game has.

Overall I think this game can be an amazing experience for anyone and even more so in groups, games don't take too long and never really get frustrating or boring, it can be addicting and is such a joy to pick up. It's just one of those timeless games that you will probably remember some years later and have fun the same way you did when you started.

I highly recommend this game and wish you all good luck and good hunting!

Posted: November 21, 2016
quoth:
...
Allow me to approach you as first reminding you that this game is very surprising and deeper than you’d think. We’ve all experienced that.
I want to reply sentence by sentence.
“I never said it wasn’t viable in competitive just that it was one dimensional and frankly not that fun.”
“fankly not that fun”
I have fun playing this map. Others do too. Subjective interpretations of maps should not be criterion for what constitutes competitive play in Duck Game. I have fun playing every map, even ones that I also feel have no place in a competitive environment. Fun is not a factor in competitive demonstration of ability because of its subjectivity. I prefer to try to keep discussions regarding criteria for maps in competitive play to be focused on observations and analysis. When we let opinions get in the way of our thinking, our ability to consider outsider arguments is clouded. This is because we have a framework that is guiding our ability to reason instead of keeping a pure, open mind towards something.
“One dimensional”
The structure of the sentence quoted above causes this particular descriptor to become a negative remark regarding competitive play. Please explain why you feel this way instead of assuming it is universally agreed upon that lower dimensionality provides a worse competitive environment overall. Discussions with substance such as that help with discourse. I gave a loose opinion on 1-dimensionality while also backing up my opinion with reasonable arguments earlier. Using arguments based on reason and observation facilitates discussion.
“Part of the depth of Duck Game is the variety of skills that can be used to gain the upper hand in a fight.”
Does this not include skills such as movement, and positioning? These are part of that variety of skills. Why should any particular subset of the total set of skills play a role in our decision making in regards to competitive play? I’m not saying such a claim is absurd, but that you should provide more reason as to why you may feel such a way.
"For some players the core mechanics of Duck game that are so important in snow 11 pale in the comparison to angles, clipping, and other tech skills unusable on that map.”
This comes across as implying that those players who place importance on those other techniques have a greater weight in the discussion of what constitutes competitive maps than players who may not place such an importance. Just because you cannot use a particular set of techniques on a map does not indicate that the map in question is not suitable to competitive play.
If you truly outclass your opponent, you can show this with any dimensionality of skills. If I can win more than you can when we restrict our input environment, then I win in that environment. These skills also exist in environments with higher dimensionality. So, when we go to play in those dimensionalities that other maps contain, we bring with us any relevant crossover skills from maps such as this. Movement and positioning are not flashy and may not excite you like a wall shot. But they exist in every other map. And they are fundamental.
If we can give players maps that showcase these abilities, we can more accurately gauge the skill level of players in this game. We can see various subsets of skills without fuzziness being caused by the presence of other options and gameplay routes. We can then see if there’s a correlation between smaller subsets of skills to the total. What is important in order to win this game? What is good?
Questions like this can be made clearer with variety. You like a variety of skills, and so do I. And I like a variety of maps where this variety of skills varies. If every map had the same kinds of options as Office16 or Industrial4 or Level3, this game would not be as fun. Instead, we have maps that showcase different abilities. Forest11 and Level4 with nade launchers. Office 8 and Industrial05 with netguns. These maps have variety built into them. And no one is looking to get rid of any of these maps.
Snow11 is another kind of variety. It feels a little slower, and is a little less flashy. There are no(t many) angles. But it’s a map that showcases input precision and meta awareness. And to me, it is awesome. It lets me see opponents in specific lights and offers an environment to improve as a player. I love that kind of experience. And in comparison to other maps, it’s special. It has a role, just like nade launcher maps and netgun maps and “gun maps” like as Office07, Snow03, etc., and any other type of map that we can distinguish given the set of normals.
" I feel that a lot of competitive players want the maps they play to not only be equipped for high level play like snow 11 but also to have variety and just be fun. It is after all why we play these games in the first place: To have fun.”
This map is equipped for high level game play, it does lend variety to the rotation, and it is fun.
The problem with reaching an agreement on this whole matter is that last descriptor. You might not have fun on this map, but I do. And even if you don’t, it has the other two elements you’re saying that competitive players are looking for.
When we strip maps out of the rotation of what is deemed competitive without justifying such a decision based on arguments regarding objective criteria such as the type of competitive environment a map is able to offer or the “variety” - subset - of skills able to be used on such a map, then we risk both creating a stale competitive environment at the whim of people’s opinions, as well as preventing ourselves from improving as a whole.
“That may be where your running into conflict about snow 11, I think people might be looking for an excuse not to play it simply because they don’t like it, and I don’t blame them.”
“look for an excuse”
Exactly. Subjectivity is the excuse. If you want to get better at Duck Game, you should welcome any environment that offers such an experience: Snow11 let’s you git gud. You might not feel that way, but it does. It gits you gud at things you can’t even see at lower levels.
Maniac, you have less than 700 hours. I have nearly 2000. I know how I felt when I had 700, and when I had 1k and when I had 1.2k and when I had 1.5k. I know what I felt at 80 hours, 230, 480. I have always loved this game for the same reason, it is fun and you can also git gud.
Trust me when I say that Snow11 can help you git gud. I have fun on this map partly because it’s a map that gits you gud. And if you find fun in gitting gud like I do then I think you’ll come to see this as a great map. And if we’re talking about taking a game seriously enough to call it competitive play, then should be the objective: gitting gud. If a map can be scrutinized objectively and argued for or against, then we know we are talking competitively.
That’s why I don’t want it banned from competitive play. It would strip so many players of a potentiality of objective improvement. It might feel weird and different to them, and this might be boring. But it’s not unfair, nor is it guaranteeably as slow as some other maps. I know that there is an untapped skill ceiling on this map and that we should explore it. I have strong feeling that the time this map will take to finish round by round will get much lower as time goes on.
I have a lot of fun exploring that kind of potentiality. It’s why I play so much and why I’m so good. This map can help you guys get better – I know this.
And I want you to get better! I want to feel like there’s someone better than me, again. I want to work towards pushing our limits beyond where we see ourselves. I have always wanted this. And I can tell when a map allows for this to be something we can do.
Snow11 is such a map.

Gosh, where to start with one of my all time favorite multiplayer games ever? It is the pure chaos of running towards the best gun, ducking and sliding across all the levels, a perfect grenade across the map, wearing shoes to smash the person below your feet, opening a present and shooting yourself in the face by accident thanks to the reverse pistol, the suspense of hurling the rock to the end zone during the intermission...

Duck Game is a very specific type of game. It doesn't go out of its way to be anything other than a perfect multiplayer game (the single player is amusing, occasionally fun, but unnecessary). It makes it difficult to review: this is a game you'll either spend twenty minutes in or two hundred hours. (Most of my time is logged in the PS4 version). Buy it, invite some friends, and have a blast.

Sidenote: I have gotten very good at making the "quack" sound and say it at least four times a day for any reason.

Posted: May 2, 2022
Duck Game is the definitive party game for competitive friends. A simple fighting game where every weapon is a one-shot kill and your movement is more important than your aim, Duck Game is a party game for a new age of couch gamers. Those who grew up sweating for their lives playing Smash on 13" CRT screens grew up into adults that needed to play something on the bigscreen with their like-minded friends - Duck Game fulfills that niche. Simultaneously casual-hilarity and competitive-sweatery, Duck Game is an absolute joke of a game that is easy to learn, difficult to master. The gameplay loop is painfully simple yet outrageously addictive. You will happily lose 45 rounds straight if it gives you the opportunity to dunk on your friends just once. The ability to collect hats and furniture pieces for your loading-screen bedroom is beyond fun and gives the game a "reason to play" as if dumpstering your friends with a rocket launcher while toxicly quaking wasn't fun in itself. If you have real human friends who are willing to meet you in person and share a couch with you, you must buy this game. It is limitless fun for a low, low price. The graphics are simple yet endearing, the music and sound effects are perfect for a straightforward party game, and the performance of the game is what you would expect for a 2D side-scrolling fighting game. It is fun to play, fun to watch - a perfect way to get a house party started.
