3 years have passed since I have bought this game and it will soon become delisted from Steam... Honestly it will be the end for me. Through this years I cant find anything thats can replace or compare with DG. The game where you can do frame perfect techs like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ speedrunner and its not even a thing for average players. The game where you can play with 8 friends at once. The game where you can teach programming to become modder. The game where you can meet so many great people. I dont envy newcomers who havent seen whole picture of the game. They think that this game is good for a group of friends for couple of evenings but not for me. I think that DG is a lot more than this at least for me... Someone says that 1000 hours - is the end for the game, but for me its just a begginning. Rest in peace Duck Game
This review was made when I had 500 hours:
My first review of my first purchased game. DUCK GAME at first glance, an ordinary game where ducks run and kill each other in different ways, everyone thinks so at the beginning. By the way, the beginning of the game in Duck Game is a test of your nerves and how persistent you are. Something like 2b2t, don't you think? There are few newcomers to DG, but they are there. The first 0-100 hours is the first stage of your verification, and if you pass it, you will open the way to the next stage. Stage 2 - you want to play DG, but you don't know how to play it and start asking everyone how to do D Shoots, how to do Ragdoll Jump and many other techniques. Many community players will not tell you anything, but simply destroy you, but there is a small percentage of players who will help you and tell you. So if you see a good player or your friend is playing this great game, don't be afraid to ask them different things. Speaking of the community, it is very concise, which is kind of good, but it seems to be bad. Sometimes you can't find a game, but you always play and see the same players. You start communicating with each other and getting to know each other among others. Also in Duck Game there are cheaters, but there are good cheaters who will just be fun and show, for example, how they play musical instruments or just show what they can do or even tell you how they did it. And Yes, many cheats in DG modify themselves. So if you see a suspicious player, do not immediately levitate or kick them, but look at what they are doing. If he will destroy you and will not even let you get out, then feel free to leave. This also applies to bad players - pingers, campers, etc. I would never have thought that a simple game like DG would involve me in music, programming, and drawing pixels. In DG, you can draw your own textures for weapons, ducks, maps, and so on. You can also draw your own caps. You can find all this on the Internet or do it yourself. Those who seek will always find it. Speaking of music, if you have a gamepad, then start playing with it from the very beginning, because then you will be very long to get rid of the keyboard and it will take you a lot of time and a bonus to this you will be able to play musical instruments and quack in different tones. About programming - this is due to mods and cheats, as I said before, they can be modified. If you are very bored, you can play with your friends in DG mods. I recommend this game, but you must either play it or not play it at all. This is the best game I've played, am playing, and will play so far. If you not laziness write +rep. And try not to lose your friends ;) Good luck! See you in the DUCK GAME.

Posted: November 24, 2021
Been playing this game with my friends for 3 years, almost every Thursday night.
This is the only couch co-op game that we keep playing on a regular basis

Gameplay

The gameplay is fluid and fast paced, with no input delay
Controls are easy to get the hang of
There's a lot of variety with weapons and maps
The skill ceiling became extremely high after we discovered angled shots
You can set the amount of rounds that you want in a match before starting
You can set the amount of rounds you want before an intermission, that shows the amount of rounds each player has won, this makes it more intense for the winning player as the others may capitalize and target the winning player


Its fun to devise strategies for maps so that you can throw the opponents off, or get to weapons faster than they can
There's also a ton of cosmetic items like hats and room decorations which are a nice touch
Extremely good soundtrack
The recent content update (1.5) added a lot more weapons and maps as well as soundtracks
It's also really cool that you can make custom hats and maps
If you are lacking weapons, maps or hats, you can always browse through the steam workshop




It's the perfect game to play with your friends and family couch co-op style
Suitable for all ages
Love seeing the look on my friends' faces when they die to a cooked grenade which was thrown from a mile away
Getting trickshot by a sniper is a whole other story, this really brings out the frustration and intensity
The heart sinking feeling when you stand on a mine and you know, that if you move, you're gone
Induces you with fear when you try to mash out of a cobweb before you're thrown off the edge
The sense of joy when you kill 3 ducks with a collateral is unrivaled



Absolute 10/10

Best co-op game that I have ever played

Posted: July 2, 2016
Pros:
- Has many weapons and tools, each with their own specific uses, range, penetration etc.
- Many unlockable hats, plus support for custom hats and maps
- Fast-paced, addictive gameplay makes it easy to start a "quick game" and hard to stop
- Rocking chiptune soundtrack
- Dedicated pitchable quack button

Cons:
- Netcode is weird; Lag seems to favor players with worse ping. I've often realized I've been shot just BEFORE an opponent stepped into range.
- There's no tutorial, so to learn the ropes you just have to get your arse kicked.
- No bots. Arcade mode has single-player challenges which admittedly helps, but only utilizes a handful of items in very specific scenarios.

Posted: June 8, 2015
Each round of multiplayer is on a new map, and you need to be the last duck standing to win the round. Win ten rounds and waddle away from those other loser ducks as you leave with the trophy. The game also has single player mini-game challenges for a variety of gameplay.

This is still one of me and my friends' favorite go to games.

PROS:
* A Very Enjoyable Experience, especially with "Local Multiplayer" for up to 4 players ()
* Lots of varying weaponry (and defenses) make each level feel non-repetitive.
* There are a few different ways to play, but most of the time this feels akin to Smash Brothers (and that's a positive for me).

CONS:
*

Verdict: A Worthy Purchase! Recommended if you like arena brawlers, and highly recommended for its local multiplayer.

I play this often in our house, and Steam Family Sharing makes this a great investment for a family or group of friends. I would have purchased a 4-pack for my friends and family; however, the Steam store originally only sold the game individually. It's worth it to get the 4-pack!

Posted: June 8, 2015
Duck game is 2d instant kill arena shooter.
The mechanics of the game are really simple - you need to use items around you to eliminate other ducks.
You can pick up and throw items, and you can use items. That's it, just two buttons.
And by "use" I mean a range of actions - from shooting the gun, to playing musical instruments, to throwing bananas around.
And you never know what comes next (kinda warioware-like) - you have to react very quick to your surroundings and changes in them (yes, you can blow up half of the level using bazooka).

Shoot, run, throw, jump, fly, jetpack, go crazy.
If you are into online multiplayer games - go for it.
If you have friends and 2-4 gamepads (and some alcohol) - go for it (but watch out for possible fighting in real life after losing!)
If you don't like crazy 2d games with simple mechanics - don't go for it, there's not much beyond that very simple combat there.

If you are interested in seeing gameplay, have a look here:

Disclaimer: You MUST, I repeat, MUST have friends to play this game with, playing with strangers without voice chat is no fun, really.
With that out of the way, duck game is no doubt my favorite game of the year (2017's), because of the fantastic job Landon did on the game, the effort people put into the music, the texture, the guns, the editor, the EVERYTHING. Everything in this game is just so fun, so well designed.

You know these games, these games people make for youtubers to play that are fun the first 2 hours and then just get dull, boring, repetitive?
Duck game aint none of that ♥♥♥♥. It's fun fun fun, you'll laugh so much it'll hurt. And even (almost) 200 hours later, I'm still laughing, having fun with my mates, using mods, creating stages, etc.
I'll list the pros/cons and you'll decide whether it's worth full price or not. I payed full price, I'm from a poor country and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ this game was worth it (Also, it's been going on a 50% sale lately, after a whole year without going on sale!)
Pros
Well designed predefined levels, that are actually balanced no matter how much people you play with
Levelling sistem that doesn't give players in-game advantages, but allows your preparation room to look dope af (We waited almost 2 years for this update!)
Balanced gameplay and weapons that leave room for advanced techniques
Fun physics

Posted: April 7, 2019
-Quick Review-
Duck Game is a 4-player, 2d shooter brawler battle arena style game developed by Landon Podbielski and released June, 2015.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Gameplay: There are basically two game modes, Arcade mode which is a single player version of Duck Game, where you choose between themed levels and race against the clock to get best times and the highest scores/trophies.


...And the 4-player battle mode where you're pitted against 3 other players (either friends, or randoms) in an all out fowl display of turducken destruction.


The controls for Duck Game are simple enough, basica movement with either a keyboard or controller, and shoot. There are a plethora of weapons and zones to fight in, and that's what keeps the game fresh and exciting.
...Well, that and screaming at your friends or vise versa.


Oh! I forgot the most important button... the "quack", my favorite, by far.

There's not much else to say about Duck Game because by design it's a simple game you can pick up, play a few rounds with friends, and go do something else.


I got out of it exactly what I was hoping for. If you'd like an idea of how the game looks I would welcome you to check out my video on the game... but since I wasn't playing with friends, it's not quite as fun as the utter chaos you normally experience while playing.

Posted: 5 March, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Those of us old enough to remember the game Scorched Earth will instantly recognize its spirit in ShellShock. Featuring an insane array of weapons, customizable tank bits, and maps, ShellShock will keep you playing for hours.

Unlocking new weapons and other bits doesn't feel like a grind at all. You earn them by leveling up, using other weapons until they get better, or by sheer luck of the draw. The in-game store has a bunch of different addons you can buy for your tank, but THERE ARE ABSOLUTELY NO IN-GAME MICRO-TRANSACTIONS. Period. Everything you can buy in the in-game store is bought using "Gears" that you earn by actually playing the game. In an age where aggressive micro-transactions are seen as a legit business model, it's refreshing to see a game that does things right.

Posted: December 16, 2020
With over 2100 hours in this incredibly affordable and fun game, an honest and thoughtful review from me is long overdue.

First of all I have to say, the amount of effort that has obviously been put into this should have warranted a price of way more than 7€. With also the option to buy this game in a 4 pack, making each copy another 2€ cheaper, this is incredibly generous and for long time players like me as well as for literally anyone who played more than like 3 rounds the money was definitely well spent.
Basically what you are buying is the opposite of an FPS-Shooter as you get as much time as you need to figure out in which exact direction and with how much power to shoot best.

There is an owerwhelming number and variety of different weapons and modes, of which many require their own and unique strategies, making for a lot of small things that even I haven´t yet figured out, and I frequently encounter other experienced players who haven´t either. All that is to say, this game should not get boring anytime soon if your goal is to perfect yourself.
Some bugs that haven`t gotten a fix or even a fixing attempt in years exist, but they are very minor and can even somewhat be exploited. Updates with new content happen rarely but surely. A big plus is that even if your PC is a literal potato it will probably run this game rather smoothly. The dev used to be playing regularly too, but, well, at least neither I nor anyone I know has seen him recently.

Most important to know however is that while it is possible to play alone, having a few friends with you will improve your experience here by a lot, I cannot stress enough how much of a difference one or more conversation partners might make. With game sizes of up to 8 players, everyone should be accommodated. If you´re like me you could also make some online friends, there are a lot of genuinely nice folks to find if you are lucky. With enough time and the help of discord or something comparable, it might start to feel more like a primitive social network than a tank game if you´re a talkative person. Sadly, the other end of the spectrum, such as rude and obnoxious players or people who seem to enjoy throwing profanities around, also has its fair share. You´ll meet players from all around the world, but for some reason, Germans (like me), Norwegians and Americans are the most common. Make of that what you will.

Before I end this review, there is one major downside here: The leveling system. There are a total of 100 levels to achive by earning xp from each round you play. This by itself is nothing bad, but after you reach level 85, each subsequent level becomes an unbearable grind. For reference, the xp requirement scales exponentially, so that level 90 is about a tenth and level 96 half of the xp it takes to reach level 100. For even further reference, getting all the way to level 100 took me exactly 785 hours and from what I gathered it is not uncommon for this number to be over 1000 hours even. Dedicated players generally sit at level 99 for months and it is understandably frustrating for them. Also, some game modes give way wayyy more xp than others, which leads to the least lucrative ones seeing little to no play at all, which is quite sad because they are just as much fun.

In conclusion, do consider spending your money here if you:
- are looking for a game to play with your friends or want to make new ones
- don´t mind slow progressing
- have a crappy PC that can´t run anything else
- liked the original worms game because this is basically the same thing with different design

If you read everything until here and meet me in game at some point, do tell me cause I´d be really interested in how many people actually read these. Until then!

Posted: April 24, 2022
As much as I like this game, I seriously can't give it a recommendation in good conscience.

I've been playing it for a decent while so I'm at a satisfactory point, so why am I saying I don't recommend the game? Easy. This is probably the most unfriendly game towards newer players that I've ever seen.

First and foremost, playing with randoms here is a nightmare. They're usually not very welcoming people, usually very toxic, and are mostly only going to want to join lobbies for EXP grinding, which takes a long time by the way, so that option's out the window. What if they want to play with friends that have been playing for some time? Well too bad, should've joined them at the same time they started playing, because you're going to be severely under equipped while your friends painfully outclass you and destroy you every game. Sure, there's single player content to help with leveling a little bit, but it doesn't get you too far, and after that leveling is only possible in multiplayer. Newer players simply have zero chance that it's not even funny. If they want to catch up, then just waste a massive chunk of your life grinding in multiplayer, easy right?

I might be at a point where the game is fun to play on my end, but this game is simply way too unfun for newer players because the weapon balancing between early level and late level weapons is absolutely busted in favor of the late level players, not to mention tank upgrades.

Posted: February 15, 2016
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I played a version of this game back in the early 90's and loved it then. We had a single cannon shot to obliterate the landscape and attempt to destroy our opponent. Shellshock Live includes over 250 weapons, I had hesitations that this would work. Sometimes too much variety can be overload.

Shellshock Live 
A Video of ShellShock Live
By: stubar
4v4 Teamplay


Gladly this game has a massive grind to open up all the weapons. I hate grinding in games, especially in PVP games. So why do I think it is good in this case? Well, the basic weapons are enough to enjoy the game to its full and recently the playerbase got a MASSIVE influx due to popular streamers publicising the game. Meaning you are pitched against other players of same experience with same weapon loadouts. I can imagine it could've been a problem with a small playersbase but not now.

Maybe preferably I'd like to have access to all weapons without a grind and be able to custom select which to include on the server I create or join a server that has a selection I like to play with. 250+ weapons is a LOT to get to grips with so maybe the devs have implemented their introductions in the best way. Time will tell...

One thing I didn't realise with Shellshock Live was that the most popular way of playing isn't turn-based but actually phase-based. So every player is setting their power and trajectory and deciding which weapon to launch at the same time. The result is very little waiting time for other players!! It keeps the game and the fun flowing extremely effectively.

Touraments have been added recently, I can't wait to try those!

The game is simple looking in design but the graphics are clean and effective.

I'll be spending a lot fo time in Shellshock for sure, highly recommmended!!

From Single Shot to shooting a Seagull that poops out... well, poop! It's amazing that almost every weapon is unique but that's not all. You can level up your favorite weapon to an even more deadly shot!


You have your classics like deathmatch and Free-for-All. But have you ever heard of Shoccer or Rebound (My personal favorite)? You'll have fun playing these different modes, all interchangeble like HP, Wind and mods.


You don't level up with DLC and microtransactions. You level up and get stronger by playing!


There is an in-game currency called Gears. You collect these while playing games. you can't buy them or cheat your way collecting them. Customize your tank, your victory song and buy special weapons only available in the shop!


Just buy it, it's a steal, even at full price.

Posted: April 4, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I have played shellshock live 2 on the browser for quite a while before I played the steam version. One thing I did not like in the browser version is in game purchases which they took out in the steam version. So I am really happy about that. It gives everyone an even ground and provides fair combat.

I love the steam version and would recommend it to anyone having an interest in artillery games.
Here is the pros and cons for shellshock live.

PROS:

1. Simple yet elegant graphics design. One does not get bored looking at it.

2. The massive amounts of weapons to obtain and upgrade. At the time I wrote this review, there are 367 weapons including the upgrades.

3. Active developer and community. The developer works with the player community to constantly improve the game with new content, new features or bug fixes.

4. Many game modes to choose from ( 8 I believe). With countless customization options that will satisfy every need. For example, you want to play with players your level, you can do that, you want a more fun and challenging game play, you can set mods to one weapons and wind to high etc.

5. 4 sections of tank upgrades to master!

5. And many more!

CONS?

1. Time consuming. Is it? I have played for 60 hours and I am already level 83. I know the game is a grind, but isn't every multiplayer game? For example, I played warframe for 360 hours, or grinded for 360 hours. Shellshock live in my opinion is a grind, yes, but compared to some other "popular" games out there, it is not a grind at all. I know low level is frustrating and everyone wants to level up, everyone wants to win. But be patient and you will eventually reach level 80 in 100 hours. Besides, the real grind starts at level 90. Unless you're hardcore and want to get every single achievement. Which I advise to not to do if you want a social life... Don't make such a big deal out of it!

2. The music gets repetitive after a while and sounds boring, but that's not a big deal. Just run some music in the background or something.

3. Hackers? This is also a big deal according to a lot of people. IT IS NOT! I have yet to see a hacker in the 60 hours i played. And besides, the latest updates reinforced security to eliminate the piratically non-existent hackers. And also, people complain about rulers......... yes, there are people who use rulers, but there are multiple ways you can take care of this. First, play a game with them, and lose, then set atmospheric nudge to ON, or set high wind, and then play the next game, and then accuse them of using a ruler, and they will be too ashamed to admit it and leave... and yeah.



Overall, shellshock live is a really fun and addictive game to pass the extra times you have. There is so much to do, so much to learn and so much rage when you miss a shot.... ayyyy.
GET IT! YOU WON'T REGRET IT!!

Posted: November 26, 2020
I'm nearing 1,000 hours of playtime, and the 2020 Steam Awards give me a reason to finally write a short review for this game, so here goes.


It's the successor to a flash game, yes, and you can tell, but that doesn't make it bad.
ShellShock Live has a core objective as simple as can be: Select a weapon, fire it and defeat your opponent(s). The great thing about it is that it's easy to get into and become addicted. It's a game anyone can pick up and start playing without much introduction. It's one of those "easy to learn, hard to master" games, because if you want to "git gud" and be consistently victorious, you'll have to develop a feel for it.

An important aspect of a game like this is replayability. Its variety is limited, in a way, but ShellShock Live overcomes this quite well with an impressive arsenal of different weapons (unlockable in various ways), a neat selection of game modes - some more difficult than others - and ultimately, allowing and encouraging different playstyles. It can become grindy; if you want to reach the highest level, unlock all achievements, or reach that #1 spot on the leaderboard (good luck), you'll need to invest time. But none of this is a requirement, you can just as easily set up a round with your friends and mess about for an hour or two.

This game doesn't need an in-depth review, there is not that much to tell. Having just been released from Early Access, if it looks at all interesting to you, give it a try. It's not big, so it downloads quickly, you're not going to spend the first ten hours getting used to it, and hell, if you really don't like it, it's not very expensive. It's a simple game that has grown up.

Posted: August 29
Overall: 9/10


ShellShock Live is the perfect example of an indie game with true longevity. Despite first coming out in 2015, 9 years ago, and officially reaching 1.0 status in 2020, This multiplayer 2D strategy tank game excels due to its blend of strategic depth, accessible gameplay, and captivating visuals.
ShellShock marries turn-based mechanics with real-time strategy, demanding careful consideration of each move, weapon choice, and environmental factors like wind and terrain. With HUNDREDS of unique and satisfying weapons and gadgets, you can develop creative strategies and adapt your playstyle as you progress and unlock more weapons to use and upgrades for your tank. This is especially true since you can reset your tank's improvements every week and redistribute them across the four branches of tank upgrades.
The customization options, while slightly limited, do add a personal touch as you can change minor things like your tank's appearance, and the map color (if you're hosting).
The main reason to play ShellShock in 2024 is for sure its accessible gameplay; It can be a great passive time killer. In the most basic sense, the game is easy to learn yet challenging to master. Within 30 minutes you can definitely get a feel for the game but even if that's not the case, ShellShock has an entire single player campaign full of levels all the way from trick shots to 2 v 2's against the AI to help you hone your skills and level up.
The biggest problem with ShellShock these days is that while the multiplayer focus enhances replayability and can offer both casual fun and intense competition, that same focus can be detrimental to the game in terms of player count, due to the game's age. As could probably be expected, any game that is almost a decade old will have trouble maintaining a player base, but especially multiplayer indie games. That is somewhat true here, as there are usually random active lobbies you can join at whatever time during the day and have a good enough time with, or you could host a lobby and get a full 3v3 with randoms in around 5 minutes or so, but this is absolutely not consistent. There are times where the game is basically dead, but to be honest, I think these kind of games are meant to be played with a personal group of friends anyway. There is certainly fun to be had with random players, but you're going to consistently have better time playing with people you know.


TL;DR:

ShellShock is an amazing indie multiplayer turn-based strategy game that is just as much fun now as it was in its prime, has very satisfying visuals, easy to grasp gameplay, and endless replayability. Regardless of the general player base not being as active these days, there's still plenty of new and veteran players to play with, but the game exceptionally thrives when you're playing with your friends anyway and for the price point, it is a MUST PLAY!

Posted: January 13, 2019
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Now I'll preface with the fact that the many hours I've played this it isn't the game itself I'm giving a negative review for, it's the playerbase and the servers that makes this game so unfun to play.

Since this is a negative review I'll begin with why I'm giving it such a review:

- 90% of the games people make are 'XP farms' which involve all the players moving to the centre of the map and shooting themselves in one big group, and the rest are '4.08x XP' Rebound games that take almost 40 minutes to finish if you're lucky. Any attempt I make to make other games such as Juggernaut or the other unexplored game modes results in literally nobody joining, thus making no games possible.

- Since there's no punishment for leaving other than losing the XP you would've gained in that battle, people will simply leave early if they think they aren't going to win, giving the other team an advantage and the rest of the team a much more difficult fight.

- For whatever reason, the servers have a tendency to randomly disconnect you from games, simply removing you from them for literally no reason. You can't control it, it just happens whenever it wants to. I can't have fun in actually battles because I'm constantly afraid of just being booted from them, like I was on the last one before I got DC'd, and that the entire enemy team left.

Better put, the game would be brilliant if it had an actually functioning playerbase and servers.

NOW, the reason I've put so many hours into this despite this is how many problems I have with the playerbase is how fantastically designed the game is.

- The visuals are brilliant. The tanks, land and sky are simple and smooth, and everything is easy to tell apart. The tank accessories are stylish, the UIs are clean, and the weapons' effects are stellar. It's clear a lot of work went into the weapons, as I'll be about to explain.

- The titanic array of weapons makes earning weapons and playing with them such a fun experience. The game has easily 200+ weapons that can be earned in all kinds of ways: via achievements, the gear shop, levelling up, challenges. There's so many weapons and so many ways to get them that it almost feels neverending, and that's a great thing in a game like this. The weapons are all so different too that you almost feel like a god when you learn what they do, and learn how to use them. They all have different kinds of uses too, so you'll rarely be out of options. Some are risk-reward-based, some are purely for utility, and some are amazing when you know how they work.

- The single player challenges are somewhat fun, but some of them aren't very fun, especially the AI-based ones since making challenging yet fun AIs is always a challenge. Of course, you get some nice weapons from them, so it's always worth doing just to expand your arsenal.

- The selection of 8 creatively-made gamemodes makes it difficult to be bored in this game, even if no one plays them. I always like setting up Juggernaut games because I like the idea of everyone taking down a superpowered player.

All in all, I think ShellShock is a GREAT game, but it's really the half-brained playerbase and the bad servers that make it hard to enjoy, even with everything that I like about it. Now, if you were playing this with a group of friends in a lobby together this would be perfect, but that's really the only circumstance I can think of that someone could legitimately enjoy this game now.

However it's locked off behind levels and ranks so unless you've poured 600 hours into the game you're going to find that most of the elitist community will destroy you instantly and tell you to work for your fun, which is tricky when there is a very limited playerbase. You'll be stuck on those basic weapons forever unless you have friends at the same levels as you, ensuring the game is actually half-way balanced.

I like the game but find it hard to recommend to people starting off, as its huge grind factor to get to the fun stuff is very offputting.

Posted: January 3, 2023
These are 671.7 hours that I won't ever see again

Jokes aside, I highly discourage you from playing this game unless you're just like me. A child who had seen his favorite YouTubers post videos frequently and really wished for the chance to play with them (never happened). Regardless, I used to frequently play this game daily and pretty much got to the point I am comfortable writing this review.

Shellshock Live is a game in which your success is highly determined by the numbers of your display. If your friends or randos you meet drastically overlevel you, you practically have zero chances of overpowering them unless one or more of the following happen(s):
1. The high level is in the middle of a lobotomy and cannot aim for you
2. You have astronomical levels of luck
3. The high level has gone easy on you
4. The high level just had to leave the game
If that doesn't happen, get ready to be whooped.

As a high level player, low level players will kick you out their lobby for daring to join. As a low level player, high level players will crush you while openly mocking your shortness of good weapons and experience (lord forbid you don't play this game as often or as hardcore as they do). Of course, a decent chunk of the playerbase is cool. The other chunk, however, makes people like you and me reconsider the First Amendment.

The game itself is fine, but it lacks heavily in some aspects:
1. The games Skill Rating system is entirely style, no substance. You have a number that goes higher when you win and lower when you lose and that is it. There's no considerations for any skill shots or displays of high damage, no consideration of the gamemode and no consideration of whether you've used up any items or not.
2. The entirety of the Shoccer gamemode is extremely poor and makes me question whether it wasn't just added because the devs just enjoy the IRL sport. One good example of this modes shortcoming is that shots programmed to go for the tank will do just that, contradicting the gamemode's goal of hitting that stupid ball that behaves as appropriately as the current Twitter CEO
3. Shoccer sucks, seriously. I've not met a single player who wasn't playing it for the achievement
4. The chatbox on the main menu is littered with absolute garbage, most of the time.

That said, this game has some redeeming qualities:
1. Many of the weapons are fun to use and look good
2. Your Rebound shots can be a display of the fact you can do more than the players who stick to 100 86 in Deathmatches as if their life was actually on the line
3. The music is really pleasant to listen to
4. More stuff that you might appreciate that I simply don't bother to count up

Thank you for reading this far, I guess

Posted: November 16, 2018
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
YouTube™ Video: ShellShock Live Review 
Views: 5,212
Read the written review here: https://steamcommunity.com/id/ParadoxWolf/recommended/326460/ Subscribe and Follow my Curator page for more reviews like this one:...


Overview
ShellShock Live may sound familiar to you even if you haven’t heard of this Steam version yet, because the game has been a fairly popular Flash title for quite a long time. Neither this nor the flash versions are incredibly unique or original titles, but that isn’t to say that they don’t compete well. It certainly seems a bit strange to title a game something that essentially translates to “P.T.S.D. Live”. But it is a game about tanks and massive weaponry so I suppose it makes sense.

ShellShock Live is a two dimensional tank game, where each player takes turns firing from their random assortment of weapons. Before you have leveled or progressed at all, you will already have a very wide range of different types of weapons to use. As you play, you’ll level up your account and your weapons, giving you all sorts of new weapons and upgraded versions of the same weapons. This is definitely one of the most fun aspects of the game, the sheer amount of different tools to play with.

The idea of so many varying weapons somewhat throws balance out the window, when each match you are randomly assigned a set of weapons from your unlocked options. You may have weapons where everything you have is hard to aim and low damage, then you may have another game where you have multiple massive AoE nuke weapons. As you level up you will also earn upgrade points that you can use to modify your tanks overall stats as well. This includes things such as how mobile it is, its armor, critical damage, luck, and a few other bonuses tacked onto those stats. These stats plus the upgraded weapons makes it less fair when fighting players of vastly different levels, but well aimed shots and some lucky RNG can quickly make up the difference. If you are still bothered by the imbalance, there are some game options for avoiding big level gaps, or even balancing out the weapons across players.

Matches in ShellShock Live tend to last no more than 10 minutes, unless you’re playing some of the more absurd game modes, such as ones with high health or that require you bounce your shot off a bumper to deal damage. As with most games, it is certainly the most fun if you have some friends that can tag along with you. You can play a mad Free-For-All or team matches with up to 8 players. It is to be noted however, that there is currently no local multiplayer option.

The game is turn based, allowing each player to perfect their angle and power in order to land their shots. Game settings allow you to change between individual turns, team turns, or all players taking their turn simultaneously. There are also several different game modes other than just trying to eliminate your opponents. This includes things such as shooting increasingly smaller targets, or a Juggernaut mode where all players face off against 1 enemy with much greater health. Match options also allow you to do some smaller adjustments like changing the intensity of the wind or overall player health.

The UI is attractive and clean. The bright, neon colors work well for the game’s aesthetics, and are easily readable on a dark background. It’s very easy to navigate the menus, quick to get into a match or to modify your settings. During a match there are clear indicators helping you know where previous shots went, your current power and angle, direction and level of wind, as well as all players’ health.

Mouse and Keyboard works perfectly well. You can drag with your mouse to get your shot’s angle and power near where you want it, and you can use the arrow keys to make smaller adjustments to get it right where it needs to be. These controls are unable to be changed, and I would also recommend against using a controller in the game’s current state. There are some things the controller is just unable to do, such as clicking on “Gear” rewards during a match, or making quick changes to your aim.

ShellShock Live is full of bright, vibrant colors. From the neon tanks and UI to the wide array of different colored weapons. The art style is clean and attractive, and reads well for this type of game. It’s easy to distinguish different weapons from one another while they’re in the air, and many of the weapons special effects are incredibly satisfying.

Even though this is a 2D game they do provide some graphical options upon launching the game. These include windowed mode, resolution, and graphic levels. The graphic settings seem to be the default Unity options and they all seem to be effectively identical.

The game has a few original songs that play in the menus that all sound fairly similar. They’re all very “epic” sounding orchestral themes, that fit pretty well into the downtime between matches. There are also a dozen different short song clips that can be used as “Victory Tunes” which are more varied in their sound. They’re all very fun and playful, and tend to be quite amusing at the end of a match.

Sound effects work well. Menu noise while mousing over options and making selections gets a bit annoying, but you won't spend too much time in the menus. Many of the different weapons use some of the same sounds, but most of them are satisfying enough. There are many silly, fun sounds tied to some of the more strange weapons as well that really ties the feeling of the game together. There’s nothing quite like waiting in fear as the pooping sounds of a Seagull lead to your imminent demise.

ShellShock Live is a fun game. It provides a lot of different options for game modes and weapon variation, as well as giving players many different ways to progress. When you can so easily just play a couple matches a day, the addition of progression really makes it so you want to keep coming back and playing it from time to time. Although there are certainly many other options for similar games, I would say for this price point it’s worth giving it a try with your friends.

Posted: June 18, 2023
This game is a very fun time-sink for people who want something to grind in the background. That being said, the player base is very old, so the XP Grind is slow and everyone else you play with who are active are much higher level, which means you're unlikely to win often until you're in the high 70s-80s in terms of player level. Also, several of the weapons in the game are just bad, with seemingly no hope of them ever being rebalanced or buffed. New daily quests will be like "Get a kill with X" and X could either be great or terrible. The worst part about it though is that I'm pretty sure the chance of you getting that weapon is higher when you have that daily challenge, so it's either do the challenge or be cursed to see that weapon often (I'm looking at you, Counter 3000). The players are toxic and unhinged as well, saying anything from the offensive to the "lol so quirky xd," there's very quite a lot of annoying people, which is a high downside to a game that's mostly a chatroom. If you want to slog for dozens of hours to get to the point where you can have fun in the average game, can ignore terribly toxic people, don't mind the game crippling you with bad weapons as challenges that get forced down your throat, and don't mind that a good handful of the weapons are actually detrimental to unlock because they're so bad, then this game is perfect for you as a normal tank battler. Otherwise, buyer beware.

Decided I should finally add a review for this.

Anyway it is a much better game than the flash versions with the main P2W element gone all you have to do is pay for the game and you're golden.

The main negatives are lack of people which can be helped by more people buying the game and due to the vast majority of people owning this game in the american time zones it is rare for me to be able to get a game during the day here, but once again that is only due to the amount of people who own the game.
The weapons are good in most cases but they seem to encourage close range gameplay over mid to long range and the xp requirements are just way to much for some weapons (shot, breaker, bulger to name a few)

But as it is still in early access there is much room for change, improvement and new stuffs.
I recommend people give it a try before you pass it up as it can become addicting ^^
This cat gives it 8/10 at the minute =^_^= €15 well spent

Edit: The game is now almost a year out and now with the recent boom in players it is finally beginning to feel like a decent game. I still recommend this game to all, it is now half the price it started at and at least 10x the player base it started with ^^

Posted: November 26, 2017
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
"Imagine Worms but with Tanks"

I found Shellshock Live after watching the Derp Crew screw around for a bit, and since then have found it sliiiightly difficult to let go of myself. It plays tribute to a lot of the older flash games, but remains current due to the one-man dev constantly updating the game with additional content that challenges hardcore and new players alike. The graphics are simple but bright and compelling, and the game offers hours of gameplay whether alone or with a group of friends.

An important aspect of this game that really entices me is the ability to upgrade everything. As you progress through 100 levels, tanks can be upgraded with new skills or parts, and new weapons can be unlocked. These weapons which are constantly being introduced can also be upgraded further to cause a outrageous amount of damage. Furthermore, the in-game store also offers a chance to purchase speciality themed weapons with "gears" that are earned throughout game-play. There are no micro-transactions which make this game stand out even further. Once you've brought the game, you own everything, which means people with a rich daddy can't get an advantage over you this way.

There are currently 8 game-modes available which respective challenges to keep people active on the servers. The aiming system is consistent and easy to get the grasp of, but new players can dive into the campaign levels to help level their tanks quicker and understand the mechanics before diving into multiplayer if they so choose.

Like all games, theres always going to be a group of party-poopers that tend to ruin the game for you. However due to such a large playerbase, you're likely going to meet some pretty rad players too, and you'll be able find more chill groups to play with. The in-game mute button also helps cease the cancer that might be pestering the current game, but you can use it as a tool to identify players before you allow them into your lobby for the next game. Rage-quitters and "Ruler" cheaters are always going to exist, so it would be nice in the future for more penalties to exist to combat this issue. Overall though, you're going to make friends whether you like it or not, because most people are pretty chill.


Shellshock Live is constantly changing for the better. Theres always new content, a great xp system, and overall fun people play with. I got it super cheap, but I'd be happy to pay a little more for the amount of fun I've gotten out of it.

Posted: March 12, 2017
Product received for free

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Shellshock Live is a very relaxing game with a frantic assortment of crazy weapons to throw at your opponents. Your mission: shoot stuff at tanks to destroy them. It's literally that - no more, no less. You can shoot with everything - grenades, frogs, fish, sillyballs, MOONS, pooping birds etc.

Gameplay is simple:
At the start of the game you spawn with the set amount of health on a (randomly) chosen map, which can be in different team compositions, 1v1 through 4v4, or 1v7, or a free for all-murder-everyone mode. You get equipped with a set of weapons randomly selected from the ones you have unlocked so far. During your turn, you can select a weapon and a trajectory to damage your opponents. ez life.

It has a level-based system in two separate segments: you can level up to unluck new weapons and perks, and you can level up your weapons by dealing damage with them. You can level up by playing missions, or playing multiplayer games. Your progress depends on your participation (kills/dmg etc, with a bonus for being MVP), the amount of trickshots you hit, and - additionally - you level up for unlocking achievements. With each new level you unlock a new weapon and an "upgrade gear" with which you can increase one of your perks (damage boosts, shield boost, mobility boost and.. luck boost).
Leveling up weapons will result in having the possibility to get an upgraded version of the original weapon, which can increase damage, range, area of attack, number of projectiles, or simply the ease to use.

It comes with a bunch of different playmodes and settings to finetune the game to your preference for you and your friends

As an easy to play, laid back multiplayer game it's very suitable to pass time or to hang around with friends (definitely recommended to play with friends; which greatly enhances the joy you can get out of the game). It has a slightly nice balance between luck, skill and silliness, although on higher levels, the weapons you get can often already decide the game.

Pros:
- Entertaining gameplay
- "Simple yet effective" graphics
- Nice music and sound effects
- ideal to play with friends
- also suitable for grinding levels/achievements for those that need that to keep them playing
- Your tank can be a beachball. (not really, but it can be round and beachballs are round)
- MOONS
- GUPPIES
- BOUNSPLODE
- Piñata music

Cons:
Only one I can really think of, which can provide quite a drawback: At later levels, the game is frequently already decided by the weapons you get equipped with. There are a few weapons that are vastly more powerful than others, and the higher you get, the more this applies. This effect stacks with your positioning (which you can alter to an extent though, if you upgrade mobility); some weapons only work in close proximity or in certain areas. This goes up to a point where getting poor weapons, or only close-range weapons when in a longrange position, can result in rendering you unable to be efficient at all. While I would not consider winning the main point of the game, it can make quite a dent in your playing experience.

All in all this game is definitely worth it. I've received it as a gift, and have fond memories of playing it. Havent played in a while, both due to lack of time, and because the friends I used to play with rarely play it nowadays (the latter definitely influences me as its much more fun to play with friends). All in all I would definitely recommend!

Rating:
8/10

I used to play games like ShellShock Live on those websites where you can play free games. Like armorgames, maxgames, stupidmonkeygames. But none of them were online multiplayer games. This game really hits the spot of amultiplayer artillery strategy turn-based game.

Players control tanks in a 2D landscape. They aim and shoot the enemy tanks to defeat them with their own in team or free-for-all matches. Shots can be fired after maneuvering its trajectory by adjusting its angle and power. Players up to 8 can play in a match. There are different game modes such as Deathmatch, Points, Assassin, Juggernaut, Rebound, Charge, Marksman and Shoccer. There are 339 weapons that can be obtained by leveling up. This game is overall a great game, but there are few flaws in the game.

Pros:

+ Great Graphics
Extreme improvement over the flash versions

+ Great Music
A cycle of calm and intense music with victory music makes the game much more appealing

+ Extreme Number of Weapons
Over 400 weapons to unlock and upgrade to destroy opponents with. More weapons are always in the making. (Although the average time period for new weapons could be better)

+ Addicting
There is a weird glitch making you go back and play over and over again.

+ Play with your Friends
Playing with friends makes the game more enjoyable than with some random jerk

+ 9 Different Game Modes
Be the last one standing in Deathmatch, inflict the most damage in Points, destroy 1 tank at a time in Assassin, steal other's voltage with damage in Charge, attack a ball to score in Shoccer, become the sniper in Marksman, team up or destroy all in Juggernaut, become an expert at imagining segmented parabolas in Vortex, and become the master of trajectories in Rebound.

Cons:

- EXTREME luck factors in game
Random starting weapons, weapons with RNG, one tank gets a close x2 damage, easy to impossible bumpers in Rebound the game is full of RNG. Luck has a good impact on who wins, however the more skilled a player, the higher chance of victory.

- Could be better Community
Many players of this game are toxic, but there are a good handful of players that are fun to play with.

If you aren't sure to buy this game yet, you can check out the flash version (ShellShock Live/ShellShock Live 2) which are both free. The Steam version has much more content, and is instead play to win, not pay to win.

Posted: 27 June, 2017
Possibly a review of Worms as a franchise rather than just WMD specifically.

I've enjoyed Worms for a long time, not just for the MP, but mostly the Single Player. Worms is a strategy game that's both simple, and also has absolutely no RPG elements. There's no grinding a unit or worry about how terrible that level up was for Lyn or farming for equipment and hoarding for later missions. Every mission in Worms, is a carefully crafted area to give you a fair but hard trouble (At least, later in the game. They start off jokingly easy of course). The later missions will outnumber you 4 to 12 worms with twice the health, and it's you'll feel great when you outsmart their dumb-but-superaccurate AI.
Worms MP is probably the most popular though, and many people play it as a joke for stupid fun. It's the type of game where when you make a mistake, it's pretty funny how it stacks up. It also has goofy weapons such as a super sheep and even a Grandma. Despite the stupid fun, I equate this game to Smash Bros in terms of "You play it for stupid fun, but then you'll end up playing it as an esports". This game has the possibility to be a legit competetive game with the proper ruleset, and Team17 is definitely acknowledging this with their ESL support in WMD.

Worms WMD as an entry in the franchise is great. It goes back to cute 2D graphics with 60fps animations, rather than stupid ugly 3D graphics in a 2D game with 30fps animations. The rope is back to being unrealistic (can rope straight up, fast, hard and not wiggly), large variety of weapons, full length campaign and extra challenges, fully-featured multiplayer.
The surprise is what they added, crafting. At first, "oh my god why does everything have crafting", then I realize the genius. This diminishes the RNG of crate drops by being able to craft what you want, but the real improvement? You have something to do on someone elses turn. No more waiting boringly. Speaking of which, this game switches turns fast (I recall an earlier Worms, there's a 10 second wait from when a turn ends and when a turn starts)

Highly recommend this Worms in particular, and the franchise in general.

Posted: 10 August, 2020
I recommend this game, as it is lots of fun, but at the same time there are reasons I would not recommend it. Let me explain.

As a single player it offers a variety of missions and challenges, which can keep you occupied for a while. But competing against A.I. gets boring quickly, because of how predictable (and bad) your computer opponents are, and then you really want to play against other humans. If you’re in a household with other family members or have real life friends to play with, it should be ok. However, if you’re a single guy living alone, like me, you have to venture into the online world to find people to play with.

For many years, I have avoided playing online games on Steam, and here I was once again reminded why I made that conscious decision back then. Now, let me first say that I did meet a bunch of nice people to play with, but, unfortunately, as always, there are a few bad apples that tend to stick out. I was barely 100 online games in, and was already confronted with the most foul language you can imagine, rage quitters, people kicking me from games, just because I won the previous one and certain “top players”, who think they are God’s gift to humanity, just because they are skilled in an online game and don’t shy away from reminding you every 2 minutes of it. These people can really ruin your online experience. If you’re a parent and you allow your child to play this game online, you may want to bear this in mind. I don’t know if these are kids or adults who never grew up emotionally, but I have ZERO TOLERANCE for this kind of behavior, especially the foul language (which goes as far as rape and death threats). I don’t care what your mental disability is, I WILL report you.

Other than that, finding people to play a game with can take a while. At times the lobby is pretty much empty. Of course, this game is already 4 years old, so naturally most people have moved on. But when you do have a game with a bunch of good people, it sure is a lot of fun. Being able to use vehicles, mounted guns, hide in buildings and craft tons of insane weapons is awesome!

Posted: 21 March, 2020
Worms. Worms 2. Worms Armageddon. Worms 3D. Worms Forts. Worms: Open Warfare. Have they made enough Worms games yet? More than 20 games exist in the main Worms series, and there's still games like Worms Blast and Worms Crazy Golf that take the physics of the Worms games and apply them to other mechanics.

What improvements were made from, say, Worms 2 (1997) to Worms: Reloaded (2010)? Umm... Worms: Reloaded did have hats. Don't get me wrong, aside from the period where things went off the rails and the Worms games went full 3D, many of the newer installments have been quite good, but they just haven't really added or changed anything worthwhile. I would be perfectly happy playing one of the original games.

Worms W.M.D is literally a game-changer. W.M.D takes the classic 2D Worms formula, and adeptly outfits it with enough new shiny mechanics and enhancements that it's a wonder it wasn't done before.

This installment of Worms adds vehicles: tanks, helicopters, and mechs, etc. Each vehicle has a set of disadvantages and advantages, and they all look and sound amazing. The drillboat is capable of traversing land OR water, which can be extremely useful in certain situations. While you can cause some major destruction inside of these vehicles, don't get caught in a bad spot; it's going to hurt when one of them explodes with you inside. Additionally, the game adds machine guns, flamethrowers, and other stationary weapons around the map for you to use as you crawl around the map. Nothing in this game feels superfluous, and it all has a reason behind it. I've found myself realizing game after game about the sometimes not-so-obvious merits and side effects of the new map elements.

Over the years, I've bought new Worms games and enjoyed them, but frequently found myself disappointed when some of the great classic weapons were removed. I'm proud to report that W.M.D brings back ALL of the best weapons from the series, as far as I'm concerned. Banana Bomb, Concrete Donkey, Super Sheep, Holy Hand Grenade, Sentry Gun, Carpet Bomb - they're all here... and they can be upgraded. In Worms W.M.D, a new crate drop has resources that you can use to craft weapon upgrades, as well as new weapons. This means that you can upgrade your Concrete Donkey to an Angry Concrete Donkey, which falls through the earth covered in FLAMES. The Shotgun can be upgraded into a Training Shotgun, which has laser sights on it. And if you are having a hard time finding the classic Ming Vase, the Dynamite upgrades into it, which makes sense, as having them be separate item slots would be redundant. The Ninja Rope is back again, and the physics are actually shockingly similar to the classic Worms games, which will be a relief for roping veterans.

Maps now will usually have buildings on them if they are enabled. When inside a building, your worms can crawl through their tunnels and seek strategic vantage points. If you don't have any worms inside a building, you can't see any enemies that may be inside. It's very well done, and adds an extra stealth element to the game.

While the game still very much shines as a multiplayer/party game, the single player modes are engaging and exciting. There are many challenges of different sorts for you to complete, and as you complete them you will unlock various goodies, such as new speech banks (accents) for your worms.

The sound effects, particle effects/explosions, and environments are all fantastic and set a new standard for the series, too. Excellent.

Having played MANY of the Worms games in my lifetime, I can confidently say that Worms W.M.D is the best game in the series. It honors the wisdom of the original games by retaining their strengths while innovating in just the right ways. If you have ever found this series even remotely interesting, you need to buy this one.

Sure, I played Armagmeddon for hours too.
Later when the 3D episodes started I stopped playing it; especially because T17 made you pay for DLC. But with Worms W.M.D I have got a full update to Armageddon.

I don't want to put too much technical detail into this review nor any spoilers.

Worms was always hard, that's what makes it whileworthy; I always have the feeling that I could improve any single turn that I make. That's why IMHO the most powerful ability is the Reset Mission button. In W.M.D a mission might easily take you several days to finish it to your satisfaction, especially the later ones (if you don't cheat [a walkthrough is a cheat too ;)]).

Another plus is that once I bought the game, I didn't have to pay for DLC (All-Star-Pack and Forts expansion). Thanks for this Team 17, back to the roots.

In W.M.D I don't miss anything in comparison to Armageddon. Except one thing: I like Armageddon's progressive electronic soundtrack more than W.M.D's mellow easy listening style whatever. But there also might be a workaround for this. [Or maybe Team17 could add some classic or new tracks. ;-)]

All in all: If you like Artillery, get W.M.D. If you like(d) Worms, get W.M.D, if you like Armageddon, then don't throw it in the trash, if you want an unforgetable evening with up to 6 or 8 players (best with friends, or if you ever wanted to banana-bomb the **** out of your little brother or sister or your parents), get W.M.D... and for the funny moments in the game, get W.M.D.

Posted: December 10, 2017
One of the better modern Worms game to date, but is it better then Armagedon ? Well that's always a difficult question as Armagedon holds so much nostalgia for many people, so it's always a given people will say Armagedon is better in every way which is well deserved since Armagedon was the most pure Worms gameplay in the franchise and the peak on how gravity,wind,weapons and general gameplay felt but people kinda wear the Armagedon rose tinted glasses a bit too much and tend to sadly shun changes or additions to the worms formula which is a shame.

So is it better ? Personally for me I'd say it's almost equal to Armagedon because it has a lot of fun new elements while keeping the core formula intact but it does do one thing kinda worse which is subjective and that's the physics for rockets and grenades which seem to have a lot more drop and odd behaviors which i wish it was more armagedon-esk, if the physics behaved more as Armagedon's I'd say WMD is maybe the better game but that's not the case, the physics in WMD aren't bad, they just feel kinda odd at times to me and it's sorta the only major thing i'd say keeping it back.
Now, the new things added into the worms formula via WMD feel like they compliment the game fairly well, such as the addition of vehicles which is something i wanted to see as a kid back in the 90s even, has finally been added to the classic 2D worms gameplay and they're a neat feature that adds a new fun,cool and silly gameplay element to Worms. If it bothers you, you can easilly turn it off in the options, matter of fact all the new additions can be pretty much turned off if you really just want the most basic worms gameplay.

Another addition to the formula is the fact you can now enter buildings, they're no longer just shapes in the terrain used in the environment, if there's a house you can now enter it and peak out of the window to fire which is pretty great and in my opinion a nice step forward for the franchise without going overboard and without damaging the core fun formula.

And one more thing they added is crafting, while waiting for your turn you can dismantle weapons and use crafting materials to craft weapons you need. Got a bannana bomb but want a holy hand granade ? Dismantel it and use the materials to make a holy hand granade. You can also modify existing weapons, such as making the bazooka leave napalm after hiting its target,craft a super flying sheep that farts out gas as it flies,craft a super bannana bomb which you can controll on when it detonates,craft an even more powerfull angry donkey,make your regular grenade into a sticky nade and so on and so on.

The rest of the game is pretty much what you expect from Worms, there's a nice campaign to mess about in with challanges and practices, an online mode that supports up to 6 players with the promise of bots finally being added into online play soon, something which i haven't seen happen in a long time.There's fair amount of cosmetic hats and voice options for worms to make your own team and maps can be easilly made in the similar way as Armagedon and uploaded to the workshop to be quikcly downloaded. There's also an XP leveling system that gives you more cosmetics for completing campaign missions,playing ranked or what most people will be doing which is playing either locally or online with some friends in a party match for fun.

So the only two things i somewhat don't like in Worms W.M.D are the physics for some weapons which feel a bit wonky and the art animation style for the worms doesn't look pleasing to me, everything else in the game looks,feels and sounds great, i especially love how there's now debris flying and bouncing around on the map after an explosion and then dropping into the water which makes it feel more satisfying, the art on the maps also looks good but as i mentioned a bit earlier the art on the actual worms just doesn't look visually appealing to me, for me they look like they were drawn in flash by some newgrounds artist and then animated in that style too, it just kinda looks a tad cheap to me but that's just my personal view on the art style used for the worms.

Overall i think it's a pretty great addition to the worms franchise and i hope it maybe catches on some more and gets improved by the devs since sadly every attempt from Team 17 to have a definitive worms game the community will move into has failed and i think this one has the chance to be that worms game that could bring majority of the small Worms community together in one place instead of having everyone spread about into so many worms games.

Posted: August 27, 2016
If you have never been near a Worms before, all you need to know is that it is a single and multi-player (local + online) turn-based strategy game in which teams of funny little Worms try to murder each other with a vast arsenal of conventional and unconventional weapons, and the destructible background reflects the violence taking place on its surface while adding new layers of possibilities. And failure can be hilarious.

I have fond memories of the Worms series since 1995. There has been a peak in 1999 with Worms Armageddon, and since then it has been a bumpy road that timidly tried new things here and there but never a solid offering with all the features that are expected to be present. The potential of the series was diluted by entries that thought they were trying some new things while constantly dropping the good stuff from the previous episodes. Strangely, overall no real progress was made and more was lost than gained.

Worms W.M.D still has some of these issues. The map specificities (fog, earthquake, gravity) from a few of the previous entries (mostly Worms Open Warfare 2) are lost. The dynamic water weapons from the 2.5D entries are missing too. The funny videos are long lost since Worms 1 and 2. The ability to draw maps did not come back (however, it is now possible to import pictures again). And finally, some details such as deeper customisation and some rope features (length) will not please die-hard Worms Armageddon fans.

Apart from those nit-picks, however, Worms W.M.D is the strongest entry in the series since Worms Armageddon. Most features are there, from the local multiplayer to classic commando missions. The 2D graphics are gorgeous, the Worms re-design is great and the overall feel is more military than goofy. It runs well (apart for the somewhat slow AI), binding new key inputs is possible, and so on. Overall, it is solid. But that’s not enough to set itself apart. So here come the novelties.

Buildings that can be entered. Good hiding places and protection, while putting tunnels back to the heart of the series. Mounted weapons that add a layer of danger. And most excitingly, vehicles! Tanks and mechas, both can jump and are easy to handle. Then helicopters, which end up being a very useful taxi for those players that dominate you and fly back to safety without burning jetpack fuel or having to master the rope. Mmmf, I have mixed feelings about that. Whatever I think of the helicopter, all those additions completely re-write the dynamic of the game. It feels a lot less static for us that are not masters of the ninja rope, and also I think the basic movements, albeit slow, are much smoother than usual since the Worms don’t get stuck just because of a small slope hindering their slimy way. And finally, crafting. I hate crafting, but thankfully it is not obnoxious here. Can be a life-saver to get a new jetpack, or eventually craft a concrete donkey if you have enough parts. Why would you craft anything else? It’s the most reliable.

To conclude, Worms W.M.D is not the perfect game. I will always miss the explosive violence of Worms 1, with its maps and bridges full of mines for chaotic chain reactions. The die-hard Worms Armageddon fans will not have every single feature that they are used to and expect to find. But then Worms W.M.D is better than everything else that the series has recently brought us, with its own novelties that are enough to justify its existence. Good, solid entry, that I hope will be expanded upon rather than dropped in favour of a quick new episode that forgets the good things once again. If it’s your first Worms or if you casually like the Worms series, or if you need to find something new to play with your friends, this new Worms is an easy recommendation, albeit a bit expensive for now.

The good ol' Worms you know and love with a fresh new look!
The updated graphics (the terrains are especially BEAUTIFUL) really capture the lighthearted fun of Worms (though I was a little suprised they went for the vector style as opposed to cashing in on the current pixel fad, I suppose that makes the game a little more timeless) The controls are as smooth as ever! The new tanks, turrets, choppers, and mechs (oh my!) add an amazing new aspect to this beloved classic. Multiplayer is great with new 1v1 ranked matchmaking. The current DLC (and more to come) really adds to the fun. It truly might be the perfect Worms game, taking all of the great aspects from the old games and adding new features that really are icing on the cake.

Now for my story...
I was raised on Worms, I've played since the Dreamcast days back in '99 (Armageddon) and honestly it is one of my favorite videogame franchises of all time. Worms has always had the amazing ability to satisfy the hardcore and casual gamers alike. I can't count the number of times I've introduced it to people (who have suprisingly never played) and their first impression is always "This is weird". But after the first match they are hooked! This feeling for me never gets old, spreading the magic and wonder of Worms and after all these years the lil' guys still got it!
Thanks Team17 for all the memories and for staying true to your roots. I can't wait to see what more is in store for W.M.D.

EDIT: Currently pretty buggy (terrain not loading fully, weapons glitching, lots of crashing on multiplayer, etc) at least for me. Also, multiplayer quickmatch lobby is a little messy- everytime a player enters or leaves it 'unreadies' you so you are constantly hitting the READY button (which is almost a like a game in itself!)

All easily fixable stuff in an otherwise great new installment in the wonderful World of Worms! (the other WoW)

Posted: September 29, 2017
A review from Worms Armageddon veteran.

Another clunky cash grab from Team 17 bloated with unnecessary bells and whistles, while the game itself isn't nearly as smooth and enjoyable as Worms Armageddon.

PROS:
+ Slightly closer to WA in terms of graphics, customizability and game feel than previous entries.
+ Now you technically can play good-old custom game modes like shopper, WxW, rope race (no bow'n'arrow though), doesn't mean it will be as fun and smooth as it used to be.
+ You can customize your team's looks.
+ Runs without slightest hiccups on a modern systems, unlike WA.
+ Proper SteamWorks integration for multiplayer.
+ Big enough single player campaign, because people buy this game to play single player, right?

CONS:
- The game's physics are really bad, everything is too heavy and there are no options to tune it to your liking. Even the "Low Gravity" item isn't there anymore. Forget about efficiently roping around, bouncing grenads off terrain for cool skillshots or making something skip on water.
- Weapon category and hotkey layout is a mess. In WA it was like F7+Space+F7 and you're on a rope with parachute selected, ready to traverse the map without worrying that a slight mistake will end your turn. Here parachute is on F2, because... I guess Team17 doesn't want you to have convenient hotkey controls...
- No adjustments for weapon power or rope length, which cripples experience from barely playable classic custom modes.
- The worms are too small. As a result, you have to zoom in too much to see what you're doing and not see the bigger picture and vice-versa.
- The multiplayer is almost dead, even despite the expected influx of new players from the game being included in a recent bundle. What little playerbase it has are kids with little skill and bad manners.
- Importing custom maps isn't as easy and straightforward as it used to be, who needs that huge community-made Worms Map Database anyway? Have a useless Steam Workshop!
- No option to import custom voice-banks, flags, victory tunes or gravestones, the vanilla ones are 'meh', and there are no voice-banks that don't sound squeaky.
- Crafting and vehicles don't add any depth or fun, they just break the balance and add unnecessary complication and confusion.
- Turrets are broken no-brainer OP trash.
- Competitive preset is too limiting, which means that you don't have many tools to diversify your tactics, only your skill at throwing grenades and shooting bazooka matters.
- Team 17 haven't released any updates in months, and probably moved on to making the next low-effort cash grab.

Avoid this game, don't let the devs cash-in on your nostalgia, this game is gravely inferior to WA in everything, except performance on modern PCs and Steam integration. Isn't very fun on its own either, especially with that ridiculous price-tag.

Posted: January 22, 2023
🔵 Requires light tinkering

To fix resolution problem change the "high DPI settings" of the game executable:
- Find the game executable Worms W.M.D.exe on your system (manage > browse local files).
- Right-click the executable, then select Properties.
- Switch to the Compatibility tab and click on Change high DPI settings, under "Settings".
- On the new window, under "High DPI scaling override", activate the checkbox: [✓].
- Select Application from the dropdown menu and confirm with OK.
- Click Apply, then OK on the Properties window.
- Launch the game.

Tested on: OnexPlayer Mini Pro 6800U

Can you believe that Worms has been around for more than 25 years now? That's just a quarter of a century!

YouTube™ Video: Worms W.M.D. - Campaign lvl 6 - Tijuana Dance With Me 
Views: 186
Worms W.M.D. on steam: https://store.steampowered.com/app/327030/Worms_WMD/ Worms W.M.D. website: https://www.team17.com/games/worms-wmd/ Worms on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/WormsTeam17/...


Worms W.M.D is a tactical 2D turn-based game where you have to make the short lives of other worms miserable with big guns.
The basic concept underlying this umpteenth installment in the series was already conceived in 1995.
Place some worms on an island and give them fat weapons to kill each other. The high dose of humor and crazy weapons, such as the concrete donkey, are not lacking and the recognition is certainly very high for old acquaintances of the series.
In Worms W.M.D you can also walk into buildings or jump into a vehicle.
If you're lucky, a tank, or some other very useful war vehicle, will drop from the sky near you, after which you can dive in to bombard other worms with bombs and missiles.
In addition to the tank, the game includes a helicopter, digger, mech and even a Rocket League car to use.
All in all, this provides an interesting new game element and the already large palette of weapons is expanded even further in this way.



Worms W.M.D is guaranteed to provide you with a lot of fun in the living room and or online!
Playing against your friends feels like old times and even after all the years since the first Worms game, the concept is still up to date.
The additions, such as making weapons and the vehicles, provide some diversity again and the online options also seem to be fine.

Campaign (why would you bother?) a complete and utter deadloss, featuring AI that can and will perform pixel perfect maneuvers to land on single pixel landscape that you didn't even know was there, or produce a game ending fluky backwards-bazooka shot that manages to send one worm into the air, and knock another into the water.

Buy Worms Armageddon instead. It's a better game, has an actual community and is half the price of this. Not even a cheapo humble bundle (how I stumbled across this) could inject life into this.

Team 17 just need to retire and live off the royalties from Worms Armageddon at this point.
