Posted: August 29, 2016
Worms W.M.D is the latest installment in Team 17‘s long running artillery strategy series about warring annelids. Due to popular demand, the game’s developer decided to go back to the series’ roots and make a true 2d game, though W.M.D still presents many changes over its predecessors.

The basic gameplay mechanics are the same as they’ve been for two decades. Players command a team of worms (which may be customized with different voice packs, gravestones and visual styles) and must defeat an opposing worm force using a wide variety of wacky weapons. The action still flows perfectly from turn to turn, and drowning enemy worms is as satisfying as it was a decade ago.

Worms W.M.D‘s presentation echoes Worms Armageddon, a game which most longtime fans of the franchise still consider as the best. From the detailed 2d art, to the removal of some controversial features such as classes or water physics, everything screams “your childhood favorite is back!” This doesn’t mean that W.M.D doesn’t try a few new things though. Team 17‘s new game introduces several new concepts to the strategy franchise, with varying degrees of success.

Chief among the game’s new toys is the ability to pilot vehicles and man static weapon emplacements. Worms can now get in the driving seat of tanks, mechs and helicopters, adding some interesting dynamics to the battlefield. Taking command of a helicopter and raining fire from above as the enemy team sits in an oil barrel filled zone never gets old. The static guns also offer new strategic options, as players have to choose between mobility and firepower, and the mounted weapons platforms can be destroyed, dealing damage to their operators when that happens.
The second game-changing addition is the crafting system. Worms can now collect resources (or dismantle old weapons to obtain the bits that make them work) and craft new weaponry, making an already unpredictable game even more chaotic. Enterprising players will rapidly learn that they can actually use the enemy’s turn to craft new gear, a welcome distraction when the opposing commander is laying waste to your troops.

Players can now make use of buildings to shelter themselves from enemy bombardment or prying eyes. Sadly, the execution isn’t as polished as one would desire, and sometimes it’s hard to tell which part of the environment is a building, and which is just part of the map’s decoration (a problem that was already present in Worms: Clan Wars, although that game didn’t feature buildings in the same way as W.M.D)

Worm customization, a hallmark of the series, has been given an incredible amount of detail. There is a leveling system that gradually unlocks more hats, gravestones, voice packs and music, making players feel as if there’s always something new to try out.

The game’s content is as plentiful as the customization options, with a generous amount of singleplayer missions and challenges, and an extensive multiplayer suite. Worms W.M.D also features Steam Workshop support, letting players download new maps created by other gamers with the included level editor.
Worms W.M.D is a successful reimagining of the long running artillery strategy series, mixing Armageddon‘s colorful visuals and tight gameplay with some welcome additions. Team 17 has created a new classic, easily recommended for both newcomers and longtime fans of the franchise.

8.5/10 – Great.

Posted: July 30, 2017
Hmm, what to make of Worms WMD. When a new Worms game is released I think "why should I buy it? I already have several Worms games". Well, a glowing review from Ben plus the fact it was pretty cheap on special caused me to give it a go. I really wasn't losing out that much buying it, really.

I enjoy it. I pretty much only play single player stuff (campaigns and matches against computer enemies) so my thoughts are obviously regarding that particular aspect of the game. The overall 'feel' of the game is great, the physics and control are spot on, unlike Reloaded, which just felt... off in some indescribable way. The fundamentals the game gets right, and that's a good start.

Having a new Worms game means a wnole new set of single player missions, which as I mentioned above, appeals to me. Giving secondary objectives gives some incentive to replay missions to try to chase full completion of missions, which is something that I'd like to do when I've gotten through them all. There are plenty to get through, so it will certainly keep me busy.

Having access to community maps is a great addition, I've downloaded a heap of maps to play random matches on, and I've enjoyed a lot of them, especially the ones that are recreations of Lemmings maps. They seem to bring out some fun games. For some reason user created speech banks aren't an option, which is very disappointing- it was one thing that was great about Armageddon. I loved my Zapp Brannigan speech bank!

I have at best mixed feelings about crafting. I get where they are coming from, but it injects luck as a factor too much into the game. I wish that the weapons that are available thorugh crafting were available in non-crafting game setups, but sadly that's not the case. It gives me something to do while the other teams are takig their turns (and I think the computer teams were programmed to faff around on purpose to allow time for crafting) but overall I'm pretty meh about it.

I like the addition of vehicles, them plus the turrets you can use add some variety to the gameplay. Their propensity to explode after not a huge amount of damage is done to them is always a factor, just as planning how barrels and mines will behave needs to be planned for when making your move.

I can't speak for online play, as I haven't tried it.

Posted: June 21
I've played Worms 2, WWP and Worms Armageddon extensively.
WMD was an opportunity to create a fun sequel but it disappoints heavily.

=== The good ===
-Vehicles are awesome and bring new ways of fighting each other
-Graphics are great
-UI looks nice
-Airstrikes are awesome
-Many cool new weapons with cool accompanying effects (airplanes, u-boats, etc)
-Ranked matches are awesome

=== The bad ===
-The game plays too slow. The animation times should have been cut in half (waiting for crates to drop down, animation of the concrete donkey, general weapons behavour, the worms themselves). The AI needs to think for 15 seconds before it makes a move. Why is everything so slow?
-None of the popular schemes that people actually play are in the game
-Baseball bat is disabled in the first 3 rounds for unknown reason. Did the CEO get owned once and decided to nerf it? Because it's clearly not coming from player feedback (see below)
-No low gravity
-Particle stutter and lag despite being a 2D game and having a monster PC with a 3090 (even after putting every setting on low)
-You can't change the girder with the arrow keys. Also disabling arrow keys by default. Why would you do that?
-The most pressing issues of its predecessor remain unchanged: buggy and frustating jumping, ninja rope still never does what you want and is even more frustrating, retarded AI despite having had over 10 years to fix it
-The water has become like a calm sea for some reason instead of wild and dangerous looking
-News feed is unclickable
-Aim controls have acceleration which is not helpful especially when time is critical and you want to aim right
-Did we really need crafting mechanics?

=== Summary ===
WMD added a bunch of cool new stuff but at the same time neglected a bunch of critical things which created a half assed sequel. Is Team17 asleep at the wheel? Are they aware of the schemes that people actually play nowadays in the lobbies of Armaggedon? Where is Kaos, Super Sheeper, Mole Shopper, Shopper and many others? They could have made an actual fun revival by looking at what the remaining player base is doing, and they ignored it. You only have to look at the player lobbies for proof.

Posted: November 7, 2021
I felt nostalgic for Worms Armageddon, after not playing for over a decade and decided to see what the progress was like on the Worms series over the years.
Came across WMD on sale and decided to give it a shot.

It captures the essence of Armageddon quite well but fails to offer any of the conveniences that made it an enjoyable time sink.



AI
Is it just me or is the AI significantly dumber than I remember?
70% of the time they're dumb as bricks.
25% of the time they work normal and actually hit.
5% of the time they'll pull of some ridiculously accurate shots, like bouncing a grenade off of multiple walls and reflect them perfectly onto the target.



- Typically wastes 20-30 seconds of their turn doing nothing.
- Constantly toggles back and forth between weapon choices.
- Walks to vehicles, enters and then exists, walks away again towards the direction it came from.
- Constantly drops mine/dynamite, takes a couple of steps away and stands around within exploding distance.
- Occasionally they'll fail to calculate an attack, so they'll either keep skipping or just randomly shoot at the terrain in front of them.
- I once ran into a rare scenario where 2 AI worms were left, both were stuck in positions where they couldn't seem to calculate an attack, so they did nothing but skip turn. Walked away for 10 min, still no progress and since there's no way to force a draw/sudden death for the round, I had to exit the match and start all over.




- Love the new maps, buildings, vehicles etc. as It all offers some decent replayability.



- A lack of bridges and a really bad seed system seems to produce consistently boring maps.
- If you occasionally find a good seed, or find one online that produces a detailed, complex map, there's no mechanism to save it in game.
- Even worse, the seed input won't even let you paste the seed, so you have to type it out number by number every time. Fine don't give us a seed manager, but how hard is it to allow us to paste text?
- Map maker and most workshop maps seem useless. I'd rather have a seed manager.





- Love the new crafting system.
- Love the new weapons and customization options.
- Love the scheme management. Allowing me to set up different configurations depending on the game intensity I desire at that moment in time.



All of the reasons below make the game a huge time sink, but not in a good way.

- Cannot disable the replay option in any of the single-player campaign modes, as it's tied to the "scheme" (which cannot be modified for campaign) rather than a global option.
- Replay gets triggered extremely easily, usually every turn or other turn. More often as the difficulty progresses.
- As mentioned above, no seed manager. Generating a good map seems impossible at times.
- No way to force sudden death/draw via ESC menu like with Armageddon. If you die early you have no choice but to sit around and watch the AI make stupid decision after stupid decision, turning what should be a couple of rounds into 10+ minutes of your time wasted.



As much as I want to complete the game, I'm really finding myself turned off from WMD because of all the annoyances that force me to waste time doing nothing.
Free time is a resource I don't have, don't make me waste it by watching your dumb AI take 5 rounds to kill a worm with 15 health.

Glad I bought it for $6, as I don't see any long term value in it. Maybe I'll buy Armageddon again.

Posted: April 5, 2018
Been playing Worms since Worms 1 on Playstation. This certainly isn't as much of a milestone as Worms 2 or Worms Armageddon but it is still really fun with some new twists added in.

So what does this do you ask? Let me walk through them.

1. Vehicles: There are vehicles allover the map now, ranging from stationary machineguns to helicopters or even the Rocket League Octane car and many more. They all serve different purposes in different situations.

2. Buildings: Similar to Worms 3D you can now enter Buildings and walk around inside it for better cover. Kinda like making yourself a fortress with the burner tool but still different.

3. Crafting: In your weapon menu you now have a second flag for the crafting menu. It lets you combine materials from dismanteled weapons you dont want or materials you collected from crates. Is overall a nice addition to make you get that one weapon you were craving for but these pesky chests won't give you.


That said they seem to have gotten rid of the class system from Worms Revolution. No more heavy, scout, soldier or scientist. At least I havn't encountered them.

Overall a great game and lots of fun!

Posted: August 25, 2016
As a big fan and someone who has over 1k hours in Worms Armageddon, I can say that WMD has impressed me. The vehicles and crafting are fun to play with and fairly balanced. The art style is clean and fresh.

There is however some downsides that keep me hanging on to WA, but hopefully will be added in updates.

1.Scheme customizability:
- Can't play mole shopper, theres no mole bomb in this game.
- Can't play hysteria, you can't set turn time to 1 second.
- Can not set mine fuses to random.
- Can't set power of weapons like you can in WA, nor can you let worms spawn with the new craftable weapons if they are an upgraded version. Eg: a worm cant have a "Cluster Bomb mkII" at the start of the round because it MUST be crafted.
Overall the scheme customizer and map editor still feels incomplete, but i have hope that T17 will update them.

2.Rope knocking physics: It takes too much force to knock a worm compared to WA in my opinion.

3.MAP EDITOR: Please make a WA map to WMD map converter.. enough said. The current map maker program is not fun to use and has to be run when WMD itself is closed. It would be nice if it were integrated into the game with more features.

4.HP Bars: They disappear... WHY!? sometimes we need to see who the leader is in shopper schemes while we are moving around...

Overall I have had a lot of fun playing basic schemes like intermediate, classic mode and ranked. but for more complex schemes I go back to WA.

Having been playing Worms since the days of Worms 2, World Party etc. I've tried to be fair to this game, but it's just a terrible addition to the Worms franchise.
The camera flits all over the place during your turns and ruins quickly chained shots (such as shotgun shots) - especially when firing offscreen.
The vehicles are a fairly mixed bag as to their ease-of-use and usefulness.
The crafting could have added an interesting element to the game, but instead is horrible to use and instead wastes valuable turn time.
Finally, the developers refuse to listen to the community and implement a gamemode where all weapons are available, so you can't just have a good old-fashioned slug-fest using whatever you like.
On top of all this, there's no point in "competing" for the World Record scores, as hackers have ruined this mechanic with 0.00 second wins on each of the stages, and Team17 doesn't care about doing anything about it.
The only positive thing I can say for this Worms game over others is the art style. The "hand-drawn 2D look" they speak of in the Steam description does look great. The "best worms experience ever" line however - so far from the truth.

Overall, highly disappointing. If I could get a refund, I would, but unfortunately I've spent a few hours evaluating it - as all games should be given a decent chance, and this is beyond Steam's refund time limit.
Don't waste your money.

- - - -

Edited from my answer in the comments:

It's a lot like it [Worms Armageddon] to me.

The balance is different on weapons, weapon speed, gravity, jump height, fall damage (and fall threshold), but it ultimately feels a lot like Armageddon.
Most of the iconic weapons act really close to their Armageddon counterpart, like the Super Sheep, the Ming Vase or even the worm selection thing.

It feels like a sequel, with the addition of vehicles and crafting: taking base features and expanding upon them.
Vehicles add more liberty, more movement, and specific strategies. Crafting allows for less wait time between turns and make the crates more crucial.

Even the UI feels really close, with the wind display, health bars, fonts...

And finally, singleplayer features feel a lot like Armageddon: training (Super Sheep training \o/), missions as a campaign, the team editor with its iconic voices. I miss the map painting editor though!

There are a lot of differences, obviously, but it really feels like Team 17 went back to Armageddon and expanded upon it.

Great fresh look to the roots of the Worms franchise. The new weapons and the crafting system add something fresh to the game and makes the game somewhat more suitable for online multiplayer. As someone who fell in love with Worms games at first sight, which was sometime around 2001 or 2002, I'm glad that this game came out and has a dedicated dev team to take care of the game and keep adding new themes and weapons. Posted: July 28, 2019
Before I begin the review I just want to say that I am not interested in the multiplayer experience, so anything related to multiplayer including the issues others are having are excluded from this review. I am only interested in the single player content, so that's what this review is about.

To begin, I remember playing Worms for the first time way back in the day, and I always loved this game. Worms always reminded me of a game called Tank Wars which was the first game with similar physics that I have ever played. I really enjoyed Tank Wars, so I was already hooked to Worms.

In regards to Warms W.M.D, I think this is the best version of Worms yet! The game runs smooth for me, their is a large variety of weapons to choose from, there are now vehicles and turrets that you can use, and you can even craft new weapons in the game!

The 2d artwork is great at suits the game well, much better than the 3d graphics. There plenty of different terrain and building types, and the random map generator offers a lot of flexibility when creating a variety of different maps to play on.

The customization is great. You get to name you worms, setup their outfits, voice, tombstone, etc. You can also customize the weapons, game related parameters, etc.

One thing I really like about Worms W.M.D is the large selection of different game modes. You got training, campaign missions, extra missions, bonus content, etc. You can also create a custom game where you can setup teams including alliances. I really love alliances! I create a team of my own worms and then I ally myself with an AI team which I created vs another AI team. It's a lot of fun working with you AI friends to defeat your AI enemies! Who needs multiplayer when you got AI friends to play with! The AI is pretty decent too. To be honest, the AI is doing better than me, lol!

Anyways, I totally recommend Worms W.M.D to anyone who likes these kinds of games. It's a fun game, it has lots of replayability, and you can play the game with your custom created AI friends! Again, who needs friends, when you got AI friends! Their such great friends, better than some of my friends in real life! So, go on, go for it, pick this game up, and have some fun!

Posted: July 16, 2018
Definitely the best worms title release since Reloaded. They have taken away a few weapons which I miss, but that is not an issue in the long run.

They've added buildings which you can "hide" inside now, which is nice. Vehicles are also a new addition, and they are not too OP, despite what your initial thoughts may be. Everybody loves the helicopter, of course. Weapon crafting is also in the game now, and its great. Every turn, you can dismantle weapons to get resources, which you can then craft into new weapons on subsequent turns.

As for the gameplay, it feels good overall. Shot power and and wind effects seem well done. It is still possible to do some trick shots with grenades, though I find their bounciness seems a little extreme.

Customization is also plentifull. Lots of options to make your worm team unique.

Multiplayer can be a little sparse at times, so your best bet would be to get a few friends to buy in. Weekends are a little easier to find games.

Overall, this is a good return to its roots for the Worms franchise. I personally love artillery style games, and think everyone should give this one a shot. (See what I did there?)

Posted: August 24, 2016
Finally, a good Worms game after so many disappointments! The controls are very responsive, the physics feel good and are very consistent, customization is extensive, the game is surprisingly atmospheric, and it sure as hell is fun! It has some massive improvements over other titles in the series, such as 8 worm teams, larger maps and (at last) a good launch. The vehicles are (to my surprise) balanced, as is everything else, including the pre-order content, and it runs flawlessly. The game is gorgeous, the sound is excellent, (it honestly has some of the best mixing I've ever heard) and the slightly more 'gritty' feel this game has compared to the previous Worms titles makes this entry into the series stand out from the crappy consolised Worms games of the past decade.
And as for a comparison with Worms: Armageddon? The game's different enough that it justifies a purchase of both.
My only complaints really are that some of the hats and soundbanks are locked behind a level system, and the slight indroduction of luck-based gameplay within the crafting system. Other than that, this is easily the best Worms game since Worms World Party, and I honestly think with a bit of support from Team17, which they have shown they are willing to give, this could be the best Worms game yet.

Good job Team17! Recommended.

Posted: September 20, 2016
First off, this is a very fun game.

But I can't in good faith recommend this game to anyone. "Full Controller Support" is a blatant lie and the QA department did not test this out very much, if at all. Input issues have been prevalent since launch, and many PC review outlets have documented this. I personally can't use the keyboard; it simply won't work, so I have to use a controller. My friend can't use any controllers (360, Xbox One, or keyboard/mouse), and Team17's support basically told him that he should revert back to Windows 7 because they're able to enjoy the game from their own rigs. The developers delete posts on Steam from consumers (like me and my friend) that complain about the lack of updates on input issues that have persisted through patches.

To me, that says all one needs to know about the state of this game. It was rushed and has game-breaking bugs that are currently either being ignored by the developers, or they don't know how to fix them so they're just deleting flame posts to cover their products' reputation. I really hadn't played much Worms since Dreamcast and only really got this game to play with my buddy, but he had to refund the game as support was non-existent.

Posted: December 15, 2023
As someone who grew up playing the Worms series, diving into Worms W.M.D was like reuniting with an old friend. This game flawlessly recaptures the quirky charm and tactical fun of the original titles, while infusing it with modern enhancements that elevate the experience.

Firstly, the gameplay remains true to the series' roots – a chaotic blend of strategy and humor. The addition of new weapons and vehicles brings a fresh layer of strategy without overcomplicating the classic formula. There's something incredibly satisfying about orchestrating a perfectly timed bazooka shot or a devious ninja rope maneuver.

The art style is a beautiful homage to the original, maintaining the cartoonish appeal but with crisper, more vibrant visuals. Every explosion, every wacky weapon effect, feels like a celebration of the game's legacy. The sound design, from the iconic worms' voices to the satisfying booms, contributes to an immersive and entertaining environment.

Multiplayer is where Worms W.M.D truly shines. The laughs, the rivalry, and the unpredictability of each match make it an ideal game for friends and family. Whether it's a friendly bout or a competitive clash, each session is a rollercoaster of emotions, from triumphant joy to comedic despair.

Perhaps what's most impressive is how the game balances accessibility with depth. Newcomers can jump in and quickly grasp the basics, while veteran players will appreciate the subtle nuances and strategies that can turn the tide of battle.

In conclusion, Worms W.M.D is a masterful continuation of a beloved series. It preserves the heart and soul of Worms while introducing enough new elements to feel fresh and exciting. This game is not just a trip down memory lane; it's a reminder of why we fell in love with the Worms universe in the first place. It's a blast (literally) for gamers of all ages and a testament to the timeless appeal of good, old-fashioned fun.

Recommendation: Highly Recommended for Fans and Newcomers Alike!

Posted: August 25, 2016
Everyone is giving this a very positive review, sadly i'm going to be one to give it a negative one.

This review is coming form a person who loved Clan Wars and loved Revolution even more (i have a playtime of 350 hours between those two). I really liked the water physics and the roping system in those games. I enjoyed how i could play around turrets by flying fast or making them role down hills. I also liked worms customisations that made an inpact on how you played the game (i'm talking about the classes)

Me and my friends played this game with strategy - always thinking about where to put worms just so would not be knocked out, we found out a lot of ways to play around turrets and avoid being washed off of a cliff.

All of these things have sadly not been added to this game. This game is by no means bad - it's fun and enjoyable but i feel like the depth and some of the tactical skill needed to play has been removed.

Also it costs 30 euros... that's a bit steep for a Worms game.

In conclusion:
I would recomend this game for anyone who enjoyed the old classic worms titles. It's a fun party game that most people would enjoy.
I would not recomend this game for people who enjoyed the mechanics and depth that Revolution offered because most of those have been removed. (i know that this group is probably smaller but it's still nice to get my voice out there)

P.S. I am a non native English speaker so i appologise for any grammar or spelling errors that i have made

Posted: May 28, 2023
Worms W.M.D is a 2D artillery turn-based tactics game that can be played with 5 other players local or online where you need to strategize well in order to survive and kill all enemy worms. I am honestly not sure if I should recommend or not recommend this game because there are things that I liked, and things that I did not like.
PROS:
+ The idea of the game itself is good. You need to combine smart tactics, fine platforming, and good aiming skills in order to beat your opponents.
+ The graphics are quite nice, and there was a lot of details put into them. Map generation is also quite good.
+ Large variety of weapons and craftable weapons that makes the game more interesting.
CONS:
- I know that you are playing with worms, but, the game is too slow-paced. Worms themselves are very slow. Time between turns is long. Crates dropping takes an eternity as well.
- The game can get frustrating at some times, especially when you use the rope, or when you get stuck in remaining pixels of the map, or when your jump does not want to reach the other side.
- Multiplayer is quite dead. You get re-queued to AFK lobbies every time. I think I would have had more fun playing it with friends instead of single-player and multi-player with randoms.
I would give the concept 8/10, but the execution 5/10.

Excellent party game with friends, loving the art style. Like using the editor to make my own assets, wish the editor was a little bit more developed in a few respects. Lack of custom speechbanks + gravestones holding back what could otherwise have been an infinitely customizable experience (but you can make hats and maps!). Crafting system is fun, and optional. Physics are goofy, nonsensical, and perfect, vehicles and turrets are a little wonky but it really just adds to the party game experience, which is what Worms has always been at its core.

The 30$ USD pricetag is certainly contentious but it's good to remember that this game actually got a physical release for the Switch, and as per Steam's store policy, a publisher using Steam to sell their game must match their pricepoint across the market. Game goes on sale regularly too (go steam), pick it up then!

Strong recommend, 8.5/10.

Posted: 1 December, 2017
I was baffled the first time I saw what Q2 and Q3 pro players used to do. For the purpose of seeing their opponents more clearly, they were stripping textures of the walls and models in the game, leaving the game with solid color objects which helped them aim better, reduce lag and so on. The same kind of 'design' is what attracted me to Ratz Instagib, beside that Instagib word in the title.

For those unaware, Instagib is popular FPS mode that originated in Quake 2 and was popularized by Unreal Tournament. It has only one rule - one shot, one kill. It means there are no additional powerups, shields, health pickups. If you miss your shot, good opponent will make you die instantly. Instagib is basically mode-for-all - you can snipe or rush, whatever you find suiting, with weapon that's reminiscent of Quake's Railgun and UT's Plasma Rifle.

Ratz Instagib is gaming title completely dedicated to Instagib where you take on a role of cute little rat you can customize with random items that drop after the game in various well known modes such as duel (one on one), deathmatch (free for all), team deathmatch (you probably get it), CTF (capture the flag) and freezetag (the same game we've used to play as kids, but in the streets).

Game consists of 13 official maps and heck a lot of unofficial maps. Official maps are very well designed, although there should be some pointer about number of players because some maps are way too cramped for 5+ players. Unofficial maps are... well, it's hit or miss really. Some that I've played are pretty good, while others are seriously horrible. There's really handy and easy to understand map editor available in the game which you can use to create your own maps. I think Ratz Editor is probably the easiest map editor I've come across in all my years of gaming.

An important aspect of every FPS is movement. In Ratz, it's really fluid, and you can change direction at any point suprising your enemies and delivering vengeance after their miss. I had immense fun bunny hopping and circle jumping properly for the first time. I never did it properly in Quake and that made me dead meat in every single match. Ratz is really simplified and works wonders even for the first time players. Additional way to control your player is quasi rocket jump you can use to boost yourself to higher ground in the game.

This is a game of skill - it means you will probably meet a bunch of veterans in the game already, but don't be discouraged - after two hours of play your eyes will already register the movement of Ratz stars and your fingers will try to emulate. All of a sudden, you will be climbing the ladder and ending your matches fourth, third, second and even as a winner. Ratz Instagib succeds where most FPS multiplayer games fail: you can have fun both winning and losing in this game. One of my matches, a two on two team deathmatch ended with my team winning 80-79. Those were ten most intense moments of my day.

There really isn't anything negative to be said about Ratz Instagib, but two fair warnings must be given out. First, game is using color scheme which will make your eyes bleed at one point, so taking a break is something you should do every match or two. Good thing is you can easily change color of enemy models, even in the middle of the match so you can see them better. Secondly, player base is really not that big, that's why I am afraid to recommend Ratz Instagib at its full price, although it's completely worth it. However, at current discount price (the first and lowest I've ever seen) of 0.79 €/$, it's a steal, and people should be beaten for not purchasing it right now. Currently, on European server that I use to play, I had full TDM and DM matches and you can always arrange a duel with players via online chat. Unfortunately, matches like Capture The Flag are harder to organize, it's probably wise to ask for people to play in community forums and add them to your friends list.

Ratz Instagib is intense, completely skill-based simplified shooter that brings back the glorious days of solid color textures aiming to drain your eyes dry and present you with Carpal tunnel syndrome. Damn good time, I have to say.

I can't remember when I had more fun with the game I've purchased after selling few Steam trading cards on the market.

***

Posted: September 13, 2015
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Feature Y/N/Rating
SLI No
Aspect Ratios 16:9, Others Unknown
Triple Monitor Unknown
Framerate Cap 120-144+
FOV Yes, 2 Sliders
Key Rebinding Full
Controller Support/Rebinding No
Options Extensive
Performance Great

PC Port Quality

The options are extremely extensive. You can map all of the controls including toggle/hold zooming. You have two separate FOV sliders for general and while zooming (up to 160 degrees) and separate mouse sensitivities for each and separate x/y axis adjustment, and y invert. You can toggle almost all of the visual effects like bloom/vignette, as well as outlines for players and objects. You can control the the color/style of everything from the crosshair, to your in-game name, the enemy and team colors, two level saturation sliders, etc. It has auto contract color picking, and the only thing better I'd like would be per-level enemy color selection. I use a red-pink, and I have to manually switch them to a green or cyan for the red/black level. You can turn off hit decals, force the default beam and death animation for enemies, hide/move the weapon model. It's a ridiculous amount of customization, and it runs great too. It doesn't have a dedicated fullscreen mode, and while that sucks, it's an issue that all Unity devs have to deal with. It starts up, loads, and closes very quickly, and the menus work very well, making mid-match changes very doable.


It's by far the fastest game I've ever played, and it feels extremely good. I found the zoom function unusable at first because of the static sensitivity, but then I found the sensitivity scaling slider, and it works great. The players are pretty small objects in the environment, so extremely long ranges happen frequently, but the movement is extremely fast and close range engagements happen often so you need a higher sensitivity to do well. So having the zoom and essentially two separate sensitivities, really helps. The sliders are numerical, so you should be able to keep the mouse to screen distance ratio the same at both FOV values, with a little math. I do wish you could disable the death animations of your own player, as certain ones can shoot the camera across the map and I don't find it very appealing.

The game is rather limited in terms of modes and maps, though a map editor was just announced and one would assume that comes with workshop support. That's good for the future, but at the moment it feels limited. The gameplay is so satisfying if you have a knack for it, but I did have a problem. I played for 2 days without issue, nothing feeling unfair at all, but all of a sudden on the third day, it because quite inconsistent. The player count was at 1600+, vs the ~700 of the two days prior. It could be my connection, and though my ping was only ~30, the game got drastically less fun. The boost (rocket jump) function is essential for quick acceleration which makes you a hard target, but if it outright fails to activate 15% of the time, you die because you stay in place when you should have shot off in another direction. It was much harder to see this, but there were also instances of shots missing randomly at all sorts of ranges. The game was updated without patch notes before I played the 3rd day. I had zero issues in this respect for about 4 hours of play across the two days prior. It could be my connection, it could be the update, it could be the servers, but whatever it is made me not want to play when I loved it the days before. It's so dependent on that speed and responsiveness, that if anything takes it away, the fun is gone.

There are two things to unlock in the game. One I'm fine with, while the other is problematic. The beam shape and death animations are unlocked via by getting achievements tied to killstreaks, the highest being 3 Monsterkills, which I believe is 6 in a row (not just without dying, but in very quick succession as well). Some of the others are tied to winning x number of the various match types. I mean I'd strive for zero unlocks at all, but these are harmless. Next is customization items for your character, that are given via a random drop system. Thankfully there are no microtransactions tied to it, but I still really do not see the point of it. It limits player choice and expression right out of the gate, and it just gets stupid people to blow $80 on some half-assed textureless 3D model on the steam marketplace. The game is so old-school and consumer oriented in every other aspect, that this one system contrasts immensely in what is a paid title. Better this than microtransactions, but it's needless regardless.


I think the rats are unappealing, and I'd like to toggle off the death animations and gore effects, but the levels and overall visuals are nice. The menus are very basic but work without issue. The levels almost all look straight out of Mirror's Edge and I really like them. I'd love to view them in full color, but the advantages of having the level saturation <~30% are too much to give up when really trying to do well. I will say though that if per-level enemy color and saturation settings were an option, that would be amazing. If you want the most advantage the way it is now, the best option is to go with low saturation, unless you want to manually adjust it before every round.


At it's best, I love this game. It feels amazing and nailing awesome shots or streaking is hugely satisfying. That said I would be wary for multiple reasons. If connection problems occur, the fun goes out the window because of the insane skill requirement. I also play on a 120Hz display with ultra-low motion blur enabled, and I'm not sure how well it would really fare without that, again because of the insane speed of everything. Finally, player count could be a real issue at some point. For months before the Free Weekend that's occurring as I write this, the game had less than 20 players. And because of the price it's offered at, I'm not sure how many players will actually buy the game and continue playing after the promotion. It has no single-player content, so unless you have a friend to 1v1 against, you're boned if no one else is online. The game has a 1v1 mode vs a random player, but a tiny pool of players means the ranking system can't really do it's job well and you'll be matched with the same insane player endlessly. I'd more than recommend it on a very cheap sale or bundle because that's sure to bring in some players for a while and the low price means even if you can only play for that week, it's not as much of a let-down as it could be at a more substantial price point. But that's up to the buyer, as some expect an hour of fun for their dollar, while others might want five to ten which is very achievable in the current market. It could use some small tweaks, but most of all I just think it needs a consistent playerbase. It's still early access, so an official release plus an even more substantial sale could very well make that happen. Because of the intensity and limited maps/modes for now it's not really something suited to binge-play, but it's something I could easily see hopping on every day or two for 30 mins to an hour if that was an option.

Posted: May 26, 2015
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I use to play this a long time ago when it was a browser game on kongregate.com. The first time I played it, I knew it had potential.

The game is exactly what it says - you're a bunch of rats hopping around playing instagib. There's free-for-all, Team deathmatch, freeze tag, capture the flag, duel and even a little survival mode to mess around on, all using only railguns. The movement feels very smooth. There's railjumping, and bunny hopping is a lot of fun (and the key to success).

Another thing I feel compelled to mention is the customization in this game. You can almost edit everything from simple graphics options like toggling Bloom and cell-shading on/off, to wall and/or prop saturation, FOV, HUD, enemy colors, your rail color, death animation/fx, and your rat itself with cosmetics. The music plays like a little radio in the corner and you can hit pause to change it at any time you want. The music kind of has that late 90's feel, reminds me of the Dreamcast days. It's awesome.

The game has a lot of maps for an Early Access game and is getting great support from it's lone developer who is active on the forums listening to suggestions and squashing new bugs rather fast, which is always great. I'm impressed with how far this game has gone and I can definitely suggest this game, especially to those who loved playing instagib mods back in the day.

Posted: May 17, 2015
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
What can I say about Ratz Instagib? Well it is a railgun, instagib multiplayer shooter which incorporates the rocket-jumping mechanic familiar to Quake and Team Fortress 2.

The game is surprisingly simplistic; move around and shoot, however a combination of rocket-jumping and the 1-hit-kill railgun create an intense, competitive environment where timing and precision is your key to success.

Not only does Ratz bring back great memories of Quake II railgun battles and Unreal Tournament's instagib mode, it has its own merits—primarily the level of customization which creates a very level playing field and a very personal experience—you are free to individualise almost all aspects of the game from the colour of your railgun beam to the colour of your name, team mates and enemies.

The newly introduced item drop system is purely based around cosmetics which maintains the balance and integrity of the game.

Game-modes include Team/One man army Deathmatch, Freeze Tag, CTF mode and most likely more to be introduced in future updates.

Updates seem to be introduced on a relatively frequent basis but at this point, the game looks very much like a finished product:




These features successfully disguise the fact that it is an early access game and are the reasons why I highly recommend Ratz Instagib!!



*Edit* Don't believe a single thing about this negative review:

Everything he has stated is a lie, there is NO lag, NO hackers, the graphics in the game are so colourful and smooth; it really is beautiful as you can see from the screenshots.

He was banned for writing a script to pervert the item system of the game and is currently deleting all comments that expose his lies so don't believe a single thing he says. He also downvoted almost all positive reviews for Ratz so that alone tells you how flawed this guy is.

Posted: January 27, 2015
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Unlike what I normally do, I won't just put a couple of lines for comedy and call it a review,
This'll be a review with "hardly" any comedy.

So, Lets get started with this, you're a rat with a deadly laser pointer that blinds people and obliterates them, who can also jump 2 metres in the air with help from it's TF2 soldier powers and stands on it's hind legs.
From that, All I can say, It's better and deviats from the normal theme of bad guys, Good guys, Soldier, Shoot shoot guns.
So yeah, Basically buy this game.

Now, Onto the drawn out bit;
Pros;
-Good movement capabilites
-Weird idea, But it's fun
-Very colourful
-Great art style
-There's an option for anything, From colour of your enemies, To every character of your name, Even your laser.
-Mutli player is fun
-The community is nice... Well... Out of the 10 people who play on the euro servers (we'll get too that)
-Brilliant for practicing hand eye co-ordination and improving reflexes
-Unlockables (Basically like hats and weapons in TF2 and CSGO)
-Good clean maps
-Very open

Cons;
-The SMALL community, This game needs more players, Many people will be put off with the fact, You'll spend 5 minutes looking for 1 game of deathmatch.
-The game puts you into games with higher skill groups if there is not enough players
-If you're coming from source games, The sensitivty is NOT the same, Be careful took me 1 hour just to find the perfect sensitivity, If you're stuck trying to find it if you play source games, Just half what you normally play on, Should work.
-Needs more maps, Once you play all the maps, It gets repetative
-The colours are very vibrant, Personally lots of bright red hurts my eyes, So the RED level is really hard for me to play
-Depending on what colour you put your enemies too, You might not be able to tell them appart from the background
-Too little unlockables
-Needs more customization (I'll come back to this later)
-There should be a counter on the side of each country which say how many people are playing and what gamemodes they are playing, Since I was waiting for a freezetag game for 10 minutes and didn't find one.

MY IDEAS;
-Add a couter to show how many people are playing on which gamemodes
-Add a unlockable which lets you design a laser design (Though make a reporting system aswell, Since people with draw unmature things with it)
-Like CS;S/TF2 has sprays, I think this game should have a custom logo you can put on your gun which you could draw ingame
-More gamemodes would be nice, Since everyone just play deathmatch
-A way too lower graphics for people who don't have good computers, I have a half decent computer and still get 50 fps.
-A way too make custom maps, Which could be voted on to be made into offcial maps, The more highly rated will appear higher on the page, And a dev can either accept or decline it.

IDEAS FOR NEW GAMEMODES;
Boss mode - 1v10, Boss can take lots of hits and you can only play boss at a rating higher than a certain amount
Jump mode - Jump maps, Get from point A too B with only rocket jumps.
Mini game maps - Custom maps which have been accepted into the game with devs approval

These were just my ideas, Hope I was helpful, First time typing something this long. :-D

Posted: April 28
In many ways, the work of a critic is easy. We risk very little, yet enjoy a position over those who offer up their work - and their selves - to our judgement. We thrive on negative criticism, which is fun to write and to read. But the bitter truth we critics must face is that in the grand scheme of things, the average piece of junk is probably more meaningful than our criticism designating it so.


But there are times when a critic truly risks something - and that is in the discovery and defence of the New. The world is often unkind to new talent, new creations. The New needs friends. Last night I experienced something new: an extraordinary meal from a singularly unexpected source. To say that both the meal and its maker have challenged my preconceptions about fine cooking is a gross understatement.
They have rocked me to my core.

In the past, I have made no secret of my disdain for Chef Gusteau's famous motto; "anyone can cook." But I realise, only now do I truly understand what he meant. Not everyone can become a great artist, but a great artist can come from anywhere. It is difficult to imagine more humble origins than those of the genius now cooking at Gusteau's - who is, in this critic's opinion, nothing less than the finest chef in France!

I will be returning to Gusteau's soon - hungry for more.

Posted: June 27, 2021
2 carrots, trimmed and finely chopped
2 celery sticks, finely chopped
2 garlic cloves finely chopped
2-3 sprigs rosemary leaves picked and finely chopped
500g beef mince
For the bolognese sauce
2 x 400g tins plum tomatoes
small pack basil leaves picked, ¾ finely chopped and the rest left whole for garnish
1 tsp dried oregano
2 fresh bay leaves
2 tbsp tomato purée
1 beef stock cube
1 red chilli deseeded and finely chopped (optional)
125ml red wine
6 cherry tomatoes sliced in half
To season and serve
75g parmesan grated, plus extra to serve
400g spaghetti
crusty bread to serve (optional)
Method
STEP 1
Put a large saucepan on a medium heat and add 1 tbsp olive oil.

STEP 2
Add 4 finely chopped bacon rashers and fry for 10 mins until golden and crisp.

STEP 3
Reduce the heat and add the 2 onions, 2 carrots, 2 celery sticks, 2 garlic cloves and the leaves from 2-3 sprigs rosemary, all finely chopped, then fry for 10 mins. Stir the veg often until it softens.

STEP 4
Increase the heat to medium-high, add 500g beef mince and cook stirring for 3-4 mins until the meat is browned all over.

STEP 5
Add 2 tins plum tomatoes, the finely chopped leaves from ¾ small pack basil, 1 tsp dried oregano, 2 bay leaves, 2 tbsp tomato purée, 1 beef stock cube, 1 deseeded and finely chopped red chilli (if using), 125ml red wine and 6 halved cherry tomatoes. Stir with a wooden spoon, breaking up the plum tomatoes.

STEP 6
Bring to the boil, reduce to a gentle simmer and cover with a lid. Cook for 1 hr 15 mins stirring occasionally, until you have a rich, thick sauce.

STEP 7
Add the 75g grated parmesan, check the seasoning and stir.

STEP 8
When the bolognese is nearly finished, cook 400g spaghetti following the pack instructions.

STEP 9
Drain the spaghetti and either stir into the bolognese sauce, or serve the sauce on top. Serve with more grated parmesan, the remaining basil leaves and crusty bread, if you like.

Posted: January 22, 2015
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Ratz Instagib, a game I played really early on, and now that it's on Steam with noticeable improvements, prettier, more maps, more customization, unlockable cosmetics, more game modes, private matches, and more fun.

The game is for people who hunger for the 'Instagib' game mode, like me, because its hard to get really good ones nowadays, aside from the old ones that has it, but this game has a focus one that one game mode only, which is Instagib, meaning insta-kill, one shot one kill, and this one is a great one, and as far as I know, it's the best one.

All the game modes are great, duel mode, death match, team death match, capture the flag, freeze tag, and survival. I haven't tried freeze tag yet, but everything else is nice, fun, and competitive, the most competitive an FPS can be actually, and it's not just doing matches and winning, there's a skill progression in which the game monitors your skill and ranks you accordingly. There's also unlockables that you can set a goal for to unlock, these unlockables are only cosmetic and will not change the games simple fair and competitive nature.

The one thing I have an issue with is the same issue I have with any multiplayer game only, and that is it doesn't have bots to sustain the game if there are no players to play it at any given time, so keep that in mind, but it has a game mode in which you can play the game and shoot at things, and that is the survival game mode, it's a solo or coop game made where you (your self or with your friends) go up against a horde of unique (land and flying) enemies where you have to dodge their slow orb-like projectiles, and shoot their core at the center of their bodies, so it's not normal bots of the same type as you with the same weapons, but it's good, requires more precision, and good to play solo or with your friends as coop. It's better than nothing one would say.

For the asking price, for the fan that I am for Instagib, and for the content that it has and future content that it will have, it's worth it, even more so if they add normal insta-gibbing bots to play with.

Posted: February 3, 2015
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
tl;dr -> If you were born during the Unreal, Quake, and Scouts-Knives era, then pick up this game already. It's sniper paintball with boosting. And everyone's on speed. 11/10.

The developer was kind enough to give out a bunch of keys when this game launched on steam, and a good friend got me a key even though I had missed the giveaway by 15 minutes. I was very excited to feel all the nostalgia of my instagibbing days. The experience was satisfying and great.

If you enjoy instagib (one hit kill) gameplay, boosting (shooting the ground to shoot yourself upwards), twitch shooting, and an intense, fast-paced FPS experience, then you will enjoy this game.

As a disclaimer, I always try to avoid mentioning the price of a game if I feel that its mechanics make up for any monetary value, however, for the current price ($9.99), the game is more than a finished product for an early-access game. Believe me, you will get your money's worth for this price if you are looking for a no-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ instagib experience.

The aesthetics are very good - the levels are nice and bright and colorful. You can customize everything from the color/type of your laser beam, to the type of explosions when you kill an opponent, to the color of your character model (and your opponents'). Personally, I prefer to have the environment in greyscale and the enemy in a bright, pop-out color (red). You can even change the color of your name in-game. When you shoot, it will leave a paintball-style mark in the color of your laser - by the end of the match, the area will look like a paintball battlefield. The music and sounds are very good, especially if you like electronic music.

The controls are typical of a traditional FPS, however, you will need to get used to the instagib style if you are a newcomer - boosting (shooting the ground to propel yourself) and constantly moving is a necessity to survival. Being able to shoot from a far is also essential (you can play around with the FOV, however, I feel that the max setting is a bit disorienting). Be warned, the instagib community for most games is relentless and unforgiving, so don't be surprised or disheartened if you have a hard time getting kills. From the servers I've played, the community seems very friendly. There is no tutorial, and the learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your experience with FPS games - in particular, with the instagib game mode.

Gameplay is extremely fast-paced - you must constantly remain on the move. There are a variety of game modes, like deathmatch and team deathmatch. The online community is fairly small, but still decent - you might not always have a full server. Everyone dies with one hit, and you can shoot across the entire map. Staying mobile, timing your boost jumps, and maintaining battlefield awareness (this is where the high DPI players will get to flex their skills) is critical to doing well in this game.

Overall, the instagib game mode is represented very, very well in Ratz, and anyone interested in that style of FPS should definitely check this out.

Recommend!

Cheers,
DJSF

Posted: May 22, 2015
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
What an awesome game. Old school insta-gib action. Start the game and and start playing, no long load times, no BS.

Positives:
-Gameplay is awesome, lag free smooth as hell action. Quick movements like in the old school shooters and if you're a fan of those you will love this game. You can sort of "rocket jump" too with the booster thingy of the gun.
-Bright and colorful cartoony graphics, which are decent. You can spot enemies easily. The default enemy color works best against almost all the maps but if it doesn't work you can always change the enemy colors from the options menu.
-Music is EPIC, like one of my favorite tracks in any game.
-Lots of options to adjust, you can even take your FOV upto 180. You can adjust your beam color, the enemy ratz's colors. Hell you can even customize colors in your name.
-Ratz fortress 2, introducing hats will please hat lovers like myself. You get random drops like in TF2 but if you don't like them just sell em on the market. Literally free money.


Negatives:
-Despite having lots of game modes like FFA ,TDM, CTF, DUEL etc you will only find players on FFA. The other games are mostly abandoned and no one plays them.
-Servers are mostly empty. You get some traffic at evenings but i couldn't find a match whenever i tried playing in the day time.
-Some technical fault with hit registration, i noticed a lot of times i hit the enemy and i hear the hit sound even before they (or someone else) kill me but my kill doesn't count. I am gonna assume that has to do with lag compensation or something like that.


Conclusion:

Get it if you're a fan of old school shooters such as Unreal tournament and Quake. Loving this game these days. I would highly recommend this game.

Posted: May 23, 2015
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This review is constructive criticism ONLY. I suggest that everyone try the game for themselves and form their own opinions.

-PROS-
Ratz maps
Instagib
Soundtrack
Multiple Gamemodes
Clear effort was put into this game
The devs have actively updated this game and I definetly see them completing it, which can't be said for many early access titles.

-CONS-
Movement feels absolutely terrible
Characters feel weightless (personal con, may not bother you)
Rails inconsistent with objects
Inconsistent boosts
No auto team balancing (in Team Deathmatch at least)
No way to see pings on players
Soundtrack (It becomes repetitive and annoying after hearing it for the 20th time)

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

I bought this game as a veteran of FPS games, growing up with the likes of Doom, Quake, Unreal Tournament, and Counter Strike when I saw this game I was instantly excited. From the videos here on steam and the reviews it appears to be a great nostalgia stimulating experience which will have you thinking back to "the old days" once again.

After watching the steam trailers and looking at the reviews I had somewhat expected it to be a standalone railgun type game on ratz maps.

What I got was a game where the movement feels awful, to the point where I'm not even sure if I'll ever touch it again for that main reason. Maybe I've become accustomed to other games styles of movement but something about Ratz Instagib's style of movement rubs me the wrong way. This is something that every player will have a difference in opinion on and has to experience it firsthand to fully understand what I truly mean when I describe it as awful.

You use your gun to boost in a similar manner to rocket jumping in Quake/UT, that's another huge mechanic that just feels really badly done and would benefit if it was made into a simple double jump/boost maneuver instead. Often times after boosting at an angle to propel myself forward and increase velocity I found myself slowing down instead, that's a huge problem in a game where it only takes 1 shot to kill you. I also at times found myself pressing the boost button only for it not to respond and end with me dead. Boosting is also the main way to get around the map, however there is a jump feature but after many attempts to string together more than a few jumps to gain speed and move around the map I found that it was largely ineffective.

Another issue would be the fact that rails are inconsistent with objects, quite a few times I was killed by rails that just seemed to magically go right through the object I was dodging my opponent around. I'm not sure if this an intended feature but I'm going to assume not since it couldn't be repeated on a consistent basis.

Looking past these HUGE issues there's tons of little ones that stuck out to me almost instantly. The lack of auto balancing teams in TDM leads to 2v1 situations on a consistent basis which honestly just amazes me that the developers didn't include a key feature like this before putting this up for early access. There is also no way to view current players pings to tell if someone is truly lagging or not, once again something that should be in the game before putting it up for early access.

Another small issue would be that players just generally feel weightless, this is something that may not bother everyone but I found it to be extremely disorienting after many years of enjoying other similar games.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The entire game needs some real changes so that it will feel solid enough before this game comes out of early access. The boosting feature should also be re-evaluated to see if it can be made more consistent as well as experimenting with the possibility of removing it all together in favor of a better alternative. Adding additional music to cut down on the repetitiveness would be highly advised as well. Overall, the game would be fun to play if they could tighten up the movement and that's the real deal breaker as of right now for me.

I really want to like Ratz Instagib and I intend to try and continue to play it and keep up with the development but I cannot recommend that people purchase this game in it's current state. However that does not mean this game is bad what-so-ever, I'm finding myself enjoying the game a lot even with what I mentioned above. You need to play the game and try it for yourself, cause it's blast. It is currently on sale for $6.02 USD and usually sells for $8.99 USD, I feel that at this discounted price that I have gotten my full moneys worth and honestly would of purchased it at full retail.

Posted: July 29, 2016
The Modern Golden Gun
Ratz Instagib is a multiplayer-only arena/twitch-shooter taken after a popular Quake & Unreal Tournament mod - instagib. This game mode is known for its one-hit, one-kill style of play and to excel at it, one must truly become a master of reflexes, map awareness, and precision. Unfortunately, the popularity of arena shooters has heavily declined over the recent decade, but Ratz Instagib manages to bring back the cult classic game mode many of us used to once love and cherish.


There are 4 different public server regions to connect to upon launching the game: United States, Europe, Japan, and Australia. I live in the US and the ping for the US server has been fine on my end. User experience may vary depending on the location. Alternatively, you can also create a private server for friends to join.


There are currently 6 different game modes supported in Ratz Instagib, described below, along with leaderboards.








There are 13 official maps, however, you can download and play a multitude of Steam Workshop maps due to a native level editor (RatzED). At the moment, there are over 300 Workshop maps to play on (including popular Unreal Tournament maps) that have been generated by other players.


In a normal match, your game rank, hit % and # of frags (kills) are presented. The game ends when the frag limit or time limit is reached. Depending on your game rank (how well you performed for that specific game, frag-wise), your player rating will adjust accordingly. A 5 level global rating system is used to rank players among Duel/FFA game types.


A core feature of Ratz Instagib is its player customization and urge to attain unlockables. The current character model has 3 accessory slots and 1 headpiece slot to display vanity items. Along with this, you have the option to customize beam color, enemy color, frag types (death animations) and beam types. Almost every visual aspect can be personalized, such as: FOV, crosshair types, etc.


The level editor (RatzEd) is relatively advanced, yet user friendly. RatzEd allows you to control lighting & player start locations, import unique meshes, and create custom textures along with providing basic level editor options (furniture, toys, objects, voxel units, etc.).


Along with general FPS movement, you can jump and activate a boost (aim at the ground/wall to propel yourself). This boost mechanic changes up how many of us used to play the game mode, as boosting can provide a much more controlled and powerful gap-closer/maker than dodging ever could. It is also important to know that controllers (gamepads) are not officially supported.


Ratz Instagib is a great and addictively fun product. I have yet to encounter any problems regarding ping, disconnections, matchmaking, or the player base. Although the instagib game mode and its nostalgia is what makes this game shine, the player customization options and friendly level editor (along with the vast amount of currently released Workshop levels) earn it a recommendation for any fan of twitch-shooters or players looking to re-experience the instagib game mode. With such a lack of similar games in this genre, especially on Steam, Ratz Instagib definitely shines above the rest and deserves a chance to be in your library.

Posted: December 15, 2021
A Dazzlingly Bright Gem With Fatal Flaws
It's not often that you can come out and say what I'm about to say, but Ratz Instagib is unironically the most fluid arena shooter that I think has ever been created. Maybe other games have different weapons or more iconic maps and sound effects, but when it comes to raw movement and the way a game handles raw aim, nothing does it better. It's hard to sound serious when the game's theme is so silly, but I'm not joking.

But there is a little problem.. Actually, it might be a really catastrophic problem for most people. The game is utterly dead. I'm not just talking about one of two lobbies with full player counts or anything like that, I'm talking completely, 100% DEAD. Despite that, if you head over to the community tab for Ratz Instagib, you'll see people constantly asking to play and trying to see if people can organise game nights. From what I've seen, these only sometimes become a reality though. As it stands, the only real action you can get is if you have a friend or two that you want to verse and you host a game yourself (which isn't hard). If you do try to find a game, you'll quickly get put into a practice waiting lobby where a single bot roams around. The bot is somewhat okay, but doesn't challenge you in the way a real player might.

So should you buy this game? If you have a love for arena fps, and you feel intrigued by what's on display here, I would recommend it, but you simply shouldn't buy it at full price because the product isn't even all there right now. I can see some random community spike happening in which the game gets a die hard fanbase that actually do play every day, but as it is now, the game is functionally a fun verses experience with friends at best, and an aim trainer at worst.

I have to recommend the game though, because it truly is a hidden gem, and everyone that has played it knows as much. This is a rare case of the community of players knowing how good a game is, but not being able to keep it alive due to how hard it is to find a public game. The solution to most people is to make the game free so that there's always enough players coming in to try it out, and so new players actually have a good experience because they can actually find a game. But that doesn't seem like it's ever going to happen, as the developer is very aware of this and doesn't seem to agree with it, or maybe they just don't care.

Either way, hats off to them for creating a true masterpiece of fps history. A game that ticks all the boxes for many, but a game that will likely fade into obscurity, only to never be replaced by anything as satisfying.

_____________________________________________________________________

, I just have to say that this game has one of the best soundtracks ever. I love the liquid jazz drum and bass on display here and I think it's a great showcase of a lesser known, but ultra enjoyable genre of music that I've loved for as long as I've known it. It's quite calming for an fps, but it does exactly what it's supposed to do, which is get you in the zone. The speed is satisfying and the percussion vocalizes the almost rhythmic element that arena fps has always had. It's an absolute standout to me and I highly recommend looking into the tracklist on youtube even if you don't purchase the game.

Posted: June 16, 2015
I first wrote this review in early access, but it is now UPDATED as of 2017-03-17

Ratz Instagib is a no-b*llsh*t, super fast-paced shooter where anyone can jump in and learn how to play in seconds. At the same time, the gameplay is almost completely skill-based and your aiming and movement skills (which can take weeks or months to master, especially the aim) directly determine the outcome of the game.
The game mechanics are as simple as it can get: you only have one weapon, the railgun, which is a one hit kill and you can boost in any direction (kind of like a rocket jump) by right clicking. The enemy hitboxes are extremely small and movement is extremely fast, which means that you have to be really good at aiming to hit your enemies.

Pros:
+ Very fast paced gameplay
+ Balanced, competitive gameplay
+ Responsive and smooth controls
+ Lots of customizations in the options menu (enemy colors, beam color, nickname color, X and Y mouse velocity, and a ton of other graphical options).
+ Performance is pretty good even though the game is made in Unity. I'm getting ~300-400fps on a i7-4790k and Sapphire r9 270x running at 1920x1080@120hz, I'd never expect an unity game to run so fast.
+ Multiple gamemodes
+ User-made workshop maps
+ Now allows connecting to a custom server

Cons:
- Could've included non-instagib gamemodes with the standard arena fps weapons and pickups

I highly recommend this as it's a lot of fun and also a great aim warm-up for games like Quake.

Posted: January 2, 2016
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
TL;DR: This game does a great job of being original and fun, It really does have a good style that not a lot of shooters can pull off now-n-days. I would recommend this to anyone who just wants to sit down and have a blast with friends. It's worth full price but if you can pick it up on sale.

Okay, before I talk about the gameplay let me address a few things. First, you play as a colored childish rat that looks like they are trying to take over the world. Second, prepare to either feel like a god or rage more then sith lords that don't get their way. And third, don't play this game without friends, because it's just not nearly as fun w/o a rage buddy.

Alright, first pros:
- Fast paced
- Fun movement
- Lots of items to customize your rat
- One shot kills
- Special kills (Head shots, crouch shots, both having different animations)
- Unlockable beam and frag types
- Unique game mode Freeze Tag
- Fun ranking system
- Ranked play
- Can customize your name to anything with a rainbow of colors, You can even use " "
- More that I can't think of atm because this game is just too awesome

Cons:
- Getting stuck in a game with really high skilled players can kill it
- There are blatent hackers in some games
- Movement sometimes bugs out
- No invisible walls to keep you in the map
- Lava pools suck
- This game can result in massive amounts of slurs and profanity

Overall:
This game is amazing, with only a few friends in a game you can have more fun than most other shooters. The movement is very momentum based and is super fun and fast. Each map feels like it's telling some form of story, and the coloring is amazingly done. This game does a great job of being original and fun, It really does have a good style that not a lot of shooters can pull off now-n-days. I would recommend this to anyone who just wants to sit down and have a blast with friends. It's worth full price but if you can pick it up on sale.

I would rate this a 9/10

Posted: July 9, 2020
Ratz Instagib is the culmination of a masterpiece and represents the essence of hard work. After playing it for a brief amount of time, it is evident that mechanically, the game asserts its superiority against other first-person shooters. The movement is carefully articulated in the way in which it grips players. It almost seems like it devours any sense of reality. As minutes pass, perhaps even hours, players will find themselves fully engaged in the combat, drenched in the very pools of sweat they generated themselves. On paper, the game is quite simple and may seem it lacks depth. However, deep down it contains elements of addiction, determination, and passion. The constituents that lurk beneath the unforgiving presentation of the game creates an unforgettable atmosphere. Experiences forged by the player cultivate and expound throughout the gameplay. The game truly holds a wealth of content. The immersive functionality breathes new light into the genre. It almost seems as if it follows the formula of first-person shooters while straying away to convey uniqueness. In this way, the game is oddly comforting, offering a sense of familiarity while still providing an exhilarating thrill.

Posted: December 30, 2016
Ratz Instagib came out of left-field for me. I discovered this game on the last week of 2016, when a friend of mine mentioned it over dinner. Later that night he bought the game for me, and I've been hooked ever since.

The game's instantly familiar to anybody who's spent their fair share of time playing arena FPS games, specifically "instagib" game modes or mods. You're given a weapon with lethal power and perfect accuracy, held back by a relatively long cooldown time between shots (in Ratz, it's fast enough to allow for follow-up shots after whiffing a target, but you're not rapid-firing this thing). You'll need to hit enemies to earn frags, while dodging their own shots. All of the maps are oversized human interiors, giving the feeling that you're rat-sized in a familiar world (another reference to arena FPS games and the popular "rats" style of honey-I-shrunk-the-kids custom maps in Quake, Unreal Tournament, and especially Counter-Strike).

The game offers plenty of customization, both in the form of extensive options (another wonderful concession to the tweak-loving arena FPS crowd), player avatar cosmetics, and even custom maps.

Ratz Instagib is a celebration of the Arena FPS and its community: From the giant bedroom maps to the tight instagib gamemodes and even the drum-n-bass soundtrack that makes me feel like I'm playing my very own frag compilation video. Fantastic custom map support, a plethora of options with support for minimal-visual "pro-gamer" settings (and even coloring your name!), and unlockable weapon effects based on player skill show that this is a game made by arena FPS fans, for arena FPS fans.

The current system is you every time you find a hat, you get to keep it and lose the one you have, or vice versa. Some hats you can 'rebuy' that you found. Others you cant.
Ive read that the hats can 'possibly' respawn randomly at times and be found again.
The problem with this system is that it sucks.
I, an owner of many hats, do not see the need to rebuy my hats i already aquired, much less some for some reason that are mysteriously never available to even buy again.
Honestly if i could rebuy ANY hat ive already found id possibly not even mention it.
Thats however not the case.
I should be able to swap to any hat ive already found any time i want, and only have an option to sell the crappy ones ones i honestly may want to sell, not because i have no choice.

This really sucks how they have it set up atm.

That all said.. the game is still decent enough and as annoying badly implemented they have done the hats..

If they fixed this.. id say the game was completely awesome. HINT. HINT.

How to get full screen mode.

In Steam\steamapps\common\Cat Goes Fishing
In the options file, change settings to this

[Windows]
CreateTexturesOnDemand=0
AlternateSyncMethod=1
VertexBufferMethod=1
SleepMargin=0

Then in game hold ALT+Enter
Done

Okay I will be the first to admit that people slap Cat on to something and call it a day and it sells like hot cakes. It has become almost a trend in gaming to put a Cat or funny animal into an unusual role and forget the importance of game design. When it comes to Cat Gone Fishing, the adorable aesthetic aside. The game is very well designed and highly addictive. Yes, it's a cat holding a fishing rod and it is adorable but that aside the core gameplay of Cat Goes Fishing is what I enjoyed most about this game. With dozens of upgrades available for your rod, boat, radar and more, you will turn your Cat into a fishing machine as you begin to battle the monsters underneath the surface. Cat Goes Fishing is a wonderful game to just load up and completely just fall into and relax while you play it, discovering even more aquatic animals after you think you've found everything. The only true complaint I could have about the game is it's lack of options, Cat Goes Fishing shows its mobile roots with no shame. While this may be disconcerting to some, I found the positives of this fun and adorable game to far outweigh the bad. Besides, guys, it's a Cat wearing a hat and fishing! Come on! It's adorable!!

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!

Posted: February 4, 2021
This game is amazing. At the start of the game, you are sitting there on a piece of land with just a simple rod to your name, as you progress you find new fish, each separately rated, each giving a certain amount of money. Eventually you do more quests and can get special upgrades to help you on your journey such as sonar or a mini-map. Eventually you get enough to get a boat and venture out further. You discover new fish and animals, you get new fishing rods with new upgrades explore further and further. You then go deeper and eventually find hats that give special bonuses. That's all assuming you are casually playing. You can play in realism mode which will make fish fight back. There's tons of lore to explore and you can keep playing for hours. There's a way to beat the game that (I guarantee) you won't be able to find without looking it up.

There are only a couple bad things to this game though. It has a lack of story line to it, it has tons of things you can look at that keep you thinking about before you started your journey, but not much story line. It has a weird money system as well in which you can get a fish, that say, is worth 64,000 in game cash. at that point when you get that its 1/5 of what you want for your next upgrade. You progress fast, then slow, then fast again. From my experience big fish worth a lot respawn 1-5 hours a time. This ranges per fish. This game also takes a lot of google searches on your first run. The last thing about this game is the downside in realism mode. I love how the game on this mode makes fish be able to fight back, but some are too powerful. A fish that is at spawn but very deep down, even with the best fishing rod and the best upgrades, can't be reeled in normally without tons of effort. You usually have to cheese the game and make it come directly above your rod and then pull it in, in less than a second.

Other than those, its one of my favorite games.
(I didn't check this review for grammatical errors, sorry!)
