Posted: February 17, 2018
Cat Goes Fishing is a simple but very cute and fun indie fishing simulator. You play as a furry little cat and in front of you lies a vast sea to scour and fish. You start on land with only a basic rod. Then you can sell the fish you catch for money to buy improved fishing gear, boats, and plenty of other items to help you catch some of the bigger, more challenging, and rare fish. There is a good amount of customization which allows you to develop your own style of fishing. The game is very relaxing and casual, and the simple controls makes it easy to play. Still there is plenty of action and strategy involved in wrestling the fish back to the surface without being eaten by bigger fish. There is a large and unique variety of fish, and a organized log to keep track of the fish you caught. Each type of fish has its own behavior and specific location that adds to the challenge of catching it. You can also find plenty of hats to wear in the sea that add a nice bonus and cosmetic to your cat. Cat Goes Fishing is short, though there is a surprising amount of depth and a lot of charm which makes this game highly replayable. This game is well worth the money and the time spent.

Posted: January 23, 2015
Cat Goes Fishing is a casual, cat-induced, 2-D fishing ‘simulator.’ The goal here is to use an array of tools, including rods, boats, even bombs in conjunction with upgrades to complete a host of quests.

The casting mechanics are fairly straightforward, as there are only three buttons you’re likely to ever use. Click for casting/reeling & A/D for movement. There is no tutorial as of the writing of this review, but getting the general sense on how to start casting to maximum effect is quite simple. There isn’t any Menu either.

While, the casting & movement mechanics couldn’t get any simpler, there is some depth on how you choose to complete the quests. There are many different types of effects you can apply to your rod to target or dissuade various types of fish or to augment other elements. There are also tools both temporary & permanent that will come in handy.

As you catch fish & complete quests, you will level & accrue currency. As you level, the quests get progressively more difficult. However, from my experience, there does appear to be a degree of randomness with respect to the quest system; old quests will pop up time & again. The quests will progressively get more & more grindy. Completing them will require you to farm currency for pro-longed periods of time, before you can purchase the necessary items & upgrades to complete them.

Yes, does have an array of hats. They are obtained by catching them so keep an eye out. The sad part is that you can’t collect them. You can only wear one hat at a time. Each hat provides a useful boost. Be wary of accidentally selling a hat, as it is easy to do.

There is an in-game catalog giving various details on the different types of fish, so it may yield some assistance in catching your desired fish.

The artwork is exactly as shown in the screenshots. The background scenery is under-utilized & quite bland. The sound is one uninspiring track looped continuously. Luckily, it can be muted with the ‘M’ key.

In conclusion, I wouldn’t label as a fishing simulator. I wouldn’t recommend it to those who love fishing & desire that experience, albeit through the eyes of a cat. Rather, is a game you pop in when you have a few minutes to kill, just for the posterity of seeing a cat catch some fish, while wearing a snazzy hat.

Posted: April 13, 2023
A cute little fishing game that starts out simple and gets more complex as you level. As you upgrade your gear, you decide on your rod and boat loadouts to catch progressively bigger fish and find cool hats. There's even rockets to make your cast go farther, and bombs to... well, get rid of pesky fish that might have gotten in your way.

Cat Goes Fishing is a pretty relaxing game, with fun moments of celebration as your strategies succeed and you manage to catch the exact fish you were after. Realism mode adds a little bit more difficulty to the game, as you have to reel in fish more carefully -- pretty great if you'd like a bit more challenge!

The only downside is that there really aren't any instructions, but if you keep catching fish and doing the quests, eventually you'll unlock things and figure out the next step.

Overall, relaxing and fun, with a bit of a strategic challenge!

Posted: November 3, 2021
A hesitant recommendation from me.
The game itself is pretty fun, though it's very grindy, and there isn't much in the way of an endgame.
But the biggest problem, by far, is the spawn rates. The game gives you quest, which revolve around you catching a specific fish. It encourages you to explore, and some of the stuff you have to do to catch certain fish is pretty interesting. But, because of the spawn rates for certain fish, it can become very, very easy to get soft locked on quests, because the fish you're looking for literally just don't exist on the map at that moment. They will respawn eventually, however this can take as little as a few minutes to hours upon hours of waiting for the fish to return.

It get's very frustrating very quickly when you get stuck, especially when you haven't done anything wrong. Sometimes, for no reason whatsoever as far as I can tell, certain fish will just disappear, leaving you stuck halfway through a pile of quests that can now no longer be finished.

Posted: December 2, 2019
I don't often review games because I am lazy, but this game deserves it. I am a 32 year old gamer and my fishing experience goes back 28 years. I played all the fishing games. A few truck simulators, all the farming simulators, most the cooking simulators, house fipping,thieving, pc buildings, job etc. This game is different then them all. Team work isn't wanted its absolutely needed. There is no fish feed, no glamour for the solo person with 50 fishes at the end you just get to celebrate the win while your countries music plays on the score tab. Its a very, very different game. I am not super familiar with this genre having only played cat mobile games for a few hours but the people playing this game are passionate. A lot of them take everything super serious which has its ups and downs but mostly ups. The player base is small enough you start to see the same people in games, but its large enough its always possible to find a full server to play on in less than 5 minutes. There is so many niches to fill in this game I suggest watching a youtube video before loading it up. The strats you need to win in this game take a lot of team coordination (average game has around 10 diff squads all geared towards diff tactics to help you win). Much deeper then it appears. Amazingly fun game.
Gameplay Video:
YouTube™ Video: Cat Goes Fishing Gameplay [PC HD] [60FPS] 
Views: 17,772
Cat Goes Fishing PC Gameplay [60FPS] http://store.steampowered.com/app/343780/ Subscribe & comment to see more: http://bit.ly/seph_au Focus on steam games, indies and early access. No nonsense.

Starting as cat with a basic rod the controls are simple, you can play this with one hand. Fishing up the smaller species initially and selling them will reward you with money, which is used for purchase of better rods or upgrades to current equipment. The game then introduces you to it's quest system, completing these tasks rewards larger sums of money. While questing the fish catalog becomes useful as it will display all species in the game.

Sometimes fishing in the depths you may discover rare hats, which not only look cute on cat but give large bonuses to both your fishing abilities and values of catches. More tongue in cheek one-use items available later include rockets and bombs but everything has it uses. In these cases scaring away packs of fish or making your cast go much further with cheaper rods. Boat travel is also included, but I have not progressed that far yet.

Content wise, If you check the store page the developer mentions and I quote.
"Regular updates will bring new fish, boats, hats, and entirely new mechanics to the game, extending your experience and offering new ways to master the game. "

Addictive and enjoyable for all ages. Easily recommended.

@developer
Only downside is the music, decent enough but maybe think about adding some more variety in future. :)

Posted: September 21, 2021
This is honestly surprisingly fun. I've played for over 40 hours so far, and I still find it fun to go back to if I'm bored. Catching every fish has proven quite difficult, but still achievable; I have 2 fish left to catch. The game is easy to pick up, there's only a couple buttons that you use regularly. The money aspect of the game doesn't last long, as you can max out all your equipment very quickly, so the end goal is to catch every fish. Classic mode is great if you're getting a feel of the game, but Realism is more fun. That being said, there will be a lot of frustrating moments when fish get away (I'm looking at you cave shark), but generally that frustration doesn't last long. Most fish are simple to catch - get the right sized bait, and dangle it in front of them - but other, rarer fish sometimes require something more complicated. You may need a certain fish as bait, maybe live bait, maybe turn off your sonar or even light! To add to the complexity of the game, there are hats and rod upgrades, which offer buffs to help your progression, whether it enhances your gameplay, adds multipliers, sets a time of day, or something else, they prove very useful. All in all, the game is a fun way to spend your free time when you don't feel like playing something intense, and I would definitely recommend this game to you if any of that sounds interesting. Good luck on your fishing adventures!

Posted: 29 May, 2016
The Mean Greens is a colorful, fun third person shooter made with the unreal engine. I will list the pros and cons of this game.
Pros:
+The game is colorful and enjoying to look at, maps like "Art table" are just riddled with colors, the lighting in the game is done right too.
+It runs like butter on my pc, and on my cheap laptop, I can't really imagine anyone experiencing framedrops with a decent setup.
+The music is catchy and nice to listen too, I had a smile on my face when I first heard the song during operation birthday, or hearing ride of the valkyres during Bathtub bash.
+Everyone has all the guns at all times, there is no reason to complain being killed.
+Each map has it's own game mode, all with different varieties. Modes like team deathmatch in the Table top wars map, FFA in the art table shuffle, Attack and defend in Operation birthday cake, and one of my favorites which is bathtub bash, a mode where you must ride rubber duckys to reach flags and deliver the flags back to your ship.

Now If what I said above is convincing you to buy the game, what I say next can probably change that.
Cons:
-While there are a ton of different game modes, some quite work out. In the map Operation birthday, the objective is to assault a birthday cake and light as much candles as you can while the enemy team stops you. After around halftime, the sides switch, so if team 1 lit 10 candles, all team 2 has to do is light 11. If team 2 lights 11 within the first minute, you've already won the game, and must wait the next 3 minutes until the round ends to be declared the winner (Which I think is stupid). Some game modes just require suicide to win. In the game modes Kitchen run and Deep freeze, all you have to do is run to your objective and do the action it tells you to (such as pushing the enemy cup off the table or unfreezing your dinosaur), so you can play the game for 4 minutes in a straight up tie, but 1 enemy touched your cup just slightly, and you lost the game.
-The servers can be absolutely horrible at times, you can hit join game and be waiting up to 3 minutes just so it could tell you that you failed to connect.
-The worst one would have to be-
The game is completely empty, I hit server browser only to find out there are 10 players online in TOTAL, if you are lucky you can find a server with maybe 6 people, and people usually leave during it. The game is fun with people to play, and no one ever plays.

Conclusion: I don't see the $10 dollar price being worth it up to now, I bought the game on release and I still don't feel like it was a good buy, but I can't not recommend this game, if you have a couple of buddys that will play it with you it's an excellent choice, otherwise wait for the price to be lowered. I see this more as a game that should be free to play, it's amazing but all it needs is a community to play it, and not a lot of people will pay for a game without players already playing it.

(Sorry if this review was long, it's the first game i've reviewed and I felt like I had to tell people about this game.)

Posted: 28 January, 2019
How do you breathe life into a few years old game that has no real existing player base? Well, if our game is an online shooter, follow the path of Virtual Basement and Code Headquarters, drop the price to a buck for at least a short time, announce it with enthusiasm, and then be there to support your game despite it being several years old with the knowledge that, by doing so, you are basically giving a lot of new players a fun and inexpensive experience that they might otherwise never have known about, which in turn gives your game a whole new lease on life.

Story

Nada. Although you can extrapolate and make it the story of yo as a kid with your friends, setting up your little plastic army men in different scenarios and having them duke it out.


All things considered, The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare doesn't really do anything special from a gameplay perspective. To me, this game is not so far off of what Team Fortress 2 is, albeit with far less gameplay options.

Basically, you join an active server and start playing. There are five weapons available (assault rifle, shotgun, sniper rifle, bazooka, flamethrower) plus grenades of course. There are no skills, rankings, or anything else to separate players. Each player is on the same footing in each game with only skill and luck separating one player from another. So, each battlefield is uniquely fair from start to finish.

I personally have only played on 20 and 40 player servers, where it's either every soldier for themselves, or it's team objective, and that is strictly determined by the specific map selected by the players (or chosen randomly if that option is selected by the majority). There is a kick option, but I haven't seen anybody use it yet, which is great since the one real issue this game has presently is there aren't enough "official" servers to host all the new players, which can make for long wait times waiting for the larger servers to have an open spot. Fortunately, you can create your own game, and can rent servers if you prefer as well. Plus, the longest wait I've experienced waiting to get into a server has been like a minute or two. Not bad considering.

There is one bug that is at play in a lot of matches, which we'll call the reload bug. Shotguns, assault rifles, and sniper rifles will often bug out and not allow reloading. So often in fact that outside of people asking for votes on specific maps for the next match, the most common thing you will see in the in game chat are questions about how to reload your guns lol.


Well, as you can imagine, a game about little plastic soldiers is going to feature artwork that is whimsical and childlike in appearance. This takes the form of the various maps, which are all children's scenarios for playing war with your little plastic peeps. A bathtub, the kitchen counter, a literal sandbox, an artist table, and so on. The graphics are perfect for what this game is. Nothing mind blowing, but definitely appropriate.


The audio is fairly standard for online shooters. Nothing too memorable. There are tunes, there are sound of battle, etc...
The audio isn't really the focus for this game, but it works such as it is even if I'm hard pressed to really think of anything that stands out.


Stupid fun. Pick up and play goodness that presently will only cost you a buck. Best buck I've personally spent in a while.

Posted: 11 December, 2015
Short description about the game
It's basically a TPS, in a toy universe, the soldiers, the weapons, are actual toy figures.
The environment is funny, you can see big sponges, huge candles. Basically, everything is bigger than you.

Gameplay
About 10 maps, different game modes which are all fun, you all start with the same weapons, you don't buy ammo, you don't call for 'air support', or such.
It's a pretty simple and minimal game, and i love it for that, lately i've been too annoyed about the lack of actual fun shooters/online games that are also minimal.

Community
Well, it's too early to talk about the community, but, you shouldn't consider it much, basically, toxic players are in every game.
However i made this small section in my review to tell you a funny store that happened to me earlier in this game.
Someone randomly said 'Votekick X', i tried to defend that one 'X' because it didn't seem fair since he didn't do anything. That 'X' that was votekicked, actually votekicked me and said 'lol'.


First of all, the devs seem like they take care of the game, and they seem to be interested in actually solving problems, i point these out for them, in case someone slipped the details on the forums, and they actually read my review.

- Sudden loss of connection, happens basically, after almost every match, sometimes before joining one.
- The 'Find Game' option, often finds a game that is already full, which can be quite frustrating.
- There is too much "invisible unwalkable space" (sorry, can't really describe it better as English is not my main language). Basically, you can walk too close to a teammate or you will be blocked by some invisible space. Which can be bad if a teammate is AFK in some sort of small space. You can't walk past him even if there seems to be plenty of space.
- The votekicking can use some improvement, but i am pretty sure it's a bit obvious, and you probably didn't work on it so far because you were focused on the game itself.

So far, so good, i received this game as a gift, a beautiful gift that make me chuckle quite a bit upon seeing it. Also, brings me alot of childhood memories.
Damn you, nostalgia!

NOTE:
Regarding the lost connection issue, i think it's because of the ping, when you browse for servers join the ones with the lowest ping.

PS:
I would love a Steam Workshop for this, and some easy ways to create content for it :)

Posted: December 14, 2015
As my childhood was all about army men games and figures, I was so excited with this game the moment I saw it, and it really does not disappoint me at all.

Pros:
+Super fun, fast pace gameplay.
+Ten different maps in total and each map has a unique objective: capture the flag, light the birthday cake candles, push the enemies' cup off the table etc. and my favourite is playing football, where each team need to put the ball in the opponent's goal while trying to blow the enemies' head off at the same time :P
+5 different weapons to switch easily between at your liking: assault rifle, sniper, shotgun, bazooka, flamethrower.
+Gorgeous graphics, and run extremely well.
+Very good and relaxing soundtrack.
+No competitive feeling, simply just fun, best thing to play after a stressful day.
+They have even added female character models now :D :D

Cons:
+No vehicle like tank, armoured car, mounted MG on jeep, anti-aircraft etc.
+No speciality class, no character customization.
+No bot to play with at night when everybody is sleeping, and the game has some connection issue, best way to play is browse from server and do not use the join game in the menu.

The little content aspect is actually acceptable for the price, but still it does even better than many triple A titles recently, which ask for 60 dollars but offer even less content than a 15 dollar game like this one!
For 10 dollars on sale or even when at full price I still think it's all worth it, and if you are a fan of army men you don't even need to read the review to decide, you must get it now!!

9.5/10 I love this game <3

Posted: May 30, 2017
Pros:

+ Nostalgia
+ Graphics and attention to details is top notch
+ Sounds are good
+ Maps are amazing


Cons:

- Multiplayer only
- Slim to no games
- No bots

The Mean Greens – Plastic Warfare reminds me a lot about Army Men back in the day. The concept, the graphics, sounds, and most importantly the maps make this game a childhood memory that has come back from the plastic graveyard. The graphics is using the Unreal 4 Engine, and then the attention to details on the army men, maps, and background are all done very well. The sounds and music fit the theme perfectly. The UI is simple and clean – ammo, objective status, health, etc. The gameplay is smooth and feels similar to the old CoD titles but with a 3rd person view.

You also have a variety of guns, but some of those guns are in need of a tweak (either buff or nerf). You can use the environment to eliminate your opponents. For an example, you can use the foosball to run someone over with it while making a score for your team. Another map has cars racing around and you can bait them (the enemy) onto the track and watch them get flown off the table.

Unfortunately, the game is multiplayer only and finding a game is pretty much slim to none. When I did manage to find a game, it was smooth and I didn’t notice any lag/disconnects. I’ve heard of some players doing special events or scheduled days to play this game so that way people can actually have a full-fledged match going on. Adding bots could help out the multiplayer scene. If someone is playing with bots and someone joins their game, they are then placed on the opposite team and they replace one of those bots. When someone else joins the game, then they join one of the teams and replaces a bot; etc.

Posted: November 28, 2017
I love this game. I'm addicted to this game. It's far from perfect, but its gameplay is top notch, and if you put the time in, your reward in skill gained pays off. The maps are all extremely imaginative and feature many different game types/modes. The graphics and music are high quality and and supplement the gameplay well. There is no single player (besides a tutorial), no bots, no progression, and a fairly sparse player base at times. I would love all of those things to be better in the future, but for now, this game still stands out as the best online TPS ever to me, and it's the only one I really play. The dev team continues to be active in improving upon the game and adding more content, so I have nominated it for "The Labor Of Love" award. (2017, 2018, and 2020) Pick the game up if competitive gameplay appeals to you and you are willing to boot it up now and again to see if there's a match going. It's so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fun.

The developers have recently stated that bots and some sort of ranking/progression system are both coming in the near future! It's a great time to buy if you've been on the fence on whether to purchase or not.

Edit 2: Bots for deathmatch and team deathmatch modes are in! They are a bit limited as they will only use the assault rifle or grenades and only work on the aforementioned modes, but they have good aim and react well enough to have a decent K/D when filling in slots online. They are a bit goofy and can be countered by a skilled player to moderate success. I don't think you're going to have a very fun time playing alone against a full match against bots, but it is possible and a nice option to have. Even if the game is empty of real players, you might end up playing with some other actual players eventually if you host your own server, because the server browser is back, both Steam and in game. When players join a match with bots, the bot slots are replaced by players, and there is one community server with no bots allowed.

In addition, cosmetic ranks are in, which is a cool small thing to reward no lifing like I do and racking up tons of hours. The ranks show a picture next to your name in lobbies and team lists in game. Your rank can only increase on official servers, and you get XP from kills and objectives at the end of a match. Because of this lack of progression on them, player hosted servers are "just for fun" in a way, and there are servers that allow for more players (20, 40, or otherwise) rather than the game's default 10 player design and limit. These big servers are a fun distraction, but don't all feel great due to an obvious lack of balancing. Unfortunately, ranks may even be tied specifically to region servers, rather than all official servers, (or there is a bug), because I only see my high rank on U.S. servers and it's back at the initial rank and never progresses on European servers. Along with the ranks are experience/kill count leaderboards, but surprisingly not one for K/D or any other purely skill based records, rather than just time spent playing in the long run. It would have been cool to have something more skill based like missions for rank, but it's not necessary. You can now also change and permanently set your soldier player model from a small set which even includes some new ones, yippee! There's even a set of "new" maps that are remixes of old maps with different layouts/obstacles and objectives. It's all new versions of Deathmatch/Team Deathmatch/Capture The Flag, and it's really great to have a bigger selection of both types of deathmatches while playing with bots. The map count was already impressive, but now it's almost excessive, and the development team seems committed to continuing to update the bots and add more maps/game modes.

Overall, the last big update with bots and ranks (and character selection and "new" maps) makes this game worth the purchase full price and without a doubt if/when on sale, but it must be said that the online is often pretty devoid of players when at non peak times, which even then is only usually one full match, or rarely, two. This game has sold one million copies on Steam, so it's sad to see that a lack of these recently added features early on may have contributed to difficulties cementing a player base that sticks around and plays often. If you can deal with playing with friends or bots only, as well using the Steam and in game server browser to check at different times throughout the day/week if people are playing, (or check official Discord/forums for times), you will get your money's worth on this title in the quality of gameplay alone. Grab you and your friends a few copies of the game in the Steam Summer Sale, (going on at the time on this writing), and wreck some plastic! I'll see you on the battlefield!

Posted: December 10, 2015
The Mean Greens is a simple shooter with some incredibly fun and unique maps.
YouTube™ Video: The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare - 60fps Gameplay & Review - A Sheepish Look At 
Views: 3,117
Genna plays The Mean Greens. A shooter where you play as plastic toy soldiers in unique and colourful maps. Click here to Subscribe ► http://bit.ly/mrwssub...

The fact that you play as toys in this game allows for some really imaginitve objectives and maps.
For example, a kitchen map has you zipline in by a string attached to plastic cups. You battle in between gigantic doughnuts, bubbles from a sink, and your mission is to knock over the enemy cup so that they can't zipline into the level anymore. There are so many creative objectives placed on colourful and alive maps. It's a nice breath of fresh air in the shooter genre.

The gameplay itself is quite simple. You sprint, jump, shoot and roll. The combat at the moment isn't very in-depth. There are no weapon pick-ups, you just have all 5 on you at once. No killstreak rewards, or class systems. Personally, I like it. It's very simple and easy to pick up and have fun with. My only gripe at the moment is the game's cap is 5 vs 5 which leaves some of the bigger maps feeling a tad bit empty sometimes, although the devs have said they plan to raise that, as well as add more content in the future, which is great to hear!

That's really all there is to say.
Overall, simple gameplay but the fun variety of objectives and maps keeps the game fresh!

Posted: December 10, 2016
The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare is such a fun game and it's design is so charming I can't deny that much work went into the game, but sadly this games community is dead or dying fast at least.

The Mean Greens is a multiplayer shooter where you play as Toy Soldiers on maps which are designed to make you feel like a real toy. Like maps in a bathtub, art table, christmas tree and a birthday party.

The overall design of this game is absolutely amazing and it's charming to say the least. But the game has many faults.

First of all each map has a different game mode, so if you like a game mode like capture to flag you can only play on the map that has it. So if you don't like the map with Capture the Flag, well too bad you can't play it on any other map.

The gameplay itself is sometimes flawed. The game gives you five weapons a rifle, a sniper, shotgun, flamethrower and a rocket launcher. The problem is the rocket launcher and flamethrower aren't that good against enemies, so it boils down to the three mains.

The hit detection is another problem. While I didn't encounter it with any of the weapons expect the shotgun, it still annoyed me so much so that the only weapon I used was the rifle.

Graphically the game looks amazing. Every map looks colorful and vibrant and overall it's very pleasing to the eye.

This game also could use something like a level up system or ranks, cause to be completely honest playing a multiplayer game where your skill isn't rewarded at least for me isn't that fun. I would like to gain XP and earn something out of playing the game.

Overall The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare is an incredibly fun game, but the problems and the dying community doesn't help at all and my honest suggestion is either skip on get it on a very heavy discount.

Pros:
+ Amazing Map Designs
+ Great game modes

Cons:
- Serious gameplay issues
- Dying community
- No level system makes the game unrewarding in a sense

Final Rating:
5/10

Introduction:
‘The Mean Greens – Plastic Warfare’ is a 5v5 competitive multiplayer team based game where you control one of the toy soldiers while fighting for various objectives on multiple stylish maps. Game itself seem to revolve around ‘Army Men’ universe, so those of you who played it back in the days will recognize it rather quickly and get that nostalgia feeling.

Few words about game universe:
For those of you who have never heard of ‘Army men’ franchise, here’s a short briefing: Game line is based around multiple toy soldier factions, who are divided by their color. It is somewhat humorous and satiric universe which depicts military conflicts in our common surroundings, like your average children’s room, or toy railway with train on it, etc.

Unfortunately, even though initial idea is interesting on paper, game line didn’t seem to catch attention of people and was a commercial failure. That, however, doesn’t mean that universe is entirely dead, as we still have games like “The Mean Greens” and open source remaining of “Army men 3” which, sadly, stopped its development in April 2018.

Gameplay-wise ‘The Mean Greens’ is an oldschool team based shooter where you can either take steady aim, or just randomly hop’n’shoot, taking out your enemies while trying to complete map objective. There are 5 types of weapons overall and you carry all of them straight after spawn. Each weapon is very specific and only works for specific goals: e.g. It’s useless trying to shoot at someone with a shotgun if they stand farther than 10 meters away from you, e.t.c.

It’s worth mentioning that ‘The Mean Greens’ features multiple gamemodes: In one of them you have to melt your dinosaur faster than enemy team melts theirs, in another you have to drag and drop the cup from the table faster than rivals and that’s not counting quite standard modes, like team Deathmatch and Capture the flag, which look quite dull comparing to previous examples.

Map designers deserve a cookie, as all of the game levels look unique, stylish, colorful and, most importantly, unrepetitive: One battlefield features underwater fights inside some aquarium, with fishes calmly swimming around you, while another map represents huge birthday cake where you have to light up birthday candles. Even tutorial is made via interesting way where players have to guess how certain things work.

Visuals of the game were already partially covered in a previous section, however it’s still worth mentioning that game is made on Unreal Engine 4, which basically guarantees top quality picture. Each model looks on a decent level. Overall gamma is quite bright and colorful, which can literally cheer you up if you’re in a bad mood.

However, if you’re still sad, even after seeing all these colorful places, plunging you in the childhood, the music will totally help you. Seriously, if there’s one thing that is done better than visuals, it is the music. Each map and menu features unique melody which suits funky combat just fine and can be listened to, even without the game. Composers did amazing job here!

















Overall ‘The Mean Greens’ is a game with great potential, yet somewhat poor realization of of some quite vital things. It could be a really popular game, but messed up server list ruins most of it. Can I recommend it overall, though? It’s more of a YES than NO game. Especially since you actually can have some fun if you gather up together with your friends and invite them to your own server. Things might change for the better once devs finally release bot support, so keep your eyes peeled to the news!

This game looks incredible! All the visuals are so good and the aesthetic and all the looks about it are just perfect! The gameplay... it could use some fixin' up.

Although the game looks stunning when you actually play it you notice quite a few issues with it, here are the ones I have found so far:

40% of the time when someone shoots you there is no way of telling you have been shot, your health goes down but there is no red semi circle or even sound effect. The circle appears sometimes and I can't even tell if there is a sound effect for being shot.
The flamethrowers are way way too op. Maybe they're supposed to be a replacement for the knife but at close range they can kill you in less than half a second before you even have time to react, the gamemodes where its hard to be a flamethrowing ♥♥♥♥♥ are the best.
EXAMPLE: I was playing a CTF and on the other team there was a guy who kept using a flamethrower, by the end of the game no one even got to their flag as flamethrowers were camping there and our team managed to kill off the 2 people that actually tried to get our flag. The end results show the flamethrower guy had 32 kills 2 deaths and his other team members combined had about 7 kills (three other people). Our team of also four people had combined kills of about 20 or less. FIX THE FLAMETHROWERS PLEASE

Last of all I just want to say that the last time I played this game there were about 4 flamethrower guys in my server and I just got so fed up of jumping server to server just to find some honest people who actually use real guns that don't have infinite ammo :l and therefore I don't even want to play this game anymore until they do something about it.

I'm not crying about being a n00b, I'm just pointing out an easy exploit that ruins the spirit of the game for me. I will upvote this game but only because I do actually like the game; 40% of the players? Not so much.

Posted: December 11, 2015
Plastic soldiers you say? Well, why not, it's not like this is the first time game used those. Suddenly an onslaught of soldiers looks kind of cute, instead of severed limbs you get shattered plastic and there is no blood. So apart from the theme, what is this all about? The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare is a multiplayer third person shooter in which two sides of plastic soldiers, greens and tans, fight on a variety of über cute maps with their plastic arsenal.

Each side can have five soldiers at most and while you cannot pick different types of little warriors, you can pick from a variety of weapons to use. Each soldier carries an M4, sniper riflle, shotgun, rocket launcher and flamethrower from which you can choose on the go. Have you used all your sniper rifle ammo? No problem, take out your shot gun and run around for a moment while your ammo gets automatically replenished, that is if you live long enough. I would say that neither of these weapons is weaker than others maybe apart from rocket launcher; which however can fire just one rocket before having to replenish ammo. The gun handling itself is far from being unique as it is very arcade like, fitting with the theme of the game I would say. If you are a fan of realism... well, you would not be even reading this review so whatever.

Soldiers can duke it out on an astounding number of 10 maps (hi SW) each equipped with a different mode ranging from typical deatch match and capture the flag to candle lighting on a birthday party. The theme of the game let the devs to come up with some really unique arenas for the soldiers to fight in which is in my opinion the biggest perk of the game. Who would not enjoy a ride on a toy train around a christmas tree or an onslaught inside a Foosball. When you are riding a little gummy duck inside a bathtub you won't even care that the graphics are not exactly perfect and some textures could use a little more work which brings me to the next part of this review, graphics.

As I have said, the game is not the "bestest" looker on the market, devs of The Mean Greens tried to bring us a fully 3D experience and as many small indie studios kinda struggle with the delivery; However for what it is, the game is pleasant to look at. It is very colorful and one will forgive it the sometimes too rough edges and blurry textures. From a technical standpoint the game runs fine and I did not notice any major hiccups on an upper mid-end desktop. In settings there are plenty of options to fiddle with while trying to get a better performance from a lower end machine.

All in all, The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare is a pretty decent game which cannot, and in my opinuon should not, compete with the popular shooters like CS:GO or Overwatch; However in itself can bring a lot of joy if you are a fan of arcade shooting in an unique arenas while listening to a pretty neat soundtrack. The main question will be whether it can keep the servers running and populated and for how long. So should you buy it? For 10 bucks it is not a bad deal whether you are bored of competitive shooters and want to relax or want a not so brutal game for your young ones so feel free to grab it, it works and it's fun!

Posted: June 9, 2016
I know what you're asking, is it like the Army Men games?

Well, not 100% quite. It is a good game, however. It's like the Army Men series, but a bit faster paced. There is no single player, there is no bots, and there isn't weapon pick ups or drops or the likes. You start out with all the weapons and they're poorly balanced.

The shotgun really out shines the main rifle, or all the weapons really. The flame thrower is a tad underwhelming and I find the reach is dreadful making it the worse weapon in the game. This balance can really ruin the game for some players. I also find the rocket launcher a bit too powerful as well, but it isn't like you have a whole lot of shots with it, so it isn't a strong complaint from me.

Though you will not get 5v5 games often, I did just finish a 3v3 game. I do not understand how this game got so many negative reviews for being dead when there is plenty of games being hosted occupied by players. It's not like it was designed for 32v32, you'll get a full game or near full game if you try.

The biggest complaint I have is level variety. You have a handful of levels that have, set in stone, only one mode of play. This means you can only play one level for capture the flag, only one level for free for all deathmatch, only one level for team death match, etc. The question is... why? Not only is it lacking levels, but it's lacking levels for game modes. It could easily implement the majority of modes on all the maps, but that isn't the case.

Ultimately, this is a fine game if you can get it on the cheap. It has great potential and I hope the developer can take advantage of it. It really could make a good Army Men series tribute, or reincarnation really.

Pros:
Nostalgia exploitation but satisfying
Good fast gameplay, easy to pick up and learn, good game to play every once in awhile with friends
Well made maps, all good looking
game modes creative and enjoyable, very refreshing, though some feel slightly similar to existing ones.
This game is still worked on frequent enough to not feel alarmed about the investment.

cons:
Dreadful balance system.
No auto balance, no option to join losing team in game, cannot switch teams when "game is about to start."
No single player, no campaign, no bots, nothing beyond PvP.
The crosshair is not perfectly reliable when used for aiming during situations where you might be behind cover; this is a common problem for other third person shooters as wel, consider this a nitpick.
Weapons don't always fire where you witness the actual gun pointing, this is especially noticable with the flame thrower.
Lacks a huge amount of variety in weapons, levels, gameplay, and many other pieces of content that can cause this game to have virtually no replay value in the long run. You're better off playing with friends an Army Men game emulator, even despite this being the newer take on the series.


Overall, I say 7.5/10 is deserved. Good game, buy it if you got a solid group of friends.

If the game were to ever develop bots and AI, this game has A LOT of potential to be a must have game for a group of friends. Whether it was to make a good campaign/coop mode, or perhaps a mode where all players fight a giant toy dinosaur or such, the potential is endless. The developers are currently looking into AI, but the results or implementation remains a mystery as of now.

To Developer:
This game needs
More weapons, see Army Men series for more. From mines and minesweeper to grenade launchers, you have options.
Vehicles and Aircraft. It doesn't have to be forced on all maps, but I do suggest you implement them in some maps for the sake of variety.
Make flexible game modes available on all maps (free for all death match, team death match, capture the flag, etc.)
More maps!

Posted: May 9
The Mean Greens is a pretty solid and imaginative shooter multiplayer game (which was obviously inspired by the Army Men series of games), which at some point seems to have sold over 1 million copies. Unfortunately, online multiplayer is pretty much dead nowadays. I was able to find a match with three other people... but that's a rare occurrence.

It seems the game does have bots you can play against, but it doesn't provide a straightforward way of just setting up a match with bots under your desired game mode, which is a shame. It should just offer a simple "Play against bots" option. Also, the game does offer a short tutorial to teach you the basics of how to play, which is appreciated.

So, although The Mean Greens is pretty much dead, and it will most likely not receive any more updates, I DO recommend it if:

- You have friends to play with

- Wait to get it with a 90%+ discount

At this point, the devs should just make the game free to play to attract more players, maybe open up a Patreon or something similar for it, and advertise a Discord community so fans of the game can find each other, and set up more regular playing sessions.

Additionally, for anyone who marks reviews they dislike and/or disagree with as "funny", when the review in question is not humorous: Doing that is , and doesn't make your opinion the right one :)

Posted: June 28, 2016
This game definitely needs more people.

The Mean Greens - Plastic Warfare harkens back to a time when games had higher standards, a time that lived its' last days perhaps a decade ago or so.
When you get this game, you'll see that everything's in there already. Very few modifications or fixes need to be done. It has that rare combination of fun gameplay, fine graphics, clever map concepts, and epic soundtrack (the soundtrack is extremely catchy and was composed by three different people, which brings a harmonious variety of music genres into the fold). This is a stark contrast to the current blockbuster games which attract large numbers of buyers whilst [initially] containing very limited content.

The major curse that has befallen this game is precisely one of numbers. Namely, too few people are playing it. This makes most parties pretty much empty. And yet, the game is still enjoyable enough to be played in a 3v3 scuffle. I see that most buyers have resorted to handing out negative reviews because of that, and this is hardly fair in my book. The devs should consider introducing bots to keep the game on its' toes for what it's worth. does that, so why shouldn't they?

What can I say? This game surely stands out in several ways. I wouldn't necessarily say that it is an underrated game, but it cruelly suffers from undeserved neglect instead.

If you enjoyed , then you'll definitely enjoy .

This game sure has some downsides. Still. But the best thing is that devs who doesn't seem to be a large group of people are still working on the game and try to stay in touch with the community at the game-related forums. They greatly appreciate players' feedback and seem to encourage it. That is what I really like.
\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\
So, What is "The Mean Greens"? Well, It's a third-person multiplayer shooter based on the UNREAL engine, featuring, as might already know, toy soldiers. Gameplay is quite simple, but this simplicity somehow makes this game even more fun. Basically, It's just simple toy-styled game where you can just play and relax in the end of the day. Of course, there are different gamemodes and maps, and, talking about maps, they are very well designed, colorful and full of decorations. Graphics is nice, however, there are some texture pop-ups, but they are not very annoying. Another good point is that game runs nice on my aged hardware (AMD Athlon II X4, 4gb ram, XFX Radeon HD 7750 (1gb vram)). There are some troubles with connecting to servers, but most of them are already fixed.
All in all, The Mean Greens is quite simple but solid game which can bring your childhood back to life. You should definately buy it when it's on sale.

Posted: March 18, 2020
Taking up the mantle of the Army Men series that's been dormant for 10+ years, The Mean Greens is a casual multiplayer third person shooter in which you play as a toy soldier fighting to secure victory for either the tan or green team. This take on toy soldiers is much more lighthearted than something like Sarge's Heroes on the Dreamcast as you'll be playing in recreations of everyday settings such as living rooms and kitchens while listening to some really charming, cheery music evocative of things like Toy Story play in the background. There are lots of well detailed maps to play on and fun spins on old game modes such as a Payload-esque mode where you escort a hamster in a ball into its cage while defending it from the enemy, or a full size foosball match where you must kick the ball into your opponents' goal. Everything looks great and it really gives this whimsical feeling that no other multiplayer shooter does.

However, there are some sort of strange design choices or afterthoughts that sort of bug me. As far as I'm aware there is no way to switch teams in the game which is killer for a small game like this you and your friends pick up to play together. Also, you start every game with all 5 weapons available to you as soon as you spawn and their ammo replenishes on a cooldown system. An interesting idea for sure, but just sort of strange. How many games let you start out with a sniper rifle, shotgun, rocket launcher, and flamethrower right from the get go? Not necessarily a negative, but it felt like there was nothing to find on the map, no weapons to get excited about or things to unlock. One thing that sort of bugged me was how your soldier just gets shot so unceremoniously. No reaction from him, no gun sway applied to you, and then you just die a quiet death. I guess they're toys so it makes sense but it just comes off feeling unpolished.

Overall for 5$ (Even as low as 99 cents on sale) it's a fun game to hop on with your friends from time to time. There are developers spending millions of dollars and years and years developing games like this so at its best it's a fun diversion to your main stable of games, but the aesthetics and music give a fun vibe that I haven't seen in a shooter like this in a while. Plus, how many shooters can you play giant foosball in while you kill your enemies?

Posted: February 11, 2019
While this game is by no means perfect and could use improvement, I feel like it does its job pretty well for what it is supposed to be as well as its price. Not only that, but I feel like playing this game as a group of friends makes the experience all the more entertaining when all of you are bored and just want some casual quick fun. Taking one quick look at it can easily remind one of Toy Story, Army Men and the Pixar-esque soundtrack just helps reinforce this feeling as well, certainly suggested for anyone looking for a game that's goofy, completely casual and not complex at all. It is visually creative, despite not being the first one at doing what it shows in the game, and the graphics mixed with the soundtrack, gameplay as well as the fact it is a third person shooter just makes it entertaining enough. If you manage to pick it up during the Steam sales and you have friends you could play it with, you and your friends could pick it up and play together; So far that's what I've done myself.

=On short=

Pros: Cheap, casual fun, potential to be replayed every now and then, interesting visuals and music choices, super fun with friends, a game that's both easy to pick up and enjoy, regular updates and devs that are so far open-minded about their game, regular sales for the game, plenty of potential, fun to explore and look at maps.

Cons: Needs an option to let you set your language manually in the options (some non-english speakers may prefer the original english text), a few translations of the game are not really correct, toxic community, cheaters appear every now and then (thankfully there's a votekick option, though, so not too bad)

Veredict: Recommended, it has a couple of issues, but I feel like it does plenty of things really well as it stands.

Posted: September 8, 2016
After just 10minutes on this game, I am enjoying it so much I laugh and cannot stop!

Graphics: The graphics use the UE4 engine and are very pretty to look out, depending on the map! Maxed out it is super smooth, no glitches for me or a single bug. Very optimised and impressive for this little game.

Audio: The audio is deeply enjoyable too. It all depends on the map you are given! Example a Christmas map plays Christmas music.. A birthday map plays birthday music and the gun sounds do sound like toys. Very enjoyable soundtrack.

Controls: The controls are so simple to use, it makes the game super easy to pickup, play and go! Cannot complain!

Gameplay: The gameplay features a decent amount of style to the game, from pushing a cup off the edge, to lighing birthday candles, then some TDM modes, but to date of this review being wrote there is not much actual maps.. Also there are not many people actually play. The max I seen in a server was 6 people, some people kept joining but never stayed long.. The game needs more people, it needs more maps... I cannot complain about it, just the community needs to go and it needs more maps. Otherwise running around as a tiny army man is enjoyable in a huge scale world!

Would I recommend this game? Yes. It is cheap and deeply enjoyable multiplayer!

Posted: December 21, 2017
When you have devs who can only say 'we totally have stuff coming soon' and never deliver stuff that is needed...your game will die. This game is dead, look at the pro reviews, notice how they even say that? Take the hint, don't buy this dead fish.

First, go check The Mean Greens steam db stats. You can clearly see when this game was in the humble bundle and how quickly(literally, within a week) the players left. Also you can see when this game had 600ish players...that also mostly left within 1 week.

Now that you can see that people have played the game and left quickly, lets get into why:

Little to no customization - Nothing to customize...no kits to make...nothing to make you any different than everyone else that plays. You don't even get to pick which kind of army man you are.

Weapons - You are given all the weapons from the get-go, pretty sure there is still 6 weapons, that is it. Nothing to work towards, everyone else has the exact same few weapons, no customization for the weapons, no skins...literally...nothing.

No skill levels or rank difference - this is a multi-part issue. Some of it can't be solved because the devs refuse to add what was needed from day 1, some of it is because the lack of players. There is ZERO type of ranking, match-making(other than the pathetically poor, REALLY pathetically poor 'join a game') or any other type of placement. If you DO get into a game, good chance there will be a good player on 1 team just dominating. That is no fun, not even a little.

No bots - For a dead game(yes dead, taking 12 months to get above 70 players during PEAK time is dead, go ahead and check, Dec 26th 2016 was the last time it had 70+ players other than just the other day) this is the worst decision, ever. No idea why there was no bots added in from the get-go. IF you get into a game, chances are it won't be close to full, if you can even get into a game when people are on.

No single player - This game is F'ing dead, and yet the devs don't want to release any single player. So...YOU DON'T EVEN GET TO PLAY. Literally. If no one is on to match into a 2-3 player game with(yeah...no one to match so no one to fill games) then you don't play, simple as that. Do you really want to buy a game that you can't play?

Lackluster devs - This one is a tough one. The devs have made 2 new maps since I bought the game...yet that is it. They KNOW it is dead and they need to do something...for some reason why that something hasn't been bots, single player, customization or any type of MM. The only thing they can say is 'totes have stuff coming soon, can't say when and can't say what...but totally believe us, even though we haven't done anything that has been needed in over 12 months, but we totally will deliver this time.'. They have been told, several times, but A LOT OF PEOPLE WHO BOUGHT THE GAME, the issues and what is needed. It falls on deaf ears and is met with 'oh we totes will do that someday'.

All-in-all I can't recommend this game to others. Dead game(check steam stats, don't take my word for it, see the pathetic player # yourself) add in no single player and no bots...that right there means NO PLAYING THE GAME(how da ♥♥♥ do the devs not understand this but keep saying 'we totally wish we could fix the playerbase count). No customization and no type of bracket/skill level difference to put the newbs with the newbs and leave the pros to their own kind.

If the devs actually fix the issues with this game and quit releasing something 'just to look nice'(2 new maps...that is it, but no bots, no single player, no customization, no ranking...not a dang thing to actually fix the game. A polished dead fish, is still a dead fish) then I will change this review, until then...I can't(and no one should, take that into account when reading the pro-reviews, notice how half of them mention it is dead...but they thumbs up...yeah...buy a dead game...) recommend a dead game to anybody, it is skeezy and sleezy to do.

Posted: May 16, 2017
There’s a lot to be impressed by in The Mean Greens; Plastic Warfare. This thought began to occur to me when, after a good 15 to 20 minutes of waiting in the multiplayer lobby with no other players in sight, I began to realise how perfectly cheesy the music playing in the background was. It’s a delightful medley, one perfectly suited to taking pride of place in any respectable escalator, even down to the way it’s instantly forgettable from the moment you walk away. As time went by and many more minutes passed without a soul to be seen, it’s perhaps the only thing that kept me sane in those intensely dark moments of loneliness.

There were other things that did a great job at maintaining my sanity, however. The colourful menu screens were also helpful; the perfect tease for the vibrancy and craziness I could expect to be thrown into, once I’d mastered the arcane magic required to summon people at will to actually play the game with me. It gave me the same pleasure as knowing there’s a cake waiting in the fridge for when you arrive home from work; that anticipation of knowing that there is something to look forward to in your future. The fact that your journey home takes 15 years and the fridge is permanently locked kind of puts a dampener on proceedings, but hey… At least you know there is the tiniest possibility of getting cake. Or actual gameplay. This metaphor might be getting a little confusing.

The unpredictability present in The Mean Greens was another fun factor that kept me on my toes, and not knowing what would happen when I tried to search for a match proved to be gripping stuff. I could end up actually finding a match (unlikely), find myself in yet another lobby, or even be met with a loading screen that looks like it's loading into a match, only to freeze and crash back to the main menu at a moment's notice. It all proved to be incredibly uncertain and exciting, something that not many other games could offer in the same weird way. It wasn’t just trying to find a match which created such spontaneous moments, either. Imagine my surprise and delight when I tried to set the game to windowed mode, only for the screen resolution to completely mess up as a result. It created a situation where I was completely unable to click on anything, and was therefore required to force quit to desktop. I never knew what was around the next corner!

Persevere with this randomness for long enough, however, and with a little luck you might be placed into an actual match with a smattering of other desperate players – all of you finally free to play the game you’ve paid for. Unfortunately, this is where things kind of start to fall apart, because the gameplay just isn’t very fun. Take a good minute or so it to digest the poor quality soundtrack constantly on loop in the background, and then another minute to scour the map and find someone to shoot at, and you’ll soon realise that combat fails to provide any satisfaction.

For instance - shooting your gun doesn’t have any weight or sense of impact to it, making you feel as if you’re shooting marshmallows rather than bullets, and the simple task of knowing if you’re damaging someone or being damaged therefore becomes far more difficult than it has any right to be. Even getting a kill gives very little fanfare or rewards, therefore making all your efforts beforehand in taking the time to kill someone feel a little wasted. It’s disheartening, to say the least.

Each map being a different game mode is also a nice idea in theory, but for one reason or another simply doesn’t work when put into practice. There’s one mode that sees you capturing flags on a speeding toy train. This sounds exciting, but it fails to feel action packed in the slightest, due to the way every death puts you so far away from the action it can take upwards of a minute to actually get back to where you were. Another mode presents almost precisely the opposite problem; you’re meant to float on rubber ducks to capture flags, but considering you can pretty much see and snipe anywhere from the spawn area (Up to and including the other team’s spawn), there’s really no incentive to ever move from your starting position. On it goes, map after map, the sparse amount of players only making games drag out their limited welcome even further. It’s enough to make you long for the lobby screen again.

With all sincerity, however, let me close off this review with an observation; there’s nothing wrong with ambition. Indeed, the developers of The Mean Greens should be commended for taking on the challenge of a multiplayer only shooter, especially when you consider how saturated the market is with them. The problem comes in the fact that I simply can’t help but feel that there should have been a moment where a healthy dose of realism was infused into proceedings. There should have been a realisation that this game, even with all best wishes, could have ended up as the barren wasteland that is has turned out to be. Measures such as the inclusion of bots in the future may not save this game or even make it somewhat appealing again, but at least they would create something that's remotely playable playable. As it stands, however, this isn’t something that will keep you entertained.

Posted: December 12, 2015
I have to edit my review out of my respect for the developers, they turned a sour situation into a good one and did right by me.

I got this game at launch full price (I wanna say it was like, $20-25) and really enjoyed it despite the lack of polish and features, as well as the bugs and completely dead multiplayer. Understandably, seeing how the developers repeatedly failed to address the dead playerbase and breathe life into the game was really depressing, because then, as I still agree now, it has lots of potential.

Well, after leaving the game untouched for probably 2-3 years, I decided to give it a go again after I saw it was on sale on the home-page. Much to my surprise, the game has received some sorely needed polish and updates.

There are tons of new maps and game modes from the last time I played, the game plays buttery smooth, and best of all, the game has dedicated servers!

In the early days of this game's life cycle, the only way to play was to host your own server or join somebody elses-- so most of the time that meant you and a couple buddies would populate a server when you had time after work or on the weekends.

Now my biggest complaint has been addressed and while I am upset it took so long for it to happen, I will give credit to the dev team where it's due, because they've absolutely saved this game from certain doom.

This game is so much fun, especially in a 40 player match. This game has infinite replay value and as long as you have internet connection, you can play it to your heart's content.

Now, that being said, it's not perfect... controller support is native but not completely integrated in the game, and the weapon switching still feels too slow/broken to me. Playing with an Xbox controller for Windows feels a bit sluggish and unresponsive even with the sensitivity adjusted. I also think the M16 is a bit unfairly nerfed compared to the old game builds, and should have some add'l range especially considering it's quite literally hit or miss on the larger maps and there is no middle ground. I think the jump physics could use a hare of adjustment, or at least be adjustable on the server side. Having access to these sort of controls over the game as a host would be cool, maybe someday?

All in all, this is a completely fun and hilarious arena shooter that's 100% worth the price of admission!

Posted: 10 July, 2018
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
[REVIEW UPDATE 2019] (excuse my spelling and grammar & strap in for a long review)

One of, if not the only game i will leave a review for because i like it so much !
This game has continued to grow on me despite playing since release.

There has been LOTS of big updates which has really flushed out the game and gives you countless reasons to keep playing.

The games Player base has tripled maybe even quadrupled since release.
Now daily having 800/900 and even 1000+ players on at a time,
filling up most of the servers. which is great!

==== WHAT I LOVE ====

There are a lot of different people to socialise with, have fun, make friends or getting help.
One of the best updates, Community workshop integration.
Allows for some serious player customisation with the use of Custom player models. With literally THOUSANDS of player models uploaded by the player base, and even more daily.
You can look how you want, be whoever you want to be and stand out from the crowd!

====================

The development team are constantly working on the game and fixing any major issues ASAP.

The latest HUGE update (7.0.0)
Added a whole new redesigned Plaza area
( which is where you will spend a majority of your time)

It is much more compact now but still plenty of room, enough to spend a good few hours exploring everything.
It is filled to the brim so there is plenty to do there.

-

There are a boat load of stores to spend your hard earned units on.
for player customisation, condo furniture or player accessories(held objects)

SO where do you get units to buy everything?

Well pretty much every type of game/minigames gives you way to earn money and the better you are the more money you will make !

You have repeating minigames on a designated open platform that everyone can take part in and try win, such as target practice, snowball fights, balloon popping and more!

You also have other game area's in the plaza such as;

- bowling which can take 4 people and integrated media players so you can bowl with your friends and listen to some music!

- laser tag, like the name suggests it's just like real life laser tag, two teams fight against one another in some laser warfare!

- casino where you can try your luck with already earned units and safely gamble for fun, with slot machines, poker, blackjack, spin to win wheels, the casino is a fun place to try get lucky

- arcade, currently a work in progress but will soon be released featuring classing arcade games like ski-ball, basketball games, whack a mole, air hockey and much much more

- trivia, again like the name suggests you can take part in trivia quizzes alone or with others to test your knowledge and earn money!

- typing derby, the last thing in the plaza specifically that you can earn money with, this is all about typing accurately but as fast as you can. the better you are the more units you will earn as always.

~
there are also a few more things to do like the Theatre to watch video's with large groups of people,

a rideable roller coaster & ferris wheel

burried tresure events and photoshoot spots to find around the map

*takes a breath*

==============================
7.0.0 Continued

As i said, this was a HUGE update but the best so far.

Along with everything we have went over this update ALSO added almost 400 steam Achievements and in game experience(levels) for everything that you can do.

So there is literally hundreds of goals to set yourself, and a lot of these take some real skill and dedication.

The plaza its self, along with games inside the plaza and other minigames all have their own achievements and exp(levels)
which can unlock you unique-
cosmetics, held items, trophies, badges and furniture

There are a lot of these new unique items and they all take a long amount of time to unlock them.
These are my personal favourite additions and what i have been trying to unlock and collect as much as i can!

=== Lets wrap it up ===

There is plenty plenty more i could talk about but i will just glaze over the rest as this review is long enough.

There are condos(houses) you can decorate to your hearts desire

More flushed out games you can play-
Minigolf, Ball race, virus, zombie massacre, little crusaders, planet panic
(with more to come in the future such as racing these are some of the best ways to earn units/money)

====== WHAT I DON'T LIKE =======

Despite all there good there is some bad, not a lot but some
Mainly due to the HUGE new update which is to be expected
Remember this is an EARLY ACCESS game too.

1- there are some instances where you can crash or your game will freeze
2- media players can rarely be bugged and stop working
3- random texture issues which makes them lose resolution
4- not all achievements are currently working or possible

Apart from that there's not too much more issues, maybe slight bugs in games but nothing serious enough to mention.

===== FIN =====
In conclusion, I suggest every single person picks this game up!

the graphics are absolutely beautiful & its seriously a cheap price for the quality and dedication from the developers.

so so so worth the price!
as i said i have around 700± Hours played already and that will keep rising!

Please try this game out and you'll soon see what i mean!
it may not be for everyone but it is certainly perfect for almost everyone!

I know you'll have a blast and welcome to tower unite.

WARNING: long review, The first part explains what's in the game for those wondering. Skip to the bottom for the pros and cons. Also spoilers of what is in the game, for people who just like to explore blind.

Edit" I am updating this review since a lot of changes have been made.

Tower Unite is a fun online virtual world that is similar to Playstation Home and Pixeltail's formal game, Gmod Tower. The main features of Tower Unite are the Plaza, the Condos, and the Minigame hub.

The Plaza is the central area of Tower Unite. There are plenty of activities such as trivia, bowling and Laser Tag. It also has stores and a theater. The theater is a place where you can upload videos from youtube or your computer onto the big screen. Then people in the game can gather around and watch those videos. Another main draw of the plaza is the casino. In the casino, you have multiple options to blow your money or make big bucks. There is also fishing, rides, minigame events, etc.

is a place to make your own. You can change it from day to night, customize it with store-bought items or use the workshop to make or use community items. There are several different condo options such as an underwater condo, a highrise, a theater, etc.

are one of the biggest attractions in Tower Unite. There are a few games in the plaza, but the main games can be found from the start menu or the teleport. The game is a variation of the game Infected from the Call of Duty franchise. There is which is a competitive version of Gamecube's Super Monkey Ball. is a vs game between the Knights and a dragon. is a capture the flag-like game with guns. is like a top-down Left 4 Dead game where you team up and kill zombies. Last but not least, is exactly what it sounds like (and incredibly addicting.)

That's the basic of what's in the game. Now here are my personal pros and cons.

Posted: February 1, 2019
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Ok, where to begin

I LOVE this game. I love it with my heart. It's one of those games that I can't hate.
I've been playing since the Gmod Tower Lobby 1 days, and every day I boot up this game I ALWAYS have fun. And one of those reason, is the people who play it.
To the new players or the die hard fans, it's people who make Tower Unite. Without them, it would be an empty husk of a resort.

The Good
The game's got love, polish, and a loving dev team who've been stuck to this idea of a social video game hub for over a . Yeah, that long, and they've only got about 10+ people working on it. Considering the amount of polish this games got, thats amazing.

People say this game is dead or dead compared to Gmod Tower, and it really makes me sad when people bring this up in negative reviews, because yeah, it's not got a massive playerbase, but it's quality over quantity. The game isn't dead compared to Gmod Tower.
Fun fact - Gmod Tower's playerbase would range from 100-150, rarely to 150 on busy days. Tower Unite's playerbase ranges from 150+ on most days sometimes even thousands during updates, but often slightly lower during update droughts.

Another thing, update droughts. When there's large gaps between updates, people rush to scream , but the problem is, they most likely don't follow the Trello page [], or aren't in the Discord, which I can't blame them for, and I honestly wish that they were made more apparent to the community, perhaps even making community posts showing update progress.

The gameworlds are fun. Real fun. When people are playing it, which with such a small playerbase isn't too often, as a lot of the traffic is at minigolf, but when it does happen, when you get that rare game, its damn fun.

Microtransactions, specifically how there . In a market saturated with microtransactions and lootboxes, Tower Unite is a breath of fresh air. Fresh spring air. That good shiz.

I don't have a lot bad to say about the game, maybe it's my fanboy tunnel vision holding me back, maybe it's something else, but there's one thing about the game I despise.
The casino.
Anyone who's followed this game a while know just how the casino is. Don't get me wrong, it's well made. It's just bad for the . Personally I think it should be removed from the game entirely, especially when the release of Lobby 3 comes out, I have that large a burning hatred for it. It encourages anti-social activities in a game.

Communication is another problem. Don't get me wrong, the devs are very active in the community. Just not the steam community, only the discussions board, their forums [] and the Discord.
In the Discord, many people have got to chat to the devs, and they can all vouch for them being very swell people, myself included, but I feel the dev's need to think of the bigger picture, the 99 percent.

This game's great. Honestly, I've bought about 6 copies for different people, some of which I barely knew, that's how much I love this game and wan't to see it succeed. The game needs work, but what it needs far more is love. Everyones love.
I honestly doubt anyone will actually read this review, but if you do and don't own this game, change that. There's lots to look forward to.
At the time of making this review, Achievements (released), RC Vehicles (released), Lobby 3 (released) and Fishing (released) are going to be added to the game hopefully soon. Check the Trello, check the forums, check the Discord. This game's going places. Soon.

Dev's, keep it up.

Posted: February 11, 2018
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Remember Home for PS3? You probably don't. Few do. It was supposed to be an online HUB world where PS3 players could gather and socialize in "cyberspace", play mini-games such as pool, bowling, etc., own and furnish homes that people could visit - and ultimately launch PS3 games from and perhaps create squads/clans/etc. with which they can all jump into a game of Killzone or CoD or whatever from Home. It ultimate failed because Sony didn't really care much for executing the concepts.

Tower Unite was originally a Gmod module, which emulates much of what Home wanted to be - except you cannot launch Steam games or anything. You participate in a glorified chatroomp-world, where you can attend cinemas (where players que up YouTube videos of memes), play laser tag or bowling or other stuff, and que up for more meaty games such as balloon race (obstacle course of sorts), games of tag, mini-golf, etc.

With various activities, you can earn gold to buy new clothes or, more importantly, furniture for your homes.
This is all well and good and forms the frame work for some really cool stuff.

However, despite me rating the game positively, it's kind of a lackluster experience in the end. Much of it has to do with the community. You can furnish your house but there's not much incentive for people to visit, you really do need to make friends, which is hard because there's not much purpose for people to be hanging out in Tower Unite. The games also tend to be deserted, with mini-golf being the most frequented mode and everything else kind of starved for players.

Still, do yourself a favor and if you buy this game, go check out the homes some people build for themselves. It's absolutely insane how much time some dudes have got on their hands.

Overall: Worth buying to check out a cool idea but lacks a sense of purpose and robust player interest.

Posted: February 5, 2023
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
It's incredibly difficult for me to condense my experience with this game into a few paragraphs. I'll do my best.

According to this game's community, I am over 1000 years old. Someone in the plaza once had the bright idea to pretend it was my birthday, and it has NOT stopped since then. I have been wished a happy birthday so many times that the words "happy" and "birthday" no longer register in my brain as real English words. I am subjected to an endless aggressive stream of confetti guns and giant cakes. When I close my eyes, I see the sickening afterglow of cake candles and hear the faint discordant echoes of a swarm of low-polygon chef dogs singing a poorly synced rendition of Happy Birthday.

And I bloody love it.

You can play many parts of Tower Unite solo if that's your thing, but above all else this is a social game. There's one thing I can guarantee: if you're looking for friends, you will find it absolutely impossible to play this game without finding friends. Seriously - jump into a plaza, play a few rounds of minigolf or hop around the public condos and your Steam friends list will explode.

I've met the best, most bonkers, ridiculous, brilliant people playing this game, and I'll always be grateful for that.
