Posted: October 7, 2017
Clustertruck is a first-person view platformer with a very fun, yet simple objective, jump from truck to truck until you eventually reach the end of a level. Though lacking in a few features most FPV games usually have, this game is fun and will eventually enthrall you. Its graphics, controls, and appearance may initially appear to be bland and simplistic, but you'll eventually realize how a lot was done with so little.

CT is a game that's purely about gameplay, there's no story here at all and while that may dissuade some from playing this game, I had no problem with that at all. CT's control scheme is simple to the point where you won't be using more than 5 buttons in the whole game. It's possible to play (while using an xbox 360 controller) just using the left thumbstick and the A button, but some special abilities will eventually require the use of one or two more additional buttons.

As I previously mentioned, the main goal of this game is to advance through each of the 90 levels by jumping from truck to truck. The final level also features an unexpected "surprise" that isn't encountered elsewhere in the game. The levels are all separated into 9 unique worlds with their own separate environment specific traps, obstacles, and music to keep things fresh. (It's refreshing to play through a game where you aren't forced to listen to a limited number of tracks being endlessly repeated) An example of the levels/environments uniqueness would be the hell themed environment where you have to avoid lava, a forest environment with loads of green landscape, trees (they won't get in your way), and even a futuristic looking environment.

On the subject of the levels/environments, it's also worth mentioning that this game has holiday specific levels. These holiday specific levels are great, but I assume they only unlock during the time the holiday is celebrated. Being that it's October, I could only play through the Halloween levels, but I couldn't play through the Christmas levels. I wanted to play them almost immediately after having beaten the Halloween levels because it's more or less extra content and these holiday specific levels offered unique traps/obstacles.

I'd also like to mention that touching obstacles, traps, the ground, and generally anything other than the trucks will lead to an instant death. For that reason alone, you'll want to always jump onto the roof of each truck, it's usually the most secure way to get through a level. Should your jump not have been good enough, there's also the chance to grab onto the back of a truck. There are a few instances in which you can touch something else as a way to maneuver through the level, but this is usually a rare occurrence.

I've previously mentioned that this game is simplistic in more ways than one, but the game is designed in such a way that it'll eventually become much harder. The trucks will vary in speed/distance from each other, the different levels/environments will offer traps to make things more difficult, and the precision required to make even the simplest jump will at times lead to you having to replay through a level. The game's possibilities will also come off as a double-edged sword. You can stick to playing it safe through this game by jumping to nearby trucks, but you'll also have the possibility to skip over trucks by use of long distance jumping and if used correctly, you'll also be able to group together jumps so it feels like one giant interconnected, fluid motion. This in particular feels really cool to do and it'll allow you to get through the levels even faster.

For the most part, the levels can be beaten in one or two tries, but a few towards the middle/end of this game will require multiple attempts. It's usually the very specific levels/environments that require the most effort to get through. Even though you'll have to repeat these later levels multiple times, the respawns are almost instantaneous and the levels aren't too long (some levels can literally be beaten in a matter of seconds), it won't really bother you that much if/when you die a lot.

Honestly, there wasn't that much I didn't enjoy about this game. What I found to be bothersome didn't ruin the game at all, but I felt there were some things that I felt could've been different/improved upon to make this game even better than it is. One thing that's almost immediately noticed is that your character (if you can even call it that) in this game is more or less an invisible entity. Arms, legs, or even a combination of both would've been useful. It's funny that you play as a shapeless figure, but sometimes your movements felt stiff. As a result of lacking any discernible shape, landing precise/correctly timed jumps can be a bit troublesome when you first start playing through this game.

Even after I got the hang of this game, landing jumps were still a hassle to deal with, especially when I had to land on a moving truck from a long distance. In this game jumps have to be measured by sight, but things would've been much easier if you had a cross hairs or something to aim your jumps with. A special ability eventually gives you something like cross hairs, but it's not available by default and you have to accumulate points before you're able to unlock it.

The game has quite a few special abilities that you can choose to use/unlock, but you can only equip two at the same time. A few of them are the ability to freeze time for a brief moment, a double jump, and a grappling hook. Honestly, some of the special abilities didn't feel quite special. A specific example would be how the double jump works in this game. Your default first jump is very high, but if you unlock and use the double jump, it's not as good as the initial jump, it'll more or less grant you a brief moment of hang time in the air. There's a very particular way to jump off of the back of a truck that'll allow you to jump really high, which is much more helpful than the double jump, but it's difficult to use. You can go through most of the game without having to use these special abilities and it won't horribly affect your enjoyment of this game. There will be some levels that'll require additional assistance in the form of the special abilities, but the number of them is very few.

Besides those problems, I also felt that some of the game's levels lacked direction. For the most part, the levels are linear and they'll always require you to go forward. You'll eventually reach a point where that isn't the case and you'll have to eventually turn backwards to advance or even descend to lower parts of the level. My problem with this is that it isn't easy to figure this out and it'll require a few deaths until you figure out what you need to do. Others may find this problematic because the game offers bonus points for beating a level in one attempt.

Despite having a fun main campaign that consists of 90 levels and additional holiday levels, CT is a short game. I didn't try to rush through the game and I still managed to beat it in three hours. Not only did it take me three hours, I was able to beat two thirds of the game in one night. Maybe it's because I found the game to be that entertaining, but my experience with this game went by too quickly. There are some gamers out there that will enjoy the game due to being able to quickly play through the game and move onto something else, but at the same time there'll be others out there that really like getting the most bang out of their buck.

To conclude, I highly enjoyed CT and I could see myself coming back at a later time to play the Christmas levels. CT is proof why many more people should pay more attention to indie gaming. It takes a simple formula, but still manages to create a fun and unique experience. I most definitely recommend this game.

Main Review

This is basically the floor is lava. You jump from truck to truck to reach the end goal. However, its not so simple! Terrible drivers, lasers, rockets, and many more obastacles try to stop your progress along the way! You earn style points and is the currency to buy ability points to make the game easier/interesting such as slow motion or double jump.

So, I played this in the beta or alpha... I had a blast and patiently waited for its release! Bought it out sale and I don't regret buying this game.

The level design is fantastic! There is also steam workshop so you can get creative with level creator! The game is short if you are just playing and unlocking abilities (aroud 4-5 hours I'd say.)

Online leader boards mean you can compete with the world or your friends to try and get the best score/speed. SO much replay value in this game!

Honestly, they took a basic concept and made it into a great game. I highly recommend you buy it or at least wait for a sale! 8/10

VERDICT:

I'd suggest getting this on sale, it's certainly not worth the asking price as it stands.

In Clustertruck, the player controls a character from a first-person perspective. They are set to jump onto a moving line of trucks, avoiding obstacles and truck pile-ups and crashes. The player is usually unable to touch anything other than trucks, and will otherwise fail their task of reaching the goal at the end of the level.

Posted: October 18, 2016
One of the best level-based platformers in awhile.

Pros:
-Hilarious. As soon as you turn on this game you're left laughing at how stupid these truck drivers are, and it only gets better when you see the waterfalls of trucks (truckerfalls?)
-Really fast pacing; even when you fail you restart immediately and the levels are fast and fun to try to get good times on. It's clear this game was created for those who like to do speedruns, as IIRC one of the game testers also did speedruns of it on his youtube channel
-Very creative level design as the game goes on, leading to "Oh ♥♥♥♥ I'm a God" moments when you succeed
-Challenging, but mostly fair
-Creative powerups that are fun to tinker with
-User-created levels add tons of replayability

Cons:
-It's not quite 100% clear where your feet are. Sometimes (level 9-2 comes to mind) it's not the easiest to know where I am going to land after a jump.
-Because of the speed, turning is not the easiest to figure out and sometimes you fail because you aren't sure where you're going to land until it's too late
-Some levels either require specific power-ups or absolutely Ninja like movement to beat (In World 7 I had to jump from a falling truck to another falling truck to beat it without a powerup, and that boiled down to good RNG)
-Music is okay, but nothing spectacular

Absolutely worth 15$. Most faults are minor or made up for by the rest of this fun, silly platformer.

Posted: September 28, 2016
So after 2 hours of playing the campaign - 100 levels. It was alot of fun.

Pros:
- Challenging and Addicting.
- Insane structured levels, ESPECIALLY THE SCI FI - World 7
- Perks and abilities (Speed trucks/ slow down time)
- Amazing boss battle
- Decent Graphics, at least it not for beefy computers.
- Workshop/Editor where you can make your own custom levels
- Gravity and other obstacles fly in your way and can change the pace of the game, quickly!

Cons:
-Too short campaign for a $15 game. Can be finished in 2-3 hours. Need more levels and bosses
-Only Three modes. Campaign and Custom Maps/Editor. Besides leaderboards, there's technically no multiplayer mode.
-Workshop levels don't look that good, the community needs time to develop more amazing levels.
-A few bugs, such as you cant view all the achievements from shift-tab or the game not starting up.

In conclusion, the game deserves a solid 8/10. The Devs did a good job on making a game extremely fun, but the fun lasts short. More levels and modes are needed for a $15 game. I do recommend getting this game but it would feel more worth it if it was on a sale.

Posted: May 17, 2017
TL;DR: If you are a veteran of air movement and a purist you will not have fun. Otherwise yeah this is a good game you should play it and jam to the music.

Let me start out by saying that I 100%'ed the game in 7.5 hours. My first playthrough was pure; meaning I beat every level without using any abilities and I chose to do this before I even knew there was an achievement for doing so.

I consider myself pretty good at going fast and flying through the air as I've spent hundreds of hours rocketjumping and surfing in TF2 and CSGO. So you would think this game was a perfect fit for me, and so did I until I played it.

So why the negative review? To be quite frank, it comes down to a couple simple principles that I believe in when it comes down to design.
1: Speed should be encouraged. (this is after all a game about going fast) In reality it is about going at whatever speed the game decides because going to fast will result in constantly running out of trucks to jump on making levels unbeatable.
2: The RNG is just painful. The trucks wildly swerve about and throw themselves off cliffs, and almost all of the stage hazards and mechanics are also entirely RNG based so there is very little actual use of skill and the game devolves into a waiting game for the planets to align and for a run to even be possible to complete.
3: The controls are weak and the physics are poor. Much of my experience in air control comes from the Source Engine, which for all its faults has incredibly tight and crisp control in the air. If I make a mistake in TF2 or CSGO it is my fault. This game however... oh boy. You run forward incredibly quickly, but side to side movement is almost nonexistent. Turning in the air is a nightmare and the sudden velocity increase when falling from any decent height results in you suddenly plummeting to the ground when you thought you might gracefully maneuver onto a truck.

So did I like anything about the game? The music for the most part is great. The last 3 worlds are a bit lacking and out of character but for the most part I enjoyed the music quite a bit. Now here's the real surprise coming from an elitist like myself: I actually quite like the abilities. They give interesting options for movement although some are vastly better than others and there are some silly combos. Once I finished the game I went back and actually used the abilities to have some fun and probably will continue to do so from time to time in the future.

This is getting lengthy so let's wrap it up. Would I recommend this game to someone who had interests similar to myself and would want to 100% the game if they played it? No. It is frustrating and stupid more than anything and I had to unlearn everything I previously knew about air control to work with the awful controls. Would I recommend this game to a more casual person who will use abilities and probably has no background in air movement like I do? Yes.

So yeah, my enjoyment was crushed by the way I chose to experience the game. If I could give the game a middle ground review I would because it does have merit for the casual fan, but for someone like myself this game was just horrendous to play through and I can't recommend it because of the issues I raised above.

Posted: June 24, 2022
Product received for free

Short version:

Pros:
+ Minimalistic art style is great
+ Cool soundtrack
+ Awesome gameplay
+ Upgrades, unlockables and extra levels

Cons:
- Some randomization can lead to frustration

"Long" version:
is a first-person platformer where you hop from truck to truck until you get to the finish line. It was developed by Landfall and published by tinyBuild.

What a great surprise this game was.
When I go for a game, I usually know what to expect – the genre, what type of gameplay it has, etc. Not here, not with .
I was bored, scrolling through my library, hoping to find something to play. I saw the cheeky title for the game but I could not really figure out what it was about.
When you first start out, you immediately get thrown into the action and I remember being super confused as to what was happening. That confusion only lasted a few seconds, however. After a few retries, I understood what I had to do and I was hooked.

Let me go into detail about a few things.

The game does not have a story mode.
It has 9 worlds with 10 levels each, 2 extra worlds celebrating Halloween and Christmas and custom maps.

Gameplay is great.
You must jump from truck to truck in order to get to the finish line – the first few levels are rather easy but the game gets increasingly crazier. It is so over the top that I found myself grinning like a lunatic a few times.
Trucks drive off edges, they are shot by huge ballista bolts and explode, they get warped by light beacons, you name it. While all of this is happening, you have to keep moving and cannot touch anything besides the trucks – environmental hazards kill you, walls and the ground do too.
The more you jump and “wall run” (or, in this case, “truck run”?) the fast you become and it is super satisfying to nail tricky jumps at top speed.
Each world features around 2 new mechanics that spice things up so does not get too repetitive.

The game is challenging but not blatantly hard.
You get scores based on your speed and how stylish your moves are. If you are having trouble with a level, most levels allow you to take you time and play it safe.
After finishing a level, you are awarded currency which can be used to unlock new abilities, like a double jump or a dash forward. These make the game much easier but you do not need to use them to complete levels and can even disable them from the start.
While a lot of levels left an impression on me, I must talk about one in particular. No spoilers but the final level is insane and goes all out. I loved it.

My biggest gripe is that levels tend to have tiny randomizations when it comes to truck placement. You should be fine memorizing most steps you need to finish on most maps but sometimes you will find trucks acting differently – it is especially evident towards the latter levels, where a lot of debris is thrown around and it randomizes everything. Totally not a deal-breaker but it did frustrate me a bit.

Graphically, looks amazing. The minimalistic art style really suits it and it does not distract you from the action.
Each world feels super distinct and exudes personality and charm.

The sound effects are rather basic but totally serviceable.
The soundtrack, however, is super high energy and hypes you up for some truck-surfing.

You are looking at around 6-8 hours’ worth of gameplay and a bunch more if you go for all DLC and try out a few custom maps.


It is an easy recommendation – it is fun, fast-paced and thrilling.

Final score: 8.5 out of 10.

If you enjoyed this review, please consider following my .

Posted: September 30, 2016
This is one of the most wildly original games I have seen in a long time.

Clustertruck's basic premise is this: you run and jump across the back of trucks that are speeding down various landscapes. Your objective is to get to the goal by any means necessary. But if you touch anything or bump anything that isn't a truck (well, almost anything), you fail and have to restart the level. It sounds hard, and it is hard, but it's also crazy fun. There's no feeling like being absolutely certain you're about to fail and then somehow turning it around into a victory.

To help matters, you earn points as you play and you can use them to buy abilities. These abilities range from things like double jump and slowing down time to making the game play like SUPERHOT. They're all interesting and offer ridiculous new ways to tackle levels.

Now some might be upset with the fact that you can pretty much see all the levels in just 2-3 hours, but the levels that are there are great. They start off fairly tame, easing you into the game and letting you get a handle on how it all works. But the game gradually ramps up the difficulty, adding new and crazier things as the levels go on. You get lasers, boulders, trucks falling from the sky, trucks being shot out of cannons at you, missile launching turrets, and more. And I found all the levels to be fun.

Well, except for the final level. I won't spoil what it is, but those who have gotten there will know what I'm talking about.

Here's the thing: Clustertruck is built around speed. It's all about getting things done as fast as you can, and the levels reflect that. Each one can usually be completed in 10-20 seconds at most. But then the final level comes along, and it forces you to play for at least two minutes. And if you slip up, make a mistake, and fail? Well you're back at the beginning. And it quickly gets frustrating. The concept is cool, and an interesting variation on the tradition levels, but in the end it just makes the tiny flaws in Clustertruck suddenly become all the more glaring. The momentum can be wonky as you jump from truck to truck. The inherent randomness in the game means that the trucks can act unpredictably. And if that happens at the wrong time, you die because of it. These flaws normally don't mean much because of how fast each level is, but the final level can become insanely frustrating as you continually retry it over and over just trying to get back to where you were.

Despite all that, Clustertruck is a great game and I highly recommend it. It's one of the most creative game ideas I've ever seen. And it's only the final level that annoyed me. The rest could be challenging, but they were still fun. That being said, if you don't think fifteen bucks is worth only a few hours of content, then I'd wait for a sale. Either way, it'll certainly be one of the most unique games you ever purchase.

EDIT: I just found out that the developers made the final level a little shorter to alleviate some of the frustration. Good on them. I'm glad they listen to feedback unlike some in the industry.

Posted: January 14, 2021
Clustertruck is a wacky parkour physics game where you jump across trucks. Since there's no story, we're jumping straight to graphics.

Graphics:

Clustertruck is a very simplistic looking game, but very easy on the eyes. Usually most levels won't be complex visually to allow you to completely focus on the platforming. Most worlds you visit are very distinct from one another and actually look very nice, my favorite one being the sci fi one, with buildings and roads covered in lights.

Apart from that the only other thing you're mostly gonna look at is the trucks, which are just plain white trucks which look the part. It's a very minimalistic game visually, but that's fine because it's all about the gameplay.

Audio:

Music is decent and actually fits the games fast pace really well. It's nice and easy on there considering all the other crazy going on like explosions, car crashes and other stuff going on at the same time. The audio overall is very par on course on what I expected, albeit a few of the tracks could have been more action packed,, but overall still very decent.

Gameplay:

This is the meat of the game and Clustertruck nails this without a doubt. The basic goal is to go from point A to B in the fastest time possible, you do this by platforming on trucks that are driving towards the finish line, but they won't stop for anything and will ram through anything in their way.

The first world starts off simple to allow you to understand the jumping mechanics and the fact you can slow down time so you can properly land your jumps, but quite soon the game ramps up in difficulty when new obstacles are introduced. Stuff like lasers, cannons and other trucks, will try to destroy the trucks you're standing on or sometimes there's going to be debris flying at you and once you land on the ground you die.

The main levels are actually incredibly fun and the right amount of challenge, as no matter how hard the game became I never felt frustrated. I felt the mechanics worked fine and often it was my mistakes that killed me. However I will say sometimes physics will mess up and the trucks will veer off and make it much difficult to make it to the end, it's a very rare thing to happen, but it does happen enough to make it annoying. Each world also adds unique threats that act as bonus obstacles to try and destroy you and it actually keeps the gameplay fresh, world to world.

Verdict:

Clustertruck is a great little game, that I had an absolute blast playing. It only took me 3 hours to finish all the worlds, but there's plenty of other stuff like an in game editor and replaying other levels that could extend your playtime, in case you want more after you're done with the main game. I definitely recommend checking this one out.

Final Rating:
8/10

Pros:
+ Incredibly addictive gameplay
+ Unique challenges to each world
+ Right amount of challenge

Cons:

Posted: October 27, 2016
Product received for free

Clustertruck is a parkour speedrun truck-jumping game with a floor-is-lava twist. Is it worth buying?

For the picture-filled review, read it on the Games Worth Buying website - http://www.gamesworthbuying.com/2016/10/26/clustertruck-review/

If you are lucky enough to have had an even remotely decent childhood, chances are you have played a game where you act as though the floor is a fiery pit of lava. The rules of the game are simple, and all kids, no matter their race, colour or creed, have an innate, almost spooky inner knowing of them. You jump from one piece of furniture to the next, and you must not, under any circumstance, fall off, or else you will end up on the carpet in the deadly lava, resulting in your ultimate doom.

Clustertruck is similar in a way, with the basic fundamentals much like that of the old game that those of us not living under a rock know and used to love, except the pieces of furniture are moving and they are now trucks driven by drunks. Of course they are.

The entire game is pretty much that. You jump from truck to truck in minimalist graphics and well designed but sometimes – actually a lot of the time – annoying but great levels. It’s fun.

Chaos and destruction, including trucks driving off the edge to their impending explosive deaths, are a normal sight in Clustertruck, and it’s absolutely spectacular. It’s not so spectacular when you’re relying on that truck making it to the end of the level, though, which happens quite often. Almost all of the game consists of evading obstacles that can make the truck below you blow up, for instance swinging hammers, flamethrowers, walls, bits of the floor getting pushed up, and other trucks.

The game movement is slippery and somewhat difficult to get used to. After over seven hours of playing the game, I’m still struggling. That’s not a downside though, it adds to the challenge and makes it more fun. There are also a few movement-based bugs (are they bugs? I can’t figure out whether they were intended), such as launching myself up off the tailgate of a truck and flinging across the levels, and using the grapple hook ability to just ignore the map and Spiderman over completely.

Spanned across nine worlds, the 90 official Clustertruck levels are a great enjoyment, especially when you’ve just aced one in one try. There is also Steam Workshop support, so as well as the official levels, you can subscribe to and download a bunch more, hand crafted by the community in the game’s level editor. Although there are only a few very good Workshop levels, it’s still pretty cool to see what creations others have brewed up.

It took me around four hours to finish all the Landfall-made levels, so I decided to try the community levels and that took up another few hours of my time.

At first glance, Clustertruck’s custom level editor looked complicated to me, but shortly after digging in and building a couple of terrible levels, I soon got the hang of it. Placing buildings, roads and dangerous traps and making trucks drive in their own paths is reasonably easy, and if I got stuck, I’d just use the relatively long and detailed help sheet.

Clustertruck has an unlockable ability system where you can use in-game points that you accumulate through playing and completing the game’s levels to purchase numerous different powers including jetpacks, slow motion, grapple hooks and levitation. This, for me, takes away the feel of the game I had hoped for, and although it’s another feature (and features are good), I would have suggested that they just scratch that idea and build the game with the initial raw, truck jumping feeling.

The game’s AI paths vary ever so slightly from game to game; sometimes you can ride a truck to the end, sometimes it’ll veer off causing a major crash, resulting in the deaths of both you and fifteen truck drivers. This is great as it adds a certain amount of randomness, but it can also be level-breaking, like all of the trucks crashing, leaving the level impossible to finish.

When I first heard about Clustertruck I was skeptical, and to a degree I still am, because I think the concept is great, but I’m not quite sure whether it’s big enough to deserve its own title.

I’m torn this time because of that. I would recommend buying it when it goes on special, but if you think you would enjoy it and wish to purchase it at its current US$15, then there’s nothing inside me that would try to convince you otherwise. It’s considerably short but it’s still brilliant fun, and for that reason I will have to say:

Posted: April 25, 2017
Clustertruck is basically what happens if someone takes the whole "look how goofy and kinda broken Unity's physics engine is!" genre, epitomized by Goat Simulator, and makes an actual game out of it. The result is a speedrun-focused platformer, with the platforms being trucks that obey wacky Unity physics.

The result is expectedly fun, and most of the levels are designed well enough that they don't become frustrating even when you keep dying to the slippery controls or unusual physics, but it shares a downside with many games like this where it's quite easy to get stuck on a single level and not really have fun any more, because the game is completely linear and all levels must be successfully completed in order to unlock the next.

(The "final boss" stage gets a special mention, however - Clustertruck mostly manages to not be frustrating despite combining slippery controls, wacky physics, and major errors requiring you to restart the run by having most stages be short. The final stage is... not, and suffers a lot from that.)

I would recommend Clustertruck to most people who enjoy action games and especially to people who have subjected themselves to Unity's default physics before, as seeing it become an actual game rather than just Goat Simulator was extra funny for me. It's not a terribly long game unless you want to replay stages to improve your score, but given its single gimmick, that's to be expected.

Posted: January 24, 2017
Gameplay
Simple and exciting. Clustertruck is a first person game where you have a handful of useful abilities that aid you in your mission of utmost importance, passing through a goal line on the other end of a runway. Consisting of nine worlds, each with ten levels, you must start at Point A and work your way to Point B by leaping from trucks and utilizing abilities like slowing time, double jump, grappling hooks, and a plethora of other odd and nonsensical ways. Despite having superpowers and legs that are likely made of muscular jello, touching the ground or colliding with any object results in immediate death.

Physics are wonderfully exaggerated and controls are easy to work with as you can guide yourself in outlandish directions between or during jumps, while also maintaining a natural balance on lopsided trucks. Propel yourself from the rear of trucks or wall-run alongside them for increased speed. Resourceful superpowered truck jumping man gives Titanfall soldiers and Faith from Mirror’s Edge a run for their money in terms of cat-like reflexes and agility.

Each world offers a different atmosphere, new challenges and hurdles (sometimes literally), and new and exciting ways to mash yourself against a wall, or house, or giant stone cross falling from the stratosphere on the fiery plains of hell. The base game is shorter than I originally expected and once you get the hang of it, most levels can be beaten rather easily.

Clustertruck also offers an Editor Mode that allows you to build your own maps and fine tune inner workings of trucks, objects and physics related aspects.

Sound
Delightful. Clustertruck offers a wonderful soundtrack of upbeat techno tunes that are prevalent through the entire experience and couldn’t be more fitting to the game itself. After playing, download the soundtrack on Spotify so that while you’re inducing panic on I-76 you have something worthwhile to listen to, you reckless freak.

Graphics
On a scale from one to ten, one being a blank screen and ten being polygons, Clustertruck gets a ten out of ten. Really though, aside from shadows, textures, and anti-aliasing there isn’t much to be fiddled with, hopefully that message was clearly relayed through screenshots and videos. It’s emphasis is on gameplay and while the simple graphics, lighting, and visual effects are charming, they aren’t the focus nor should they be.

Replay Value
Missions provide slightly different approaches each restart as trucks don’t always move in a specific pattern, and a decent amount of abilities can offer new forms of playstyle. It’s arguably dependent on the player, if short yet challenging runs and climbing time trial leaderboards are your thing, you may get more hours out of it than most. If you’re like Buzz Lightyear and ‘not aiming for the truck’ is your style of play then I would argue that you’ll find Clustertruck dissatisfying sooner rather than later.

Wrapping Up
Shorter than expected for the price but excusable for the amount of fun it’s gameplay provides. An enjoyable experience that reveals more depth and difficulty as you progress. Clustertruck is a unique interpretation of “the floor is lava” that works with very little to produce a lot of fun.

Posted: December 8, 2021
It's a 3d platformer where you jump on trucks. But saying that is like saying Mario is a game where you jump on goombas.
Where Clustertruck really shines is how the platforming -feels-. Going fast feels great, and little tricks like jumping against the side or back of a truck to gain a huge horizontal/vertical speed boost feels sick to perform. You have plenty of abilities to allow for silly things like yeeting a truck you're on at high speeds, but you can finish each of the levels in the game without them, and blitzing through hard levels by sheer precision platforming alone feels excellent.

The game's content is a little slim - only 110 levels overall, which can easily be played through in a few hours or less if you're good - but what you get there is delightful. From truck cannons to jumping off a cascade of midair trucks to fighting Truck Satan, there's a surprisingly large amount of variety and no gimmick ever felt it overstayed its gimmick.

If you want more content, you can replay levels to aim to cut down your times (if you're the speedrunning sort, I imagine this game would be pretty fun for that) or download fanmade stuff from the workshop (though from the ones I played they don't really stray too much from the maingame levels.)

Also, the soundtrack slaps - a lot of fast-paced rock and techno to get your blood pumping.

Overall, it's a pretty great experience for what you get. Definitely worth it if you're looking for a quick, hype game.

Posted: November 8, 2016
Product received for free

Truck Trucks Truck Trucked Truck

[Disclaimer: I received a press copy of the game for review purposes, which does not reflect or modify my opinion of the final game.]

Trucks. Trucks. Trucks.

Pros:
Fun, polished platforming that’s simplistic but filled with unique abilities and twists in the level design.
A powerful level-editor that makes for a huge wealth of community levels.









So if you couldn’t tell by that opening, this game involves a lot of trucks. Clustertruck play on the entire gimmick that it’s a first-person platformer where the platforms are unpredictable, moving vehicles that you jump on top off, almost in Megaman X-like fashion. Clustertruck unfortunately takes awhile to prove itself as a game worth the pricetag, but if you’re willing to play beyond it’s campaign with it’s community levels and for chasing it’s time in the leaderboards, you'll find yourself in a experience that constantly changes up what is a simple formula.


The game is simple. Jump from truck to truck to the end of the level. There’s 89 campaign levels, plus a final boss fight. Each World and each level however, constantly shake up the mechanics, with tons of new gimmicks, traps, and more. You can also unlock unique and bizarre abilities, perform crazy stunts, and even play the game as if it was SUPERHOT.


This is the ingenuity of Clustertruck. The developers really know how to take a simple idea, and fully expand it to a project that does full justice to the idea. I found myself easily wanting to replay the levels again and even get to speedrunning it, so that really must say something about how it handles it’s small amount of content. For the most part, I enjoyed all of the levels with the exception of the Final Boss, which at launch was incredibly frustrating and a incredibly sour way to close the game’s set of levels.


In my opinion, Clustertruck suffers from a major design flaw, and that it's a platformer where your platforms are slow, unpredictable vehicles of chaos that will not catch up if you're ahead. It really means that there’s no sense of constant motion and flow, which kind of sucks. If you’re trying to speed ahead, the front car will always either get destroyed or there will be no additional platforms you can use to continue moving. You could build up a crazy combo of airtime but it will usually get interrupted because by then you’re already ahead of the entire pack of trucks.


It’s presentation is simplistic, with a enjoyable soundtrack and a lot of vibrant worlds to play through. The game’s titular trucks don’t change, but the world around it does, which slowly turn the levels from simple, small maps into a completely strange aesthetic covering the entire map. The game is also quite optimized as well, but it really could do without the annoying motion blur that comes with the “Bloom” option. It makes the game incredibly distracting and difficult to play.


If you’re left wanting more levels, you’re going to want to rely on the community for it’s wealth of content. The level editor is almost like fiddling with Unity’s intuitive Scene Builder, and it’s already been the result of fun and unique levels. Hopefully the community will keep at it for months to come, as it's one of the only ways the game will most likely continue with new content.


So overall, Clustertruck is a solid package that can be unappealing to those who are uninterested by the concept. But if you're willing to look past its flaws, it's a solid product that’ll last you a varying amount of platforming fun.

Posted: August 8, 2020
Clustertruck is a romp filled with nonstop mayhem, where your enjoyment of the game hinges on your ability to tolerate a whole lot of malarkey.

There is no plot to speak of in the game, but the game's central concept isn't hard to grasp. The floor is lava (metaphorically, of course, except for a few times where that's more literal), there are trucks (ergo, the game's name), and you must hop from the top of each truck in an effort to reach an end goal. It's simple, and it's chaos. See, ultimately, Clustertruck is a comedy game of sorts, where the manic scramble for the finish line is rendered into physical comedy by the fact that the trucks, the levels, and at one point the devil himself are all hellbent on stopping you. So, you scramble over trucks and around obstacles and pray, pray that the gods of probability are on your side.

See, tight controls and unlockable moves notwithstanding, there's a core tension at the heart of that's genuinely hard to look past. The game asks for perfection (going as far as to offer a bonus to the player should they beat a level in their first go) while falling back on a physics model that we can generously call "a bit too inclined towards chaos." And, of course, that's ignoring the handful of levels to trip you up. All too often, actually completing a level of the game requires foreknowledge of what the level holds, which can lead to what are a lot of deaths and retries. , by virtue of its central premise (physics + trucks + platforming = comedy), is difficult. And there are absolutely times where you have to put the game down out of sheer, agitated frustration.

Is that necessarily a bad thing though? Despite my own inability to beat the final level (which though I'm certain be done, I could not for the life of me tell you ), the game itself is remarkably enjoyable. Though not even remotely fair, it's got an arcade-y flow to it that's pretty engaging, with a slappin' soundtrack to boot. Plus, there's the level editor too, if that's your kinda jam. Make no mistake, is extremely hard, but that's not to say that it's not fun. Honestly, last level notwithstanding, it often feels like being part of an inside joke with the dev team. "Oh, my god, you're asking me to do what?" you might ask with a dumb grin as you hop between trucks falling off a cliff into an abyss of lasers. That's the vibe. It's a good vibe. Not a fair or reasonable vibe, but certainly a good time at least.

You will hate trucks for eternity after playing this game.

Posted: September 21, 2017
Leaping from the roof of one truck to another like I’m in a John Woo film as they speed wildly across terrain filled with terrors, traps, and pitfalls is a fantasy I didn’t know that I had. The sheer grandeur and scope of the whole thing is something special in itself, but even when (or if) you get over that, there’s still a pretty entertaining game left, even if it’s forcing you to participate in one of the least intuitive acts of modern gaming – first person platforming.

Trucks gon give it to ya

The first bits of Clustertruck challenge you by forcing you to execute difficult jumps and land on trucks that seem to be getting further apart. This is before you obtain enough of the point currency used to unlock any of the “abilities” like double jumps or slowing down time. That alone can be tough, but it is forgiving enough that it kept me motivated to continue playing. However, I eventually came to gauge my performance by the position that I had achieved on the global leaderboard. Rarely did I break even in to the top 20,000 for any particular level, but it really showed how creative people could get in completing even the simplest levels with such speed. As you progress in the game, you come to find levels that shy away from precision jumping and rely more on the players positioning themselves and having perfect timing to make their way to the goal. Later levels build on this in a logical way by combining both skilled jumping and impeccable timing to make for some unique challenges. The levels are split up in to nine worlds that each have different backgrounds and specific hazards, for instance “Laser World” has obstacles and hazards that predominantly feature lasers that will kill you instantly if touched. The worlds greatly diversify the types of levels you encounter and along with the natural progression of the game leave any given portion of the feeling much different from the rest, even though you will always be bounding across the same white trucks.


It’s apparently possible to complete Clustertruck without using any of the unlocked abilities, there’s even a leaderboard in each level for those that don’t use any, but I can’t imagine how it would be possible for some of them. Abilities like double jump or dash are extremely useful for making long gaps, and time slow or truck freeze can be indispensable when things are falling apart. There’s even the ability to throw down your own truck to land on/jump from. I think they even make the game more fun in many ways. Yet even without these, you can warp back to the start with a simple press of the R key on your keyboard and of course do the same fairly quickly after your inevitable death with the escape button. It works similarly to Super Meat Boy in that regard, except without a little video of all of your horrific deaths played after your success. This keeps the pace of the game up and limits the frustration you feel from some levels that have *especially* difficult designs.


Clustertruck’s difficulty can definitely be an issue and left me raging on some of the tougher levels. The concept of platforming in a first person 3D game is one that has always been notoriously rough and even with the extra maneuverability the character has, I would be mystified by times where I’d miss a landing or “collide” with part of the obstacles. In addition, it often seemed like I had either to execute some difficult tasks with perfection or make it to a point where I had a split second to figure out what to do, but it took me a dozen tries to figure out what was actually necessary. Some levels would take me well under a minute while others had me cycling through for 10 to 15 minutes just trying to figure out the solution and execute it properly. These issues threw a wrench into an otherwise well-paced game. The biggest problem I had was upon reaching the final level. I won’t spoil anything for you, but I can say that it changes up some of the core gameplay and is significantly longer than any other level, which means that those extremely common deaths can have you redoing a large portion of the level far too many times. I understand the need to make a final level stand out, but I found the design to be so disappointing I didn’t actually bother finishing it, which is a rare outcome for me.


At this point, you’re pretty regularly going to see Clustertruck’s $14.99 price discounted under $5 and for that price it’s well worth grabbing. It may not be that long of a game and it does pad the content with seemingly arbitrary difficulty at points, but the experience alone is worth $5. It is always wonderful to have a style of game that stands out from the crowd but is inherently simple in its design. Clustertruck delivers that while also give you an adrenaline rush to boot.

So if you see this game on sale for like 3-5 bucks, grab it, but don't pay full price as I think 15€ is a bit too much for this game.
Important for the achievements hunters out there, it is not possibly to get all achievements for some people (including me). There's an achievement for beating the game without abilities but it doesn't recognize the final level as played without ability, even if you did. I didn't buy any abilitys's, so I can't even use one, but I still didn't get the achievement. I'm not alone with this problem, so it might also affect you.
If you don't care for achievemnts, go for it, it's a nice game

Product received for free

This game has been on my wishlist for as far as I can remember, and while I have been keeping an eye out for it I never really felt the need to get the game, until recently when a friend of mine gifted it to me and realized that I should have gotten this game way sooner.

I grew up playing Valve's GoldSrc and Source games, so some of the movement mechanics felt pretty weird to me. Not that it's a bad thing of course, it has its own style and I've grown to very much like it as I've played the game more and more. It's just a small heads up for anyone who might or might not be in the same boat as me before getting the game. Very quickly you'll stop noticing that, and the game will feel very much natural.

As someone who doesn't even like platformers all that much to begin with, I was more than pleasantly surprised to find out how fun this game could actually be! I've only watched some gameplay footage of it, so I didn't expect to see anywhere near the amount of content it really has. You can tell that the luck factor is very much there, but there's still a ton of skill involved and it's a fun journey trying to master all the mechanics it has to offer.

Absolutely can't recommend this game enough, non-stop dopamine rushes guaranteed.

Clustertruck must be one of the most ridiculous "flow"-games I have ever played. It somehow reminded me a lot of surf-maps back from the golden Counter-Strike era.

Basically, you jump from truck to truck to reach your goal with completely ridiculous physics, absolutely insane level design and at neckbreaking speeds. It looks kind of boring, but playing this game has a unique kind of flow to it which only very few titles are capable of achieving. There's a solid amount of unlockable special abilities (both passive and active) to make your life easier, but it is also possible to finish the entire game with only basic jumping.

I was more than positively surprised by this and might have ended up playing this way longer than I possibly could have anticipated. On sale, it's a bargain and even the current asking price is actually quite fitting for the amount of content players are getting.

I'm pretty torn on this. When everything aligns just right in the game, and you have a really good run, it is incredibly fun and exhilarating. However I think that the game is missing just a little bit of polish on the jumping/movement mechanics before I would recommend it. There were just far too many times where I felt like I did everything right and had a spectacular run going, and somehow it just completely fails to do what I expected it to - making me smack the back/side of a track and fall down rather than doing a mantle/jump or wall-run - the character just slides off the truck awkwardly - or I feel like I just barely made a jump, but I die instead.


It's unfortunate, because there does seem to be a ton of potential here - my quick play session was a roller coaster of emotions, peaking back and forth between utter joy and complete frustration. In the end, it was just too frustrating, not because of some well designed difficulty, but a complete disconnect in the movement system between what I was attempting and how the physics of the game reacted.

Clustertruck is a fast paced action-platformer in which you need to navigate between the rooftops of trucks as chaos unfolds around you.

Pros:
-Really fun, and challenging at the same time. Trying to nail a landing or figuring out where you are as you are launched into the air is both exciting and tricky in this game.
-Simple graphics and the great soundtrack add the fast-paced extreme rush of the game as you jump from roof to roof.
-Main campaign is reasonably short, but there is a lot of community made maps which you can enjoy.
-It has Achievements.

Cons:
-Novelty value of the game dies down pretty quick. Only fun for a few hours at a time.

Overall this is great if you looking for something fun just to pass the time before doing something else. Worth a grab during a sale.
6/10

Posted: September 28, 2016
Many of the other negative reviews are spot on. This game has a good concept, but as others have said it is rather short. A friend and I had a lot of fun in the earlier levels. The game felt like deaths were your fault. As the game progressed, not even half way through mind you, A LOT of issue became the norm. Hit detection is abysmal. I consitantly would get fall through the hood of trucks when landing on them from a long fall (which many levels require to complete). You will find yourself having to restart regularly because something off screen "colllided" with you. This is made apparent when levels require you to move through very tight obsticles. This is terrible game design as you can not see yourself. You have not clue how big your hitbox is, and it is bigger than the viewport. The physics are also extremely buggy. As others have mentioned the controls will switch between being extremely tight, and being unacceptably loose, often times mid jump, making landing difficult. Jumping is also extremely varied, especially the second jump on a double jump. Sometimes jumps throw you almost straight forward, instead of up, Sometime the second jump is a large increase in height, other times you barley move at all. The way the player interacts with trucks is also buggy at best. The player can move along the side of and the back of the truck. Sometimes this will result in you being thrusted into the ground, perpendicular to your vector of motion. Other times you will rocket up the side of the truck, soaring into the air much much higher than you could ever jump (usually slinging you into a some obstacle). The trucks also seem to randomize their movements. I like this idea because you can replay levels with a different experience. This issue with its currrent implementation is that way too often all of the truck in front of you will simply drive off of the map, or create a blockade that trucks can not pass, making progress impossible. This last point would not be so bad if all of the other issues with the physics engine, collision, and inconsitent player controls also causing deaths. All of these thing create an experience that leaves you thinking, "Good thing I got lucky, and the game didn't screw me thank time." Which feels bad to say the least. The first 3 worlds have moments where beating a level feels like a skille victory, but they are also rather easy.

In short, with the only solid feeling levels being worlds 1-3, and the game being riddled with loss causing bugs, bad hit detection, and very inconsitent controls, this game feels pretty bad a lot of the time. It is not worth the price tag until they fix these issues. This is at the end of the day a sloppy platformer. Get it on sale (or donate to the humble bundle to get it) or don't get it at all till the issues are patched.

When my friends ask me what my favorite game of all time is they always expect me to say either one of the Witcher games, or Fallout, or any other AAA title, and they are always suprised when they get Garry's mod as the answer. I grew up on this game. Days home from school "sick" , rainy weekends, normal afternoons.. I was always here. It was my routine. My comfort. TTT, surf, sandbox, a little prop hunt now and then...

Some of the best moments of my life came from this game. I know, i know. Pathetic right? But i've made some of the most important friendships i've ever had on this game. It was my home for 5 years. and i regret nothing. This game may seem simple and maybe even a little stupid. But that's the point y'know? a simple thing for you and possibly some friends, new or old enjoy. I miss it. I miss the good times. Hopefully this review will make someone buy it, and then they'll learn what i've been talking about. It's an amazing thing.

Posted: November 28, 2021
Cheesecake recipe

Ingredients
Ingredient Checklist
Crust:
1 ½ cups graham cracker crumbs
¼ teaspoon ground cinnamon
⅓ cup unsalted butter or margarine, melted
FILLING:
4 (8 oz.) packages cream cheese, softened
1 ¼ cups sugar
½ cup sour cream
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
5 large eggs
TOPPING:
½ cup sour cream
2 teaspoons sugar

DirectionsInstructions Checklist
Step 1
Preheat oven to 475°F. Place a large pan filled with 1/2 inch water in oven.

Step 2
Make crust: Mix graham cracker crumbs and cinnamon; add butter or margarine. Press crust onto bottom and 2/3 of the way up a 9-inch springform pan lined with parchment. Wrap a large piece of foil around bottom of pan. Freeze until filling is prepared.

Step 3
Make filling: Use an electric mixer to mix cream cheese, sugar, sour cream and vanilla. Blend until smooth and creamy. Scrape down sides of bowl. Whisk eggs in a bowl; add to cream cheese mixture. Blend just until eggs are incorporated.

Step 4
Remove crust from freezer and pour in filling. Carefully place cheesecake into preheated water bath. Bake for 12 minutes; turn oven to 350°F and bake until top of cheesecake turns golden, 50 to 60 minutes. Remove cake to a wire rack to cool.

Step 5
Make topping: Combine sour cream and sugar; spread over cake. Cover and refrigerate at least 4 hours.

Posted: August 3, 2023
Peanut Butter Cookies

Ingredients
1 cup unsalted butter
1 cup crunchy peanut butter
1 cup white sugar
1 cup packed brown sugar
2 large eggs
2 ½ cups all-purpose flour
1 ½ teaspoons baking soda
1 teaspoon baking powder
½ teaspoon salt
Directions
Beat butter, peanut butter, white sugar, and brown sugar with an electric mixer in a large bowl until smooth; beat in eggs.
Sift flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt into a separate bowl; stir into butter mixture until dough is just combined. Chill cookie dough in the refrigerator for 1 hour.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Roll dough into 1-inch balls and place 2 inches apart onto ungreased baking sheets. Flatten each ball with a fork, making a crisscross pattern.
Bake in the preheated oven until edges are golden, about 10 minutes. Cool on the baking sheets briefly before removing to a wire rack to cool completely.

Posted: December 23, 2014
Do I really have to write this review? I am just one in thousands of people who wrote a positive reveiw for Garry's Mod. Chances are, this review will never convince someone to buy Garry's Mod. It'll just be lost in the 100,000 positive reviews out there. Well, here I go anyway.

"Where do I start?" This is the question asked by anyone playing Gmod for their first time. It's also my question that I ask about this review I am writing. Hmm...

_The gameplay...the gameplay...hmm... Well, there's singleplayer sandbox. You can do...uh, whatever you want really. Just addon a few addons, and you can be entertained for hours. Battle NPCs, make cool scenes for cool screenshots, explore maps, be a superhero (spiderman addon!), and much, much, much, much- you get my point, right? Almost all content is user-generated. Make your own content! Multiplayer. In Multiplayer Gmod you can roleplay. I'm talking normal RP (DarkRP), Military RP, Star Wars RP, etc, etc. In multiplayer Gmod, you can battle, prophunt (yay), hide 'n seek, and much, much, more.

_Graphics? I'll rate the graphics...drumroll please... 7/10. This game is and older game. Came out in 2006. I guess the graphics are good for 2006, and people enjoy the game and don't complain much about the graphics, but I'm not gonna lie, they are outdated and look old. It's not 2006 anymore.

_Hear the bullets flying. The zombies growling. The people chatting. The boxes jumping... The sound in this game is great! Every sound is loud and clear, and there are a varitey of sounds.

_Play this game. Play it again. Play it some more. Play some now, and play some later. Play it over and over. Play it as long as you want.

_My Personal opinion. Get this game. Now. Get Gmod on sale or not. I'm not gonna stop playing it for a while and I'm already at 50+ hours of playtime. I love this game! WAIT! Before you go and buy this, then you wonder why there are all the missing maps and errors in most games, get Counter Strike: Source, so ALL the textures are supported. You need it to play MOST multiplayer games.


Gameplay: 9/10
Graphics: 7/10
Story: N/A
Sound: 8/10
Replayability: 10/10

Overall 8.5

Even though, this is one positive review on Garry's Mod, out of the thousands of positive reviews that have been submitted Garry's Mod, I hope this one convinces you to buy... Gmod

-Star_Hawk_

review:
Posted: March 5, 2023
This game got me into PC gaming. I was around 10 years old when I saw people on youtube like Venturiantale and later VanossGaming play this. I watched people play this game for 2 years until finally I got my own laptop and after a while of figuring out how to install steam (and getting a virus in the process) I bought Garry's Mod
with a steam gift card I had asked for that Christmas. My dream had come true. I played sandbox, multiplayer servers, installed a couple mods, etc.
I was hooked for a couple months, sinking hours into the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you could do in this game. Every video game I had ever played up to this point had no freedom compared to this game. I would think about all the things I'd do in this game when I got home from school, then spend hours finding something else to do in it, falling into a rabbit hole of creativity in the process.
Slowly over time the feeling died down a bit. Like most source games, this game acted as a gateway into other games on steam. I installed TF2 because of Garry's Mod, and although I wouldn't seriously play tf2 for years after installing it, it became my most played video game of all time. I've been living in a cycle with this game for over 7 years. I'd be completely obsessed with Gmod for a month then for a couple months I'd rarely play. Then I'd be driven back to this game. Back to 500+ mods and no objective.
In my mind, this quality gives this game immortality. The sandbox which relies on people to keep building it further, unhindered by developer updates making mods obsolete or any expectation that the game has for you. This game changes constantly through modding, and the life and death of individual multiplayer servers and gamemodes, but it will never truly change. It wants nothing from you when you boot up the game. It has no qualms about your choices.
There is beauty in a game never changing. So many modern developers and customers want video games to be new and exciting, to such a degree that it becomes absolutely obnoxious. Such is the case with battlepasses and open beta titles which start out great then become so much better through constant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ updates that nobody even recognizes the title anymore and they refuse to play the game.
Garry's Mod will never change though, it will always be the same experience you had when you played the game 7 years ago. It won't let you down because its different than it was, it expects nothing of you when you return. The only thing that does change the experience is completely optional through the workshop.
I'm very happy to see Garry's Mod getting updates and bug fixes after all these years. It truly warms my heart that undoubtedly the greatest sandbox video game ever made is still being looked after. Just don't change the identity of this game or the innate experience of total freedom that this game provides.

TLDR

If you want a brilliant sandbox which will never let you down despite the state of modern gaming, buy this masterpiece.

Posted: September 28, 2022
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Posted: November 12, 2020
Garry's Mod is THE sandbox game of Steam. Really, what more can I say? After putting over 400 hours into it, including various gamemodes like TTT, which are incredibly fun when you have people to play with, I decided I'd finally make a review on it.

The Good:
- Absurdly good workshop and ridiculous modding capability. If you can think it, it's probably out there somewhere.
- Runs on just about any machine from 2005 and up. (Heavy mods and large maps can cause frame drops!)
- Likely the best platform for learning LUA coding for games.
- A good time-killer with friends.

The Bad:
- User guides are always filled with spam. Ignore these since they won't have any helpful advice. But really, what advice do we need for this game anymore?
- Loading times get long with lots of mods. You didn't think I'd at least name ONE minor problem, right? Part of the modding charm.

The Ugly:
- None that I can think of since I don't think this game actually has heavy-handed DRMs.

Like I mentioned before, Garry's Mod is the staple sandbox game of Steam. It belongs in anybody's library. It's cheap worth every penny, sale or not, and can provide anyone with literal infinite gameplay.
Thank you, Lord Gaben, for this Source Engine masterpiece. 10 out of 10.

Edit: I mentioned this game's insane moddability. Did I mention this game has mods? I'll mention that this game has a ton of mods.

Posted: February 25, 2021
This review is very short. Garry's Mod is not a game. It is a physics toy and sandbox style tool. In Gmod, you can reluctantly do whatever you want to.

You can: build things such as cars, buildings, bunkers,
airships, boats, or whatever you can think up, use weapons from other valve games, as well as add-on weapons created by other people, play with physics, kill NPCs with literally anything, drive a world of vehicles, paint, destroy stuff, spawn props, spawn ragdolls to pose and beat up, make a machinima for use on Youtube or other video websites, listen to music, and MUCH MUCH more.

There are addons to download, like maps and player models.

The maps can vary from Counter Strike to Team Fortress, Portal to Garry's Mod, and Day Of Defeat to Left 4 Dead. A very addicting toy from Team Garry.

Posted: December 2, 2023
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Posted: June 25, 2022
Being a single parent to my daughter—who is now 17—has been difficult for the past two years; whether it's supporting my daughter's cello lessons, or catching up with her usage of the Xbox Game Pass, I've tried. Finding ways to connect with her through hobbies most natural for her age has been a tough journey, for she is always out with friends now, or watching Disney+ in her room.

I let her customize my Steam profile for me—I asked for a goofy theme, and got something else instead, but as long as it makes her happy, so am I—and bought her Garry's Mod to see if I could perhaps play alongside her.

I recall all sorts of fun modes such as Prop Hunt back in my college days, groups of friends and online folks playing in-between study sessions. The highlights of those memories, those bits of enthusiasm, now I can share them with my Sarah. For the first time in the past five years, I was able to teach her a thing or two about a game! Come to think of it, this is the happiest I have ever seen her while being 'Player 2' for a change.

After spending countless hours playing this in the past, now I can make it easier for Sarah while she takes her Steam Deck whenever we go out camping at our local lake. If her mother hadn't passed away due to C-19, I know she would be here with us, proud to see our beloved daughter spend some time as an extroverted adolescent. Now Sarah's all into crazy mods and physics videos! Thank you for bringing new, geeky moments for me to share with my little girl!

Garry's Mod
Is not a game. It is a physics toy and sandbox style tool.
In Gmod, you can reluctantly do whatever you want to. You can: build things such as:
cars, buildings, bunkers, airships , boats , or whatever you can think up.
*Use weapons from other valve games, as well as add-on weapons created by other people.
Play with physics, kill NPCs with literally anything, drive a world of vehicles, paint, destroy stuff, spawn props, spawn ragdolls to pose and beat up, make a machinima for use on YouTube or other video websites, listen to music, and MUCH MUCH more.
There are addons to download, like maps and player models.

Posted: June 21, 2015
Garrys Mod

The most enjoyable and mod filled game on steam, Garrys Mod. Garrys Mod is an amazing game with a good amount of gamemodes and lovely servers. You may want to play Sandbox and smack around batman or play TTT and rage because you were rdmed.

Gameplay


Garrys mod does not have a specific type of gameplay ranging from Prop Hunt to Stop It Slender. However your gameplay can be significantly improved by using the steam workshop and adding items.

Mods

Garrys mod is a game focused upon the premise of random and fun addons. I personally enjoy being a watermelon and firing pizzas from a bazooka. Garrys mod has an amazing amount of mods including characters and items. This is a game focused around its modding community.


TTT is the most famous gamemode in Garrys Mod. The premise of the game is simple. At the begining you are assigned a role, you are either an innocent bystander, a detective, or a traitor. However do not worry if you are innocent for this is trouble in terrorist town meaning everybody had guns. The innocent and the detectives try to find out who the traitors are while the traitors try to kill them all off. The gamemode is fun and server usually will have cool player models or gun. The main downside with TTT is rdmer's. RDM stand for Random Death Match and an rdmer is someone who out of the blue will try to kill you. This means an inno/detective randomly kills an inno/detective or a traitor kills an traitor or an inno just randomly kills someone who is a T. This really spoil's the gamemode making it unenjoyable at times but usually admins or mods will be on to help you or they will have an option to directly report it to kick/ban the person.


Sandbox is where creativity and stupidity flourish. Sandbox is where you can get all your downloaded mods and just have fun. Sandbox is just fooling around and having fun. It is one of Garrys Mod most hilarious game modes (if you play with the right people).


So if your planning on playing Sandbox I would recommend playing singleplayer or creating a hamachi or another program to play with a select group of friends,

If you plan to play other gamemodes I suggest playing multiplayer and trying to find a nice server which you can enjoy.



+ fun alone or with friends
+ many gamemodes to enjoy
+ massive amount of creative and fun mods
+ overall great community
+ highly enjoyable


- rdmers
- will end up overloading computer with mods


Garrys Mod is a must buy with its countless possibilities. It may take you a while to find a nice server or the gamemode that is for you but when you find it good times will be waiting. The mods are just so amazing that I salute all the mod makers for their effort and allowing me to become a watermelon with a portal gun.

Posted: June 24, 2018
The sky is the limit, quite literally.

There are so many things you can do in this game, it makes some AAA games look small. When you buy Garry's Mod, you are really paying $10 for a blank canvas. It's up to you to find out what you want to do with it. You can mess around in the sandbox, making cities, waging wars, doing heists with friends, really there is no limit. If you don't like to use the sandbox mode, no worries. This canvas you bought can do so many other things. How about you play a game where you and many others work together to try to kill a small group of Traitors who are also trying to kill you? How about a game where you disguise as props and play a big game of hide and seek? Theres way more than just that, but I hope you get my point. Valve has given us this canvas where you can do whatever you want. The Steam workshop is your portal to all of the things you can get to shape your canvas and make your game how you want it to be. There really isn't much describing you can do with this game, because you, the player, make it what it is.

Posted: October 4, 2017
At first, I was going to make a review about garry's mod, and why I've found it unfun recently. But then I had a revalation. A eureka moment, of sorts. At first, I joined a MilitaryRp server, waited 10 minutes to be trained, then left.

It wasn't fun.

I got bored so I decided to join and troll a dark "rp" server (heavy quotes on rp) just to laugh at all the bad servers. I joined, picked the dog job the server had, walked up behind someone, and said as loudly as I could "OMAE WA MO SHINDERU" and started attacking him. This turned into 10 minutes of role-playing as a edgy anime character, ending with a final duel between me and the guy I tried to kill. He pulled out his ultimate werewolf form and defeated me.


It was fun.

This is what made me realize what garry's mod is, and why it's fun. Garry's mod isn't really a serious game. It's not meant to be taken seriously. I mean, look at the store pictures for it. Doesn't it just shout "serious military roleplay"? When you take garry's mod, and try to bring seriousness to it, it's hard. Take the MilitaryRp server, for example. Why did I even need to be trained? I've played those servers before, and they ALL make you go through training. All they teach you are meaningless boring stuff, like ranks, faces, and other things that you probably never use.

When you try to make this game a slog of rules, it just ruins it.

This game shines when silly stuff happens, and is encouraged. You can do some weird stuff too.

Try it.

See what weird stuff you can come up with.

Never be serious.

From Olympus, to Lazarus, and Tamewater. Providing me friendships I wasn't able to enjoy after school by strict and afraid parents, up to the end of when I'm in college now. There were so many of them, all of us with bad computers and not enough money to either get the top games or the parts needed for them. We started as kids and teens with an idea and the game of imagination, and after seven years, I only regret that we got tired of it. Even me. Here's to Garry's Mod; the game isn't holding up anymore these days, many players are leaving for better games or college; reached about as high as it can go... But damn did it reach high. Thank you Gmod, and all the friends I made. It was so fun, and if I could go back, I'd take that trip again.
