review:
Posted: January 4, 2016
NOTE: THIS REVIEW IS OF THE EARLY ACCESS VERSION AND IS SUBJECT TO CHANGE AS VERSIONS ARE RELEASED.

(Written as of....Alpha V0.3.0. Can't wait for the update this friday!)

The game right now is fun but has issues. The gameplay is rather simple. One player is a baby who must die before time runs out (I think it's 4 minutes.) while the dad must keep him safe.

Now while the gameplay has evolved over the versions (Pills used to heal baby too and were infinite.) the game has some serious balance issues. I was able to play for about an hour as baby (I'd leave and make a new lobby each time so I'm always baby.) and was able to win every time, often before the first 30 seconds. Forks spawn near the crib and you can easily jump up, grab it, and use it on an outlet to die instantanously. If a hammer is on the TV stand you can smash the coffee table and eat the glass to die quick too.

Daddy gameplay is fun too but it seems very easy to shut baby away from harm if you know where to look. (Put knives and forks on sofa, etc.)

The main ways to die as Baby are either electrocution by outlet or poisoning (Glass works the fastest.) drowning or cooking yourself in the oven takes too long and can be easily stopped by Daddy, which should be made faster.

The game also has technical flaws. Often the countdown before a match starts glitches and I have to alt F4, but it's rare. (I get it often enough I'll complain on the review though.)

The house has alot of rooms locked (WIP stuff not added yet.) so I can't say for the finished state yet. It might be more balanced and fair if more rooms are involved (there's literally no reason to go upstairs currently. Nothing dangerous spawns up there aside from power outlets you can use to zap yourself, and there's no falling damage. There is a funny dildo hidden in the bedroom though.) but it's hard to say. I know the next update adds ventilation shafts and more chores Daddy can do.

Speaking of the chores, they're not easy. Putting all toys away takes a good deal of time and by the time you're distracted doing that Baby often offs himself. Finding the smoke detector battery is iffy. Sometimes I swear it doesn't spawn at all, which might be a glitch. (Or maybe I'm not looking hard enough.) The next update adds more chores and daddy powers. Doing the chores gives you daddy powers like being able to see Baby through walls or see objects through walls, or be invisible to baby.

Now for the main question, is it worth the 5 dollars? Honestly, yes. The game has serious potential to be amazing with more features which are coming soon.


EDIT: It's been a long time since I came back, but here I am! This section was written after the outside update was released.

The game was expanded. Baby's crib was moved to the bedroom, then it was moved to the baby's room which was previously locked upstairs.

New rooms include a garage where you can blow yourself up with a car or set yourself on fire with gasoline, an office room upstairs, a shower upstairs with chemicals for baby to drink or burn in the shower, a laundry room with a washer and dryer for baby to die in, and an outside area with a pool.

They added weapons for the baby and daddy like a taser or a ball blaster, etc. You can now drop the toaster in water and get electrocuted, or blow up a fork in the microwave. New chores include cooking for the baby, washing him, etc.

Family Gathering mode was added, which allows 8 players. You now have achievements and can get hats for doing them.


However, the game is now out of early access. They added music which many people have complained about, but I actually like the music just fine.

I have one major issue. The game wasn't ready for release yet! With the newest update, the game is broken! After Baby kills himself, the game doesn't seem to recognize it. You're forced to spectate until time runs out, and Daddy basically wins by default after time runs out.

Also, some achievements are broken. I swear I've spent an entire match just playing with the piano and the achievement didn't pop.

Is the game still worth the money? Maybe. But the developer needs to get his act together and fix these bugs! How did this pass playtesting? The "Game doesn't recognize Baby dying." bug literally happens every time, and it breaks the game! it's been a few days (At least 3) and the developer didn't release a hotfix or anything!

It shouldn't have left early access yet.

Buy it if you want, but keep in mind in it's current state it still feels early access, and has game breaking bugs.

Posted: June 19, 2017
Several reasons why you should NOT buy this game

1 - Movement and controls are buggy/clunky
Trying to pick things up and manipulate your environment is very difficult. Items may drop out of your hands, slide around, or phase through surfaces. In a game that relies on your ability to pay attention and act quickly (especially for the dad players) it really hurts the game's playability.

2 - The game is heavily sided towards the baby
Some may say this point is subjective, but it's hard to prove otherwise.
*The baby has TONS of options to kill itself with. A baby can so very easily consume a toxic material (which the house is absolutely LITTERED with), burn itself, drown itself, and much much more!!!
*Sounds fun until you play as the dad, who can only lock cabinets, cover up outlets, and attempt to put toxic materials out of reach (which is downright impossible considering how many bottles of bleach, soap, and batteries are in every cabinet of the house).

3 - The game is DEAD
Even if the game was balanced and played well (which the other points prove it absolutely does not) There are no players playing this game. The makers of the game decided to create a bunch of weird game modes that sounded fun, but only split up the online lobbies further. Nowadays it'll probably take you roughly 30 minutes of waiting in matchmaking (don't even think about queuing up for baby, because everyone prefers it over the dad) or if you're lucky there's some random person who is sitting in an open online lobby.

Final verdict: Stay away from this game. It may seem inexpensive and funny, but I guarantee you'll get bored with it extremely fast. Don't waste your money.

Although there are a few strange-looking animations and limited exploration in the current early access build, this is pretty promising. I've never found any glitches, and the main mechanics for the game are already in place and hilarious.

The game is simple, one player is a suicidal baby, trying to find any means of ending its life. Where the other player is the panic-stricken dad trying to keep the baby safe until mum comes home.
Every time a round starts, object locations are randomized, allowing for some pretty good replay value. The baby can end its existence in a multitude of ways. E.g: Stick a fork in an outlet, drown itself in the sink or cook itself in the oven.
As the dad, you have the ability to take objects out of the baby's hands directly and put them on higher up counters out of its reach. You may also lock certain cabinets if you find a padlock, or turn off faucets.

At the moment, the game is relatively well balanced, although I feel like the dad might be a bit overpowered if the player chooses to follow the baby constantly.
Right now, you can complete a chore by throwing all of the baby's toys into the toybox, and then obtain a random powerup like the ability to see items through walls or be invisible to the baby.
This chore is completely optional though.
I feel like the chore(s) should be mandatory, so they must be complete as well as the baby survive until mum comes home. It might sound a bit tough for the Dad, but it's the only method I can think of to prevent the dad from just preying on the baby constantly. Besides, he can force pull objects out of the baby's hand. Perhaps the baby could respawn in a random spot instead? Those are just a few suggestions.

Overall, I can't wait until more death opportunities arrive, and more house rooms are created. It's a really funny base for a game, and genuinely well executed. (Perhaps also a game mode where the baby needs to run away from the dad, because it can be picked up and thrown into the toilet or oven?) Did I say that out loud?

Recommended!

Posted: October 31, 2017
Who's your Daddy: An Update History

I used to be able to say "Yeah, I can recommend this game, it's fun and can be made into a meme. The community is nice and the game is fun. The house isn't finished yet but in a few updates I'm sure it'll get better" and it did. More rooms got added, more ways for the baby to die and more ways for the dad to counter these new tactics.

But with time, comes decay. Youtubers hyped up this game and their viewers flocked to the game to play it and do what their favorite youtubers did. Then the youtubers left to play other games, then the followers ditched the game to follow like sheep. The developers tried their best to keep the users. They added a new soundtrack, but the radio in game played music as well. That made some people begin to leave, the devs didn't want this, so they added more.

They added the pool, which was a faster way to die the bathtub way. So the bathtub method was useless, the pool was quieter and didn't require setups, the baby could get under the car and prevent the dad from getting to him. So the devs made it so the dad could crawl, this made the dad clip through walls. Players wanted to pick the baby up, so the devs added the baby grabber claw, but players didn't like that it could break, so the devs made it so the dad could pick up the baby when they had depleted stamina. This broke for babies who were always sprinting.

By this time, the Youtubers left, and so did 80% of the playerbase. But the newly named "Evil Tortilla Games" company was not ready to give up yet, so they added a baby car and pool cover. There was already a pool counter but the devs didn't seem to care. They just added new gamemodes, some of which are broken. But those are for another review to cover. They added hats at some time, but some of them didn't unlock, others did, but the players didn't get the steam achievement.

As one final resort, "Evil Tortilla Games" implimented single player challenges, but this wasn't what the players who asked for singleplayer wanted. Some wanted a version where the dad was an AI or the baby was an AI. But in the challenge "Race Dad to the Bedroom" The dad doesn't even move, and in the dad mssion "Get all the babies out of the Pool" the babies are constantly moving. These actions did not please players...

Now we're at today, October 30th, 2017. The developers recently released an update that upset players. Bug fixes? Optimization? Nope, Just a "new" halloween map. People are still talking about fixing the game in the comments. Evil Tortilla Games has given up on this game, If you haven't noticed they released "Zooicide" their new "Meme" game. Youtubers have played it already. It seems like that game is losing it's charm already, heh. How the cycle continues.

Posted: May 14, 2016
I'd have to say, if you're interested in this, do not buy it, at least not now.

Bought it a while ago for my son and I to play, after he was watching a let's play of it. Seemed like a goofy game to mess around with.
It is, actually.
For maybe a round or two.
When we first got it, it had issues, but hey, it's early access, right? Well, as each update came out, it seemed like there were more and more issues. Weird lag, objects not working, getting stuck, random people joining our password protected custom game, etc.
Then, out of nowhere, it's 'released'. I'm sorry, but this game is NOT ready for release.
Not sure where to begin.
How about performance? Pretty abysmal. Can be running smooth, but then the framerate just plummets, mouse movement is all jerky, and it just feels rough.
Graphics-Quite poor. I'm not one to judge a game by it's graphics by any means, but overall, the game just looks bad. Looks like the devs just slapped it together and called it good. Character models are atrocious (hats and glasses are humorous though), textures are all over the place. Some look fine, but others don't make any sense. Go outside and look at the achievement room. The room is flat, but the 'bricks' taper off. Good example of it being slapped together.
Controls-Serviceable I suppose, although picking up items and using them is a major chore.
Balance-absolutely ridiculous. It's not a matter of who is going to win? The baby or the daddy? It's a matter of if the baby dies in one minute or two. The daddy has only a couple things he can do to stave off the baby's death, but there are sooo many options for the baby to off itself, it quickly turns into a race to see just how fast the baby can kill itself, especially with warping through vents.
Idea/concept-brilliant. Actually a really good idea for a game, but there are so many issues right now, I'd stay away. We'll probably keep playing it off and on for a while to see if things improve, but it's quickly becoming tiresome.
One thing I forgot about, and just remembered. The soundtrack. One of the most annoying and grating soundtracks I've ever heard.

f you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an bomb quiche recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 1 Pie Crust - "refrigerated- softened as directed on lable"
2. 1 cup half-and-half or milk
3. 4 eggs, slightly beaten
4. 1/4 teaspoon salt
5. 1/4 teaspoon pepper
6. 8 slices bacon, crisply cooked crumbled(3/4 cup).. make more you heathens
7. 1 cup shredded Swiss or Cheddar cheese 4 oz
1/4 cup grated Parmesan Cheese
8. Tablespoon chopped shallots, if desired

Directions:

1. Heat oven to 350°F. Place pie crust in 9-inch glass pie plate as directed on box for One-Crust Filled Pie.
2. In medium bowl, mix half-and-half, eggs, salt and pepper; set aside. Layer bacon, cheeses and onion in crust-lined plate. Pour egg mixture over top.
3. Bake 40 to 50 minutes or until knife inserted in center comes out clean. Let stand 5 minutes; cut into wedges.

*************** TIPS ****************

1. One frozen Pillsbury™ Deep Dish Pie Crust may be substituted for the refrigerated Pie Crust in this recipe. Place cookie sheet on oven rack. Heat oven as directed. Prepare filling and follow directions on package for One-Crust Filled Pie.

2. Sprinkle chopped green onion on top of baked quiche for a pop of color and flavor.

3. Air fry that bacon for optimal crisps.

4. Use a wire whisk to beat the half-and-half with the eggs, after seasoning them. A whisk is the most efficient way to really blend them together, creating a custard mixture that will meld well with the rest of the ingredients.

Posted: March 8, 2016
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
-Quick Review-
Who's Your Daddy is genre I'd like people to start using called "Creepy Simulator", on par with the games: "What's under your blanket !?" and "Shower With Your Dad".
If we're speaking specifically, it's a competitive, co-op game between a baby and father, the person controlling the baby is trying to kill himself or herself, while the father frantically runs around trying to keep the baby from death's grip.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Story There's not much to say about the game's story, however *I* have a number of stories from playing the game. I purchased this game to play it with my younger brother, and then laughed until I cried at all the hilarious events that took place.
To all of my friends who sent me messages saying "oh god, that game"; instead of judging me from afar, you should have joined my twitch stream and laughed along with me .
From setting myself on fire as a baby, predicting what my brother was going to do, and hearing his frustrated screams of "don't give me those pills! Keep that apple away from me!", it really was a hilarious stream.

I'm not going to spoiler tag my whole review, but lets say this game is way more fun when you don't know very much about the mechanics of the game. Grab two copies of this game, grab a friend, skype, and enjoy. Read on if you don't mind having basic gameplay spoiled.

I have already explained the gist of the game. If you're the father: you try to keep your child alive by moving dangerous objects away, and giving pills and fruit to your child to keep them healthy until mom gets home! As the baby your objective is to get yourself killed in one of the very many MANY ways of doing so, drowning, freezing, burning, poison, power outlets, and more that are still being added (03/07/16) as the game updates.

Some may criticize the game on it's graphics, or glitches that may happen while playing. Naturally in most games this would be a negative quality, but there's a hilarious novelty about the game, and it's not over priced for the entertainment.

There are no steam achievements at this time. This is a game which would be fun to have "dumb achievements", just so achievers can grab an easy 100%, since the game at this time is purely 1v1 co-op, an achievement for each death would be very easy to teach people the various ways you can die, or power ups you can unlock as the father.

Who's Your Daddy is priced at $4.99, now I normally grade games by 1 dollar for every hour played, but for this game I make an exception. The quality of laughter and company of my brother over ruled the standard rule.
At this time I've spent two and a half hours playing the game. I have no doubt as the game is updated we will continue to play it occasionally, so even in price and hour the game will probably make it!

There's not much else to say about the game, the developer has already made a great game, and we can all look forward to seeing what other madness will be added to the game, and hopefully the developers don't get picked up by child support services before the game comes out of Early Access.
I recommend this game for anyone to play with another friend (if you have a funny friend, it's even better), if you're generally a solo gamer this is a skip for you.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Posted: January 23, 2016
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
At a glance, Who's Your Daddy might look like just another one of those garbage games that somehow passed through greenlight - but unlike most of those games, Who's Your Daddy is actually surprisingly fun. The game's concept is fairly simple, in which one player plays as a baby and tries to kill themself using a variety of household objects, while the other player controls a dad trying to protect the baby, providing a shockingly realistic portrayal of actual parenthood. There are a variety of ways for the baby to kill themself, like eating batteries or dropping a toaster in the sink, giving the game replayability by challenging yourself to kill yourself in creative ways. The dad gets various objects to try to protect the baby, like a tool to lock drawers and a baby grabbing handle to temporarily pick up the baby, and can also do chores around the house to get powerups like Dad Bod, which allows you to carry heavier things. The game is only in alpha right now, but the developer seems to be fairly diligent in adding regular updates that add new features and ways to die, and at five dollars per copy I think it's a pretty good game to get together with a friend and have a few hours of laughter.

Posted: December 24, 2015
What started out as a joke on Funnyjunk.com from a despised, sad cat man, turned into the family friendly game of the year. "Who's Your Daddy" is the sleeper hit of 2015, the brain child of Thehumanidiot, turning decades of volunteer dad work into a full hands on simulated experience.

The goal of 'Who's your daddy' is to make sure that your spawnling doesn't remove himself from the gene pool too quickly (High School is the most appropriate time for this.) You do this by making sure that the baby can't eat dozens of batteries, stick forks into electrical sockets, and drinking blue juice under the sink. Alternatively, if you are playing as the baby character, it's your job to be as much of a little ♥♥♥♥ as humanly possible. This is more choice than a Telltale video game.

The graphics are nothing to write home about. The dad is a heteronormative cis white male, with the baby able to change its appearance based on what actions it has undertaken. It's possible to turn the baby into Shrek if you eat too much blue juice, for example.

The soundtrack consists of one song that constantly loops. It is actually the newest hit single by young money rapper Drake, where he dances like a complete bozo on film. The song plays in the main menu, and from the in game radio, a statement of how every single song on the radio is exactly the same. Not only are we treated to a parent trainer, we also have a strong message about the media today.

All in all, 'Who's your Daddy' is an ideal game for anyone that wants to have a nice friendly game. The price is cheap, the graphics inducing nostalgia, and the gameplay is simple yet effective. I fully anticipate when we're treated with 'Who's your Daddy' at EVO 2016.

Posted: May 15, 2016
You know, this game is hilarious when it works - but it rarely does.

Controls are finicky (which is a huge problem as the daddy!) but are probably passable.

Incredibly easy to win as baby -- EXCEPT the win condition is bugged and only maybe one out of 10 wins as baby actually ends the game. Most of the time you are stuck waiting on the timer to say daddy wins.

You probably need 2+ parents just to win against a single baby if that baby is competent (which is a strange sentence to be typing, believe you me).

No access to menus of any sort in-game, incredibly limited information for daddy regarding baby unless you follow it like a hawk.

I CANNOT recommend this game in its current form, unless you don't mind a very experimental and incredibly unbalanced release. Not to mention the fact that it rarely works properly.

My hope is that the dev continues to be responsive and polishes this up - it has potential!

Posted: December 24, 2023
"Who's Your Daddy" is not just a game; it's a transformative experience that played a pivotal role in securing custody of my 8-year-old son during a tumultuous divorce. This seemingly whimsical game became the unexpected key to mending our relationship and, ultimately, influencing my son's choice to stay with me.

The game's premise, where one player takes on the role of a vigilant dad and the other a mischievous baby, provided a unique platform for us to reconnect. As we navigated through the virtual household, laughter and communication flowed freely, breaking down barriers that had built up during the divorce process. The cooperative nature of the game acted as a conduit for us to rebuild trust and understanding.

Our in-game adventures spilled over into real life, as "Who's Your Daddy" became a symbol of our shared experiences. The lessons learned in the game—teamwork, communication, and a healthy dose of humor—began shaping our interactions beyond the digital realm.

When it came time for custody decisions, my son's preference to stay with me was clear. The shared moments and newfound bond forged in "Who's Your Daddy" played a significant role in influencing his decision. The court recognized the positive impact the game had on our relationship, ultimately contributing to the successful custody arrangement in my favor.

In conclusion, "Who's Your Daddy" goes beyond mere entertainment—it's a catalyst for healing and familial rejuvenation. Its power to reconnect and build bridges is a testament to the impact video games can have on real-life relationships. If you're navigating the complexities of divorce and seeking a way to strengthen your bond with your child, "Who's Your Daddy" might just be the game-changer you need.

Posted: June 7, 2018
At a first glance I thought I would hate Human Fall Flat.
“Oh, this is another one of those wonky psychics ragdoll games that are obnoxiously hard to control,” I thought.
...
After playing it, I can now confidently say that my first impression was spot on. The only surprise was how much I enjoyed playing it.






I was honestly surprised at how much fun I had playing Human Fall Flat. I tend to avoid ragdoll/physics-y games - Getting Over It, for example, looks like an absolute nightmare to me - but I don’t regret playing Human Fall Flat at all.
Human Fall Flat is an absolute blast if you don’t take it too seriously or just like goofing around. I wouldn’t recommend it if you prefer serious games, as it’s very likely that you will just end up getting frustrated. The choice is entirely yours.

Posted: March 23, 2020
If you're up for hours of finger-cramping and sweaty hands (keyboard and mouse gameplay), this is a really great game to struggle through with friends or even strangers. The story levels/dream levels are extremely fun to play and I absolutely love how some of the achievements for the game are out of the way and some may be time-consuming. In addition to the dream levels, there are hundreds of workshop maps that will cater to your liking; parkour maps, puzzle maps (i.e. mazes, riddles, sudoku, puzzles, etc.), hide and seek maps, battle arenas (i.e. sword or lightsaber fighting), bunnyhopping maps, etc. Although, I do have to say that finding a really good map after playing all the most popular ones of all time is a bit like finding a needle in a haystack, but it's worth it.

The levels are meant for you to get from spawn to the exit and there are a couple of tutorial tools IN THE BEGINNING OF THE GAME to help you (dream level called "Mansion" and "Mountain"), so all those reviews about not knowing what to do in game, did not pay attention to the voice overs or the helpful hints.

If you play a lot of the workshop maps and can handle the language barrier, I do recommend downloading the Google Translate app on your phone to translate the foreign maps (mainly Chinese).

Cons:
1. There is camera bobbing, which can get pretty annoying, and the initial few hours of playing this game will give you a headache/motion sickness, so beware of that (my friends and I got used to it eventually).
2. At certain times of the day, if you're playing on a public lobby, either hosting or joining a random lobby, there will be a lot of people, especially children under the age of 15, who will troll you, so also be cautious of that.
3. Sometimes when you're hosting a lobby, some of the interactive parts of the workshop maps will show as moving for you, but not for the other people in your lobby. This is more of a Unity thing from the map's creator part; they may have forgotten to code some of the nodes or whatever for multiplayer version.
4. If you are hosting or joining an online multiplayer lobby, get used to the lag that follows whenever a new person joins the lobby or just the lag between you and the host. Lag happens, get used to it.

Lastly, I concocted a list of great maps to start off with a friend(s) on Reddit. Enjoy!

P.S. Feel free to add me on steam if you want to play with someone. I'll be glad to show you the ropes. If you actually want to find someone to play with at any given time or have questions regarding Unity, workshop building, or some technical stuff, join the official Human: Fall Flat Discord server for a quicker response.

Posted: November 13, 2020
Probably the most pure fun I had while playing a game. It's so simple at first, but keeps giving new tools to play with, and with friends it's completely chaotic in the most erractic way. It's really meant to be played with friends and that's when the game trully shine. This game is the biggest example about the expression to not judge a book by it's cover.
It does not look like much, but this game gives so much with it's extraordinary gameplay that it's hard to explain how fun it is. One of the very rare game that made me cried from laughing too hard.
Ps: I have no idea how fun this game is by playing it alone, never tried. But from what I experienced, interaction with other players is what makes it so damn funny.

Edit : oh wow I never expected so much positive reactions from my little review. I'll take the chance to add a few more useful informations.

- The gameplay seems very messy at first because it takes a bit of time to get used to it, but you can really be precise once you master it. LOTS of variety in the levels. Climbing, puzzles, jumping, breaking, driving, swiming.
- The music is surprisingly very good despite being a small game.
- You will not hear it a lot, but there is a narrator that is pretty good too in the early levels.
- You like achievements? There are many achievements to get by exploring the maps, some are quite challenging!
- Yes I plan to play it a lot more, I'm far from getting bored of it.

New edit : I played it more since last time and tried more things, so here are a few other things to expect as well :

- There are more mechanism that I was expecting. It seems like almost all base maps introduce new tools to play with. Different vehicles to control, from a small boat to giant liner, truck, crane etc.
- Example of new interaction : Electricity related puzzles.
- All levels can be completed differently. You can "cheese" them and it's fun to do as well as beating them like how it is intended.
- The game is regularly updated. Since I got the game, the game was updated several times with new waiting room and new levels, as well as some "official" skins.
- You can download a crazy amount of fan made maps. Some are almost as good as the base game, they are simply not featuring achievements. Some are completely bizzare and unique. Memorable exemple that I remember : A star wars arena with laser saber, and a level where you could watch some old real cartoons like we were in cinema. Completely unexpected.

Posted: January 1, 2018
Wow I'm quite impressed with Human: Fall Flat. I don't typically go for the wonky physics-based puzzle games, but there is a reason this is a top seller. It's very fun, and very well put together. It spoon feeds strategy to you until you have your bearings. It's never made me rage quit, and even got me to chuckle a few times. They are still pumping out content, and the multiplayer aspect is icing on the cake.

Essentially, you are controlling a dude and interact with the world by operating his left and right arm seperately. You are gonna want a controller for this. You can carry stuff around, and pull yourself up from ledges. It gets a little fancy, but not too fancy. The puzzles vary, but it's usually the put-the-box-on-the-button kind of deal.

Pros:
+Very polished and easy to play. The graphics are becoming more and more charming for me.
+It holds your hand until you get your bearings. They make the learning curve easy.
+The levels are interesting little stand-alone sandboxes that even have little secrets in store to reward those that want to stray from the main path.
+It's quite addicting because the puzzles are just challenging enough. No rage yet from me.
+There is a lot of content already, but more stuff is being added. Workshop support is being added, as well as all kinds of new skins.
+The music and lighting and ambience are very well done.
+Multiplayer is a blast.


-None that I can think of.

I think this is worth full price.

This game is truly amazing. At first, you spend a bit of time grasping the controls and marvelling at your ability to climb and move things. You could use your new buddy to try new ways of doing them, though. I'd say this game is worth whatever it's being sold at, because you can't put a pricetag on honest fun.

Posted: March 19, 2023
Human: Fall Flat is a delightful and quirky physics-based puzzle game that will have you laughing, scratching your head, and grinning from ear to ear. The game's charmingly simple graphics and hilarious physics engine combine to create a truly unique and entertaining experience.

As the player character, you control a floppy, malleable human who stumbles, falls, and flails their way through a series of physics-based puzzles. Whether you're swinging from grappling hooks, dragging boxes across precarious platforms, or using catapults to launch yourself across gaps, every moment is a hilarious and unpredictable adventure.

What makes Human: Fall Flat truly special, though, is its emphasis on creativity and experimentation. The game encourages players to try new things, to think outside the box, and to come up with their own solutions to each puzzle. There's no one "right" way to complete a level, and the freedom to explore and experiment is what makes the game so incredibly fun and engaging.

But what really sets Human: Fall Flat apart is its sense of humor. The game is full of slapstick moments, absurd situations, and tongue-in-cheek references to pop culture and other video games. From the various costumes you can dress your character in to the hilarious sound effects and dialogue, the game is a non-stop barrage of laughs and giggles.

Overall, Human: Fall Flat is a delightful and refreshing take on the physics-based puzzle game genre. Its charming graphics, hilarious physics engine, and emphasis on creativity and experimentation make it a must-play for anyone who loves a good laugh and a fun challenge.

Posted: September 1, 2017
Human: Fall Flat is one those hidden gems that manages to take you by surprise and offer you a really well thought-out experience. The game itself is visually simple in style, but fantastic in its presentation. There is a genuine adventure to find here and it can only be achieved if you continue playing it.

At first glance, it gives the impression for being a linear puzzle game. From the mechanics and controls to the environment - it does seem like just an ordinary game that relies on its experimental physics. Yet, there is a layer of wonder to it and shows us that a lot of love and care went into making it very fun for the player. Once you've progressed past the first couple of stages, get ready to discover huge areas to explore.

You are free to approach each stage however you please. Many of them encourage creativity since it offers you more than one way of completing an obstacle. Not to mention that every one of them is challenging enough to feel rewarding at the end, because there is a clear logic to their design. While the motions of the character may seem confusing at first, you will eventually learn how to control them and be more accurate with their actions.

The soundtrack is perfect, helping you relax as you try to figure out the puzzle in front of you, which fits in with the gentle nature of this game. And if you think the solo playthrough isn't pleasing, then you are in luck. With split-screen support you can invite a friend over and complete the game together, making the adventure a lot more hilarious. Go for it!

I'm definitely going to recommend Human: Fall Flat.

Posted: July 24, 2020
Follow my Curator page, Fruit N Doggie Reviews, so you can be updated whenever I post a new review.
Overall Rating - Average ★★★☆☆

First Impressions
Human Fall Flat (HFF) was a very popular game on YouTube. I saw people floundering and flopping around, seemingly struggling with the controls to make the doughy characters move the way they wanted. It's not a game I was going out of my way to get, but when it came up in a bundle, I went for it. I played HFF with a friend when they visited me, and though I wouldn't say it was a complete blast, it was more fun than I might have thought otherwise.


Gameplay
The best way I can describe HFF is to call it a platformer, with puzzles and obstacles you have to navigate around. In other games, you'd make use of a double-jump, and very quickly get past anything this game has to offer. However, the only things at your disposal are short jumps, pulling yourself up onto ledges, and interacting with levers, steering wheels, and other simple tools. You'll use these abilities, in spite of the clunky controls, in order to knock down barriers, open doors, and get to elevated areas, so you can progress to the next stage.


It'd be easy to dismiss the controls in this game as bad, but they actually work “well.” For instance, I usually found it easy to climb up ledges, as you lift your hands over your head, jump up so they'll latch onto the platform, and pull your view down so you pull yourself up. The bigger difficulty came from picking things up off the ground, as getting your hands at the right angle can be hard. Sloppy controls are part of the obstacle and fun of this game, although I'd be lying if I said they never frustrated me. Another big issue was with the camera, as your character will get in the way of seeing where his hands are located, or as you try to move an object into the right location.


At the beginning and end, you'll read a few messages from radios you pick up, but that's as far as the story goes. I think they could have added more here, and emphasized the humor of the game, but it's fine without a plot. As you come across different stages and situations, there are some background elements that hint at what's going on, but they're really just obstacles to overcome.


The visuals are pretty good. Objects that make up the environment and items you can interact with are three dimensional, and as you make contact, have a sense of gravity and physics. I think the art style has a pleasant softness to it, and has good color schemes for the variety of settings. For instance, the ice stage has trees and other background elements to contrast against the white snow. Plus, snow falls from the sky. You're also able to customize your character with different costumes, with many skins available in the mod community.


When going out of my way to listen to the music, it's surprisingly somber sounding. I didn't necessarily expect goofy sound effects or carnival music, but the soundtrack would be suitable for a story-rich, dramatic game. It really comes off as incongruent, because the gameplay is too silly, yet the music is very good. There are sound effects, such as when you crash into the ground and use machines, but it's somewhat limited. Everything seemed to fit well enough though.


🌟 There are a reasonable number of checkpoints scattered throughout each stage. Also, if you're playing with others, only one person needs to reach it, for everyone to benefit.
🌟 You can play the entire game by yourself, but it's much more fun if you play with others. I don't know what it'd be like, but it claims you can play with a total of eight people.
🌟 The game has a nice variety in stages and obstacles to deal with. Plus, if you're skilled or explore enough, there are shortcuts to skip past different sections.


❌ There was one section in the Aztec stage that I found incredibly aggravating. It involved a platform on a lever, and two boxes. Getting the platform to cooperate, while moving boxes onto it, was difficult, even after figuring out what needed to be done. Thankfully, this was the worst part of the game, and later areas weren't any harder than this.
❌ Although the time it took me to beat the game was fairly high, there's not very many stages to play through. I'd have enjoyed more of them, with simpler challenges, just to enjoy navigating around in more areas. Stumbling about is part of the fun.


🔍 Controlling the direction you face is essential in order to play HFF. It's not hard, but it feels different from other games I've played, and takes some time to get used to. After all, normally I wouldn't need to face a specific direction in order to climb up onto a platform, or grab an object.
🔍 I found that lifting my arms up made it easier to carry objects, as they otherwise drag against the ground. This is also good life advice.


It's hard to quantify what makes the experience of HFF enjoyable, because on the surface, it shouldn't work. The situations that players deal with can be somewhat whimsical and interesting, but the tasks themselves would be significantly easier in most other games. Although there were times I got aggravated with the title, it wasn't as rage-inducing as I'd have thought, in spite of how long it takes to do fairly simple things. That being said, I played the game with someone else, and think it'd be a much different experience if I'd done it alone. I wouldn't suggest anyone go out of their way to get this game, because surprisingly enough there's quite a few releases that deliver similar experiences. However, I still recommend HFF, as I had more fun with it than I thought I would.

Product received for free

A fantastic introspective on what it means to be human. Much like in real life, you control a bumbling, squishy specimen tasked with solving a variety of problems, mundane or otherwise. Most YouTubers and casual gamers only see a funny ragdoll meme game. But not me. I believe that this game is a true metaphor for life. In fact, the game is highly metaphorical in almost every aspect. The multiple ways to get around a problem is a metaphor for free will. The way that when you fall off the map you land right back on it is a metaphor for starting again when you've made a big mistake. The act of falling to end a level is a metaphor for the "rollercoaster of life" philosophy, which states that when you are at your highest point, you can only go downhill from there. The game's levels take you through the essentials of what it truly means to be a human. Whether you're destroying walls with a wrecking ball (a stunning metaphor for how society breaks itself down over time), exploring a medieval-themed land which requires you to perform exhausting manual labor to find your way to the end, or rewiring power through circuitry to open doors, you're learning a new life lesson about what makes you you. The character customization is insane. You can make almost any type of human you want. You can even be a dog. But no matter what you are or what your character looks like, you will be climbing your way to victory, much like we humans strive for success in everything we do. This game is brilliant. I have never seen a game that takes itself and its subject so seriously. What an absolute masterpiece. 10/10

late disclaimer this review is ironic but the game is great definitely get it especially if you have friends

The game looks like it was originally designed for single player. Playing the game with just keyboard and mouse may discourage a lot of people so it is recommended to use a controller. Solving the puzzles to advance into the game is fun. Playing local-coop adds more fun. However, because of the extra player, you'll be able to advance through a lot of puzzles without really solving them, it makes the game a lot easier because the stage is not adjusted for co-op.

A lot of people may not like the game because of the controls, you have to control the left and right hand individually and the camera is tied to your movement; you'll be looking up to reach things and then be looking down while climbing. Some extras about the game are the easter eggs, some alternate/absurd ways to advance through the puzzles, and customizable look/color for the character.

People with no local-coop partners requested for online multiplayer and the devs added it as a free update. This is why I had it voted for a steam award. The online multiplayer support for this game features 8 players and that breaks the default games stages. With this, I hope they add more stages designed for co-op. Workshop support would also help the game a lot so players can make their own stages and have it designed to be solved by 2, 3 or 4 players.

Posted: June 14, 2023
Human Fall Flat - A Quirky and Physics-Based Puzzle Adventure

Overall Rating: ★★★★☆

Human Fall Flat, developed by No Brakes Games, is a quirky and physics-based puzzle adventure that offers a unique and entertaining gameplay experience. Players take on the role of Bob, a wobbly and whimsical character who must navigate through a series of challenging levels using his unconventional movement abilities and problem-solving skills.

Graphics: ★★★☆☆
The graphics in Human Fall Flat adopt a charming and minimalist art style that adds to the game's whimsical atmosphere. While the visuals may not be the most detailed or realistic, they suit the game's comedic and lighthearted tone. The physics-based animations of Bob and the interactive objects in the environment provide a sense of playfulness and unpredictability.

Gameplay: ★★★★☆
The gameplay of Human Fall Flat revolves around controlling Bob's ragdoll-like character to solve physics-based puzzles. Players must manipulate objects, climb, swing, and jump through the levels, all while navigating the challenges presented by the game's unique physics engine. The controls can feel intentionally clumsy, adding to the game's humor and creating hilarious situations as Bob stumbles and flops his way through the obstacles.

Puzzles and Challenges: ★★★★☆
Human Fall Flat offers a variety of puzzles and challenges that require creative thinking and experimentation. Each level presents a different environment with its own set of obstacles and puzzles to overcome. From using objects to create makeshift ramps to swinging on ropes and levers, players must find unique solutions to progress. The open-ended nature of the puzzles encourages exploration and invites players to approach challenges in their own way.

Cooperative Multiplayer: ★★★★☆
One of the standout features of Human Fall Flat is its cooperative multiplayer mode, allowing players to team up with friends or other online players to tackle the puzzles together. The multiplayer aspect adds an additional layer of fun and laughter as players collaborate or unintentionally hinder each other's progress, leading to amusing and unpredictable moments.

Replayability: ★★★☆☆
While Human Fall Flat may not have extensive replay value in terms of storyline or branching paths, its physics-based gameplay and cooperative multiplayer mode offer some replayability. The joy of experimenting with the game's physics, discovering new ways to solve puzzles, and the potential for different experiences with friends make it worth revisiting.

Conclusion:
Human Fall Flat delivers a unique and entertaining experience with its quirky physics-based gameplay, charming visuals, and cooperative multiplayer mode. The game's humor, puzzle design, and open-ended approach provide a refreshing break from traditional puzzle-solving games. Whether playing solo or with friends, Human Fall Flat offers plenty of laughter-filled moments and enjoyable challenges, making it a worthwhile adventure for those seeking a lighthearted and creative gaming experience.

---{Game Mechanics}---
☐ WASD to move
☐ Easy to understand
☑ Easy to learn, hard to master
☐ Kinda difficult
☐ Wait, how do I walk again?

Notes:
The game is a puzzle solving game, with rag-doll like movement. WASD to move and right and left click to grab. Have you ever played "Getting Over It"? It can get that frustrating at times, especially if you play for a while or after a difficult day. The one complaint I have is how frustrating the mechanics are, and its not even a complaint. I just get really frustrated when it doesn't act the way I want it to. The level design is either intended for speed-running, or idiotic. There are entire sections of levels that can be skipped by giving it some thought, and I like that, but there are some places that seem like they didn't try to prevent skips.
I have never encountered a bug in my 20+ hours on this game, which is awesome. Plus, they release a new level every once in a while. I got 20 something hours from doing a couple of plays and all of the achievements, and you could get even more from downloading levels from the workshop. All in all, I think that if this game is on sale, you should probably grab it!

9/10 because of some frustrating late nights trying to get some achievements!

Posted: September 9, 2020
ОБЗОР НА HFF
ЭТО НЕ ВЕРОЯТНОЕ ПРИКЛЮЧЕНИЕ "ПАДАЮЩИХ ЧЕЛОВЕЧКОВ" КОТОРОЕ ЗАТЯГИВАЕТ С КАЖДЫМ ЧАСОМ.
СОВСЕМ НЕ ВАЖНО ОДИН ТЫ ИГРАЕШЬ ИЛИ В КОМПАНИИ ДРУЗЕЙ СО ВСЕГО МИРА, ТУТ МОЖНО РАЗВИВАТЬ СВОЙ SKILL ИЛИ ПРОСТО ДУРАЧИТЬСЯ (ВЕСЕЛО ПРОВОДИТЬ ВРЕМЯ), КАЖДЫЙ ДЕНЬ :-D

YOU CAN TRANSLATE MY REVIEW INTO YOUR LANGUAGE WITH A ONLINE TRANSLATOR. THANKS FOR YOUR LIKE AND COMMENT ))

ЛИЧНЫЕ РЕКОМЕНДАЦИИ ПО ИГРОВОМУ ПРОЦЕССУ:
- СНАЧАЛА НАСТРОЙТЕ ИГРУ ПОД СЕБЯ В НАСТРОЙКАХ, СДЕЛАЙТЕ ЧУВСТВИТЕЛЬНОСТЬ МЫШИ НА ПОЛНУЮ, А ОБЗОР КАМЕРЫ МОЖНО ПОДОГНАТЬ ПОД РАЗМЕР СВОЕГО ЭКРАНА. ЧЕМ БОЛЬШЕ ЭКРАН ТЕМ МЕНЬШЕ СТАВЬТЕ УГОЛ ОБЗОРА.
- ЕСЛИ У ВАС СЛАБЫЙ КОМПЬЮТЕР, А ИМЕННО СЛАБЫЙ ПРОЦЕССОР ИЛИ ВИДЕОКАРТА, ТО СТАВЬТЕ ГРАФИКУ НА МИНИМУМ. И ПОМНИТЕ ЧТО ЕСЛИ У ВАС ПЛОХОЙ ИНТЕРНЕТ, И ПРИ ЭТОМ ВЫ HOST, ТО ВСЕ ИГРОКИ БУДУТ ИМЕТЬ БОЛЬШОЙ ПИНГ КРОМЕ ВАС.
- НОВИЧКАМ ВАЖНО ПРОЙТИ СНАЧАЛА ВСЮ STORY, А ПОТОМ УЖЕ ПРОХОДИТЬ ДОПОЛНИТЕЛЬНЫЕ КАРТЫ, ПОЛУЧИВ БАЗОВЫЕ НАВЫКИ. И ТОЛЬКО ТОГДА НАЧИНАТЬ ИГРАТЬ В БОЛЕЕ СЛОЖНЫЕ КАРТЫ.
- ЛУЧШЕ СНАЧАЛА ПРОЙТИ БАЗОВЫЕ КАРТЫ STORY В ОДИНОЧКУ, ТАМ МНОГО ЗАГАДОК И ГОЛОВОЛОМОК - ЭТО ПОВЫСИТ ВАШИ НАВЫКИ В ТОМ ЧИСЛЕ МЫШЛЕНИЯ.
- ОБЯЗАТЕЛЬНО ПОСМОТРИТЕ НА YOUTUBE ПРОХОЖДЕНИЕ "HFF WORLD RECORD SPEED RUN" ЗА 6 МИНУТ И ОБЯЗАТЕЛЬНО ПРОБУЙТЕ ПОВТОРИТЬ ВСЕ ДЕЙСТВИЯ.
- ДАЛЕЕ ЧТОБЫ ИГРАТЬ НА КИТАЙСКИХ ИЛИ БОЛЕЕ СЛОЖНЫХ КАРТАХ ВАМ ПОНАДОБЯТСЯ НОВЫЕ ДОПОЛНИТЕЛЬНЫЕ НАВЫКИ ТАКИЕ КАК:
- ДЛИННЫЙ ПРЫЖОК С МЕСТА BUNNY HOP:
- РАСПРЫЖКА- ЭТО СЕРИЯ ДЛИННЫХ ПРЫЖКОВ, КАЖДЫЙ ИЗ КОТОРЫХ, НАЧИНАЯ СО ВТОРОГО, ЕЩЁ ДЛИННЕЕ. ТЕМ САМЫМ ВЫ НАБИРАЕТЕ СКОРОСТЬ И ПРЫГАЕТЕ ТУДА, КУДА ОБЫЧНЫЙ BUNNY HOP НЕ ДОПРЫГНЕТ.
- И ЕЩЁ 1 КРУТЕЙШИЙ ЛАЙФХАК ПО ПРЫЖКАМ --> ЕСЛИ ВЫ НЕ МОЖЕТЕ ПЕРЕПРЫГНУТЬ КАКОЕ-ЛИБО РАССТОЯНИЕ И ВАМ КАЖЕТСЯ ЧТО ФИЗИЧЕСКИ ЭТО НЕ ВОЗМОЖНО, (ПОСЛЕ УПОРНЫХ 2 ЧАСОВ ПЕРЕПРЫГИВАНИЯ ОДНОГО ПРЕПЯТСТВИЯ), ТО ВОТ РЕШЕНИЕ, ВЕДЬ НА "UNITY" ЕСТЬ КУЧА БАГОВ И ЛАЗЕЕК :
УСИЛЕНИЕ ПРЫЖКА ПРИДАЁТ ЭЛЕМЕНТАРНОЕ ЗАПРЫГИВАНИЕ НА КОЛЛЕГУ, СТОЯЩЕГО НА КРАЮ. И ВО ВРЕМЯ ПРИЗЕМЛЕНИЯ НА НЕГО ВЫ ОДНОВРЕМЕННО ДОЛЖНЫ ПРОСТО ПОДПРЫГНУТЬ. ТЕМ САМЫМ ВЫ УСИЛИТЕ СВОЙ ПРЫЖОК РАЗ В 5 ;-Р
- УДЕЛЯЙТЕ МНОГО ВРЕМЕНИ ТРЕНИРОВКЕ ЛАЗАНЬЕ ПО СТЕНАМ, КАК ПО ВЕРТИКАЛЬНЫМ ТАК И ПО НАКЛОННЫМ СТЕНАМ - ЭТО ОЧЕНЬ ВАЖНЫЙ НАВЫК.
И СО ВРЕМЕНЕМ ВЫ НАУЧИТЕСЬ БОЛЕЕ СЛОЖНОЙ ТЕХНИКЕ ПОДЪЁМА ПО ВЕРТИКАЛЬНЫМ СТЕНАМ ДВУМЯ РУКАМИ ОДНОВРЕМЕННО, ЭТО СУПЕР СКИЛЛ ПОЗДРАВЛЯЮ ВЫ УЖЕ ПРОФИ.
- УЧИТЕСЬ ДЕЛАТЬ САЛЬТО ВПЕРЁД И САЛЬТО НАЗАД, КАК НА МЕСТЕ ТАК И С ПРЕПЯТСТВИЙ, КАК СТОЯ ТАК И В РАСПРЫЖКЕ, ЭТО СДЕЛАЕТ ВАС ВИЗУАЛЬНО КРУЧЕ ДРУГИХ ;-))
- ЗАПОМНИТЕ, ЕСТЬ РАЗНИЦА В ТОМ КАКУЮ МОДЕЛЬ ПЕРСОНАЖА ВЫ ВЫБЕРЕТЕ. ЭТО БУДЕТ ВЛИЯТЬ НА ВАШ СТИЛЬ И СЛОЖНОСТЬ В УПРАВЛЕНИИ ИГРОЙ.
- ПЕРЕВОДИТЕ КИТАЙСКИЕ ИЛИ АНГЛИЙСКИЕ ТЕКСТЫ ЗАДАНИЙ В ИГРЕ С ПОМОЩЬЮ GOOGLE ПЕРЕВОДЧИКА ПРОСТО НАВЕДЯ НА НИХ КАМЕРУ.
- ИГРАЯ С ДРУЗЬЯМИ, ЛУЧШЕ СОЗДАВАТЬ КАРТЫ ПОДХОДЯЩИЕ ПО УРОВНЮ ИГРЫ ДЛЯ ВСЕХ ИГРОКОВ. И ЛУЧШЕ ОБЩАТЬСЯ В ГОЛОСОВОМ ЧАТЕ STEAM ЛИБО В DISCORD, СОЗДАВ ПРЕДВАРИТЕЛЬНО ГРУППУ.
- УЧИТЕСЬ БЫТЬ КОМАНДНЫМ ИГРОКОМ !!! ЭТО ЦЕНИТСЯ У ПРОФЕССИОНАЛОВ HFF.
- ИГРАЙТЕ С СИЛЬНЫМИ ИГРОКАМИ И СЛЕДИТЕ КАК ОНИ ПРЫГАЮТ ВЫШЕ И ДАЛЬШЕ, КАРАБКАЮТСЯ БЫСТРЕЕ, И ПОВТОРЯЙТЕ ЗА НИМИ.
- ЕСЛИ ИГРА ЧАСТО КРАШИТСЯ (CRASH) - ЗАПУСТИТЕ ПРОВЕРКУ ФАЙЛОВ ИГРЫ В СТИМЕ. И ЖДИТЕ.
- И ПОМНИТЕ, ЕСЛИ ВЫ НЕ МОЖЕТЕ ПРИСОЕДИНИТЬСЯ К HOST, ИЛИ К ВАМ НЕ МОГУТ ВОЙТИ НА КАРТУ И ВИДИТЕ ТОЛЬКО ЭКРАН ЗАГРУЗКИ, НО СЛЫШИТЕ ЗВУКИ, ТО В 90% СЛУЧАЕВ ЭТО РЕШАЕТСЯ ПРОСТЫМ ПЕРЕЗАПУСКОМ САМОЙ ИГРЫ (REBOOT GAME).
-----------------------------------
!!! В ЦЕЛОМ, ЭТО ОЧЕНЬ ВЕСЁЛАЯ ИГРА ДЛЯ УДОВОЛЬСТВИЯ ОТ ПРОЦЕССА И КАЙФА ОТ ДОСТИЖЕНИЯ ЦЕЛИ, ПУТЁМ ЛИЧНЫХ ИЛИ КОМАНДНЫХ УСИЛИЙ. ЛИЧНО Я, НИ РАЗУ НЕ ПОЖАЛЕЛ О ПОКУПКЕ.
РАЗРАБОТЧИКИ ПОЖАЛУЙСТА ИСПРАВЬТЕ ОШИБКИ И ОПТИМИЗИРУЙТЕ УЖЕ НАКОНЕЦ ИГРУ, СПАСИТЕ НАС ОТ ВЕЧНЫХ ЗАВИСАНИЙ ВО ВРЕМЯ ВХОДА НОВЫХ ИГРОКОВ В ЛОББИ, ИЗБАВЬТЕ НАС ОТ ВНЕЗАПНОГО ЗАВИСАНИЯ ИЛИ ВЫЛЕТА ИГРЫ ПРИ ПРОХОЖДЕНИИ ЛОКАЦИИ !!! И ДА ПРИБУДЕТ С ВАМИ СИЛА ДЖЕДАЕВ HFF НАВЕКИ, АМИНЬ !!!
-----------------------------------


1 - ЦЕНА ОПРАВДЫВАЕТ ИНТЕРЕС (А ПО СКИДКЕ МОЖНО УРВАТЬ ЗА ПОЛЦЕНЫ).
2 - МОЖНО ЗНАКОМИТЬСЯ И ОБЩАТЬСЯ С ЛЮДЬМИ ИЗ РАЗНЫХ СТРАН В ТЕКСТОВОМ ЧАТЕ. НО ТОГДА ЗНАНИЕ АНГЛИЙСКОГО ЯЗЫКА ОБЯЗАТЕЛЬНО.
3 - МОЖНО ИСПОЛЬЗОВАТЬ ОШИБКИ И БАГИ ДВИЖКА UNITY
4 - ОЧЕНЬ ХОРОШАЯ И ПРАВДОПОДОБНАЯ ФИЗИКА В ИГРЕ.
5 - БЕЗ ТОРМОЗОВ РАБОТАЕТ ДАЖЕ НА СТАРОМ НОУТБУКЕ 2010 ГОДА ВЫПУСКА. С МИНИМАЛЬНЫМИ НАСТРОЙКАМИ ГРАФИКИ.


1 - ДО СИХ ПОР НЕ ОПТИМИЗИРОВАНА И ПОХОДУ НИКОГДА НЕ БУДЕТ Т.К. РАЗРАБЫ ПРЕКРАСНО ГРЕБУТ ДЕНЬГИ И БЕЗ ЭТОГО ГЕМОРРОЯ.
2 - ВЕЛИКИЙ И УЖАСНЫЙ ПИНГ МЕЖДУ СТРАНАМИ И КОНТИНЕНТАМИ (((
3 - РАЗРАБЫ ДЕЛАЮТ ИНТЕРЕСНЫЕ ОРИГИНАЛЬНЫЕ КАРТЫ, НО ДОЛГО-ДОЛГО, И ЕЛЕ-ЕЛЕ.
4 - ЖАЛЬ ЧТО РАЗРАБОТЧИКИ НЕ ДОГАДАЛИСЬ ОБЛЕГЧИТЬ ЖИЗНЬ ИГРОКАМ И ДО СИХ ПОР НЕ ДОБАВИЛИ КНОПКУ УДАЛИТЬ КАРТУ ИЛИ ОЧИСТИТЬ КЭШ КАРТ В ИГРЕ. ТАК КАК ВСЕ КАРТЫ, КОТОРЫХ НЕТ У ВАС, НАЧИНАЮТ ЗАГРУЖАТЬСЯ НА ВАШ КОМП САМИ И ЗАНИМАЮТ ОЧЕНЬ МНОГО ГИГАБАЙТ МЕСТА СО ВРЕМЕНЕМ. СПРАШИВАЕТСЯ НА-ХУ-Я ??? А ПОТОМ ПРИХОДИТСЯ УДАЛЯТЬ ИГРУ ЧТОБЫ ОЧИСТИТЬ ВСЁ ПОЛНОСТЬЮ (ПОСЛЕДНИЙ РАЗ ЭТО БЫЛО 55 GB), А НЕ ЧАСТИЧНО.
5 - ХЕРОВО ЧТО НЕЛЬЗЯ ПОМЕНЯТЬ ВСЕ КЛАВИШИ НА ТЕ, КОТОРЫЕ УДОБНЫ ТЕБЕ, А ИМЕННО НЕ МЕНЯЕТСЯ ОТКРЫТИЕ ТЕКСТОВОГО ЧАТА "T"

Posted: July 6, 2019
Good game, but beware.

Devs/Publisher pulled a really nasty move and silently removed Linux support.

Not only removing it, but entirely breaking it by walling off Linux users to play with Win/OSX users due to version checks.
Could be fixed if the Linux depot would be deleted, but that is apparently too hard.

Now to play again with other platforms, Linux users have to force Steam to download the Windows version and use Proton.

I'm not against the decision, it's understandable that more platforms are a pain to a small team, but this could have been handled extremely better than it has been.

Posted: September 27, 2017
Been playing this with my daughter (she's nearly 11), and its been a lot of fun. We both take joy in being able to find solutions to the puzzles that aren't nessecarily the "right" way to do it, and the mishaps that occur as we try. (We spent ages with the boats and the water wheel in the Water level but because we were doing it together it never got boring or made us want to switch off)

The music is lovely, but minimal.
Graphics are simple but effective. We grew quite attached to our gooy avatars, even more so once we decked them out.



Two thumbs up from both of us.

Posted: June 2, 2019
I had never heard of this game before until this week, and I don't know how because it is superb. Your character has sort of the floppy, flailing, uncontrolled type of movement you find in games like Gang Beasts and Totally Accurate Battlegrounds, so it is rather challenging to control your character. The game sends you through a series of puzzle levels similar in nature to what you would find in the Portal games, and has multi-player co-op levels in addition to single-player. The co-op levels are designed to be completed by two players, but you can have up to four players in a session. The only problem with this is that sometimes one or two players can be left without anything to do for a certain task, but having more than two players can also help with finding solutions quicker and completing difficult parkour and timing-based tasks that will inevitably require many tries to get right.

The main frustrating thing about this game is that you can end up getting yourself into situations where you must reset the level at your last checkpoint. You will have to deal with moving unwieldy objects from one place to another using your floppy controls, and sometimes these objects will get stuck somewhere and won't de-spawn and re-spawn, meaning you'll have to reset the checkpoint. This isn't bad on some checkpoints, but some require more tasks or more difficult tasks than others.

Another issue is that objects sometimes re-spawn in bad positions where they are unusable, such as a gondola being upside down or a vehicle spawning on full-throttle forward, so you'll have to reset the checkpoint until everything spawns correctly. Your character may also be spawned in a place where you'll immediately fall of the edge of the map or into the water, causing you to die instantly. Your character may also be spawned stuck inside a solid object, which will probably require a checkpoint reset again.

But overall, this game is a lot of fun, especially in co-op mode. With the hilarious character physics, the rage-inducing challenges, and the humor provided in the game, you are bound to have a good laugh with your friends. If you want something that you can play with friends to keep you occupied for a while, I highly recommend this.

Posted: July 31, 2016
Recommended, but with caveats.

The game is mostly fun, and I got some real moments out of enjoyment out of some of the puzzles and especially out of the character.

The feel is a little like Octodad meets Portal, but without the soul of either, and that's part of the issue. You get a snarky narrator for all of, like, thirty seconds, and then the game is mostly played in silence. The music is nice...when it's there. The whole thing feels a little empty. The world looks like it has interesting stories to tell, but you'll never know, because there's no substance beneath the puzzles.

By the end of the four hour play time, some of the puzzles start to wear thin. Especially because the second-to-last level is frustrating, what with all the water around that makes even the smallest screw up into a drowning offense. Be prepared to respawn and restart puzzles there a lot...which is not fun. Also, the final level feels pretty repetitive over most of its length, which isn't great.

Where Portal and Octodad left me wanting more, I was perfectly happy to be done with this game in the end. I didn't really want to spend any more time working through the world.

I hope there's more support, maybe some new levels provided that provide more diversity. But one of the core problems, the ultimate hollowness of the game, isn't going to be fixed by patches. The narrator at the beginning makes it feel like the devs wanted to make this a more fleshed out experience, and just ran out of time or money.

If you're in to wonky, physics-based puzzlers, this is worth picking up. If you want them to have some depth, keep looking.

Posted: October 13, 2017
TL;DR: Jam packed with secrets to encourage exploration and so many paths to take it's hard to tell which was the intended way. Solo, multiplayer, skins, workshop support, this game has everything it needs to become even more amazing and endearing than it already is!

Puzzle folks, physics folks, fun-loving folks, rejoice!

Human: Fall flat is a romp through myriad trials of your squishy human body with the ultimate goal being conquest of your environment. Be it destruction, climbing, teamwork, or even construction and maintenance aided by heavy machinery, the simple controls and aesthetic hide away the breadth of activites in the game.

Hilarious mechanics relying on the sometimes less-than-gracious procedural animation system leads to silly and often unexpected ways of getting around and getting the job done. That isn't to say the controls don't lend themselves to finesse with a bit of skill and timing. From flopping lazily over chasms to deftly monkeying over and around puzzles in a few levels, the game is deceptively easy to pick up but hard to master.

Level design allows for shortcuts and endless creativity. You'll be surprised how many times you think "oh, THIS'LL break the game/skip the level!" and suddenly an achievement pops and you're faced with yet another puzzle; the devs knew you'd do that and rewarded you. I've played the game twice solo and once with a friend in the new multiplayer mode and consistently find new ways to get through the level. Siege is so vast and yet so dense and mysterious, I could spend hours going hand-over-hand up those ziplines. If only I had 3 friends to explore with me!

Customizing my character must be at least an hour and a half of my time in this game, you can select from tons of clothing options, customize them, then paint logos on them, paint tattoos, and share them with your friends or the world on the workshop. More architecturally inclined? Build a level to challenge yourself or frustrate your friends, and again upload it to the workshop for fame and fortune!

The game is admittedly short for those wanting to speedrun it, likely completeable in about an hour or two the first time, but it's no less fun and you'll likely either want to perfect a speedrun or find the secrets after passing so many by on a fast run. Exploration is truly rewarding and reall the way to go anyways, as that's where the bulk of the content is. Not only are there secrets, there are shortcuts or ways to get around that are far more fun than object puzzles!

Human: Fall Flat is essentially what a story mode in Gang Beasts would be if they moved away from the combat-focused model. It has the climbing and carrying mechanics you want from Gang Beasts with consideraly more finesse and control over hand placement, throwing, and body position.

Keep in mind this is NOT an Early Access title that's been abandoned, but a fully released game that's still getting love and care from the devs. This is such nice dev behavior to see in the age of abandonware, I feel that commitment alone warrants a second look at this title. The devs are also passionate about bringing the best mechanics into the game and are cognizant of player suggestions.

PROS:

Encourages outside thinking
Novel puzzles with minimal filler
Total freedom of traversal
Replayability for years
Easy to pick up, hard to put down
Endless customization
Workshop support
Online/local multiplayer
Hilarious situations lone or with friends
Extremely forgiving

CONS:

You can never have enough of a good thing
Sometimes unstable, but doesn't crash
Character customization tools a bit clunky
Small online presence means most MP sessions need friends or previous arrangements

Posted: July 27, 2016
Product received for free

A Open-Ended Physics Puzzle Exploration Game
YouTube™ Video: Human: Fall Flat || Open-Ended Physics Puzzle Exploration Game || Let's Play Part 1 
Views: 208
#humanfallflat http://store.steampowered.com/app/477160/ Add me on Steam: http://steamcommunity.com/id/desolater_iv/ Add me on Twitter: https://twitter.com/DESOLATER_IV

+ The game is incredibly fun! Your character moves and behaves in a silly way like it's made out of jelly, but honestly controls incredibly well. You complete all sorts of physics based puzzles by moving, pushing, platforming, climbing, and so fourth.
+ There are multiple ways of completing many of the puzzles and stages which gives the game a nice sense of replayability as you will no doubt think of new ways to solve puzzles on your second playthrough. I found this to be so refreshing as I was often searching for ways to skip past puzzles I did not want to solve which often included some crazy parkour or creating some alternate route.
+ Very creative levels and puzzles
+ A surprising amount of vehicles that you must control entirely with movements from your character. Catapults, Cranes, Various types of boats, a truck and so fourth. I found it pretty amazing that you actually have to grab the paddles, and row yourself to shore in a canoe on one stage.
+ The way the character moves can be very comical at times as it flops around.
+ Character creator, which lets you paint and if you have a webcam paste pictures onto your character.
+ Great soundtrack that fits the vibe of the game very well.

- I feel like the story was a bit lacking. At the beginning I had thought I was supposed to explore and discover something at the end, but nothing really happens.
- A bit short in length, although the last 2 stages are incredibly long.


This game really deserves more recognition! I would love to see a sequel of some sort!

Posted: November 10, 2022
The game in question is a veritable gem in split screen co-op (and dual monitor) for aficionados of physics-based puzzles. It must be acknowledged that the level design is a significant contributor to this. The levels have been meticulously crafted to fully exploit the game's unique physics system. Playing locally in co-op or online with up to eight players is an exceedingly enjoyable experience.

Regrettably, the only blemish, as previously noted, is its lifespan. The ability to create one's own levels does little to offset this deficiency. While there are currently 500 levels available, the inherent nature of the game's style makes it exceedingly difficult to construct a novel and engaging puzzle. Even if one manages to do so, once it has been solved, there is little incentive to revisit it. Furthermore, levels that cater to a more uninhibited style, such as platformers or ski slopes, are ill-suited to the game's physics engine, often causing it to crash and resulting in an unsatisfactory and unresponsive experience.

It would be unrealistic to anticipate levels akin to those found in GTA5, as the physics engine is primarily designed for the somewhat mundane task of puzzle-solving. While I thoroughly enjoyed this game, I can only offer it a score of seven due to its inherently limited lifespan, despite the developers' best efforts to offer a multiplayer mode and a workshop. This is due to the strength and weakness of its physics engine.

i am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Posted: February 4
As a 50-year-old single father of two, life's challenges often felt like insurmountable obstacles, especially after the tragic loss of my beloved wife. Grieving, I found solace in the virtual world of Human Fall Flat, a whimsical game that unexpectedly became my lifeline.

Through its charming puzzles and quirky physics, Human Fall Flat offered me not just a distraction, but a new perspective on life. As I navigated the game's whimsical landscapes alongside my children, laughter replaced tears, and joy slowly began to fill the void left by loss.

With each puzzle conquered and each silly mishap shared with my kids, I rediscovered the simple pleasures of companionship and play. Human Fall Flat became more than just a game; it became a catalyst for healing and a beacon of hope for brighter days ahead.

In the end, Human Fall Flat taught me that even in the darkest of times, there's always a glimmer of light waiting to guide us back to happiness. And for that, I'll forever be grateful.

Posted: 10 April, 2017
I'm pretty sure you've played this or something like it on a Flash site before. Take a hapless mook and rough 'em up with explosives or bicycles or catapults or what have you until their ragdoll spasms get a chuckle out of you. I didn't expect much from Happy Room and I got exactly what I did, plenty of silly, gory action with goofy contraptions. And it even exceeded my expectations in a few little ways, enough to keep me chucking clones into the meat grinder.

You've got the best job in the world, testing weapon systems on meaty specimens without any of those pesky ethical concerns to stop you. Starting with basic mines, spikes, and guns, you earn additional funds for new instruments of destruction as you prove the worth of the tools at your disposal. These quickly branch out into useful and goofy devices like launch pads, zero-gravity generators, buzzsaws, morning stars, and so on. There are also special objectives to complete for bonus funds and points to upgrade your weapons with. The more damage you do, the more damage-dealing goodies you get to play with. Simple.

A typical gameplay loop consists of setting up your murder chamber, running the test, and then seeing how things panned out. If you didn't beat your previous best you don't get anything so you have to rearrange your killbox for greater lethality. And if you did do more damage, you get more money so you can make the room even nastier. At specific total damage values you get new toys, split into explosive, gun, spike, and miscellaneous categories. Certain unlocks make a huge difference like launch pads that keep your dummy moving past traps, portals that can warp him around the room, and sawblades you can make sick little conveyor belts with. You'll also have four side objectives to complete at any given time, like stick ten crossbow bolts in the dummy or have him frozen and on fire at once. Completing these earns you upgrade points that give your tools important new abilities, such as allowing them to attach to ceilings or reach further or do more damage.

Each test ends when the dummy stops moving and stops taking damage, and most of your equipment is stationary so a major goal is working out a system to keep him going as long as possible. Nearly everything has ammo (actually more like durability) including spikes and sawblades so you can't keep him going forever. This sounds like a weird limitation but it works in practice because it focuses strategy on bouncing the dummy between all of your traps, not just cornering him with a tiny killbox. It also gives rise to entertaining tools like the big rockets he can get stuck on and the superlasers that smash him into the opposite wall.

Your dummy suffers visual effects for whatever he suffers, whether it be fire or acid or being nibbled to death by piranhas, so prepare for some gruesome scenes as you get better at abusing him. A handy status screen shows you how much damage he's taken to each of his ragdolly parts, helpful for determining where you need to focus your efforts. The final break point for damage actually kills the dummy, which awards you an -ALITY for whatever struck the killing blow. There are achievements for each of these to keep you invested after unlocking everything and perfecting your murder machines. You'll be spending plenty of time just getting to that point and chasing the many side objectives, so don't expect to be done with the game anytime soon if you like messing dudes up.

There are only a few weak points worth mentioning, all pretty minor. For one, the rough English on some objectives and upgrades can add some guesswork to what you're doing. Also this can go either way but tests never run the same way twice, even if you don't change a thing between them. This might frustrate meticulous or impatient types but I kinda liked running a single room multiple times to see how good it could get or if it ever freaked out. Overall Happy Room proved to be more engrossing than I ever thought it would be. It's the kind of game where I'll play for 30 minutes, then go back to work and suddenly realize I should have hooked up the tesla nodes to the piranha tanks, and then excitedly tell my coworker what I figured out and end up in a meeting with HR that afternoon. Totally worth it, because sometimes you just want some dumb fun and Happy Room is that, plus a little extra.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at or on my !

I like to take my friend to my ''Happy Room'' where we shall play. My friend thinks there will be icecream. I have different plans. Fun plans!

I love my friend.

I love my Happy Room.
- - - - -
Lugubrious ragdoll fun! Destroy them with a large variety of weapons, and perform tasks to progress your funds!



This one plays a lot like the main mode, Laboratory, but with different weapons. Laboratory has an experimental setting, while Dungeon has more of a classic vibe.
You start with some bombs, and on the top of the screen there are four quests that reward money to be able to place more weapons in your room, and upgrade weapons with a second currency. For example the quest can be to hit one dummy four times with bombs. When you complete a quest, you immediately receive a new one. Some quests require just some slight adjustments to the room, but most quests require a dedicated layout, and most resources in one type of weaponry. New weapons are unlocked by improving your turn record of damage to the dummy.
At the final parts of the quest you are tasked to deliver the killing blow with a certain type of weapon. Those are tied to the achievements for this game, together with the quest progress.

The idea of this mode is that the mouse cursor is a weapon. Your mouse can be an axe, a shotgun, or a firespewing dragon for instance, and you pay for every hit or shot. There are still some items that are placed beforehand in the room, such as trampolines.

Besides the modes there are also new achievements for sandbox mode, to kill a dummy with every and only weapons from a category, such as explosives. Or simply every weapon in this game!

It was fun to return to this ridiculous game! When playing through a mode, you can get a bit burned out with the mechanics. You basically are doing the same thing over and over again with minor differences. Some of the challenges are very tough, but those are the ones I remember best from nearly five years ago! Like a challenge to be hit a bird in sandbox, by launching a dummy into the sky! If you rather see the rooms do their thing, and don't feel particularly like building the room, you can find community made rooms in the workshop.

This game is just simple fun. It's only sold here on Steam, and goes for €2,49 during sales. Not many of my friends own this game. Recommended by me!

75/100

Posted: January 16, 2017
I play this game on the weekends, when I'm at work, and I absolutely love this game. Happy Room allows you to create your own deathtraps, and see how they work out. The fun, and sometimes annoying, thing is the different dummies react differently. For example, I'll set a bouncer to fling the dummy toward the wall and then get blasted by a death ray, and maybe have him land on a spike trap... On a test run, I'll see where one dummy lands, but following dummies land in different areas. So, you really have to work at destroying these dummies.
The only thing that I would say that they could do, to REALLY make this game above and beyond, I wish you could edit the dummies. If there was a mode, or something, that allowed you to edit the dummies to look like other people that would put this game over the top. I'm sure I'm not the only one... There's other people out there that has just had a bad day, and you edit the dummy to look like someone that rubbed you the wrong way, and then blow them to hell and back... It turns your day around.
I highly recommend this title. It's cheap, it's insanely fun and addictive, and I would only add that one small feature. Other than that, GREAT GAME!!!

Posted: January 6, 2018
Achievements: All possible, none are too difficult.

Pros/Cons:
+ Addicting
+ Very stress relieving
+ Many unique weapons/tools that unlock through play
+ Upgrade system
+ Different modes (normal, sandbox, desert)
+ Nice grid system to place things down precisely
+ Unlockable hats/costumes
+ Great time killer
+ Cheap
+ Rooms can be uploaded/downloaded from the workshop

+/- It definitely has that unpolished flash game look/feel. I don't necessarily consider that a bad thing, though.

- Some upgrades can entirely change the purpose of an item
- Some items can be tedious to place a lot of
- There's no faster fast-forward than 2x

Overall:
Happy Room was a fun little time killer. Blowing some poor guy apart was incredibly stress relieving and I don't care what that says about me as a person. It was really fun to test out different strategies and find out different ways to do the most damage or land the last hit with a certain weapon. Give it a shot if you're bored.

Posted: February 24
Happy Room is an absolute blast! The combination of creative weaponry and the sandbox-style environment allows for endless experimentation and excitement. The game play mechanics are smooth, and the physics engine adds an extra layer of realism to the chaos.

What sets Happy Room apart is its perfect balance between challenge and enjoyment. Whether you're devising elaborate traps or simply unleashing mayhem, every moment is filled with adrenaline-pumping action. The variety of tools and weapons keeps things fresh, ensuring that each play through is a unique experience.

The graphics are vibrant and quirky, perfectly complementing the game's light-hearted yet delightfully chaotic atmosphere. Additionally, the sound effects add to the immersion, making every explosion and collision feel satisfyingly impactful.

Overall, Happy Room is a must-play for anyone looking for a fun and engaging experience. It's a game that will keep you coming back for more, eager to discover new ways to unleash destruction and rack up high scores. Highly recommended!

Happy Room is a game with not a lot of content and not a lot of replayability. The game is most fun for the first half an hour or so, when there's still an element of puzzle involved in trying to complete objectives to progress. However, once you complete the grind and unlock every weapon in the game, there's little more to do besides achievement hunting. In fact, half my total play time has been dedicated to achievement hunting.

However, being priced at under $10 for a few hours of game time, it actually can be a good timewaster. It can be fun (and somewhat sadistic) to watch a test dummy get ripped apart by a bunch of lasers, but that enjoyment only lasts a few hours at most.

Overall, it's interesting. Everything in the trailer is more or less what you're getting. A compelling premise (Devolver definitely marketed this as well as they could), plenty of interesting ideas and moments, with somehow brilliant level design yet mediocre bosses.
