Posted: 18 November, 2019
Pikuniku is a charming little puzzle platformer that reminds me a bit of Locoroco. It lacks in content, But it makes up for it with co op gameplay, a funny story and a very coherent experience.

It has a little story, It is very short, The story should take you around 2 - 3 hours. but it is a good experience, The game is very coherent with all its elements, The soundtrack, graphics, gameplay, story. It all feels just right. You play as a little red monster with 2 legs, You mostly spend the game helping the npcs with their problems, There are also a few very basic side missions.

There is Local coop in special coop levels, You can also play Bassketball locally against eachother. The levels are pretty short, But it should fill up about an hour of co op gameplay, I think coop is pretty fun, but it could use a lot more levels with a lot more challenge in my opinion.

There are a bunch of challenge levels which have fast platforming or puzzles, But they are not hard. There are also a few bosses, But the game offers no real challenge, except for a single mini game. The game has a few missable trophies but these trophies stack between games, It also has a few missable achievements, But the game doesn't take very long

The game has a bunch of outfits which mostly have special abilities you need to progress in the game. There are also a bunch of secret areas which mostly are not very hard to spot. The game is funny in a childish way, It is very suitable for kids.

The graphics are pretty unique, It reminds me a bit of Locoroco, It is very childish It fits the style of the game well. The soundtrack also fits the game very well. The performance is great, The game is locked to 60fps, but it syncs to the display refresh rate if it is higher when you turn Vsync on.

Mostly you are looking for objects, solving puzzles or looking for ways to accomplish something. The game is a nice mix of gameplay, There are also a bunch of minigames that can be fun but frustrating, One achievements requires you to get a 999 score on a minigame, When I got to 600 and dropped the ball I was done.

Overall I can recommend the game, It is great for kids, But it is also a nice game to play if you are looking for a casual game with some simple puzzles. The co op is pretty cool too. I have to give it a 8, It is a good game, But it certainly lacks a bit in content for the price.

Posted: February 29
Pikuniku is essentially Capitalism for Babies in game format. I played the game alongside my 5 y.o. child who was able to enjoy the game with help reading out the dialogues and solving some of the harder puzzles and battles. Just like the characters in the Pikuniku universe, she started out being very excited about seeing Mr. Sunshine and the prospect of getting "free money", but gradually started to question his actions. The game became a helpful tool in explaining the impacts of rampant capitalism and overexploitation of resources. This was of course all possible by the virtue of the game's entertaining storyline and gags, enjoyable soundtrack, as well as endearing character designs. All this at an affordable price, to boot. Now that we have completed the game, we have also had fun playing the co-op stages together.

Posted: May 14, 2020
PikuNiku is a bizarre adventure wrapped in an adorable aesthetic with some anti-capitalism glitter scattered on top. Given the silly nature of the game, I can almost guarantee that you will be entertained. However, perhaps more attention should have been spent on the gameplay as it is quite basic and has little replay value.
Side note: I still have no clue why the game is called PikuNiku (picnic in Japanese).

Played with Playstation 4 controller and my lovely partner

Positive:
PikuNiku emanates fun. The game immediately sets the tone by blasting you with an over-the-top slapstick cutscene, which is then followed by nonsensical events, silly characters, and countless bizarre encounters (battling giant toast, to name one). I never doubted that entertainment was the main focus of the game, from the wonky walk to ? soundtrack (don’t get me wrong, the soundtrack suits the game perfectly). Yet out of all the peculiarities, discovering the dancing insects was my favorite feature.

Neutral:
Only about 3 hours of gameplay for the singleplayer adventure. I personally find that slapstick humor doesn’t work more than once. If you know what's coming, suddenly the humor is lost. This happens to be the case with PikuNiku, rendering away any sort of replay value. This is further enforced by the lack of a chapter select option, mediocre minigames, and a limited endgame (discussed in further detail below).




PikuNiku is great… if you play it once and only once. Perhaps I’ve had enough of games rely too heavily on humor rather than gameplay. Overall it’s entertaining and worth several good chuckles but sadly is also littered with poor design choices that end up taking away from the experience. Would maybe recommend to younger audiences or anyone looking for something mindlessly humorous.

Posted: August 6, 2023
Pikuniku is insane. I can not name a single other game that pulls so many new things and gimmicks out so randomly and so consistently. One second, you'll be playing hide and seek with a rock, the next thing you know you're fighting a demonic toast in his own hellish realm, then you're playing an aspiring game developer's new game, or giving a wizard a golden tooth of a silver frog in order to get your greatest wish, to just chilling on the beach. And the best part is, everything I listed here is not required in order to complete the game. Someone playing the game could just miss everything I listed here, just because they were cruising on through the story. If you got some free time and a little bit of spare change, pick up this game. Trust me, you won't regret it.

Posted: October 8, 2020
I’m going to do this one a little different because Pikuniku is a simple game and it only needs a simple review. It’s one of the cutest and funniest games I’ve ever played.

2020 really, really sucks, but man I have been very fortunate to play just so many incredible games this year, and Pikuniku is up there with the very best. Pikuniku has an easy to understand, well-paced, and fun story. It has lovable characters, even the antagonist. It has writing. Seriously. The visuals are nice. The platforming is simple, but fun, and there is even a little variety when it comes to gameplay. Music and sound effects are masterful, and for achievement hunters there is a challenge, as well as local co-op options (now accessible through Remote Play!).

Pikuniku’s only shortcoming is its sometimes floaty controls, which make a little bit of the platforming just a bit annoying. It’s also relatively short, but maybe this contributes to what a great, condensed experience this is, so this shortcoming is debatable

Haven’t laughed so hard playing a game since (which I was lucky enough to play this year), and before that ?????

Get it. Play it. Love it.

Posted: January 25, 2019
I bought this game on release after watching Supermega play the co-op mode on their channel. The game is by no means a long one, but the content within is a joy to experience. The controls are intentionally a little slippery, but it adds to the charm in a way. You're given essentially free roam after completing a few objectives, and can explore the different areas at your leisure. The platforming and puzzles feel good, with the gauntlet segments offering a welcome bit of challenge to break up the flow of the game. These gauntlets are completely optional, and the frogs at each checkpoint can teleport you to the entrance if you end up wanting to leave early. The game also has several minigames that are a joy to play, one of which is available to play with two players instead of against an NPC. The story is presented in a way that I absolutely love seeing in games that offer the option to explore. The narrative is presented simply, and gives you an objective. However, there's no real pressure to accomplish these objectives in a timely manner. This changes, however, when you get into the final stretch of the game, where you're railroaded towards the final boss. One of my biggest pet peeves with games is when the story gives you an objective that you really should be focused on, but also tries to encourage exploration. A big example of this is Fallout 4. You emerge from the cryo chamber knowing your son is kidnapped. The story is presented in such a way that exploring feels morally wrong. Every moment you spend getting sidetracked is another moment that your son may be in danger. It takes away from the impact of the story and makes it feel more like a slog than an adventure.

I do, however, have a few minor problems with the game. The first of which, is that some of the controls are a bit unclear. Now, the core controls are very well explained, and it doesn't take long to get a hang of it. Mainly, I still don't know how to use items from my inventory. I have a postcard, but I don't know how to use it with the mailbox. Perhaps I haven't tried the right mailbox, but as it stands, this is still a mystery. Secondly, there are some areas that will require exiting out to the menu and reloading. The one that comes to mind is in the forest, where you can accidentally trap yourself in a hidden underground chamber by blocking up the entrance with acorns. You can't kick them in such a way that they roll all the way out, and the only other exit is to a smaller room that holds a trophy.

Overall, this game is wonderful and worth every penny of its modest $13. The controls feel good, despite some seldom frustrating platforming segments, the story is well-written and intriguing enough to keep the player moving forward, the world has many secrets to uncover that make exploring feel worth-while, the minigames are fun diversions that add more character to the world, the boss fights are varied and challenging, and the only problems I had were minor ones that honestly don't hold much of a bearing on the quality of the game.

I haven't had a chance to play the co-op levels yet, but this game has earned a place in my library as one of my favorite diversions.

Posted: December 8, 2020
At first glance, it might look like a nice, little, and peculiar puzzle game inspired by Adventure Time and set in a somewhat dystopian narrative, but it masterfully manages to playfully explore some of the more serious themes like mindless consumerism and labor exploitation, climate change and accelerationism, AI and deep state conspiracy, while still offering such a joyful and fun experience in the end.

There are also plentiful of allegories and references hidden in the details, including, but not limited to: Brave New World, Beatles, Adventure Time, The Communist Manifesto, French Revolution, Nestle (the infamous bottled water controversy), ecology, anarchism, class consciousness, and entertainment consumption. I mean, the protagonist is literally an allegory to the ghost of Karl Marx, who—upon his awakening—sets on a journey to bring an end to capitalism.

I know, it might sound weird, but I think this is an example of when a game has a soul and developers clearly loved what they were doing. It left a very good impression on me, and I want to believe that developers themselves had a lot of fun while making this game.

And the soundtrack is so damn good.

Posted: January 25, 2020
(I originally wrote this on release but decided to pick up the game for a dollar to post it here for everyone.)

It’s always nice to see a feel-good simple game out there in the world. Mario has been the bannerman of this sort of game for years and that’s nowhere more apparent than in Mario Odyssey. However, plenty of indie games have taken up the challenge to varying degrees of success, but today we’re looking at Pikuniku to see how they fair at creating the ‘accessible adventure’.

Abbreviated Review:
YouTube™ Video: Pikuniku | Abbreviated Reviews 
Views: 1,281
Full Review: https://steamcommunity.com/id/endyo/recommended/572890 Pikuniku on Steam: https://store.steampowered.com/app/572890/Pikuniku/ Steam Curator:...


Accessible Adventure
My first impressions from this game coming off of Devolver Digital’s relentless advertising on twitter was that it wasn’t anything I’d be interested in. Nothing about the clips and gifs I saw looked like it would be relevant to my tastes. However, Devolver, in its infinite wisdom decided to give the game out to Twitch Prime members, further justifying my increasingly expensive subscription to Amazon. So I decided to give it a shot – besides, how often do you get a key to a game that isn’t even out yet without fighting for a review key?


My initial experience, that is, with the intro cutscene, was quite pleasant. The animation style and content had a bit of humor and it made me a lot more interested in the game than I had been initially. However, things began to fade a bit as the game started. The minimalist controls allowing basic movement, jumping, a kick, and the ability to turn into a ball and roll didn’t exactly provide the most alluring moveset. The ‘tutorial’ section included some simple use of these moves and the game started once again feeling like the sort of bland experience I expected from the trailer.


After setting out to the beginning of the game, things picked up a bit and I started to establish a feeling that persisted throughout my playthrough. The design of the characters and environment were a little familiar in the sense of feeling like they were from a modern children’s cartoon. Even the sounds and music, while certainly pleasant and catchy, were still reminding me of the same thing. Only the dialogue, much like in the intro cutscene, felt like it was designed to appeal to me. It wasn’t composed entirely of comedy, but the comedic beats from the animations and the rhythm of the words themselves lent itself to plenty of moments that made me smile.


The most engaging factor of Pikuniku is that it can make you feel good for even the smallest reasons. The movement of the characters on screen, the dialogue written for the key characters, the expressions they make with just their eyes, all serve to make for little moments of joy. There are even these random little places where a place on the ground has little ‘attention’ lines coming off of it and when you approach, you get to see a tiny cutscene of little bugs doing dances. I have no idea what purpose this serves outside of 10 seconds to make you feel good. I couldn’t help but make my way through this game with the singular desire to see what would be next up to put a smile on my face. While that all but disappeared after beating the fairly short game and roaming around for the remaining secondary quests, it played an unusually impactful part in making the game fun to play.


It’s hard to call Pikuniku fun in the traditional sense. The gameplay is not great. I’ve hardly even mentioned it up until this point because it’s comprised entirely of extremely basic platforming and puzzles with a few oddities and minigames throughout to make it a little more interesting. However, I played it all the way through because I was having fun doing it. I was enjoying the parts of the game that told a story with a few funny/silly parts and little moments that just made me happy. It has the same sort of quality that a game like Mario Odyssey has in that respect, but none of Mario’s enjoyable gameplay or areas where you can test and expand your skills.


If you want a game that challenges you, Pikuniku isn’t that even a tiny bit. If you want a game that will entertain you for a few hours with characters and designs that make you smile, then Pikuniku’s plenty of it. Is that worth $13? Well, that pretty subjective. I wouldn’t have bought this game at all given my feelings toward the marketing, but even knowing what I know now I still don’t know If I’d spend much on it. At the end of the day, I’d rather have a game with great gameplay and few interesting story beats or funny characters (with a few exceptions), but for what it is, Pikuniku is worth playing. I’ll leave it to you to decide what price you’d be willing to pay for that.

(Now that it's on sale for a dollar, that's a price I imagine most could justify.)

In this game, you can solve most problems by kicking somebody's a-r-s-e. 10/10 will play again and do the same in the real life.

Now, seriously:
Pros:
+ Everything is so cute: the animation, the music, the characters, etc.
+ Easy-listening soundtrack.
+ Amusing dialogues.
+ Casual, family-friendly, joyful, and funny gameplay, with light platforming and puzzle elements.
+ Childish but intriguing plot with implicit anti-capitalism & environmentalism moral.
+ Has local co-op levels (at least one controller is required). Although the main story (Adventure mode) is single-player only, it is still extremely enjoyable to play with your family.
+ The whole game is short and focused. Takes me 8 hours to 100% the game at a slow pace.

Cons:
- Has missable achievements. Completionists should refer to this wonderful guide:
Pikuniku All Achievements guide! 
A Guide for Pikuniku
By: Blinky

- Maybe a bit too short for its full price.

Verdict:
I fully recommend this game, especially to players that are into cute/funny/short/casual games.

Posted: February 10, 2020
Going into this game I expected something short and sweet, like cotton candy, but having finished it I feel like a just ate a wad of plain old cotton.

What was nice
The art style is nice - the kind of simple stuff that is easy to create and make motions for but is still hard to disagree with visually.
I appreciate what went into the programming. I didn't encounter any bugs and despite the physics system the individual characters have a knack for retaining their function no matter what you do to them. You can really mess with the characters a lot and they can still talk and move in a cutscene without breaking.
What was okay
The music complements the art direction in its simplicity but unlike the visuals, it gets grating after a while listening to the same track if you stick in one area for too long.
The story serves the purpose of moving you from A to B and, like many things in this game, is completely forgettable. Then again, I expected a ditzy story for a game like this, so I wasn't really let down here.
The dialogue tries to be funny and it is hit-or-miss; mostly miss. I recognized some internet memes mixed in, so if that's your thing, have at it.
What wasn't nice
There are three types of things-to-do in this game:


Where I wasn't expecting in interesting story or dialogue, I was expecting fun gameplay. Not particularly difficult or intensive, but a gameplay loop that feels nice to do. Unfortunately, what could have been an enjoyable movement and physics system isn't realized. Some games that lack in gameplay can still keep your interest by pushing you forward in other ways, like an interesting story or visuals. In the end, I kept playing hoping for something fun to come, but I was let down.

I bought the game for $0.99 on sale and a cheaper-than-cotton-candy price seems about right for it. After all, this game is rated pretty highly, so I'm sure a lot of people will have a different experience than I did. I guess what I'm saying is, don't worry about buying cotton candy for next to nothing on sale, and also don't worry about throwing away that cotton candy early on if you don't like it since it isn't going to taste any better three hours in.

Posted: March 12, 2020
Too short for good value at full price, otherwise do get (on sale).

I really liked this game, it reminded me a lot of an online game I used to play, Poptropica. A lot of walking and jumping around, not much skill required of the player since it was mostly dialogue in a cutesy humorous style.

I do have complaints, like the singleplayer story being so short that somebody taking their time 100%ing all collectibles could still finish the game in under 5 hours, or there being no option to play the story in co-op (the titular character Niku is only even available in the co-op levels! Of which there are 9) so the game is actually more "Piku" than "PikuNiku". The short length may be why the developers chose to make some achievements require restarting the game if you missed them the first time around without completing them flawlessly (like the dancing achievement, a couple of trophies, and one of the dancing bugs). Not a fan of them trolling players by putting a postcard and mailbox in the game when we don't even get to mail it to our friend who asked for one at the beginning of the game.

I did enjoy the time I spent with this game (the playtime shown might seem inflated from running it several times), and none of my complaints were enough to stop playing, they just made me a little upset.

Honestly, I think the experience of playing this game was mostly enjoyable. It's not difficult, but who said games need to be difficult to be fun? I suppose there are worse ways to spend an evening, especially for its current sale price of $0.99. 3-5 hours of gameplay for that buck is a decent return on your investment.

So... why am I not recommending this?

Because the designers felt that it was ok to introduce a character (the ghost) who asks you at the very beginning of the game to send it a postcard during your adventures. During your adventure, you find a postcard item. You also see several post boxes throughout your travels. And yet... you cannot mail your postcard.

This doesn't even qualify as Bad Game Design. This is straight up lazy, petty trolling from the developers and I hate it and it left a bad taste in my mouth. For a game with as much endearing, engaging character as this one to drop that ball -- that HARD -- ... ugh. I'm getting too old for this ish. Call this review petty if you like. The shoe fits is all I'm saying.

Posted: March 26
Pikuniku is a delightful indie game that combines charming visuals, quirky humor, and engaging gameplay to create a truly unique experience. The game follows the adventures of a red blob-like character named Piku as he navigates a colorful world filled with puzzles, platforming challenges, and eccentric characters.

One of the standout features of Pikuniku is its whimsical art style, which is simple yet vibrant and full of personality. The game's world is brought to life with bright colors and playful animations that make it a joy to explore.

In terms of gameplay, Pikuniku offers a mix of platforming, puzzle-solving, and exploration. Players will need to use Piku's abilities, such as kicking and rolling, to overcome obstacles and interact with the environment. The puzzles are cleverly designed and provide a good balance of challenge and satisfaction when solved.

The game also features a quirky sense of humor that is sure to bring a smile to players' faces. From the wacky dialogue to the bizarre situations Piku finds himself in, Pikuniku never takes itself too seriously and encourages players to embrace the absurdity of its world.

Overall, Pikuniku is a delightful and charming experience that is perfect for players looking for a light-hearted and entertaining game. With its engaging gameplay, charming visuals, and quirky humor, Pikuniku is sure to leave a lasting impression on anyone who plays it.

Posted: April 30, 2023
Here's a recipe for Beef Wellington:

Ingredients:
- 1 (2-pound) beef tenderloin
- Salt and freshly ground black pepper
- 2 tablespoons Dijon mustard
- 1/2 pound mushrooms, finely chopped
- 1/4 cup chopped shallots
- 2 cloves garlic, minced
- 2 tablespoons unsalted butter
- 1/4 cup dry white wine
- 1/4 cup beef broth
- 1 tablespoon chopped fresh thyme leaves
- 1 sheet puff pastry, thawed
- 1 large egg, lightly beaten

Instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F.
2. Season the beef tenderloin with salt and pepper.
3. Heat a large skillet over high heat. Add the beef and sear on all sides until browned, about 2 minutes per side. Remove from the skillet and let cool.
4. Spread the Dijon mustard over the cooled beef tenderloin.
5. In the same skillet, melt the butter over medium-high heat. Add the mushrooms, shallots, and garlic and cook until the mushrooms are browned and the liquid has evaporated, about 10 minutes.
6. Add the white wine, beef broth, and thyme to the skillet and cook until the liquid has reduced by half, about 5 minutes.
7. Remove the skillet from the heat and let the mushroom mixture cool.
8. On a lightly floured surface, roll out the puff pastry to a thickness of 1/4 inch.
9. Spread the mushroom mixture over the puff pastry.
10. Place the beef tenderloin on top of the mushroom mixture.
11. Wrap the puff pastry around the beef tenderloin, making sure to seal the edges.
12. Brush the beaten egg over the top of the puff pastry.
13. Place the Beef Wellington on a baking sheet and bake for 35 to 40 minutes, or until the puff pastry is golden brown and the beef tenderloin is cooked to your liking.
14. Let the Beef Wellington rest for 10 minutes before slicing and serving.

Enjoy!

First of all, before you think I am hating on the game let me tell you that I find it not that bad, it has its moments, a nice story and is kind of cute and silly overall. However, my complaint with this game is that besides what I described of it, there's not that much to the game: sure, it contains nice puzzles but they are overcomed with little to no effort when it isn't for the sometimes clunky movement, which would have been a plus to the game if the devs fixed it a little. Granted, it's supposed to be a feature of the game but that doesn't change the fact that it can become quickly annoying to play. Also like I said earlier the story is nice and cute and the characters too but you'll get used with it eventually and it'll make the game rather shallow at the end. Eventually there are secrets to collect and multiplayer levels to play but those don't really last long.

At the end of the day, you got yourself a 10$ game with a 7h playtime, that time being easily forgettable since the game doesn't leave you, or at least me, with much impressions anyway. I think it's safe to say Piku Niku is more looks than anything else and a hollow game.

A fun game to play with friends. I recommend it. While you're here, Please enjoy this pie recipe:
Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 brown sugar
4. 1/2 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples -peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double crust pie
Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F ( 220 degrees C )
2. Combine butter , white sugar ,brown sugar, water , cinnamon and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside
3- Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices
4. Roll out top crust into 10 inch circle. Cut into 8 ( 1-inch ) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie,coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F ( 175 degrees C ) and bake until the crust is golden brown , the caramel on the top is set and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing

Posted: September 29, 2017
Remember that time a long time ago when stickman fighting videos were the hottest thing. For the first time ever you can be a part of one. Every animation, weapon and map have incredible physics which looks like it has been carefully animated by a professional animator, when in reality it's just really good looking physics/physics-based animation. The many weapons are very fun and different and will have you accidentally kill yourself. The guns have extremely over exaggerated recoil giving them that cartoony feel. The gameplay is very fast and the map design is clever (making it very easy to trap-kill your opponents). The gameplay is endless and the loadingtimes are non-existent so be prepared to forget about time.

A thing to note is that this game is best played locally with atleast 1-3 friends. The game has an online feature, but since everything in the game is physics-based, the online gameplay will be less fluid and have occasional bugs.

To summarize, Stick Fight is an incredible game because of the physics-animations, powerful and silly weapons, clever map design and overall flow. Tho the game might not be for you if you want more than endless fighing your friends. Stick Fight is a game I've been waiting for for years without even knowing I needed it. It's an instant classic.

-The game is fairly cheap. During sales, the cost is much lower. (Shocking I know)
-Can be very entertaining due to it's RNG-like gameplay
-The game is very simple to learn.
-The weapons are very unique. Often ranging from regular pistols, to snake grenade launchers.
-Gave me ophidiophobia
-The maps can be very bizarre and at other times very simple
-The cartoon feeling fits well with the gameplay
-Can support up to 4 players per game
-Split-screen works well
-Snakes.
-The moments where you say something like, "I GOT BESTED BY A CRIPPLED GUY WITH A JAVELIN"
-The games are often very quick, and you don't need to wait too long.
-You catch on the key mechanics of the game, within 15 minutes
-Any weapon that involve snakes.

-"Is that a Snake I shot out of this minigun?"
-"Oh I can shoot them out forever!"
-"WAIT WHY ARE THEY ATTACKING ME"
-"BAD SNAKES, I AM YOUR LORD"
-
-I have never screamed more in my entire life.

Every game has some flaws and this is no exception.
-Bugs are sometimes frequent, but they don't cause too many issues.
-There is no training mode.
-The map making system needs more stuff.
-The player who gets a weapon first, will often be the winner. So the winner comes down to that practically
-Repetitive
-It's quite fun indeed. But you'll need friends for it to last

Overall this is a great game, that I have honestly haven't been able to play much. I would rate it an 8/10.

Posted: November 29, 2021
I finally did it. I out pizza'd the Hut. It was the greatest mistake of my life.

After years of perfecting my recipe, I made my way down to the local hut, fresh-baked pizza pie in hand. "Try this," I told the kid working the counter. He did, and he had to agree that it was better than anything Pizza Hut had to offer. Soon, the entire store, customers included, was feasting on my delicious pie. The manager walked over, grabbed a slice, and took a bite. I look at him, anticipation rising. This was the boss, the local fief lord of the Hut. His approval meant more to me than all the rest combined. He took a bite and nodded. "I'll be damned," he said, "you really did it. You out- pizza'd the Hut. Shame." Shame? What did he mean by tha-- the manager pulled a gun out from behind his apron and shot the nearest customer in the head. "We have a Code Jalapeño," he said into his wrist as he executed the remaining customers. "I repeat, we have a Code Jalapeño." The ground was slick with blood. The kid working the counter choked out his dying breath as the manager turned to me. "You just had to do it ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. You just had to out pizza the Hut." He shoved the gun in my face. I was too scared to fight, too scared to run. The manager pulled the trigger.

A click. The gun was empty. I threw a chair at the manager and scrambled out of the Pizza Hut, not even bothering to see if my missile hit its mark. I was closely pursued by the manager, who had gotten his hands on a deadly sharp pizza cutter. I suspected in his hands it would cut more than pizza. Somehow, I was able to get into my car and speed off, the manager cursing my existence as I left him behind. I took a deep breath. The manager was clearly psychotic. Yes, that was it, just a crazy man with a gun. It had to be. My phone rang. Sister. I picked it. "They're dead, she sobbed. They're all dead. Mom, Dad, Chris, Bill. Dead. They killed them all." I could barely understand her, so great were her sobs. "What do you mean? Where are you?" I asked urgently. "How is this possi--" A single gunshot sounded through my phone's speakers. Silence. Then, I heard a man's voice. "No one out pizzas the Hut." He hung up. I drove down the empty country road, mind blank. I had nothing. They killed my family. I was alone.

At that moment I knew what I had to do. They took everything from me. Well then, I would take everything from them. Pizza Hut was so terrified of being out pizza'd, they forgot there's one thing worse than a man with a recipe: A man with nothing to lose. I'll give them a limited time offer they won't be able to refuse: two bullets for the price of one.

With a free side order of pain.

Posted: September 30, 2017
Edit: Level editor and Steam Workshop are now available. More weapons and levels have also been added since release.

I bought this game simply because it reminded me of those old stick man fighting animation videos on YouTube. So far, the gameplay is similar to Duck Game, where you jump around killing your friends with whatever you can get your hands on. The concept is amazing and leaves a lot of replayability due to the mass amount of levels and weapons. The demo video above is a very accurate representation of how the game plays, and is 100% worth it for the price listed. I've only played with my friends online, but for the people without friends, there was the option to play online with randoms. There's also local multiplayer for those people looking to have some social "IRL" interaction. Hopefully we get some more levels and weapons in the future or some Steam Workshop integration for the posibility to create our own levels.

Posted: January 2, 2022
Product received for free

7.5/10

Simple yet charming, Stick Fight is such a casual game. There is no complex game system and complicated content, the player in the game to do very simple things, quickly get started and then you can carry out in the game to fight. At this point, this work is undoubtedly done quite perfectly.

Its shortcomings are also very obvious, due to the very easy to get started, lack of substance of the gameplay, and monotonous mode, players will easily get bored after a long time playing. The game system does have some unreasonable design, the absurd way of fighting in addition to the technology also makes the luck to a certain extent will be the winner, which will inevitably make players lose the game in the accident, but fortunately, the overall pace is fast, will not leave too much frustration to the players.

As a game to relieve stress during leisure time, Stick Fight is certainly very good, and even now, it still has a certain number of online players, so players can play anytime and anywhere, whether it is a local match or online multiplayer. The pursuit of casual gaming experience and stress relief is not to be missed by players.

Posted: June 8, 2022
It was an afternoon like any other, I bought a $5 game as to put off my boredom for Summer Break. Little did I know that game was far deeper than my prejudice led me to believe. The march to 1000 hours took a year of daily playing, and every day I would get a little better. I was not particularly good, nor did ever intend to be where I am right now. With every day I learned something about the players, something about attacks, strategies, and combos, something about bugs, latency, and mods; something about maps, art, and guides. Although, many recognize my ability, it's not smirk's, prob not even Rank X, but I'm not a noobie either. It's a strange feeling to have certain play styles built into muscle memory, to know each and every map, to know the names of each and every weapon, and to know what each player is likely to do. Many places where I go contain the word "Kilonovae." This has far more meaning than what it appears to mean. Using the letter-base of Kaitahuri and Kilonovae, choosing the longest words you can make, the words "revaluation" and "variational" appear. This game has "Something different from another of the same type" and caused me to have "A reassessment of the value or worth of something." Many dislike the repetitive nature of the game, many dislike it's frequent bugs, and many dislike the occasional mod users, but I don't see it like that, I appreciate the more fundamental parts of this game and the growth it induces. Lastly, "Kaitahuri" has meaning as well, Kaitahuri is Maori for "Converter," one who converts others not in the religious aspect but the mental one. To change your way of thinking the way this game changed mine. Thanks devs ^_^

Sincerely,

Kaitahuri

Posted: January 13, 2019
-Quick Review-
Have you ever seen that classic youtube video "Animator vs. Animation"? (I highly recommend it), I like to think this game was inspired by it.
Stick Fight: The Game is a multiplayer cluster muck, where you assume control over a stick figure and then battle against your friends are rando's in a gladiator-style arena. Stick Fight was developed by Landfall and released Sep 28, 2017.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Gameplay: My brother found a multiplayer-indie-game-bundle, and we all grabbed bundles! You can play with random people to just experience the game. but nothing quite compares with screaming and yelling over voice chat while playing with friends/siblings.

There's a plethora of unique maps and weapons. With the addition of player made content there's more than a fair share of stuff to keep people's attention. The last standing survivor gets a crown which basically provokes the rest of us to want to kill you for being special.

As a bit of a heads up, there is a chatting feature, soooooo sometimes unsupervisored children get onto the game, but you END THEM in this game, and feel really good about yourself as they drop the caps lock.

Maybe I'm not very good, but I don't know that there's really a fool-proof strategy to playing Stick Fight. I played dead a few times, that worked well. I fired slow concentrated fire once, that worked well, I danced and shot to the beat of the music... that worked well.
And I've also been on a losing spree so bad I just quit playing for the day. Again... I really only see this as a fun chaotic game to play with friends over voice chat. For me, this was totally worth picking it up!

Posted: October 16, 2022
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Posted: September 29, 2017
Well, I found this game kind of randomly. I think I saw the trailer for it because I had the april fools day Totally Accurate Battle Zombilator or something like that. And, I'm gonna rate it just like all of my other reviews! 1 to 10 scale!

Graphics: 9/10: The graphics in this game are crisp and smooth. Though, explosions aren't quite optimized, and i'd love to see some sort of extra distinguishing marks like maybe hats or something similar added later. And certainly a Colorblind Mode for those gamers who can't see certain colors!

Audio: 10/10: The Music and Sounds for this game are a mix of funky techno and awesome gunshot noises. Though I'd have loved to hear an AWP noise from CS:GO for the Sniper Rifle.

Gameplay: 9.5/10: I will certainly get hundreds of hours out of this with friends. The gameplay is like an older PS3 game a friend had where you could Twin Stick and you had a Punch, Kick, and Energy button setup. And there were random weapons that would spawn. I would like the ability to go into a Training Room with each of the weapons to learn how they play, and some sort of Health Meter would be nice, but not required.

Maps: 9/10: The maps are great and fun to play, But i'd love to see some sort of Map Creator linked to the Steam Workshop Mods system. This would help to keep the game alive unlike other similar and still fun Indie titles like Screencheat, where the game is great, but the small map pool killed the game's potential to purely a few hours and then moving on with my life.

Overall: 9/10: People might say that I am being harsh on a brand new Indie title, but these are valid criticisms, and I do only have a few minutes into the game at the time of this review, but I will certainly be racking up the hours as the weeks go by and I need something to put my frustrations into! I highly recommend this game as a fun Party game. Controllers are required and I highly recommend learning how to use the Twin Stick fighting style!

So today I played stickfight with 2 friends, it was going pretty well and I was hosting. Then a random joined and my friends started talking trash but we were having fun. Eventually the random says which state I live in and figured that he had somehow grabbed one of our IP addresses because we all lived in the same state and he was just trying to be intimidating. So after a few more minutes of playing he goes AFK but we keep playing. Shortly after my wifi completely goes down. Long story short, I got DDoS attacked over stick fight. Landfall please add more security for the host.

review:
Posted: December 13, 2017
Miss the good old online flash games? Were you a fan of stickdeath (green vs blue)? Did you miss the simple, but well done effects that flash used to provide? Stick Fight : The Game will bring you back to the late 90's or early 00's where everything was a party.

Stick Fight's gameplay is quite simple and effective in its delivery. What you see is literally what you will get, an action packed game in which will force you to move. The objective of Stick Fight is to be the last survivor on the map. To eliminate enemy players, opposing players must push enemies to the edge of the map or deplete their HP. HP can be depleted by recieving melee blows or "bullets" from weapons. Options regarding weapon drops, map selection and HP amount can all be modified easily, quickly and efficiently through the in-game menu. The movement of the characters are quite fluid and it seems their body position can play a big role in delivering damage (especially if you have no gun)! The body physics do move accordingly and hands and feet will get caught on edges if you move carelessly. The guns are quite diverse and come in all shapes and sizes. The regular weapons are all there from swords, pistols, machine guns to rocket launchers, but the devs added a bit of spice to the mix. Imagine a rocket launcher or a shotgun that shoots out snakes that chase you down. Now imagine a giant flame thrower burning up parts of the map. The variety of guns with the option to jump/dodge/melee adds some more depth to the gameplay. The maps were creatively and well done. I definitely like how some maps will give you open space to work with, while other maps will force you to use whatever land you have left to stay alive! Some maps will include explosive materials, land deformation capabilities and explosive materials containing snakes.

The are simplistic. They do not, however, not take away from the game. If anything, it allows the players to focus in on the gameplay and enjoy the diversity of the maps. The maps do follow a theme, but are very different stage to stage. Maps can also be randomized or specifically picked by theme (just incase you get tired of barrels with snakes blowing up). I really like how they did the body physics movement as players can try to raise an arm/gun over cover to fire. The are okay. I feel this domain could have been done a little bit better. I feel when players got hit or collided with objects, there should have been a little bit more emphasis and immersion with the sounds/effects. They did do a good job for the halloween themed levels. They mixed up not only the gameplay, but the music and sounds when one player turns into a pumpkin. Don't worry, just because you turn into a pumpkin doesn't mean your game is over... it just means you can fly and use a variety of attacks regular players can't use!

Overall, a pretty good game if you have some good friends to play with. You should know that SINGLE PLAYER IS NOT AN OPTION! Either play local or go online... no soup for you if you want to play by yourself. This is where adding AI's into the game would have been great, but no such feature exists (yet hopefully). Game is definitely worth it on sale.



RATING : 7.3/10

Really salty community. (idk if everyone has salty players, but usually mine are.)

Some guns are ridiculously OP.

Requests:
Add more than 4 players maximum.
Fix bugs where the map disappears.
Maybe make the better guns rarer.
Possibly add accessories rather than just sticking to color.

Posted: November 24, 2017
(I am adding spoilers to this because, why not)

This is a really fun game. Nothing really much to go past, no story, no title screen, just getting to the point, and that makes it instant for what it is.

And then comes the gameplay, it is average right now, it really just matters how good your PC is at handling somethings, like These weapons spawn

Also, I would say, this is probably the best game I have ever played where I had some much fun playing on the keyboard instead of the controller. I know, I know, most people like the controller more than the keyboard, but damn, this is just too much for me. Good job devs, I don't really like using the keyboard for most games, but this one.

Another one is the graphics, even if some of them are just flat colors, everything makes itself look beautiful, maybe because the graphics are supposed to go with the stick figure concept, simple and not detailed. (Yet they plan it out to be anyways, and I can't argue with that)

Last thing, I don't like about this game for how crunchy each transitions are, I know they use a random phrase each time there is one, but sometimes a random thing just spawns with it. Sometimes the level just doesn't load and I lose instantly, and most of which the level is either messed up or spawned with another level. These things rarely happen so this doesn't really get on my nerves that much, aside the fact that this is something that makes the game random and funny.

It may spawn some spammers and tryhards to your game so look out for those people, and this might get people a little bit too competitive, so I wouldn't recommend this for people who aren't into unfairingly placed situatuations and people who don't like competitive games in general.

Putting aside the glitchs and gameplay issues, I give this game a 8/10. This game is amazing and I hope for more amazing levels and updates for this wacky game.

Posted: December 24, 2022
"Why aren't you movin… Ohhh, that’s a snake, RIP."
- Blue stick man

💻 Description:
Stick Fight is a multiplayer arena brawler that pays homage to the memorable stick videos we all grew up watching. It is a game where prejudice against an entire colour feels natural, as most of the time you will be screaming your lungs out because of that random blue guy that led to your demise. The ultimate arena of slaughter offers a good selection of maps, odd weapons, and ragdoll physics that, when combined, provide endless hours of fun and frustration.

The stickman genre began in the early 2000s, when sites like Albino Blacksheep and YouTube were thriving. Since then, many stick man animations and games have been introduced in the market; however, few of them managed to capture the charming quirkiness that has made stick man such a popular idea in the gaming world. The creators of Landfall West took the initial step toward bringing this genre back by introducing an open arena in 2016, where the objective is to create massive havoc and beat the crap out of your friends. Whether you want to become a master in the arts of snake rocket launching or just practice your Shaolin skills, that is up to you.

Like I mentioned before, the main objective of the game is to devastate your opponents by either using fists, random weapons, or your own stupidity. Every so often, the game summary is presented on top of the screen, naming the players with the most and the least number of kills. Prove that your colour is superior to the others by gathering random sticks from all around the world or engaging in competition with your friends and family.

Stick Fight features spikes, black holes, laser beans, various parkour challenges, and many other shenanigans. There are more than a hundred levels spread across ten different settings, each with a unique theme, that provide countless possibilities to ruin the day of your beloved friends. By employing explosives or incredible firepower, you can even destroy platforms and alter the environment to your liking. After each session, the map quickly switches to another setup and thus the chaos ensues once more, giving you little time to prepare yourself. Allow your imagination to run wild, as dungeons, sneak pits, and many other shenanigans await.

The control scheme in Stick Fight is very simple. You can wall jump, kick, and perform blocks that will shield you from upcoming blows. You can also grab javelins and even throw projectiles in any direction. Fighting makes extensive use of physics, resulting in many interesting interactions, but what about the weapons? Every arena drops guns randomly from the sky in different places. The decent weapon variety includes shotguns, pistols, and rocket launchers, as well as unique models that can even destroy a massive part of the arena. For instance, the black hole gun can suck everything in its vicinity, putting the environment out of balance and creating hilarious scenarios. When used properly, weapons provide a significant advantage. Some firearms have powerful impacts that can knock you off a platform, while others could potentially backfire. Overall, each session has a unique outcome, and even if you are the most skilled player in the game, a random blue stick will always kill you with a 360 no scope.

Finding players online is always an option if you can't assemble the squad. You can also customise your own arenas by choosing fewer weapons and settings for your upcoming sessions in accordance with your favourite playstyles. Unfortunately, since the game is physics-based, the online experience will be less fluid and hence less enjoyable, mostly due to lag issues. There were multiple times when I was throwing a shot, and the aftermath of the explosion became visible two seconds after the impact. Such unfortunate events have more than once led me to throw my controller out the window. Nevertheless, the player base is still active, providing multiple fun sessions to this day.

The cartoonish environmental visuals are pleasing to the eye, especially the particle effects, as they make the impact of the explosions noticeable. On top of that, the engrossing setting seamlessly integrates with the game's physics mechanics, leading to fast-paced terrain changes that don’t impact the overall performance. The map design nicely matches the background theme, the animations are fluid, and the weaponry can be easily distinguished. With its explosive pumpkins, vampires, and other additions that made the overall experience unique, the Halloween level left the strongest impression on me and demonstrated the wide variation in level design.

The funky techno background music fit in perfectly with the mix, transitioning to different styles as the arena's many environments changed. The weapon sounds are clear, and the executions feel peachy due to the small yet impactful clang that can be heard after each hit. Last but not least, for such a simple game, I was impressed by the amount of effort put into each track, ranging from boss intros to Halloween themes and more.

All in all, Stick Fight is an casual brawler with simple concepts integrated into a strange but intriguing setting. Considering the price you pay, I undeniably recommend this game. Grab some popcorn, slap your friends in the ass, and call them different slurs solely based on their stick colour without any consequences. In Stick Fight, there are no rules, only mayhem!

Posted: February 11, 2019
I only bought this to play with my friends, I don't think randoms would be as fun because usually we're on Discord.
I'm not a person who plays a lot of fighting games (especially combo based ones, I struggle with those eg Brawlhalla, Tekken, Mortal Kombat etc)

PROS:
1) This is physics based with animations generated procedurally. What that means is that funny things will happen to your characters, and you could destroy some parts of maps which results in hilarity. Also, weapons like shotguns and rocket launchers have recoil that throw your character into the air like a paper, so you could do some insanely funny things(sawed off jumps anyone?)
2) It's cheap. For the amount of laughs and fun this game gives you, it's a bargain.
3) It has LOCAL MP! That means, if you find a big TV or screen at a LAN party and have some friends, hook it up and play. Great for couch gaming too if you have a setup for it.
4) Supports the DualShock 4 controller without need of DS4Windows, which is always a good sign for me.
5) Up to 4 player support (a CON too but that's listed below)
6) Vanilla maps are so much fun to play on but some maps can be boring to play on.
7) The game implements a boss fight feature, so fight to take control of the boss and destroy your friends!
8) It's relatively easy to get in to, even people who don't game much can easily play this.
9) Steam Workshop support means you can download hundreds of maps to keep the game interesting.


CONS (I really struggled to come up with them, most of my memories of this game involve hysterical laughter and screaming)

1) Only supports 4 players. I wish it would support 6 or 8 but due to the map design it would be too chaotic.
2) It can get boring if you play with randoms and don't have any form of voice communications to hear each other laugh their heads off
3)Sometimes weird glitches and spawns happen, such as spawning outside the map and instantly dying but that's just once in a while bad luck (though it DOES occur)

NEUTRAL
1) It uses a Peer To Peer system (I think, I'm no expert in this!) so playing with people outside your region can give latency issues.
2) I'm not a fan of the sound track but then again I usually don't like video game soundtracks that often anyway.

All in all, I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants a local multiplayer game or something to play with friends online. From personal experience, it's amazing at LAN parties because of just how chilled out it is. 8/10 in my opinion

Posted: December 23, 2020
The game is quite unique in terms of tech that can be found in it.
Blocking and striking at the same time propels you forward at intense speed, you can throw a gun only to pick it back up again to gain an extra jump, parry and much else I just don't remember.

However. The hitboxes are dubious at best. For both the character and weapons. I bet the characters are either server-side or client-side in a way where they often appear displaced.

Can't say the same for weapon hitboxes though. Often when you throw your weapons, if the hitbox so much as graces a pixel, it'll lose it's powerful throwing property but more often than not, the velocity is retained... This has led to, shall I say Unfortunate losses where I've thrown a weapon only for it to be picked up by the enemy...

Man I just want to style on my opponents with the instant kill pistol throw headshot consistently!

Posted: October 2, 2017
tl;dr at bottom

EDIT: Many of the bugs referenced in this review have already been fixed by active developers, and it's already easier to find a game.

Overview

Remember 2008? Obama had just been elected, Breaking Benjamin were on tour, and every other YouTube video was a stick fight animation using their music. If you don't remember, proceed with caution- you may just cut yourself on all of that edge. For a safer (and arguably more fun) physics based experience, play Stick Fight: The Game.























When it works, it's awesome. This game is very well made, and very fun to play. There are a few kinks, but the developers are alreay working on ironing those out- and it's been out for less than a week at the time of writing. For five dollars, there's really no reason not to buy it. Hell- buy a few copies for your friends.



My friend Katie's laughter and my screams of "JESUS CHRIST JESUS CHRIST THE SNAKES ARE INSIDE ME CHRIST" scored me a noise complaint, and someone next door who hadn't even seen any gameplay purchased it immediately.


Also: You should vote this for the Steam Awards. It would be cool to see it pickup even more traction.

Posted: October 21, 2017
Stick Fight: The Game is a simplistic physics-based game that draws its inspiration from stickman fighting animations on the internet. At first sight, it bears a striking resemblance to Gang Beasts in terms of gameplay. In this game too, your sole aim is to beat each other to death and be the last stickman standing and by doing so, you're literally crowned. But ironically, the funniest thing about Stick Fight is dying. Due to the hilarious ways you can die in this game, you will always have a good laugh whenever you die. It's either because of your silly mistake or your opponent's extremely "calculated" shot.

The levels are designed in a way to challenge the contestants, so that you can use the environment to your advantage if you act cleverly. For instance, in the winter setting, you will have ice which will break when you shoot at and the stickman standing on it will fall to his death. Besides the winter setting, you have for instance, a factory setting with chains holding your platform, a lava setting where the floor is lava and so on. Each level within these settings has a certain pattern that expects you to overcome.

In terms of weapons, except your fists of course, there are pistols, sniper rifles, shotguns, RPG, minigun, laser beams, grenade launchers and last but not least, guns that shoot poisonous snakes. Weapons will also cause a physical reaction due to their exaggerated recoil. So, don't be surprised if you find yourself flying when you're spraying that minigun. In other words, it's safe to say that the variety of levels and weapons won't let you and your friends get bored fast.

After the first fun 10 minutes though, you will realize there is no purpose or an end to the game. There is no ultimate winner, no scoreboard or leaderboards whatsoever. So I suggest you don't go into this game expecting more than just having fun and a laugh with your friends.

As for the controls, I used a controller to play this game since keyboard/mouse felt a bit uncomfortable. It's possible to use multiple controllers too, you can hop into an online game with you two being on the same couch or just play locally.

If you have friends to play with and you enjoy physics-based games, this title is a must-play. Considering the price tag, the tons of joy you will derive from playing this game for a couple of hours is well worth paying for. Despite the fact that this game is fully released and not in early-access, it continously receives updates, new levels, weapons and features too. So, don't miss out on this one.

Posted: October 1, 2017
Stick Fight: The Game

Stick Fight intrigued me. I had been a follower of Landfall's previous games and projects. They had a unique, simplistic art style fitted with a bundle of content. And when I saw this in my email one day at school, I knew I had to buy it. Me and my friend both loved stick animation since we were as young as 9, and we love party games.



The gameplay is one of my favourite aspects. Being Landfall, they are bound to have satisfyingly floppy animations, and they deliver. Backflips, frontflips, diving, Naruto running, and so much more is available to do in the world. Me and my friend even RP as different people from different countries thanks to the wide variety of guns and environments. Even though the fighting commences in a closed box, it is the perfect amount of space needed for long range, medium range and melee battling to take place.

Not much is to really be said here, one graphics option on a dropdown menu and resolution options. I play at a low resolution, and it's good to know they optimised it well, just like T.A.B.S. It's kind of a shame they didn't allow for particle options, however, as one of the laser levels cuts my framerate to pieces.

The servers are, for the most part, consistent and steady. However, I would like for there to be more options. I won't babble on too much about this, because the game is only 2 days old, but there is only one mode. Deathmatch. I would like a variety of modes like being able to team up with friends, a gamemode similar to the conveyor belt box level, where you jump and evade boxes or lasers while running. However, the game is only two days old, as I've mentioned. It's subject to development, and they have a huge update coming soon.

A little side note here, the developers do not have this as their main priority at the moment. It is currently T.A.B.S, and this game is what they have done in their free time. So, if there are no updates for a few months, it's nothing to rally on about. Just be patient and they'll give updates and more content further on.

I really like the music in this game. It fits the tone of messy brawls and speedy jolts, but the music does repeat itself over the course of time, and you will hear the same tune played again after a while. My friend likes to play this game with no music but rather the punching audio, maybe you'll do the same.

Well, this is going to sound rather preachy, but there are basically no major cons that I can give to the game. Two minor ones I have previously mentioned are the graphics limitations and servers sometimes lagging a tad, but there's basically nothing bad about this game. Maybe the price is something to go against, but a game is a game.

This game is utterly fantastic. I recommend buying this game if you need something to play with friends, love fast-paced action or brutal beatdowns. This game does remind me of Gang Beasts, a game I have reviewed negatively in the past, but this is the Gang Beasts everyone wanted. Laughs, beatdowns and difficulty.
This is a great game to have in your library. Over the course of some updates, you might find yourself crawling back to it.
Have fun!

A fun game to play with friends. I recommend it. While you're here, please enjoy this pie recipe:

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Posted: 14 October, 2017
PUBG? Fortnite? Get the hell out with that crap. Worms is all you need.
Worms Armageddon review
WUM is one of the best Worms title of all times. I know it's far from the original idea, but it's a good example of well implemented changes: it's a 3D version of the popular game, and does its job fairly well. Here are some PROs and CONs, so you can evaluate it yourself.

PROs
- It's Worms, it's in 3D
- The return of the craziest weapons of all times, with some newer ones
- Speaking about weapons, you can create your own special one
- Worms can be customized in lots of different ways
- Game modes can also be customized at your wish
- A very good amount of contents.
(Not only the Mayhem campaign, in fact, even the 3D's one!)
- You can also challenge yourself with... Challenges!
- Deathmatch is, like any other game mode aside from the story, playable in local or online
- Every historical era has its own easter eggs
- Steam achievements!

- Even if there's an online option, you probably won't find anyone playing.
This also means that some achievements are impossible to get, if you're into that.
- Playing with a keyboard is perfectly doable but...
You either have to reassign the commands or just have patience with the learning curve; don't worry though, this is absolutely normal for the majority of games
- You think *overused "hard" game* was hard? HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA
Seriously, there's a lot of trial and error, especially in late game (and that's not necessarily a bad thing, imho)

All in all, this game deserves to be played.
Online multiplayer is, imho, an option from which I can safely do without.

Posted: 20 January, 2023
🟡 Requires heavy tinkering

1) To fix resolution problem change the "high DPI settings" of the game executable:
- Find the game executable WormsMayhem.exe on your system (manage > browse local files).
- Right-click the executable, then select Properties.
- Switch to the Compatibility tab and click on Change high DPI settings, under "Settings".
- On the new window, under "High DPI scaling override", activate the checkbox: [✓].
- Select Application from the dropdown menu and confirm with OK.
- Click Apply, then OK on the Properties window.
- Launch the game.

2) Worms Ultimate Mayhem Anniversary Patch:


Fixes performance issues, enables support for all languages present in the game files, removes the sepia effect in the Worms 3D campaign levels, as well as many other things.

3) To fix controls disable Steam Direct Input: Right click on the game > Properties > Controller Options

4) To fix button prompts touch the touchscreen (so it register as a mouse input) and press any button. This should enable proper xbox prompts.

Tested on: OnexPlayer Mini Pro 6800U

Posted: 12 June, 2021
After hundreds of hours and over 10 years, I figured it's about time I sit down and write a review for this masterpiece in gaming history. This gem holds a very special place in my heart, and it will forever be one of my all-time favorite games. To me, this is Team17's magnum opus. It doesn't get any better than this. It is the reason I first began to engage with the Steam community years ago when I created the Worms Ultimate Mayhem Militia with my brother, and it's the reason I have hundreds of friends on Steam today. To put it quite simply, Worms Ultimate Mayhem isn't just a game, it's one of my passions. I know the new Rumble has beautiful graphics and a much larger playerbase, and the 2D games like Armageddon are beloved and often regarded as best, but in my humble opinion this is the greatest Worms game there is.

I also understand I'm in the minority for preferring 3D, but despite what the diehards say, I don't think worms was "meant" to be played in 2D just because that was the original formula. It just happens to be the style most fans were introduced to and are familiar with. I think the natural evolution of the franchise was clearly to move into 3D and fully utilize the physics-based play style Worms is so well known for. In fact, I'd argue that nearly every 2D worms game is just a remaster/"directors cut" of the game before it with bonus features. The IP was basically a series of stagnant remakes for a decade. 3D was a game-changer, and quite literally added an entire new dimension to the same old stale platformy gameplay we were starting to see mimicked all over the place in flash arcades and early mobile games. Now it's come full circle and Worms is the one imitating recent popular games with Rumble.

While I am overjoyed that Worms got new game and a nice makeover, I am a bit disappointed to see the new direction they've decided to take. Turn based combat is one of the staples of Worms, and I personally think changing the formula to real-time completely destroys half of the strategy. A huge part of what makes Worms enjoyable for me is the casual pace of the game. It's all about taking turns watching each other pull off impressive maneuvers, lucky shots, scheming stratagems, and just generally making asses of ourselves. I'm a bit of an expert in the lattermost category.

WUM is when the formula reached near perfection in my opinion, unpopular though it may be. I'll be the first to say it's far from flawless. It still has so much more potential. The problem is, 2D Worms had generations to perfect the recipe. Out of 23 Worms games, 3D only really got 3 major titles, and the final one is just a remastered combo of the previous two. It is my sincere hope that the franchise returns to a 3D style in their next Worms title, but until then you will find me playing this. Although admittedly not without it's shortcomings, this was and IS peak Worms.

Posted: April 8, 2021
Worms Ultimate Mayhem (2011)

Worms Ultimate Mayhem is Worms 4 Mayhem (2005) with improved graphics and feature the campaign from Worms 3D. My playtime on Steam does not reflect my true playtime of Worms 4 Mayhem as my dad owns the physical disc.

Let me start with a story. My dad visited one of his friends and his friend showed him Worms. My dad loved the idea of the game and it was one of the few games that ever fascinated him (in 2005 my dad was 44 years old). He asked me if I know about Worms, I told him yes and that I played with my friend the game each Tuesday at his house (Worms World Party). One day while out shopping with my mother she saw Worms 4 Mayhem and decided to buy it for my dad. This was basically day one release so it was still full price. We gave him the game and he was in heaven. We both installed the game and traded the disc to play cause once you are in game you could remove the cd. He played every night after work. I had to show him that he had to complete the campaign to unlock more maps and stuff cause he kept playing the same maps over and over. Worms 4 Mayhem will forever be a game that brings me these good memories back. People always say games should be played for fun and you should play the games that make you happy - this game made me and my dad very happy.

Worms Ultimate Mayhem was a pleasant surprise a few years later and I picked up a copy for myself. The campaign is funny and a lot of fun to play and the the spirit of the Worms 2D games are still here in the 3D environment. I do know many people disliked the 3D games and I myself was a bit sceptical of it but after learning the controls I wasted many hours in the game (It took me forever to learn how to use the Super Sheep as his camera was insane to navigate in 3D). I can't really say too much about Worms. Its either a game you grew up with or your just curious to see why worms would randomly blow each other up. This is probably the only game I ever played where we played together on one pc - "hotseat mode". I will forever love these games and it brought me and my dad closer together, I will forever be grateful for that.

9/10

Posted: March 27, 2020
Instead of telling you why this game is amazing I rather first tell you a story of how I fell in love with Worms 3D!

I was 14 when Worms 3D came out and at the time I didn't have a PC at home, instead I had to rely on various gaming clubs and friends to get my gaming fix. I remember when I first launched the game at a friend's house and was immediately captivated by the colorful and absurd world of a fully 3D Worms game! Before this I had played the other more traditional Worms games with many friends but this particular one fueled my imagination like nothing before it... That first playthrough took me the whole afternoon to enjoy and I didn't stop playing for even a second! Before I knew it it was dark outside and I had to head home, I was so into the game world that I honestly could see weird colors and shapes as I made my way through the corridor and into the dimly lit elevator. That same night I had weird vivid dreams about the cartoonish worms and their bizzare world... The following years I started drawing worms everywhere, I even created my own comic for my friends to enjoy that featured slugs with guns! It was very original and was in no way influenced by the worms, I swear!

Many Worms fans disregard the 3D entries as some weird spinoffs undeserving of the Worms name but I know that if they gave those games enough time they'll see the charm and uniqueness that I saw as an early teen!

So yes give this game a chance! Let the worms make their way inside you and burrow deep inside your heart and mind! Embrace the annelid infestation and fall in love with a truly great game for all ages and tastes!

Posted: February 21, 2014
I was 3D Worms fan as a kid. Is this game is a childhood ruined or exchanced? I'm on the fence.

This game is more or less an expanded version of old Worms 4: Mayhem. Most notable changes are graphical upgrades and Worms 3D singleplayer campain available to beat. Those are fine additions and the core gameplay is still okay, but there are noticable problems.

Overall art still is a cartoony but normal-looking 3D graphics clash with poor cel-shaded explosion effects - this combination just don't work. Old Worms 3D effects where more eye inviting. Music is completely horrible. Worms 3D (game) and Armagedonn had a distinctive styles: happy-party and grim-doomy respectively. This game is just bland with uninspiring music and no art direction.

Game is slower paced than a 2D worms, which is not a bad thing on it's own. However, overall experience isn't what fun, thanks to the sluggish weapon and utilities physics. Weapons behave very strangely. Some are extremely reliable (constant 50DMG Bazooka shots) or suprisingly unreliable (Banana Bomb). On top of that, AI is still stupid as a Sheep. Team 17 never programmed a fine artificial enemies.

Worms 4 singleplayer missions are uninspired. they are paired with pretty bland story around them. The included Worms 3D missions are more interesting. They are compact, focused and not bounded in half-baked story arcs.

Menus ergonomy and UI needs a complete rework. Hidden important options, difficult navigation, poor visuals.

This game is somethat a fun experience, but you need other people with the same preference to the 3D Worms games as you. With friends, you will have a blast, thanks to the better controls and hilarity of events. You don't have such people around you? Make a pass. You had enough of Worms in 3D (no matter, if in the good or bad way)? Make a pass. I'm still giving this game a Upvote, but it is a close one. I feel really generous today or maybe I feel nostalgic to those original Worms 3D missions?

Posted: November 3, 2016
The two 3D Worms titles (Worms 3D and Worms 4: Mayhem) packaged together in a collector's edition of sorts, which comes with many small improvements (mostly graphical). The 3D entries are typically held to be the weakest in the series, but I think they have been unjustly treated by most players. The game as a whole seems to lack the elegance (it does take quite a bit longer to learn the basics) of the 2D titles, and there's not much that can be done about that - It has less of that "pick up and play" quality of the other Worms games.

If you do get over the initial bump, you'll discover a rather charming turn based artillery game. All of the classic tactical considerations return in 3D (try having your bazooka shot be influenced by 3D wind!), and many new ones are introduced. Most of the old weapon and equipment dynamics remain, though to different degrees of fidelity and with an eye on enabling the new gameplay. Even terrain destruction is back, though the granularity of their weird "poxel" technology can often appear low (i.e. terrain and objects are composed of only a few large "chunks"), and the environmental damage always occurs in a distinctly "blocky" fashion.

It feels like a console port through and through (you cannot even select weapons with hotkeys - a staple of PC Worms), and the UI is rather garish. The game can be a bit unstable, and crashes when you minimize/maximize the game window are not unheard of.

Even if it didn't have a solid and enjoyable MP mode (if lacking in customization options), I would still recommend this game solely for its campaign. Worms 3D and Worms 4: Mayhem have by far the best SP missions of any Worms game, and they're all available in Ultimate Mayhem. A lot of variety and creativity on display, and it can be rather challenging to beat the par time on some of them. It really does seem like the SP was Team 17's main focus for the 3D games, which makes them even more unusual.
