Posted: November 8, 2014
For the record my favorite Worms game of all time is Worms Armageddon. The art style, the game play, weapons, level editor, and game layout (options, theme, layout of menus) were all done right. This is when games were made to be bought once, and to be bought as a whole.

I saw Worms Ultimate Mayhem as a recommended game instead of Armageddon. The first thing that caught my eye was that this game was the 3D version of what I loved so much. I figured for the on sale price, I'll give it a shot. I can tell you that I am not at all disappointed with my purchase (except that Worms is still a turn based game! I wish they would make a real time one - how? Well I'm not getting paid to make or suggest games). Seeing worms in 3D is phenomenal, and the art and them style they chose to go along with the game just fits it perfectly. The game play is just as good as ever, however will take some time to adjust and get used to the new range/power system. I didn't know a worm could throw a grenade three football fields away from the map. Lesson learned.

Game play itself can be seen from first person or third person worm view. Weapons are varied as usual and are cool to use and shoot. The explosive or corrosive materials found around the map can also be used to eliminate your opponent. Does the 3D land disappear after you blow it up? Damn right it does. How are the camera angles? Actually quite consistent when using weapons, can be a bit confusing or frustrating when simply observing the map. I find that even with unchecking the inverse box for camera angles sometimes it turns itself back on. This is usually fixed by simply squaring the screen with the worm again. That's essentially the only complaint I have is the camera controls.

This game does have CONTROLLER SUPPORT - which is greatly appreciated. It can be a little choppy though... which can effect the level of you liking this game. It is a fun game - and can keep you busy for a while with the story, challenges, or just a quick match if you're able to work with the wonky/blocky controls.

For future Mayhem games (or 3D worm games), maybe try getting rid of the turn based system, or play around with allowing more first person type of play. Do something XCOM : enemy unknown would do (wait, take cover and fire at the enemy when in range) with worms the player isn't using. Also, please try to improve the camera controls!

(I did get this game on sale :)



RATING : 7.5/10

Posted: May 18
Worms Ultimate Mayhem is no doubt an evolution to not just Worms 3D (the game that brought the iconic strategic series featuring the charming worms full of character from the 2D realm over into the fancy new 3D world) but also further improving what the series has to offer as far as campaign story missions and character creation goes alongside other nifty features!

To start off here, seeing as this is the 8th game in the well-established series, (or 10th if you include the spin-offs Worms Blast and Worms Golf) Ultimate Mayhem brings out a whole new host of levels set across five different timelines in twenty five unique missions alongside three crafty tutorials and a bunch of extra challenges to boot, whereby the goal is as it's always been: To destroy the enemy worm team by any means necessary!

Though given that the story here has been given something of a 'make-over', seeing how the missions in all previous Worms campaigns had you do random stuff strewn across a multitude of different landscapes without any narrative coherence between one and the next, as Ultimate Mayhem brings time-travelling into the equation as you start off in 'modern' (though the game contextualizes it as the 'construction' period) where the game goes relatively easy on you at first before throwing in the harder challenges once you get into the four other time periods, that being Medieval, Wild West, Arabian and Prehistoric.

Now seeing as the gameplay transition from 2D to 3D was always going to be a bit of a challenge for Team 17 to rework here, I can hardly fault them for making it a tad on the easier side of things (believe me, I've tried the original Worms on Steam here and it's FAR more unforgiving even when you just have the 2D gameplay to worry about!) as I've always gotten the impression that both Worms 3D and this game were aimed at a more casual audience, people who enjoy the vast strategies offered in a destructive turn-based game such as the Worms series but often preferred to be introduced at a more 'gentle slope' so to speak!

Given how there is a lot more freedom when it comes to the exploration and navigation side of things, the AI still holds up well enough for the most part (although I say this primarily as an amateur Worms enthusiast) but experienced strategy gamers may find themselves disappointed when they put the AI to the test as opposed to messing around for fun since a key part of success in Worms games is positioning your worms in the best places for attacking the enemy as well as keeping them safe from as many types of attacks as possible, with how a safe tactic to winning many of this game's missions here is finding the quickest way for the enemy to be introduced to the blue depths of the water for a quick and easy kill! (Baseball bats are the easiest by far, with fire punches trading horizontal distance for vertical height and shotguns being weaker on the push side of things but granting you two shots instead of one)

Touching upon the character creation itself, Ultimate Mayhem adds more depth to the already improved formula of Worms 3D by allowing the player to fully customize their team members, going further than just the team's flag, voicebank and grave by presenting a wide variety of hats and wigs for worms to don on their heads, various gloves/glasses and moustaches/beards to don and even having their very own unique 'team weapon' that was introduced in this game which lets you create either a firearm, grenade or air strike of your own making, letting you adjust the damage to worms/land and strength of the blast itself alongside other various elements that are either positive or negative, seeing as Team 17 thankfully made a good job of balancing it so that you didn't make a god-tier weapon that could easily be made more accessible than the ultimate weapons featured in this game!

Speaking of which, the variety offered in this game is a point of contention for some as there is a smaller total of 39 unique weapons and tools compared to Worms 3D's more substantial 46, though given the new inclusions here such as Starburst that acts as a more versatile Kamikaze, Sentry Gun that acts as an automated turret that shoots at any moving worms within range with multiple cartridges per turret and Alien Abduction that puts a spin on the old Battle Axe by throwing in random teleportation and health gain/loss effects that can either benefit or harm the affected worms, it is debatable as to whether the loss of classics like the Homing Pigeon and Scales of Justice among others is worth the new weapons for some.

On the note of remasters, seeing as I have been referring to this game as 'Ultimate Mayhem' and not the original game's title 'Worms 4: Mayhem', the changes made to this version of Ultimate Mayhem include improvements to the graphics by updating them to High Definition standards, online multiplayer to take the strategic gameplay of Worms to the next level with real human players and a whole assortment of new challenges not previously in the original Mayhem game on the PS2 and Xbox alongside all the missions from Worms 3D! (Plus various Quality of Life updates to further refine the tried-and-tested gameplay of the series)

Truth be told, the game itself does hold up pretty well for the most part though, alongside the aforementioned issue of difficulty and less weapon variety compared to Worms 3D, I do have some problems with the AI not being as capable or as smart as they were in the 2D games which, whilst contradictory to a point I made about this and Worms 3D being more accessible due to being easier to find success in through it's less complex (and competent) enemy AI, I find ultimately detracts from any serious competitive gameplay as the only challenge you'll find outside of beating some of Team 17's own personal times on each mission is to play online with other players.

Sadly the online itself is it's own issue as, despite trying for well over an hour of constant waiting and fiddling about, I was only ever able to get one single match and no more, which itself is a shame as Worms Ultimate Mayhem has plenty to offer with it's 3D take on the dynamic strategic gameplay that this game provides, though it would seem that Worms Armageddon has the most popularity when it comes down to the overall fanbase.

In conclusion, Worms Ultimate Mayhem is well-worth revisiting here in 2024, seeing as it still has plenty of the iconic tactical gameplay that is rather unique to this series and, when combined with that charming Worms humour and all the new bonuses and additional content provided in the remaster, it holds up surprisingly well for a game that originally released almost two whole decades back in 2004.

Definitely worth a purchase in my eyes here!

TLDR Version:

• A return to 3D Worms gameplay with the remaster featuring HD graphics, online matches and the whole compaign from Worms 3D alongside new challenges being added (+)
• Fully customizable worms with dozens of hats, glasses, facial hair and gloves to make your team stand out alongside a creative 'team weapon' system exclusive for your team's use with balanced customizable parameters (+)
• Improved story with voiced cutscenes telling the wacky story of a 25 mission long adventure travelling across 5 unique time periods (+)
• Worms Ultimate Mayhem is more accessible to casual players as a result of the AI not being so aggressive coupled with more options to tackle opponents in the 3D world (+)

• The variety of weapons in Mayhem (39) is less than it's predecessor (46) which the remaster sadly does not fix with bringing classic weapons from the prequel (-)
• Ultimate Mayhem's AI is not as competent as it could be, resulting in less of a fun challenge for experienced veterans of the Worms series (-)
• Online is close to dead as finding matches with other players can take a long time without friends who also play the game (-)

Gotta give this game a negative review for two reasons. Controller support and the content from the older games it promised.

Normally I'd understand if a game doesn't have good controller support if it wasn't originally made for use with one. Or perhaps the game just doesn't lend itself very well for use with a controller. That's fine. But since this game includes levels the Playstation 2 game it should worked perfectly fine with my PS4 controller. Here it doesn't. They had all the resources to match it with that older game. The mappings included are horrid and trying to get it set up like it originally was is tiresome and still doesn't work quite right. The menus hardly work at all as well no matter my mappings. Plus without having the original game in front of me I don't know for sure how it used to be set up so I was never able to get it right. Plus I had to use DS4Windows instead of native support which shouldn't be needed.

Also speaking about that PS2 game, they included some of the levels from that game which was great. However they didn't include all the levels. I bought this game because I wanted to relive the PS2 days on a better system, my PC. And if they don't include that entire experience then I don't care as much for this version.

So yeah, this game wasn't what I was hoping for nor was able to be played very well and let me down.

Worms.
On the one day you choose to be the first worm, on another day you choose to be the second worm. You make use of the second amendment, you arm yourself with what is your very human right and you go out and fight for what you believe in: Liberty, Freedom of Speech, Sanctity of Jesus Christ and Federalism.

Worms is a tactical RTS strategy war simulation shooter where you take up arms with your worms and shoot onto other worms. You, the player, switch between what worms you play, arm everyone individually and go out to defend what you believe in by crushing your foes using your immense fire power.
This game is another symbolism of what is going on in the real world. A cry for help by the brave developers to the players, the citizens of the world and defend what is good and holy.

First of all, this game actively supports the right of a healthy minded citizen to bear arms. You get to see the actual destruction, the crushing power of your arms against those who want to take away your freedom, those who want to remove what you believe in by replacing it with something sinister and dark.
Do you, dear reader, believe in freedom of speech, in the right to exercise any kind of religion without having the state interfering with your affairs? Then this game is for you. You will go out, arm your worm and actively defend your rights.

The developer promises that for every shot fired in this game, a real shot against a globalist is done which means that with every worm you kill in this game, we make a step further in winning this war against the world government, against dictatorship and people trying to take away your rights.
You might ask yourself "Why should I play this game to do something that I do not feel the consequences for?" The answer is simple: America. You fight for it, no matter where you live and what you do, all the time, everywhere, always, anywhere. This game brings this right, this sacred ability to protect what you think is necessary and important to whole new level and this is exactly what we need.

Do not believe the mainstream media. I am just asking questions, why aren't you? This game is a gem in a massive pile of dirt, you need to acquire, you need to play, you need to study it.
Be the resistance, be the voice of freedom, be the winner of the infowar.

God bless America.

Posted: December 12, 2016
I have played Worms Ultimate Mayhem 3 hours and counting. I wanted to write this review well after Worms had been released, all of the DLC had been released, and when the modding community had really had a good opportunity to get a foothold in. Worms is an amazing game all in all. To those people who were giving this game 0's and 10's on the very first day it was released, within the first 10 minutes of playing, all I got to say is that those reviews don't help ANYONE. A game like this takes time to grow.
Gameplay
Gameplay probably features the biggest changes and improvements of the worms series. Improvements can be found from various aspects of the game, from combat, exploration, crafting and character building. Compared to Worms Reloaded, the combat is much more responsive, faster and dynamic. Enemy variation is amazing in WUM and it was often surprising to see new features and abilities added to already known enemy types. Crafting is one of the biggest and greatest part of WUM. As soon I saw the new crafting system of WUM in E3, I knew it was going to be great and sure wasn’t disappointed. With More Worms DLC you can also build your own robots, and go far as building your own kickass Sentry Bot. With the improved crafting looting and exploration became more important and rewarding. Junk rarity was also in great balance, I often found myself missing needed materials which then motivated me go out to explore the wasteland. With the new crafting system also came the settlement mode, which allowed players to create their own towns and settlements. To me the vanilla settlement mode was dull in many ways. Either way the settlement mode can a lot of fun with mods, allowing you to actually craft something genuine and incredible. The leveling and perk system was also redesigned. While there was nothing wrong with the previous system, the new system was a welcome change.
Atmosphere
In general, the atmosphere in WUM is subtler than in previous entries. Fast Food Dino felt much brighter and hopeful than the desolate Gibbon Take or Monster Bash. This is likely due to the more vibrant weathers. To improve immersion, team17 did a nice job of reducing the amount of loading screens. Abandoned towns now could be explored without having to struggle through the 5 second loading screen every now and then.
Story and Quests
I personally enjoyed the main plot, mainly because I didn’t expect much of it I got what I expected. Most of the main storyline was very good, it definitely had some memorable moments, difficult choices and the total length of the story wasn’t too bad. As for side content and quests, which were usually good but often hard to find. Radiant quests in WUM have a large role. The highly criticized voiced protagonist and the new dialogue system didn’t bother me, which did undoubtedly pose problems. But to me they were welcome changes, which felt like taking one step back and two steps forward.
Overall
While WUM did sacrifice some of its predecessors RPG elements, it still turned out to be one of the best open-world shooter that I’ve played. Worms did change for better or worse, but as for me, it’s still a Worms game, and a damn good one.

I never felt better charging the beaches with my Worm brothers. I quite literally cannot get enough of this game. If God were willing, I would play it every day for the rest of my life. I would start an entire e-sports branch dedicated to playing this exact Worms game. I would have my own team and would dominate my own competition. I beg of you, dear reader, to purchase this game for not only yourself but for your closest friends. I did and we have a bond stronger than diamond now. Stop wasting time playing lazy AAA games that are just recycled content every year. Instead, play this gem of a game. I promise, you will not regret it.

Worms Ultimate Mayhem is generally what people consider to be the best game in the series when they don't think armageddon, wwp or w2 are. And rightfully so, the prebuilt maps are a blast, and on this version of the game, the list of them is huge. I also like how the customisation here is much more depth than in any other game in the series. Name me one other game in the series that allows you to change your hands! (don't say worms 4 mayhem). Team weapons, flags, etc. I also enjoyed the campaign, lots of light-hearted humour and originality. One mission you're destroying wind machines in order to lure out a wizard, then you're escaping from a flooding dam that was blown up by the enemy, and taking care of them. You also have to protect the Professor in some missions too! Brilliant! I haven't got to play online much, but it doesn't seem very good. Sorry guys; you know what I'm going to say, online is a ghost town.
But the single player kicks so much ass that it makes up for this.

Btw guys, I found the speech bank that fits with the speech of your worms in the story mode cutscenes; it's 'Asbo Boi'. He's a dlc voice though, in the customisation pack.

Score: 9.1/10

- includes two campaigns to play if you want to enjoy the game without friends
-large array of maps all the way back from the original 3d worms game up to newer titles
-fun map destructibility

cons:

Posted: September 21
A surprise with the amount of enjoyment I got from this game. The 2 singleplayer campaigns this game compiles aren't "masterpieces" per se, but I would wager that they're among the few in this series that are actually worth trying.
The little stories that are built for each mission is quite charming and I think Team 17 achieved the peak of their humour here. The writing can be a little cheeky but most of all charming.
The map design also feels interesting with the particular settings and themes they include. There's also a lot of variety with how you'll see a different gimmick or objective on every other mission, that seems unparalleled in the series.
The only issue with the campaigns is how conservative missions can be on landscape destruction and degradation. Some missions you'll be able to create massive craters with explosives, and then there's some which don't allow that, presumably to make mission completion more carefree for the player, but it does feel at times like the game is neutered somewhat.

The transition to 3D feels well realised here. There's still some issues with the camera when hugging walls, but it does feel like the game is designed to accommodate this new camera angle in several ways to the player's advantage. The Worms games have a tendency to include physics that are equal parts humorous and frustrating, and this game executes that well here. I've had several moments where I make my worm jump but he bounces off the edge of some terrain and falls into the dreaded "drink" to drown. It's something you have to take into account like in any other Worms game.

Given how lukewarm some of the entries in this series can be, this one in comparison feels like Team 17 firing on all cylinders... well, that is until we consider the problems this port faces. This quality game isn't being maintained by anybody but passionate fans. So your vanilla experience may include weird performance, crashes (mine personally crashed twice on the Dracuworm mission), there's a bug on mission 6 of the Worms 3D campaign that makes it impossible to complete so you have to look around for a solution, and other such technical issues.
Somewhat reluctant on the thumbs up because of the above paragraph, but the core game is good fun so that's why I settled on the recommend.

If the 3D branch of the Worms series didn't irk you, then you will find this really is the ultimate edition. It has the Worms 3D campaign as well as a new one, and tons of other new features. My Xbox One controller is working quite well, although the game didnt tell me what buttons did what. You do need a mouse or keyboard to skip the launcher.

It's definitely a charming game. I really think it could have benefitted from a little cel-shading but otherwise, it runs great, and the destructable environments make things very dynamic. Of course, most fans feel like the move to 3D made the game too unreliable to play and I tend to agree, but I'm still enjoying it. It's just a very different game. You'll find arching lobbed grenades way harder, but direct line of sight attacks are much easier to hit. And it also gives you an indicator for when melee attacks will make contact, so you won't goof them up.

Good game here. I'll keep returning to it, but it wont replace the 2D Worms experience. It's a supplement.

Posted: June 14, 2017
This game means a considerable deal to me. Because of this I have held off on writing a review because I was concerned I wouldn’t be able to remain objective, but playing this game on and off for 11 years speaks volumes of its quality, convincing me that maybe I had something worth saying.

I grew up playing Worms. When I discovered Worms 3D on the GameCube my mind was blown. 3D felt like the next logical step in progressing the series forward. The Worms gameplay loop was as fun as ever and translated into 3D smoothly. It made the game feel bigger and better without jeopardizing any of the core mechanics that gave the series its charm. It was a little janky at times, but that contributed to the chaotic nature of local multiplayer. I got years of fun out of that game.

There were a few subsequent 3D entries in the series, and it provided the time to really develop the formula. Unfortunately the majority of the Worms player base seemed to prefer the 2D titles, generally citing the tighter controls and more predictable environments allowing for a more competitive multiplayer scene.

It’s impossible to say if this public sentiment is what stopped subsequent 3D titles from releasing, but when Worms left the 3D series behind, they left with a bang. Ultimate Mayhem provided the last little bit of polish the series needed to truly perfect the 3D formula. Everything there is to love about Worms is there and is performing at peak capacity.

The weapon selection is full of so much variety and allows for so much versatility. In combination with the randomly generated maps, no match will ever be the same as the last. The worms are more expressive and full of personality than they’ve ever been before or since. The iconic Worms comedy is—of course—present, and is so ingrained into every inch of the game that it’s impossible NOT to have a good time playing this game, even if you’re losing.

That’s just local multiplayer. We haven’t even begun to scratch the surface of what this game has to offer. Online multiplayer, LOADS of single player content; deathmatches, challenges, a full blown story mode, the ENTIRETY of the Worms 3D campaign in HD.

When all the game has to offer is laid out like this it makes practical sense why this game would be a good value, but the real reason I have kept playing this game for 11 years is because of how apparent the passion behind it is. Team17 went absolutely above and beyond to make this the biggest and best 3D Worms game, and that’s what allowed me to get to the point where I’m so biased about this game. It was good enough to make me buy an Xbox 360 when it released. It was good enough to spend countless hours playing match after match every weekend with the boys. It was good enough to make me purchase it a second time when I got a PC, and a third time when I got a PS3. It was good enough to convince me to 100% all the achievements TWICE.

I am biased about this game. But the quality of this game warrants it. Even now, 12 years later, no game has ever been more worth it to me. If we get another 3D Worms game I will be the happiest man alive. But if we don’t, I’ll just keep playing this game, and will keep adoring it.

Posted: June 28, 2018
A game series that got the transition from 2D to 3D right.
Ultimate Mayhem combines Worms 3D and Worms 4 Mayhem into one game and is an absolute content monster overall.
Two singleplayer campaigns with changing objectives in every mission
Challenge mode
Various multiplayer modes and options playable offline or online with up to three other players
50+ Multiplayer maps with the possibility to make your own or let the game generate a random one
Tons of options to customize your worms and create a team weapon for use in multiplayer
37 weapons and utilities, some new some from previous games

The controls are alright but need some tweaking before they are fun to use, controller support is serviceable.
One thing that is pretty subpar is everything that revolves around online play. Disconnects happen regularly and the player who's turn it is is always a few seconds ahead. Not a big problem in a turn based game but still annoying. The few seconds of wait time between turns also add up over the course of the match and make the game a bit less enjoyable.

Ultimate Mayhem offers three DLC packs which do not add all that much but one of them is free, the "Multiplayer Pack" has some of the best maps and the last one adds more customization for your worms. I'd say go for the Deluxe Edition.

If you plan on buying this for the multiplayer make sure you have some people to play with as otherwise you will have a hard time finding random people.

I recommend it as an easy to pick up game and rather unusual experience that is great fun in singleplayer as well as multiplayer.

Posted: 12 May, 2020
200 character summary
Overcooked 2 is an amazingly chaotic management game for up to 4 players, chop the ingredients and cook them as fast as possible for a nice tip, There are a ton of recipes and surprising kitchens.

Story & Characters 8/10
The story is set in The Onion Kingdom, The Onion King read from an old book and he summoned these undead loafs of bread called the Unbread, They are hungry and will consume the entire Kingdom if they are not fed in time. You play as one of the many available chefs and it is your job to feed the Unbread to save the world. The story plays out trough some dialogue from the king after certain stages, The story is nothing special, but it is a funny universe and it should give you a laugh or 2.

The Onion king his dog and all playable characters are extremely likable, They don't say much but they all look very funny, If you are a shark a mouse or something way crazier, It will have a friendly face. The enemies are a little disturbing but also quite funny, Undead loafs of Bread, It probably won't give you or your children nightmares.

The game is mostly focused on multiplayer, Every single gamemode can be played with up to 4 players, Online, Local but also a mix of the 2. You also can play it solo, But you will control 2 chefs and have to switch between them to manage the kitchen. it is still the same game, A very chaotic experience, Coordinating with yourself is harder than it sounds.

There is the Story mode, which brings you to an overworld where you can launch levels, You start in 1-1 and before you can start 2-1 you have to visit the castle and talk to the Onion King. There are 6 worlds in the main campaign, and every world has 6 levels. There is a ton of DLC, some free and some paid which bring a bunch of new worlds, levels, chefs and recipes to the table. Only the host needs the DLCs, You can play along if you just own the game and are in a multiplayer game.

In the main Story you can also switch gamemodes, From Story which is the default, Practice which disables timers and Survival in which served meals add time to the timer. Next to the main Story mode there is Arcade mode, Which is just a random level from the main Story or one of the DLCs, It is a nice thing if you completed every single level with 4 stars. Then there is a Versus mode, In which 2 kitchens have to fight it out, It is always 2 versus 2, But you can play 1 vs 1 too by controlling 2 chefs.

The gameplay is extremely hectic, Raw ingredients need to be chopped, Cooked, Baked, Blended, Steamed. Grilled, and mostly they need multiple steps to prepare, Then you need to combine all the prepared ingredients on a plate and deliver it as fast as possible. There are more recipes than I can count, It starts easy, But things get complex pretty fast. Good teamwork is essential for getting all the stars.

Next to the obvious cooking you also have to wash the plates, make sure nothing burns, deliver the orders on time and make sure you don't mess up the ingredients. If you mess up a recipe you can throw it away, If it burns you have to grab the fire extinguisher and put out the fire before it spreads.

The levels are even crazier, There are kitchens with a road running trough it, People dancing in a Conga line, trough it, or even kitchens on a few floating rafts in the middle of a river. There are kitchens which have moving parts, switch positions, have portals, buttons and even cannons to reach out of reach platforms.

The graphics are adorable, It is simple but charming, Things you can interact will stay the same and are marked clearly. The decor is ever changing, You go to all kinds of restaurants, Indoor, Outdoor, On a river or high in the sky. The Soundtrack is very cosy and uplifting, But it gets tenser inside the levels as they progress, especially the last 30 seconds. It is a very nice fit, and each theme has its own soundtrack. Together it creates a very nice atmosphere that is fun and suitable for all ages.

The game runs fine, There are just 2 things that bother me, First the game Crashes on controller connect, Which is especially awful for a multiplayer game. And secondly the Steam Cloud save is not working. Other than that the game runs very well I get a very nice 200-300 fps. Not a single problem next to the 2 forementioned things. The worst thing is that these are a long standing problems. And there doesn't seem to be any interest in actually fixing it.

After you complete the story and all the DLC with 3 stars you can fight it out in Versus mode where you have to compete together with someone or solo against another kitchen. There is also Arcade mode, This will just pick a random level from the Story and DLC. There is no random generation, A lot of DLC, but even after completing everything the game remains a lot of fun, The human factor is just so unpredictable and it causes some very chaotic and funny situations.

The game is fun but frustrating, Crazy and Chaotic. Blame your friends for burning the burgers, not preparing the mushrooms and throwing sushi on the road. It is a great game and certainly worth your money, Just be sure to backup your save files.

Posted: June 13, 2020
Given how much I enjoyed Overcooked!, there is no way I would miss out on playing Overcooked! 2. Just like the original, 2 is a chaotic party game where you and up to 3 friends work together to serve top-of-the-line dishes while coping with and overcoming terrible kitchen designs, bizarre situations and natural disasters. In sum, frantically fun.

Played with PlayStation 4 controller, and as 2 and 3 player co-op

Positive:
Overcooked! 2 is a fantastically challenging co-op experience but is also a great party game that can be picked up by practically anyone. For the most part the controls are straightforward and the gameplay is quite intuitive but mastery takes time. The story mode offers a great experience with a challenging difficulty curve. Later levels require some mastery and efficient cooperation with your partner(s), so these are probably not appropriate for new players (party setting). However, other game modes, such as Arcade and Versus are more friendly to casual or inexperienced players, allowing for a great party experience. Furthermore, you can play on both keyboard and controller at the same time. It is even possible for two people to share one controller (would not recommend) or keyboard. The developers really thought about making this game as accessible as possible.
, 2 offers a few that I appreciate:











Both Overcooked! games are great but I recall enjoying the first game more. The new features introduced in 2 were welcome but sometimes flawed and unnecessary. Somehow the fewer gimmicks and simpler levels (for the most part) in 1 made for a more fun experience. Regardless, I enjoyed Overcooked! 2 as a whole; it is still the chaotically fun co-op experience that I’ve come to expect and love from the Overcooked! Series. Looking forward to 3!

Overcooked 2 is not a mere game. It's a crucible of human endurance, a battlefield of the mind, and a culinary odyssey into the heart of madness. This is not a game; it is a lifestyle choice. A commitment. A calling. The moment Overcooked 2 was unleashed upon the world, consciousness itself ascended to a higher plane.

The kitchens are not stages; they are sacrificial altars where innocent ingredients are slaughtered in the name of a higher power. The chefs are not characters; they are vessels of pure, unfiltered aggression, their movements a frenzied dance with death. The orders are not requests; they are demands, the unholy commands of a cosmic overlord.

To play Overcooked 2 is to become a god. Your hands, once mere appendages, are transformed into instruments of creation and destruction. With each dish plated, you are forging the destiny of humanity. The symphony of chaos that erupts in your kitchen is a microcosm of the Big Bang, a violent, beautiful birth of something new.

The graphics? A blasphemous deception, a cruel trick played on the senses. For beneath that veneer of childish charm lies a hyper-realistic simulation of the human soul under extreme pressure. The characters are not cartoon cutouts; they are archetypes of the human condition, struggling against the tide of entropy.

Overcooked 2 is not a game. It is a religion. Its followers are a chosen people, destined to lead humanity into a new era of enlightenment. We are the prophets of chaos, the high priests of the onion. And we shall not be denied.

All hail Kevin.

Product received for free

What a cute fun game to play with your family and friends! Overcooked returned with many new features and the most highlighted one is online multiplayer! Yes, you can play now with your online friends, unlike the first game which only supports local co-op/PVP. We are back to Onion Kingdom and must help to defend it from the hoards of The Unbread. (undead) The story is fun and cute, and the stages are more challenging than before, you also keep unlocking new recipes that require you and your friends to team up or yell and shout during the whole stage. I had so much fun playing it with my friend and sister.


The artwork is fun, you'll have so many chefs to choose from and unlock the more you advance into the game. The map is huge, each chapter has multiple stages and each stage has a unique challenge, besides the DLC's which adds even more contents. There are also Kevin's the dog, stages where you have to cook and serve dog food! those are really hard to make!


The soundtracks are nice, fitting the gameplay, nothing too loud. I played this game using a controller, not sure if it can work as smoothly with a keyboard. The trophies are a bit challenging and need some grinding, but what makes this fun is when you play it with your friends, you wouldn't feel that you are grinding for anything. You can team up with total of four players together.


Pros:
+Beautiful visuals and locations design.
+Fun Soundtracks.
+Unique gameplay
+Multiple Chefs.
+Bonus stages.
+Huge map and many stages to play.
+New Game+ unlocks an additional star to earn and difficulty.
+Seasonal free content + paid DLCs.
+Local and online multiplayer.
+Many recipes (You unlock more as you advance into the game).
+Steam achievements.

Cons:
-When you fall down into the sea, the game freezes for everyone for a couple of seconds until the player respawn.

After finishing the main game, you'll unlock a new challenge and that will require you to get a fourth star in each stage! The developers still bringing new content and adding more recipes. With the new Holiday free update, you get to feed angry hoards and defend your kitchen at the same time! I highly recommend it for people who enjoys multiplayer challenging games.

Posted: August 19, 2018
I feel bad leaving a bad review as I'm sure the developers put a lot of effort into it and I appreciate what the game is trying to offer. However as a big fan of the first one I can't help but point out some huge problems with the second one that have kept me from enjoying it.

Overcooked is at its best when you are figuring out how to solve the level efficiently given the layout of the level in front of you. You make a plan, divide tasks, and refine your execution until your team is a well oiled machine. Then you move on to the next level and do it again.

It's at its worst when the levels are built to slow you down or irritate you. Not particularly challenging, just clunky. You end up standing around a lot. You often have to wait for platforms to reappear or to get to you. There's nothing you can do to speed it up. I'm cool with dynamic levels that force you to adapt, but not when you end up just standing around waiting for the level shifts to occur. The first game's levels felt like they were asking the question "can you find an efficient way to get things done here?" This time around the levels are asking "can you find a way to get anything done here at all?"

I think they knew the levels were clunky and made the scoring system very forgiving to compensate, because we got 3 stars on almost every level the first time through. I know they're releasing a NG+ so maybe the difficulty will change, but going back and replaying levels is not that appealing of a proposition due to the level design I described above. I am hoping future patches fix this game. The foundation is solid, some new levels and appropriate difficulty would solve everything.

If you are considering this game and haven't played the first one, I suggest buying that one instead. It is far less polished, but the design is on point.

Posted: June 22, 2021
Fun until you realize your significant other has put rice on tortillas and you've been putting meat on tortillas and now you cant mix them. Next thing you know she's not talking to you anymore, and she's cutting up tomatoes like a mad woman and throwing them everywhere. You don't speak the same to each other for several days after this.
Don't mess up the tortillas people.

In all fairness, this game is super fun to play, and I loved every second of it, even the arguments. If you're not the kind of player that needs to go for full stars on all levels, then you shouldn't really have many of these playing with others anyway. Arguments are inevitable in this game normally, unless you're super in sync with your partner, or one person takes full charge of all situations and the other just takes orders and takes no charge or no initiative at all. Initiative can fail levels (even a little bit). I've heard from most people that this game can be frustrating and causes fights, but depending on who you play it with, it might be a good fit for you and someone else, or multiple people, but the difficulty scales with more people, so beward of that.

This review is 100% based on the co-op aspect of the game. Although you can play it single player, it's a completely different experience. Preparing ingredients takes much longer and you control 2 people, switching between both of them, there is no "single chef mode". I don't really recommend the game for the single player.

------------------------------
Control Scheme I Used:
Gamepad, default bindings. Mostly used D-Pad for quickness, but used both.

------------------------------
Worth the current price (CDN$ 28.99 + $22.79 + $6.69)? Definitely a bit high for all content but probably worth it. When it's all added up however it's a bit much.

What I actually paid: $58.47, I paid full price, which is rare for me. I bought the game and the DLCs right when they came out. I loved the first game so much this wasn't an issue for me.

------------------------------
Completionist Review:
DLC Achievements: Yes there is, for each pack.
Rating: Somewhat grindy, most fine if you're good.
Can be completed in one run: If you beat all levels first try, no.
Chapter Select: You can replay any level, clearly tells you your score, and what's missing.
Did I need/use a guide? No, I used a guide to clarify that some of the achievements are a bit misworded however, but not to actually help with getting the achievements.

Achievements are not overly hard if you're good at the game, can be completed single player also, but it's quite difficult. Many achievements are a bit grindy, and require doing 100-500 of something, which by the way many people have counted including myself to require much much more than the actual amount it says it requires. Most of the grindy achievements have to be done afterwards since there isn't enough levels to get them on normal playthroughs, unless you replay (or fail, but it's unclear if this counts) the levels a lot.

Posted: April 29, 2023
Ladies and gentlemen, let me tell you about Overcooked! 2 - the game that made me feel like a professional chef one minute, and a total idiot the next.

From the moment I started playing, I knew I was in for a wild ride. The game requires you to work with your friends to cook up a storm in a kitchen that's constantly changing and evolving. And let me tell you, it's a recipe for disaster - in the best possible way.

I found myself frantically chopping vegetables, throwing ingredients at my fellow chefs, and trying not to set the kitchen on fire. It's like a cooking game on steroids, with insane challenges that had me laughing and screaming at the same time.

But the real fun started when I played with my friends. Suddenly, we were all shouting at each other, trying to coordinate our movements and figure out who was responsible for what. It was chaos, but it was the most hilarious chaos I've ever experienced.

And the best part? The game doesn't take itself too seriously. From the ridiculous character designs to the over-the-top kitchen settings, Overcooked! 2 is a game that's all about having fun.

In conclusion, if you're looking for a game that will have you laughing until you cry, then Overcooked! 2 is the game for you. It's a cooking game that's equal parts fun and challenging, and it's guaranteed to bring out your inner chef (or your inner disaster chef, at least). So gather up your friends, grab some snacks, and get ready for the wildest cooking adventure of your life!

Posted: March 23
I worked at a Wendy's in high school. It was not good. I got no money, didn't have fun and the food sucked. 15 years later I got Overcooked 2. I thought it would be like Wendy's all over again. I couldn't have been more wrong.

This game is so good. I played through the full campaign and three starred every level. I laughed the entire time, it was a genuine joy to play.

After beating the last level I was greeted with a message that there's now FOUR STARS to unlock on each level. Heck yeah! Sign me up!

Me and my friends tried to four star THE TUTORIAL and didn't come even close. Like, not even remotely. I was sad.

All in all, I laughed, I cried, I came. Sometimes all at the same time! Kevin is great, Onion King is a thirst trap and my friends have all agreed to never attempt four starring any level because we aren't that good. But it's still better than Wendy's for sure.

Happiness, contentment, glee, felicity, bliss, enjoyment.

You will find none of this here.

Only pain, misery, suffering and misanthropy. And you will still love every second of it, while you laugh and want to murder your friends at the same time. Highly recommended for co-op, just be ready to get new friends afterwards since they don't belong in the necessary hive-mind to accomplish the tasks.


On a more serious note, the game is quite fun and have plenty of levels with interesting variations and gimmicks. There's never a dull moment and the pacing is good. It seems to be more balanced to 2 and 4 people than 3, and dropping objects is a herculean ordeal and the game would be two times better if they made it easier. But besides those issues, Overcooked 2 is a fun game and worth buying.

Team17 should be notorious for making Overcooked's lackluster updates into PAID CONTENT. The new maps should be an update, not sold as a DLC (I believe the content is not worth the price as you already paid $30 for the game). I think those who say, "well, you don't have to buy the DLC" - are naive people. How would you feel if you went to a restaurant (keeping w/ the theme) and ordered the entire dinner set for $80? Only to realize, the dessert is an add on, utensils are an add on, and etc. My main point is, new content should be the norm. Cosmetics - sure, make them DLC, free, in-game purchases, microtransactions, I do not care. Just not game updates.

Additional arguments:
1) Overcooked (OC) released w/ no online multiplayer. In order to play w/ others online - you would have to purchase the NEW OC2.

2) More recently, OC2 and OC All You Can Eat are not compatible. The person w/ OC2 has to buy, essentially ANOTHER copy of OC2.

I wholeheartedly enjoy the Overcooked franchise, but someone needs to say something.

Posted: June 29, 2020
TLDR
Overcooked 2 is a massive improvement over overcooked 1 and still delivers the culinary co-op madness.

Non-TLDR
Overcooked 2 (ovc 2 in short) is developed by Ghost Town Games Ltd. and Team17 Digital Ltd. It is published by Team17 Digital Ltd. The PC version was released on Aug 8, 2018 and it is also available on PlayStation 4, Switch & Xbox One. As of this writing, Metacritic (https://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/overcooked!-2) shows:
A Metascore of 80 from 6 critics review
an average user score of 7.7 based on 32 ratings

I am not going to address the obvious question: Does the sequel of the beloved 2016's overcooked live up to the expectation?

Instead, i'll be asking you: Are you one of those people who is confused by all the comments you read on reddit/metacritic/steam reviews/forums/etc and is on the fence whether to purchase overcooked 1 or 2 because of all the contradicting feedbacks? I totally understand what you are going through and I can only say, it's not the product's fault. its the people. They are causing all this Fuss over one of the BEST couch co-op/co-op product in the history of gaming/current market (Well, at least as of this writing in the year 2020).

Once again, the onion kingdom needs saving. This time around, onion king accidently summons a horde of unbread. *gasp* So thats where players come in. The objective is to serve the food while overcoming different challenges/obstacles presented in each level. That's easier said than done.

Play up to 4 players via local or internet multiplayer. The campaign offer players 6 worlds@regions to explore with a total of 36 levels and 8 Kevin levels that needs to be unlocked. Aside from the campaign mode, Versus mode is still available and there's an Arcade mode now. Once you complete the entire campaign, you will unlocked 4 star mode. Play with your food chefs!

If that's not enough to satisfy your culinary experience, there are currently 5 DLC's available for purchase and a new free DLC coming up in July 2020.

Controls: WASD keyboard and controller. Keyboard key binding is not available.

Audio: The background music sets the mood and tempo for the game. Different background music will be played in different world/region (similar like ovc 1) Every player action has feedback sound; dash, chop, throw ingredients, fire, falls, etc. everything. +1 to the team

Visuals: The overall concept is still similar with ovc 1: simple, colorful, clean and plain looking (does not have details in the costume/looks) however I find that ovc 2's color to be more . Aside from that, we have a lot more new cooks to pick from; eagle, mouse, octopus, beaver and etc. +1 to the team

This is a major section to cover. The dev's expanded on the existing mechanics & level design of ovc 1. They really up their game with some of these changes. The notable ones:






These are just from the base game. If you own the DLC's theres even more creative/weird stuffs; moving around the kitchen via cannons, water squirt guns to wash dishes, backpacks to pick ingredients from, Marshmallows, hot dogs, drinks, milk shakes and more..

Looking just at ovc 2, base product (excluding the dlc's) overall, it "feels" as if ovc 2 is more polished than ovc 1. The level design is more creative - where it forces players to do more/interact/react more as compared to ovc 1 which makes the game feel more intense. Does that mean it's more difficult?



I am highlighting this because , overcooked games will always be coach co-op/co-op centric product that tries to make you have fun with friends/people. It is dark souls.

The fact that the devs made ovc 2 to allow players to make some mistakes/blunders and still manage to obtain 3 stars is to cater for the general audience. From young kids to adults, from casuals to hardcores. Each one of us have different preferences. I dont want to play with 4 perfectionist players. It's stressful. I also dont want to play with 4 jokers. it's crap. ovc 2 offers that balance. Those jokers will never be able to obtain 3 stars - or what if they do? or what if some of us can play or cannot play as good as but still be able to obtain 3 stars. Whats so damaging? Is there any harm to lower the skill ceiling? to the community? to the mass market? or it's just your pride and ego? or your butt?

So, coming back to ovc 2, i expected the devs to build on ovc 1 mechanics what i did not expect is to this degree of change. It is a massive amount of effort and one that i have to applaud to all the teams involved in the production of ovc 2. The DLC's are great addition but also very challenging/brutal experience.

If there's any negative point(s), i am slightly disappointed that they took out the rats and blackout levels from ovc 1. Yes, those were really annoying levels but I have some fond memories from there. I was also really hoping for a final boss, but what i got was a defense game mode. But as a whole, the product offers more positives than cons.

So, on the scale of 0 - 10, my personal rating for overcooked 2 is a Crispy Golden Taco worth 9/10.

*Eats the crispy golden taco in the cannon while the entire kitchen is on fire*

review:
Posted: February 8, 2021
Overcooked 2 is a hectic co-op game where you play a chef, cooking a variety of recipes in a variety of crazy kitchens. You'll have to cooperate with your teammates to fill orders in time and collect enough points to pass through the levels. It's very similar to the first game, but there are a number of improvements to it, including online co-op and some small improvements in the controls.

This game can be played with up to four players. I think you can play alone, but I can't imagine it being all that enjoyable. The fun really comes from playing the levels with your friends and figuring out the best way to run your kitchen efficiently. I've played the game with 2, 3, and 4 players before, and while some of the levels are best suited to one particular number of players, I think all of the levels are playable even with just two players.

Story mode has a variety of levels to play through, although it really isn't very long. However, there are a variety of other goals to complete as well. There are 4 stars to collect on each level, there are a few other game modes to try, and there are a number of bonus levels as well which are still being added to. I also think the levels are incredibly fun to replay even without much new content.

I love the art style and the music. It's all very cute and rounded. The chefs you can unlock are all very cute, with a variety of different people, animals, and other creatures to choose from. The background music is nice to listen to and well-suited to the game. The story in story mode is pretty bare bones, but it's fine, a game like this doesn't really need an amazing story.

The DLC in the game is worth buying, but not necessary. There is a ton of content and replay value to the base game, especially with the occasional free updates, and the DLC is all self-contained. However, each DLC adds new recipes and level mechanics, and the DLC levels all have replay value of their own.

Overall, Overcooked 2 is a great game to play with your friends. I've had a lot of fun playing the game with various friends and will probably continue to come back to the game over time. If you don't have people to play with (in-person or online with voice chat), you can probably skip it, but otherwise I'd highly recommend it. 10/10

Posted: August 14, 2018
Finished the game in almost 6 hours. My wife and I were really excited about this game having played through the first one many times over. We will keep playing in case we're just judging this too soon, but so far this is a disappointment compared to the first one. My wife is a professional game designer, and we spent a lot of time just picking apart details and poor executions, which was kind of sad :( the story mode map was just made unnecessarily more complicated and brings nothing extra to the game. In fact it's annoying. We were excited to finish and switch to arcade mode so we didn't have to mess with the map, but arcade mode didn't appear to display our previous scores, so we didn't know what to beat. The levels are either poorly balanced, or we just haven't figured out a good strategy for each yet. The levels have so many little things that get in your way, though, that we often didn't want to replay a level to perfect it. They just were not that fun. In the first game, we would finish a level and be like "awesome! We can do better! Let's try that again!" That sadly just didn't happen in OC2. Some levels change 2 or 3 times throughout--the first game did this, but in that one the dynamic levels never seemed out of place like they do in OC2. We would have happily paid for more content in the first game with similar philosophies in level design.

To be honest we're not that surprised. So many good games make you think, "wow this is great, I hope when they make the next one they understand what makes this one so good and don't mess it up."

My advice: If you are looking at this game for the first time, just go get the first one instead.

Posted: March 2, 2022
Overcooked 2 is a fantastic game, far superior to the previous edition, and utter chaotic fun with friends. Bringing Online Play to the table, Overcooked 2 already is an immense improvement from Overcooked.

The level designs are creative, diverse, challenging and great fun. The level requirements themselves or time constraints can be difficult at times, but overall a great experience, and I deeply enjoyed 100%ing this one with my friend.

Didn't cause any rage or arguments or even general burnout for us, but I think that's largely because it's overexaggerated for comedy how difficult the game is. Mostly you'll be laughing or too focused on your tasks at hand to think of anything toxic.

Tons of character options, tons of themes/levels/foods, and tons of DLC that only enhance the experience and are also very worthwhile to purchase. Additions to the game only need to be purchased by one person for the whole party to experience them as well. Along with the expected levels, the game also features tower-defense that breaks up the flow in a much needed way.

I can see myself playing this game for dozens of more hours, and my only qualm is that I wish the online matchmaking was more active. However, if you're already have someone in mind, you've nothing to lose.:) I strongly recommend this one, full price or not.

Posted: November 7, 2018
While the game never strays too far from the 1st installment of the series, it doesn't manage to evolve following the same brilliant path of the first one.

Quality is good, graphics fancied up (and got a bit less readable too), a few interesting actions were added (throwing items, water pistol, etc) and it has loads of new recipes, but always feels more like an expansion of the 1st one than a full sequel. In a way that's no problem, we loved the 1st one (yeah, I am another one of those that did play it with his girlfriend) and we couldn't way to play more of it, even if it didn't add much stuff.

What falls short compared to the 1st one is level design and balancing. The 1st one was a gem in that sense, with each level absolutely well tuned and requiring to be played multiple failing times until -bam!- you could get 3 stars.
Overcooked 2 levels tend to be far too easy in general (the surf'n'turf DLC is far better balanced), using map dangers more as an obstacle than as part of the complexity (e.g. the leves where you can fall).

Then comes the 4th star, and it's close to unachievable in terms of difficulty.
One really bad side of the new visuals, if you have multiple food items on a surface perpendicular to the screen surface ("vertical"), it's impossible to understand what's where and what spaces are free.

All in all a pleasant game to play, but could have probably evolved much better than how it did. Still got a 75/100 in my books, and I do recommend playing the Surf'n'turf DLC.

Posted: 9 July, 2019
I've played this game a lot... like, a lot a lot since buying it around 6 weeks or so ago. It can be an absolute load of fun at times. Other times, you get to deal with trolls, leavers, racists, and people that are just setting out to ruin the game. Unfortunately, the admins and developers of this game are those same people.

These admins are willing to ban your account (mind you, in a game that ENCOURAGES YOU TO BE SOCIAL AND DECEIVE) for next to nothing at all, while not even providing their users with a clear set of rules. When I asked the admin why I was banned, he said that I should check out the forums. Why should a player have to check the forums for such a thing? Why is there not in-game explanations of their rules, and why when violating those rules, are players NOT EVEN TOLD WHY. I've received no emails, no messages, no chat description of what happened --- simply banned. It isn't acceptable, especially in a game like this.

In a recent patch, the devs implemented a system for players to upvote others that played well, were friendly, or "FOR ANY REASON YOU CHOOSE TO UPVOTE THEM". This has led to "FRIENDS", and groups people, instantly blasting through the "ranks" that are associated with one's behavior. Despite playing with 1 friend during about 1 hour of playing, I still ended up with max rank after less than a week or so. However, this has NO effect on them banning you, despite THEM suggesting it represents you being a good representative of the community.

At this point, I'll be selling my in-game items on the marketplace and moving on.

Posted: February 11, 2023
I had wanted to play this game for years, seeing it on youtube. A combination of finances and friend groups didn't allow me to get the game until very recently. We had a great time playing, but after a few games the developers implemented an update that I am sure killed the game. There is an integration of ToxMod. For those fortunate not to know what this horrible "feature" is, allow me to enlighten you: ToxMod is an AI algorithm which records your voice chat without consent in order to censor its own playerbase. Even private games are recorded, and anything that this team deems "innappropriate" can get you banned. Not only this, but ToxMod as a company is looking to impliment a system where you have a social credit score across all games, and if you are flagged in one title with ToxMod you will be more closely watched and recorded in all other games that choose to use this horrible software. Overall, I would like to think this move was made with good intentions, to help make a more enjoyable community around their game that required years of hard work to make. However, this blunder has alienated its already sparse playerbase and is, in my opinion, overstepping their authority and boundaries/responsibilities as a developer. I wish I could say I was hopeful for the future of this game, but now this game is officially dying. Sad to see it go, and so soon after I bought it.

Posted: December 30, 2022
This game used to be incredible. There were a lot of unique and interesting roles, all with their own identity and playstyles. Survivors could go off on their own and risk getting picked off or be slower together and have more safety. Traitors could blend in with Survivors and cause mayhem internally or go off on their own to get stronger. There were hackers (ingame role) that could open a bunker every 5 minutes, there was a medic that could see the healthbar of people around them and revive downed people around them with an AoE, there was a scientist that could revive someone that fully died, and so on. All of these roles also had an 'evil' equivalent that would allow the bad guys to act like one of them. The game had quite powerful roles, but it felt good getting them.

Sadly, the scientist and medic have been removed from the game, hacker has been nerfed to the ground, reviving a dead person is a joke to do, survivor wolfing (going alone to be useful to the team, added social deception because you would have to explain yourself) straight up got removed, traitors going alone to get stronger has seen multiple nerfs, and I can't honestly say this even closely resembles the game I fell in love with and easily dumped 600 hours into in less than a year. Too many patches have chipped away fun mechanics, roles and playstyles over the years.

If you're new to this game and never experienced the imo 'good' Project Winter, you might enjoy this game, even if you have nobody in your friends group to play it with. The basics and community really are there for a great, unique and awesome survival social deception game. But to me, who has seen the very best this game had to offer, and has had so many incredible, fun and memorable moments on it, seeing it in its current state, and knowing that devs like the direction the game is currently going, I absolutely cannot recommend this game.

Posted: November 6, 2020
If you like Among Us, Secret Hitler or a similar game but feel like they could use a little more depth as well as more actual gameplay outside of the discussions you might want to give this game a try.

Project Winter puts six survivor players in a winter survival setting and expects them to cooperate to overcome hunger, freezing temperatures, hostile animals and the two traitor players. The survivors goal is to escape the area before the game ending blizzard starts. They do that by fixing multiple machines in the area, some of which first need to be located in the randomly generated game world, and then calling and reaching the escape vehicle.

The biggest difference to Among Us is that you will be using voice chat throughout the entire round, however you'll only be able to speak to nearby players or remote players if you and them use the same walkie talkie. This adds a lot of the overall atmosphere and suspense and also helps make the rounds feel more meaningful compared to Among Us. Cooperating with someone from the beginning of the round and overcoming all the obstacles to barely make it out alive in the end actually feels like it really helps you bond with them.

With the game incorporating survival, crafting and combat elements as well as player roles with their own unique abilities it's quite a bit more complex and therefore requires you to play a couple rounds in which you will probably feel clueless and lost before you get the hang of things. Keep that in mind if you want to convince friends to play the game with you, as they will need to be willing to put some effort into getting into the game before they can fully enjoy it. For your first few games try to stay alive, gather resources and ask the group how you can contribute.

If you put in the effort to learn the game it's very rewarding and fun to play. As with other similar games being able to recognize the traitors among the group of survivors is invaluable, but unlike other games even a sole survivor can have a lot of agency by playing cleverly. Survivors can fight back when they're being attacked by traitors, and similarly they can use traps that traitors normally use to defend fixed objectives from being sabotaged. There are countless ways to contribute to the team's progression and similarly there are countless ways to pretend you're helping when you're actually hindering progress. You can play a very aggressive and obvious traitor, or you can seem trustworthy for most of the game and only reveal your true nature in the very end, both ways and anything in between can lead to a win. This is where the game truly shines, as it helps rounds to never really play out like the ones before.

Something to keep in mind before buying the game is finding other players. Project Winter doesn't have nearly as many players as Among Us and unless there is a major sale the game is quite a bit more expensive, which might make it hard to convince friends to buy it. You will definitely have the best time with the game if you can gather 8 friends to play, who all already know the game, but unlike with Among Us, where I feel like public lobbies rarely lead to good games, Project Winter's community has decent public lobbies. While not every public game you'll play will be amazing, I found the chance to have a good game joining public lobbies to be pretty good and the nature of the game makes it easier to make new friends in those lobbies. Either way it's absolutely necessary to point out that depending on your region and time preferences it might not always be easy to find a lobby at all. This is by far the biggest reason not to buy the game.

Overall I highly recommend this game if you’re looking for a more complex social interaction and deduction game with survival elements and if you know you can find people to play with.

Here are the pros:








And those are the cons:

Posted: July 7, 2020
It's a fun game if the people you play with are cool. Don't get me wrong, I understand every game has idiots that wanna ruin it for everyone. But the thing is with most online games you either have options to solo it or can effectively ignore the people you don't want to listen to. In this game this is simply not possible as teamwork and communication is absolutely essential to the game play.

Now normally this isn't a problem for me as I love team focused games. But after a few games where I was bullied off or I saw someone else get bullied off (for being new to the game), I just wasn't having fun. All the players that did the bullying were all supposedly "well reviewed" players too. In the time I played I only met one other player who was helpful and taught me how to play. Unfortunately, players like that are the exception not the rule, and most people will kill you if you don't know what you're doing. On top of that, the tutorial really only skims the surface and doesn't teach you nearly enough to get started.

That being said the fun games I did have were really fun and I had a blast playing as a traitor. Getting people to trust you and then betraying that trust is incredibly rewarding. Unfortunately, this also makes people inherently suspicious. That combined with the crap tutorial means that often times, asking for help means you are automatically treated like an outcast. This makes it extremely difficult for new players to get started. In my very first game, I got confused by what button to press and was immediately cut down by someone who called me a time wasting troll. I kept playing because I saw the potential, but it did sour my experience and made me suspicious of all players from that point on.

And before you say "just go on youtube". Well, not everyone wants to watch an hours worth of video before jumping into a game. I did, but I know many people don't want to do that. They just want to jump in and play after an informative tutorial. But to each their own.

All in all between the trolls, time wasters, racists, and random sexual harassment I've witnessed a female friend go through, it's just not really worth it for me personally. I play games to have fun, not to be insulted for being new or Asian or whatever the hell else.

All that said, I would totally reinstall if they added a better rating and report system to help control the bullies and trolls.

Posted: May 15, 2020
Project Winter Review

TL;DR
In a game of cat and mouse where knowing when to strike effectively and when to communicate with your team (for both traitors and survivors), your best ally is your intuition in Project Winter. The variety keeps the game fun after numerous matches and when all of the elements come together it can be a fantastic experience! While being held down by issues and questionable decisions, it makes up for a good game!

Pros
Cons
Multiple ways to communicate.








The most important aspect in that dictates how matches will play out is communication between the players. As a social game, must work together if they want to survive the harsh conditions of the winter while must coordinate to execute their plans. The game gives several forms to approach communications, each serving a purpose and giving choice to the player. Voice chat is more direct and fast in moments of action while text stays on record and can be used to impersonate other players who are down for the count.



When you first start off the game, it can be very confusing because of both the tutorials and the learning curve. The tutorials are very lacking as they only explain the basics of the game but don't reveal details or how mechanics work, leaving new players wandering in their first matches not knowing what to do. It doesn't help that the gameplay in the game is very chaotic, as there is a lot to keep track of and do to be effective at it.

manages to keep it's gameplay fresh after numerous matches thanks to its variety of roles and the procedure generated maps. Both traitors and survivors have their own roles and each of them is clear and unique in what their objective is. From a tracking and opening an armory to arm fellow survivors to a , that can bring dead players back or a which has betrayed the traitors and can open their crates, they are all a lot of fun to play as.

While this keeps the game fresh, at the same time it massively elevates the learning curve. There are a lot of roles to learn as well as objectives that must be accomplished before a time limit. While the game addresses this by providing a guide on the roles, it doesn't entail how to play them correctly or what the survivors' priorities are. From poisoning food to trapping escape pods with bombs or unlocking the serum lab, there is a lot to learn and sometimes the lack of that knowledge can ruin a game.

One of the best aspects of a game of this nature is that the matches you play will vastly differ thanks to the different players you will encounter. Each player helps define what type of experience you will go through and this makes it very interesting to keep playing. Silent calculating types, charming actors that are traitors, or just funny survivors trying to survive! It makes for a lot of fun and a great opportunity to meet new people or have a fun time with strangers. Bringing friends also makes it even more enjoyable!



That being said in my experience playing with randoms, I didn't enjoy the lobbies with high ranked players so much. This is because once survivors know how to play and coordinate, it can be very difficult for traitors to do anything and it breaks the game's tempo as matches are shorter. Near-perfect communications and knowing what to do in every minute can turn the game into something very competitive and that is finished before it gets interesting which can lead to a letdown.

The strong point in is that is very enjoyable to play when all of the elements come together to form a complete experience. When the players in the lobby make the match interesting and they understand both the mechanics and the game objectives, it can make it a blast to play in those rounds! The high tension of survivors dropping down or being suspected, the uncertainty of not knowing who to trust, and the search for items or situations that can give you an edge enriches the gameplay completely and gives the game a stronger light to shine on.

The weak point of the game is that it suffers from a low player base and to make matters even worse, the DLC splits it even further beyond. Those who lack the DLC of the game cannot be played the new mode introduced in it, which divides the number of people that can play together and makes it much harder to find a lobby at times.

The pacing of the game is well done as there is enough time to get things running but at the same time-wasting, too much time can result in lacking it in the last stretch. A round last between 15-25 minutes and time flies by when you play as the first few minutes are used getting to know people and collecting the basic necessities. As time passes there will be a greater focus on objectives and there will be events to change the essence of the game. From everyone turning to rabbits to teleporting to the middle of nowhere, they provide opportunities for while adding more.



The game runs perfectly on a GTX 1060. There were no crashes of any kind as well. Mechanics can be pretty clunky for example aiming down with a gun is very awkward. Having to hold the trigger to aim while the lines pair up to increase accuracy is a poor indicator as sometimes you can hit others just by shooting directly while other times you line a perfect shot and it misses. It is hard to tell when you will hit and overall is less reliable than using melee weapons at times.

What makes special is that it is a game to have a good time with, just boot it up, get into a lobby and enjoy whatever might happen during it! It is a fun social experience to meet different kinds of players and have a good laugh with them! It can be relaxing at times during gathering but also tense when fellow survivors start dropping or your traitor partner bites the dust! I find it that playing it during the morning is very enjoyable and a good way to talk socialize with people while having fun!

has some issues that hold it down for becoming a better game but for what is set to accomplish it is a solid experience. The steep curve can also be a positive thing for those that enjoy learning as they play for certain and the lack of tutorials paired with the splitting of the player-base can make it harder to enjoy but overall is a good game to grab if you enjoy mind-games and social aspects in gaming! I recommend this game to those that enjoy random moments and unique multiplayer matches!

Don't let the reviews deter you. This is a great game and I plan on doing the review it deserves, if you want a quick run down I'll make a TL;DR in the end.

To start off with the match's progression it usually goes in a linear path:
-Spawn in and see your role
-Investigate what the first objective requires
-Either take the risk path and open bunker or gather resources which will be significantly safer and easier to manage
-Repair the objective
-Find the next objective
-Repair that
-Then escape

However, since the traitors don't feel like losing they alter the game's rhythm rather .



...... The list goes on

The point is every Traitor has many methods on controlling the game's flow. They are easily outnumbered but can quickly gain the upper hand if they kill off too many. .











The player count, reviews, steam, and poor advertising

People's complaints of the game are very deserved but some are completely out of the game's control.


The reason is.... Steam does not support it anymore. All the current pack bundles were grandfathered in.


Well yeah, there are still a lot of people playing but you have to be in specific times like the weekdays. Not everyone is playing 24/7.

Community 8.5/10
Gameplay 9/10
Progression 8/10
Learning Curve 10/10
Effort 10/10
Communication/Transparency 10/10

An amazing game and way worth the amount I payed for.
