Posted: January 11, 2022
I have mixed feelings for this game. At first I really enjoyed Project Winter, the community was awesome and kind, and the game was a blast to play. However, after it became crossplay, it became a lot more toxic. Admittedly this increased toxicity ruined it for me and I haven't really played much since. I would recommend this game, however, I don't feel like it would accurately represent my current stance.

Here are some issues I came across:

- Although it is better to communicate verbally it opens up an avenue of harassment due to the lack of protective ambiguity for female sounding players, young sounding players, and players with accents. These groups are frequently the targets of harassment and the mic becomes a unfortunate necessity. (There are other options of communication within the game, but the reality is you will usually die first if you don't use a mic.)

- Many were excited for Xbox to join. Crossplay is always something to look forward to, avid players were excited to have more players fill lobbies, and Xbox would give Project Winter more recognition it deserved. After Xbox joined, it unfortunately backfired. There quickly became a keyboard vs controller division. Xbox players used their party chat instead of the in-game chat, PC had an upper hand with ranged weapons, and there was a massive experience gap between new Xbox players and the older PC players at the time. This rift between Xbox and PC was a breeding ground for unpleasant interactions. I hope time has healed this.

- Lastly, There is a social ranking system that is not great, It takes a lot of time and self promotion to get a better rank and one toxic lobby/game can destroy it. In addition, If you have a gold ranking (the top rank), it resets to bronze or red if you are inactive for a month. They have tried fixing it, but in my opinion they should just get rid of it.

With 400+ hours played, I can say this is a fun game. However, the increased toxicity has made this game less enjoyable for me. I do somewhat recommend the game, but I would only recommend playing it with your group of friends.

Posted: December 19, 2020
Bought the game a while ago together with friends. During 2020 it has been our favourite game to play during lockdowns, as a mean to stay together (and kill each other ruthlessly ;) ).

The game basics are really easy to grasp (a helpful tutorial is also available) but the deception abilities and attention to details (BE SMART! TAKE YOUR VITAMINS) are keys to become a really skilled player. I suggest to play with your friends for a while before playing with others, but you can always start with unknown players: it will be more difficult in the beginning but after some time you can really make the difference with your team and win.

TIPS:
- LAB: try to always open the Laboratory as soon as you can if you are on the "good" side... but also if you are the Traitor, as using the Truth serum on Innocents and accusing them of being evil is a real PRO prove.
- DON'T WANDER ALONE: wild animals, cold and hunger kills too, and Traitors are always there when you are an easy "prey"
- BEWARE OF THE LONG CON: everyone can be a Traitor, even your chubby-buddy for the entire game.
- PAY ATTENTION TO GHOSTS SIGNALS: dead players will still try to help you differentiate traitors from good fellas, always look for the signs! (e.g. "Cooling down" specific players or "Healing" everyone)



BLACKOUT: the DLC adds new events, items and a ton of new roles. Playing as a traitor is more challenging (you are alone and need to convert Innocents in bad minions), but it is incredibly worthy (and fun lol) to convert more and more Innocents to your side. RECOMMENDED!

The game is well maintained, with frequent updates, events and new gears. Very active community on Discord, with suggestions and tips for new players, new proposed functionalities, troubleshooting, etc.

Definitely good replay value =)
Worth to buy! (Got mine with a little discount -DLC included- but under 20 euros is fine)

Posted: December 19, 2019
This was one of the single most disappointing experiences of my gaming life. I absolutely love social-deduction games, like Mafia, Werewolf, Town of Salem, etc. So when I came across this seemingly similar game, with the added twist of cooperative survival and objective-based 3D RPG-style gameplay, I was thrilled!

However, despite the well made game and simplistic (but beautiful) art style, there were several *glaring* flaws which immediately ruined the experience and soured my views on the game. To start, the community is very small and surprisingly toxic for the size. During my second ever game with other people, I was random killed and then asked random game knowledge questions as a 'quiz' which I needed to pass for the other players to pick me up.

Toxicity can be ignored, though. I play League of Legends, I'm used to that. What can't be forgiven, however, is that the current meta within the game is for the Traitors to rush weapons early and then attack and kill everyone. The entire 'social-deduction' aspect of the game vanishes immediately. If you don't rush weapons early, as well, you're easily dispatched by the Traitors, and since the Exile function doesn't do nearly enough to matter, the Traitors maintain a massive advantage throughout the entire game.

I requested a refund after trying to play one or two more games, all of which resulted in the same game flow and same boring, disappointing experience.

Play Town of Salem.

Posted: January 1, 2021
This game is really fun and quite enjoyable. I think it's simultaneously been a bit lost and a bit spotlighted due to Among Us's popularity, but don't mistake it for the same game--aside from the fact they are both hidden role games, they share very little in common, and in my opinion, that's for the better.

The game focuses on survival-type gameplay (all players need to keep their health, warmth, and hunger at high enough levels or risk dying) while survivors (innocents) must try to work together to solve objectives and make an escape. Traitors sabotage the innocents, sometimes trying to blend in and other times leaving on their own to gather stronger materials (such as guns, stat-boosting drinks, and traps) to make a more obvious ploy at hunting down the survivors.

More advanced gameplay modes are included as well, with many different roles for both survivors and traitors, bigger maps, etc--as well as entirely new DLC mode called "Blackout" (which I find admittedly difficult to understand and play even after maybe 5-10 plays, and which has admittedly fewer lobbies--note that you can't play with anyone who doesn't have the DLC, period).

One small downside that I'll note is that any game with voice chat such as this is going to end up with some downsides. If you have a feminine voice, you may become a target. I've been called slurs multiple times in this game or otherwise harassed. While the majority of public lobbies are friendly, even one nasty player can ruin a game if they want to, and other players rarely step in unless you already know each other.

That being said--it also encourages friendships. I've begun to recognize a few players I've had fun playing with and we often intentionally join each other's lobbies for a bit of fun. It's really difficult to overestimate how much voice chat can spur friendships on more than typical text chat does. Hopefully, this will only become more true as I put more hours into the game!

Overall, definitely reccommend. I think the experience is much better overall for people who have masculine voices, but assuming you're willing to put up with some occasional ♥♥♥♥♥, I think it's fun and worth it.

Posted: November 28, 2020
It's hard not to write a review without comparing this game to Among Us, but here goes: this social deception game has a lot of depth, and the gameplay loop can vary so widely from game to game. Pubs are great, and the players are really helpful in providing help, guides, and really enjoyable experiences overall. The game scales down surprisingly well to where I'm running it on integrated graphics, and YMMV on that much, but the game is very good and I've had quite a few memorable games that didn't just amount to a win or a loss. That's a key difference between this game and other Mafia, Secret Hitler style games like it: the alt win conditions are great! The neutral roles, I'm a bit more iffy on, but it's hard to deny that they provide a breath of fresh air if the game's meta becomes stale. All in all, enjoy this one if you're getting bored of Among Us, or just try it out if you've never tried a social deception game up to this point. You won't be disappointed!

Posted: January 20, 2023
The game has proximity, the mechanics are decent, and the objective of the game often keeps players moving and communicating, which ends up making it a very social experience. This social aspect is, in my opinion, the only reason this game has the level of replayablity that it does.

I have met just about every one of my friends that I regularly talk to on this game. I don’t think there is a game better for that sort of thing. The unfortunate downside to this being such a social game is that it naturally relies on the community to make it a fun experience. You will meet some of the funniest and chill players in this game, and then the lobby will eventually die and the next one you hop into will feature players pulled up from the deepest circle of hell.

My advice is to find those players who you enjoy playing with, and cling onto them for dear life. Too many games with the wrong players will leave you unhappy and drained extremely quickly.

The playerbase is rather small, at least as far as the regulars go. This is a good thing and a bad thing in my opinion. Its small size and variation in experience level and playstyle causes the game to be very cliquey and fosters a community that often feels like high school all over again.

As far as the gameplay goes, it can be surprisingly entertaining. There are so many hilarious moments that happen just about every time I play to this very day, and that says a lot as I have a ridiculous amount of time played. The pace of the game can vary quite a bit. Sometimes your whole lobby will be doing absolutely nothing and other times you have 2-3 people who run off together immediately and try to finish the objectives as fast as possible. Both of these extremes can negatively impact the game in their own ways. If the players do nothing then you sit there for 30 minutes just to die to the blizzard at the end, and if you speedrun the objectives then you don’t let the game progress in a way that will allow for those unique and funny plays that make it worth playing.

There is also a very small skill gap in this game, and instead there is more of a ‘knowledge gap’ that separates the community based on ability. Also, unfortunately, the pvp aspect of the game is much more effective to rely on than deception. Experienced players realize this and are able to get themselves out of situations that they realistically shouldn’t be able to get out of. I believe these things are some of the key reasons that new players don’t come back to the game; and it all comes down to them not feeling like they have a meaningful impact on the result of the game. I honestly can’t blame them for that. I do think this can only be fixed by the community members though, as I don’t see anything the developers could really change with the game that will stop experienced players from ‘abusing’ players who are new to the game.

Overall, I really love this game and I have spent an ungodly amount of time on it for a reason. I think there are a lot of changes that would benefit the game a lot, but in the end the only way to balance a game like this while also keeping everyone happy, is to give us many more custom game settings. Also these settings need to work consistently, as I have seen a ridiculous amount of bugs in custom games, and it is already hard enough to normalize them. Everyone has a different view of what an ideal game is and I feel like changing up the normal mode game mechanics will cause more issues than it will solve, unless there are custom settings implemented that enable players to play with the older settings.

TL;DR very interesting and fun game where you will meet the best and worst people the world has to offer.

Posted: August 19, 2019
Product received for free

This review was brought to you on behalf of Abyssal Ascent Reviews in collaboration with its developer. If you liked it, please Follow the Curator and Join its group. Thank you!

Project Winter is a team survival game where all players are thrown into extreme elemental conditions and so the team must activate a distress signal and wait to be rescued. However, this isn't your only challenge as someone from your team is a traitor whose goal is to prevent you from escaping.

You can create improvised tools, weapons, first-aid kits, items for repairs, and much more so long as you have the necessary resources. Your goal is to work as a team to succeed, figure out who the traitors are (who are randomly selected), get food for sustenance, and materials for crafting or repairing. You will be able to purchase cosmetic items for your player (yes, there are loot boxes) after completing optional special tasks that you can choose at the beginning of the mission as well as for useful actions during gameplay.

Playing as a traitor, you must prevent the survivors from escaping by all available means whilst not allowing yourself to be discovered. How will you do this? Your goal is to shift the blame of your misdeeds to others, sabotage repaired stations, and even kill other players, without being seen of course.

As for the core online component, you should always be able find a suitable lobby to join or simply create your own, but the reporting system works quite poorly and is in need of some serious improvement. Some survivors can be very toxic and complain about you simply because you have the role of a traitor (it happens often) even though that's a core element to the gameplay, which is a huge minus, and get you kicked/banned. Sore losers can fundamentally ruin your experience. The developers need to remedy this. The crafting system is also pretty weak. Want to make an axe? You need stone and wood. Want to make an electrical circuit? You will also need stone and wood. ... What???

Despite the negatives, Project Winter causes both positive and negative emotions. I like working together cooperatively, and not all aspects of the game became immediately clear mind you, but it all depends on each player and their contributions to the end goal. It's fairly easy to recommend, but just be aware of its shortcomings going into it.

Posted: November 6, 2020
A LOT more tricky than Among Us. I'd say 'Among Us' is basically 'Project Winter for dummies'. Not that that's a bad thing.

So my first game (after finishing the tutorial) involves me running around like a headless chicken. Not knowing wtf to do, because you have to FIND the objectives without a gigantic indicator in a pretty large map. (unlike among us)

The Reality:
->MASSIVE<- learning curve. Only 1 map and it's in front of the cabin. You're supposed to look at it. Memorize where you're going and trek there. Very survivalist. But might deter a lot of people.

Characters walk slowly and run after a few seconds, it felt like i needed to press the keys harder. Something to consider if you have Carpal Tunnel (which i do).

'Among Us' has everybody running around doing busywork to fill a win gauge. Project Winter you actually have ROLES. From Hunter to Scientist. everybody has something to do. This makes it quite exciting.

Hunger and Freezing Gauge makes it so you have to routinely resupply at the cabin. The game's focus is mainly survivalist as opposed to "whodunnit". Which is good. The thing about 'Among Us' is: If you constantly play as a crewmate, the game gets boring VERY quickly. But in this game, you could focus on supplying food for everyone.....and poisoning it.

The Experience:
After fixing the first repair site we set out looking for the communications tower when suddenly everything goes white and i'm in an area i don't recognize. The panic sets in, then the hunger. I start frantically wandering.

I manage to find a walkie talkie! i shout into it, but only silence answers me. I guess i was the only one who found a walkie-talkie. After wandering around some more; by gods divine grace, i manage to find sustenance. Now all i need is warmth.

I BARELY manage to make it back to the cabin. Allow myself to bathe in the warmth of the fire. From what i remember, The map in front of the cabin marks the objective as being to the south. I prepare myself some berries for the long trek ahead. Exit the cabin determined to help my compatriots! ....and am immediately headshotted.

Game Over. Turns out i was the last survivor. It wasn't silence that answered the walkie talkie, but Lady Death. They speak the same language.

Posted: February 4, 2021
I've done a lot of thinking over the past few weeks about this game, and my refusal to boot it up again. My disgust for a giant game breaking issue that has been unresolved up until this point is the final nail in the coffin. This is my first ever game review, and this issue that I will describe below has given me the drive to actually write one of these up. After discussing this in length with multiple discord servers of seasoned veterans in this game, I am trying to do the right thing for the general community and warning them about an issue that destroys the integrity and any sort of level playing field this game is currently capable of offering. I am here to warn others and steer them away from looking to buy this game until it has been fixed.

With over 300 hours logged in PW, I've seen a lot of different strategies, had countless fun games, and a lot of good memories. Honestly, there's a lot of awful ones too. Simply put, this is a combat simulator stapled on top of a social deduction game. I'm not the biggest fan of some of the combat mechanics such as crossbows seeming to have very poor ballistic programming compared to the guns, but I'll get to the point.

There is a VERY NOTICEABLE difference in movement speed between controller players and keyboard and mouse players. It is such a substantial difference that it makes this game unplayable. It seems as if in the process of programming controls for controller players, they are capable of moving in more than just the cardinal directions. As pathing and terrain highs/lows have a big impact on the speed of your character, the difference in mechanical hardware that a player chooses to use will end up with large differences in the speed of two characters. A player on keyboard and mouse will be limited to navigating with cardinal directions, which will be slowing the character down as they cross over different terrain. A controller player is capable of consistently moving in directions not available to a keyboard player, cutting down precious distance between the two in relatively short amounts of time. Testing this difference seemed to result in a controller player moving about 4x the speed of a keyboard player. I've seen an empty handed keyboard player get chased down by a weapon wielding controller player and STILL manage to run faster than the keyboard player. And believe me, these players have hundreds and hundreds of hours logged into the game. This is not a matter of player vs. player skill.

I'm not sure what else to say regarding this game besides this: the mechanics are fundamentally broken. It will lead to serious frustration when playing against certain people. It will lead to unfair situations that are beyond a player's skill. This game feels more and more like it has devolved into a subpar combat simulator and less and less like a social deduction game with heavier combat elements. There's no point in playing a game where social deduction can be tossed out the window in favor of running someone down and burying them in the snow with no chance of them escaping. Devs: fix this. It's unacceptable. Buyer beware, this is probably not the social deduction game for you.

Snippet:

The game is A LOT OF FUN. I mean, the excitement of a survival game, the thrill of social deduction, the soothing graphics and atmosphere ... just go for it !

The ins and outs:

You and 7 other players are stuck in the middle of nowhere with just a cabin and a fireplace to get warm. Use your fists and brain to gather wood and craft tools, explore the land to find fuel, parts, guns ... fight off the bears and wolves, set traps, and almost as importantly, take care of your mates.
A quater of your squad (a squad of 5 people, up to 8) is actually only interested in sabotage, treason, and murder. While you'll try to reconnect the beacon and call for excraction they'll do anything they can to stop you; or maybe vice versa.

Gameplay:

The game has an ingame voice chat. Use it to talk with the people around you. Craft or find talkies to discuss with a friend from across the map and secretly elaborate plans... Or go oldschool with the proximity text chat, or written messages to your talkie friend.
Use weapons and tools to fend off animals, gather ressources or food, use traps to kill bears... or just use everything to kill your mates; the ones you suspect.... or just sabotage the mission in a bloodbath. If you are more of a subtle player: sabotage doors, steal ressources to slow down the escape process, or just take the helicopter before they do.




Buy it, join discord, find people to play with, make friends, have fun, kill someone, see, no biggies.

Posted: January 9, 2022
This game is currently in the Humble Choice for January 2021. If you are interested in the game and it's before February 1st, 2022, consider picking up the game as part of the current monthly bundle.

A survival game, no wait, social deduction, no it's a cluster!@#$… wait, it’s all of these things.

Project Winter is an interesting game, there are 8 players and each player is either a survivor or a traitor. The survivors try to get rescued, the traitors don’t want to be rescued, and there are a couple of objectives to complete. In the two games I played, the survivors tried to restore power then they had to find and fix up a helipad. It’s a good concept.

The problem is this is also a dense game where the tutorial doesn’t give you a ton of information and I think because a lot of people are new to the game from Humble that they’re not playing it right. Communication is a bit light, there’s no social deduction, and on both games, the mega blizzard killed the group which apparently is an artificial time limit. At least I’m pretty sure it is.

This is a game where you’re going to have to learn the game, and probably one you should play with an established group as the influx of new players and the fact so few things are well explained is a barrier to entry.

Pick this up if you want a more active Among Us, it’s far more complicated than that and players have to work together rather than doing their tasks, but this feels like it could be a really good game, though it’s one that players will have to put in the time and effort to understand.

If you enjoyed this review or want to know what I think of other games in the bundle, check out the full review on or subscribe to my Youtube channel:

Posted: May 9, 2023
Project Winter is an absolute blast of a game that seamlessly combines elements of survival gameplay with the traitor concept similar to the cardgame Werewolves of Millers Hollow. This game truly sets a higher standard for party games.

What really sets Project Winter apart from other party games is its perfect balance of survival, teamwork and betrayal. The survival aspect of the game keeps you on your toes as you scavenge for resources, explore ruins and battle against the harsh wilderness, while the social deduction aspect keeps you constantly guessing as to who among your friends is eventually and inevitably going to stab you in the back.

But what really makes Project Winter stand out from other games in this genre is its incredible replayability. With a variety of different roles to play and multiple different maps to explore, you'll never run out of new experiences to enjoy with your friends. Each game is a unique and exciting adventure that will keep you coming back for more. This makes Project Winter way more fun than Among Us. The game is much more dynamic and engaging, and the gameplay is much more suspenseful and rewarding. With its excellent combination of survival and social deduction elements, Project Winter truly raises the bar for what a party game can be.

In conclusion, I cannot recommend Project Winter highly enough. If you're looking for a fun, engaging, and challenging party game that will keep you and your friends entertained for hours on end, then look no further.

Gdybym miał porównać tą grę, to najbardziej podobna jaką znam jest Deceit: jest grupa śmiałków która próbuje uciec z miejsca, w którym się znajdują, aby się ratować, a zdrajcy muszą im przeszkodzić. Nikt prócz zdrajców nie wie, kto jest zdrajcą nawet przy zabijaniu, więc lepiej skupić się na ucieczce, obserwując innych graczy, bo zdrajca staje się silniejszy gdy go nie widać. Zdrajca może grać pasywnie bez zdradzieckich sztuczek trzymając się grupy, stając się niewykrywalny, ale to nie warto na dłuższą metę, gdyż ktoś musi przeszkodzić w ucieczce (cóż, chyba że gracze się zabijają między sobą).

Co więcej ma w sobie Project Winter? Przede wszystkim kluczowa jest współpraca. Samemu gracz nie może dostać się do bunkrów w którym magazynowane są materiały niezbędne do osiągnięcia głównego celu. Samemu nie da się nawet przeżyć przy pierwszym kontakcie z wilkami. Mając zaufanego towarzysza możesz osiągnąć wiele, o ile ten towarzysz nie jest zdrajcą, no cóż...

Wcielając się w zdrajcę, ma się wiele możliwości na uśmiercenie reszty, i nie tylko uśmiercenie, a przynajmniej uniemożliwienie ucieczki. Jest wiele sposobów, ale żaden nie jest skuteczny na wszystkie sytuacje. Coś co się wydaje skuteczne raz, następnym razem może nie mieć aż tak owocnego efektu. Zdrajca musi dostosować swoją strategię do strategii grupy, zauważyć i wykorzystać ich słaby punkt.

Los towarzyszy może zależeć od ciebie! Prowadź ich do zwycięstwa... albo zguby.

Posted: May 14, 2021
TLDR - Buy this game (with the DLC) for $6 during a Steam sale if you are an adult cis white male or have a degradation kink. Otherwise, reconsider for the time being.

When I first downloaded this game, I absolutely loved it.

The community had some toxic people here and there, but overall it was friendly and welcoming and I made a lot of wonderful friends from the lobby. I loved the mechanics of the game, and it quickly became my go-to game. I was playing it most nights after work for several hours and became fairly well known in the community. The DLC was my favorite and what I played regularly (and how I would recommend that anyone play the game). When I heard the Xbox update was happening, I was excited because that meant that there would be more players to play with since the community was pretty small.

And then the Xbox update happened, and I immediately felt regret for ever being excited.

The TLDR for this next section is basically this - the reporting system for Project Winter is extremely broken and is going to bring you a lot of frustration if you end up in a bad lobby (which happens fairly often thanks to the fact that this game is included with gamepass. Trolls don't lose anything if they are banned from a game that they didn't pay for, so they will play until they get banned, wait the 24 hours - 2 weeks, and go at it again.)

After the cross-play update, the number of sexist and abusive comments that I received in games skyrocketed. I faced multiple lobbies where I was griefed and killed almost immediately because I was a female. Now, I know that toxicity unfortunately comes with certain games and certain communities, so it didn't bother me, but I became concerned at the amount of other female players I knew that were giving up the game because of the amount of abuse they were receiving. And the abuse wasn't being targeted at only women, but all minority groups. I play almost exclusively in the DLC lobbies, so I knew I wasn't even getting the full force of the abuse that was in the regular lobbies. So, I began recording all of my games and reporting the toxic players both in game and in the Project Winter Discord with video proof. The devs had said in the Discord that they were doing the best they could to weed out all of the "toxic" players in the Xbox community like they had done for the PC community in the past, so my hopes were that by reporting with undeniable proof how abusive some of these players were being, something would be done and the community I had grown to love would come back, right?

Wrong.

The only terms for a permaban in Project Winter is if you cheat. I believe they are *just* now increasing that scope after a lot of pushback from the community to include if you use the "most well known offensive slur," but from what I can gather, in most instances a toxic player (with video proof) will only be banned anywhere from 24 hours to two weeks (although I think it is usually on the shorter side). The devs/community mods often point out that they play games with the community all the time and it always goes well for them so the community "really can't be that toxic", but I don't think they understand that any "trolls" are on their best behavior if they are in a lobby with them because they know they will get banned. Combine a free game with short ban times and, well, you get the picture.

The second issue with this is the in-game mechanic that involves swapping skins with a dead player. While this can really help with deception in the game, it is a nightmare for toxic players. Switch skins with someone that you killed out, hide the body, and you are free to go on a toxic rampage under someone else's tag and get them reported! There have been actual instances of legitimate players getting permabanned because a cheater stole their skin after they killed them, axed the whole lobby, and got reported for something they didn't do. Luckily on the main instance I saw of this, several members had video proof that the legit player was not the one actually hacking and it was another player that stole their skin, but I wonder if the player hadn't had other players to back them up with video proof if they would have been allowed back in their game on the ban appeal, which leads me to my last point.

Because Steam freely allows you to change your name, it is really easy to troll lobbies this way. Someone can change their Steam name to yours and if they have the same ranking as you, easily impersonate you in a lobby if you are a regular. Now, while I don't think this would impact in-game reports for toxicity, it does make me worried for Discord reports because all they require is a name and a reason why you want to report them. Video proof helps solidify your claim and makes it more likely something will be done (that something likely being a 24 hour ban, but that's not the point), but with most reports users aren't required to submit their Steam account or anything of the nature to be able to track what accounts the player played with. So, what does that mean if someone changes their username to the same as mine, is super toxic in several lobbies, and then changes their name back? The mods claim that they check those things and that someone can't hide from a ban by changing their name, however considering that they permabanned someone for cheating that DC'ed when loading into the lobby and had their skin taken by a hacker, I don't really believe that they are actively looking into those claims. I think they are taking it at face value and if username X is reported (and they do decide to take action), they will take action against username X instead of seeing if username Y had anything to do with it.

Lastly, the game is really overpriced for what it offers and what the community has become. I bought it on sale with the DLC for around $6, and I would only recommend buying it if it is on sale for that price and you have the patience to deal with toxic people. The community has gotten slightly better as time has gone on, but I don't use my mic when I play anymore (which is rarely) so that could also be why I am facing less problems.

I really loved this game, and I am so disappointed at what it has turned into. Maybe six months from now I will be able to come back and enjoy a game with friends but for now, any time I load into it I leave because any open lobbies have players that I have had issues with in the past, or I end up being targeted because I am not using my mic (which is a whole rant for another day). I hope things change for the sake of the wonderful players that I have met that made the game fun for me in the past. For now, I will play First Class Trouble instead.

The location-based chat feature is my favorite element of this hidden traitor game. The game is excellently balanced in Normal mode (too easy for survivors in Basic and Blackout). Unlike many other games in this genre (Depth, Dead by Daylight, Among Us), the game is not ruined by having new players play with experienced players. Roles are randomly assigned and not present in every game, so you never know what surprise abilities another player may have. Project Winter Review
Project Winter follows the veins of deceptive social games like Town of Salem and expands on the same idea tremendously, offering up a well of content and depth that encourages extremely creative play. It's such a shame, however, that an ocean as deep as Project Winter is only inhabited by the population of your average household fish tank.

A: Simple, because the game is unplayable for me. For almost two hours I sat as a helpless fly on the wall because the game repeatedly failed to detect my microphone, even after trying recommended fixes on their discord. I eventually resorted to becoming a mute student while friendlier members of the community taught me how the game worked. Moreover, the player population is so low that it took ages for me just to find a suitable open lobby in my region. I'd gladly sink far more hours into this game if I could.

Let's continue...

Everyone gathers basic resources such as wood and stone for warmth and tools at the beginning of the game, but it doesn't take long for the group to separate, spreading out in the woods. This is where the game truly shines. Project Winter's chat is proximity-based, both text and VOIP. This leads to certain moments where you may overhear traitors plotting with each other behind a treeline, or maybe even witness a murder of a fellow survivor. Much like other deception games; paranoia and suspicion play a crucial role in Project Winter. You'd probably find yourself in hot water if the group notices the partner you set out into the woods with has failed to return to camp with you.

Project Winter boasts a steep learning curve as it features and intricate crafting and item combination system. For example, players may find or build walkie-talkies, which allow them to directly contact other players who possess walkie-talkies of the same colour. With the only other option of communication being through proximity voice chat. There are even crates littered across the map that will only unlock for traitors, but will sound a quite audible alarm once opened. In my experience, traitors have often opened these crates for items such as poison or weapons. Knowing a shot ringing out from behind the treeline would raise suspicion, traitors would often dispose of any evidence and flee the scene, rousing even more paranoia within the group.

Sometimes, even if you do end up in a lobby which starts, the game dissolves into madness and confusion. I've joined groups filled with new players twice and both times, nobody knew what to do or say when someone got killed. We ended up with no escape plan, made no progress towards identifying the traitors, and no coordination. Luckily, my earlier experiences were far more pleasant, preventing these incidents from souring my overall perception of what this game is really like.

Project Winter's item combination system adds a wealth of depth to the art of deception. Traitors have the ability to poison food items to assassinate stray survivors. Your trusted buddy that had just handed you a walkie-talkie or valuable supplies may in fact be planning to betray you by separating you from the group, then plant evidence on your body with the intention of framing you as a traitor, gaining the misguided trust of the other survivors. Every game has the potential to unfold in an entirely different way, which sets it apart from its peers, which favour far more simplified mechanics. Project Winter is therefore a welcome addition to its genre.

At this point, you're probably wondering why I barely have any play time down despite the praise that I have for the game. So let's be realistic and talk for a second here.

I have no doubt that Project Winter is a great game with a decent amount of replayability. Its mechanics are intuitive and innovative. I truly have no complaints over the game's content in terms of quality delivered. The issues that mar my interest are technical and social in nature.

As mentioned earlier, my microphone simply failed to work with this game. I understand that the game is early access, and it may have been my fault for not applying the fix correctly, but a bug is a bug nonetheless. Moreover, it seems that this microphone issue isn't common. Most if not all the people I've met playing this game have had no issues whatsoever, but that's why you have the ability to refund games on Steam, so I wouldn't let that stop you from trying out this game.

The social aspect is Project Winter's main problem, and may even be its downfall. There is a massive division between players. I've met a small handful of high-level people who I assume are this game's loyal fans, but most of the others I've met have been low level players. Rarely do I ever see someone join the lobby with a rank that fills this gap between levels. From my standpoint, I believe that though there is an active and loyal fanbase behind this wonderful game, its newer players aren't being engaged enough to continue playing. This game is most active in the US region, which usually has at least one or two games running when I check on it. The bottom line is that Project Winter, for the social deception game that it is, simply lacks the playerbase and popularity to provide a consistent experience. I simply don't have the patience or time to attentively sit in the lobby browser waiting for a joinable game to appear.

Do not let technical difficulties scare you. You can always refund games, remember that.

Project Winter delivers everything it advertises without a doubt. I'd recommend it to anyone with friends who already own the game, or anyone who intends to purchase the game along with at least 6 other friends. Otherwise, the player population is simply too low for games to be found on a regular basis. I truly wish this weren't the case.

I have just been playing the game for about 12 "hours" (Not all of which is play time by the way, added in just now to clarify, as most of it is sitting in empty lobbies) in total and there is a serious troll issue with this community. The majority seem fine but the aggressive few truly spoil it and will keep this player base low if it's allowed to continue and some notice isn't put up that people should yes, lie, confuse, create chaos, kill ect but not troll.

------POST EDIT NOTE
actually dead game 
A Screenshot of Project Winter
By: Brechnor

(how can I possibly have 20 hours played when these lobbies are empty most of the time)
-----END POST EDIT NOTE

In one game recently a couple of hours ago I was planting mines at the repaired stations to protect them. one guy (who turned out to be the traitor, no surprise) was harassing me over it accross the game after that, mad that I was right about him. I did not sadly know about the reporting system. (well I still can't find one in game)

In the game after that happened I said "are you the traitor again lol" and he suddenly turned salty and mad, got every one to exile me, started throwing abuse like "no mic shouldn't be playing" "don't play with me again" "stop following me" "you are no good" "useless player" *paraphrasing* etc (dare I say the whole point of the game is to work "together", no? so far all the other games I had people with mics were more than happy that mine isn't currently working and had no issue communicating requests for help)... In isolation that wouldn't matter but it was sustained in that subsequent game which in my opinion, shouldn't be accepted and each game should be taken as fresh with no bearing on the last.

The irony is in the game before the one that he was a traitor, he was fine, told people to join him and ally with him etc but suddenly turned angry because I was right about him in that game when he was, which as far as i'm concerned was completely uneccessary.

If i knew about the report feature I would have definitely filled one in, I will investiate where it is now. Sadly it's too late to report that game unless you can go through my previous games and try to find it then listen to the voice logs.

EDIT: There is no clear report feature in game. All I can find is "go to discord". Some things need to have immediate report methods within a game or it's just too late, which just looking at any past game with chat options will tell you.

Can you please make the report function a little more obvious and perhaps place a very clear moderation warning on the introduction (splash) screen of the game that verbal or text based harassement based on previous games won't be accepted, state that logs are recorded (or not) and that new players are not "useless" because every one has to learn at the start when they are new. (in fact I would argue that calling out the traitor correctly is more clever than useless)

I can't recommend the game to my steam friends in its current moderated state. If it wasn't for the lack of clear rules that seem to make these people become unhinged then this would seriously be one of my top most played games on steam. EDIT: Not any more, sorry.

The few like this can truly spoil the atmosphere of the game, and do some serious long term reputation damage to it if moderated action or accepted behaviour isn't made more obvious to them.

EDIT at 19/20 "hours played" (false time report, actual played time is MUCH much lower)

1: Lobbies are empty 90% of the time, the game only came out a few days ago and i've had it for a couple of days, it's basically dead even though I don't like using that term, it does apply here. my actual game time is only a few hours and not the 19 that steam is reporting.

2: The game disconnects you and doesn't let you back in, even if you are still on the internet.

When there are lobbies it's cool to cancel the ready status, apparently



apparently they do however get banned eventually;


Yett there is no in game button to do that while a game is in progress.

3.1 Games have no admins, there is no one to look at live abuse or harassement or to put server warnings in chat.


They say you can report via discord but by then it's already too late to not sour the experience.

3.2 I still could not find the in game reporting system, if there is one.

4: The chances of actually completing a game with other people are slim. I spent 10 mins on my own after saving 2
survivors who just decided to leave/use escape pod and not returning help in kind.


4.1: You can finish on your own but have no choice but to start with a minimum of 5 people, preferably 8.
Do you want to play with a friend and learn to survive? Nope, you can't do that.

Posted: August 15, 2020
This is currently the most fleshed out and enjoyable social deduction game, in my opinion. Aside from just social manipulation, there are a ton of different ways for traitors to sabotage the objectives or slow down and prevent survivors from escaping. Anywhere from siphoning parts out of the objective, planting mines, bear traps, poisoning food, jamming radios and leading people into the wilderness to kill them where no one can hear them, to simply running around the map and opening traitor crates to get buff and fight the survivors head on. Completing the objectives as a survivor isn't particularly easy either and takes a good bit of communication and teamwork. The game offers additional incentive to complete the match and objectives by giving points that can be spent to open crates or purchase cosmetics.

My only complaints are: 1. The lack of a decent tutorial. It took me hours to get any sort of grasp on the game mechanics and even now 30 something hours in there are some things I may not completely understand. I've hardly touched the DLC for this reason. And 2. Dead players being able to essentially reveal Traitors by debuffing them in front of survivors. It doesn't happen often, but when it does it can feel pretty cheap.

Overall though, I highly recommend. The game can often be a ton of fun and is a great tool to improve social skills.

Game was fun until the Xbox/Crossplay update. They opened the game up to a wider audience; great, right? Nope.

I've heard the n-word more in one day of playing this game after the Xbox/Crossplay update, than I've ever heard previously in it. Actually, I think I never heard it when it was only PC players. Pub games, which were the typical hit-or-miss that you'd expect from multiplayer games, have fallen into miss-or-miss-or-miss-or-hit. A lot of third party communication going on, e.g. one survivor dying and then multiple people no where near, with no radios, know who the traitor is; a lot of very horrible people getting on and using multiple slurs. It's a multiplayer game, so your mileage may vary, but from my experiences, it's pretty bad.

I don't say any of this out of the assumption that I'm the best player or even a good player. I play the game, try to have fun, that's it.

It's not a bad game, it's pretty fun when the stars align, but that's few and far between. The games can be decently long and drawn out depending on how the traitors and survivors play, how much they know, etc. It can make the game a lot more grindy and boring at its worst.

They also recently updated the roles, which I'm not a giant fan of. I get what they were going for, but I personally don't like it.

Recommended if you have a large friend pool and like Among Us, but only if you're willing to learn a bit about roles and such, otherwise it'll just be a big drag.

Posted: December 9, 2021
If you can name a social deduction game, I've played it. My favourite games of all time were social deduction games. With that, I can confidently say that THIS IS NOT a social deduction game. If you're playing this game for the social deduction aspects, you've picked the wrong game. This game's PVP system vastly overpowers any advantage from social deduction. The only time that this game plays out as a social deduction game is if you get a group of like-minded players who want to play for the social deduction aspects of this game, and create a private match. Otherwise, it will not play out like one.

In normal mode:
In lobbies with bronze thumb players (basically new players), the majority of them do not, and have not played social deduction games before, and there will likely be a few trolls or metagaming friends. It does not play out like a social deduction game. You will likely make it to the end as a survivor with a few minutes left, and then the traitors will attempt a last-ditch effort to win through PVP.
In lobbies with bad silver/gold thumb players (basically experienced players), the same is probably true with their experience in social deduction games. However, they are all a little bit more experienced, and as such, know that the game's PVP mechanics far overpower any social deception/deduction that someone might attempt, and as such, don't even try for it. The traitors go off into the wild and buff up with energy drinks, and slowly pick off survivors, because the survivors are barely coordinated here.
In lobbies with good players, the survivors all rush objectives, while the traitors buff up, preparing for fights. There is only PVP here. If you try sussing someone who is in the group, they will leave them alive, because one weak traitor is not very impactful if everyone just goes in a group.

The only alternative is Blackout mode, where I have sunk the majority of my hours. In this mode, there is only one traitor, who can convert the survivors. Due to the fact that the evil faction will inevitably grow larger, soon beyond the point where you can stop it, the survivors must attempt to employ social deduction. However, they do not, and as such, this gamemode has a 90% traitor winrate from what I've seen, the only survivor wins coming from experienced lobbies where the survivors mindlessly rush the objectives and win within eight minutes, or the traitor is new to the game, and doesn't understand how to play.

Needless to say, the only time where social deduction is required is if you want to actually have fun, which does not happen unless you play with friends.




Otherwise, this game is great for interacting with people, and finding new friends!

Product received for free

At a research station in a frozen tundra, where the weather has turned for the worse with massive storms becoming more frequent & extreme, eight survivors are trapped. Not everyone is who they pretend to be. Two traitors have infiltrated the ranks and disrupted communications, and other key equipment will need to be repaired in order to call for a rescue. In order to survive, you will need to work with the other survivors to loot buildings, gather needed resources such as craft food, tools & weapons, and repair broken machinery. Good communication & teamwork is vital; venture off on your own and you make yourself a target, all while trying to avoid and identify those who wish to see you fail. The traitors are outnumbered but will gain strength as the game progresses, with their own set of perks & abilities that the rest of the team does not have. They will also gain additional advantages for making you fail in your missions. Finding out who they are is not easy; vigilance is needed in your observations of everything that happens around you. The traitors are not your only threat; wild animals are roaming about – they can be eaten, or if you're not careful, they may eat you. Periodically a vicious blizzard will roll in; get caught outside for too long and you shall perish. But death is not the end; once your life has ended your ghost will have a few powers to either help the survivors or debuff the traitors. Good luck survivors!

Released on May 23, 2019, by the developer Other Ocean Interactive & Published by Other Ocean Group, this is an action cooperative survival game at heart with a mixture of strategy and RPG elements. It features an outstanding low poly graphics in a bird's eye view. It is accompanied by a delightful soundtrack as well as very well-done sound effects. Its proximity-based voice chat allows for communication with anyone in the vicinity. Alternatively, there are two radio types you can use to speak privately, as long as no one else has one. It has a set of creative mechanics at play that has a medium learning curve, so it may take you a few games to grasp how everything works. With random generation for the game world and multiple escape scenarios, no two games will never be quite the same. Full controller support allows you to play it your way. With character progression that unlocks clothing sets, and rewards that allow you to buy multi-tiered loot crates with the money you earn to customize your character to your heart's desire.

Quite a remarkable survival game with its unique genre blending. Though the traitor mechanic isn't totally original, they managed to use it to their advantage and made something remarkable and essential to the title. I play a lot of games with the mechanic and totally enjoy them, especially with friends. The winter biome is done nicely, and those blizzards are really something else! (I have an infinitive love for titles that feature a good winter scenario.) I admit I am not the greatest at the game yet as I am still learning everything. Playing with pubs is not my favorite thing to do; I prefer playing with friends personally, and I am really looking forward to more of my friends getting the title. Finding games is not all that difficult; often servers will be full though, and finding an open lobby is difficult at times. I found that when there were no open lobbies, you could just open one yourself; it will fill pretty fast, and then you're on your way! With a fair retail price and randomly-generated games, it’s great value with a great amount of replayability.

As there is no single-player gameplay to learn the game, I would have liked to have had a tutorial to introduce the player to the core mechanics. I personally do not like having to jump into a game with seasoned players who take advantage of your lack of knowledge. A basic tutorial giving the player the needed knowledge for basic survival & key mechanics would be quite helpful for new players.

Posted: November 23, 2020
A less casual approach in comparison to Among Us, although still accessible. There is a tutorial and roles are explained well. You will need more dexterity and better hand-eye-coordination for Project Winter. The aspects of deception are comparable to Among Us, although Project Winter offers a lot more possibilities, while a lot of the finer psychological aspects remain in one way or another.
For instance, if you know what your friends sound like when they're lying, you can apply your knowledge just as well in this game. Then again, if an alibi doesn't quite add up, you might end up killing one of your loved ones. And just as in real life, killing your friends is always kind of a bummer.
Oh, and you might have chaos ensue when people randomly start hitting or blaming each other. And then, once someone is dead, you can wear their clothes to make yourself look like them, because that helps with the formerly mentioned chaos. So if you're also a good voice actor, this game could become your new favorite.
The community consists of, I would say 68-87% okay people (at least okay to play with, not necessarily to marry) and your occasional griefer/troll. But don't worry, there's also a report function and an indicator for a player's reputation, represented by a thumbs-up-icon with colors ranging from red (nu-uh) to the standard bronze (whatever) to silver (whatever+) to gold (okay). Note that not every okay player has a golden reputation, as reputation resets over time. So sometimes you'll have to play with them first to get to know them better. Yuck, I know.

This is supposed to be a recommendation.

Posted: October 14, 2022
Why you should or should not play Project Winter

What is Project Winter?

An awesome survival game with the main objective of escaping, you can LITERALLY betray your friends. For those of you who know of among us, might relate it to this game however it is a lot more in depth. Instead of tasks you need to craft weapons, items and cook your own food in order to survive this game... while also being watched by the traitors. There are more ways to die other then just the traitor killing you, you can die from bears, moose, wolves, and even the COLD. There is proximity voice chat which plays a huge roll in the overall game (Like yelling who the traitor is). There is still more too it, but I will let you figure that out for yourself!



-'Oh god whats happening'
-'Did I just die from being eaten by a bear?'
-'I just murdered a snow man'

This game had a roller coaster of emotions, and you can tell that the creators took the time to really make this game work with a variety of hilarious and technical things. At first I really thought "Among Us knock off" but then I actually played it and it was so much more intense then that.



I would say the overall playability is pretty simple and straightforward... the do have a tutorial but I did not play it and went straight in. The randoms in my game actually helped and taught me how to play the game... they thought it was hilarious that I didn't play the tutorial and just went straight in confused and afraid.




For keyboard and mouse it is basic controls, WASD for walking and your mouse keys for cutting down trees and such. You can still change your keybinds before, after and during the game.
During the actual game play, it is pretty straightforward, crafting, running, foraging, etc. This game is also both keyboard and controller friendly, I believe they sell it on multiple platforms as well so you will run into a load of different kinds of people.
So far my computer did not lag, and it looks like you can edit the graphics and make it a pretty low running game if needed.
There is also a load of character customization that is included in the main screen, you have a variety of items you can choose from.
There are events that happen during the game which makes it harder to survive or identify the traitor (like snow storms, the traitor teleports you etc)
Considering the amount of different ways you can die because of this game, it can become super complicated when you are being hunted and one of your only safe spots is the cabin itself but you cant stay their forever because you do need to escape the game.
When you die you can choose to spectate and see what is happening and help out by giving people warmth and food or hurt by making people suffer and speed up the decreasing of food and warmth.

There are other game modes, however I only played one of them so I will not be mentioning them in this review.



In my opinion, the graphics in this game are unique and beautiful. There are spots in the game where you can stand and admire the games beauty at a different perspective compared to your eagle eye view. They did an amazing job with snow, snow trails and character design.



AMAZING 10/10 got rick rolled the first game I played with a father son duo.
However, if you do not like playing with children under the age of 14 then maybe do not play this game. The game is a range of ages, and from what I saw there is an equal amount of people under the age of 18 as well as over.



You can play for as long as you want, because this game is more on the competitive side, you can play over and over and over again. The game can take anywhere between 10-30 ish minutes. Then you can choose to stay in that lobby of people or switch lobbys and play with different people.



Honestly, I would recommend this game if you enjoy foraging, crafting, survival and competitive pvp roles. For me, I enjoyed it because everyone made me laugh and made me have a really really good time while playing the game. As for if I would play again, I might, so far though I haven't. Now one more thing is that the game isn't too too active, there could be more players but I understand that is dependent on the person themselves, but that is not going to change my overall opinion of the game itself!

I hope this 'review' which was more my opinion then a review, was helpful in some way. Have an awesome day wherever you may be! Don't get mauled by a bear okay... only do that in the game.

Despite this, I still have lots of memorable moments and exciting encounters. This is one of those games where you need to be a patient person to enjoy it.

Posted: January 1, 2021
There is a surprising amount of depth in the raw mechanics of the game:
- Precisely timing a 99% charged swing maximizes DPS / efficiency
- Timing your swings while spinning extends your range
- Moving with nothing in your hand increases your speed
- Aiming to throw extends your vision
- Throwing items at someone slows the target
There's also a lot of strategy you pick up on over dozens of hours:
- Guarding and trapping objectives
- Hiding and destroying resources
- Determining what information is safe to say in proximity chat, over a radio, or globally (e.g. 2nd objective beacon)
- Acquiring info from snow trails / losing pursuers in a chase
- How to position around high ground, north camera, and hiding places in combat
All of the mechanics can be part of the social and deceptive elements. All of the following is important information:
- Who stayed to mine rocks
- How a group reacted upon finding radios
- What items someone leaves in a chest
- Which direction people suggest to travel in
- Who touched which dead bodies
I could write a list of maybe 70 things to keep track of and even then each game brings unique circumstances that challenge these fundamentals. This game has a lot going on.

Posted: July 28, 2022
If you started out with Among Us or are familiar with other social deception games, but ever felt like it lacked an element of interactivity or ability to affect the game through teamwork and gameplay, this is a game for you.

Adding in combat (and not a simple one-button kill option) and the need to keep your stats (heat, hunger, and health) in order leads to a much more involved game that makes it replayable over many months, with no two games being exactly the same. You can take things into your own hands at times, but it is often important to rely on teamwork to be successful.

For those new to the game, there is a bit of a learning curve, but relying on the tutorial and easy game modes help to pick up, followed by asking questions of players as you get into regular games. Having a headset makes playing the game much easier. Some might find that learning curve too daunting, but there are many regular players that otherwise didn't really consider themselves "gamers" prior to getting the hang of this game.

The reporting system and the discord server help to combat the trolls you might find in any game. Overall, a great game with a good core group in the community that you will get to know well and meet up to play with frequently!

Posted: 20 May, 2021
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Basically, it's a 2D battle royale game where you fight 63 other colorful animals to the death with guns and various melee weapons (lollipops, newspaper, fly swatters, pizza cutters, etc.). It's fun, cartoony, silly, and cute, and I love every bit of that. Oh, and this game penalizes death with random, bad animal puns, so prepare to get "diskoalafied" a lot.

The gameplay is very fun, and it's great when you get better at it! In fact, there are also a wide variety of weapons for different play styles, and most weapons have some sort of a more rare upgraded version:
Do you like firing fast? Get an SMG (or Thomas Gun) or a Pistol (or Silenced Pistol)
Do you like instantly destroying people up close? Grab a Shotgun (or JAG-7)
Prefer to pick off people from a distance? Get a Hunting Rifle (or Sniper Rifle)
Hunting rifle too slow? Get a Magnum (or Deagle)
Want to track enemies? Get a Bow and Sparrow (or Sparrow Launcher)
Want to remove multiple people from the game really fast? The minigun is super fun
Like healing teammates or doing poison damage that completely ignores armor? Grab a dart gun
Like explosions? Grab some grenades


You have so many options for playing this game or trying new things. You can hold two weapons (besides melee and grenades), so try mixing and matching and see what you like most. There are no wrong answers here (though holding TWO shotguns probably isn't the best strategy, but you CAN do it if you want to!). It's not really a rock-paper-scissors sort of game, either, since you can hold both the "rock" and "scissors" at the same time.

There are also a wide variety of places to go in this game, and the map design overall is really good and has a lot of content in it for you to explore and find more stuff in. And, yeah, there's actually lore in this game! Cool, huh??

The community is also pretty good here, especially outside of the game, though the in-game chat pre-game can be... weird. Let's just say it's not moderated very well.

Community interaction is something the developers do a pretty good job at, and they're especially good with content creators like streamers and people who make videos.

The soundtrack by Jake Butineau is also really good. You can get it on Bandcamp or listen to it on Spotify or YouTube. I recommend giving it a listen!


This game is free-to-play. But spending money DOES grant you access to more content.

Here's the usual preface that the game makes clear: There is absolutely no gameplay advantage or incentive to actually spend money on this game. In fact, not even the free unlocks do anything to gameplay. Your character, gameplay-wise, is the same the first time you play the game as it will be the 1000th time. So, being a tap dancing cyberpunk tiger wielding a giant axe will not make you any more or less powerful than the default fox. And the Default Dance is the best dance, anyway!

HOWEVER, if you don't buy the Super Edition (around $15 at the time of writing this), some milestones (therefore, some unlockable cosmetics) are not available to you. Of course, the game will track your stats, so if you DO decide to buy it later, you can simply go back and click "Unlock" on all of the milestones you unlocked. Also, while there are loads of free stuff you can unlock, it's worth noting that Carl coins drop twice as much with the Super Edition, which means some of these free unlocks may take longer to get if you don't have it than if you did. I don't consider this one-time thing a "microtransaction" since it's a one-time purchase that gets you a large portion of the game.

But yes, like many free-to-play games (or even paid games nowadays), this game ALSO has a premium currency ("SAW tickets"). There are no gambling mechanics, and anything that can be unlocked through gameplay - which is most things - CANNOT be unlocked through microtransactions (and vice versa). Not everyone is OK with microtransactions (and if you aren't, you've probably made up your mind about the game at this point!), but it's at the very least an honest system Pixile has here.


This game is fun to play over and over again! While it has risen in popularity recently, it's not MASSIVELY popular yet, with typically only around 500-1500 players online depending on what time you play the game. So, you may find that games can often take between 2-4 minutes to fill. It does have bots, meaning you're going to be seeing people like "Dave from Sales" and "Not a bot" a lot in here. Bots provide a fair challenge, but once you figure out how they work, they're pretty easy to deal with (unless you're alone against a group of bots... oh dear).

So, I'm going to give this game a recommendation! The core gameplay is quite fun, and it's free, so there's nothing to lose by merely trying it. Other battle royales didn't really click for me, but this game sure does!

Posted: March 24, 2019
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
A Battle Royale game for people who don't like Battle Royale games. I've read a good few comments in the chat where people say this is their favorite Battle Royale, and I'd have to agree. Matches are quick and gear is plentiful enough so you can kit yourself out with a viable loadout shortly after dropping. You may or may not have the highest tier gear, but it does not take long to find something that suits your style or the situation and you can dive right into the gunplay. Different weapons work better in different situations, so there is some thought that goes into what to cary. Shotties are devistating at close range. The AK and the uzi are both automatic weapons, but the AK is superior at longer ranges while the uzi's rate of fire will out-damage the AK when close up (provided you land your shots). Sniper rifles do heavy damage and will eat the opponent's armor, leaving them vulnerable. Half of the battle is just using the right tactics for the right situation.

In SAR, encounters are frequent enough to keep things interesting and the pacing of the storm always keeps you moving. Of course battles can and will end as quickly as they start and send you right back to the title screen, but I've had fun every time.

Check out the free version and give it a go.
(If you enjoy the game, the full version gives you access to all the cosmetics you unlocked. It doesn't give you a competitive edge, but you get to look pretty and it supports development :P)

The shortest way to describe it is "Fortnite but Furry", but there's more to it than that.

Posted: March 6, 2022
This is not just the most adorable and wholesome way ever to slaughter each other, this is also a game where everything about payments and rewards feels so considerative and appreciative towards the players.

The amount of playable characters and cosmetics you can unlock just by playing (even without getting the Super Edition) is incredible. Even if you lose matches frequently it still feels rewarding. You know about those things called Season Pass in games like those? (Ofc you know, it is a rethorical question. :P) Usually you have to decide if it is actually worth paying for the upgraded version to get all the rewards out of them, because you don't know if you have enough playing time to actually finish them and get everything out of them. Not in this game though - no oh. Here you can finish each and every single pass you paid for and can even have two of them active at once. You can pay for old passes and still just see them through if you like at any time.

You don't pay for the chance of maybe getting everything you paid for in time. You pay for getting everything you paid for in you own pace and time. This is something that deserves a lot of praising cause I've never ever before seen something like that. Are they trying to make money with it? Ofc - They worked hard on it. Are they trying to squeeze every penny out of their players to make a somewhat enjoyable experience while playing possible? No, they do not and we should all love 'em for that.

Posted: December 13, 2018
EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
A well-polished 2D BR with an FPS feel to it
Disclaimer: Have spent over 60 hours playing the game since Alpha and am now a community mod. This is sort of a review/guide hybrid.

Tl;dr: Super Animal Royale is a smooth overhead 2D BR with an FPS feel owing to unique sightline mechanics and solid sound design as well as short rounds. It’s both a battle royale for people that don’t like battle royales and also a great game for vets tired of the usual grind.

Super Animal Royale (SAR) catches your eye at first with the well-done character art and beautiful environments. It’s not overly detailed to the point of turning into static noise, yet every item in the game looks lovingly crafted with unique features. The game is easier to approach than most other BRs and serves as a great entry-point into the genre. At the same time, there is plenty to learn and figure out as you get better and ascend to the top of the food chain more and more often.

The super animals are essentially bipedal versions of their species that can dance and use lethal weaponry. And there are a variety of weapons that are easily recognizable and do about what you would expect from them. As well as some unique standouts like a rideable hamster ball that can take down others at full speed and bananas that slip players up. Yet more powerful weapons exist with some only found in the occasional drops from a mole that appears at random on the map.
You start off with a few animals unlocked and others yet to be researched through DNA you obtain by playing matches.

The different animals all have the same hitboxes and stats so any difference is purely cosmetic. There is plenty of clothing, items, emotes, dances etc. that drop randomly at the end of a round. I appreciate this model as it keeps the playing field level by giving you all gameplay related features right off the bat and limiting unlocks to cosmetics. And no loot boxes unlike certain other games.

The map is sizeable with plenty of different environments to explore. From a claustrophobic swamp with its many bridges to navigate to a frozen over tundra to a research facility where they [REDACTED]. There’s definitely a living world here with plenty of lore to uncover. And there to ignore if you wish to focus more on the gameplay. It is also quite navigable by foot without feeling stranded just because you lack a vehicle.

The gameplay differentiates itself from 2D battle royales in part by having a line of sight system. While the game is presented in an overhead view, you don’t automatically have full knowledge of everything on the screen. Trees, rocks, houses, and even stacked crates can obscure your vision. This allows for tense situations where you have to rely on the game’s sound to figure out where you opponents are.

And what a great sound design this game has. Everything sounds pleasant to the ears and feels crisp. Figuring out where shots come from is pretty easy and also essential to staying alive. Rolling, running, and crouch walking all have varying levels of sound. While you might wish to roll forward towards an enemy, doing so close to them will be quite audible and give away your position.

Also worth mentioning is that running will reduce your weapon accuracy. Crouch walking and standing both help out in landing shots, but also expose you to enemy fire. Learning to balance aim accuracy while on the go will be key to surviving. Most of the time you can get away with reasonable accuracy while running, but it is sometimes worth slowing down and aiming a few key shots with your magnum or sniper. The shooting is ultimately more arcadey than realistic so don’t worry too much.

The pacing of this game stands out from other BRs. SAR takes no more than ten minutes to finish a single round which is often just the start of the midgame in similar titles. Dying after a few minutes of looting is far less frustrating than spending 20 minutes running around just to die to a random headshot. This is the ultimate game for when you’re waiting on someone or something and just want to get a quick match in.

The core battle royale mechanics are all here. Up to 64 super animals launch from an eagle flying across the map. You choose where to jump off and conveniently the game also tells you when fellow teammates eject. There is an ever shrinking circle outside of which you take damage. There is a healing mechanic that is streamlined wherein you gather health items that are added to a health juice bottle that you carry around. Plenty of items to be found lying around. There’s several degrees of armor. And you can currently queue up in Europe, North America, or Asia as either a solo player, with another person, or in a 4-person squad.

And lastly, the game just feels smooth. From the animations to gunplay to the actual game running on my computer. You can run this thing on pretty much any computer released in the past decade and it’ll run perfectly. There’s been a ton of optimization since the game’s launch and your average modern gaming rig will max this easily with plenty of power to spare. Look down on games that can’t run at least 300fps smoothly at all times? SAR’s got you covered. Dislike sloppy networking code that robs you of kills? SAR performed reasonably well even when I tried playing it on the Asian servers all the way from New York (~230ms ping).

This game is just polished to an insane degree considering the small team size and the fact that this is their first such title on PC/MAC. They have been incredibly responsive on their discord when it comes to bugs and feature requests. The game’s grown from a small map with scant items to multiple biomes and a full arsenal in a fairly short time. I’m reasonably optimistic about expecting more of the same in the months of early access to come. Given the low entry price, I feel that I’ve already gotten my money’s worth in the alpha/beta tests. And with more features promised in the future, it already feels like a steal.

Posted: September 11, 2021
Super Animal Royale, or SAR for short, is a great not-so violent take on the popular genre. SAR does a great job of providing an set of good intuitive controls that gives it's easy to pick up and play appeal.

On the surface, SAR comes off mildly childish. You see this with the lack of blood splashing everywhere, the play-on-words dead screen send offs and a light-hearted poof as your gravestone appears. Your chosen animal, of which there are diverse choices which stand out from each other, can be customized with evolutions and various stylish clothing choices. Skins can be obtained through Easter Eggs, completing some PvP tasks or through an in-game shop with a micro-transaction option in addition as a way to spend currency earned through playing the game.

Overall the gameplay is rather simple to pickup, and genuinely feels rewarding when you get better at the game. The base controls feel almost perfect, but none the less the items, weapon variation, special ability, utility item and health consumables are nicely implemented and fairly balanced. Time to Kill can vary greatly, but skill is a major factor in quick kills, your own luck also appears to have a devastating effect on time to kill mechanics also.

With a smooth solid game play experience that is youth friendly, this title can be expected to deliver countless hours of replay-ability.

Posted: July 28, 2022
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.
