Posted: November 28, 2019
My Experience

I actually started playing ibb & obb with a friend like six months ago. We immediately found the visual design to be charming and the gameplay design to be clever.

However, and perhaps this is just me, I find puzzle games like this to be exhausting. In your more traditional AAA action/adventure games, you'll have an action segment, then a puzzle segment, then an action segment, etc. In ibb & obb, it's just puzzle after puzzle after puzzle. So, instead of the game itself managing the pacing, you'll need to manage it yourself. For me, this meant only playing ibb & obb in 30 minute to 1 hour increments. In addition, it could be one of the reasons that my co-op partner and I would put the game down for weeks at a time.

Additionally, please note that there is quite a bit of platforming in ibb & obb. It is much more of a puzzle-platformer than a pure puzzle game. There were multiple sections that required precise timing and movement to navigate, and these were difficult even after you figured out what you were supposed to do. The execution itself could be a roadblock.

Although ibb & obb seems to be a well-designed puzzle game, I can't claim to have really enjoyed my time with it that much. I'll give it a recommendation though, because it could be that I just don't like the puzzle game genre very much.

Posted: September 6, 2016
Ibb & Obb * 7/10

No story. No settings. Just Puzzles. End of Review.

No, seriously, how can a game like this be so nice? Really, there's no story because it wouldn't change that much, the setting is irrelevant it's more about the art itself. The only thing that matters in this game is cooperative work, and that's because this game is Cooperative only, either local or via servers.

So, this is a sidescroll platform and you have to play with a friend as Ibb & Obb. All you have to do is run the two fellas along the world. A world split in half by the ground and you can switch side through occasional portals in order to get past dangers or obstacles. Obviously the other side has an inverted gravity and this is just one of the many little things that you will notice along your runs with your friend as there will be many more obstacles and situations that will require cooperation and teamwork, tight syncronization and creative solution as the more you'll progress through the levels, the more complicated and elaborated the situations will be.

The artistic aspect of the game is so minimalistic, but colorful and polished, kind of childish but it's not that kind of dumb childish. It's something relaxing and maybe a bit nostalgic. The music isn't anything outstanding but it's a very nice and light musical accompaniment that will encourage that relax sensation you have while playing this game.

I must admit that I kind of get angry when I get stuck with games both for difficulty or unsolvable puzzles, but with Ibb & Obb it just doesn't happen. I stand and wait, I try to figure a solution, a workaround, I discuss with my friend a possible way to pass through and if we just can't figure it out we'll just end our session to resume the next days (with success).

Posted: March 22, 2015
Starts out very interesting and follows a good principle: simple enough that they players always know that they have all the tools they need to solve a puzzle. They also use very frequent mini check points, so you don't have to start a whole level over.
...
But then it digresses into really tricky timing platforming with multiple challenging tasks in timed sequenses and the fun sort of drains off to exaspiration. Put another way, when you know how to solve a puzzle but they needlessly have easy to fail tight timing/positioning things that all have to be done as one continuous chain where either person can fail, and have to do it all over again. I think I'd rather play something else at that point.

If you really really love tricky platforming (both pricision/timing and intelectualy challenging), you may really like this game. I liked if for a short while and then hit a point where it felt like a chore and I didn't want to pick it up again.

Posted: October 25, 2020
I don't write serious reviews often, but I just want to talk about how disappointed I was by this game. The first half of it was amazing. The co-op puzzles were very fun and satisfying to solve, and it had brilliant level design that gradually introduced the nuances of each gimmick. But in the second half, the puzzle aspects get dialed down in favor of platforming challenges, where the co-op aspect often feels like an afterthought. My friend and I often got stuck in later levels, not because we were stumped by a puzzle, but because dodging an enemy required stupidly precise movement (magnified by the fact that if one player dies, the other instantly dies too) and gravity bubble segments where you both have to complete it at the same time if you don't want to fight against the camera. Once the game introduced a darkness gimmick we just gave up and decided it wasn't worth completing. This game could've been amazing, but instead it was just saddening. But at the end of the day, that first half was a fun time, and I recommend it just for that, but I sincerely wish the rest of the game maintained that same design.

Posted: March 13, 2018
A harmless looking, cute little platformer with relaxing music and some neat co-op mechanics like jumping on each others heads to reach higher places, killing upside down enemies so your friend can collect their gems, or pushing each other into angry shadow hedgehogs for the heck of it. Repeatedly. Even though that kills both of you.

When I say harmless looking, what I mean is, don't let the adorable little blobs deceive you. This game is actually evil. It's stressful, can be hectic, sometimes requires precise (co-operative) timing, will kill you over and over and over, and it might make you feel exceptionally dumb at times.

It took us about 7 hours to complete in co-op. Apparently, there is a speedrun somewhere out there which takes about half an hour and which I refuse to watch because my self-esteem can only take so many gut punches.
(To be fair, those 7 hours also include several cases of murder, some manslaughter, and quite a few occasions of "giving up and looking up a walkthrough".)

The graphics are very nice; somewhat simplistic, colourful yet easy on the eyes, and even aforementioned shadow hedgehogs (who are out to kill you) are oddly adorable.
Some might find the music a little too relaxing, it can create a very false sense of security, but I personally liked it a lot.

The gameplay isn't exactly special, it's a platformer. Sometimes it's a bit hard to land on a narrow platforms, especially in cases when you have to be quick about it, but overall I think it's alright. Occasionally you have to run from things that follow you, without being exactly sure what comes next, so a bit of trial & error is definitely involved, though as long as you're in the game, checkpoints are fairly frequent.
There are no save points within levels (or stages). You have to complete them before it's reasonable to throw your controller out the window in utter frustration; but technically, the levels are short enough to make that okay when you don't spend too much time staring at a puzzle in dumbfounded silence.

There are secret levels and hard to reach bonus gems in each stage which I can only assume are even more complicated to reach than the ways forward. We might have found one of those secrets way back at the start of the game, but if we did, it was an accident, and I'm not sure it ever happened in the first place. It's nice that this is a thing, though.

I very much recommend this game if you have someone to play co-op with and aren't likely to disown your friend just because they've thrown you into a shadow hedgehog one too many times. While it's possible to play it alone, you'd have to be utterly mad and maybe possessed by several demons to do that.

Posted: July 4, 2016
Positive:
- Simplistic yet beautiful art style
- Nice calming music
- Simple, functional game mechanics
- Gradual learning curve
- Difficult challenges
- Very fun and fair
- Replay value (improve your score)

Negative:
- You need another player

Conclusion:
Ibb & Obb is a fantastic puzzle-platformer. It's mechanics and physics are simple enough but the game gradually becomes more complex such that you have to combine these simple mechanics to solve the later puzzles. While difficult, it is very fulfilling to finally solve them.
I haven't tried playing this game with strangers online, but I can imagine it can be frustrating if you can't communicate properly (there is an in-game function to communicate with your partner but a voice chat would probably be more useful). Thus I would only recommend getting this game if you have a reliable friend to play it through with you. Still an excellent game though.

Posted: July 12, 2015
I have never wrote a review before but this game is so cute I had to. I bought this in a sale but I would say it's worth the full price as you will have so much fun with it!

This is a lovely and fun game to play with a friend or a loved one as it is a fantastic puzzle solver. You will enjoy playing it even more if you use a microphone in multiplayer so you can communicate and help each other to complete the levels.
It took me and my friend 20 hours to complete it and to do all of the achievements. The 'Quality Time' achievement was a lot of fun to do and took a couple of hours to achieve. Both of us enjoyed playing this and had a lot of fun dying throughout due to the varied difficulty. The levels start off simple and as you progress the later ones become frustrating and a little troublesome, but if you keep trying you will eventually finish the game. We both became stuck on some puzzles for awhile but we found the solution by trying many different ways.
It is quite interesting and difficult to find all the hidden crystals and obtaining the highest possible score on all levels, but there are guides that can help you with that.
In the game you can move your mouse and some paint follows which I thought was an excellent way to show the person you're playing with if you had an idea. Also, when you finish a level ibb & obb do a dance which I found adorable.
The whole of the game is bright and colourful, and is worth playing to the end so you can see the final cutscene.
After completing the game I decided to craft the badge. The emoticons turned out to be pleasant to use and the backgrounds are cute due to the little characters on them. I will be using these often as they are my favourites.
The only negative I'd have to say is that the last few levels were really difficult for me and I made my friend do most of the bits because I couldn't, I probably would have if I practiced over and over. This game involves teamwork if you're playing on multiplayer and patience to finish it. Oh, and another thing, I wish there were more levels!

10/10 for ibb & obb! <3

Posted: January 6, 2019
Marketing ibb & obb as an exclusively co-op game was a huge mistake,
because it is very possible to play, enjoy, and beat the game as a single player, using the keyboard to control both characters. The result is a really interesting and difficult puzzle-platformer, well worth the price if you're looking for a challenge.

It's also possible -- though very challenging (and very rewarding) -- to 100% the game as a single player controlling both characters. I wouldn't put it in quite the same box as other "tough-as-nails" platformers like Super Meat Boy, since it has puzzly mechanics that are quite different and unique. But that's really part of it's charm.

It's by no means a "casual" experience to play it as a single player. But if you dig stuff like SMB, you really should give it a go.

Posted: June 22, 2016
One of the most enjoyable co-op experiences I've had. Great puzzles, beautiful art style, cute characters, good music. Get a whole lot of mileage out of a handful of simple gameplay mechanics. You'll find yourself screaming in frustration, shouting and pumping your fist in triumph, erupting in cathartic laughter as it finally seems you and your friend will accomplish the intricate, difficult procedure you've spent so long figuring out and attempting, only to see your friend make a stupid mistake and ruin everything at the last second.

The game only lets you communicate with your online parter by drawing blobby, imprecise lines onscreen. This could be seen as a drawback, but in fact it becomes its own meta-puzzle: how do I explain this detailed series of actions that will involve precise timing, without using any words? You come to develop a rudimentary syntax; you start saying yes and no by moving back and forth and jumping up and down, respectively, or you draw frantic scribbles on the screen to indicate frustration. It's so much more satisfying to solve puzzles this way; you really feel like you've accomplished something beyond the game itself. Of course there are also those infuriating moments when you give up trying to use the in-game language and resort to Steam chat, or even make a phone call and talk through it in real time. And then there are transcendent moments when you and your partner both know exactly what to do without attempting any communication at all.

It's also great fun to be a jerk and push your partner over cliffs or into enemies.

If I have only one criticism it's that if you're playing with more than one friend (say, one online and one IRL) there's no reliable way to keep track of which levels you've finished with each friend. Like, I beat the game with friend A while I was only a few levels in with friend B, and then I'd start up the game with friend B and some of the puzzles would start to seem mighty familiar, and I couldn't be sure if it was only because I'd already played them with friend A, or because I'd also already played them with friend B. You can reset ALL of your progress, which would have made it easier to kow where I was with friend B if I'd started with them AFTER beating the game with friend A, but I had two games going at the same time so deleting my progress with friend A would have deleted the friend B's progress as well, and it wouldn't have been fair to friend A, either, if we ever decided we wanted to go back and try to get all the crystals on certain levels without replaying all the others. The option for separate play "sessions" could have solved this (I always thought having three save slots in the Zelda games was overkill, but now I see the reasoning behind it). But, lengthy complaint notwithstanding, this is really a minor problem.

I was lucky enough to get this in a double pack as part of a bundle, but It's definitely worth the full price.

Posted: January 15, 2023
Two friends out for a stroll.

Story:

There's not really a story in ibb & obb. The basic gist is that you're traversing through the environment to reach a party that's being thrown by your friends, but that's really all I can muster and I could be wrong. It's not really a story driven game and therefore not much to talk about here.

Graphics:

Visually ibb & obb is a delight to look at. The art style is described as a bunch of abstract shapes getting eyes slapped onto them and a very nice color palette. Honestly that's one of the most striking things about the game, is the colors. They have some very nice shading and it really pops during the night moments of the game with some genuinely great lighting.

Level from level usually looks pretty similar with very minor changes to the background. You'll mostly be encountering the same type of enemies, characters and similar backgrounds. The latter of which has some big changes, like a few different gimmicks that I won't mention here, but I wish there were more interesting environments.

Audio:

Both visually and from the audio perspective of the game, it's a very mellow game. Even in the more "action" packed moments of the game the soundtrack never really goes crazy. It's actually very nice to listen to and doesn't become grading, cause there will be moments where you will have to stop and think through a puzzle.

There's not much other sound effects to speak of. Killing enemies, squishing balls and other things make minor noises which some of them are pretty funny once you get playing, that's really all you'll be hearing. It's design is on point considering they're very soft and satisfying to listen to.

Gameplay:

ibb & obb is a puzzle platformer where the main focus is teamwork. The game is co-op only so you'll need to get a friend to tag along with you on this journey. The whole gist is that there's a lot of moments where you will need to help each other reach platforms and clear a pathway that the other player can cross.

ibb is a short and can't clear certain jumps so you need to use obb as a moving platform to get yourself up to platforms neither of you can reach. There's also gravity inverting pools split across the floor and the whole gist is that you need to build up momentum to clear them. That's what the puzzle boil down to, find a way to build enough momentum to clear a gap.

The puzzle design is genuinely difficult at times and had me and my co-op partner stumped because certain moments seem so tight on time that it requires borderline perfection to clear and it had us wondering if we're missing something. You can also die, but the game is generous enough with checkpoints that it's not that big of a problem.

The controls themselves are pretty simple and work really well. There's not much to mess up here as all you can really do is walk left and right and jump, so it works pretty well and although there is sometimes really tight jumps that are janky to make, it works fine for the majority.

However there is some big issues with the game. One of them is the online co-op of the game being incredibly broken. There are moments where the game will break and will lock one character in place and not let him move which will force you to restart the entire level from the beginning and certain levels are long. One of the hardest levels nearing the end of the game has a moment where you can quickly die multiple times at the end of the level and lock the game and end up having to go through all of it.

Verdict:

ibb & obb is a really fun co-op platformer that's both cute in it's design and surprisingly challenging once you get to the puzzles. I had a blast with my time and although there were some infuriating moments, it's still an experience worth going through with a friend.

Final Rating:
7.5/10

Pros:
+ Adorable art style
+ Soundtrack is easy on the ears so it doesn't get grading when you're stuck on puzzles
+ Some genuinely great puzzle design

Cons:
- Online CO-OP is pretty buggy
- Certain levels have incredibly tight windows for performing jumps

If you liked this review please consider joining and

Posted: May 12, 2019
I was looking for a good co op game to play with my girlfriend. She's an inexperienced gamer, but really wanted to find something we could enjoy together and this game fit the bill perfectly.

ibb & obb is the definitive co op platformer! The style is soft, colorful, and simple, yet beautiful.

The controls are simple run and jump and the gimmicks of bouncy floors, reversed gravity, spikes, etc. are familiar and easy enough to figure out, but used in a brilliant combination of ways.

Plus the enemies are defeated by one person moving to the upside or downside of the platforms to hit their weakness while the other person collects the loot so not only do you cooperate to traverse the platforms by jumping off each other, but you also cooperate to defeat enemies and collect loot.

If you know someone who loves platformers or someone who wants to play with you, but may not be too skilled this game will work for veterans and newbies alike.

ibb & obb can offer:

1) 15 usual levels plus 8 hidden, secret levels; those regular levels will gradually increase in length, difficulty, number of enemies and score;

2) co-op mode as well as solo play-through; solo mode significantly toughens the game, because you will have to control two characters by yourself, meaning while Ibb (say, your left hand) jumps and runs away from a bunch of blackened hedgehogs, Obb (now your right hand) is rushing away and breaks down the same hedgehogs from another side of the surface. Either is upside down, that again, adds more challenge.

Solo gaming is still possible, but it might take a player slightly longer to reach the end of a level.
Oh, and Carry them through the traps, hedgehogs and puzzles, that's a sweet challenging goal.

... they can crawl, fly and dive, jump and chase you. Not to mention that they vary in sizes too.

A player will encounter them in quite places and during pursuits. Precision timings and coordination is the key to proceed. Clear instruction and trust is a must. Of course you may always play a silly sausage and push your friend off a cliff and hear him yelling at you. ;)

Posted: August 25, 2023
ibb & obb: A Blissful Co-op Puzzle Delight

Meet ibb and obb: two adorable blobs that look like they've jumped straight out a DOTS candy box. Yep, Little gumdrop doodads.

Their simplicity, showcased through a straightforward color palette and vibrant saturation, offers a pleasant visual experience. From the little characters to the levels they inhabit, everything exudes charm.

Controlling these bouncy creatures is a joy. Jumps and movements feel precise, making any missteps entirely my own doing, or occasionally my partner's sneaky nudging—though, I can't really blame the game for that.

Be prepared to perish, often in your buddy's company. A single touch from an enemy sends both players back to a checkpoint. But fear not, the game is kind, offering generous checkpoints that quell the frustration of restarting.

One might assume that with just a jump button, the puzzles would be shallow. Prepare for a surprise, as ibb and obb defies this notion entirely. The puzzles are nothing short of ingenious, thanks to the ever-present normal and inverse planes. Switching between these realms is the key to solving these cunning enigmas.

Much revolves around momentum—a concept expertly wielded in challenges. Momentum must be passed from one player to the other with the precision of a maestro's baton. Picture the portal puzzles in Co-Op, but add infinite fall momentum to launch your partner like a lightning bolt.

Beyond puzzle-solving, points beckon to be collected. Destroying enemies in their vulnerable plane spawns these collectibles. Secret challenges and tucked-away corners house hidden points, adding an extra layer of exploration.

Communication between players is pivotal, and the game offers both voice chat and a quirky smoke signal. I highly advocate for voice chat unless you enjoy slamming your head agaisnt the wall and enjoy frustrating your partner.

Online multiplayer reigns supreme in this Co-Op adventure, but the partner search could use some fine-tuning. A limited search made me redo levels, repeatedly rescuing my game partner who I had trouble speaking with given they refused to use voice chat. Yet, the true essence of ibb and obb lies in its LOCAL co-op gameplay—this is where it truly shines.

When all is said and done, ibb and obb stands as a fantastic puzzle game, crafted with co-op camaraderie in mind. Partner up with a kindred spirit, and you're in for a whirlwind of challenges and exhilarating victories.

I will say Steam offers ibb and obb in two packages, one game or a two-game bundle for a great deal. I wholeheartedly recommend the latter, so you can gift one to your co-op buddy in crime!

Posted: June 7, 2015
The artwork is very charming, but the game is deigned to be too much of a puzzle with a single set solution. Many mechanics are quite punishing for little reason.

I found that they made it all too easy to unintentionally grief your teammate, through no fault of your own.

There were some interesting concpts, but some of the puzzles required your coop partner to sit there and watch you as you failed over and over again despite knowing the solution to the puzzle.

There are a lot of creative things about this game, but I alsso believe they made a lot of questionable design choices.

Why do you die everytime your idiot ally dies?

Why is it that for a coop I never feel like I'm working together with my teammate?
Why am I always getting in the way of my teammate and greifing them?

Why do these puzzles only have one solution to get past them?

On the other hand they have beautiful stylization, and what aI believe to be a very pretty communication system that you use without words, But this game is very unintentional.

I did however love the pricing for a twopack and I believe that all coopgames should follow a similar model wherein you are required to play with someone else, but an extra copy of the game costs a little bit more.

Posted: March 22, 2022
"Ibb & Obb" is a small co-op puzzle - platformer with a minimalistic colorful world, adorable characters, effective gameplay mechanisms, great pace, well balanced difficulty and nice music. But most importantly it's a game designed to focus on the cooperative experience, which is absolutely fantastic. The numerous puzzles, full of portals and paradoxes, are creative and challenging and require good communication and synchronization by both players. The final result is absolutely enjoyable and you'll certainly have several entertaining hours playing it along with a friend.


Manometer: 9/10


The good
- Cute, minimalistic, colorful graphics. It isn't anything special but some levels are pretty nice looking.
- Fantastic co-op experience. The players always have to think and work together, sometimes also synchronized, in order to beat each puzzle. One of the best games out there that are based on communication and interactivity.
- There is a big variety of creative puzzles and clever gameplay mechanisms that require imagination in order to solve them. Each level offers new challenges. Some of them require more thinking, while others quickness and synchronization.
- Simple yet effective control mechanics. Although the game essentially uses only a stick and a button (for jumping), there are so many different things to do.
- Well balanced difficulty. Great pace. It is challenging but never extremely harsh. You will get stuck at some points for a while but not for too long. Also, it gets more difficult gradually in order to let you smoothly embrace its world and mechanisms.
- Cool animations. They are also simplistic but smooth and funny (especially when Ibb and Obb stand still or stare passing by objects).
- Nice, energetic music that helps player find rhythm.
- Sound design is simple but also works well. Some sounds, like dying one, are hilarious.
- Adorable characters. Ibb and Obb are loveable, small balls are cute.
- It has some scattered collectables and hidden routes to discover here and there, which makes it even more challenging and gives it more replayability.
- It's a great idea to allow you draw lines with the right analogue stick (or the mouse) in order to communicate with the other player. It allows you to play it with someone without even needing voice or text chat.
- You can play it solo by moving both characters using the same keyboard or gamepad. It's so hard though, that I wouldn't recommend even trying it.
- It is very relaxing.

The bad
- I'm not sure if this is a fault of my internet connection or their servers or the actual game but there was a continuous lag everywhere. Constant frame drops along with disappearing, freezing or teleported characters will cause multiple accidental deaths. It is playable for sure but these glitches can get extremely annoying and take away a lot from the game's magic.
- The most common gameplay mechanism is when a player needs to climb over the other player's head (in order to perform a bigger jump). So, I assume that the characters should have been designed with square heads instead of rounded ones. This would be a lot more helpful in order to exactly know where you stand or when you have to be precise.

Posted: November 16, 2015
This game is cute, has great music and challenging puzzles. And you play it in cooperation with a buddy. What's not to like?

The puzzles are challenging not only in regard to their solution. They often require both players to perfectly execute several steps in a row, with very little room for error. This can mean that you have already figured out the solution and make it halfway there but then you misstep: Start over. Then, your friend is too fast: Start over. Then, you jump a little too early: Start over. Then, your friend hits an enemy: You know the drill. Solving a puzzle can get quite tedious.
Another issue is savegames: One level took us up to an hour (in the later stages), depending both of how well we could crack the puzzle logic and execute the steps. During that, the game saved our progress just fine; if we failed a puzzle, we'd only be back at its beginning. But whenever we had to quit before finishing the level (or had a desync or just didn't feel like trying the same puzzle for the umpteenth time), the next time, we'd have to restart the whole level from the beginning.
Finally, playing it with a friend across the ocean, we found that in-game voice chat was delayed by a few seconds. Maybe it doesn't happen with less of a distance between you and your co-player. For us, it didn't help, what with some puzzles needing near-perfect timing. Towards the end, we thought about using an external solution like Raidcall, but it never came to that.
Overall, the game can get quite frustrating.

Before this, we played Portal 2, which did a better job of e.g. the savegame issue by having many smaller levels, so if you had to quit at some point, you wouldn't have to replay as much as in this game. And there, when you already knew the steps leading up to where you'd left off, they were usually pretty easy to reproduce. If you're looking for a fun coop puzzler, I'd rather recommend Portal 2.

Posted: January 17, 2016
ibb&obb is a really fun and addicting game if you play it together with a good friend of yours. I highly recommend buying the 2-pack bundle and to play with a friend.

The game is kind of a physics puzzle platformer. It is self-explanatory, from the first to the last stage you will see new elements being introduced in a way that requires no further explanation. It's intuitive and fun to explore the new elements.

The music in this game is a highlight. It matches the clean, calming artstyle perfectly and fits the athmosphere of the stages perfectly. Get the soundtrack if you can, you won't regret it.

The replay-value of this game is ok. As long as you have more friends to play it with, there will always be one who you can introduce to this game and trying to get 100% of the crystals and secret stages with them is just as fun as trying it for the first time.

What I dislike is that the audio volume resets every time you start the game, it's far too loud. Also, when playing with friends from overseas, the game suffers heavily from lag - not really the games fault, but I found that to be annoying sometimes, anyway.

I'd recommend this game to anyone who hasn't played it yet and who has a friend to play this together with. I could imagine that single player is too hard, as you'd have to control both characters at once, but maybe you'll like the challenge of that, too.

ibb & obb: Gravity-Defying Love Quest

ibb & obb isn't just a game; it's a journey my girlfriend and I embarked on to test the limits of our teamwork – and our patience. Navigating through gravity-twisting puzzles and laughing at our synchronized mishaps has turned this game into our favorite.

Cons:
Nope. No cons.

Posted: January 16
I've always liked these types of co-op games, where both players physically depend on each other at all times to solve the puzzle, instead of being locked away in seperate rooms solving 2 different but realted puzzles. Ibb & Obb is very simple in concept, but some of the levels get pretty clever, and actually require some thinking.*
That being said, i would not recommend to play this for a few reasons.
1. Theres is a noticable difference between what the two players see. When i played this with my friend situations where it looked like i jumped in midair from his perspective, but in actuality i jumped off of his head. Normally this wouldn't be too big of an issue in a puzzle game, but then theres the second problem
2. Towards the end of the game, it devolves from "oh thats clever" to "i cant tell if this is the intended solution", some later levels only require technical skill from both players, and almost no actual puzzle solving. Due to these two problems me and my friend couldnt finish the game, it was just too inconsistent and infuriating.
3. This ones not as bad as the others, but it still significantly lowered my enjoyment of the game. For some reason, this game is very slow, the loading times take forever and the time the frames often go below 30.

If its on sale, sure, you can have a few hours of fun, but i would definitely not recommend completing the whole game.

Posted: April 23, 2015
This seemingly simple little indie game is so much more than I expected!

I have been having an absolute blast playing this game with my friend. It's a similar experience to what we had playing Portal 2 co-op, occasionally hurting our brains trying to solve a puzzle and then facepalming when it becomes blatantly obvious (after you've spent 15 mins trying to solve it of course). ibb & obb actually has us both in tears a few times, just dying with laughter as we repeatedly fail jumps and die to the Studio Ghibli-esque wandering soots.

The graphics are PHENOMENAL - the simplicity of it all works so well and the vibrant colours make me so happy. Even the darker levels were executed so well and add to the game: You have just enough vision so that it doesn't hinder you playing (like so many other games where you can't see 2 inches in front of your face) and it's fun not being able to see the soots. Nothing like a spikey lil surprise to make your day eh?

Not gonna lie, I normally rage a bit while playing platformer/repeatedly dying games. Like I said earlier I've had the exact opposite happen..I cry with laughter when we keep dying. The whole atmosphere of the game is very zen-like and relaxing, and the gameplay is just so fun (lots of wooshing and sounds are made while flying through the sky) that I haven't raged or gotten annoyed whatsoever..which is great. :)

Can't recommend this game highly enough. What're you waiting for go grab a friend! And if you don't have any friends...you should rent one for a day just so you can play this game. It'll be worth it, I promise.

Posted: November 13, 2017
What a amazing game. You can read my rating from the numbers of hours played :) Especially I recommend this game for anyone who enjoys a cool platformer with kids. I really enjoyed every moment of those nearly 50 hours of gameplay.

With my eldest 9-year-old daughter we played the most time. We tweaked our performance trying to hit zen in every level. And we did succeed. What a great way to teach your kids persistency! We got all the 10 achievements and that is something as you may realize if you buy and play this game. It's hard work with your friend but try it with your kids! I wish you luck with that one ;)

With my 6-year-old boy we got familiar with the levels and tried to conquer them but not minding the diamonds and zen. This was a great way co-operate and of course persistency was needed here as well. Sometimes there were demanding timing and syncing challenges to overcome. But we usually did it and if we didn't in some parts we asked her sister to help :)

With my 4-year-old daughter we played the first four levels again and again which both of us became very familiar with. She did enjoy those levels more than me but you have to treat your kids equally. And it's an important thing for a kid such young to enjoy same games as the rest of the family.

I tried this game also with my wife but she wasn't too keen on ibb & obb nor computer games in general.

I liked the graphics and artwork and the world where our friends ibb and obb operated. I liked the physics and the 2-way-gravity in the game. With simple "trampolines" and ports to different gravitys you can make wonderful things as I learned while playing. Game had nice problems to solve what included syncing and timing tweaking with a partner or just thinking your head off how to get through and move on. We just loved being carried by another player and we had great talks while playing and figuring out what to do next and who does what and when. A nice way to teach your kids to communicate and to achieve common goals.

Sometimes we had to watch videos from Youtube to figure out certain secret levels but usually we solved problems ourselves.

We played with arrows and WASD so there were 50 hours of quality co-operation in close contact.

I loved it!

Posted: April 24, 2022
ibb & obb is a very cute, charming, and colorful co-op puzzle platformer. The idea is straight forward - you must work with your teammate to navigate various terrains and help each other reach certain areas that are otherwise impossible to reach on your own, all the while collecting crystals and avoiding enemies. There are 15 levels and 8 bonus areas that vary in difficulty from straightforward to having to think quite creatively/coordinating very precisely. The last 4-5 levels are difficult in terms of 100%ing them, but are still fun to do. The game is best played via online co-op; remote play together works, but given the precision timing that's required in some areas, it can be finicky.

All in all, the game is a lot of fun and is a great co-op puzzle platforming option for people interested in the genre.

Posted: 2 May, 2021
This is a game that completely changes based on how you play it and how long you've played it for.

At the 0 hour mark,
BTD6 is a cute monkey tower defense game that seems fairly straight forward. You just place down monkeys, and these colored balloons called "bloons" come that your little monkeys pop with darts. Your favorite Hero is Quincy, because he's all you have.

At the 25 hour mark,
you might have had a couple of people tell you what's "good" or "OP" in the game, then you start using these towers and upgrades for all your games. However, you still have no real understanding of what's going on in the game whatsoever, fumbling around in the dark and dying randomly to rounds all of a sudden when you thought you were doing great. Your favorite Hero is Striker Jones, and certainly not for the right reasons.

At the 50 hour mark,
you seem to find more towers and upgrades that seem to work or seem good. You might even start to catch on to the common "problem" rounds like 63, or start to think that you know a thing or two about the game. This is however, a fleeting illusion. And I assure you that you know nothing. Your favorite Hero is Obyn, because RISE!

you've won many games on many maps and difficulties. You may have even won your first C.H.I.M.P.S. game by following a guide. You start to think you're good at the game. What short-sighted vision! 90% of the game can still completely crush you at this point. You may even be tempted into purchasing completely pointless micro-transactions now that you're already hooked. Rest assured that doing so is completely pointless and will not make you any better at the game. There are a few rather brutal (you think) game modes *cough* Half Cash *cough* Apopcalyse *cough* which for the life of you, just can't beat. Your favorite Hero is DJ Benjamin, because let's face it, we were all there someday.

you've really started raking in the Monkey Money just by finishing maps and playing the game. You've already bought all the heroes and their skins. At this point, you start becoming increasingly greedy for game completion, you want those fancy looking "Black Borders" everyone is talking about. Unfortunately, you just haven't put enough time into the game at this point to have the knowledge or skill to beat all the game modes legitimately, and so you spam Cash Drops for hard game modes like Half Cash, and beat C.H.I.M.P.S. by watching guides. You fool yourself into thinking that you're a superior Bloons player, when you are in reality just a chimp. Your favorite Hero is Adora, because you think she's good when she's not.

for the first time you truly start to wonder: what the **** is actually going on in this game? I've watched monkeys pop "bloons" for 500 hours, but in truth, I understand nothing. Your thirst for understanding game mechanics deepens and your search for the truth begins. You join Discord servers seeking for knowledge from superior Bloons players (who just troll you, reply in esoteric memes, and say things like "vrej"), spending hours reading long complicated Reddit posts and crawling through Google spreadsheets. Finally, you learn some proper terminology like "damage" and "pierce". Where was all this information in the game? You ask yourself. The striking revelation hits you like roaring thunder: It's simply not there! Nothing in the game tells you anything! "tHiS iS A bIg pLaNe", really? You even start reading those long detailed patch notes from every update. Your favorite Hero is Pat Fusty, because he's actually good.

for the first time, you actually feel like you understand the game just a little bit. And rest assured, if you've put that many hours into the game, you probably do understand it just a little. At this point, you can finally beat every game mode in the game legitimately. You may have even completed the easier Expert maps on C.H.I.M.P.S. You've found your way. No longer do you rely on any of the intentionally badly designed game "features" characteristic of mobile games. Cash Drops, Powers, and Instas become completely useless and pointless. The last time you've pulled out a Cash Drop was more than 500 hours of playtime ago. They're probably all piling up in the back closet like a mass of adult toys. Now all you want is to beat those hardest maps in the game. What they didn't tell you is that simply beating them all is not the end. Your favorite Hero is Quincy, the starter Hero, because he can beat every map on every game mode.

your priorities shift again. Your only goal is to become even better at the game. You realize completion is pointless and the only real growth is in experience and skill. You challenge yourself with the hardest game modes on the hardest maps in the game. But even that isn't enough, so you move into Challenge Editor to create and beat even harder game modes that don't even exist in the main game. C.H.I.M.P.S.? Why not try C.H.I.M.P.S. with only 2 Towers, or only 4th Tier towers, or only 1 DPS tower, or A.B.R. C.H.I.M.P.S., or C.H.I.M.P.S. with Triple HP MOABs. The possibilities are truly endless. Original theorycrafting also starts to come online at this playtime. You tap into secret knowledge known only to the most elite high-level Bloons players and think of completely new ways of understanding different parts of the game. Mastered Mortar micro? Try Ace micro. Haven't heard of RNG-manip in Bloons? Maybe you'll be the first to discover it. You start to question your favorite Hero, because even he can't beat some of these tough challenges.

you break through into the league of God tier Bloons players. Anything even in the main game becomes completely trivial. Name any 3 towers, and you will beat almost any map on any game mode with them first try. You turn off Monkey Knowledge because it makes the game even easier than it already is. You play every game with C.H.I.M.P.S. rules, and not even intentionally. If it was possible, you would Half your Cash for all games just for kicks. #Ouch becomes Couch and Puddles becomes Cuddles. Custom Challenges become trivial too. 2TC is a joke. Try Half Cash C.H.I.M.P.S. on Rake. Your favorite Hero is Adora, because you did 2MPC on X Factor with her.

The next challenge... is Reverse Half Cash A.B.R. Triple HP MOABs Double HP Ceramics Quadruple Bloon Speed C.H.I.M.P.S. on Bloody Puddles.

you return to the depths of filthy and paltry casual gameplay. You've played this monkey game for so many hours that all the endless chasing of top 3 medals and pushing of the skill ceiling has become... meaningless. You've already done it all and yet you've accomplished... nothing. What is there left to do other than make meme custom maps, impossible challenges and play C.H.I.M.P.S. on "Your Mom but at a different angle"? Or as DJ Benjamin says, "Turn up the Double Cash!"

is this really the end?

Posted: 26 November, 2020
→ Bloons TD 6 is set in a near-orwellian dystopian future where humanity's evolution has taken an alternate path; Evolving us into hyper-intelligent monkeys running a banana-fueled economy, which has been propped up precariously with a monkey housing-market shadow-banking scheme (but with banana bucks and bloons). Use government sponsored bloon-money (read: blood-money) to hire genetically engineered super-monkeys, psychopathic mercenary soldiers, surgically-enhanced unfeeling cyborgs, feed live sacrifices to the monkey Sun God, and to generally create horrendous weapons of mass poppage that will help you on your monkey business preventing the EXTREMIST Bloon terrorists from passing through and INFLATING the monkey economy, POPPING the housing-market bubble your monkey government has entrusted you, Big Brother, to protect. Do your duty and prevent BILLIONS of innocent monkeys from spiralling into homelessness and poverty by keeping bloon-kind chained where they belong, floating the economy and holding up Big Banana Goverment.

== The gameplay ==
→ BTD6 is a highly addicting tower defense game with amusing and diverse paths to create the mystifyingly satisfying noise that is balloons popping. (If you like the sound made by messing with bubble wrap, you've just found your gamer crack.) You start off placing your typically cheap monkeys-for-hire on the track, and gain progressive account-bound experience that unlocks tower upgrades and points for a monkey talent-tree that keeps you coming back for another go, while also keeping you from being overwhelmed by the insane mass of tower options and build paths you eventually have straight from the beginning. By the end of it you'll be plopping down mortars that can focus fire anywhere on the screen, helicopters that follow your cursor (or the enemy bloons if you're lazy), druids who spam chain lightning, and even necromancers who resurrect zombie bloons that move backwards on the track, popping their former brethren.

== On the pay-to-win issue ==
→ Even if you're a player like me who typically hates grinding for unlocks, the gameplay is so satisfying I felt like I was making typical progress in a monkey RTS / RPG rather than being slogged down and penalized for not making in-game purchases. The pay-to-win isn't much of an issue in multiplayer either (it just means an easy co-op win).
→ If you're having trouble with the progression I recommend spiking your upgrade unlock rate without spending real money in a couple of ways:
(A) Git gud and out-scale the bloon waves past the end wave into freeplay mode for BIG wads of player XP
(B) Run a few maps blazing-fast over-and-over again for wave-based XP that goes towards towers present on the screen.
(C) Getting lots of free the micro-transaction currency from first time map wins and challenges (hint: there is sometimes big bonus currency for winning a randomly selected map on each difficulty tier even after you've 100%'d, bigger on higher difficulty, and quests given on the home screen for even more).
(D) use free OP towers you get from near-constant in-game events and map victories for play-to-win ez mode on challenges and maps you're too lazy to tryhard on, or
(E) get carried by the bored 1000-hour randos in easy/intermediate queue who've ended up with WAAAY too much free micro-transaction currency and map-victory towers in co-op queue.

== Some things of note + tips ==
1) In co-op mode, the dev has made a brilliant design decision to prevent actual text typing and you instead communicate through a monkey-see monkey-do style emote menu. Communicate like its monkey Dark Souls.
2) There is a massive, extremely NOT-casual difficulty spike as you go upwards towards expert maps. Get together with the bros for co-op and rip out your hair together while having tons of headache-inducing fun in voice chat on Discord, scheming how the hell you're supposed to win without backing onto your play-to-win towers that are straight-out disabled on certain challenges.
3) I've seen this game on sale for $0.99 at least twice so far at the time of this writing, pop it on your wishlist and you might catch it that way again.
4) By some form of dark magic, this game has an active Youtube community with lots of gameplay tips, tricks, and mind-exploding big brain tower micro for you to dig up. Give it a search!

== TL;DR == go try Bloons TD 5 on NinjaKiwi's website and imagine that but better

Posted: January 12, 2021
So many times I'll see the dismissive and insulting put down of a game on here - "it's a poor mobile port". And I mean, in a lot of cases, they're not wrong. A lot of junk does get pulled over from mobile and often with an inflated price tag too, and often done quite lazily.

Happily while this IS very much a mobile game, it is a shining example of how to do it right, and just because it lives on mobile, it CAN exist here too.

Right off the bat, this is obviously a Tower Defence game, so of course it works well on mobile screens. However, it is not a lazy copy/paste of other games. It very much does it's own thing and after at least 5 other main entries, they've refined and added so much to make it a compelling and quite deep game all round.

Plenty of maps, and the "towers" in this game are the monkeys who have different abilities. YOu have your basics here - the basic single shot type, the area of effect blaster, the elemental or explosive attackers too. But it's more diverse than that. It's by no means a simple rock/paper/scissors that so many tower defence games descend into, where you have to pre-empt the next wave and build towers to suit.

No, this game has monkeys which can only be used on certain types of land (and in later stages, the land gets rather minimal too), have really diverse capabilities to combat enemies like camouflaged balloons that only they will track or reveal, or metal balloons that require a sniper or cannon type to pierce. So the balancing act here is much deeper and entertaining, especially when you get to harder difficulties.

The "enemies" in the game, being the balloons themselves, and they are MANY! There's something lovely and cathartic about hearing shedloads of balloons get popped at once, and this lends to the enjoyment well. Later waves will often become overwhelming instantly if you've made poor choices in tackling them ,as there's just that many that come in waves. But despite this, it's fair. If you mess up, you learn what you did wrong and fix it next time.

On top of this, there's a basic levelling/XP system where levelling up rewards you with XP points to improve your monkey's abilities slightly. Again, this is a great help with harder difficulties and later maps, and I feel is REALLY well balanced. You earn about at the right rate as you play. It's so easy to get that bit wrong.

On top of this, there's added frippery like cosmetics and UI changes and so on if you wish for it, as well as daily, weekly and monthly custom challenges and seasonal events. These are usually rewarded with different skins, or heroes or sometimes new monkeys themselves.

All in all it's not only well polished, well paced and deep enough to keep coming back to, but it has enough there for repeated play even if you finish the main game (which I'll point at out 60 hours in myself, I still have not finished).

So, as tower defence games go, this is right up there with Defense Grid, Sanctum and some of the other shining examples. Don't overlook it as a mobile cash in because it isn't. If you like tower defence you will absolutely love this, especially if you like the cute aesthetic. Ninja Kiwi seem well involved in keeping up interest with the events and challenges so I doubt anyone would tire of this quickly at all.

Posted: January 23, 2021
The eighth entry in the Bloons Tower Defense universe, BTD6 does not dissapoint. It stands as a grisly and realistic representation of war, and it does a very good job of what it set out to be. An emotional journey from start to finish, forcing you to question the morality of your very being. It pits brother against brother in a violent war of attrition, and it doesn't shy away from covering controversial topics considered too problematic for media today. The protagonist himself isn't a cookie-cutter perfect individual either. He has flaws which are expressed extremely well and serve as a driving force for the main story, making you question his next move. BTD6 does a superb job of putting you in the shoes of its characters and forming connections to them. You feel what they feel every step of the way. It's chock full of emotional scenes that will leave you sobbing one moment, then filled with hope the next. BTD6 is a wonderfully crafted game, with substance that will keep you going for months.

If there is only one piece of media you need to experience in your life, it is Bloons Tower Defense 6.

Truly, a masterpiece of a game.

Posted: October 4, 2022
After playing thousands of games both singleplayer and multiplayer, unlocking all achievements and getting every solo map medal, I think it's time for a review:

If you like tower defence games: I recommend.
If you like any previous Bloons games: I recommend.
If you want something casual and chill: I recommend.
If you want a bit of a challenge: I recommend.

The tower type variety is interesting and diverse, with 5 tiers of upgrades each (plus special "paragon" towers)
The game devs have been providing free updates for years.
There's lots of achievements and medals to get.

I live in a one story house in the suburbs, my address is 308 Negro Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque New Mexico 87104, my name is Banana Bateman. I am 27 years old. I believe in wiping out bloons as a whole, and a balanced diet and a rigorous exercise routine. In the morning if my face is a bit bloon like I'll put on an ice pack while practicing throwing darts at bloons, I can pop a thousand now. After I remove the ice pack I hop on my computer and boot up Bloons TD 6 to start my bloon poping genocide for the day. I pick my favorite map, Monkey Meadow. I usually like to start out with Sauda and a dart monkey. I'll save up to start buying banana farms which I upgrade to 2-0-0. I will then farm till I am able to buy my favorite tower, the super monkey. After I then start the process to obtain the vengeful true sun god, once done I leave my computer, grab my banana bunch, and leave for work. By the time I get back the game will usually end on round 268, my best is round 302. There is an idea of a bloons player. Some kind of abstraction. But there is no real player. Only an entity. Something illusory. And though I can hide my cold gaze, and you can shake my hand and feel flesh gripping yours, and maybe you can even sense our playstyles are probably comparable, I simply am not there.

Posted: February 20, 2020
For anyone who played btd4/btd5 and liked it, I would say BTD6 is a huge improvement and well worth getting. For people new to the BTD series, I think this is a good tower defence game with plenty of strategic possibility both for casual/lazy players and those keen on higher effort gameplay. Placement/combinations absolutely matter, and all towers can be put into reasonably effective use, but don't expect to just throw random towers around and win everything.

This game is NOT!!!! pay to win at all, despite containing one useful iap (double cash), and some typically irrelevant ones which nobody ever needs (the usual assortment, basically ingame money, skillpoints, and free consumable towers).

People who are more interested in achievements/full completion than just playing for fun, be aware that some achievements are grindy/slow and certain track sub-mode completion medals are ridiculously hard to get, involving VERY accurate placements, spot-on timing, and some random factors which effectively force multiple attempts. I have all singleplayer medals though and only one achievement left (cant be bothered buying race attempts to get it sooner) so it is doable.

I think this is a great single player game, co-op however, either stick to easy modes or play with a friend, else frustration is likely. And I will say this one more time, tower combinations matter. Buffing effects matter. Don't just throw random things around without thinking, learn what towers pair well or you will miss half the point of the game and fail to defend on basically anything above beginner difficulty.

Posted: June 10, 2023
To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to play BTD6. The sheer intellectual fortitude required to strategically place your monkey towers and pop those pesky bloons is simply unparalleled. It takes a superior level of cognitive prowess to comprehend the intricacies of the game's mechanics and the optimal placement strategies for each tower.

While you mere mortals waste your time on mindless games, the BTD6 connoisseurs engage in a mental dance of precision and calculation. Every placement decision must be weighed carefully, taking into account the pathing of the Bloons, the unique abilities of each tower, and the optimal combinations to create devastating strategies. It's a mind game that separates the intellectuals from the casual gamers.

And let's not forget the magnificent tower upgrades that add another layer of complexity. As you ascend to higher levels of play, the choices become more critical, requiring a deep understanding of the game's intricate mechanics. It's not just about popping bloons anymore; it's about mastering the art of synergy and finding the perfect balance between offence and defence.

Oh, and the diversity of bloons themselves! From the humble red bloon to the mighty BAD, each bloon presents its own challenge, demanding careful planning and adaptability. And let's not forget the DDT, which will end you in the blink of an eye if you're not prepared. Only the truly gifted can handle the ever-increasing waves of bloons, adjusting their strategies on the fly, performing godlike micro, and emerging victorious against overwhelming odds.

But let's face it, dear non-BTD6 players, you're missing out on an intellectual feast. While you fumble around with mind-numbing games that require no more than mere button mash, we conquer intricate monkey-based warfare with our genius minds. BTD6 is not just a game; it's an intellectual masterpiece, a testament to human ingenuity, and a celebration of strategic brilliance.

So go ahead, continue your mundane gaming endeavours, but remember, you'll never quite reach the heights of intellectual stimulation and mechanical complexity that BTD6 offers. The bloons await their demise at the hands of the chosen few, the intellectually elite players who can truly appreciate the unparalleled greatness of Bloons TD 6.

Posted: November 3, 2020
This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

War. War never changes. And now, the rubbers come again to decimate what remains of our people. We have managed to hold our ground against them on 5 separate occasions. Now, they think they are being crafty by sending in even MORE types of Bloons and blimps.

They thrive off of death - fueled by CO2 taken from the fallen. We taunt them by laughing directly at them - exhaling that precious resource they need to survive. Other's simply make a gesture. Just look at the face of the Sub Commander as he points at the next target. Our weapons have improved since the last crusade. New monkeys have joined our ranks. Proof that every life lost is a spark fueling the rebellion further.

As long as our darts are sharpened, our magics are prepared, our bombs and tacks are ready... we shall stand together. We shall pop wave after wave until they finally stop coming. They think lead and ceramic are protection enough but they are naive. The Bloons have even resorted to heresy and dark magics to gain an upper hand - and we brought in Druids and Alchemists. They are only stalling the inevitable. Though it seems they've created a new type of Blimp to simply blitzkrieg our defenses. We must remain stalwart and not completely underestimate them in their desperation to pillage our Monkey Villages.

We're taking the war to new Maps and Terrains - to places we've never gone before. We must live in unity rather than fear. And new Champions are rumoured to stand as Heroes alongside our fellow monkey brethren. These Heroes represent something we've not yet seen before. Hope.

There is no fear; for the Monkey Sun God is with is. And by His fire, the rubbers shall be cleansed, purged and redeemed. Let us pop until every last one of the rubbers is GONE and we can finally live in peace amongst our banana farms at last. There is much work to be done.

Posted: May 31, 2021
TLDR
Bloons TD 6 is the mick jagger of tower defense game. A little bit wacky, fun, unique style and definitely a jewel for TD gamers.

Non-TLDR
Bloons TD 6 (BTD 6), developed and published by Ninja Kiwi. The PC version was relased on Dec 17, 2018 and it is also available on the Iphone/Ipad. On Metacritic (https://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/bloons-td-6) it has:
0 Metascore from critic reviews
An average user score of 7.4 from 30 ratings

If you've played Flash games before, you'd probably come across bloon td. if you are someone who loves tower defense games, you'd probably slay a ton of bloons before ninja kiwi (and other flash game developers) migrated to steam because Flash is no longer supported by Adobe. So these group of people have seen how bloon td evolved till today.

As for the younger generations, this may seem like some wild, crazy, mess up monkey revenge business against balloons. Did i mention that it was also fun/can be frustrating at the same time?

BTD 6 offers players 40 over maps to play. it comes in 3 difficulty and each difficulty has different set of challenges - that will test your skill and knowledge. For some odd reasons, BTD 6 has a complicated map system for online/co-op game play.








Your towers have it's own leveling system. Aside from that, the more you play, you also gain up exp for your own account - this is the monkey knowledge system. As you level up, you gain monkey knowledge points which can be used to purchase "perks" for your towers or heroes tower. Yes, there are heroes tower which needs to be unlocked & purchased (not microtrans). If i am not mistaken, the first 2 heroes can be unlocked and given to you after you reach certain levels.

Other than all of the above, you now have:


On top of all of this, it has a trophy store, where you can purchase various in-game elements; visuals/ui/emoticons. Nothing that can affect the gameplay. You earn trophy from odyssey game mode. finally, it has a microtransaction shop.

BTD 6 isn't just your standard Tower Defense game with all this features.

Visuals: It's 3d'ish looking. colorful, clean. certain maps have objects to interact/block your line of sight. Monkeys and bloons have been properly designed. no complains. +1 to the team

Audio: Energetic vibe. I believe you can purchase additional soundtrack from the trophy store. (yet to try). There's a jukebox to enable. +1 to the team

Controls: Mouse. For more advanced/hardcore gamers, you can use keyboard keys.

As a tower defense game, your goal is to prevent the bloons from exiting the map. If it does, your life will be deducted. Once you lose all of your life, the game ends. At this point, you can either replay from scratch or use monkey cash to re-try again.

What makes BTD 6 complicated is the difficulty and what game mode you are playing on. A standard easy vs Deflation easy is 2 totally different game mode while they share the "common" easy rules. Same concept applies to the other difficulty/harder maps.

On the surface it may seem like all the maps and bloons are the same. So, what exactly makes the game "harder"?
The first criteria is the game mode which you are playing. It will set the tone on how hard/what sort of challenge you will be presented. (1 hp game, magicians tower only, reverse path, half cash etc)

The second criteria is the difficulty levels. On a general note, the higher difficulty you play, you will be required to play more levels. easy: 40 levels. medium 60. hard 80. you will encounter much harder bloon types (mix and match from various properties: camo, ceramic, metal, rainbow, regrow, FORTIFIED! etc). The bloon type is what dictates "how hard the game" will be.

In order to beat hard maps, you will definitely need to max out your tower levels and invest into monkey knowledge. Heroes are not prominent until you start to play on hard maps or you have a particular way of playing/sync it with other towers.

The tower themselves are unique and depending on your style of play, you can mix and match certain tower styles. In this sense it gives flexibility to the players - some may opt of the ninja tower but others prefer the sniper.

Bloon TD has come a long way. I wouldn't say BTD 6 has revolutionize tower defense games but it's certainly not your average tower defense. What makes it fun/challenging is the bloons. Knowing your enemy properties and spawn at which level will greatly increase the gameplay experience else its going to be bonkers.

40 over maps playing solo can feel repetitive and boring. On harder maps, where you are required to play 80 levels or more (more time spent) can be a turn off after xxx hours.

Going co-op, you will have to stick with the map layout and without a proper way to communicate, can turn the game into a messy monkey business. Spamming of emoticons that doesnt make sense. I dont voice chat unless i am playing with my friends. in other words, playing online with public you have to bare with the: 1) map layout (free for all or play in a section of the map), 2) communication limitation 3) knowledge of the person..and style of play
can lead to a experience.

ever played in a co-op map where one of the player just build 1 tower in a hard game map?
or leaves immediately once the game starts?
or mass tower hugging at the entrance?

On the other hand, if you are playing with knowledgeable people, you learn and have more fun. I wished there was a way to add them into your friend list. I would love to have more co-op maps that are free to play style than sections though.

So, on the scale of 0 - 10, my personal rating for Bloon TD 6 is a no-monkey business, creative coconut mess that is fun. An easy 8/10.

Posted: October 13, 2022
--- REVIEW ---

I am going to list my resons for and against buying this game and will conclude the review with my personal opinion.

PROS:
+ Easy to learn (even my 60 year old father understands the game's mechanics)
+ Nice graphics and effects
+ Relaxing soundtracks
+ Daily challenges and more events (e.g. Boss battles, contested territory, odysseys)
+ Lots of ways to customize your experience as a player (many unlockables in the trophy shop)
+ MANY playable maps (at LEAST 10)
+ Many ways to play the same maps (not in terms of official gamemodes, but you can limit yourself by using only one type of tower for example)
+ A lot of achievements (they help you in-game by giving you useful stuff like monkey money, insta-towers and more and outside of the game, you can flex with them around your friends)
+ Playable both solo or with up to 3 other players (multiplayer CAN make the game much easier at the beginning, gets chaotic really fast)
+ No P2W (you can, if you want to, but everything can be done without spending a single cent)
+ Runs pretty smoothly as long as you stop playing at a round higher than 100
+ This game gets frequently new content added (most recently a new paragon tower)
+ The game has an active modding community (BEWARE: Mods can get you "banned" when used in multiplayer or on ranked events!)

CONS:
- This game used to be half the price it is currently (RECOMMENDATION: Wait for a sale!)
- Once you reach a high round (100+), the screen will be full of monkeys and more, making finding your cursor is as difficult as finding Waldo (or Wally, depending where you are from)
- The gameplay itself stays the same (what I am trying to say is that once you found a consistent strategy to win, you will probably not try new things out and that makes the game really boring, especially on high rounds when all you can do is stare at the screen and hope that the 1 FPS hell finally comes to an end (usually at round ~150)
- There is no motivation to play further than round 100 (seriously, no achievement, no better insta-monkeys, NOTHING)
- We tried the coop-mode many times on many occasions and we found out that the connection is really unstable (either you or your friends get kicked out and in the end you play solo again)

CONCLUDING WORDS:
I recommend this game, because it is a pretty fun single player game, which can be modded and also played together. I got this game for about 6€, which is half the current normal price, therefore I recommend you to wait for a sale (honestly, always wait for sales). If you are looking for a game with deep lore, that is also made for multiplayer only, then you are wrong here. BTD6 is made for casual players with a hatred against the evil bloons, who also play solo most of the time. New content is being added frequently, which makes the game feel more alive. If you are looking for a game with many achievents, which are also tricky to unlock, then this game is made for you. You also definitely need good strategic knowledge to properly advance in this game.
Feel free to write your questions in the comments and I or someone else from this community will try to answer them as good as possible.

Posted: October 2, 2019
I went into this game with a deep fondness for the fifth installment of the series and actually held off playing this for the longest time. Maybe it was because I just needed to get used to the art style or something, but either way, I got some motivation to sit down and play it once and for all.

The comments below are my thoughts!


* A downright ludicrous amount of upgrades, with three paths per tower that now go into the fifth tier
* Extremely tight balance that's only getting better via patch updates
* The art style really grew on me as I played it, it looks fluid in motion and very pretty
* While some songs are certainly taken from 5, the new tracks are beautifully composed
* Between unlocking all of the upgrades, monkey knowledge, and heroes, alongside the vast amount of tracks to play, rest assured you're getting bang for your buck
* Between the purple bloons, DDTs, and BADs, there are more bloons to assassinate than ever before!


* Microtransactions are here, but far from mandatory to get the most out of BTD6. I actually purchased Double Cash mode alongside a decently large number of Monkey Knowledge points, though half of the reason was to support the developers.
* While there have been many improvements and new additions to the game, some cool features from 5 are missing, such as the specialty buildings and a select few towers


* There's still quite a few visual bugs to be ironed out, such as upgrades on your monkeys showing the incorrect description (but rather the description for the next upgrade) and a pretty bad bug with the tutorial that leaves you stuck in it forever with no way out (other than to just leave).
* I hate to be that guy, but Bloonchippers and Dartlings were pretty sad removals


I was utterly blown away by how good this game is right now. The balance, look, feel, all of it is incredibly addicting and charming to play. And while it could certainly use some additions and fix some kinks, BTD6 is here to stay and I'm very glad it turned out the way it did. Even I, a hardcore BTD5 enthusiast, cannot see myself going back to that game anymore now that 6 is here and offers so much more. Support the developers, guys!

Posted: June 2, 2019
Most of the negative reviews are from people who didn't bother giving the game a chance.

The microtransactions barely do anything and are pretty irrelevant, you don't need them. All they do is level you up in the game which is something that is pretty easy to do and you don't earn much for levelling up; just some bonuses for your towers which are disabled on the higher difficulties anyway.

The game itself is very fun and in my opinion the best Bloons game so far. Every tower has three upgrade paths and 5th tier upgrades. There are lots of maps at various difficulty levels as well as lots of different challenge modes. I played the game on my phone since launch and only recently got the steam version and this version runs a lot better than the phone version. I was having trouble on the phone because on high rounds the game will lag and sometimes crash but on here this doesn't happen. You can also transfer over your data between the different versions and it also transfers over to your steam achievements as well.

I only have one real problem with the game which is that if you put too many towers the game will crash and this is nothing to do with your pc, it's to do with the game engine itself.

This is a minor issue since i had to get every single max upgrade tower in the game down plus many other random towers in order for it to crash like this but at the same time it's a little disappointing if you're trying to see what the max round you can reach is. In the normal modes you probably won't encounter this issue because you won't be able to get enough money, you'll only encounter it in freeplay.

Despite some old towers not being in the game yet, the game is being updated relatively frequently and one has already been added back in the past so hopefully the others (especially engineer) will be added soon.

9/10

Posted: January 5, 2020
Bloons TD 6 is a highly addictive, top-down, 3D, tower defense game.
A game that might look like a flash or mobile port at first glance, but has way more depth and strategy than expected.

Each fight starts of in a map with a path running through it, your goal is to position monkeys to ensure that none of the enemy balloons make to the end of that path.
There are several different monkeys, all with their own special ability and upgrade trees.
As you make progress the enemy balloons get harder to pop and some balloons later in the waves can only be killed by monkeys that have the right upgrades.

There are special monkeys in the game too which are called Heroes, those can be bought with monkey money which is a in game currency.
This currency can be bought with real money but also earned by completing missions.
Heroes are special monkeys that you can bring into play, but unlike the standard monkeys, you are limited to only one of them in the fight at a time.
These special and strong heroes automatically upgrade each round until level 20, with each level unlocking a new buff or skill.

At level 30 you unlock Monkey Knowledge, which is another skill tree to make your monkey troopes even stronger.
Together with the tons of maps which vary in difficulty, challenges, events, achievements and CO-OP mode there is enough to do to keep you busy for many hours.

The graphics look fantastic, sharp, fun and colorful.
A really nice feature is that with each upgrade, that you buy for the monkeys they slightly change in appearance to make it easy to distinguish them.
The game is capable to suck me in and keep my attention by making it feel rewarding completing each wave and achieve a perfect highscore.

It's super addictive and it's by far my best 0,79€ spend.

Leading up to Hitler’s rise to power, a Russian biologist named Ilya Ivanov garnered a great deal of infamy by perpetrating crimes against nature. At the behest of Joseph Stalin, Ivanov attempted to impregnate human women with chimpanzee sperm and female chimpanzees with human sperm. Stalin believed that human/ape hybrids would make the perfect soldiers, and could be used in combat operations. These hybrids would lack the mental capacity to challenge Stalin’s orders, but maintain the ferocity and strength to carry out these orders in ways that no regular men could.

Like it or not, the series is as close as we can get to Stalin’s dream, albeit a kid-friendly version.

Posted: August 10, 2022
Update, 11/26/2023: Everything still rings true. The dedication of this development team is the stuff legends are forged with. Mostly forged into metallic objects that pop balloons.

Full disclosure: I started with Bloons TD1 that used to run on what is now an archaeological find known as Adobe Flash!

Before continuing: There is a cash shop in this game. It is not very intrusive and is only there when accessing the daily challenges or if you go looking for it. I have never once needed to purchase anything from this cash shop in my 440 hours of playing Bloons TD6. It is strictly for and that's it. Everything can be earned simply by playing the game and ! With that out of the way...

If you were to dismiss Bloons TD6 as a – I would not blame you. It is the finest in cartoon silliness. The game is filled with a multitude of monkeys using high powered, dart throwing weaponry to pop, deflate, or otherwise protect their home from balloons, or as these apes call them. From lasers to icicle spike throwers to literal catapults – This game has it all and more in weaponry.

Once you break through all this silliness in the presentation, you will realize that higher level play Efficient methods to properly manage money generation, minimal tower placement, reselling already placed towers to quickly change builds, counters for specific waves, or countering bosses – Just to name a few. It quickly goes from an fun distraction to a bit of a nerve wracking display of skill and planning.

Couple this together with an absolute love from the developers to keep adding in more content – New maps, new heroes, new towers, new bosses, new game modes, new aesthetics to unlock, etc. – It will be multiple hundreds of hours before you run out of stuff to work towards – I should know, I'm still at 440 hours and climbing. Yes, some of it can be more of the same – But there is just enough variety and difference in maps that it has a lot to offer in terms of new ways to challenge yourself.

Another advantage - For those who are looking for an approachable and fairly easy game for their young kids to play - This game definitely fits the bill. Easy enough to simply be fun on the lower difficulty modes and still offers rewards for your kiddos to unlock, they'll be finding new ways to throw darts at Bloons. Harder difficulties reward the kids with new monkeys they normally cannot afford to see on the lower difficulties, which in turn might make them challenge themselves. The game is rather brilliant in design for something that is just monkeys flinging sharp metal objects and air filled rubber balls.

There is online co-op, but from my limited experience most interactions are through predefined emotes to cut down on language barriers and introducing your 5 year old to George Carlin. This will not stop that one player from just sitting there and placing only farms and not sharing their money with you to just be a troll, but that is just open internet co-op these days. You could, in theory, be that awesome parent that just plays with their kids though. Be awesome Mom or Dad! There is only one form of competitive play that has recently released and it is fully PvE competitions for high scores rather than PvP competitions against other players.

With all of this, the beauty of Bloons TD6 is the fact that it can both be a fun distraction for when you just need some chill Bloon popping fun in your life or an extremely technical display of your gaming knowledge. Often times on sale for less than $10 USD. Pick it up if you like tower defense games and need something to fill that void for both fun and challenging.
